review_body: Maybe the best club I have ever visited. You can order from a menu even in the longue.Comfortable beds and rooms are alright sized. It is very difficult to find big rooms in Tokyo, so for that, this is a good size. Gym and pools are very good.Short walk from the subway station.Absolutely recommended.

There’s literally nothing you could complain about with this hotel. Top class hotel. Definitely up to the intercontinental standards. Superb location for business and pleasure. Breakfast is at the intercontinental level, and there is nothing wrong with it. The food is fresh and plentiful, which is good. What’s not to like about it

the location is very good, near the subway station. Staff were all extremely accommodating, amicable and make it simple for the check in and check out process. Meals were good - generally great. We like the manners in which staff are so responsive and learned in their service to us.

The hotel is perfect . Helpful staff , service is fast and check in is seamless . It’s one if my favorite hotels traveling. The Restaurant in the lower lobby is fantastic breakfast, lunch or dinner you will not leave hungry or unhappy . Plenty of places to walk to and is centrally located . You will not be disappointed .

The ANA InterContinental in the Akasaka [bordering Roppongi] area is in a terrific, central location, very close to the US Embassy. Its location makes this a good choice for those on business. It has its own subway entrance -- Tameike -- on the Ginza-sen subway line, for fast access to all subways.The hotel is located in the Ark Hills complex of Akasaka/Roppongi, and that includes the beautiful Suntory Hall concert hall; and restaurants on two floors in the neighboring Ark Mori building. The level of service at the hotel is five-star elegant. This is professional hotel management at its highest level. As a result, the hotel is also a popular choice for Japanese weddings: it's a remarkable insight into the culture to watch a young couple in full western wedding attire descend the lighted stairway to the main lobby, to be greeted by family and friends tossing lotus flowers in their path! Dining (and drinking) in the hotel are VERY pricey....drinks in the cocktail bar on the 38th floor (which provides a view of Mt Fuji far in the distance on clear days) averaged over 2,500 [over $20 bucks USD] a pop. The buffet breakfast price was over 3,500 yen a person [over $30 bucks]. But not to worry: there are marvelous French pastry shops nearby -- one in the hotel's lobby or on the plaza of Suntory Hall.We loved the service, the cleanliness and the convenience of this hotel, which maintains super-high standards. A memorable and absolutely enjoyable stay in Tokyo!

Stayed on the 35th floor with access to the lounge. The room was great - quiet, comfortable bed, etc. We requested extra pillows and they were delivered within a few minutes. The star of the show was the staff in the lounge. The quality of service was top shelf and the food was delicious. Highly recommended.

My husband and I stayed here two nights and really enjoyed our stay. The hotel is very beautiful, the rooms are a bit small but good for two people. The concierge staff Kan and Ai really made our trip with their helpful tips and restaurant recommendations. They really went above and beyond!

Our last stop on a long, exhausting trip around Japan. Lovely from the moment we were greeted in the lobby. Beautiful view of the Tokyo Tower! Concierge agreed with our choice for early sushi for dinner so we could return to the 36th floor for sunset. We arrived at the Mixx Bar and had amazing drinks and conversation with Koichi Koyama, who was very attentive and an excellent mixologist!

The rooms are basic at best, and out dated but clean. Poor view considering they are not full. Zero seating in front lobby except 4 seat behind escalators.( lobby bar area is usually closed off for some reason. Room service and buffet offer room temperature food. Poor service in lobby bar, I had to flag down server twice. We booked here because of Intercontinental’s reputation but this location is just not it at the moment.

It’s so active and full of costumers. at first reception wise needs to do better when they tell you your room will be ready beyond the check in time although they provide you with a temporary and you reserve a suites, so the start was frustrating and I only booked for 2 nights.Good as it’s maintaining the IHG standard, and the underground station is just next to it.But the area is slightly far from the major shopping areas.They need to do better for there furniture and TV channels.

Great hotel in the heart of Minato and walking distance to the lovely Hie-Jinja temple which you should visit whilst staying here. Prompt service, friendly staff, quiet rooms and an array of restaurants to choose from.

We stayed here recently. The rooms are average at best-and the bathrooms very disappointing. The service is solid-but the check in area has unbelievable long lines. The concierge service is excellent and the buffet, if included, is well worth it. Upgrades needed on the bathrooms!

Stayed here for two nights as was traveling for business to japan. to my shock i was told there will be a power outage on one of my stays which actually had my whole plan disturbed as i was forced to return around 12 am as i wouldn't be able to go up to my room until 4 in the morning and the reception staff was so casual about it. they should have informed us before we booked not on site.

The service of the front line staff leaves much to be desired. 1) When we arrived at 2am, there was nobody to help us with the luggages. The bell staff was just standing behind the counter and looking at us. We noticed over our stay that it seemed to be the standard procedure for all guests regardless of time. This is unacceptable for a 5 star hotel. It should be standard service for the bell service staff to go out and help guests with their luggages. 2) When we asked the counter staff if she could help to store something in the freezer, her reply was that we should ask their in-house restaurant ourselves. Most 5-star hotels would have made the arrangements for their guests rather than tell the guest to go figure it out themselves.The staff basically do not extend help and we felt our stay was not very welcoming.

Overall very good stay with prompt services, fast track check in/out for IHG Ambassadors, efficient and kind service. Well done to the entire team who worked so hard during the busiest period of the year!

Due to the typhoon in Tokyo and I came here due to the hotel availability . The hotel is a bit old but the services are good.It is near to the Roppongi area and convenient store is just next to the hotel. Get the room that having Tokyo tower view which is really awesome for me during the typhoon day.
user_name:
karlwang
Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

review_body: If you run into any issues the staff will ignore you. The hotels infrastructure is falling apart, our room smelled mainly in the bathroom it smelled like sewage pipe burst. We had another issue with the airport shuttle and was spoken to in a very condescending manner “why are you here” I said we’re here for the shuttle. In their very rude tone said you need to go to the basement, was not told about the basement location. Julian Cole yelled at us saying he is not responsible to give us every bit of information about the hotel. This went on for 15 minutes loudly arguing, Julian insulted us and used discriminatory language many times in the conversation, he didn’t even look at us while he spoke it was so rude and disgusting behavior. This is completely absurd if you provide a service that customers pay for you need to provide the full information. I escalated this issue to Sumumu the duty manager he said would give us a refund for our entire stay, I checked my email he lied and credit only one night. As I called back and said there’s a mistake you said you would refund the entire stay, he kept saying it was not possible even though he already promised we would refund the entire stay. Again, an argument with the Duty Manager he was unresponsive and kept dismissing the issue. This was then escalated Makoto Mori, again another argument they kept saying it was not possible, which ended him hanging up on me. I plan on escalating the issue to the CEO of IHG Keith Barr.

First of all, I am a Spire Elite member of IHG and a Titanium Elite member of another major hotel chain. I just arrived Tokyo having stayed at a hotel at the competing hotel chain in Osaka right before my arrival in Tokyo. It is a difficult review to write, to be honest. There are so many things that the hotel does well, and not, it would be unfair to describe the hotel using one single score.Let’s start with what the hotel does not do well.1. I called the hotel before I made my reservation to find out if my reservation, using points, would include breakfast. The answer I got was “yes”. Then when I arrived, I was told, “you are not getting breakfast since you are using points to pay for your room”. Maybe it has to do with IHG, elite members of the competing chain always get free breakfast. Anyway, the answer I got was astounding. The front desk person saw my disappointment and gave me complimentary breakfast anyway, but this was not what I expected after having called the hotel before my arrival;2. I asked if I could get a complimentary rollaway bed for my 4 year old before my arrival. I could have gotten no as an answer but again I was told yes. Then, nothing happened;3. I booked the room for 3 people, but I was given 2 sets of towels, tooth brushes, slippers... what happens to attention to details that is what Japanese people are well known for?4. This is my second stay at the hotel. The first time was in late 2010. They had minor remodeling since my last visit, but things remain dated from a cosmetic perspective. The hotel still looks like it belongs to the mid-80’s;5. Bedroom has no USB port... none! it says so much about what kind of customers it targets;6. It is a big hotel, and staff is always busy. However, for a brand like InterContinental, staff should not let customers be aware that they are being rushed. It is clear that the staff is busy all the time, and sometimes, maybe because of lack of time, I was brushed off. It wasn't one time when I was brushed off. If I didn't know better, I could have interpreted it as arrogance.Now let’s talk about things that it does well.1. Location - right next to Taimeke-sanno station;2. If you look at their bathroom, it tells so much about how they keep up with their maintenance. Although the bathroom looks like one that came from the 80’s, everything looks new (meaning very little wear and tear);3. “Some” of the hotel staff was great.It is my first time visiting an InterContinental as a Spire Elite member, and I feel quite strongly that the IHG loyalty program is not as strong as the other loyalty program I am also a part of. From the benefits that I am getting to the way I am treated at the hotel properties, I feel that IHG is not so much into keeping their customers staying within the chain. The hotel can do much better with the way they handle customer requests. When yes means no, it can only lead to customer dissatisfaction.This should really be a 3.5 star review.

3 stars instead of 2 as they were able (after a lot of pressure from me) to give us an early check-in around 9am after a long haul flight.But the room was ancient and tired, with scuff marks on the furniture. The bathroom even older - probably from the 1970's...The location was good for exploring Tokyo, an easy taxi ride from Haneda and the limo bus to Narita made it simple.We didn't eat in the hotel.Bed was OK but linen average quality and the room was quite warm with no way to cool it. Not a hotel we'd rush back to.

Desperate is the word. The rooms are so tired and run down that you never relax in your room. I stayed on a business trip with about 10 other people. I was shocked to discover on the 3rd day that some people had even worse rooms than mine. My room was old and stale, but it was at least spacious. Other colleagues on the trip said they barely had enough space to maneuver around the bed. I find that most hotels in Japan have great bathrooms. The bathroom at ANA Intercontinental must be 15-20 years old, and has a strange glass window with blinds separating it from the bedroom. I returned to my room once in the middle of the day to find the housekeeper cleaning. She was working so hard, and I could tell she took a lot of pride in her work. I was kind of shocked, because the room felt rather dirty. I realized it wasn't because the housekeeping staff are neglecting their duties, it's because the rooms have gone far too long without any investment. Similarly, I felt bad for the front desk team. They seem to spend all day dealing with complaints. The front desk was constantly mobbed with guests begging to move to a different room. I understand there are a handful of renovated rooms that are less grim.The hotel has a wide range of food and beverage options, and the food and drinks that I had were good. We had dinner once in the lobby restaurant and I had room service. Service was attentive.
user_name:
BvonBlix
New York City, New York

review_body: Have been there a few times. Rooms are good, very clean and lots of hot water in the shower (wife think they could upgrade the bathroom).Good atmosphere in the lobby, "intercontinental style", and breakfast is amazing.Good location next to the Ginza line, walking distance from roppongi.Good option for.both business or staying with the family.

Round the corner from the US Embassy with many foreign guests.Some of the staff welcomed me back and even asked if I wanted the same table as the previous visit. One chef went out of us way to cater for my client's requests.Very good service, location is a few mins walk from shops, restaurants and the subway

Great hotel, great location. Great people if something goes wrong . They are customer centric and if for any reason something goes wrong ( which may happen ) , they will do everything to make you stay a success .

Stayed for 4 nights. Big hotel with luxurious lobby. No bellboys on check in so carried suitcase my self. Room was smaller than expected but with a comfortable bed good aircon/heating and good soundproofing. Breakfast is amazing and by far the best I've had in Japan. Loads of restaurants and cafes on site but prices are extortionate. Hotel is next to the tube station of Ginza line and also great that you can use the Airport Friendly Limusine bus from/ to Haneda and Narita airports .

Room was a bit dated / small for what we were expecting in an Intercontinental but maybe we got the “worst” they had because we booked with mostly points. Lobby was quite gorgeous. Regardless, it was clean and we slept well, which are two most important qualities in a hotel. Toiletries provided. All of the restaurants in hotel were pretty pricey. Close to the subway. One review mentions they have an airport shuttle, but we were told they didn’t. Again, maybe only for certain levels of guests. We took the subway back to Tokyo station and used Narita express to get back to airport.

With its clean rooms , rich breakfast buffet , very convenient location for easy access to Narita International Airport as well as Ginza Subway Line , and beyond all with its excellent staff dedicated themselves to make the visitor happy , comfortable and relaxed , I have really felt at home . Great thanks and appreciations !!

The hotel was booked through corporate system. Check-in was fine. But room was small, dark, old. They wanted to give me 2 single beds while I booked a king size bed. After complaining for a while, they finally got me a room with king size. All my colleagues got 2 small single beds and were very unsatisfied. Breakfast was good, and buffet diner as well. Globally very below the standard and surprising in a hotel that hosts restaurants such as a Pierre Gagnaire. Bad value for money.

We stayed 8 nights at the Ana Intercontinental Tokyo in the Kaze and Tsuki Suites. The rooms were large, modern and very comfortable. They even provided a crib for our one year old. The best part of our stay was the service. This hotel has the best club lounge and the service by all the staff in the lounge was absolutely exceptional. A very special thank you to Kai Harada, the concierge who took care of us and helped plan our daily activities. Also to Yasuo and Michiko (my apologies for wrong spelling) thank you for taking such good care of my family every morning. We sincerely appreciate it. You made our first stay with our son a memorable one.

Have stayed several times. Arrived early in the morning only to find that the room had been given away as no late arrival notice was given to hotel. The hotel manager arranged a temp room. The renovated rooms are in good condition the others have a worn down look. Beds are comfortable.Bus limousines serves the hotel from Haneda Airport, a 45 minute ride. Taxis are easily available. The restaurant serves a sumptuous breakfast, staff are courteous and sufficiently attentive. The buffet dinner is over rated. The hotel is conveniently located.

If you would like to spend time around Akasaka, Ginza or Roppongi , I think this hotel should be convenience for you (Tokyo subway: orange or Grey line). there are shuttle bus service between hotel & airport. Breakfast is variety with American , Japanese & Chinese with good service . I think if you can get upgrade or stay in high floor should be better than standard room.

ANA intercontinental Tokyo is a classic grand five stars hotel , 844 rooms 12 restaurant and bar , location is good enough to travel everywhere and really close with Subway (walk within 3mins) . There had a 24hours gym room and concierge , front desk . In here I would like to mention a staff from front desk , Ms. Manukau Kobayashi , she did everything with a lovely smile and welcoming on her face . And I would like to thank you Mr. Mori to arrange us a nice room for cerebral our anniversary , is my pleasure to stay in your hotel. Absolutely I will come back again and i hope to meet you next time , Don’t work too hard ^_^Nothing more important than your attitude and service in five stars hotel.

Spent a couple of nights here in Tokyo. The Hotel is beautiful, clean and in a great location. Star Bucks and other eating options a very short walk away. It was clean, comfortable and overall a great experience.

Second stay here, and am undecided if I will return or try the Hyatt next trip Pros: Good and convenient location, nice rooms if you get the upgradeCons: Substandard service at breakfast, not great coffee, extremely expensive, very busy, lacking personality I keep wanting to like this hotel more, especially for the price. Its big and very busy (had to wait a long time and no IHG ambassador check in line/assistance on check in or out). Front counter staff are nice, concierge is helpful, hostess at breakfast is cheerful. The service at breakfast is awful. Servers are unfriendly, takes 15 minutes to get a cup/carafe of tea or coffee, and they act extremely bothered (albeit in a relatively polite Japanese way) if you ask. There is not a smile or a moment to be had. It feels very assembly line, rushed, and really ruins the experience..especially considering the previously mentioned cost. Comparing this breakfast experience to IHG properties in Seoul, Vietnam (Hanoi/HCMC), Taiwan, and all over Europe, it is my least favourite.

If you have a heavy suitcase, please use the airport express bus, not subway. The nearest subway (Ginza Line) is quite a walk away and does not have a lift leading to this hotel. Other than this, the hotel is well-located and has lots of eateries around. U can even walk to Roppongi. The rooms are well-appointed and well-equipped (expected of a 5-Star hotel). We stayed here for 4 nights. But what I cannot fathom is the tobacco smelling corridors and room. In the end, all my clothes ended smelling of tobacco! The nice view from our room doesn’t compensate ....

Greetings are welcoming and reception is efficient. Bell boys are great. Room is very old and dated. However, its clean. Typical lower end hotel. Would rate it a high 3 star to 4. Definitely not five star. Good business location and lobby is crowded.

Stayed here in nov for business trip, checked into a premier room, room is quite big for Tokyo standard . besides the rain shower head , there is 3 water jets shooting water simultaneously, pretty awesome experience.Breakfast spread offer Japanese and western food. Good variety .

We stayed at the ANA Intercontinental Hotel for two nights during the Rugby World Cup, and we were delighted we did! Everything about this hotel is fabulous; the staff, the bedrooms and bathrooms, the food, the club lounge...the list goes on...We stayed in several other Intercontinental Hotels during our stay in Japan, this was the best! They should be proud.

This hotel is steps away from the subway. We saw many sites by taking the subway which was fast and easy to figure out. Our hotel room on the 17th floor faced the Tokyo Tower which is beautiful when lit up at night. The hotel staff is very respectful and responsive. Our room was very comfortable, especially the beds and pillows. One night we ate the buffet dinner. Although it was a bit pricey ($73.00 US apiece) there was a good variety of food to choose from and the desserts were to die for! I used the treadmill in the gym and the staff was very helpful. My only complaint is that the lobby needs more seating. Most of it is taken up with restaurant seating.

Having stayed in 4 Intercontinental Hotels in Tokyo area this was head and shoulders above the others. It is in a very busy area of the city but once inside it is a haven of peace and quiet.Modern good sized bedroom with great bathrooms. Fantastic staff across all the departments that we interfaced with were first class. Club room fantastic and a real oasis whether its for breakfast, afternoon tea, snacks or evening meals. Great restaurant options within the hotel.Will very happily visit again

We had a really great stay here for 4 nights and the level of the hotel was wonderful and exceeded our expectations. We stayed in their Premier Room category and it was perfect. Great bathroom feature with the glass (will save the surprise for the next guests)! The restaurants were also great experiences - Steakhouse, their Japanese Restaurant Unkai, as well as their Hero Bar (where they live streamed the rugby matches by the outdoor pool) were all great. The only let down for us was the Sauna room, where we hoped to enjoy after the long flight over which seemed to have been closed for the duration of our stay. The sauna also only seemed to be located in the Men's Locker Room - which was odd as I am sure many women would also like to enjoy this facility (including myself). Overall, a great hotel and very well located!

We stayed here as part of a mastercard prize experience & we were really impressed with the service from the doorman who took our bags to the lady checking us in, to the housekeeping for our room care & even the gentleman who came to fix the bathroom sink that wasn’t draining. Everything about this hotel is I would say is 5 star & the breakfasts were excellent too. The rooms are spacious with great pillows on the bed & housekeeping even asked what time we would like our room serviced. We would highly recommend this hotel to everyone who likes a little luxury in their lives.

Stayed here for a week during the Rugby World Cup and I was so impressed by this hotel. The facilities, staff and location were outstanding and the Buffet Breakfast was one of the best I have had. There are a variety of shops and resturants in this Hotel but the only negative is that they are WAY over priced and to be honest I wouldn't eat there unless it was part of your deal as there are so many more resonably priced options just out the door.I would definately stay here again as I just loved the atmosphere and the Hotel had everything you could possibly want.

This was my first business trip to Tokyo and I was very pleased with my two week stay at the ANA Intercontinental in Akasaka; and, I already have plans to stay again on my next trip in the coming month. The accommodations are comfortable and clean (if not entirely new/updated), the staff very welcoming with the overall level of service exceptional, and the food (in particular the breakfast buffet) outstanding. I found the location well situated for my needs, with taxis readily accessible out front, subway entrance within a block, and some good restaurants within reasonable walking distance - although I wouldn't describe the local area in general as a place to just wander about. Key negatives to note would be that hallways were quite warm and there is limited ability to cool down the room (note, my preferred sleep temp is about 3 to 4 degree-F lower than the wall control allowed to be set), and TV options are lacking in English (so I mainly streamed news etal via my phone/iPad). I enjoyed dinners in four of the hotel restaurants, but the 36th floor lounge/bar was pricey and a bit of a disappointment after the hype of the views -- and as a non-smoker I found the smoke poorly contained and very noticeable on the non-smoking side. In stark contrast, the Parisian style patisserie on the lobby level offered a significantly better aroma of well priced indulgences. Overall the ANA Intercontinental gets my strong recommendation, even though you won't find me hanging around at the Mixx Bar Lounge.

This is the Worst hotel I have ever stay. Facilities and rooms is old but that's fine. The biggest problem is the staff quality. The lady who did my check in didn't smile n greet ,asked and swiped my credit card without telling me how much deposit would be taken. I asked her how much has been taken, only then she replied me just to check the validity of my credit card. From a 5 star hotel, I would have expected her to consent my acknowledgement before performing such act.i asked the concierge staff for the map of metro, the he gave me the map and pointed out where am I , again, no smile and didn't proactively provide route guidance. That is not the service I expect from a 5 star hotel. Even the service from 3 star hotel is much better than this so called 'five star hotel', However, I would like to express gratitude to the staff Ai from front desk, she is the only staff who smile at me in my entire stay. Do yourself a favour, stay away from this hotel. I've stayed in lots of IHG properties and so far this has been the worst ever. I should have listened to my friend's advice to stay at IC Tokyo Bay or IC The Strings by Shinagawa station; where the hardware and software are way better than this aging property.

Stayed here for RWC 2019 and can only recommend this hotel as the staff are extremely friendly and very professional. Breakfast is comprehensive and can’t be faulted. Two minutes away from metro station and there is a shuttle to the airport.

I have stayed in this hotel on many many occasions and I am always happy with the choice. This time I stayed for a few days during the rugby world cup so the city and the hotel were busy.The hotel service was as usual very good. The location of the hotel is great if you want to walk and be near the entertainment areas although you need a taxi to get to Marounouchi or Ginza. The rooms are clean although not large. The TV options are minimal. Food options are great. And the lobby is a hive of activity. Great bar on 36th floor with great views. Service throughout if very good and very human. Recommended.

Stayed here for two nights earlier this month whilst visiting to watch England play Argentina in the rugby World Cup. What an amazing hotel. The staff were very attractive and so polite. The room was very good great view of the Tokyo Tower, bed was very comfortable as well. Gym had all you needed for a short stay. I ate at the steakhouse and the meal was excellent. Had drinks in the da vinci and mixx bar. The latter being on the 34th floor giving great views. Had breakfast both days great buffet affair. One final thing the service at this hotel is amazing and in fact it is what I found everywhere I went in Tokyo.

I stayed here for 4 nights in October. From my arrival at 4pm the front desk was very friendly and explained everything. I am a IHG member and booked the standard room but was upgraded to the Executive room. ROOM TYPE: Very spacious King bed with Couch and Desk. Mini fridge, Tea and 2 bottles of water included daily. Pajamas are in the drawers but no robes. Decent closet space. Bathroom has a window looking into the bedroom, single sink, standard American size tub with shower. Well equipped toiletries, and bathroom, but small in overall size. Beds are very comfortable, room service is available 24-hrs and maid service is wonderful, Towels are thick and plentiful. HOTEL AMENITIES: There are several restaurant options. I only ate at the Tea Service buffet for lunch. It was a good selection of “American” and Japanese fare, some pasta, pizza, salad and cold cuts. Dessert buffet offers several types of chocolate fountains with fruits and cakes to dip, variety of Macaroons. All high quality selection. This was 46.00Yen pp/I also had a drink at the Bar on the 37th floor. Beautiful views of Tokyo, Great service AND their cocktails are a real work of artYou can change your currency right in the Lobby at a Thomas Cook machine, there is also an ATM. A French Patisserie is in the lobby and offers wonderful variety of baked goods, ice cream, coffee and juices. If you are looking to purchase an Airport Limousine Bus ticket back to the airport, you can do this at the Bell Desk and then pay for it at the front Desk at check out.I was able to view Club Intercontinental which is located on the 37th floor. Service a breakfast, light snacks and drinks as well as office space and plenty of areas to work if needed, floors 34-37 will give you access to this floor, if you book a Club floor room,Over all, Great rooms regardless of level, amenities and service was all top notch

My wife and I stayed at the ANA for four nights as part of our honeymoon. The hotel is really well located and the staff are great. The only reason I’ve given 4 instead of 5 stars is the hotel rooms are a little outdated, especially the bathrooms and the swimming pool was closed for our stay due to the Rugby World Cup Bar. The bar was great for watching the RWC games but it would have been nice to know about the swimming pool closure in advance of our stay. The hotel is also below the standard of the Hong Kong Intercontinental which we had stayed at just before this visit. The only other minor complaint would be the Mexx bar at the top of the hotel. Whilst an amazing venue, unfortunately even the non smoking seating area stinks of cigarette smoke. In summary, we would definitely stay here again and the staff in particular were attentive and great. Grethel Goto, the reception manager deserves a special mention because she was engaging, personable, professional and attentive throughout our stay...

Arrived on 11.30 am at the hotel , Ms. Dummai greet us with warm welcome. She’s very kind and helpfull. Surprisingly , she gave us room upgrade and free chocolate for our honeymoon gift. Thanks also to Midori Saito to help us arrange the honeymoon in this hotel.

Very disappointed by this hotel. The check-in experience was sub-par and not accommodating. The room and bathroom are old and not well maintained. This is well below what I've experienced in similarly priced hotels in the area. Very disappointed.
user_name:
Beziers345001
New York City, New York

review_body: Very upmarket Beautiful place! We just spent a day there shooting a add in one of the rooms. It is like having a honeymoon all over. The view we had from that room makes you feel you do not want to leave the room just order in! The room was not big but had everything you needed.
user_name:
griffin165
Cape Town Central, South Africa

review_body: This was our end of holidays in Japan and we decided to splurge on a suite (2 adults + 2 kids) for the last couple of days before we flew home. Was it worth it? Financially probably not, but kids and us had such a good time. 35th floor Lounge access was included in our booking, which offers fantastic breakfast options away from the overcrowded restaurant downstairs. Between 5.30 to 7.30pm drinks are served for free, so champagne was flowing for us and food options were very good. Plenty to eat for kids too, and despite a note saying that kids younger than 12 cannot be there at that time, we had no problem (if you have a little screaming brat though, they might kick you out, it's nice and quiet there and people want to enjoy their drink and food). The evening few from the top is very good as well, no need to go to Sky Tree. Room was spacious and clean, staff friendly and accommodating. One note of caution though, swimming pool. Somehow we missed the info that it is seasonal, and we checked in a few days after the equinox. Autumn already, so the pool was closed, despite 30C outside, sunny and humid (rules are rules, right? it's Japan after all). It was supposed to be an attraction for the kids, but did not work out.

On our 3rd trip to Tokyo, we wanted to take advantage of an area we weren't familiar with. There are ample restaurants near the hotel, but it's not super exciting within 10 minutes walking of the area. The metro station is really close, but prepare to walk a lot to get on the train. From there, you can go anywhere. 600 yen for a day pass got us around as a family. The hotel was really nice, but nothing particularly WOW. We did not eat at the restaurants since it is more interesting for us out of the hotel. The hotel was very spacious for Tokyo standards. Our family of 5 had 2 rooms and it was comfortable.

True class, real people to serve you at every level. Rooms are a good size with all amenities including a housekeeping service that does a great job everyday not every third or fourth. Great selection of eateries. All you would expect from an Intercontinental.

Bus frequency is 30 minutes and that is the best feature of the hotel. Otherwise the hotel now is quite old and rooms look dated. Location is fine, restaurant are good. Breakfast spread is nice. Felt it is too expensive and not good value.

I’ve stayed at this hotel several times I’ve the last few years and it is a really nice place with excellent, we’ll trained staff. The rooms are nice (not opulent by any means, but extremely comfortable.). There are 2 good bars and several restaurants including an outstanding sushi place. The only complaint I’d have is that their pool was closed for annual maintenance and this was not mentioned 6 weeks when I booked. (And I love to swim when travelling.). But overall the hotel is thoroughly recommended and I’d go back for sure.

Really enjoyed staying at this hotel it is very clean staff is very friendly.The room my husband and I had on the 21st floor was a nice size. The king size bed was very comfortable.I would highly recommend staying at this hotel but don't dine here the food is way too pricey and not that great. Go for a short walk about and you'll find plenty of places to eat with better prices and better food.

I had the pleasure of staying at the ANA Intercontinental during November 2018 for business. The location of the hotel was terrific, with a very short walk to the subway, as well as many other places. We had breakfast at the hotel, and we enjoyed the continental as well as Japanese offerings (pretty sure my husband had the mackerel and rice every single day with tears of joy). The Ark Hills complex right next door also had some terrific places to eat, and so did Roppongi, also very close by. Our hotel room was well kept and good amenities, and the service was excellent. We enjoyed the cute chocolate pop-up shop as well as the drinks/seating in the lobby area after a long day, and overall had an excellent stay here. Would highly recommend it!

Inter Continental.There have been many things to say about this hotel. The great part was that the concerie was very good, they gave great directions and guidiance during our stay. We only have two disapointments for the hotel. 13% Service ChargeI was told well before going to Japan that it is a dishonor to tip people in Japan that it is a Taboo. Tipping in Japan without a good reason, or doing it the wrong way, could come across as crass or rude and there are only a few times when a tip might be appropriate. Although tipping is sometimes acceptable in upscale Western hotels, most of the hotel staff that you encounter are trained to politely refuse tips and tokens of gratuity. But this hotel’s restaurants they take it to a new level. At this hotel there was a 13% Service charge added to the bill and a 8% Sales Tax. When you are paying higher prices as it is I do not want to see a MANDATORY Service Charge, 3450 YEN (US$34.50) for the buffet $10 for an orange juice then they add 13% for not doing anything.  The Swimming PoolWhen you visit a hotel you expect to pay more for Spa services but not to use the outdoor unheated swimming pool . This Hotel attacks you. At 4000 YEN per day per person (US $40) it would have cost us $640 in pool fees for our 8 day stay at the hotel. Room rates do not drop below $200 ever. But then ask $80 per couple per day to take a 20 min dip in the pool! When we visited the pool we were not impressed at all. The entire place is set up to promote drinking Mumm Champagne and swimming. I do not think drinking and swimming mix well (drownings happen fast when drunk). Most of the swimmers were kids under the age of 14. They are targeting minors to drink. BAD MARKETING. While there we saw 4 lifeguards, if you can call them that , standing around check out the tan each other had and seeing who had a better tan line. They were chatting with a couple of girls with their backs to the pool. These four were NOT doing their job. In 5 seconds a kid could be drowning and they would NOT have any idea that it happened. It would be better off that they were not there and a sign read “NO LIFEGUARD ON DUTY” because that is what was going on, at least they would know they were the primary watcher. What was these peoples 4000 YEN going for?The Front desk is way understaffed. Only one person was on the desk and one person telling you to wait in line? Why? Get more people behind the desk. There are how many rooms in this place? Holiday Inn Express Provides a daily newspaper but this hotel did not once in the 10 days we were there.

Throughout our stay the staff could not have done anything more to help. Whatever you need the hotel will make sure they help. From check in to check out they were excellent. Upon check-in we were offered champagne in the champagne bar which was most welcomed following the flight from London. The location is very good with the Tokyo metro directly next to the hotel and there are always taxis outside the hotel. Breakfast was delicious and there is a great range of options for guests. The staff are most friendly, we were very grateful to the concierge team for all their help throughout the stay. As well as this the team in the lobby dining were brilliant - there was one lady who gave great advice regarding Kyoto for which we were grateful. Staff at this property take time to take an interest in your visit to Japan. The bell captain was very helpful in having our suitcases sent to Kyoto which saved us having to take them on the train - this was something we went into use in Osaka and when we travelled back to Tokyo. We could not have asked for a better room. Unrivalled view of Tokyo tower to wake up to for four days was great. The only downside is the fee to use their outside swimming pool. I would have thought that if there had to be a fee it was have been considerably reduced for guests compared to what the hotel currently offers. If staying in Tokyo again I would consider this hotel and recommend to anyone. Overall a 5/5 for the hotel experience but the outdoor pool fee was somewhat disappointing. If it was not for the swimming pool I would give this a 5 as everything else was perfect.

we stayed for two nights in executive level room and found this hotel met our high standards. The room was spacious and well appointed for pleasure or business. The 35th floor executive lounge was well staffed - you could conduct all hotel business and arrangements from the guest desk in this area. The food and beverage presentations were excellent quality and service - the staff were very attentive and courteous. The hotel is well situated and only a few steps to the Tokyo subway. Airport shuttle bus service is available daily and reserved through hotel as well as tour services.

Loved the location of this hotel. Walking distance to the busy roppongi area and also access to many of the subway lines. It's also home to some of the best restaurants. Very convenient and loved the airport shuttle. It was a good price for the nice bus limo.

As you can see I have travelled the whole world.Japan and it’s culture continue to amaze me. Each time I come here it’s just a great feeling.Great people great food and their culture! Amazing.If you get a chance to come to Tokyo please do visit ANA IHG cascade cafe and also the view from 36 th floor. Amazing!!My sincere thanks to all the colleagues including:Izumi Sekiguchi Shinji UedaSayeed DangolShigeaki AndoAoi NaitoHiroyuki AbeKana FuruyaThey are excellent!

Central hotel with fantastic service and facilities! Highly recommend for business or leisure.The food was of high quality and room service teams were top notch! I recommend the sushi which was some of the best I have had in the city.

Avoid the lobby bar. We stopped there whilst waiting for our room to become available and had a couple of beers - $30 Aus for a small beer. I expect that drinks will cost more in a hotel bar in a major city but this is just ridiculous and the drinks and service were poor anyway. It's an ok hotel but I won't go here again because I just object to unnecessary and obvious rip-offs such as this.

I was pleasantly surprised that the hotel offered halal options for Muslim travelers hence that made it easier especially for business travelers who may not have as much time to look for halal restaurants outside. Within walking distance to the Tamaike-Sanno subway station. Google will direct you to Exit 13 as nearest to the hotel, but it will involve a short flight of steps. If you have heavy luggage, use exit 14 to get to surface level via escalators.Close to Roppongi and Akasaka area for restaurants and other evening entertainment.

Hotel is lovely, with a gorgeous lobby, lots of really nice restaurants (teppanyaki on 37th floor is a highlight) and bars (champagne bar, the main bar and the on on 36th floor are all pretty amazing). Nice spacious gym, swimming pool also good. Rooms a bit small and weirdly laid out, but we just sleep there so it doesn’t bother us. Concierge super helpful- did a ton of bookings for us. Great breakfast too.And location is awesome.

I used to have great expectations from IC hotels as top of the IHG offers. This stay at their Tokyo hotel confirma that the brand has old and rusty hotels. No acknowedgement f IHG status: room wasn’t even ready at 3pm, they gave us a room close to 4pm. If this is how they treat IHG members, what about non members. AC was quite bad innthe room: with unbearable heat outside and having overpaid for a room at the IC, AC should be a given. Maintenance was pleasant and helpful but they acknowledge that building is old and functioning is sub par. Breakfast was 90% for Japanese taste- with all the Western tourists it would be nice to have more Western variety. We didnt get other meals because they were ridiculously overpriced. Location is good because metro and convenience stores are right there; still far frim the action.Best of the hotel: JULIAN COLE, a concierge. He made our trip by recommending best spots to visit: so knowedgeable and hepful. Julian, you redeemed other shortcomings of this hotel. Thanks to you!!
user_name:
Gabriela R
New York City, New York

review_body: Stay on 3 weeks in this hotel for Business. As usual, good rooms very clean and great service. The Restaurant Pierre Gagnaire (on the last floor) is just amazing. very central and close to major public transportation line.

Booked a junior suite for four nights and it was lovely. But despite that high price everything on top is extra, including £30+ per person for the pool, for each visit. The pool was sold as a beach venue when we were there, but it is surrounded by concrete, and being on the 4th floor, has no views. It's more a business hotel to be fair, and not that well connected for the tube - not far, but still quite a walk with bags. The area outside isn't that attractive, being next to an urban flyover. The hotel would be fine for business, it's smart and modern, but a bit souless for a family break. There are a few breakfast options nearby, but few real eating options, so you will end up travelling, unless on expenses which is when the hotel's expensive dining options come into play.

Stayed here on business for a week. The hotel is centrally located and close to the metro. Sights like the Tokyo Tower and Imperial palace are within walking distance. The hotel itself is full service with excellent staff. The dining options are extensive but expensive. Rooms are very large for Tokyo and offer western style prongs so no adapter was needed. The elevators were fast and efficient making trips to they lobby quick. The only drawback was a lack of English language channels on the TV.

We stayed 4 night in late June 2019, very impressed with their service and the buffet dinner. Housekeeping is excellence, we got our room clean when we got back to your room and they are quite generous in providing the shampoo & other toiletries (which we got very little from other Intercontinental). Room is nice with a good view, but the bathroom is very dated, we have been staying in many intercontinental Hotels and we are surprised to see 3-star hotel bathroom. Location was ok, walking distance to subway stations (not terrible).

This hotel is in a good location. It's only a block away from the train station so you can go to various tourist spots without a lot of hassle. You do have to build in the extra travel time. It also has direct bus service to/from Narita and Haneda airports, convenient! The multilingual staffs are a great help. The room is small and you can really see (and hear) the age of the hotel when you go into the bathroom. I fit a family of 4 (2 adults, 2 kids) in the regular room which had 2 full-size beds. The bathroom is quite old. You can hear all the pipes shaking when you turn on the water. It works though, no issue. There are 2 bottles of complimentary water which is nice. Currency exchange machine is right by the check-in counter.There are a lot of restaurants, various cuisines, within the hotel facility but they are quite expensive. If you have breakfast included with your room, the breakfast buffet is quite nice and lot of options. There's a bakery/coffee place just down the street if you have to buy your own breakfast. For reference, the Chinese restaurant offer dishes that cost about $20 - $30. They were delicious but small in portion (don't think US portion) :) The dinner buffet was about $71 for adult/ $30 for kid.

Great location, with a subway station right outside the hotel. My room was comfortable but I did feel like the air conditioning was a little weak. The concierge Issei Miyake-san deserves a mention for exceptional service. We forgot an item of luggage in a taxi and Miyake-san was able to track down the taxi company, coordinate with the driver and collect the luggage and deliver it to us within the evening. In general, the concierge desk was amazing with constant help and guidance on how to get around Tokyo and plan our days. Great job.

We stayed for just one night so that we could go to the embassy early in the morning. Tokyo tower was nearby and Roppongi wasn’t far either. The staff was very accommodating and the concierge was friendly and pleasant. He even gave my 5 year old daughter a kimono bear. The hotel was beautiful and clean and had a great view of Tokyo. With Tokyo tower lighting the night sky. There’s nearby shopping and plenty of places within walking distance to see. 10/10 WILL visit again

Very comfortable rooms, good choice of restaurants with extensive menus. However, they do charge for some of the basics. I have never had to pay to use a hotel pool before - and the shoe-shine is not complimentary - highly unusual for a hotel of this class.The location is not great - nowhere near any of the great tourist sites or shopping.

This Hotel excels at service at every level imaginable. Having stayed at many of the IHG hotels, this is for sure the best by a long shot.The rooms are great. The hotel is in an awesome location, close to the metro and many good restaurants. There is a shopping mall nearby with luxury goods too.From check in to departure, the staff are excellent and take care of everything. The restaurants and bars are superb. You have to try the bar on the 36th floor offering a great view of Tokyo! The cigar bar and lounge had great single malt whiskeys and other drinks. The cigars are kept in pristine condition.The breakfast requires some time to get through the excellent variety of buffet. From western style bacon and eggs to miso soup and sushi, it’s all there... I would return to this hotel without a blink if asked!

Terrible customer service, over crowded.If you need any information head to the door people, they are helpful and friendly. Concierge are useless.Wouldn't stay there again, and certainly would not recommend it to anybody.

We choose this hotel aspecially because of the possibility to swim after a busy day in Tokyo.However, we had to pay 32€ per person a day for using the pool max.l 30 minutes ?! So we did n't swim at all...

The Intercontinental was exactly what I anticipated and look for in an Intercontinental Hotel. I've stayed in a few of the years and never been disappointed. I have one qualm and that is the additional cost to use the pool. I'd much rather have the tariff for the room have included pool access and not have to pay extra to use what is what I'd call a standard facility for every major international hotel. Despite enjoying my stay immensely, next time I travel to Tokyo I likely look elsewhere for a Hotel where the pool is accessible without payment.

This review is a little late as I stayed end of April through early May. Arrived very early but the hotel was extremely accomodating and checked us in within minutes and had a room ready. Our visit was at a busy time, the hotel kept us informed with advice that certain days and times would be busy for breakfast. They were extremely proactive in dealing with the large influx each morning. The breakfast buffet was the most extensive I have seen. The hotel has several different types of restaurants and bars. The hotel is not just convenient for the metro but also a number of tours use it as a pick up place. Any hotel is only as good as its staff, every single member we came across were happy and helpful. It was a pleasure to stay at this hotel the first Intercontinental I have stayed at.

I Want to share my terrible experience with all of you . This is a letter that we send to the concierge at the hotel that explains everything. Julian Cole | ジュリアン　コールChief Concierge| チーフ　コンシェルジェRooms Division | 宿泊部I am so sorry and disappointed in reading your mail. Specially when in person the people from the concierge desk did not have the courage to stand by your decision of charging us. That is very dishonest and coward. Something we did not feel in a country like Japan at all. Japanese people are straight forward and just. Your answer is quite the opposite to that. You should never had confirmed the reservation with the restaurante since you never had proof of receipt of the confirmation from our agency. Specially considering that in the other two reservations you did receive acknowledge from te agency. Moreover, you did not receive proof of acknowledgement from us when we checked in. If you had the interest in such, the least you could do was to give us the confirmation at the time we checked in. Not only passing envelopes under our room door. It is very dishonest as well from you that we learnt from your decision of charging us from my credit card statement and not from an email from you. We will definitely raise a strong complaint with the Intercontinental Hotels and will even analyze the possibility of proceeding legally against you. Of course we will make a lot of negative noise against you and your team in Mexico because what you did is not of the Japanese culture standards.

We took the mono rail from Haneda Airport to Hamanatsicho station and flagged a taxi which took us only less than 30 minutes to arrive at the hotel on a busy Thursday evening. Once arrived, the curbside Greeter (a charming young Japanese lady) assisted us to offload our luggage with a bright smile. There were a short line-up for the registration procedures but Grethel was very helpful and accommodating, we engaged in a very friendly chat and she certainly shows how much she enjoyed her work.Sofia managed to completed our procedures in no time and we settled in our 2 rooms shortly after.The room size is quite reasonable with city views, the bathroom is kind of small but acceptable. The hotel have a lot food outlets and facilities but 2 convenience stores located just within minutes walk.We enjoyed staying here compare with the one at Tokyo Bay.

Stayed here twice with family this month in an Executive king and had a fabulous experience. I was a bit nervous after reading some of the reviews but it was completely unfounded in my experience. Service was excellent, from room service, reception, the patisserie and the lounge. Room was spacious and modern and the bed was super comfortable. I highly recommend paying a bit extra for an executive room because you get a fully updated and spacious room and modern bathroom with a nice soaking tub. Views were spectacular. We stayed on both sides so had the Tokyo tower once and a pool view the other time. We didn’t eat much at the hotel (too much deliciousness to be sampled in Tokyo), but we had room service for breakfast usually (the intercontinental breakfast is huge and can easily feed two at a reasonable price) or got coffee and croissants from the Pierre Gagnaire patisserie (some of the best croissants I’ve ever had, even better than in Paris). The location is super convenient too with the limobus dropping and picking you up right at the door and the Tokyo metro just a 5 min walk away. Get yourself a suica or a pasmo card and the whole city is at your fingertips (we went everywhere!). There’s a 7-11 right next to the hotel with a full international atm and amazing food! Sounds strange to an American but convenience stores/conbibi are well known throughout Japan for their excellent and fresh food. We got rice balls with various fillings, excellent sandwiches, and a ridiculously good ma po yakisoba there, not to mention ice cream and candy. The whole Akasaka and Roppongi area is full of restaurants. We found an excellent sushi place nearby and top notch ramen a short walk away as well. We had an exceptional stay with wonderful service and will certainly be returning to the Intercontinental whenever we visit Tokyo in the future!

Stayed here for 5 nights for work, the customer service is extremely poor, lunch buffet menu is the same everyday without much variety, not sure if they consider for guest who staying more than 2 days with them - or maybe they are just aiming to serve guests who stay with them for a day. Pool was tacky and overall architecture is old and dated. Air conditioning in the room was heavily smelled of humidity and no de humidity was provided in the room. But concierge was helpful to open the door.There’s a metro station entrance about 4 minutes walk but you need to walk 10 minutes in the underpass tunnel to reach metro station.

We booked a long way in advance and got a good deal. The beds were really comfy and the breakfast was amazing. The service is excellent and the staff were very helpful and welcoming. We had a twin room on the 18th floor and they are quite shabby and need a refurb. We felt the communal areas were tired too. Didn’t eat in the restaurants so can’t comment on those. Be aware that the hotel charges guests about $40 to use the pool (we hadn’t realised this but in any event it was raining when we were there) which I think is pretty awful. It’s well located and all in all we had a good stay.

We stayed there for a small group business meeting in early July. The hotel staff is just way too busy to provide a more personalised service or make you feel welcome. Waiting time to check in was rather long. I stayed there for five nights and the person at the counter refused to give me late checkout past 1 pm even though I had a lunch appointment. All I asked for was till 2 pm - not a huge ask! Many other hotels I’ve stayed in in Tokyo would have been more accommodating but not this one. Rooms were clean and nice though not very big. I totally dislike taking a shower in the bathtub - very old fashioned bathroom and really needs a refurb! Then there was the breakfast queue, although the buffet was pretty good. We also had ala carte dinner at the Cafe one night and food was really average. The bar on the top floor had a fairly good views though.Overall, not impressed.

There are a few high points here; the sky view bar, the breakfast choice and the generally good service. This is let down for me at least by a few things. Some easy to fix, some not so easy.My room was very small, normal for Tokyo maybe but for me, very small. The toilet for example has a half width door that misses the toilet by millimetres on opening and a only had a half sized bath. The decor is dated and a little shabby and in my case, although a non smoking room, stank of stale cigarettes, the carpet too was stained and in generally poor condition. One complimentary bottle of water is provided, with more available in the mini bar at £5 for 500ml.... not acceptable in my opinion. The last ‘equivalent’ hotels I stayed in the last two months provided multiple free bottled water. (Sofitel Sentosa Singapore, Wanda Reign Shanghai). The hotel has reasonable facilities, a free 24h gym (gets quite busy), a sauna and a 20m outdoor pool (£30 a time though, even for guests) so understandably empty. This by the way is the ONLY outside space in the hotel, so if you want to sit outside and read a The water thing and £30 for the pool is a bit of a rip off in my view. Small rooms I get, Tokyo isn’t a big place but for nearly £250 a night I’m not prepared to put up with dated, shabby decor, carpets and a smoky room.

Check in took ages and there was only one person on the desk who was busy checking in a large group. There are two sets of lifts and I was not shown the correct ones to access my floor which resulted in a return to reception and then using the correct lift. The rooms are tiny and dated, there is no space for a bedside table, in fact storage is a shelf behind the bed which I have never seen before. I would not stay in this overpriced hotel on my next visit to Tokyo. The main frustration is that once complaints were raised they were met with apologies but no remedial action was taken.The restaurant was reasonably good and the staff definitely try hard to make the guests happy.

Ok so the rooms aren't the most modern ever but the 24/7 gym makes up for itBuffett also decent In a good spot7/11, Starbucks, coin laundry...all pretty closeAlso Roppongi So lots to doBut again Rooms are a bit dated

6 Star Service. Metro station is nearby and some restaurants have opposite of the Hotel, if you want to dine outside of the hotel. Hotel have also restaurant. I went there for a business conference purpose.

Direct airport limousine service. Plenty of restaurants around. Nice breakfast spread. Rooms are small, and expensive, but reasonable considering Tokyo standard.Walkable distance to metro station. Ideal for business trips.

I had a single room which was quite compact, but comfortable and efficiently designed with all the expected amenities well organized in a fairly small space. Everything spotlessly clean. The cafe restaurant was great for breakfast, good selection. I made use of the gym, which although not huge was big enough and pretty well-equipped. The airport shuttle bus worked very well. Overall a good experience.

My husband is a regular guest in your hotel every time he visits Tokyo for work. This week, he is back to your hotel due to work and could not celebrate his birthday for him. So I had contacted your hotel to help me arrange a birthday cake to my husband as a a surprise. I would like to thank everyone especially Yuka-san, Made-san, Mayu-san, all team members in the Club Lounge and Reservation teamA big thank you to everyone for helping me to surprise him with a wonderful cake this morning. He was definitely surprised to receive the cake it. I can't thank you enough for the great effort you have put in to ensure my requests were made. Big thank you!!!

just returned from a two night stay, my only disappointment was that I didn't stay longer. As an Ambassador member I was upgraded to a jnr suite. Whilst not a huge space it was perfectly formed, beautifully decorated and had the most perfect view.We were greeted in the club lounge by Young, who was the perfect host. Young was very warm, professional and knowledgeable, she was a on a mission to delight us. Throughout our stay every staff member interaction was excellent.The Club lounge offering was excellent, loved the breakfast and evening canapes. We also enjoyed the Tokyo bike experience which is complimentary with the lounge.We were celebrating a 1st wedding anniversary and i would like to thank Young and Elvin (F&B experience manager) and the restaurant team in Pierre Gagnaire for making the evening so special and truly memorableMy friends and I live in Dubai and have been spoilt with eating and drinking some the worlds best hotels, however our stay at the Intercontinental Tokyo redefined hospitality.Thank you and we look forward to staying again

My family of 4 (2 Adults & 2 Children) stayed at the ANA Intercontinental in the Kaze Club Suite with Club Access, and my goodness was it a dream. The hotel room was clean, spacious and just divine for my family. Japanese hospitality is one of the best in the world, nothing can compare to how we were received in the Club Lounge by Miss Kim and her amazing staff. My children were doted upon arrival and during our whole stay. Miss Kim went out of her way to organize a surprise birthday cake for my eldest who was turning 9 during our stay here. We have stayed in many club lounges throughout the world (first time at the Intercontinental chain) and the service here at the hotel has been the best by far. The made to order Breakfast was fresh and tasty each morning. The afternoon high tea was delightful. We ate dinner at the buffet downstairs in the lobby one night, as tasty as it was I do think a little pricey but still enjoyable.Access to their rail system was excellent. A short walk to the escalator leading into the tunnels and then maybe an 8 minute walk to the Ginza line. Public transport is very efficient and easy. I highly recommend this amazing hotel, and if you can afford to pay that extra amount for the club lounge it is totally worth it. Staying here was on of the highlights of our Tokyo stay.Thank you to the amazing Miss Kim and her ever so attentive staff for making our stay at the ANA Intercontinental so memorable.

Gorgeous hotel in a great location. It is perfect for business travellers. Wifi was really good. Great choice for breakfast. The lifts were a bit confusing initially but other than that I honestly couldn't fault the hotel at all.

ANA Intercontinental is located in the heart of the city. The hotel is a little far from the train station. There is a direct luxury coach from Narita airport taking about one and a half hour plus to the hotel. The check in process is efficient and is located on the first floor. The rooms are a little small by international standards but are comfortable

We attended for a works conference early June and stayed for a week. This trip was 100% business so not many of the leisure facilities were used. Though we did frequent the bar on floor 36. It’s worth noting that smoking in bars are still permitted in Japan so if you’re a bone smoker stay sat by the bar as that is the non smoking section. I had a twin room on the 7th floor. Floors in the lift are accessed by the use of your room key. The rooms were a good size and even though my room was close to the elevator you didn’t suffer from the usual noise. There was a good amount of storage and a large bathroom with in bath shower. The bathroom was a little dated particularly the shower but it worked fine. You received a fantastic range of toiletries just in case you forgot anything and a well stocked mini bar. My room overlooked the swimming pool. Breakfast was daily on the 2nd floor at the main restaurant. There was a good selection of fruit, cereals and cooked options which ranged from local Japanese breakfasts and your more American style pancakes, crispy bacon and waffles. There was also a good range of pastries. They also made a great pot of coffee! Checkin and check out were speedy and efficient. Having arrived at 09:00 we did a couple of hours wait for our room which was ready at 11:00 but it wasn’t an issue. We popped out for a walk around the Imperial Palace Grounds which was about 20 mins away. A 2 minute walk from the metro this hotel was in a threat location. My stay was very pleasant and all staff encountered throughout our stay were very lovely and helpful. I’ve no issue recommending this hotel to fellow business travellers.

I hesitated to comment because It’s relatively judged based on its surrounding venues.. but by far its customer service lacks ingenuity and knowledge compared to others...once I called the main number, got re-routed twice to the bell desk, and all I wanted was to schedule an airport bus. I was instructed to do so online! Why would people pay and stay at a hotel if all the concierge assistance was re-directed to myself?I’m giving it a1 star for its location and convenience of access from the airport (both Haneda and Narita has a direct limousine bus route with flexible schedule), and the solid fact that I have to press one to submit a review.Hotel Okura would be a much better option, and if you wish to be closer to metro station access, Roppongi Villa Fontaine. Grand Hyatt Roppongi if you prefer the full bonanza (one station away, busier district with a lot more tourists).

My family couldn't have enough about ANA Intercontinental after our 3 night stay. This hotel has a perfect combination of location, comfort, and hospitality.We took the airport limousine bus from Narita airport and the bus took us directly to the hotel. I am a platinum ambassador and I was upgraded from Tori suite to Kaze suite. There were ample room for my family of four throughout our stay. The room had everything we ever needed. Bed was very plush, bathroom was the fanciest one we ever used (including the Hi-Tech toilet), and view was spectacular from our 34th floor room. We were in the club level so we had the privilege to use the club amenities through out our stay. My wife enjoyed the Pierre Garnier's breakfast set each day and I really loved the traditional Japanese breakfast. The quality of food and service at the club lounge was exceptional. Afternoon tea set was presented beautifully and had a lovely Japanese aesthetic quality. Most of all, the staff at the club lounge provided exceptional service and we felt a wonderful sense of Japanese hospitality. My wife needed to buy some cough syrup for our daughter. The staff helped us by printing out various brands of childrens cough syrup so that she can take it to the nearest pharmacy and purchase it. They went extra mile to help us out.The location of the hotel was also great. You are no longer away from 10 minute walk to 3 different subway lines. Ginza line was most useful, as you can go to Shibuya, Ueno, and Ginza directly using that line.I will definitely use ANA again for my next trip to Tokyo.

Arriving after an 11 hour flight I wanted to go for a swim but it closed at 5 pm What a shame. Had a shower instead. Massive buffet breakfast in the falls restaurant and was pleased by the service. Great.

I only stayed one night at the Intercontinental but would absolutely stay again. The rooms are large and comfortable, service is excellent, and the hotel is well located in Asaka. I only sampled the breakfast buffet which was fine but lacked much in the way of fresh fruit options. The hotel was running a Matscha promotion in its restaurants and I wished that I could have had the chance to enjoy!

This comfortable clean and efficient hotel makes a great base for anyone doing business in Tokyo. The style probably makes this more suitable for business or couples visiting rather than those with young children. Friendly, helpful staff go out of their way to provide support and a luxury airport bus runs regularly to Narita and Haneda airports from level 1.

As a Spire member staying at this IC for the first time, it’s such a let’s down. Where to start... I know my company paid for this room, but as a Spire member, you would think I’m at least get my welcome points or complimentary drink, or acknowledged as a Spire member. Nope, I had to give them my number, asked for my points, like begging for 600 points! Hahaha, I have been to other IHG properties when my company paid for my stays, and I was given my welcoming amenities without asking for its. Then to my room, the pictures speak for itself. Molds in the bathtub, Japanese love to take their baths, I was gonna such, but for sure I won’t be bathing in this tub. On the the sofa chairs, I can safely said I won’t be sitting on its. Anyway, IC never consistent with how they treating their loyal customers when it’s come to weather you paid for your stays or your company does. So disappointed.

I love my clean simple but elegant room with a great view of the vicinity. The drawer full of kimonos is a nice add. The service is excellent, everyone so kind, polite and helpful. The food options at the hotel are very expensive, unfortunately.

The hotel breakfasts are fantastic- probably the best, day after day, in a top quality hotel anywhere in the world! The huge range of foods appealed to the mainly Japanese, Chinese, Indian and European palates. Amazing!The hotel was full when we checked in and we were allocated a very small cramped double even though it had all the equipment but just felt claustrophobic.We got an upgrade, and apart from sealed windows (no fresh air) this new room was great.The other restaurants and bars in the building are well presented, all with charming staff, high quality food at lunchtimes and dinner. The only shocks are the minuscule centimetres of wine for truly exorbitant prices. The cheaper malt whiskies are just OK.The concierges tried hard but we struggled with tubes, trains and taxis and finding the names of shops and restaurants around the Dome and the Ginza areas often standing outside but failing to see them on our google searches.

I made reservations here as this is the best located Intercontinental in Tokyo. Reviews made me hesitate, but after our stay, I was very satisfied. Before we arrived, I requested a paid upgrade to a Premier room. These rooms have been renovated. We had used a 2 for 1 coupon for 2 nights and points for our other 3 nights.All in all, I like this hotel. The location is excellent. The Airport Limo bus makes a stop at this hotel from both Tokyo airports. The hotel is close to 2 metro stops. There is a huge amount of places with a 1/2 mile to eat. There are many restaurants in the hotel. There is a small coffee/pastry shop as well. The hotel's breakfast buffet is very large but a little high priced. We did the buffet once. We had 2 mornings that we had to be out of the hotel by 7AM, so doing a buffet isn't worth it.The room was a decent size and very clean. The room size was more like an American hotel room. I found the bathroom again, very clean and decently sized. I do not understand these complaints about the bathroom being small. We had a king bed room. We had a sitting area with a loveseat. Which I used for one of our suitcases. Overall, I felt we had plenty of room. I did much research and then chose to pay for a small upgrade to get a renovated room. I think it was $25 US and seeing other room pics, it was definitely worth $25.Service in the hotel was very good. The concierge and the bell captain were both very helpful to us.Would we stay here again? Yes, providing that a good rate was available.

We stayed for two nights in May and found the hotel perfect for our need. It was close to the Metro Tameike-sanno station. Our 19th floor room has a view of the Tokyo Tower and was spacious for a Tokyo hotel. Everyone we encountered was very helpful in giving us direction and answering questions we had. We will come back again

I stayed here for 2 nights as a preference given I am a IHG member.Check in was smooth and the staff spoke English. I was upgraded on arrival to a club room as none of the category above what I had booked were available - excellent!I have now stayed here three times and this time was the best - service, room quality etc all high class. In contrast to my last IHG experience in Chicago this was so much betterI would stay here again

The hotel is like you expect from Intercontinental. Excellent service and good location in Tokyo. Very comfortable room with excellent bed for a great night sleep. Extensive breakfast of high quality.

I had a mixed experience at this hotel and felt there was a large difference between the hotel generally and the Club Intercontinental - it was like 2 different hotels. On arrival after a long flight and transfer via the limousine bus we found the entrance unattended by any staff, there were no bell staff to assist with luggage. The bus drops passengers at the level below the lobby where the reception is located so you need to navigate a large lower level, find the elevators and take your luggage upstairs yourself. This was contrasted with the hotel the bus stopped at before we arrived at the Intercontinental. At that hotel, there were multiple bell staff waiting to greet the bus and passengers with trolleys for the luggage and a friendly greeting. I was quite surprised that Intercontinental didn't have even 1 staff member available. I expressed my disappointment about this on checkin, but the staff member didn't seem to be concerned about this, there was certainly no apology given. As I had a Club Intercontinental room I should have been directed to the club for checkin, however I was kept standing at the main reception for checkin. Again, after a long flight I would have preferred to go straight to the club.The 'other' hotel, the club experience was excellent. The staff are exceptionally warm and helpful, taking time to chat to guests and provide assistance, information and tips about Tokyo. Breakfast was exception with 3 or was it 4 seperate menus. I had the breakfast from the french restaurant which was very innovative, along with a traditional western breakfast. Afternoon tea and evening canapés were available, but unfortunately they didn't vary from day to day. The room was newly refurbished and very comfortable. Blackout blinds ensured a restful sleep, and the room was very quiet. There were very limited English speaking channels on TV and I was disappointed that there were no pay to view movies available. I used the gym one morning, but after that preferred to walk around the local area in the morning. The subway is very handy and there are a range of places to eat in the Ark shopping centre next door. The main hotel lobby area was always very busy and crowded when I passed through, again in contrast to the peace and calm atmosphere in the club.

Having a group visiting this hotel, on their arrival at 5pm, their keys were not ready and they had to wait for the keys. After a long flight from the USA, this is not a way you want to start your travel experience. They had given our keys out to a larger group of the Olympic Committee and here we are a 4th time repeat group waiting. I found that very inconsiderate and selfish of this hotels management staff decision making. And our reservations were 2 years advance reserved! Bad Form! Saving factor: Julian the Concierge and the Breakfast at Cascades Restaurant. Steakhouse steaks are thin rather then the thick steak I envisioned. Pictures show thick steaksRoom 2315 Executive room, tattered worn furniture, scratches all over the dresser.

I loved my week long stay in the hotel . Well connected to public transport, room had a good view of the city, staff was very polite and responsive. I tried almost all the vegan dishes in the in room menu and the taste was good. Especially loved the tomato soup.

Overall, this is a good, big style hotel. Many amenities to chose from. Room was a nice size, although the bath room was a bit small. Decor is a little tired and I was expecting more for an Intercontinental. Staff was very helpful and service was good. They offer a very extensive breakfast and we had a very nice (but pricey) meal at their steakhouse. Feel it is more like a 3.5 but willing to round up given the service.

We stayes 3 nights in a room on the 35 floor. The room gave a very luxurious feeling. We had a clubroom and that gave us access to the club lounge where we had breakfast, afternoon tea and cocktail and tapas every day. All the beverage was included and there was a free choice of alchohol. The menues for all three meals was very good. The service was prima from the day we arrive to the day we left. The facr that there was three exclusive meals included made the price absolutely tolerable. Would definately recomend this hotel.

We stayed there for two nights after a Viking ocean cruise. The hotel was in an excellent location, with the convenience of the subway on the same block. The hotel was very clean, the room well appointed, and the breakfast buffet was excellent, with numerous choices. We enjoyed the extension of our trip to Tokyo and found some nice restaurants around the area as well. The lobby was lovely and there was also a great view from the 32nd floor bar. There were some very nice high-end stores in the hotel as well as a small variety of restaurants.

Stayed for one night, it seems a very classic hotel but it is tired. Service is nice. Room size is average, but the hardware in the room seems very old. But location is not bad, there is few restaurants nearby.

What a wonderful hotel to stay in while visiting Tokyo. If you are looking for a lovely western style hotel in a great location, go ahead and choose the Intercontinental here in Ana. The rooms are lovely, very clean and the staff is outstanding.
