The concierge and his team will make sure you have all the information you need to get around Tokyo, see the most important sights and enjoy quintessential Tokyo! Enjoy!

We booked this hotel during the golden week with my friends. As IHG ambassador member I was expecting a lot of this property. I have requested the price to take the club intercontinental to the reservation of the hotel they ask me to pay 200€ extra per night and per room for that witch is the exact amount difference between the rate paid and the club room rate. Usually I get 20% discount with my membership status. When we arrived my room was beautiful but the bathroom was too small and they are not doing turndown at night. The sofa of my friend’s room was stained and burned by cigarette and the room furnishings were horrible. After complaining about the second room the first response were « we are aware of the rooms in poor conditions » but they continue to sell it, it was taking two nights of our 4 nights stay for my friend to change room. The second thing is that avoid to go to the cascade restaurant just to have coffee, they charged us 3250¥ for two coffees it’s unacceptable for just American coffee. Then we wanted to book a sukiyaki restaurant we had the name of the restaurant and ask the concierge to book it. Even with a simple restaurant booking we had an issue again they book a different restaurant.The only goods points were the bars of the hotel the Mixx bar on 36th floor with beautiful views is amazing, the champagne bar on lobby floor with very professional and kind staff and to finish the Da Vinci bar and cigar lounge to have a good after-dinner cocktail.In my opinion it will be better for you to avoid this property which is not up to the intercontinental standard. There is an other intercontinental in Tokyo Bay witch is much better than this one.

If you are a business person or... on a group tour. This might be the hotel for you! It was however, for our vacation, a big disappointment. The hotel is a huge, 1980’s style edifice. The neighborhood is nice but not convenient to subway or important sights to see while in Tokyo. So if you are just cashing in points as an IHG Spire, don’t do it. Not worth it. I usually really like Intercontinental Hotels, but this is not up to standard. They do have a nice breakfast. But that is it. Rooms are tired. Needs a remodel. I paid $250 per night and used points for the other two nights. My bad.

We stayed here for 2 nights before and then again after a cruise around Japan.Firstly if arriving at Narita airport book the airport limo bus service.It drops off at the hotel and is a fraction of the Uber price.We arrived late morning and had to wait a few hours for our room.Avoid the Cascade café unless you want to pay 1400 yen for a cappuccino,the coffee shop is less than a third of the cost.However we did get an upgrade to 34th floor with fantastic views of the city and all mod cons.On our second visit our 16 th floor room was spacious but dated and a bit shabby.We didn’t use the restaurants apart from the coffee shop for croissants and coffee.We did use the 36th floor bar which has great views but again is expensive £31 for a beer and gin and tonic.The restaurants and bars in the Ark centre are expensive but the gardens are beautiful.

We stayed in this hotel for one night when in Tokyo. We were impressed with the decoration and size of the place. There was an excellent choice of shops/restaurants/bars. Whilst there, we tried a bakery and the bar on the top floor. Our rooms were spacious and clean. The location is ideal for nightlife and visiting the Tokyo tower. Would recommend for couples, friends and families with older children.

Very good hotel. Our suite was excellent. Staff very helpful. Hotel was happy to book restaurants outside the hotel for us and were very helpful with suggestions of places we may not of found ourselves.

Have just had a six night stay at this hotel and have had a great experience there. Right from the start the Reception Staff were very helpful and as it was our first time at the hotel gave us a free room upgrade (two room levels according to what they said) giving us a room on the 30th Floor (3025). The room was spacious with a very large, comfortable double bed. Mattress was lovely and the pillows gave just the right amount of support. Good size flat screen TV with two English channels available, well stocked mini bar (Not used), room safe, settee, desk space and chair. Good lighting and air con as well. Also had a Nespresso coffee machine which saw a lot of use from me. The bathroom was large with the WC having heated seat and all the bells and whistles you expect from a Japanese toilet. (Wifey now wants to find out how we got one like it in the UK!) There was even a TV in the bathroom although no English channels on that one. The bath itself was just about big enough for an average sized woman to bathe in should she desire but us bigger types would not be able to lay out in it. That said the shower was powerful and hot so no problem for me. Usual good quality toiletries available if needed including a Pandora's box of goodies like sewing kits, cotton buds and the like. The room was quiet enough for a good nights sleep and the air-con quiet enough it could be left on overnight without disturbing you - something i appreciate being a very light sleeper. We cannot comment on the food available at the hotel even though there a number of restaurants forming part of the hotel experience. For out taste we felt they were all quite expensive with even the basic breakfast buffet starting at over 2000Y a head (£14 at the current rate of exchange)We felt the hotel was well located with access to the subway only about a hundred yards from the lobby (with a Doutor Coffee Shop right next to it if you need it) Family Mart and 7/11 also close by. Al the staff we encountered were incredibly helpful and most spoke very very good English. All in all a very pleasant stay and we would be happy to go back.

Quality of the food average or less. The spa treatment was the worst I have ever experienced. The room eventhough I was upgraded at the time of check in was very average. It's not a real 5 star hotel.Look for other 5 star hotel in Tokyo. Don't bother about this one.

Arrived early on a red-eye and the hotel let me use their excellent gym facilities to shower and change for a morning meeting. Came back and checked in later in the afternoon. Hotel room was decent sized. Though I have stayed here a number of times and they do have smaller rooms and it can be quite hit and miss what room you’ll end up with. Overall a really good hotel, great location and easy to get to and from the airport with a shuttle bus to both Haneda and Narita.

I'm sorry, but this is far away from a real 5 star hotel and also for its price and its brand.It's hard to write about a hotel that you return after a good experience and also because you chose it considering i am a high level loyalty member. The level of disappointment made me write just after I arrive on the hotel where I am now .The room looks old, outdated and they have curtains on the shower, wich has together with a bathtub wich I consider very dangerous for older people...The bathroom is so tiny that you can't use it without closing its door ... and had to beg

I arrived at the hotel at midnight.However, reception staffs give me a lot of smiles. It make me feel safe. The hotel was full booked,so no grade-up service. The reception staff offer the breakfast to me at check-in. It is very quick without stress. Good hospitality.

ANA Intercontinental hotel, I have stayed in this hotel on several occasions in all my business trip to Tokyo, Japan. The staff are all very competent and sensitive to your needs. The breakfast is really great. Location is good because easy to move around with- the place i would come back to for my business trip all the time. The staff are very competent and the venue location is good.

Located within a few steps from several train stations and right in the heart of Akasaka, the ANA Intercontinental is highly recommended for those who wish to explore Tokyo via public transportation and on foot. It is also close to several shrines and a short walk from the Tokyo Tower. The Airport Limousine also stops here so it’s convenient for tourists who wish to take the bus to and from their respective airports (Haneda or Narita).The hotel lobby is very elegant and unsurprisingly reflective of its 5-star stature; unfortunately, our room was a total contradiction. It was small, cramped, and the bathroom was just HIDEOUS: like something out of a motel stuck in the 1970s. It was dingy, the mirror was stained, the bathtub was grimy, and the toilet was antiquated. Our room was practically screaming for an update. I was also very disappointed to learn that they had assigned me a room with two twin beds, regardless of the fact that I had stated that there would be three room occupants when I made the reservation. Where did they expect my 18-year old son to sleep? On the floor? Well, in order to avoid this mishap, they made me shell out an additional $100 for a rollaway bed. Gripes aside, I have to say that the staff were very attentive, friendly, and accommodating. Breakfast was also excellent: a buffet that showcased plenty of choices from both Western and Asian cuisine.Sadly though, I don’t think a good breakfast offering and friendly staff would be enough to convince me or members of my family to return.

We stayed at the ANA InterContinental for two nights after arriving from Melbourne and prior to travelling to other prefectures.The rooms are spacious and luxurious, was welcome after the flight. We needed to organise our bullet train passes and there was an office less than 10 minutes walk from the hotel - remember to take your passports with you or you won't get your passes - I learned that the hard way!The staff were very courteous and were able to help us with directions. I would definitely recommend the InterContinental for anyone staying in Tokyo!

This is my preferred hotel when in Tokyo, the service is attentive but not intrusive and the staff look after you very well. The rooms are sensibly sized and despite the usual scary toilets they are very well appointed.

チェックイン可能時刻15時過ぎにチェックインしたのに、フロントで、まだ、部屋の清掃が終わってないので、16時半まで、クラブラウンジで待って欲しいと言われた。幼い孫二人を連れていて、時間をかけて、クレームをつけることができなかった。たとえ、アフタヌーンティーをサービスされても、幼い孫二人をあやしながら1時間半以上待つのには疲れた。(元々、我々はクラブラウンジに入る資格は満たしていた) これまでに訪れた一流ホテルで、このように長時間待たされることは一度もなかったので残念だ。We checked in after 15:00, but a reception stuff told us towait at the club lounge till 16:30 because our room had not prepared yet. We could not spend much time to complain about the hotel service because we were together with our very young grandchildren. So tiring to take care of them for an hour & half even if the hotel provided us the English tea set. ( We had already had the right to use club lounge.) We’ve ever had no experience like this among high-class hotels we’ve stayed, so it’s disappointing.

It’s been 5 years since I last stayed. Surprisingly room deign has been renewed. It’s cleaner than before. It was so...dirty. It was the reason I decided to change a hotel I stay during business trip. Although I am positive room design was renewed, looks like...cheap hotel such as “business hotel” called in Japan. Room is so small. Particularly shower space is really cramped... Service level of this hotel is worse than before. Particularly takes time when you call to room service, bell desk or reception.5年ぶりの滞在。驚いたことに部屋のデザインはリニュアルされて以前に比べてだいぶん綺麗になりました。このホテルを使わなくなった理由がそれだったので、嬉しい驚きでした。ただ部屋は相変わらず狭い。特にシャワールームが狭くて。。。サービスレベルは以前よりも悪くなっている気がします。特にどこに電話かけても他のホテルと比べ出るまでが遅い。ここは改善したほうがいいです。

This place is not only a great hotel, but it is well located for business or pleasure. 50 meters away is Tamieke-Sanno Metro, which serves 3 or 4 lines, and is very well connected. The hotel rooms, even at the low end, are perfectly OK for a vacation. There are several restaurants on the property, including a French bakery! Close by are many smaller restaurants, including Dean & Deluca and Starbucks! We really like staying here, and the staff are helpful (especially the Concierge, for restaurant suggestions/bookings). There is a great bar on 37, from where you can Mt Fuji on a clear day!

My April trip to Japan was timed to perfection with the cherry blossoms open in full bloom. Unfortunately it also meant that all hotels in Tokyo were full or at exorbitant rates. The ANA was the only place available.Couple of points to note:1. Location wise, Akasaka and where the ANA is located are not the most convenient of locations. It’s a bit of a walk to the metro station, so not quite your tourist hotel.2. The property itself is quite old. It didn’t look as though it changed much from when I was last there (15yrs ago) though I’m sure it’s had a face lift in most parts of the hotel.3. Be mindful that some of the rooms (singles can be VERY small 22sqm).The experience for me as a whole was fine. 1. Check-in was smooth (✅) 2. Staff very courteous (✅)3. Room was decent (32sqm) (✅)4. The bathroom was a bit outdated (❌)I would recommend that when booking you ask for a queen bed or double. Don’t eat at the hotel, there are great places to eat around Akasaka and Ginza and roppongi are close enough if you want to splurge and eat. When checking out avoid 7:00-7:15am. I made the mistake of thinking it was early enough and I should be fine and done in 15mins. At that time there were only two people at the front desk and all it took was one guy checking out to ask a hundred and one questions for the line behind me to go 10 deep. After 7:15am I noticed (or maybe the hotel finally noticed) that there were 4 more people helping out with check outs, but it didn’t help me as I was first in line and there for 20mins just waiting.

I am a loyal ihg member and love intercontinentals. This is NOT anywhere near the standard of the others. It is a poor version and twice the price.Bad points-the porter broke my case by splitting the zip. Accidents happen. However the reception giggled and offered me no help with it at all.-my partner booked the hotel. Apparently even though I had paid for it and had my ihg card and stayed for four days they wouldn’t honour any of the rewards as my name wasn’t the lead name on the booking-the rooms are tiny - I mean really tiny!-the water in the rooms had an expiry date of 2015 (its 2019)- the bathroom was tired, had a style of 1970s avacado plastic and the grouting was dirty-our bed wasn’t made because we didn’t notice that you had to leave a plastic card on the bed to tell the maid you wanted it made(what?!?!)-the hotel bars and reception are by far the most expensive place to eat and drink we found in the city. And it isn’t worth it! The same beer and wine a few feet away will cost about a fifth of the price- when we arrived we were recommended by reception to drink in the 36th floor bar. Half of which was smoking and the other non. However the bar shares the same air with no divider so it stank. As did our clothes. We had to leave the bar because our throats became sore. When we asked if we could drink anywhere else in the hotel we were told no, they were all closed (it was 10pm)- the minibar is astronomically expensive. With a kit kat costing 5 pounds and a half bottle of cheap wine 30 pounds. Minibars are expensive but.... Good points-the main entrance is prettyOverall, this hotel is greedy, lacks good service and is very tired. I would not recommend anyone comes here. For less money you can stay in far nicer authentic and value for money hotels. If you want to burn money for little return then this is the hotel for you.Ihg - if you would like more information then contAct me. This hotel is letting your brand down. It is not a scratch on somewhere like the intercontinental in Bangkok which is far cheaper and much much better. Maybe the managers needs to go and see what an intercontinental is supposed to look and feel like.Bad bad hotel :-(

We are vegetarians and had enough variety to choose from. Specially once you are on the road you realise the vegetarians have a problem with food in Tokyo. The Hotel gave us a good meal before we set out for the day.Julian Cole at the front desk is a Gold Mine. We would go to him with the travel maps and he would set our itinerary for the day. His advise was very helpful for our short visit there. The metro just outside the hotel was a big boon.

Stayed 3 nights during my tokyo visit. The location was good. Very close to metro station. It is not a hub like Shinjuku. But you can stay in a quality hotel with reasonable rates and visit all the must see places via metro. Recommended for families. Nice friendly staff, clean hotel.

I get it this is Tokyo, but IHG should publish the room sizes on the website. The single "basic" room is so small it is claustrophobic. The location of the hotel is good. The gym is basic but okay. Plenty of expensive dining options. My room (booked with points) was not ready at 3 pm. I got a drink voucher. The lady who checked me seemed sure it was more than adequate and was not particularly apologetic.Book a large room or stay elsewhere!

The ANA Intercontinental staff is extremely friendly and helpful. I stay here quite a bit and the rooms are nice and large and the beds very comfortable. A much nicer gym than most business hotels I stay in and its available 24 hours a day. The internet is acceptable for streaming (5mps up and down) and the Wi-Fi strong throughout the hotel. Lots of restaurants are a short walk away and you can even find a Craft Beer bar within 15 mins.

I wanted to rate this hotel "Excellent" because the newly renovated Tori Suite is spacious, well-designed and has a sofa bed which is good for families. The staff at the Club lounge are nice and helpful too. However, the horrible check-in experience and poor housekeeping marred our entire stay. As a Platinum member I had thought that we could get an early check in but we had to wait till 6 pm as the previous guest checked out late. This ruined our plans for the day. We were not offered a complimentary upgrade. In fact, nothing was offered. It wasn't until we voiced our displeasure that we were finally given an extended check out and token points. This is in stark contrast to the Intercontinental Osaka where we were given an upgrade without asking, a welcome fruit basket, a bottle of wine and a personalised note from the GM.Housekeeping too was a disappointment. I noticed fluff from our clothing lying on the carpet after the room was cleaned and the next day I placed a small piece of tissue on the carpet as a test. When we returned in the evening, the tissue was still on the carpet.Platinum members - you'll probably get better value with a regular room.

This is a very nice hotel that is popular with western business travelers. The breakfast buffet is pricey but the service is excellent. If you don't want to do the breakfast buffet, there is a Starbucks five minutes away. The rooms are about average for this type of hotel. The staff is very accommodating and friendly. Tokyo metro is also within easy walking distance. I would recommend this hotel to anyone traveling to Tokyo on business.

Stayed here for 3 nights on a short personal holiday to Japan. The hotel its situated in the government district but it's a half hour walk go most places of interest (quicker in a taxi).We arrived at 10am and were allowed go check in early / this I have to say was amazing - thank you guys so much.Our room was on a high floor (junior suite) andrew delightful - and the included breakfast scrumptious.Loved it - hope to stay again one day

Me and my family were booked at the ANA Intercontinental for 5 nights and we were really happy with our stay. The room that we got had a living area which was separated by a sliding door to the bedroom. It was really spacious. The shower and tub has a waterproof TV. The minibar refrigerator was the medium size and not the ultra small in the other hotels that we stayed in.The breakfast buffet is located at the 2nd floor and the area was big with good selection of Western and Asian dishes.This hotel also had several restaurants within. Unfortunately we didn't have time to eat in.There is also an grocery located in the adjacent building.A Tokyo Metro Station is just located outside the building.Will definetly be back here for our next visit and would also highly recommend this hotel to friends.

Arrived from the airport on a crowded limousine bus and was about fifth in the checkin queue. Within seconds five extra staff were operating on the checkin desk which was a great start, the customer always comes first and they were demonstrating that. The room was a nice size, bed was a bit soft, and pillows were a choice of very soft or very hard which was unusual. I had a twin room to myself and the pillows were the same on both beds. Breakfast had a good choice, I tended to go quite early and noticed the queue was quite long around 8-8:15am when leaving, perhaps the breakfast area is a bit small for the size of the hotel. All in all a good place to stay and I’d go there again when visiting Tokyo.

Accommodation ( and most things ) in Tokyo is expensive, for the location, size of rooms and quality of food, ANA is pretty good. Service is generally very good in Tokyo and this hotel is up there. Very handy for the business district. 2 minutes from the Metro and 10 minutes walk to Roppongi. I wouldn’t bother to upgrade for lounge access, not worth the money. Breakfast is a nice spread. Other restaurants in hotel have decent food but I think you could do better and certainly cheaper elsewhere.

I have been a regular guest at Ana Intercontinental Tokyo for close to 20 yrs. The hotel is still nice but they have increased the price by 40% since my last visit and is no longer worth it. Reason for the price increase I was told due to Tokyo Olympic in 2020 ??? Well Sayonara - There are better hotels for less money in Tokyo.

I’m staying at the ANA Incontinental Hotel in Tokyo for the first time.It’s well located for what I need and if you like walking, it’s easy enough to get around.The hotel is good for what it is with a huge entrance with two restaurants (more later).The rooms (33rd Floor) are big enough although the see through dividing wall between the roon and the bathroom and shower stall was a surprise until I stepped into it and the glass fogged over! Very clever.Bed was big and comfy and the all important pillow was great.Breakfast was pretty standard for this sort of hotel with a lot of choice and the all important omelette chef.Things I didn’t like.Lifts are slow, but at least they indicate which lift to wait in front of - forever.Gym - big a well lit but pretty standard equipment with no spin bikes (someone tell them that cycling is getting bigger and those typical hotel bikes with plush seats, one adjustable setting and an old screen are so yesterday). Also needs more space for yoga/stretching.Last but certainly not least, I had lunch at the Atrium restaurant and had a rather good burger with two, 190ml bottles of coke. Just got the bill (literally just now) and found it was AUD60 not including tip (“service charge”) and tax. The coke alone was AU$12.Seriously? OMG I hate to think what my 2x bourbon cost last night.....Would stay again tho, good location.BTW, the additional questions below are, while a nice thought, not really relevant to a great many travellers.

it was well worth trying out the this hotel , since trying the one in Paris it was worthtaking a look and see just how it would be , and i must say expectations were met and then some, from the restaurants to the fitness, ,to the low level High End Shopping, it gives you everything you need and more all in One, For the first time in Japan it has made me appreciate the Word ,Outstanding service , five star and if there would be such a thing as six I would surely give it that ,breakfast, lunch and dinners , the Mixx Lounge , a fabulous place to be and to Meet great people from Japan and from all around the world ,it is truly a remarkable international hotel, i would recommend this place to all my friends and anyone interested in visiting japan for the very first time, the transport links (underground is exceptional as well) transport to and from the hotel is fantastic as well , you will not regret having stayed in this hotel, my suggestion is to try one of the suite, there second to none, i believe we will be returning and staying in this hotel and other in the brand...

We stayed here for 4 nights for a few days holiday before a business engagement in Tokyo. We had booked a Kaze suite (upgraded from the level below with Ambassador IHG group). The suite on the 32nd floor had a living area with sofa, table and chairs, TV and bar. Next to it was the bedroom and bathroom, separated with a sliding door. The room was very clean, cozy and practical. We also had access to the lounge on the 35th floor. The lounge at this hotel is huge with a lounge area, dining area and business corner. You can also use a small meeting room if needed. The lounge serves breakfast and warm+cold tapas for dinner time. The quality of the food was excellent. It's always quiet so you can really relax. We also went to MiXX lounge and bar for Saturday brunch. That was another outstanding experience with a wide range of Italian inspired food. The King Crab legs were awesome. We also had breakfast at the ground floor restaurant once. It has a huge variety of food (Japanese, Chinese, western) but it can get busy there between 8 and 9. The staff at the hotel is extremely helpful and very efficient. No problem with English language at all. I wholeheartedly recommend the ANA InterContinental Tokyo.

Due to a miscommunication (not the hotel's fault, my office's), I arrived a day earlier than expected. After a bit of back and forth, I got a decent room though not with a very good view and with two double beds rather than a queen as I had desired. The staff were amazingly responsive throughout my more than 2 week stay. I would gladly stay here again. Thanks!

Good: - location: Tameike-sanno Station exit 13 is just outside the building, really convenient if you're taking the Tokyo Metro- in-house restaurants are delicious albeit pricey - staff are very polite & communicates well in English - 7-11, Family Mart & Lawson are a few feet away in all directions - French macaroons, if available as dessert in the buffet restaurant is a must! Things to note: - the hallways and elevator area by guest room floors are a bit dated -- not a big deal but it may bother some people - the bathrooms may seem tight compared to North American standards -- but that's not surprising - the bed is a bit lower to the ground, unlike the newer North American beds where we need step stools to get in & out of the beds - they have very limited English speaking channels if you're trying to watch TV to unwind at night, best to download movies from Netflix

The room and service is good, lots of international staff at the hotel can speak English very well. I love their breakfast buffet! The bathroom is clean, has a bathtub & automatic toilet-but as expected Tokyo bathrooms are smaller than in other countries.

Intercontinental at Tokyo Bay is a nice hotel, though a bit old. Our room has a very good view looking at Tokyo Bay and the Rainbow bridge.The room is medium size and the bathroom is medium too.The staff are very helpful. They approach you to inquire whether you need any help with anything before you approach them.Within walking distance are restaurants and shoppings.The Ginza district with it's many restaurants and shoppings is about half hour by taxi.

This hotel is just good enough. I think they can do better. Other hotels in this class have it all. Nice modern gym, amenities, updated rooms, friendly staff. This one is just shy of all that. It’s busy and maybe they can’t slow down enough to add the personal touches? Update the rooms to lighten them up. It’ll do, if your company is paying, but their competitors are nearby and easily outdo this older property.

Stayed here for a 3 day business trip in Shibuya and it was a nice respite each day. The room was nice, functional; the hotel quiet for jet lag sleeping and multiple restaurant options within the property

Spent five nights here when visiting Tokyo. Quality service from check in and throughout stay. Very helpful and pleasant staff. Used the Intercontinental Lounge on 35th floor, great for breakfast and light dinner. Great views of Mt Fuji on sunny days.

I was a wee bit concerned after reading the reviews on TA, but I had an absolutely wonderful stay.Stayed from 26-31 Jan.I am an IHG member.Booked a Club room.Was Upgraded to a suite.The Club facilities are World class. Up there with any top Hotel in the World.The service is unparalleled. Everyone is always smiling and extremely helpful.The room was very clean.The Bathroom new.The location is Excellent. Next to the UG Metro.We walked to Roppongi, Ginza and Torra... and took the train to everywhere else.If we ever visit Tokyo again, this is where we will stay.

This hotel is very big and impersonal, but with friendly and helpful staff. The rooms would need a renovation. Good location Close to Roppongi and some good restaurants. Very Close to the metro. Overall ok but nothing that we will remember.

I stayed at the ANA 3 WEEKS ago with my family in 4 rooms. This time I am back for 6 nights by myself on business. The ANA is a great hotel with nice rooms and very friendly staff. The manager Julian San was very helpful to us due to a late checkin issue. The restaurants in the hotel are pricey but good. The gym is great and the location is very close to Roppongi and walking distance to many bars and restaurants. I would definitely recommend it for business or pleasure

Good rooms, large and comfortable. Quiet despite being central and in busy city area. Good restaurants within, particularly pastry shop and Japanese restaurant. Sometimes extravagant decoration, see the macaroon Eiffel tower on the picture!

We have recently completed a 4 night stay here as a stop over on our way to England. Check-in was flawless and we could tell from the get go the staff were excellent. The concierge staff were a god send, extremely helpful and full of great ideas and local knowledge. They also directed us to a small coin laundry across the street so we could get some washing done so we weren’t packing dirty clothes. The train station is a 1 minute walk from the hotel and we loved the convenience of the nearby 7/11. Breakfast at Cascade was exceptional with excellent choice and attentive staff. Unfortunately we didn’t try the other restaurants on site because we got scared off by the bill for a basic dinner at cascade on our first night. The rooms were very clean and the housekeeping staff were very polite and always had the rooms on point. The smoking room at the lobby is absolutely revolting so if you are a smoker, use the vending machine room (outside) downstairs. We will definitely come back to this hotel and we are grateful for a pleasant stay.

A beautiful hotel with a great view of Tokyo Tower and Mt Fuji. Large by Tokyo standards. The staff are very professional and welcoming. A great selection restaurants and bars serving quality food and drinks. I stayed in both a standard room and a club room and I would definitely recommend spending a bit extra to get a club room!

ANA Intercontinental Tokyo is a big hotel with more than 800 rooms, so it can get quite busy, especially during peak periods. Even if I'm an IHG Club member, and there is a special lane for check-in, I still needed to wait to be attended to. Stayed in a Junior Suite room. It was a decent size, with a small living room and it accommodated an extra bed and three adults. The bathroom was quite generous in size and also had a bathtub and a shower with body water nozzles. The breakfast buffet had a good variety of Western and Japanese food. But better to go early or late as there's a horde of hungry diners. If you don't want to eat too much, there's a Japanese cafe just outside the hotel, next to the entrance to the Metro subway. The Metro is the convenient and cheaper alternative to getting around Tokyo, as long as you know where you're headed. Plenty of helpful signs in English and Japanese in the subway. A convenience store is also just a few steps away outside the hotel.My only negative experience here is that I was bitten by bed bugs during the first night. I don't expect this to happen in a five star hotel, hence the average rating I gave. I reported this matter after I got back to my home country. The hotel's Housekeeping advised me that that they called in the pest control people right away. The hotel Housekeeping was quite helpful when I informed them that my daughter left her eyeglasses in our hotel room. By then, we were already back home. I was able to get back the eyeglasses within 5 days, after agreeing to pay the minimal Japan Post express mail charges to my country.

Stayed there in early January to what can only be described as complete chaos - huge breakfast queues, staff unable to conduct basic tasks (checking-out was astonishingly handled, forcing me to walk out without a copy of my invoice and settled things via email) and the rooms are dated beyond reason whilst very expensive... It's a huge hotel for groups and airline staff so staying there can only make sense at hugely discounted rates otherwise there are so many better ones to pick.

Nicer than the regular holiday Inn hotels... Wish the ladies locker room had a sauna like the men's... Has four or five restaurants and three or more bars... Live music was nice in the evenings... Staff was very friendly

We arrived at our hotel about 12 at night after a 17 hr flight. No refreshments offered on arrival. We were booked on the 7th floor with not much of a view. Rooms are dated and bathroom in definite need of upgrade. We were booked in a 3 sleeper. No double beds, all single, husband, wife and child. No biscuits offered with tea. Breakfasts are of international standard. Lobby area is vibby. Was disappointed after staying at InterContinental in Shanghai. Was the only reason we booked InterContinental in Tokyo. All in all, has good location

Stayed four nights with family and booked two rooms. We arrived early in the morning and requested early check-in. They were kind enough to provide one room so we could leave our luggage and freshen up. Facilities are really good with a decent size gym and sauna. Breakfast was good but the Japanese option could do with a bit of an upgrade. Especially on the protein options where there was only grilled fish which was very dry in all four days we had breakfast. The metro Tameike-Sanno Ginza line is very close by and provides access to Shibuya, Asakusa and Ginza which are all popular tourist destinations.

First of all, the staff throughout the hotel is phenomenal with the exception of housekeeping. Someone from housekeeping went through my things. Nothing was taken, but still unacceptable. The Pierre Gagnaire bakery on the premises is absolutely to die for. I will be thinking about the pastries for a long time to come. There are 8 restaurants in this hotel. We had dinner at the Pierre Gagnaire restaurant as well. It’s a 2 star Michelin restaurant. I was a little disappointed honestly because I expected him to knock my socks off. Especially after having his pastries. Most of the food was excellent but some of it had some weird combinations that tasted like soap and it felt like he was trying too hard. The buffet was most definitely average with many things falling below average. It could definitely use improvement. We ate both dinner and breakfasts. The sushi restaurant was above average but not the best sushi we had. The Japanese style restaurant that had sushi was excellent. The Chinese restaurant was most definitely meh. Room service was also meh bordering on yuck. We did the afternoon tea service with the ruby chocolate. The chocolate was super sweet like white chocolate and it was pretty expensive. If you feel the need to do it, split it. Our room accommodations were nice but the mattress was old and consequently pretty uncomfortable. Location is good, it’s the Tamieke-Sanno stop on the Ginza line, making it easy to get around. The hotel does not have laundry service but there is a laundromat across the street. We would probably stay here again but keep in mind that the hotel and restaurants are extremely expensive so disappointing because they don’t meet expectations considering the prices.

As the many reviews written before, yes, this hotel is in dire need of a face lift. Bed felt a bit sunken in, and hotel is very dated. Nevertheless there were several elements that overlooked this for us. Staff was all kind and helpful. Breakfast buffet was pretty phenomenal and YES - the green tea muffins are life. Bathroom had a good sized tub, and room was rather large for Tokyo standards.Overall, had a decent stay.

We stayed there for almost a week during a business trip and everything was what would be expected of a solid 4 stars hotel. Make sure to get a remodeled room as the lower floors one seemed a bit dated. Everything else was fine and the location seemed quite good (we had many tours organized but many points were interest were within 30 minutes walk)

The hotel was nice, the staffs were friendly. They even gave us a complimentary room upgrade. The buffet was delicious, I loved the pastries, while my boyfriend loved the ramen. We will surely come back.

Extremely small rooms and we specifically requested for wheelchair accessible room which was not provided as they don't have any. The attitude is 'take it or leave it'. Breakfast was ok. The subway is not wheelchair accessible and it's either a long walk to trains or take a cab. Halal meal available in room service menu but nothing fancy. Good service. All in all we were disappointed.

I stayed at this hotel on a business trip for two nights. Like many other hotels in Tokyo, the room was incredibly small- indeed, the size on par with many other budget hotels I stayed in. The decor was a bit old, although well maintained. Newer amenities, such as USB charging as seen in many other hotels, were not available.In terms of location, this hotel is quite central- within walking distance to Roppongi, Tokyo Tower and the Imperial Palace. There is also a small supermarket nearby.Given the price paid for this hotel and the convenient public transport system in Tokyo, if I were in town for leisure in future, I would probably choose to stay in newer hotels in the suburb instead.

I’m not a big fan of flying and I’ve been on United airline, Virgin, Delta, Southwest, ChinaAir, even a private chartered jet and few others. ANA impressed myself & my husband. It was smoother & more quiet than others we’d been on. Given that it’s probably a newer model but they have a nicer place to plug in our phone charger, a removable remote for our tv and a comfy headset. Oh and they have this awesome feature on their windows. You can adjust how dark or light it is without closing anything. It was so awesome! So you can make it darker so the sun won’t shine through like a car window tint but still be able to see outside!! How awesome! Sadly we didn’t get a window seat this time. The food wasn’t too bad either. We had rice & curry with cold noodles and fruits. Our 10-11 hrs flight went more comfortably than we had hoped. Thanks ANA airline!

This hotel is within walking distance to Roppogi Hill, a frequent busienss place. There is also a subway entrance right underneath the hotel, which is connected to Shinjuku or Ginza. US embassy is behind the hotel above the hill. In the elevator, you will see a lot of American travelers. Hotel room is relatively big compared with Japanese standard. As a Spire Elite member, you will get sort of upgrade but not a suite for sure. No club access just like any other Intercontinental chains. Even if you buy an ambassadorship, it won't help.

There is one big negative and that is the dated rooms. They need an upgrade. The pillows were flat and I was attacked by the shower curtain every morning. You don't see shower curtains at the higher end hotels. Not what I expected at an Intercontinental. The rest was great. I loved the breakfast buffet which was included in my rate. Matcha muffins are my new favorite. There are a dozen restaurants to choose from within the hotel. The whiskey bar had a decent selection of Japanese liquors. The location has subway stops nearby and is walking distance to Ginza and Imperial Gardens. They will book you a seat on a bus back to Narita. Service was exceptional, but expeditional service appeared to be the norm for the Japanese. It would be an easy 5 stars if they could get the rooms updated.
user_name:
Turner S
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Anywhere decent to stay in Tokyo is not going to be cheap and although this hotel is expensive I do feel you get a very good experience with excellent service. We are a family of 5 so we had to book 2 rooms to accommodate us. As an ambassador member I am supposed to get a guaranteed upgrade which did not happen on this stay (first time) but rather they provided additional points to compensate. Our two rooms were beside each other on the 21st floors with a stunning view of Tokyo tower. Both rooms were clean upon check-in and were serviced very well on a daily basis. We had breakfast everyday in the lobby restaurant (Cascade) and as some people mentioned it is crowded which it was but the service we received on a daily basis was fantastic. Huge kudos to Elena and her team for providing a 5 star guest experience at breakfast. Each day she made sure we had a decent size table and always made sure there was a high chair and our baby's own plate and cutlery. The concierge team was very helpful in providing suggestions, bookings and directions. The Mixx bar is a great atmosphere and it is pricey but so is Tokyo. Lots of food options in the neighbourhood - my suggestion is to walk towards the left towards Roppongi where you find something good for sure. The G line and N line is the most convenient for guests. We took a taxi to and from Haneda and the fare was reasonable.

Stayed for 4 nights in ANA, which is conveniently located less than 5 min walking distance from 2 metro entrances (Tameikesanno and Roppongi-Itchome). The Tori Club executive suite was large and very comfortable, which was to be expected from a 5-star hotel of a well-known establishment. The gym was large and reasonably fitted out but definitely packed and busy between 6.00 - 7.30am. What really stood out was the lounge and lounge service. Firstly, the lounge is HUGE. At least 2-3 times the size of lounges of other 5-star hotels. Secondly, the STAFF are extremely friendly and take service to the next level. Staff such as Narita (i hope i got his name right - he said it was spelt the same as the airport) made the experience in the lounge so much more pleasurable. The lounge team was collectively impressive and service standards were consistently high. Kudos to the team and their manager. Thirdly, the FOOD is amazing. The lounge has 3 meal services spread throughout the day: breakfast, high tea for the afternoon and tapas/cocktails for the evening. Breakfast is served ala carte (not buffet style) in the lounge and patrons have the option of selecting the breakfast set from the in-house 2-michelin star restaurant Pierre Gagnaire at no additional cost. If you tend to sleep in or wake up late, don't worry because breakfast ends at 11am. Afternoon service (2-4pm) is high tea and the selection is very respectable. Evening service (5.30-7.30pm) serves free-flow cocktails and also tapas from Asian or Western menu. Dishes change every night so i never had to repeat the same tapas dishes throughout my 4-night stay with them. All in all, it was a wonderful stay and i would like to thank the ANA Intercontinental for their service.

Stayed for 4 nights on business in ANA as it is within walking distance from our office.Metro station just outside of the hotel and the hotel shuttle does make a stop, however it is as easy (and most of the time faster/cheaper) to travel by train to Tokyo station and take a taxi to hotel.Hotel is pretty big and can feel very crowded, especially restaurant for breakfast.Rooms are for Tokyo a good size, but do agree with some of the other comments: hotel does show signs of the time and can use a refurb, especially the bathroom.Stayed on 14th floor and was very quiet, even being just next to elevator.If you like to avoid the crowded breakfast, there is a great bakery in the hotel, just next to lobby area and you can charge to your room.

Let me begin by stating that I'm a long time IHG customer and my stay here was one of the worst I've had over the last 10 years.1. I let the hotel staff know months ahead that my wife & I will be travelling with a 7 month baby. Despite this, when we showed up they put us in a room with twin beds, despite the booking being for 1 king bed. There was a gap between the bed and the wall as well so it was impossible to shield the baby from accidentally falling over in his sleep. After bringing this to the attention of the staff, they simply replied with the standard "Sorry Sir, there is no other room avaiable."2. The sofa in the room was dirty with visible stains on it! Anyone who has been around a child knows that they tend to try to standing by holding sofas, beds, and other fixed structures and in the process end up licking whatever they're holding. Clearly we expected cleanliness to a standard higher than this given this property boasts about being a premier property. Who knows what those stains were.3. Due to the inconvenience I was told the next day I would be upgraded to a King Suite. Of course when they moved me to another room it was a standard king room (which I didn't mind) but why make empty promises when you have no intention on fulfilling them?! This was a waste of hard earned money!If you are considering whether IHG loyalty will pay off, trust me it won't. I am a platinum elite member with IHG. You are better off going with any other brand except for IHG!

First thing first. I read alot of horrible reviews of this focusing on the dated rooms and horrible interior. It was actually not as bad as people said. The bathroom is very dated but it's still a very nice hotel.It has very nice facilities and restaurants. Here are the negatives. This place is obviously mainly for international guests and it's very obvious. It's very true that ihg platinum elite particurly get nothing at this place which is of no fault of the staff or the managers since these policies are set in place by the higher ups. Service was amazing and the tower of macraroons was super cool! So I don't really understand the poor reviews based on the amount of free stuff which you werent supposed to get? The gym is very nice but there is no squat rack or real pull up bar. Here is the negative part of staying at a hotel aimed towards foreigners in Japan. Some of the guests have strange gym behavior. I don't know why. Placing towels everywhere after use for no reason? Someone told me there saving a machine. He wasn't anywhere near the machine for a good 15 mins. Racking weights out of order. Other weird strange behaviors. I agree with the other reviews on corporate alpha males haha. Overall the experience was actually quite nice. Wish the lights were brighter in the rooms. I stayed at regular twin room. It wasn't horrible.However I have to tell you, I specifically choose to stay at three different hotels this week to help me know which brand treats me the best. Hilton treats you the best. Marriot was second, and ihg benefits were the lowest with particularly no benefits even at higher levels. The prince hotels blows people out of the water. Thanks everybody for reading this far. Basically this is a business hotel. It's ok but don't come in with crazy expectations.

Very nice hotel, great rooms, nice dining options, friendly and efficient service. Good location. I would recommend and will return. Treat Ambassador members in Intercon program very well. My favourite amenity is Japanese toilet seats!

This was the third time I have stayed in this hotel, but the first time with my family on holiday. This was the first hotel on our family holiday touring Japan. Amazing room with amazing amenities. The restaurant in the lobby, Cascade, was top quality for our morning breakfasts, giving our picky eaters in the family something to fill them up! The service from the hotel staff was amazing. The area was nice and safe (where in Tokyo isn't safe?). Would highly recommend this hotel if you want to be in an area away from the hustle and bustle of the more tourist areas. The area here seemed to cater a lot to business travelers.

This hotel with over 800 rooms works. ( as you would expect from Intercontinental) Staff is very efficient and polite from reception to housekeeping, over breakfast service to the bar on the 36th floor. Special recognition for the Doormen and woman who are doing all an exceptional job upon arrival and when grabbing a taxi.Nice is also that the hotel has some bicycles which allows you to discover the nearby area ( i.e imperial palace grounds) all by yourselves. Roppongi area ( bars/shops/restaurants, ) is within a gentle easy walk and totally safe.When you stay over during the weekend be not surprised by the many Japanese wedding couples who uses the hotel. Makes it lively and authentic.Hotel has plenty of restaurant offerings. ( even with possibility to smoke if that is what you are looking for)Enjoyable stay in the city of Tokyo.

We stayed here for five nights in a club level suite. The room was great, spacious, luxurious and well equipped. The club level lounge offers a great breakfast, afternoon tea, evening tapas and beverages with a good level of service, until something goes wrong, which unfortunately it did for us. After a couple of days my husband realised his expensive Bose headphones had gone missing. The only place he had used them was our room and the club lounge. We reported the loss to the club level reception and asked them to check with housekeeping. They were very dismissive as if they didn’t want to acknowledge something could go missing from either place. We never got them back, so we can only surmise that they were either stolen from our room which is very alarming or alternatively an opportunist fellow guest in the club lounge saw them unattended and took them. Either way it doesn’t sit well. When we checked out , reception said they were aware of our issue and would be in touch. My husband received an email from the club level manager saying if they appeared they would let us know. Please look after your valuables if you stay here.

The last year or so I've chosen to stay elsewhere amd it was nice to be back at the ana intercon.My oast complainants have beem around the breakfast and just due to circumstances I did not eat here on this trip.The levelnof service is faultless as is the cleanliness including the rooms.As an ambassador member I was upgraded to a suite which has plentt of room and noticeably a much larger but also much better shower vs the hotel rooms.Overall very pleased and next trip will be ana intercon.

Last month my husband and I returned to this hotel for a second visit, and I can't think of anywhere else I would like to stay in Tokyo. It was as enjoyable as I remembered from a couple of years ago. Yes, the lobby is rather old-fashioned and the rooms and bathrooms can be updated, but otherwise it's a perfect city-centre hotel. The location is unbeatable and all the staff are friendly and helpful, especially the concierge staff, who were very helpful in sorting out the complications of the Suntory Hall booking system. Do yourself a favour and buy a Club Lounge pass if it doesn't come with your room. You will be welcomed by name after the first time you visit, and the happy hour has an amazing array of canapes. After a long day of travelling one evening we just ate supper in the Lounge and didn't go out for a proper meal, but it was more than adequate. The views are stunning and on a very clear day you can see Mt Fuji.The only possible downside is if you wake up early, the gym will be very full with corporate Alpha Males.

I have been to this hotel for the second time, this time with the family. The service is great with friendly smile. The rooms are great and has almost everything. The breakfast buffet has many many options for every taste. Just stay and enjoy the greatness of IHG quality.

We stayed here on our first visit to Tokyo. The staff was very friendly and I felt confident asking for their assistance. The breakfast buffet was huge and delicious. However, the rooms were just, “ok”. I expected better room accommodations for a highly rated hotel. But all together, it was a good visit. Thank you!

The ANA InterContinental Tokyo is located between Tameike-Sanno and Roppongi-Itchome Stations. While it is centrally located, quite a bit of walking is needed to get from Tameike-Sannon station to the hotel and transfers are required to get around the main tokyo subway lines. The hotel is not near any JR stations as well so Japan Rail Pass users, do take note.The hotel is a grand modern hotel. I had a corner single room with views of the National Diet Building, facing the Imperial Palace. The hotel is located in a civic district and business area which can be a little quiet at night compared to areas like around Shinjuku or Ueno Stations.The service here however is excellent, the hotel staff had been very helpful when I got a delayed baggage and need their help with the documentation. I also left behind a jacket of mine but after an email to them, the hotel was able to safe keep it in good condition and a friend was able to pick it up for me a couple of months later.Overall, I had a comfortable stay and was very impressed by the high standards of service from the hotel.

Located in business district. There are shopping malls amd restaurants surrounding the hotel. There's also a train station nearby. It takes around 1hr from Narita airport to hotel.Room and toilet are a decent size and simply decorated. From the room on a high floor I could see the tokyo tower which is the highlight of my stay.

My husband and I just stayed in Ana intercontinental Tokyo hotel last month for 4 nights only. The service was great and hotel room was clean as well. However, the pillows were all too soft and no support at all. Even I folded the pillow, I still couldn’t feel the support. It would be wonderful if the room can have some renovation as I can see it’s aging.

The hotel really should pay more attention how it treats Royal Ambassador members and not to the absolute minimum required by the program.The hotel is used by many airline crews and is close to the US Embassy and hence higher security.Could be reasonable option if elite treatment would be better.

Stayed here for our last night in Tokyo and it was a great, comfortable stay.Accessibility: Quite accessible as one of the stops of the Ginza line leads directly to the hotel. Exit at A13 and the hotel towers a few steps ahead.Check-in: It was fast. And the staff upgraded us to a room one level higher than the one we booked so it was bigger than the standard room they have. Everything was ready once we were in the room with water and a welcome gift.Room: The executive room is 28sqm which is okay. Better than their 22sqm standard room. We had a little bit of breathing space. What I loved about it was that there were outlets at the bedside table, which I don't remember having in our previous stay two years ago.Didn't get a chance to try their breakfast this time since our flight was early and had to catch the 8:30 Friendly Limousine Bus to Narita Airport. But we did try the Mixx Bar at the 36th floor, which offers a great view of the cityscape.Staff were friendly in giving us directions and translating some of the Japanese words for us. They were always smiling and greeting us and ready to help.Lobby was grand with a spectacular display of a tower of macaroons from Laduree. Really, really lovely!Checkout was seamless as well and we had our limousine bus tickets billed to our room.

A solid choice in Tokyo with convenient access to the amazing Tokyo metro system. Nice rooms with excellent views form the higher level. Wonderful service from the concierge. My only complaint is that the onsite restaurants are very expensive and we had to look elsewhere for meals...however, the concierge found us some excellent dining spots.

I had a very comfortable stay here during a business trip.Rooms were very clean, the bed comfortable, turn-down service was much appreciated and showed attention to detail. I particularly liked the lighting and vibe of the room - it was warm and cozy, without being dark or gloomy. It made one quite relaxed and ready to turn in after a busy day. Location is quite convenient as well and I had a nice view of the Tokyo skyline. I'd recommend this to anyone looking for a great hotel for a business trip.

Stayed at Ana intercontinental Tokyo for ten nights. This a Hotel has the highest of Standards. At the Front Doors you are meet by smiling Staff,through out our stay the Hotel was five star. Rooms are large for Tokyo, spotless clean Hotel.a wide range of foods at breakfast  The Hotel Staff work hard make your stay wounderful.

I have stayed at this property twice over past 12 months and really like it. What do I like most?-Easy to catch taxi-Buffett breakfast is very good-Friendly Staff-Priced wellRooms are not gigantic but efficient with nice amenities. Definitely a good value.

I stayed here for 4 nights as a preference given I am a IHG member.Check in was smooth and the staff spoke English. While the room wasn’t new it was typical IHG standard and I was happy with it.Ordered room service on a few occasions and it was efficient and tasty, I would like more of a local flavour to it though.Location was good and I walked to Roppongi very easily.Taxis available from the lobby and this made it very easy to get around.I would stay here again

A friend told me to try this hotel in Tokyo, as the new refurbished Club rooms were great and very modern. That was indeed a fact, surprising bathroom see through walls that become white when in use. All the other gadgets were nice and the view superb.Not so much for the regular rooms that my assistant mentioned were quite worn out.The Club was great with special and pleasant decor. Not happy at all with the car service provided, using small cars and even though requiring large lead time. I was forced to use cabs.

This hotel location is excellent and food are also very good. However, I feel entire hotel need to be renovated if Hotel seek for 5 stars hotel. There are many new hotel built in Tokyo and shows 5 stars. In order to compete those newer hotel, I would recommend to renovate as soon as possible to maintain 5 Stars.

Our taxi pulled up outside the huge Die Hard-esque tower block that houses the ANA InterContinental Tokyo, one of three IC properties in the city. Opened in 1986, the tower is part of the Ark Hills complex in the Minato ward, and is just around the corner from the US Embassy. One of the many entrances to the Tameike-Sanno metro station is conveniently located directly adjacent to the hotel, although it is a good five-minute walk underground until the gate line is reached. Presumably as it was approaching midnight, there were no bellboys outside the lobby, so we headed inside to the reception desk where we were met with a warm welcome by a fairly new member of staff; check-in lacked the usual polish for this reason but was well-intentioned. As everybody has to start somewhere, these things are easy to forgive. As a Platinum IHG member, I was offered a choice of a welcome drink or points; as usual I took the points as the welcome drink is somewhat pointless with Club access included in the rate. We weren’t offered any help with our bags, which again I put down to the new member of staff on the desk; I actually usually decline help anyway as there’s nothing worse than having to wait for them to be delivered to the room, particularly at a late hour.Thanks to my Ambassador status, we had been upgraded before arrival two categories from a Club InterContinental room to a Kaze InterContinental Club Corner Suite. Whilst the majority of the public areas around the lobby and non-Club rooms are looking somewhat dated, Club floors have been extensively and elegantly refurbished and are decidedly swish; it’s essentially a different hotel entirely on the upper floors. As we stepped through the door to our suite on the 33rd floor, the telephone rang; reception had forgotten to give us our pre-ordered (through the hotel concierge) Shinkansen bullet train tickets, and they were sending them up now. Once these arrived I was able to look around the suite a little more. The suite itself was comprised of two principal rooms; the living room was spacious, with a large three-seater sofa, armchair and dining table with two chairs. Oddly there was no desk in the suite; instead, what appeared to be a side table housed one of several telephones and various other items more suited to a desk. The dining table was home to the Ambassador welcome fruit plate, and several welcome gifts of varying levels of interest and taste. The savoury snacks were replaced daily. To the right of the entryway, a walk-in closet provided a useful place to hide everything that is often unsightly in a hotel room, although the space could’ve benefited from better lighting and a mirror. The safe was also located in there. Backing onto the closet was the stylish tea, coffee and minibar station, which included a Nespresso machine. I always think it looks a bit stingy when only one bag of each tea (TWG in this case) is available in a room clearly intended for two people. Walls throughout the suite were exquisitely panelled or covered in subtle wallpaper, accented with art, whilst the floor was a sumptuous patterned carpet. The thoughtfully designed mood lighting and window coverings were controlled via switches, and of course there were plenty of power and USB sockets in all the right locations. The bedroom had an armchair and side table positioned adjacent to the angled window, with a small wardrobe housing robes and kimonos adjacent to the glass-panelled bathroom. Whether intended or not, although there was space for a sound bar below the TV in the bedroom, unlike in the living room there was no sound bar here. Both TVs stayed on their previous channel when switched back on; a minor point, but incredibly handy and frustration-avoiding and one which more hotels should follow. Whilst there was no complimentary Ambassador mineral water anywhere to be found, the normal branded IC bottled water was available and regularly replaced. Through a rather heavy self-closing door, the bathroom was spacious and beautifully designed. As is common with most Japanese hotels, the shower and bath were located within the same mini wet-room, the concept being that one should shower before a bath to ensure cleanliness. Whilst I can definitely get on board with this in theory, the proximity of the shower to the bath means that in reality the bath gets dirty from the shower somewhat defeating the point, as well as being unnecessarily complicated to clean. Amenities were by Salvatore Ferragamo, a nice change from the more usual Agraria products used in non-suites. The separate toilet room featured a bidet toilet; not technically a washlet, since it was a Lixil rather than a Toto, although I can assure you that the effect was the same. This mini room, more a cubicle, was on the small side and would’ve benefited from at least a shelf to improve its practicality.After a comfortable night’s sleep on a typically Japanese supportive but snug bed, breakfast was sought in the 35th floor Club InterContinental lounge, but not before taking a moment to admire the view from our suite. The lounge is arranged with a seating area directly behind reception and dining area in a long thin space to the right. The seating area offers numerous different options for relaxation, including a small library, but doesn’t immediately appear to be particularly well coordinated design-wise. ‘Cosy’ is not a word I’d use to describe this lounge what with its open layout and multiple mirrored or reflective wall surfaces, but it’s certainly not an uncomfortable or uninteresting space, particularly with its expansive views of the city from three aspects. The dining area is the nicest part of the lounge, with well-spaced elegantly-laid tables (many positioned to take advantage of the view) and two sumptuous buffets decorated with fresh flowers. For a club lounge, the à la carte menu is notably extensive, and includes a menu from Pierre Gagnaire, representing what is the only two Michelin star breakfast available in a hotel club lounge anywhere in the world. The breakfast waiting team were always professional and usually efficient and were happy to take customised orders. I enjoyed the Pierre Gagnaire breakfast one morning (which incidentally was not available on the Saturday morning); on other days I enjoyed a selection of other à la carte options. Everything was of excellent quality, although I’m in no rush to demand all my breakfasts in future are made to Michelin star standards. We enjoyed afternoon tea in the lounge on a couple of occasions, although unlike in say the Singapore Club InterContinental, I actively had to seek out a member of staff for service when seated in the lounge area (as opposed to at one of the tables), and drinks were generally not poured at the table. Afternoon tea is entirely waiter-led, something I’m not a huge fan of as I’m more at ease just helping myself to a few items rather than being presented with an entire array of things I may or may not like (although admittedly the latter is usually better presented).My schedule only permitted one sampling of the evening canapés; this was yet another nicely presented buffet offering an excellent selection of both Japanese and Western items. Drinks were made to order at the tended bar (which doubles as the second buffet at breakfast time), and a daily rotating menu of hot canapés was offered table-side. I popped down to check out the gym and outdoor swimming pool that same evening; the gym looked nice enough, but the pool area was rather austere with 1980s tiling in abundance. I also looked around the ballroom and conference area one morning, which was decorated in much the same way as the lobby.When it came to check-out, the lounge team took care of all formalities and offered help with bags and onward travel. Although I might be tempted to try one of the other IC properties on my next visit to Tokyo, the ANA offered a great suite and solid lounge experience, with the added novelty factor of a two Michelin star lounge breakfast. With some further investment in refurbishing the non-Club floors, and perhaps some slightly more proactive service in the lounge, this would have been an even better stay.

Hotel’s room needs renovationBook it if you need to stay in Minato area and you can use points Breakfast was good but pricy Not a 5 star hotel compare to other I stayed in Japan ...Pool use with charge

I spent one night and left as soon as I could. I had a standard room which was old and smelt very badly. Old bathroom, old carpet, old furniture. Horrible. The hotel is over 30 years old and needs urgent renovation. I also had to wait at the lobby and there’s almost no place to sit. All people that work at the hotel are very kind and speak many languages.Buffet breakfast is ok.Location is good but next to a highway.Not a 5 star hotel.

Just came back from a 4 day work trip - everything was wonderful. The room is great, service is phenomenonial but anything you eat there is overpriced. The hotel has a great location to popular foodie area

I arrived after a 12 hour flight from London and room not ready which was frustrating as I had requested early check in and flagged my arrival time. Took 4 hours to get my room which was painful and I felt quite unwell by the time I got my room. Other than that I enjoyed my stay. Nice rooms with a good view and good food. I tried the Chinese restaurant for room service which was great and the 2 Michelin star restaurant which really was a great treat. Stayed for business and was a good hotel for business travel - strong WiFi and rooms comfortable to work in.

I am a regular at IHG hotels, this is the usual if not better than the normal Intercontinental Hotel but the staff are unbelievably good, really great time here, if coming to Tokyo great for museum of the digital image and easy to city, great visit

front desk seems not very understand my room rate, I have asked 3 employees about my room rate, until the last one finally gave me a acceptable answer. housekeeping left a dishcloth in my room. there is a dust on my yukada.

Nice Hotel, with good room size in Japan. All services are very good and even more. I really like the service. It's expensive, that is for sure, but you really are paying for very good service and room amenities.

My wife and I enjoyed our stay here mainly for its location. There isn't a whole lot "close" to the hotel, but if you're willing to walk a lot, there's plenty of restaurants and shops to explore. We loved that the hotel was right next to a subway station. There's a lot of walking from the subway station entrance to the platforms, but the walking is all underground where it's warmer (we went in March) and dry. The subway station by the hotel is also less busy than others on the weekend, so it was nice to not have to crowd with everyone else.Our room was a decent size. We had a king, two chairs w/ small table and a desk in our room. The bathroom was outdated, but clean. Nothing spectacular or grand about our room, but nothing to complain about. The hotel itself feels like any other InterContinental. We would stay here again if we come back to Tokyo.

Nice place to stay with family. Centrally located place. Easy access to Taxi for shopping , restaurants and station Great view of Tokyo City and Tower. We enjoyed our 3 day stay. Ideal place to come with family

We stayed 3 nights with our kidsThe rooms were excellent very clean the staff was very attentiveThe breakfast at the club lounge was very special very high level great service by the club teamThe concierge service very good close to metro stationWe had a great time

The front desk staff was professional and the lobby was gorgeous upon arrival. Breakfast buffet was fabulous, but I was disappointed that my room was small and overlooked cemetery. My bathroom was tiny and outdated as well. I have stayed at the Intercontinental hotel in Shinagawa and I preferred that location. Although it was the same hotel chain, my room was much nicer and updated.

I stayed at this hotel recently during a visit to Tokyo and enjoyed my stay very much. The front desk staff were very friendly and courteous and assigned me a nice room with a view of the Tokyo tower. I was a bit disappointed with the salmon dish I had at the restaurant at the lobby level: it was too small a portion and very expensive. I used the bus service when I left for Haneda airport and it was very good. I recommend this hotel to any visitor to Tokyo.

Stayed a few nights while in Tokyo. Hotel is ok. Decent breakfast and service was good. Rooms are a bit bland with pretty small bathrooms. Nothing wrong with them, just felt a bit like a mid-range Marriott in the US.

This was our first stop on our honeymoon trip and we can not recommend this hotel enough.At check in, we had a lovely warm welcome and it was all smooth. They went out of their way to make it a memorable experience - including a bottle of champagne. This was much appreciated given how jetlagged we were!The room was large, airy and spacious. The glass window into the bathroom was interesting!The buffet breakfast was delicious with lots of options! And to top it all off - fab location!Thanks you for making the start of our honeymoon so special!

I am staying in the Intercontintal Ana Tokyo for the first time , even though we are IHG ambassador and were automatically upgraded to a one level up room , you don’t really get any other benefit compared to what we experienced in other intercontinental hotels, ,saying that we really enjoyed our stay , location is great as it is very close to an underground station (Tamekai Sanno) which have few underground lines that is very handy for exploring the city , one other plus thing is that the Narita airport limousine bus drop off /pick up area is literally T the hotel ground floor .Finally breakfast is amazing

First trip to Japan and I am glad that I got to stay at ANA Intercontinental. The location was good and the subway was one minute walk from the hotel with great connections to move around the city. The area is a bit quieter than other areas like Shibuya & Shinjuku but I prefer that. The staff are a great asset and I would probably choose to stay there again on my next trip to Japan. Breakfast was excellent!

I stayed here for a week on are second week in japan , First thoughts of the hotel , it was definitely a business hub and not somewhere for a holiday, We was on the 21st floor the corridors smelt like cigarette smoke and the carpets where not very clean. Now to the room it needed more light features as was very dark at night even with all the lights on. The bath room was terrible for a 5 star hotel , ( Shower in the bath it was a 2 star hotel bathroom)Good points was the bar on the top floor which had amazing cocktails and a nice view

I’m giving this hotel 5 stars not because it’s the chicest of places I’ve stayed in, but because everything as a whole- from the lobby, staff, amenities, bar and buffet were amazing.First off, I must start by saying that this is very much a business hotel, but I do appreciate the concessions they made for families- adjoining rooms, gift bags with slippers and toys for the little ones, but I couldn’t get over the steep price of their pool admission. I think it was $35 or $60 per person (per day!) to access the pool. Granted, you got some alcohol or something with it- but families with young kids were not best served by this policy and for a family of 5, that is a ridiculous price. I think the intention was to prevent over crowding at the pool and it worked!The rooms were clean and well appointed- I loved the Toto toilets (which are standard in Japan, I guess). The bathrooms were rather small though, as in, a larger person might have to enter sideways and the toilet was practically in the tub- no lie.The breakfast buffet was great! It had every thing you might need from American to English to traditional Japanese to Chinese breakfast. A+++The staff were attentive yet unobtrusive and the concierge was extremely helpful in helping us chart our course via train each day. This hotel is almost on top of the train station and is central to most of the interesting spots in Tokyo. Don’t look for anything other than a cityscape view though- it is in the middle of a concrete jungle. The bar/lounge in the 32nd (?) floor was a nice touch if you didn’t feel like leaving the hotel. I’d stay here again.

IHG standards fully maintained on this property. Front office and concierge staff was fantastic. To Roppongi, Shibuya, subway and fish market is close by. Across the road there is a coin operated laundry. Small shopping grocery shops around. There are few great restaurants, buffet and a bar as well. We throughly enjoyed our four day stay at ANA , Akasaka.

Had three great nights at this property. Being a Royal Ambassador (IHG membership level) I got access to the club lounge. That means exclusive breakfast service and an exciting coctail hour - for 120 minutes - with premium beverage included. Nice views too from this club lounge. Would definitely come back (not sure if you can buy upgrade or if you have to book a lounge room but it’s worth the investment). So can’t say anything about the other restaurants or bars at this hotel... Also had a twin room with modern facilities, good bed and high tech toilet :-) Took some 90 minutes from Narita with airport express train (Keisei - book online!) and transfer to the metro’s Ginza line.

This hotel made our stay in Tokyo absolutely amazing. Our room had a great view of Tokyo tower - so we didn’t bother with going to other viewing decks to see it. We got to see it day and night every single day. Instead we opted to see Tokyo views from skytree. Rooms very clean and beds comfortable. The room size is very spacious by Tokyo standards. The breakfast buffet is amazing; we ordered room service to bring it up. Fresh and very tasty. Prices are what you expect for a 5* in Tokyo. Concierge and receptions always very helpful. Location wise; it’s close and walkable distance to a few lines. No more than 5 mins. The subway leading there is directly outside the hotel. This is a nicer / business part of town. Away from all the hustle and bustle of shinjuku. The rooftop pool is amazing ! Stunning views of the city .

I’ve stayed at this property regularly since ‘13 (in fact, I was there for a few months while looking for an apartment); this was my first time back in about 2 years. There are so many things I love about this hotel - it’s very reasonable considering it’s Tokyo, the property is in a great location (close to many restaurants, stores, easy access to the airports, etc.), the rooms are clean and the service is top notch. The two major downsides - in my opinion - are: they won’t guarantee you a non-smoking room (no matter how hard you try) and some of the rooms haven’t been renovated in a long time. There are also a few other odd quirks as well, e.g. they charge you to use the pool. I got upgraded to the club level room given my status, which has the newest rooms. They are VERY NICE and are an absolute steal for the corporate rate I was paying. The bathrooms are very small but I didn’t mind at all given the price I was paying (in particular, I almost had no room to sit on the toilet...take a look at the picture...it was a bit ridiculous). In the end, this property will continue to my choice when visiting Tokyo!
user_name:
legacytraveler1
New York City, New York

review_body: The hotel is absolutely gorgeous. There are a lot of places to eat, inside the hotel or around the hotel. The rooms are super clean. The bathroom is gorgeous. I wish I can have this kind of a bathroom at home. What a luxury! The shower amenities are so perfect especially when you are traveling with kids. There is a small television next to the bath tub and kids love that. The toilet is so modern, warm seat and washes you up that you feel so clean after potty. The staff speak English and are very hospitable and courteous. The bed is very comfortable and I so love the pillows-beautifully soft. Because you are a tourist so you are mostly out sightseeing the beautiful city, you will come back to a very polished room and made up bed. What else can you ask for???
