They were always polite, patient, insightful, and attempted to accommodate all of our requests. We made a number of restaurant reservations through them - all of which were fantastic.The hotel is also very convenient. The airport limo from both Narita and Haneda stop at the bottom floor of this hotel, making transportation in and out of Tokyo a snap. You can purchase your tickets from the front desk - my thanks to the staff for making this so easy for our group. The subway is a bit of a hike, but there is a tunnel connecting you underground so it's easy to navigate. There are also a ton of restaurants, cafes, and convenience stores adjacent to the hotel. Perfect for snacks or last minute shopping! I do have to caveat... Since I was vacationing with a big group of friends scattered across multiple rooms, it was interesting to see the stark difference in the quality of the rooms on club levels vs non club. While still comfortable, I must say that I have stayed in business hotels in Shibuya that were in much better shape for a lot less money. I certainly would not classify them as luxurious nor worthy of a 5-star hotel rating. If I had spent five nights in one of those rooms, this review would certainly look different. I'm really hoping a full update is in the works for all rooms.

The ANA Intercontinental Hotel is a decent hotel with very good breakfast buffet. Rooms on upper floors (club floors) are updated while majority are not. Was disappointed my room was so outdated but it was clean and sheets were crisp and ironed.
user_name:
Toni H
New York City, New York

review_body: ESP Review of ANA Intercontinental Asakusa/Roppongi – Tokyo, JapanThe Summary: Nicely maintained Intercon in great central Tokyo location with exceptional service level. One of my favorites world-wide. The Vibe: Classy hotel with modern updates and many dining and lounge options Location: Great location between Akasaka and Roppongi. Best way to reach this hotel from either airport is by Limo Bus (~$30USD). Closest train stops are Akasaka station and Roppongi Itchome station, both easily walkable from the hotel which is in the Ark Hills complex.Room & Bath: It would surprise most people how old this hotel actually is as the rooms are very nice, well maintained, spacious (for Tokyo), and with modern styling. Some rooms have great views of Tokyo tower and other areas of TokyoAmenities (wifi, gym, pool, etc.). Wifi is very good. Gym contains mainly cardio equipment and a universal machine. Pool is outside on 4F of the building. There is a beautiful club lounge which I use to access as Royal Ambassador in years past but now they have excluded this benefit and one can access only by payment or purchase of room type. Food & Beverage: The hotel has multiple dining and lounge choices with great buffet option on the lobby floor and other options on the floor above. There is also a nice two level lobby bar and a brandy/cigar bar on 2F with music most nights. Staff & Service Level: I have stayed here many times and have found the staff to be consistently helpful and polite. Misc. The hotel is located in Ark Hills complex which contains many other dining options and also a performing arts center. During cherry blossom time, the road behind the hotel is awesome in bloom. One can walk to both Roppongi (~10min) and Asakusa (~8min) for many more dining and entertainment options. Would I Repeat?: Absolutely. One of my favorite hotels with a great combination of location, service level, room quality, and amenities.

ANA has some interesting reviews ranging from glorious ratings to middle of the rung. My verdict is as others describe it which is: in need of an overhaul/refurbishment. Whilst the foyer may look fine, inside is not. It’s worn out and tired. For one night it’s fine but simply can not compare to equivalent star hotels around Asia. This is more like the Excelsior in Hk standard. I’d give it 3 stars.Location is fine if you have an office nearby and 15 Min walk to Roppongi Hills or 10 mins to Kamiyochi station.Whilst the hotel is getting old it is easy to get here from the Hamamutscho terminating station for the monorail from the airport. Cost ¥1,200 from the station to the hotel. The taxi fares are reasonable here and kept in pristine condition.I’m going to try a different hotel next time because this is just worn out and not very uplifting if you have work to do. Breakfast is normally 4,000Yen however you may get it for 2,900Yen on discount. You can try exiting on Level 3 for Ark Hills to pick up food into an office complex. Saves you having to walk out the front and around to get there, There are no international power points but you can ask for an adaptor. The points are all Japanese 2 flat vertical pins. Iron and board is standard but downside is no free bottle of water so just another thing I have to buy which is standard in other hotels in the same chain.Bathroom has a tub with a shower curtain and I appreciate it’s Tokyo and space is at a premium but it is dated. The toiletries don’t fit in the old tiled soap holder.There’s no bathroom Scale if you wondered.Fortunately there is a 7/11 or Family Mart nearby. The other convenience store but further way is called natural Lawson.Just a bit old so marked it average. The corporate photos are very glossed up compared to reality.

I can never quite see what the fuss is about Tokyo's classic hotels. I usually stay in the Okura, which is well appointed and has quite spacious rooms, but just looks about 20 years out of date for a makeover. So this time I went to the ANA Intercontinental and found it pretty much the same.So maybe I'm just at odds with Japanese tastes. But the rooms, in fact the whole place, just seem dark and dated, as if the whole thing needs to be brightened.I should say the hotel staff were very good, and moved us up a few floors after the first room we were in was too dingy and small. It seems there had been some communication gone astray as we had asked for two interconnecting rooms and they didn't seem to be expecting it. So they were helpful and as polite as Japanese staff always are.It is well placed, particularly for any government meetings in Kasumigaseki, or for meetings up the hill in Ropponggi; Otemachi and Marunouchi are a bit further away but just a taxi or a subway ride.

We stayed here for 4 nights to race the Tokyo Marathon. We had an initial issue at the start over room booking but this was soon resolved. Loved the hotel, great beds and shower. Location easy to navigate from whether using the subway or cabs.Best of all are the hotel team - all on the money, well trained and very, very customer focused, nothing was too much trouble. Finally the breakfast buffet, without doubt the best one I've seen and enjoyed in any hotel I've stayed at in the world. Overall great stay, loved it.

A busy hotel that caters to the business traveller. The room was small and the bathroom was smaller... both in dire need of a refresh. The cocktails in the Mixx bar were good but it was very smoky, and we were a little surprised to see so many "professionals" working the room. Ambassador Club was very good.

The check in was very fast and efficient with friendly and engaged and helpful staff. The concierge provided very good guidance on local dining and was very helpful. The first night was in a "standard" room which was small, dark, and dated. However, it was clean and the bed was very comfortable. I checked out to travel to Okayama for one night and then checked back into the ANA InterContinental for a week. This time I had a "deluxe" room which was very nice. Great bed and nice work area but the bathroom was a little small. The Executive Lounge was outstanding with friendly staff and a very comfortable atmosphere for work and relaxation. A very great experience the second visit.

I have stayed here multiple times on business over past few years and found they have a well oiled machinery to cater to hordes of business travellers who frequent this property. Proximity to Tokyo office of most MNCs ensures this sits in the most preferred list for business visitors. There are multiple restaurant options available within the hotel as well as in very close proximity to cater to diverse tastes. Service is always very professional and in line with Japanese standards. Special shout out to Pierre Gagnaire Pains eat Gateaux at the lobby level that provides welcome respite to industrial breakfast buffets at hotels. The variety of mouth watering options here would give anyone with a sweet tooth, a sugary high. If one would like to stay in Tokyo as business visitor and reach meeting locations in business district in quick time, I strongly recommend this property.

Outstanding support from the concierge team - Miho. I had a friend staying in the hotel and wanted to send a gift, Miho went out of her way to get us the perfect gift for our friend within a few hours. Absolutely amazing customer service

My family and I stayed at the hotel for two days. We had to change room after the first day. The hotel insisted that we cannot stay in the same room since the room was booked on the second day. This was very inconvenient. I had to call several times to get the luggage moved from the first room to the second.The difference in the two rooms that we stayed was notable The first room was well appointed and was luxurious. The room on the second night was tired and small The room on the second night was similar to the rooms that were booked for the family.

We stayed at this property for 3 nights in a premier room in September. We loved everything about this property.Given this is one of the largest cities in the world, the room size was comfortable. It had more square footage than we typically get in NYC. The window views over the city were fantastic and they offered a nice couch in the room to sit and enjoy it from our room on the 32nd floor. We highly recommend getting a room which gives access to the Club Intercontinental Lounge on the 35th floor. It was recently renovated and offers extensive amenities including full breakfast, tea time and happy hour complete with cocktails and hors-d'oeuvres. The breakfast options were expansive with a variety of local and western dishes. Don't miss the tea time, the food spread is delicious and they offered the largest variety of beverages we have ever seen at a hotel cocktail hour. Enjoy all of this with expansive views of the city and attentive service. This lounge experience really sets this hotel apart in our mind.The hotel has an outdoor pool which is a unique find in the city. We loved spending a day relaxing our aching legs from all the sightseeing we did the days prior.The hotel offers a wide variety of restaurants on-site from casual to Michelin rated fine dining restaurants. One of our favorite experiences was enjoying The Champagne Bar with the live piano music in the background.We found the concierge to be extremely helpful in making dinner reservations before we even arrived at the hotel. They were extremely responsive via email and helped us to plan our days. They provided daily packets with our reservations including clearly marked addresses and directions on how to get there. Really top notch service.Lastly, we loved the location. It was in a safe area with plenty within walking distance and it was steps from a train station which made it the perfect base for exploring Tokyo. We will definitely return to this hotel on our next Tokyo visit.

The hotel service is as good as a five star hotel that you can expect from. The room is clean, bed is comfortable with choices of pillow. However, I personally think that the standard pillow is too flat. There are foreign staff here. But Japanese staff here can also speak English fluently. Though I can speak Japanese but it seems unnecessary here. The location is in business area. It’s a bit difficult to find local restaurants, and you don’t get the atmosphere of Japan in this area.

Room is small, but ok in this location. very convenient location in minato, by walking distance or few subway stops to many scenery points. Strawberry festival is good. All you can think about strawberry. Even cocktail with massive strawberry profile.

I am an Intercontinental Ambassador Member at platinum level. I couldn’t give five stars due to the construction going on at the club level and the disconnected the two banks of elevators so the have been at times painfully slow. Overall this hotel has it all, their rooms on the higher end are well appointed and extremely clean. The staff is beyond perfect as they are very attentive to your needs at any time. I received a welcoming gift upon arrival in my room and then one on checkout. The rooms and all common areas are spotless and perfect. The breakfast buffet is well stocked and the club lounge is a great place to meet up with friends before heading to dinner. There are many great restaurants in the hotel and around the area. The concierge will set up any reservation you want. I have stayed here many times and have never been disappointed in the impeccable service. This is a beautiful hotel that I highly recommend to any type traveler. The room I had, had the glass bathroom that instantly fogged the glass electronically upon entering. It had many USB ports and outlets. The bed was very comfortable as was the rest of the furniture.

ANA InterContinental has an ideal location for the business traveler as it is right in the centre of many large office buildings and close access to the subway system. The only thing about its location is it is definitely not the "Tokyo" feel i.e. it is geared 100% for the business traveler and outside there really isn't that much unlike say if you go to Shinjuku area etc.The hotel like all IHG properties is horrible for IHG Rewards benefits, I am Spire AM and I got one room upgrade which wasn't that great and no breakfast etc. They did allow me to check in early but I had to keep checking back with the front desk while I saw other people getting their keys etc.This is a large property, so it has a fairly good gym and other facilities but everything is fairly bare minimum. The rooms are really spacious for Tokyo/Japan standards so that was really nice. I had to ask for turndown service, it is not automatic and both times it was missed even though I requested it. The staff was nice overall, this is a big place so some things take a while. The hotel was very clean though, per a lot of Japanese standards. Overall, a decent hotel - definitely good for the business traveler - although the safe doesn't fit a laptop - heads up.

Family stayed here when they came to visit me in Tokyo for a week. The location is fantastic - being right in the middle of Roppongi and Akasaka, and the restaurant has great food. The rooms are smaller and starting to show their age a bit. Overall a nice hotel, but average in price value.

I just enjoyed a most memorable 10 days at this SUPERB establishment!! The hospitality & service was simply extraordinary in every respect. I received an enthusiastic greeting from the Intercontinental reception team upon arrival & escorted to my room. The room was beautifully appointed, spacious, comfortable and featured a wonderful view. Over the next 10 days I took full advantage of the Intercontinental ANA's many amenities including the exceptionally well managed, beautifully decorated and exceedingly delicious morning breakfast buffet, the excellent attributes of Ka-tsu health & fitness club (especially its 24 hour availability) and the very helpful and capable business center.Most importantly however, I was once again made to feel uniquely welcomed by the young men and women comprising the Intercontinental ANA's outstanding staff, many of whom I have come to know as “family” (especially Junko-san & Satomi-san). They consistently conveyed a sincere, personal interest in ensuring all aspects of my stay from pick-up to departure were “first class”!! Having stayed on many previous occasions over the past 10 years, I have always been impressed with their competence, engagement skills and genuinely sincere efforts to make all guests feel very special. This of course is a direct reflection of the ANA’s overall hospitality approach – “Omotenashi” elevated to the highest level and managements’ constant attention to detail that set this Tokyo property apart from all other Asian hotels. If you want an unparalleled and exceptionally enjoyable experience then Intercontinental ANA Tokyo should always be your first choice!!!Safe travels to all, Ed Stikeleather.

Excellent location, nice spacious rooms (somewhat dated: especially bathrooms). Breakfast could win from a little more variety: various very cool bars (Mixx!) and restaurants with sympathetic staff to finish it off (prices slightly less sympathetic, but you know that....): that there is no still water for free for IHG gold members strikes me as somewhat weird. When issues arise (wifi problem), staff is there in 2 minutes and things get really resolved!! Overall very positive.

Huge hotel designed for conferences. Good location right on the Ginza line. However, the hotel applies internet filters and blocks access to many sites that they deem offensive (ie Gay and Lesbian sites). The doormen are very friendly and willing to assist in locating companionship and witnessed many of these ladies in the halls, as well as heard them as they kept us up in the middle of the night (let me be clear, there is nothing remotely romantic about this hotel and no one would ever plan an anniversary or romantic getaway at the ANA Intercontinental).

After a bad start to the trip, being delayed by the unusual snow fall, it was excellent to have a smiling face and lovely hotel to rest in. Recommended for any business traveler that needs to be in the region.

We stayed on the Club floor, which is the only way to go. Complimentary breakfast, afternoon tea, pre dinner drinks and snacks. For the price - the room was disappointingly small. Also lack of Japanese bath house - Onsen - was disappointing, having trudged around Tokyo all day a long soak would have been very welcomed. The standout of this property is its unparalleled service. Fabulous.... didn't have to lift a finger. Bookings made, services sought out, all done efficiently and discretion. Concierge and lobby manager, possibly the tallest man on the planet, really made the stay special. Fabulous dimly lit bar with quality jazz playing was a favourite each night after we returned from dinner. Well located

Had to stay again for business in Ana Intercontinental hotel and was this time appointed a newly refurbished Club room. Disappointing. The new bed was very uncomfortable. As you see on the attached photo; a firm mattress on wooden board bed-base...well actually just a plank. A slatted bed-base would have at least been better and be able to shape the mattress around the spine. The bathroom was this horrible nowadays trendy 'fish bowl' glass bathroom. So cramped that the towel rack is located above the toilet seat. When you switch on the light the glass does get frosted but still no privacy regarding noise. Door did not even closed properly. And the bathroom just seems to take all the space of the room.

Sitting in DaVinci’s having an Old Fashion listening to Piano and Bass music relaxing before a big day of work in Japan. Great selection of Whisk(e)y. Incredible service paying attention to the customer is a priority. You can relax in the comfort of the lounge area or sit at the bar. Both equally good. Bar tenders are great.

Upgraded to a superior room with better views and free internet on-site. Had been in too many small hotel rooms in Japan and wanted to end "fancy". I was not disappointed. Great room, newly refurbished and very good breakfast. One of the best hotels I have stayed at.

Dear All friends of Hospitality industry,Ohiyo & Sawadee krub!!Please review my comments as per below.We stayed here on First period 24 to 25 Jan,18 ( RM 2406 ) and Second period 26 to 27Jan,18 ( RM 2122 ) respectively.Such an excellent entire front desk team from the main door up to the room ( Many thanks for Lobby manager for show your care upon our arrival and once again Many thanks to FOM for greeting ourself for the second stay ) Spacious room, Cleanliness and Tidy were top notch, Great Job for house keeping team as the cleanliness is the most important for hotels, Comfortable bed and bath room.A BIG THANKS to Ms. Joyce for making all necessary arrangement for us, you made our last trip in Japan completely finished 101%. In additional the taste of breakfast was absolutely perfect well done plus variety of menu which is great ( Tell you the truth your breakfast better than some five stars in England) likewise all staffs at breakfast time was very helpful. You don't need to looking for or call on them but they will approach and reach to your table when timing is right and i totally say " Those things are attentiveness and efficiency service ".Many thanks for male staff whom arranged taxi while we were heading to Narita express station. Taxi driver also was polite and assist our luggages once we arrived at Station.Over all, It was not only meet the services at ANA Intercontinental nevertheless your services was exceed our expectation. We would be more than happy to give your PERFECT five stars as well as HIGHLY RECOMMEND & RETURN for your hotel. In the meantime, We wish very much to return again next year 2019. Hopefully our comments will share to all your WONDERFUL staffs.Arigatou Gozaimasu!!

We chose the ANA InterContinental for four nights of accommodations during our Board of Directors meeting in Tokyo and did not have a good experience. The rooms were stuffy and out of date, with no ventilation in the bathroom so that an enormous amount of condensation accumulated on the windows, even with the bathroom door shut, resulting in significant pooling of water on the window sill. I would wipe it off with a hand towel, which I would have to wring out four or five times to rid the window of water. I have never seen anything like it in any hotel, much less one that describes itself as Tokyo's best luxury hotel. Also, if you are female, you will not have access to the sauna facilities, which are MALE ONLY. This is not mentioned on the website. Simply unbelievable in 2018. One of our party arrived in his room to find a strong unpleasant smell in the bathroom, although it was promptly addressed upon reporting the issue. Finally, we had a number of issues with our reservations, including one of our Board members who was asked to check out early, despite the fact that we prepaid the room through the following day. This significantly disrupted her day. Another of our party arrived late only to find his prepaid room had been given away. The wifi, another business travel essential, was often slow and spotty. The only positive aspect of our experience was that the morning breakfast is a very good buffet and service was generally very good, apart from our problematic experiences with the front desk.

Might not look so much like a brand new 5* Hotel, but they simply do everything right and nothing at all will disappoint you. The hotel has a very long history, and here you see, how a perfect hotel works.Other hotels impress you with boutique style. But often enough, that's about it. Amongst many others, I was in New York at W Hotel Times Square. Looks perfect, but I am not sure if they know ho to spell the word "service" at all. But knowing the policy of W (and alike), one does not go there for service. You go there to stay in a cool and trandy place. And somehow, it is good to be left alone and not to be pampered too much, there. It is cool to stay, so don't complain.ANA Intercontinental Hotel Tokyo is a place where - once you stayed there - you will come back for sure. Everything - litterally everything is perfect. They sure know their jobs. At this place, the Japanese show their every strenght. Hospitality written in capitals and perffect food, everything works perfectly.Sure, there are many other hotels especially in Tokio which can easily compete with the ANA, but they add a personal touch to you stay, just at the perfect amount.Folks, you will see me again and again many times in the future. (Like in the past)

Stayed here for about 6 nights and what a great place it was!Could have more options for vegetarians Room was not vacuumed on two occasions but after complaining was sorted out quicklynear the Tokyo Tower

I stayed at the Ana Intercontinental, not to be confused with the other Intercontinental by the waterfront. This one is convenient as it is close to a lot of business quarters, often at walking distance. While it is a good 5 star, let’s not get spoiled, I was a bit disappointed. They had no clue about veggie food. There was hardly any vegetables at their big evening buffet, just a bit of mixed pieces of lettuce that had seen better days. No real vegg dishes. We had dinner also at their Chinese which was supposed to have a Michelin star somebody claimed but I thought service was so and so and non-heg food looked ok but not exceptional. Also no clue about veggie. My veggie degustation menu was as bland and ordinary as it gets. A scandal really. Then we had dinner in their high-end Japanese. Service was chaotic. I got all my dishes at once, in one big pile, which turned them cold of course. One of the others got his first dish once we were all done with our 4 courses. Other stuff arrived at random. Friendly and keen to serve, sure enough, but they could not understand our queries about the food. Again no clue about veggie food. Had to patch it together, half with side dishes. Aoart from the not-so-spicy wasabi, nothing really had any taste. Was outraged because of them taking pride in their sea cucumber dishes. We were just back from the Maldives and the Padi people were complaining the locals were illegally poaching all the sea cucumbers, which is catastrophic for the corals. All of this to ship them straight off to Japan for high prices.The Mixx bar at the top floor had seen better days and was one cloud of sigarette smoke. The rooms were small and must have looked good 40 years ago. Everything smelled of old carpets. This place needs an urgent refurbishment!Fitness was good but outdoor pool needs urgent lick of paint or more - see photo. You could summarize this as a hotel for smokers, as they were pampered in all restaurants, even the lobby lounge, etc. There was no escaping the clouds of smoke anywhere. Together with the brown decoration, It was a timewarp back to the end of the seventies when all places looked and smelled like this. The weekend afternoon tea was very nice though. So different from some of the other outstanding, world-class hotels I have had in Tokyo.

I really loved this hotel. The lobby/hall is spectacular and it reminds me of an era of class and elegance of 1970s. I was amazed of the beauty of this common area and the piano :-)It was Christmas and the Christmas tree was amazing...I am sure they had to spend at least a week to decorate it so elegantly. Staff are amazing and extremely professional with 100% IHG standards. I felt so pampered and comfortable in this hotel. The room was about 19sqm but very cosy and elegant. I would have appreciated Japanese amenities (soap, shampoo, etc). I would definitely go back to this hotel next time I'm in Tokyo

The hotel has its own charm, not new but All things work and clean, excellent location, service is excellent and improved so much over times. All staffs are very nice and helpful. I have been visiting this hotel since early 2000 and i can notice the level of service continuously improving for the better. I have notified the hotel in advance and they have accommodated my requests when i arrived. Proactively helping the customer to have an enjoyable stay in the hotel. One of the concierge, Miho, is extremely helpful with restaurant reservation request and her recommendation is also excellent. A very happy customer.

Large and busy hotel in the Roppongi area of Tokyo. Excellent customer service and nothing is too much trouble. Rooms are spacious and very decent for a quick business trip however in need of a refresh as quite dated. Good service fitness facilities and huge breakfast buffet with good array of western and local options.

Ana Intercontinental has been a little disappointment. Having paid more than 300 euros per night, we expected quite a lot more from this 5* hotel. It has good restaurants, breakfast has many options, and gym is quite decent, but the room itself was very much outdated. The furniture needs to be changed and the bathroom did not match the japanese standards. Old bathtube with shower curtains and toilet with no options.The staff is very little english speaking. No waterbottles left in room.

We visited this hotel over the New Year. For such a busy period the hotel was operating extremely well with an easy check in, bags were delivered within minutes. The room was really quiet for such a busy period and had everything that we needed. Breakfast was also quite good and had a great selection of western and Asian cuisine.

First, the staff is wonderful - hardworking, attentive, helpful. However, it seems that the hotel systems are stuck in the 90s. It seems to take forever to get checked-in because of incredibly slow data entry. The elevators were unbelievably slow. Also, the management apparently over-sold the club level rooms because while we were there for 4 nights, every night we had to wait for an available seat for canapes and drinks (however the staff promptly ended all service at 7:30pm, regardless of how long guests had to wait to be served). Both at breakfast in the main area, and the club lounge for evening canapes and drinks, the food stations were frequently empty and required a long wait to be replenished. For a 5-star hotel, these inconveniences and lack of guest service is unacceptable. We were disappointed and won't return.

the hotel itself was nice,- a grand hotel with international standard- hotel rooms in proper size, no more squeezing in limited space- full suite of hotel service available, from bell boy at entrance to concierge service- staff all speak good english- decent choice on breakfastthe only thing with this hotel is the neighborhood, it's an embassy area so you expect it's a very quiet districts. there are no shops, retail, restaurants nearby, a 10+ minutes walk is unavoidable.there's a metro exit near the hotel (exit 14), but it's off from most metro gates, it takes you 10+mins walk at underground to reach the exit14, another 5 more mins if you're travelling back on Ginza or Choyoda line. Sadly JR line didnt pass thru this area.So I would say travel is a bit inconvenient for this hotel, a pity.

Fantastic hotel with great facilities and helpful staff. Really great central location with easy access to all the areas I needed to get to.Lovely food for breakfast and dinner.Simple to get a taxi from the front of the hotel.

I stayed in this hotel for a 2-week business trip last November 2017. The hotel is centrally located with easy access to Tameike-Sanno Station (Ginza line). There are a good number of restaurants nearby albeit expensive. I never took breakfast in the hotel restaurant on the 2nd floor (i.e., Cascade Cafe) as there is always a long queue. My package came with no free breakfast but there's a Doutor Coffee Shop nearby that I go to to grab a quick bite on the way to the Tameike-Sanno Station. For shopping, Tokyo Midtown is a 10-15 minute walk. Otherwise, it is pretty easy to take the subway to any of the known shopping areas in Ginza, Shibuya, Asakusa, etc.During my stay, the room was kept clean daily. They provide 2 pairs of pajamas inside the drawers which can be useful if you forgot to bring your own or need extra cover in cold weather. They also provide a traditional bamboo foot massage barn which you will find inside the closet. The in-room personal toiletries and amenities are generous.Hotel staff were great and most of them could speak English. Overall, it was a pleasant stay for me (and my son who joined me in the last weekend).

A great hotel in a central location.Excellent service staff who are always ready to help.The rooms in the executive floors are new and are very modern. Be aware if you have allergies to new carpet or dust from the fluff for new carpets you may have an allergic reaction (as I did). Nonetheless this will pass and we had a great time.Note though that when the hotel is busy the lifts are very slow so bring your patience along with you.The executive floor is excellent for cocktails, breakfast and light meals and the staff there are first class.A number of Michelin quality restaurants to chose from. Highly recommended!

I've stayed in many hotels in Tokyo- as I am often here for work & pleasure. Overall, this hotel has a nice atmosphere but quite unremarkable otherwise.Maybe I was there during a busy time, but the service was not great, compared to other places in Japan. They messed up the key card, had long queues for check-in, so everything took forever. Plus the elevator was always full and I would often have to wait and miss couple of the them before one was empty enough to get on.Location is pretty good with lots of nearby restaurants and shops, but the closest metro stop takes a good 10-15 minute walk (mostly underground), so that can be a bit frustrating.

As I am a member of InterContinental Ambassador, I booked this hotel and they guaranteed room upgrade and late check-out. The hotel is very close to two different subway stations where you can take the train of different lines. There is a small supermarket nearby and a shopping mall within 5 minutes’ walk. I was upgraded to a corner suite which is really big. However, the room is a bit dated and perhaps the housekeeping did not clean the room thoroughly. There were some grease stains left behind. The amenities were the usual InterContinental standard, TWG tea, Nespresso capsules and Thann spa products. The breakfast was sumptuous. There was a wide spread of food, western and Japanese. It’s good to enjoy a wonderful breakfast before sightseeing or shopping.

Great place to stay, very friendly staff and good service, it is only couple of streets away from the centre of town, also couple of Metro stations from Tokyo Station, easy access to everything and away from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo streets...

The hotel facilities and service deserves the 5-star ratings. Very warm and friendly staff who goes the extra mile, and clean and comfortable room to relax after a full day exploring Tokyo. May not be located in key touristy locations such as Shinjuku or Harajuku, but the Tokyo metro service is efficient and there is a station located near the hotel to get you anywhere easily. Was not aware till later that the hotel host a Michelin star coffee house. Highly recommended hotel to stay in Tokyo!

I've had high expectation walking into this hotel, as another reviewer put it, "It's an Inter and you know it's good." Unfortunately, this property greatly disappoints.Maybe because it was the holidays, the lobby was crowded like a zoo and we waited a little while before someone tended to us (although our luggage was taken by the bell captain before we walked in the door). The check-in itself was smooth, but we didn't get a room upgrade (which can be hit or miss at Intercontinental for Plat/Spire members) or the higher floor I requested two months ago or even the room type I booked (booked queen received twin).The room itself was the worst part. If you stick to downtown Tokyo standards, you can call it spacious. However, it just needs a renovation badly. The beds were less comfortable than the ones at a Crowne Plaza. There were only 4 power outlets in the room, and only two were functional. The Internet was slow (3 Mbps) and unencrypted. The A/C was too cold at 22c and too warm at 23c. If the room was on a higher floor, the view could've been good. But at 15F, all we got was the tip of Tokyo Tower and Roppongi Hills. Also, the lower-floors were only serviced by 2 elevators and we had to wait 2-3 minutes every time.The bathroom was even worse. The shower temperature was unstable, the bidet only has 3 buttons and uses a dial to control the water flow. The sink has a crack and the metal parts were rusty.The hotel was unable to offer us a different room as it was fully booked.Service was speedy and professional. The concierge was able to help us secure a last minute reservation at Bills (which itself was a disappointment) despite the restaurant told us they had no availability.Location-wise, if you are travelling for work, then it's very centrally located. However, if you use public transit, the nearest subway stations (Tameike-sanno, Akasaka or Roppongi-itchome) were 10 minutes away.I would not be wasting 56,000 JPY or 60,000 points at this hotel in the future and neither should anyone who's not travelling for work in Tokyo. Maybe I should try the Strings next time.

Very good service with spacious rooms. Variety in breakfast. The hotel is in the idle of the commercial enter, hence all the offices are at a walking distance. Very convenient for the business people.

We checked in for 4 nights at Ana Intercontinental Hotel. You can unload ur luggages at Hotel Entrance Level 1 and the Conceirge will help u bring to your room after u check in. Parking is available conveniently at B2 & B3. U can take the elevator to Level 2 which is the Reception.If you are Hotel Guests, parking costs only 3,500 Yen for 4 nights Although the basic room size is not big (about 28 sqm), every tiny details are well thought of. Electrical points can be found at bed side table for charging your appliances and night light is available too. Shower facility is of Top Notch Quality.The best of all is you can order complimentary breakfast for in-house dining.This Hotel has few of Tokyo’s Top Restaurants. UKAI at Level 3 caters to Japanese Fine Dining. The renowned Teppanyaki Akasaka Restaurant, on Level 37, offers Excellent View of the City and serves A5 Kobe Beef. However, the bill is also very attractive.

This is a large, major hotels in Tokyo, and you will often see flight attendants and pilots from many airlines check in and out here. Service is very good, but this is Tokyo, you can get the same outstanding service at other hotels as well.Room size can be considered large for Tokyo. Room is a bit outdated. I have stayed at InterContinental Tokyo Bay and InterContinental The Strings, they have newer rooms and less expensive.Central location, easy access to Ginza and Tokyo Station. Just 1 minute walk to subway entrance and 10 minutes to take subway to Tokyo station. Taxi to Tokyo station is just about $15, and taxi is always available outside hotel lobby. Also near Roppongi, Shinjuku, Tokyo Tower.Since this is a large hotel, there are many restaurants inside. Food is actually very good. However it is quite expensive. Dinner buffet is ~ $65. A single small piece of premium dimsum costs about $10 a piece. Many restaurants and many food options to choose from.One negative point about food is Vietnamese Pho on their in room service menu (which many people don't really care about.) I have been eating a lot of Vietnamese Pho and I ordered this out of curiosity. The way they made Vietnamese Pho was totally wrong. I could not even recognize it as Pho. If they don't know how to make it, they should not even offer it on their menu. For those who have never eaten Pho before, they would have a wrong impression of how the famous Pho is.Gym is ok with adequate equipment and open 24 hours.I would stay here again, because of their good food and location.

very well located, this is a busy place. Unfortunately, this makes the breakfast experience one of queuing on daily basis. Great food quality and good service though.rooms are spacious and well appointed, quite rare in tokyo. Lobby elevators are a little confusing at first, as some of them need a change of elevator to reach the upper floors.would not be my first choice for my next trip to tokyo, but wouldnt mind returning either.

My abiding memory of this stay (5 nights) was always having to queue for breakfast each morning, which was strange for an Intercontinental - am sure the staff can sort out how to better manage this!? Overall a really comfortable hotel - a good sized room, well equipped with coffee maker etc and quiet with a modern clean bathroom. Convenient location for various metro stations - not too much within walking distance of the hotel though.

Tried this hotel for the 1st time in Tokyo and my expectations were simple exceeded.Was travelling across Japan and for any traveler, you know how expensive it can get to leave your luggage at “left luggage/baggage” facilities. Knowing that it would be a few daya before my check in, i called the hotel to see if its possible to peave my luggage and claim it on the day i’ll check in. No questions asked, they were happy to do it for free.Upon check-in, there was a minor issue as the hotel was fully booked. Having waited for some time, i was instantly upgraded to the Junior Suite! What a treat!!! The room had an amazing view of tokyo. A separate bedroom and living room cum office area. They had several great restaurants including a 2 michelin star resto (too bad we didn’t get to go and try it). We did try the bar at the 36th floor, that again gave us an amazing view of tokyo at night time. We also tried the steakhouse for some wagyu!!! It was amazing!!!Will definitely stay at this hotel again. Oh did i mention that it has access to the metro just a few meters outside the hotel. Great for those who take the train to get around.

So the room was really nice and well appointed. Great service. Impressive lobby with a champagne bar. Room was very affordable but the restaurants very expensive. Convenient since its a stop on the Narita Bus line. Nice location close to Roppongi and the subway.

It is a good hotel in a very convenient location next to a subway station. Staff are very nice and helpful, but some rooms need refurbishing; I stayed in two different rooms and one of them needed updating.Breakfast is really good

An excellent accommodation choice in Tokyo. Located in an international district with plenty of very good restaurants that are used to foreigners. Metro station just a few meters away. Withing walking distance from Roppongi Hills and all its exciting sights.We were on the 33rd floor and the view was amazing. Impeccable service. Special mention for the concierge team who helped us with restaurant recommendations and bookings.

Stayed there for 3 nights in Nov 2017. Hotel is located in the middle of Akasaka and walkable to both Roppongi and Akasaka mitsuke, which is very convenient for dining and drinking, yet hotel area isn’t too busy, not too touristic so we felt like living here in a good way. Room is god size for hotels in Japan, well cleaned and comfortable. I had to contact hotel prior to arrival and prompt response was just amazing, felt a Japanese kind of service already before arriving.

Spacious, clean rooms with plenty of amenities in the hotel. All staff were professional and polite. The restaurant on the upper floor was especially good but that's expected for the price. Pretty good location, but you can always catch the train (pretty close walk) or a taxi. Very satisfactory experience.

Very good for all purposes. I was in Tokyo for the weekend followed by a couple of business days and the hotel accommodated nicely both.The only remark i would make is that due to the size of the hotel and the number of guests that are served daily, service can seem a bit cold and lacking the personal touch.

We stayed for 2 nights. Family of 4, 2 adults and 2 kids (ages 6 and 4). Stayed in room 1502 with a king size bed. We asked housekeeping to bring us 4 extra blankets and sheets, so made beds for kids on the floor. Worked very good. The room is very small based on American standards, but we weren’t there too much during the day, just to sleep at night :) the room did smell a bit with smoke, also there wasn’t a lot of lighting, wasn’t too bright. The mattress was very comfortable to our liking. We got nice terry bathrobes and good quality slippers. Amenities in the bathroom were amazing, top notch. We left the cards not to change our towels so we could reuse them, but the towels were exchanged any way. Had breakfast and dinner at Cascade restaurant. Outstanding food and amazing presentation. Cudos to F&B director and the chef. Restaurant was very busy for breakfast, but the buffet line never ran out of food and there was always enough staff to attend to our needs. Don’t know about buffet price as it was part of our group package. Couldn’t find any tea bags though on the buffet, looked like there were small individual tea carafes on the station with tea bags in them. But no variety/choices of tea where you can choose by yourself Had lunch at The Mixx on the 36th floor. One word: WOW. Staff is amazing, food delicious, presentation outstanding, view breathtaking Meeting rooms are nice, a bit hot though. Excellent line and dishes set up for coffee breaks. Small cups though, again, based on American standard. Check in was smooth, Russell from Australia was very courteous and acknowledged our IHG membership status. The hotel lobby smelt very nice :) My husband liked the cigar shop, said it had great variety and quality, spent a few hundred $$ there :)We were a bit disappointed about DaVinci main bar. Interior was amazing, so we walked in for a drink, turned out it was closed to public. I guess it was booked for a private event. That was a bit disappointing. We went to the bar right across (can’t remember the name, it’s overlooking the lobby), but it just wasn’t the same

Good location, very clean guestroom, many eating place in the hotel and surrounding area. The price is a little high based on room size, but it ok'd to use this hotel.The service is much better than other hotel in Tokyo area. I would use this hotel again.

The ANA is one of those big, luxurious hotels, with a grand foyer, polished service and more space than they could ever fill. The foyer is full of Americans as it is close to the embassy. One gets the feeling it is the choice of business people traveling to Japan. The price for a glass of wine or coffee in the foyer reflects this. The room is typical of a grand hotel that is starting to show its age. It has all the luxury appointments, is full of expensive marble etc but shows the wear signs from years of service. Regardless, its a wonderful room and generous in size for japan. In the court yard next to the hotel, there are numerous affordable cafes and restaurants. This was our last hotel at the end of a two week trip through Japan. Finding a burrito bar in the foyer was a welcome dietary change from noodles and rice. We stayed in Shinjuku when we first landed in Tokyo. I personally found more to see and do around Shinjuku than I found around the ANA. The ANA was our return hotel, coming back from Kyoto to Tokyo, prior to flying out. It's a perfect choice for this purpose as its easy to access by train and has an excellent shuttle bus service to the airport. In short, its a WOW hotel with comfortable rooms, well trained staff and good access to bus and train connections. Plus, you can get some familiar food, if you are craving the taste of home.

What a fantastic hotel. Upon arrival, we decided to upgrade to a Club Room, which turned out to be a great decision. The rooms are stylishly renovated with beautiful new bathrooms, and our room had a gorgeous view of Tokyo Tower.The Club is fantastic. Wonderfully attentive staff, nice ambiance and great selection of food. We much preferred the a la carte breakfast in the Club to the main buffet. Great afternoon tea selection, plus drinks and substantial canapes from 5-7pm.I was worried that the location was a little far away from things, however the subway entrance is just outside the hotel, with access to the line which services Shibuya, Shinjuku, Harajuku and Ginza, so super easy to get around.

Not really near to shopping malls. Tokyo Midtown is about 15 min walk and that is an upmarket mall. There are many eateries near the hotel. On level 7 and the room is small. Hotel provided bottled water & humidifier when requested.

Had a great two night stay on the club floor of this hotel. Was a great location for business meetings. The staff on club floor were extremely helpful and arranged dinners and spa appointments without a complaint. I would stay there again in a second. And club floor is totally worth it.

I stayed here in 2015 when I was there for business, the rooms were good size for Japan and the hotel was pretty awesome. The only thing i was a little surprised was with, being a hotel guest, they still charged a $40-$50 to use their pool :) I was not too happy with that. Overall a decent trip and would come back someday for sure.
user_name:
atulmaha78
New York City, New York

review_body: We stayed at the ANA whilst enjoying 4 nights in Tokyo.Luckily on arrival we were upgraded to a Junior Suite which was annoyingly only for one night so chose to pay extra for the remaining 3. I found the room to be a good size although I was surprised that the hotel was expecting my 2 year old to share our bed whilst providing a cot for my 6 week old, upon chasing we were provided with a second cot as this was still adequate size for a 2 year old.I found the sleep comfort of the rooms and facilities to be good, the staff helpful and welcoming and the options for dining to be decent. The pool was disappointing as this was seasonal though.Where the hotel stood out was the club lounge and facilities which were excellent, the breakfast, all day dining an high tea were all amazing as was the 2 hour complimentary cocktails etc.There is a charge for this and if I was to book again would consider whether booking a club room was the best value.

Made a res and paid in full for premium room for three with breakfast. Was given a single bed and told a roll-away or another bed would cost extra (three guests were clearly stated on res). Also told breakfast for three would cost extra (breakfast for one was provided). Manager straightened it out and was cool but not a great welcome. Hotel needs a facelift, but prices are way cheaper than Hyatt (which is 5 star all the way) so maybe you get what you pay for.

Everything was perfect about this hotel – service, dining, rooms, location. With easy transfers from the airport, welcoming attitude, well-appointed rooms, sumptuous buffet, Cascade café, it is a great choice if you’re on a business trip in Tokyo.

A very convenient hotel to 3 major metro lines. We received a nice upgrade and gift due to my husband's birthday. They were also able to let us arrive 2 days early due to a typhoon that disrupted our plans, although the first night was quite expensive. Although they gave us a club floor room, no access to club, which we understood but that would have made the birthday even better! The very best, most diverse (so many cultures represented) breakfast buffet, but expensive! In fact, all the restaurants in the hotel are over the top. The Chinese restaurant had tiny portions for top dollar. Luckily, since we were stuck there in bad weather, we discovered all the great restaurants in the adjacent mall and on different levels. Lots of food shopping there too for takeout. Very attentive staff. One small issue is there is almost no lobby seating so hard to meet someone. Excellent choice if you need to use IHG Points and perks.

@___welcome! We are experienced travellers and our goal is to provide an exciting feedback based upon our expected (what we were looking for) experience: short stay, romantic stay or business stay. The review normally consists of a quick summary (energy.eto_Review), a more detailed infographics, including our credentials, (energy.eto_Info) and some great additional pictures about the locations (@energy.eto on Instagram).@___energy.eto Review. Our expected experience was: having a business stay. This hotel is quite famous hotel in Tokyo but not really sure for what...room is honestly average for similar categories and cleanliness is not the best of Japan. The ground floor smoking room is embarrassing for such a huge hotel but if you have a good budget you can enjoy the terrific view of the Mixx Bar & Lounge. You must have a sweet or breakfast at the Pierre Gagnare Pains at Gateaux. IHG Platinum guests might experience some problems getting the right benefits (e.g. room upgrade) or a warm welcome.Have a look at some picture and you will understand more!What was awesome: the Mixx Bar & LoungeWhat will probably be awesome in the future: service@___energy.eto_Info. For a couple of exciting pictures and our infographics please visit us on Instagram @energy.eto@___thank you! Please help us marking this review as useful here and following us on Instagram

I have loved everything about this hotel. The staff go out their way to make you looked after at all times, the rooms are pristine and restaurants on site have a great selection of freshest meals. The manager is personally overlooking to make sure every guest gets a memorable experience and is always there eager to assist and excels any expectations. The personnel are incredibly polite and resourceful - they gave us the best recommendations. We have nothing but praise and really felt welcome and at home during our stay.

I guess I didn't enjoy this hotel as much as I thought I would. This was due to the truly outstanding hotels I'd stayed at earlier in my Japanese holiday, in small towns like Kanazawa and Takayama: these were really personal experiences, full of local flavour and Japanese politeness. In contrast, the Inter-Continental in Tokyo is a big city business hotel with a cold impersonal feel. The staff were rushing and stressed and sometimes the advice we received as tourists was inaccurate (but, thankfully, was corrected the next day by a different, more informed, staff member). If you are in Tokyo on business, this may be the hotel for you. However, if you are a tourist, I recommend you look elsewhere.The breakfast offered a wide variety of food suitable for all guests: my only complaint is that the pinapple pieces had the skin and core attached, and the halved kiwifruit had the skin left on - making it very difficult to eat these items easily.

Adjacent to a shopping Mall and the Underground this is a comfortable hotel. Don’t order anything in the hotel: we ordered a pot of coffee and a small Diet Coke and it cost £20. Eat and drink in the outside establishments for a much more reasonable budget. Breakfast was good but don’t be late, the last serving time is the time they start to clear away the buffet. Hotel room was of a good size for a Tokyo and well fitted out.

I stayed for two nights and enjoyed it. The rooms are spacious with nice amenities. Location is close to almost everything that you want to do. A lot of good restaurants in hotel and around the hotel. Sunshine alpha mall is about 10-15 min away by taxi. I recommend this hotel. MB

Very good IHG hotel in downtown Tokyo. Just a taxi ride from the train station. Good location, bakery, shop. Clean. Walking distance to Tokyo Tower (less than 1 mile). Close to business district. Would recommend and stay here again.

This hotel is nice. Rooms are a good size, especially for Japan. Service was good, but not exceptional. I have no complaints about the service, but some other places we stayed at in Japan went above and beyond what was expected, though they did not here.The location is great for being a tourist. The metro tunnel entrance was just outside the hotel.

This is an excellent hotel near to the city centre. The rooms are very comfortable and hotel facilities excellent. The is a good gym and outdoor pool. The bar on the top floor is very classy. Breakfast was outstanding. WiFi was good and free. the central bar area was also very high class.

I stayed here for one night on a free IHG annual award night. Considering the room was free, I don't have a lot of room to complain. And I don't really feel the need to--this hotel overall was pretty solid. The location is an a decent area. Very safe at all hours of the night. Plenty of nearby food that's open late and walking distance to Tokyo Tower, which I thought was fantastic. The service both at the front door and the front desk was very good and much appreciated. They spoke great English and were very helpful. The lobby here is beautiful, but the rooms could use a refresh. Our room felt very old, but the bathroom was great, with a mirror that doesn't fog up when you take a shower, and really strong water pressure in the shower. While the room was old, it was very clean. I would probably stay here again. No issues. The bar on the top floor has great views and good drinks, make sure to check that out if you stay here.

I had a flight in at night. Originally was going to wait until morning to meet up with the shbjj team. My girlfriend was so worried that I didn't have a place to stay at night. She wanted me to rest up well and be safe. So she booked the intercontinental hotel for me. Love has no limits. Its so wonderful, I just wished she was with me touring the city along my side. Luckily I brought our sweetheart Minnie bear. Not sure if they had shuttle so I took a taxi for 50usd it was only 15 minutes away but still pricey considering its night time travled there September 2015 for a IBJJF tournament at the budokan. the next day I took the metro (takes a bit of getting used to) but i was able to meet the rest of my team there in Shim bamba.

The rooms here are large for Tokyo standards, with all the usual in-room amenities you can expect from large chain hotels. I stay here are it's close to our office and it's also pretty close to the shopping areas of Shibuya (~10 mins by taxi) or direct by the busy Ginza line.The room wifi was not particularly fast, and no complimentary bottles of water was provided in the room. The room itself was a little dated, furniture is a little worn, tiles in the bathroom are yellowed from age etc.I didn't sleep very well, as the provided pillows are extremely soft - my head would sink in the middle of the pillow and the sides of the pillow would press against the sides of my face. I resorted to folding the pillows in half in order to get sufficient elevation and to keep the pillows from suffocating me when I turned onto my side. All 4 pillows provided were the same (usually hotels provide at least another type of hardness).Apart from that, nothing else to complain about. I must say I much prefer the Japanese brand hotels when in Japan as they're usually more modern and new, albeit a lot smaller.

This was a fantastic hotel, our room was very large, the bathroom first rate, the gym and sauna were fantastic as well. Someone wrote that it was dated, I can't believe that, it is very modern. The breakfast room was beautiful, and the choices outstanding. Would absolutely stay here again. It was very close to a major subway stop, and very easy to walk to, took about 10 minutes. Tokyo subways are huge, so you walk a lot, but very nice and very easy to use. It is expensive, but that is also Tokyo.

I've stayed twice at the ANA recently, I've experienced both the refurbished and non refurbished sides of the hotel. The non-refurbed rooms are tired, but however, well appointed and everything you may need. The refurbed rooms are exactly what you'd expect from the Tokyo Intercon. Happy hour up at the Mixx bar must also be done for great sunset views out over the city.Staff are friendly and helpful, altho service at breakfast can be a bit hit and miss due to language barriers.

My first impression wasn’t that great, but the hotel worked hard to improve my opinion. This was a business trip, so my booking was handled through corporate and I was reserved in a standard king room. Unfortunately, I wasn’t able to upgrade my room prior to arrival because the online system could never find my reservation - long story that I won’t go into here. Upon arrival, there were no upgrades available.After visits to the Peninsula and Aman properties in July for vacation, I certainly wasn’t expecting 5 star accommodations, but the standard king was subpar. The next morning, I checked with the desk manager Russell and he was able to find a king room on the executive level for us. This was a totally different experience - very comfortable, fresh, modern, well appointed, with a fantastic view of the city. The shower was well designed with intuitive operations for the rain and handheld shower faucets (ladies, you know how frustrating it is to accidentally turn on the rain shower). Shout outs to Russell for securing this room for me and checking on my wellbeing throughout my stay - he went above and beyond, ensuring a pleasant stay.The executive lounge is equally pleasant with wonderful meal and drink services throughout the day. The space was well designed and comfortable. Truly a space that you could relax in. The staff lounge staff was exceptionally helpful, pleasant, and genuinely caring.I visited the fitness room each morning and enjoyed the clean, cool space. It was never too crowded, but could use 1 more elliptical and 1 less treadmill. The Mixx bar was a great place to enjoy a cocktail and light meal. A shout out to Kor (I hope I got the name right) for excellent service each time I visited.Overall, enjoyed my stay and here are a few things for the hotel to consider as they evolve the offerings forward -- A welcome email. I didn’t discover the airport shuttle until check-out, too late for me to us. I couldn’t upgrade till I got to the front desk, too late, nothing available.- Update the standard rooms, if nothing more than fresh carpetingand drapes, and a shower door.- fragrance of the enviro and bath product are too heavily cologned. Choose a less polarizing scent.- add and elliptical to the fitness room and light snacks (ie, raisins, fruits, etc.).- the elevators are super slow, not sure if anything can be done about that.
user_name:
Advourner
New York City, New York

review_body: My room had a nice view and attractive amenities. The lobby is gorgeous and the staff was excellent. Each employee appeared dedicated to making a guest's stay more pleasant. A concierge helped me make sightseeing plans and offered suggestions for using the Tokyo subway, which I found convenient and easy to navigate. Although the benefits of being a Platinum member of IHG are minimal, what appeared to be a room upgrade and a free drink at any bar in the hotel were nice benefits. The hotel is the last stop on the limousine bus route to Narita, which is nice benefit when departing but not so great if arriving from Narita.

If you are looking for a very good luxury hotel in Tokyo the the Inter is one of the best. The staff are all extremely helpful (as if Japanese wouldn't be), and everyone that I spoke to speaks English very well. The rooms are fair size for Tokyo but very well appointed. The Club Lounge is always great with afternoon canapes that are special. Great location and a damned good restaurant.

We spent five nights here and found the hotel very comfortable. Our room was clean and a reasonable size. The breakfast buffet was good and although we had to queue for a few minutes, we were quickly seated. On a couple of occasions, we didn't want a full breakfast and the patisserie had a brilliant selection of croissants and pastries, plus good coffee.

We stayed here for 3 nights. Comfortable room, well equiped, clean gym (no extra charges unlike most other hotels in Japan). However, queues for lifts and breakfast an often be quite long which can be frustrating. Also, bathroom looks dated. Hotel is in a lovely area, with leafy trees and plenty of space for jogging. If you want a hotel in a quieter, not a bustling area, this is the hotel for you.

I stayed here in June and the hotel in general was good, maybe a little tired, however room size was good, in room amenities good, gym very good, and staff overall friendly, however not the Concierges! Be it in the early morning or afternoon, the ladies always asked for our room number first, which I thought a little strange, and after getting my room number was never spoken to with my name, what’s the point to ask for my room number then? They seemed to be either nosy or a little too convinced of their abilities, when asked for simple directions I never got a clear answer to my questions, and was told to take a taxi to most of my destinations. When asked to make a reservation at a restaurant they didn't come across to happy to have to call up the restaurant, and spent ages on the phone to tell me afterwards that the restaurant did not accept reservations because they were very busy, and just go there and try our luck, most of the restaurants I went to were not as bad as the Concierges told me they would be and we never had to wait more than 5 minutes to get a table. Eventually we just stopped going to the Concierges for assistance and made our own way across town. I think it would be wise for the management to provide all of the Concierges a little training in how to treat their customers, if Concierge's would be more professional I would probably stay here again, because of the great location and overall nice hotel.

Despite five star accommodations, the hotel is not up to modern standard as visitors from around the world with tattoos are completely discriminated against. I was ordered to put on a full body suit in order to be able to lie by the pool because of my tattoos on my upper body. Being a well travel individual, I would expect this in smaller Japanese hotels but not something like the Intercontinental Hotel chain. When I complained to the manager, all he could say was sorry and that they cannot do anything about this hotel policy. Once again, I feel completely mislead by the international appearance of Tokyo. Japanese hotels and bath houses need to update their policies on foreigners with tattoos if they want to welcome 20 million tourists for the 2020 Tokyo Olympics. EXTREMELY DISAPPOINTED!

As a bed for the night this was fine. But frankly I found the hotel dated. Old rooms. Old fashioned restaurants (a cigar and whiskey bar?). Felt like I was in South Dakota. Breakfast was underwhelming in choice and imagination. There are many better in Tokyo

ANA Intercontinental Tokyo offers a very modern property that is located a short walk to many government buildings, restaurants and even a few tourist sites. We stayed here while on holiday and really loved it. The breakfast buffet is incredible and at night there are several restaurants on site to choose from. You're also close to the Ginza Line and several sites such as the Imperial Palace, Tokyo Tower and Zojo-Ji Temple.

First impressions last so when the Receptionist recognised that I was staying in the hotel for a big birthday treat and gave me a free drinks voucher then I knew it was going to be great. Deluxe room big with Nespresso machine, big tv and even remote control curtains from your bedside. Bathroom a little pokey. Go for high floor (31st) for great night time views of city. Buffet breakfast was included in my rate - big selection of European and Japanese food, however they need to sort out table allocation as a couple of mornings there was a queue of at least 20+people waiting for a table. Westin Doha still my number one luxury hotel but the Intercontinental Tokyo is a close second.

A good place to stay- friendly attentive staff - Helpful & understanding Chef who made Vegetarian options for me each day of my stay. However was disappointed as an IHG Gold Elite at checkout that they charged much higher than quoted rates. Really in Bad Taste and Business practise.

Wow! That is the best way to start this review.I stated at the Ana Intercontinental Hotel during a recent visit to Tokyo.Although the hotel had standard-sized rooms, they made up for the size in the elegance of the common area and the attentiveness of the staff.My room had a wonderful view of Roppongi Street and the bed was quite comfortable.I giggled at the high-end commode which looked more like a robot with the electro automatic bidet that not only kept me clean but sprayed my bum with warm water.Breakfast was a divine mix of Asian and classic English flavors, and dinner options were never-ending.I will definitely stay at this hotel during my next trip to Tokyo.

Had a great stay last month. 6 nights. Hotel was a great location to explore Tokyo. It isn't that close to any particular spot but it is a great location to branch out to other sites. Love the pool. Views from the bar on the 36th floor were great. The Floor Manager, Julian, deserves a positive mention.

This stay was my 4th or 5th at the ANA. The hotel is reliable and reasonably priced for being in Akasaka; thus my return visits. The hotel is clean, well run and a hub of activity. We stayed in room 2011 which was a nice room on the quiet end of the hallway and on the back side of the hotel avoiding late night highway noises. The staff is very responsive. I had an issue with a rattling sound in the air conditioner, called the front desk and the clerk indicated he would send someone right up. (In any other hotel, that would mean a repeat call after several hours). Someone came right up and fixed the issue immediately!! The breakfast buffet (according to my guest) was the best during our stay in multiple hotels in Japan. It is large, varied and has convenient hours. My biggest issue was the 4000 Yen per person charge for using the pool. I think that is outrageous - approximately $75 for a couple to use the pool! I complained about this at the front desk. In all fairness, Mr. Nakajima at the front desk listened patiently and then offered us free pool passes for the duration of our stay. So, while I do thank him for his consideration to us, the pool fee is still too high in my opinion. So despite my issues with the hotel, I am still giving the highest rating because overall, the ANA Intercontinental always delivers quality service.

Only stayed for one night & then took off early the next morning so cannot comment on the location. However the hotel was fabulous and very comfortable. It oozes luxury when you first walk in. We were upgraded to a deluxe room which was very spacious, particularly by Japanese standards. My only minor gripe is that we arrived quite late and decided to go up to the bar for a quiet drink and bite to eat as it was the only place open in the hotel (11pm). The bar turned out to be quite small for such a big hotel, playing loud music and food options were very limited. We ended up going back to the room and ordering room service. They made up for it with an excellent buffet breakfast the next morning though.

What else can you ask for a 5 star hotel? However I just notice that breakfast is always the same (i've stay for almost 4nights) so better not to taste all food at once .. Room is spaceous and had a very fast wifi connection...

The location of the hotel is excellent, close to many restaurant, points of interests, etc. And yes, the hotel itself is very elegant and also modern in the lobby area, the breakfast is very good, however it is a little bit strange that they sit guest in normal Lobby area seats, like on sofas, sofachairs, etc. but I guess this is better than to wait until some seats get available in the "normal" restaurant / breakfast area. The only reason why the hotel is getting a not so good rating is because of what they can consider a "Standard" room. The beds (to twins, not a re quested King) are very low, short and more like a Futon style with very uncomfortable mattresses (and not to talk about the pillows). The connecting door, which I never like, was that thin that I could do everything my neighbors did and I guess vice versa. But the last thing which really hit me was the bath room, wow that was in the 70ies state of the art, but in todays world for a "Luxury" hotel not acceptable.

Stayed for 7 days last August while on business. Within walking distance to many good restaurants in Roppongi and within jogging distance to Edo Castle (~9 km jog to get to the castle, circle the outer moat and come back). The Tameike-Sanno metro entrance is right where you emerge from the hotel so if it rains and you don't have an umbrella you can stay relatively dry and still get to wherever you need to go via the labyrinth that is the Tokyo metro system. The breakfast buffet was overpriced and failed to impress. I did not repeat as I much prefer this low key joint nearby called Nakau where all the Japanese salarymen fuel up for the day. The room was on the small side but comfy with the obligatory futuristic Japanese toilet. Umbrella was provided which was thoughtful. Overall the hotel was great value but my colleague stayed at the Imperial where the service was supposedly superior for about the same rate.

Only a few tweaks are needed to make this hotel one of the best IHG properties.The main niggle about our Premier room was the fact that there is a window between bathroom and bedroom. Even with a Venetian blind, if one uses the bathroom in the middle of the night, the light awakens ones partner and if that is not enough the auto flush will!The other niggle relates to the pool. Whilst we accept that property costs in Tokyo demand a fee for use of the pool, the Yen 4000 per person per visit was somewhat high when the poolside loungers had no padding or mattress.Other than the above, the hotel is clean and very well maintained ; the decor is minimalist which accords to zen principles.Staff were very polite and helpful, answering every query thrown at them.The Cascade cafe is subject of separate review.

We had a nice week staying at this hotel. We love the customer service and clean spacious room. We also enjoyed daily breakfast buffet. Station is very close to major sites in Tokyo and next to subway station. Highly recommend this hotel.

The Ana InterContinental Tokyo is great, and the expansive lobby is beautiful if you're lucky you may even catch newlyweds coming out of a wedding ceremony. The rooms are good, and I highly recommend trying to get one with a view of the Tokyo tower trust me it's beautiful at night. The beds are comfy; pillows are plush, and duvets are perfect for a guaranteed good sleep. The club lounge is the largest I have ever seen. The breakfast the best I try my best never to miss it. The club lounge staff are very welcoming and can make anything happen. They've made reservations, last minute reservation changes, organized a tour of Tokyo, and much more to make my stay memorable. The hotel is about a 15-minute walk or quick taxi ride to Roppongi and Roppongi Hills.
user_name:
BigRo77
New York City, New York

review_body: Everything in this hotel was basically fine, but not up to the standards I've found at other Intercontinentals (mostly in Europe). The exception was the breakfast buffet, which was comprehensive, excellent, and the first hotel breakfast I've found in Tokyo that I really looked forward to.The rest of the stay was just kind of... odd. Check-in and check-out were slow, for not really any clear reason. Before checking out I bought a bento box at a shop nearby and was surprised to find nowhere in the lobby to sit and eat it (ended up finding a little bench next to the elevators where nobody could see me). After checking out, and against my better judgment, I went to the top-floor bar to pass time before my airport bus, and despite the place being completely empty it took 15 minutes to get a simple cocktail.The room was unmemorable - decent amount of space for Japan, small desk, uncomfortable couch. The swimming pool is outdoors and closed in the winter. Didn't check out the other fitness facilities.At other hotels in Tokyo in the same price range, the service is absolutely delightful, down to the smallest detail (eg the moment I start walking across the lobby, the doorman steps into the sensor of the automatic door so it's already open when I get there and I don't suffer the indignity of breaking my stride to wait for the door to open). I didn't feel that attention to detail here.

Room was fine after I changed to one with a proper shower. Bed and linen very comfortable. Restaurants were good, especially the sushi. Gym OK. Pool was also good, but it was irritating that you had to pay for the access even as a guest of the hotel. Staff was very helpful, kind and serviceminded, top score!

First time to Japan we stayed here at Ana Intercontinental for several nights.Comfortable and clean rooms with all the amenities we'd expect and appreciate. Very friendly staff, especially the concierge that helped us organise restaurant reservations. We weren't able to rest during the day due to the renovations above our room but it wasnt a huge issue as we planned days out till late. Unfortunately, the hotel location was the only issue we had, its far from any of the train stations and shops so we needed to taxi or allow for abit of walking since there wasnt a JR station in walking distance we had to navigate our way abit.But all in all, this was a great hotel.

Went to tokyo on 12 august 2017 and stied in ana intercontinental .first of all the location is great because you can take the metro and go any where in tokyo in minits .the hotel is clean and servers is great , the staff is friendly and helpful. highley recommended .

We stayed there for 3 nights on a business trip and had the most comfortable stay imaginable. The location is perfect being right on a Airport Limousine stop and the Subway is not too far either. The rooms are spacious and the service is exemplary. We will surely come back here again and very soon!

Stayed several times for business. Efficient staff if not especially friendly. Could take the bus directly from Narita to the hotel which was great. Main restaurant has huge food selection and is buffet style. Something for everyone. Its food quality was standard hotel, good but not great. Several restaurants. I was not impressed with the steakhouse. Service was excellent but steaks are obviously expensive but it was not a very good steak and I did not finish it. The more traditional japanese restaurants were terrific. I would stay here again.

I had just an one-night stay here and it was an overall good experience. The staff were friendly, polite and very helpful. Room was reasonably sized and very clean. I am not crazy about the location as many have pointed out that it's a bit of walk to nearby train stations. Overall, I had a good experience inline with my expectation of this high-end brand.

The ANA Intercontinental in Tokyo offers fairly spacecious rooms, compared to most of the other hotels. There is a real closet, enough space for suitcases and a comparably comfortable bathroom. Good service including turn-down and a great breakfast offering everything you expect. The only problem is, that the waiting time to get breakfast might be long when having breakfast during rush hour, which is around eight to nine and this needs to be improved. In general everything without any complaints, the only problem was, that there are ongoing renovation works during the day which make it hard to get a little sleep after early flight arrival, this is why I deduct one point from the rating.
