Roppongi ichome station is notorious for its long way from the ticket gate to the closest exit to Intercontinental. If you use Namboku line, I recommend to use Roppongi ichome station to go to the hotel.

This hotel was great. Nice and quiet, with plenty of bars/restaurants on site. The fitness center was decent and not over crowded. The breakfast buffet was wonderful. Easy shuttle to the airport-approximately 70 mins. My only complaint is that the common areas and bars had the smell of cigarette smoke. But this seems to be a common problem in Japan where people think it's still okay to smoke indoors.

Seems to be a different Intercontinental Hotel, surprised to have to call and ask for free bottled waters. A lady hotel staff told me that they want to give fresh one, I got one have a date 19.7.17 on it, not sure its expired or fresh till 2019.Location also quite long walk to nearest subway station.Anyway unlikely to return not because its next to cemetery.

Recently had the pleasure of staying at ANA Intercontinental Tokyo Hotel for four nights on business, directly after about a week of business in Singapore. Perhaps it's my lack of experience with travel in Japan (vs. places like China, Singapore, Australia, and US), or perhaps it was just a case of being in the right place at the right time, but I sincerely, highly, and deeply enjoyed this hotel. The customer service was delightful. The room was clean with lots of nice features and amenities. The bed was comfortable. There was ample space for luggage and for moving around. What's more, I slept extremely soundly, as the room (and likely the area surrounding the hotel) was quiet throughout the night. The construction of the hotel dampened out noise from overhead and from adjacent rooms. It was almost poetic to draw back the blinds and to be greeted by the gentle dawn around 5AM in "The Land of the Rising Sun". Both the breakfast and the room service meals were delicious. The wifi was fast. The area surrounding the hotel made it easy to dine, shop, have coffee, and take the subway (eg. walk up to Roppongi in one direction or down to the Ginza subway line in the opposite direction). A lot of my previous misperceptions and misconceptions of travel in Japan (based on a lonely trip in Yokohama last year) melted away at this hotel. It required (or perhaps allowed) me to reframe the past to have a whole new picture of Japan. Cannot wait to take a long weekend vacation in Tokyo. Will insist on staying at this ANA Intercontinental. It's the best of the best.

Nice room and nicely equipped, but the room did still smell a lot from smoke although it was a non-smoking room.Nice but expensive breakfast.The wifi should be available in all areas of the hotell, not only in the rooms.I also find it strange that it cost extra to get access to the gym.When I spend a lot on a hotel room like this it is strange to have to pay extra for these things, I would have found it natural to have them included.

I have been staying for almost a week and I booked it on the basis of it having a pool for guests. However, there is a 4000 Yen charge even for hotel guests which is frankly irritating. The rooms etc and excellent as is true service and even though I am staying on business the irritant of additional fees means I may book elsewhere on my return. Unfortunate as otherwise it is a great hotel.

Very friendly staff is available at all times. I must say, you cannot stay here and not take in the food at the buffet. There is a great variety of Asian and Western selections. Accommodations were great too! Very clean rooms and spacious bathrooms.

NB - this review is based on a family stay, I'm not sure any of this would apply to a business guest.There are lots of strengths but all come with a qualification:1) Room was relatively big (for Tokyo) but hotel charges cY9000 per night for a rollaway bed.2) Breakfast was truly excellent - almost certainly the best hotel breakfast I've ever seen - but it was only included for two of us in our package and the Y4000 charged per person buys a meal for 3 at a typical tokyo restaurant.3) Location - good eating options, a starbucks and a small supermarket are all useful but was billed as being in the Rappongi area by our travel company, yet it is over a km walk away from the Rappongi sites you'd want to visit (MORI tower etc).. Tameike-sanno subway entrance (4 lines) is less than 5 mins walk away, but then walk to the platform is another 5 mins +. This gives easyish access to most places you wish to visit. NB For the M line it is almost a km through the station. Taxis are a good option cY1300 to get to Ginza.4) Facilities - we were attracted by the pool, and knew the cost, but didn't realise the exorbitant charge is per visit rather than per day (i.e. you pay twice to use it before and after going out. We didn't use it. Similarly children not welcome upstairs to see the view at night. And drinks charges etc are ridiculous. 5) Service - generally very good if a little impersonal. Concierge support was mixed.Overall, would recommend looking at Courtyard Marriott Ginza as a better option for a family stay.Also - 2 key Tokyo recommendations I wish I'd known sooner - use the JR loop line. Buy a 48 /72 hour subway pass - cheaper than Suica.

Only spent one night here but would have happily stayed longer. The room was small but had everything you could wish for.Didn't have breakfast due to early start but they have a shuttle bus to both airports.Great city views and great location with the centre of Tokyo.

The Hotel is very clean and has friendly staffs but the building is very old. The pillows in the room were also a little uncomfortable. Therefore the foods (breakfast, lunch and dinner) are very delicious.

The rooms are super-comfy and large, especially for Tokyo. Don't skip the breakfast which is huge and delicious. But we need to give a special mention to the service, which is always legendary in Japan but especially good at this place. Go for it.

Every time when I had a business trip in Tokyo, I stay at Ana Intercontinental Tokyo. Through those 3 years, this hotel has no change in terms of lobby decoration, services and room conditions. It is value for money if you are looking for a good location, sizeable room and convenience. The travel time from Haneda Airport to Ana Intercontinental Tokyo only takes you 30 min by Taxi and around 5,000 yen.

We have stayed at this hotel many many times due to its location (next to my husband's office) and as most reviewers said, the rooms are dated. But the most concerning thing in this hotel is their pillows. We can never sleep comfortably because none of their pillows support the neck and head for a good sleep. The regular ones are just way too soft and once you lie down they go flat. And the hard ones are filled with tiny balls that hurt. Please please change your pillows!

This is a very big hotel, with an impressive foyer. The staff also have a strong command of English.The best thing about the hotel is the buffet breakfast. It certainly fills you up all day long, and there is an abundance of options. The other benefit is that the Limousine Bus (to either Narita or Haneda) stops directly at the hotel. Further, the housekeeping did a good job of maintaining cleanliness.Our room had a good view (of the Tokyo Tower) but felt small. The bathroom was cramped, especially since there was only a bath/shower (versus having one of each).The hotel is situated in a nice part of Tokyo (a lot of French restaurants), however it is quite far from the action (a positive or a negative depending on your preference). There are two subway stations nearby (but both require a decent walk, although Tammeike-Sanno is mostly undercover). The biggest travesty was the huge price to use the pool. I can't remember the exact number, but my partner and I were pretty disappointed when we found out a simple swim after a 35 degree day would require a substantial additional cost.

We totally enjoyed our stay at the ANA InterContinental. The hotel staff was exceptional and the room was beautiful but I personally do not like the window in the bath looking out into the bedroom. Having to draw a blind for bathroom privace seems like a strange design. We did opt for Club Level which is a good choice. The service in the Club is outstanding. We were leisure travelers and found the location worked perfectly and we enjoyed walking to many beautiful and notable sights. I highly recommend the hotel!

We stayed at Ana Intercontinental Hotel from the 27th of July to the 2nd of August. While the hotel was located conveniently and the staff were very cheerful and helpful, the rooms were disappointing. When my agent booked the hotel for me she didn't know what was the difference between a classic and a standard room. I was afraid we'd get the outdated rooms reviewed here on TripAdvisor. Next thing I know, we did get the outdated (classic) rooms! I honestly wouldn't have minded them so much if I hadn't paid that much money and if it wasn't a renowned chain like the Intercontinental. To me, that wasn't the real issue as much as us not being able to pay for an upgrade as the front desk flatly refused us informing us that the hotel was busy and rooms were fully booked. A couple of days in the hotel, and I guess we just got used to the rooms. All the staff from concierge, to hotel porters and to security guards and housekeeping were super friendly and courteous. So I cannot fault the service as it was superb. If only the rooms were not old and depressing! Oh, one more thing, complimentary was not readily available at the rooms. When asked, they told us to call housekeeping for them. But we bought our own. Maybe if all rooms were refurbished in the near future I'd stay there again.

Stayed here with hubby who’s an IHG Ambassador and young daughter. Asked for a no-smoking room at the time of booking. The hotel lobby had a faint smell of smoke but I brushed it off, thinking that’s alright, that was only the lobby. When we got out of the lift on the 19th floor, the smell of smoke was stronger, so it wasn’t surprising that our room smelled of smoke too. I wanted to ask for a change of room/floor but hubby was tired and thought if the corridors smelled of smoke, he doubted we would get a perfectly smoke-free room. So we put up with the smell for 2 nights. The room looked tired. The toilet seat had dried urine on it from the previous guests. The following day, housekeeping missed several things. This hotel didn’t match up to the standard of many other Intercontinental hotels we have stayed at.

My wife and I were all impressed by the spacious and tasteful lobby and other facilities the very first time we walked in the hotel. Our room was also spacious (for Tokyo standard) and it was well equipped with high quality amenities. As an IHG member I was entitled to free Wifi; the connection was fast and smooth. The location of the Hotel is perfect for exploring Tokyo as it is well connected with two subway stations. Exit #13 of Takeike-Sanno Station, which is a connecting hub for 3 subway lines, is just in front of the escalators connecting to the main lobby. However one has to allow 10 minutes walk from the platform to exit #13 and there are also climbing steps in between. There is a foot bridge connecting the hotel lobby to the Akasaka Station and the time to walk to the Station is about 5 minutes; no need to walk on any steps as both escalator and lift are available. Taking the subway from these two nearby Stations to Shibuya, Ginza and Roppongi is within 15 minutes. Adjacent to the Akasaka Station are two small but well equipped supermarkets and a number of restaurants for casual dinning. The front desk officer Chihiro Sawada who helped me for check in was absolutely great. She provided us a great overview of the Hotel and the needed information in a highly professional manner. We could not have asked for more. Ymke Simonis and Miho Obana working at the concierge were also delightful and helpful recommending us dinning options and making the reservation for us. Without their help it was impossible for us to have such great memorable dinning experience in Tokyo. Indeed all the staff working in this Hotel were very friendly. We highly enjoyed the buffet breakfast at Cascade Café. There was a great selection of food covering both pastries, cold cut and hot food. The make to order egg dishes were the best ones I ever had in Tokyo. Having a drink at the Mixx Bar located at 36/F was fantastic as the Bar commands a panorama view on the city. InterContinental ANA had everything we could possibly need for our superb vacation in Tokyo this time. We will recommend this Hotel to all my friends and will certainly stay here again shall we come back to Tokyo for a vacation or a business trip.

First time to Japan and wasn't exactly sure where to stay. Decided on the ANA Intercontinental as it had an outdoor swimming pool which is an extra I always look for as I enjoy getting by the pool and either cooling off or reading a book to get some sun. To find out that I would have to pay AUD$50 each time to sit by or swim in the pool was absolutely ridiculous and I've travelled to many parts of the world and not encountered this before, so it was no pool for me this time which was disappointing. Next thing that didn't impressed me was that although I arrived late to the hotel (during the night) there were no staff on to greet me, take my bags, usher me to check in etc which I felt again was disappointing and not welcoming at all. There were only the check in staff and thankfully check in was ok. I booked a 2 double bed classic non smoking room and was upgraded to a higher floor or so I was advised. The room was clean, reasonably spacious and looked a little tired to me. The shower seemed a bit grotty as well and I really think that perhaps the hotel could do with a soft furb upgrade to help freshen it up a bit, particularly the bathrooms. What I had booked also included breakfast and whilst it was busy (had to queue before being seen to a table) it was a substantial buffet breakfast so there were no complaints there. You could walk to the subway station (about 5-7 mins) which is handy if you wanted to go everywhere by train. One night enjoyed a walk up to Roppongi Hills (took about half an hour to get there - it's uphill from the hotel) and it seemed a nice area to be in. Felt safe and it was clean everywhere we went.The staff in the hotel were generally good, although some of them, their English was poor which I thought was strange for a large international property. Service was ok as well. I expected better from both, the staff and the service.Lastly, I'm an IHG Platinum elite status member and joined the Ambassador program before I left for Japan. Did all my room bookings via the IHG website (was staying at other IHG hotels while I was in Japan) and was advised that I wouldn't have to pay for my accommodation when I checked out except for any mini bar purchases and anything else that I may have incurred during my stay which I was fine with. So when it came to check out I was given my bill and it seemed that my credit card hadn't been charged when I made the final booking back in Australia and so I was not happy with all that, as it seemed that all my IHG bookings were now not paid and it seemed that I would have to pay for each of them upon check out at each new hotel. This didn't impress me at all. In fact it put a dampener on the stay at the hotel and it wasn't a good start to the holiday. Anyway it was sorted in the end and the hotel made a goodwill gesture of reducing my account which I was thankful for as it was IHG's mistake that nothing had been prepaid. Last time I book anything via a hotel website.Would I stay here again, no probably not. Although having stayed in another hotel in Tokyo on the way back, the location of the hotel was ideal to subway and surrounding area / district.

First time in Tokyo and stayed in a great hotel. Modern, comfortable and conveniently located. Rooms are small compared to western standards but the room never felt crowded. Concierge service was great and drinks at the lounge on the top floor were amazing.Hotel is within walking distance to Roppongi and there's a metro station right outside door.I recommend ANA Intercontinental to anyone visiting Tokyo.

Hotel for business travelers with a lobby that deserves some up-date. I arrived in the evening and the atmosphere was a bit sad. The room was adequate and the location of the hotel perfect for my needs. Next time in town I'll opt for something warmer.

Staff is gentil, and easy to get good english! Consierge was perfect on getting us the tickets, maps etc...Room was ok, both hotek we stayed had tough mattress (some Japanese thing).Hotel has several restaurants but prices raise at dinner and even more at weekends.Wifi is free and work great.

I come to Tokyo every 2-4 weeks and changed Interon's previously due to the ANA being at times excellent and at other times off the mark.Unfortunately this trip was back to being not as expected for this level of hotel.Mostly it is a fantastic hotel and I must say the service is world class and they do seem to value feedback.That said, what on earth is going on with the pillows here! They are simply terrible and beyond the worst sleep I have had on any hotel for this reason until on my last night I change to the alternative pillows.The standard pillow collapse as though they are filled with marshmallows and the alternate pillow is literally filled with mini ping pong balls - odd and both very poor.The room service late night was simply terrible and I bacon cheese burger that I am convinced was pre cooked earlier that day, re heated and just disgusting.*They were very apolgetic and did remove from the final bill and said feedback is very important, however I had the same issue twice on a past stay.Many good things to say about the ANA, however it is a shame they can't get what should be the simple things right.I just booked my next trip for two weeks time and it is at another hotel now.

Spent 3 nights at the ANA Intercontinental Tokyo. Bed comfortable, upgraded to room on higher level.Had breakfast downstairs, lots to choose from and nice coffee. Staff very polite and courteous. Only downside is the pool, I have travelled to many places with swimming pools on premises this is the first hotel that actually charges patrons to use the pool, bit of a downer, otherwise lovely hotel.

ok its not bad but has a few let down areas.its bright,blingy and a bit OTT.The rooms are quite small.The bed is big but the matress a bit soft for me.The pillows are awful featuring four empty pillow cases!bed linnen is excellent.the bathroom is a ley down as the shower is an attachement to the bath with a flappy soggy curtain.shower is distinctly average.towels were ok mid range fluffy.there is a fridgethere is free internetthere was a table to work at.the room is neutrally decorated and comfy.the curtains are a let down and allow a lot of light in.Breakfast can be hectic and i have to say a bit of a let down for a hotel of this class.its ok but there are better in the same price range

Very skilled people . Generally good English speaking . Nice hotel and very pleasant Club lounge . Great location for a city like Tokyo where you can anywhere in a reasonable time . The main restaurant  Nevertheless may be a little noisy when crowdy

I stayed for one night at this hotel and really enjoyed the classy feel. The service was extremely friendly and kind. The room was very spacious and comfortable. I wanted to use the pool but was told I would be charged for it (like 3,000 to 4,000 yen), which I thought was not reasonable especially because I'm an IHG member. The lobby area is very nice but had a slight smoky smell. Overall, great hotel!

I stayed here for 7 nights on a recent business trip. The hotel itself was excellent, staff were top notch. It was great having multiple restaurants within the building as after a very long day options were available. Location was great with the Ginza line close. Being central Taxis were reasonably priced to most central locations due to the close proximity. The basic room was of good quality with a comfortable bed. Size was good for Japan. Only complaint i had was promotions at restaurants advertised in the room were declined at restaurants because 'I didn't ring up and book'. I thought this was strange and dishonest, especially as they were empty. I was too tired to argue so let it be. Overall, top notch hotel which I would gladly stay at again.

Excellent stay and moreA special hotel in the services and tenderA team of wonderful staff in the sense of the wordExcellent reception and the finest lodgingGood advantagesBreakfast buffet magnificenceExcellent restaurants and cafesThe room cleaning services are pretty goodSwimming pool and a great spaClub Lounge Integrated ServicesConscious and helpful concierge

The ANA Intercontinental Tokyo provided a fantastic base to explore Tokyo. A short walk (1.7km) and you're in Roppongi and if you like to walk, another 4km and you're in the midst of Shibuya, although there are many multiple stations within close proximity to get you there. A 20 min walk in the opposite direction and it's easy to explore Ginza, therefore, a great location to base yourself from. The aesthetic of the hotel is quite nice however the bathrooms are slightly dated. If possible, a package with breakfast included is the optimum choice as the breakfast buffet is quite expensive. There are many stores within close proximity such as 7 eleven and Lawson, which offer an array for cheap food and beverage options such as salads, sushi, bento, beer, wine and sake. If in need, they also offer a small selection of toiletries as well as confectionary. Mixx Bar and Lounge on the 36th floor provides quite a nice outlook over Roppongi and the Atrium bar is quite large. The live entertainment was underwhelming, tired and generic and detracted from the atmosphere of each space. This was disappointing considering how creative and dynamic Tokyo is. To summarise, the ANA Intercontinental Tokyo provides a brilliant location to explore Tokyo and a very comfortable place to rest. I would happily stay here again.

We stayed as a family in the height of summer (not the best time to take kids to Tokyo!) - luckily we had access to the fantastic pool and amazing club lounge, both outstanding for Tokyo / Japan and most big cities. Probably the best Club Lounge I've ever visited and that was due to a number of factors - firstly the size and spectacular views, secondly the incredibly diligent staff who all spoke great English and spent so much time helping us with ideas of what to do in Tokyo with kids, how to get there, what to see etc an finally the food - this was more like a fine dining restaurant than your typical club fare. Outstanding. Our room was awesome, the location on a long weekend was really quiet but very accessible to everywhere we wanted to go and there were loads of interesting restaurants in the vicinity as well as in the hotel itself. Despite having noisy children in tow, we never once felt unwelcome or a nuisance and would definitely recommend this property to anyone looking for the quintessential IHG experience. One of the best Intercon's I've ever stayed at.

I stayed a week at this hotel while participating in a tradeshow at Tokyo Big Sight. The hotel sits virtually atop the Ginza line (tameike-sannon -station G06) . We we able to walk out the door, down the escalator then 50 m to the metro. We made one connection at shimbashi to the Yurikamome line and we're at big sight in around 40 minutes.Right beside the metro is a family mart and a lawsons in the metro stationThe rooms are clean, well appointed and the staff very efficient. We had a snag during checkin but they quickly rectified it.Lots of small restaurants also in the metro system and across from the hotel in the direction of the metro.You will notice many have these machines out front. Basically you select your meal, pay and it spits out a ticket. You give that to the restaurant. No handling of money by the staff. Its quick and efficient. But remember if you see the machine to buy your tickets the staff cannot take an order directly

Loved staying here. Service is 5 star, best pool in Tokyo, great location The club lounge is incredible and a must. Service was incredible, thank you.As we were checking in I saw a guest checking out and was giving the concierge a gift - this is that sort of place. Front office and club staff are worldly, helpful and engaging Thanks also to manage Russell for his attention to detail. One of our kids was sick during the night so he met us in the club lounge the next morning with some electrolytes!!

Perfect hotel to stay at while in Tokyo with rooms clean & comfortable, all restaurants are typically high quality with very good serviceThe views from floors 36 has a great Bar & 37 fantastic Teppanyaki restaurant are great viewing as Tokyo starts to light up at nightLocation to trains station very close, bus service to Narita airport makes it very easy for transfersOur dietary requirements were met without any hassles

This hotel is located very central to the downtown area. The rooms are ok, the service is good and the breakfast has a lot to offer. If you are meanwhile looking for a small familiar hotel, I wouldn't recommend this one. We chose it, since prices are reasonable and because we didn't spend a lot of time in our room. Our primarily intention was to discover the city.

The instant recognition of ANA Intercontinental was evident when I mentioned at Haneda International Airport Limousine reservation desk. This recognition transcended language and accent barriers late at night and were helpful after a long flight with my wife and daughter....we just wanted to get to our hotel and rest. I was considering a rival brand with same club access at the Odaiba area but Intercon was better located and the price difference was a wash. We were here for almost a week and truly Intercon was able to anticipate our needs.Room. We upgraded to the Club Intercontinental room. I thought this was worth it considering all the extra privileges that a club level opened up. We got the Premier room which was smaller than most American rooms but in Tokyo expect space to be premium. We got a King bed a love seat with an ottoman which was perfect for me. Though the room was small, the design afforded maximum use of all the spaces available: drawers and extra storage spaces afforded us to store almost one week's worth of luggage with room to spare. An umbrella was inside the closet, a shoe brush, shoe horn, shoe and laundry bag. The room was serviced twice and bottled water was replaced every time. Wireless wifi was strong and a cable data port was also provided which I used (as my work still doesn't provide wireless laptops).Bathroom. Again small by American standard but very well equipped. The seat had the Japanese style bidet wash with multiple control selections. Seat was heated. A flat screen TV was inside. Auto flush sensor. Amenities were standard Intercon which was very well stocked. A basin style sink and luxurious bath were standard.Lobby. It was huge more like a shopping mall. There were 2 levels with a good size restaurant, stores, and meeting places. At least one or two ladies in traditional kimono gown greeted and provided a warm welcome to guests. The rotating (revolving?) doors had safety features that prevented getting clipped. A door man was outside assisting in luggage or opened doors for taxis. At night there was live music on the 2nd level.Club Lounge. Located on the 35th floor, entrance was controlled by key card for club members. Then you were greeted by your name at the reception desk by the hostess. Wait staff will cater to your needs: will arrange tables for your party, provide a menu, and ask what drink you preferred.Club Lounge meals. Though it was buffet style, a menu was handed by the staff for additional ala carte items. Both buffet and ala carte had western and Asian choices. Meal service were for Bfast, afternoon high tea which I believe is an Intercon tradition/standard, and an evening reception. I especially loved the afternoon high tea as intricately prepared sandwiches (small portions) and sweets/desserts were offered. For the dessert they served these local delicacy that included what they called sasa mochi, which were a type of rice cake wrapped in leaf and then tied in a bow. These presentation of desserts I've experienced only in Japan where desserts are so beautifully wrapped and packaged, I almost don't want to open it as it will ruin the visuals. The desserts were also delivered to your table on a multi level tray for an added touch of luxury. The evening reception added alcohol on the all day available beverages. Tapas were added again both western and Asian selections. Desserts, finger foods, cookies, peanuts were available. The drinks beverages that were available all day were your standard Coca Cola selections, Suntory tea, canned juices, and bottled water.Club meeting room. I used the well equipped meeting room for some work items. The office administrator will set up the schedule your office needs and the room. Pens notepads will be provided. VTC was available thought I didn't need it. And by the way the Intercon provided pens were much higher quality than the Marriott pens I've ever received.Club service/concierge. The hostess booked transportation requirements. We availed of the 'romance train' to Hakone and also our departing limousine bus to Haneda. We tried getting the Shinkansen/bullet train through the hostess but the JR office was closed on that evening so we did it ourselves by showing up at the JR train office the following day. They also provided us with detailed itinerary, train maps, schedule and even which exit to take on the train stations.Location. The area is called Chiyoda. It took 25 minutes via limousine bus from Haneda. It was a 2 minute walk (with an Intercon provided outdoor escalator) to a Tokyo subway Tameike Sanno. This was part of the Ginza line which took us on the same line without transfers to some of Tokyo's top attractions. Ginza line terminated on Shibuya (shibuya scramble, shibuya 109 shopping, Hachicko Memorial). Also Ginza line terminated on the other end at Asakusa station (Sensoji Temple and Nakamise shopping street). Along the same station took us to the Harajuku area via the Omote sanno station. Of course Ginza station was the old commercial still vibrant shopping area. Within walking distance was Roponggi. The concierge will say that taking the train will be longer. We did take the taxi. One can see from the Club Lounge floor the Japanese Diet (Parliament) and the Imperial Palace grounds. Tokyo Sky tree was an 870 yen taxi fare. So was Roponggi.When my daughter realized our stay was ending and we were going home she was a bit sad. IHG was that good. Will certainly return again on our next trip to Japan.

This hotel was lower quality than I expected, when talking about the rooms, but as always the Intercontinental chain was not disappointing with the food and restaurants which were all very good. The breakfast has a wide variety of options and it is recommended to have it there. The hotel is close to the underground station and that comes in handy. It is very clean and the beds are comfortable.

Excellent hotel with great hospitality. Friendly and helpful staff. Unrivalled location. Close to just about everything in Tokyo. Just a few minutes walking distance to many attraction. Fantastic lobby and great restaurants within.

With three subway lines close by, this property is well located to get around town. Getting into the hotel from Narita airport, however, is a bit limited with only hourly stops on the airport limo bus. The last bus to Narita is also pretty early, so you may end up with a long wait at the airport. (Service to HND is a bit better.) Once at the hotel, it's reasonably appointed and the breakfast buffet is large and diverse. Other than breakfast, however, there are plenty of restaurant options nearby -- including the Akasaka and Roppongi Hills areas if you don't mind the walk, or even Ark Hills right next door -- that give wider variety and higher value. The hotel is older, that's true, and some rooms could be updated. There's a fee for the gym, but with so much walking to/from meetings, I got sufficient exercise without the gym. My only pet peeve was the delay in getting the room serviced -- which sometime wasn't until late in the day. But since I'm usually out of the hotel during the business day, this isn't a deal breaker.

I didn't plan on staying at this hotel but due to a last minute change of business plans I ended up here for a few nights. Pros - Fantastic customer service. Polite and professional staff.Good size roomsGreat breakfast selectionGood locationGood selection of restaurants in the hotelCons - The hotel feels a bit dated. Like it needs a good refit. The carpet in my room was grubby. The sink was cracked. Not the worst I've seen but certainly could do with some improvement.

spacious and comfortable room for single occupancy. But the pillow is not comfortable as too soft for me event after having 3 pillows stacked together. Also the direction to the room is like a maze and sometime does get lost.

I am currently at the hotel still, and the room is small and very dated. I've stayed in many Intercontinental hotels in low end rooms (presumably similar to what the average viewer is considering) and this room is by far the worst Intercontinental room I've experienced. This is particularly poor given the price point ($250-300/night)I understand that hotels are expensive in Tokyo, but earlier this week I stayed in the Conrad for only $40 more for a vastly superior room. In addition to the aged furniture, the upholstery was worn, the bathroom looked like that of a small town Hampton Inn, and the bed was uncomfortable (admittedly my preference rather than absolute). The service is typical of the Intercontinental and Japan-excellent throughout. Still, despite the great staff, I'd suggest spending a bit more for another hotel more meriting a 5 star designation.

it is a nice hotel, we booked a japanese suite, with a city view at nite and mount fuji in the morning. it was a great stay. close to metro but the walk to the platform was quite far. a lot of food at the breakfast buffet. the first hotel we encounter with good english speaking staffs after our 3 weeks holiday in japan.

Great hotel that offers spacious comfort in room compared to the traditional Japan small room sizes. Good location steps away from subway. Beds are comfortable and sleep two people very comfortably. Nice city views and great location to walk everywhere. Breakfast buffet is tasty with lots of variety but pricy.I always stay here during my business trips to Tokyo. Bus service to/from Narita works very well.Staff very courteous and attentive.

I was here for business and my son joined me. I am a spire elite ambassador member and stayed a total of 5 nights in a small two twin Bed that was an upgrade supposedly on the 22nd floor. The hotel rooms are showing their age. Pro'sStaffLocation to metroBreakfast Buffett Exercise room1600 yen cab ride to Tokyo train stationCon'sNo recognition of my status with IHG4000 yen to use the poolRooms tended to be cleaned late only two sets of towels left had to ask for more 3 days finally stoppedOverall if I was not here on business and using my own money I would be dissatisfied for the overall value.

This Hotel is amazing. From the moment you walk in you are treated so special. They are very friendly and can't do enough to help you with your every need. Rooms are well set out. Bathroom is big and bath is huge as well. Shower has plenty of room and also water has good flow and pressure. Rooms are very clean too. No noise was detected during the night. A/C is very good also. Cascades for breakfast was great. Lots of fresh foods to choose from every morning.

Absolutely gorgeous! Perfect location. 10-minutes walk to Ginza, 5 minutes walk to Roppongi. The breakfast is worth staying in the hotel, you will never find anything like this in Europe or in America: European, Japanese and oriental food in wide variety. Fitness and indoor pool are available. The rooms are not quite big, that is pretty standard for all the hotels in Japan.

For those who read the short story - become an IHG member, reserve a window seat at Unkai restaurant (the view is stunning) weeks in advance and book the breakfast buffet - it is the best I have ever seen. For those that read the details they follow:To Julian (lobby Manager), Tetsuji (Duty Manager), Matsumoto (restaurant manager) and Joyce (restaurant liaison) who all went out of their way, a massive thank you.I had only booked two nights at ANA Intercontinental as a stopover. I chose it being an IHG hotel and the highest ranked in Tokyo. They honoured my IHG status gleefully and went out of their to introduce themselves despite my short stay.I had one very small problem which was sorted by the Duty manager personally coming to my room inside of 5 minutes.I had one request of the concierge who drew on my map a route to walk which was perfect.I met the Australian lobby manager in a lift who knew my name without me telling him. He recommended Unkai restaurant and the Da Vinci whiskey bar as a perfect japanese experience and it truly was. Matsumoto and Joyce in Unkai restaurant were brilliant hosts. Please book ahead. The tables by the koi pool are stunning but reserved well ahead of time. I didn't get one but th emeal was glorious anyway. I know there are a lot of beautiful, expensive, traditional japanese restaurants. I haven't tried them, but I don't understand how they could be better than this one.Da Vinci whisky and Cigar bar is a perfect way to finish the night.Complaints - nil

This hotel is just amazing. I have not stayed at many crazy 5 star hotels, so if you have you might think otherwise but this is very good value for money. 300 USD per night, great rooms, superb service, nice sky bar, great view (if you stay on mid-top floors) and amazing breakfast.Free internet if you book executive and up.

Stayed here as we had to do some business at an embassy. The property is located centrally and in easy walking distance to trains, subways, restaurants, supermarkets and general shopping. We had a spacious room on the 18th floor with an excellent view. bed was comfortable, bathroom had everything that was needed. It's not cheap for Westerners, but that's Japan for you. $ 16.00 for a glass of beer or house wine is the norm here. The lobby is large and clean, there are two or three restaurants in house. As IC Ambassadors we enjoyed this stay and will be back for sure.

Enjoyed my stay at the ANA Intercontinental Hotel. Like other Tokyo hotels it's a bit older than many other Asian hotels but kept very well and clean. I was given an upgrade to a junior suit (IHG Spire Elite) and Club level but sadly couldn't use the executive lounge as I had my wife and young daughter in tow (children are not allowed exec lounge access here). The staff are gracious and everything you expect from a top hotel in Japan and location is excellent with Roppongi walking distance. The only downer was the Teppanyaki Restaurant (Teppanyaki Akasaka) which seemed a bit over rated considering its status and reviews on TripAdvisor and seriously expensive - cost us more than Yen50,000 for 2 adults and a child with local (not Wagu or Kobe) beef and half a bottle of wine. We had a much better Teppanyaki experience at Mon Cher Ton Ton in Roppongi - much more variety, size of portions, taste, theatre and half the price of Teppanyaki Alaska

Incredible assortment of meat, salads, breads, cheese, fruits, fish, cold cuts, ice cream, chocolates and beverages, al for about $35 us, ask for senior discount over 65.You won't be disappointed, gets crowded --if you get the point why!

We stayed for 3 nights and we had a great, hassle-free stay. The room, the facilities and the service is exactly what you would expect from a hotel of the stature of Ana Intercon. It does not do anything special to impress or overwhelm you but neither does it disappoint. In short, it's a good and safe choice. There are many restaurants and convenience stores very near the hotel. One thing that truly stands out though is their breakfast buffet. It's probably the best that I've ever had. Don't skip it.

Easy access from the airport, the hotel was very busy when im check in, but the prepare my key because im an IHG member. I got the best View to Tokyo tower. Very friendly front desk.Thank you for the great experience.

Beautiful and Huge hotel in Tokyo ...was upgraded to their junior suite on 34 floor ... buffet breakfast was elaborate and superb . They were generous in getting some vegetarian options ...heart club was good . Didn't use the pool . Service and staff were Top Notch ... this hotel has 845 rooms ... never felt the hotel was crowded , but during our stay the hotel was totally booked ... will love to go back to ana intercontinental when we are back in Tokyo ...

One of good location hotel where you have good selection of restaurants right at your doorstep, you also have supermarket at basement where it connect to the Tokyo Metro not to mention there are two stations for you to choose and another supermarket sit in JETRO building next to hotel where open 24 hours.You also have convenience shop like Seven Eleven (711) and Family Mart right in front the hotel also a choice of Starbucks and Dean & Deluca if you like to have a coffee or tea whether in the morning or afternoon.Overall, They have nice location, grand lobby with a good choice of restaurants,but the only point which I would say is their room due to small size and not that luxurious as you expected from InterContinental brand.

Great place to stay. Close to subway.Probably 10 min walk for good Japanese food.I am a gold elite member but they gave me a lower floor and asked for 100 USD to lounge access. Also they gave me a twin sharing. No big deal.The service all over was fantastic except one person.Breakfast spread good. The colleagues outside also very friendly.I hope trip advisor asks about the bad apple prior to posting.

Despite requesting an early check in several weeks in advance, I still had to wait two hours for a room - the only way to have guaranteed an early check-in would have been to book an extra night, which at a cost of £240 would have been excessive.Once I got my room, it was reasonable - all expected amenities including the automated Japanese toilet. However, the style and wear and tear indicated that a refurbishment is due.The room was reasonably quiet although some noise from othe guests was evident.In terms of service, I had breakfast a few times, which was excellent and in general the service was good, although sometimes slow and erratic in the Mixx bar. Food there was uninspiring - fried chicken and chips was very average but the beer was cold.Overall, I'd stay here again if I was visiting my offices as they are less than five minutes away. However, if I was visiting for tourism then it's slightly off the beaten track but within reasonable walking distance to Ginza and "downtown."

I have stayed in this hotel for over 20 years. My most recent visit saw such dramatic improvements in room quality, amenities and service, I was literally not sure I was in the same hotel. Service is impeccable, restaurants and bars numerous and great views from rooftop bar. Nice wine selections and just a really comfortable classy place to stay.

I could not have been more satisfied wih my last visit. As member with Spire Royal Ambassdor status which is IHG's highest member status and really having over 1200 lifetime stays (yeah not joking - almost 4 years living over my life time in their hotels) i have reasonably high expectations about my visits and may have a little better than average insight to what comprises a great hotel stay. The ANA intercontinental is one of their best properties. Great service, and great rooms especially the renovated suites and finally which I usually dont mention - great food. Well done! Don't change a thing.

Nice hotel, comfortable, clean, with exceptional customer service. Hot water is hot, linens crisp and clean, rooms traditional with pleasant decor throughout. We had a very nice 2 room suite very comfortable with large bathroom. There was ample light and a desk for work. The view from our window was awesome. Breakfast buffet was great with all things a buffet should be. There were lots of selections, delicious pastries, fruit, eggs made to order or omelette. The coffee was very good in this restaurant.There are numerous restaurants within the hotel, Steakhouse, French, Japanese, and Champagne Bar to name a few. There is also a wonderful pastry shop with coffee beverages, preprepared salad and sandwiches, with soda and water. If you don't want the expense of hotel dining there are some really nice restaurants and ethnic food dining areas right next to the hotel. A 7-Eleven and Family Mart in close proximity and easy walking distance. I really liked this hotels location, ease of getting to subway and bus service, amenities and cleanliness. Restaurant food was good, and the service was exceptional at all level. The concierge was very helpful with recommending transit and securing a cab for us.I would absolutely go back for another stay and recommend this hotel for business and leisure.

Very nice facility. Great buffet breakfast place (selection) but if you are looking for something smaller, there is a nice bakery/cafe on the main floor. The hotel is located near several subway stations - easy access throughout Tokyo and to the HND airport. The highlight of the stay was interacting with Mr. Yamaguchi (a day and sometimes night manager). Very professional individual dealing with my needs to extend my stay very efficiently. Thank you, sir.

Overall this qualifies as a good, recommendable business hotel that does the job, delivers good sleep, hot showers, reasonable food (although at a price) - and fitness facilities are OK for the frequent traveller who needs to stay in shape - overall recommended without any reservations.

We spent one night at the ANA Intercontinental Tokyo before returning home. This was our third hotel in Japan and the one with the most dated room and bathroom.I was impressed by the helpfulness of the hotel staff and it was in a convenient location.

Thank you ANA Intercon for an excellent customer service all the way from your reservation customer service that immediately attended to my queries and service requests, front desk who has been so welcoming and accommodating, concierge service for helping us with our luggage storage needs and even lending my niece a phone charger (she forgot to pack hers)! We enjoyed our room layout and amenities -- so in sync with the beauty and splendor that Tokyo has to offer its foreign visitors! Your breakfast spread is amazing -- we had a leisurely breakfast and we enjoyed the food! Thank you for making our stay albeit brief, in your hotel a memorable one ❤️ looking forward to staying again with you in my next visit to Japan!

Spent 3 nights here; it's in a good location. You can take the airport limousine bus here. The subway station is only a short walk away. There's lots of good dining in the Roppongi area. Concierge staff are very helpful and will give good recommendations, make reservations for you and advise how to get to the place. It's the second time I'm staying here and I am very happy with the choice.

Quite a standard room, but the thoughtfulness of HSKP makes a difference. The hotel does not provide complimentary water, but HSKP boils water for me each day when they service my room. Room was serviced well and yukata always placed on my bed for use. LOVED TH PILLOWS!!!Although the rooms are a little dated, but you can see there were maintenance carried out and things are in working order and clean. The staff cares for their property.Check in/out were done promptly, efficient.Why I did not give a full score - concierge service was great and the lady was very knowledgeable, but did not mention that for me to take the red metro line, I actually have to walk close to 1km underground to get to the gate...Also, Bell desk staff were very helpful except for one particular gentleman who rather not acknowledge me...but those I dealt with were extremely polite and helpful.The airport shuttle limo can be booked there, but they failed to let me know that the tickets are issued by front desk when payment is made there - causing some concern and confusion on my part. Please inform guest when they book the shuttle with you that they can charge to their room, and when payment is made at the front desk, the limo tickets will then be issued. The bell desk takes care only to book the seat on the selected day/time the guest wants - simple and clear instructions like that would help.Many dining options next door (Ark Hill) and a supermarket in that same building.Overall, I would stay with ANA Intercontinental again.

We have stayed in some of the best hotels in the world and this hotel actually had my room prepared with the feather pillows and duvets replaced ahead of time. I was amazed! The room was clean and the staff helpful. The location is good. We were there with a tour group and they were very well organized. Karen

We loved this hotel from the minute we arrived to the minute we left. Location was perfect, facilities were great, staff more than helpful and went out of their way to assist us. I hope to return here in warmer weather to enjoy the pool!

Very convenient location! Our room has 2 double beds , super clean and large enough for 3 adults.The metro entrance is just half a block away. We took the limousine bus ( 3100 yen one way per person) from Narita airport to be dropped off right at the hotel, no dragging luggage all over town. Excellent concierge service, excellent breakfast buffet. If you are a member of HG rewards group ( or register to become one) you have complimentary wifi and discount breakfast. And if you book your sightseeing tours with Viator they all pick up at this hotel. The hotel let us store our luggage when we travel to Kyoto for 3 days. So many convenient details that make our trip much more enjoyable!We will definitely use this hotel again.

Spent there a week in April 2017. Very clean, good variety of food, very accommodating staff. Only thing to be aware is the line to get to breakfast in the morning - serving people to their table sometimes take long, so be prepared. Besides that no downside. Can perfectly fit business travel or families.

From the time you arrive you are treated like a valued guest. Rooms are well presented rooms and have all facilities to make your stay comfortable. The buffet breakfast is full of variety to suit any dietary requirements. This hotel is within walking to many restaurants and 2 subway stations. Would recommend using this hotel as your base whilst in Tokyo.

The hotel is greatly located in a very nice area. Lots of cafes, convenience stores and subway nearby. Rooms are nice, beds comfortable and very clean. Is not a super new one but offers a lot. The pool is only outdoor and the fitness is nice. I would recommend walks around in the morning as area is cute. Great views from my room. Breakfast is nice and diverse. The restaurants are nice but on the upper scale though. The buffet dinner - Peruvian for a while is nice but pretty expensive. If you want a bite, try the cafes or stores nearby.

Stayed in ANA Intercontinental Tokyo. It was very beautiful and one can easily get around the city. Their breakfast buffet was amazing. So many varieties of food to try and the staff are very competent. A place to stay when you visit Tokyo.

ANA Intercontinental hotel is based in a very central location. Comfortable rooms, good food - breakfast and other meals. If you want a quick snack or a cup of coffee, just troop down to the basement level, where there is a Starbucks. Lots of restaurant choices around the hotel. A slightly long walk takes you to the Palace grounds (about 20 minutes walk). Taxis are also freely available - there is a metro station about 2 mins away. Overall a good experience.

Absolutely love this hotel and the staff. I've stayed here 4 times now, once for business, came back twice with family and the most recent being February this year with friends. Hiroyuki Abe on reception is such a delight, so friendly and helpful with my requests.Smartly dressed business men/women everywhere, posh functions happening everyday .. definitely a very high class hotel. I didn't see many kids around and wouldn't say this hotel was one for entertaining children, although I may be wrong. However, still a very warm and welcoming atmosphere for families and holidayers. Room got upgraded because of my IHG status. One of my mates was 5 months pregnant.. unplanned... but the staff accommodated to her crazy, demanding, hormone induced needs and were incredible respectful/polite. We called up reception for a spare iphone plug and the bellboy that came kept apologising and bowing when he was struggling to explain that it was from reception, bless him!Before arriving at the hotel, I've always ordered items from Japan that don't ship internationally, the hotel very kindly accepted these orders and placed them in our room upon arrival. The indoor gym is a decent size, most active around 7am. There are two sets of lifts, both of which skip some levels so that's something to keep in mind. We didn't eat at any of the restaurants in the hotel because Ark Hills is situated next door and has a lot more on offer, food wise. 7/11, family mart etc very close by. Tameike sanno tube station entrance close by. Never had a problem with the hotel services, hospitality etc and will gladly be coming back in August!

The grande dame of Tokyo, she is beginning to show her age around the edges (small bathroom etc) but everything beautifully clean and well maintained. Staff here are an absolute pleasure and definitely 5* in all respects. Breakfast buffet was great and dinner in the hotel is the easy option although there are plenty of restaurants in the nearby Ark Hills complex if you fancy a change.

My second time staying at the Intercontinental. Just so much good to say about this hotel. The rooms are very comfortable and many of them command stunning views of the Tokyo cityscape. The staff are very friendly and accommodating. The hotel is perfectly situated between Roppongi and Akasaka, walkable to both neighborhoods. The airport bus takes you directly to Haneda.

I stayed here late last month for couple of days and it was totally worth it! We arrived early and of course the room wasn't ready but it was totally fine. The bell boy and reception were very accommodating and throughout our stay with our requests and questions about train, bullet train, and sumo practices! They were amazing!Breakfast were very good with lots of variety - was really really impressed! Location was good - close to the US Embassy and all that, a walk from Ropponggi district (which has amazing food!). All in all, we had such an amazing stay here!

The hotel is well located and easily accessible to the Ginza line and other connections. Within walking distance of a lot of attractions. We had a room with a view of the Tokyo tower and the city and that was a big plus. Found the concierge service very helpful.

Ana Intercon cam through for us. Scheduled delegation from Houston to stay during a major conference. Everyone was pleased -- particularly me! Fast service for any and all requests. No request was too difficult. Sleeping rooms were a fair size for Tokyo and the cleaning service each day was beyond compare. Food within the hotel was excellent and the options just outside the hotel in Ark Hills were great (Bubby's, Aux Bacchanales and Ruby Jack's). Get a room facing Tokyo Tower for a great view and higher floors are better to avoid traffic noise.

The size of room for this hotel is quite big for Tokyo and very convenient to walk around, staff always friendly and polite. Easy walk from hotel to Tokyo tower and the tube station is just next to the hotel :) will definitely come back. Also they do good room service as well :)

Nice hotel with well appointed rooms. Western style hotel with English spoken. Breakfast buffet is only so-so, though the other restaurants are quite good. Views from higher floors are nice. Good location - next to multiple subway stations. There are definitely nicer hotels in Tokyo though price to value this one is pretty good.

Incredible staff at this hotel. From the moment I arrived I didn't lift a finger for anything. Staff was always ready to help with any need I had. Rooms were good size for Tokyo standards. Had a great view of the city and Tokyo Tower. Also, tons of amazing restaurants right in the hotel (and I'm the last person that would recommend a hotel restaurant, but truly great). I used IHG points for my entire stay as well.

I selected this hotel because it was close to where I was conducting business. Stayed here 4 nights. There were no problems during my stay; but I wasn't wowed by anything either (except the breakfast buffet, which was fabulous but expensive). Like the fitness center and bar at top of hotel; most disappointed in the business center.

Stayed here as the Grand Hyatt was booked up. Stayed at the Intercontinental in Singapore last year and it was really nice and luxurious so was expecting something similar here, but it wasn't the case.The common areas of the hotel are really nice but entering the room was like stepping into a different, much less posh, world. The fixtures are not in bad condition but they are just spartan and not welcoming/cosy as you would expect from a top-rate hotel. The bathroom was the old type with shower curtains - I'm used to seeing them at American hotel chains, but not in nice hotels in Asia. It was also very cramped - had to slide in between the toilet and sink or tub in order to open and close the door. The layout could have definitely been designed better.The layout of the room could also be improved as sideways walking was required to access the bed from the side along the wall, while there was lots of space on the window side. Another reason for the spaciousness on the window side is that there is a tiny kid-sized couch. Would be better off replacing it with a comfortable adult-sized armchair if not a larger couch (which there was definitely room for). Sleep quality left much to be desired as I regularly woke up with pain in my hip. At first I was unsure if it was me, however the pain has not returned since returning home to my own bed, so I am blaming it on the bed. It is the cheap type of mattress. The pillows were horrible. They were down pillows but inadequately stuffed - once you lie on them they pretty much disappear into nothingness. I took the extra pillow from the closet which was the buckwheat type and it was like a brick. I woke up one time with ear pain from being squished between my head and the brick pillow. I was wondering if it was perhaps a Japanese thing to provide bedding that was suited to back-sleeping, but remembered that the Grand Hyatt is super comfortable. I will stay there next time.Also, while it may appear that there are several subway lines within walking distance of the hotel, all of these are substantial walks of about 15 minutes, all but one involving uphill climbs. It got tiring after a while.

Its a grand but old Tokyo hotel. You can get competitive rates for the ANA but you do get what you pay for. I have now seen photos of the premium rooms but the entry level basic room I stayed in was pretty old, particularly the bathroom. Location was pretty good. Food quality good but very expensive even for Tokyo hotel standards.Pros:- Good location near Roppongi, with access to public transport readily available- Plenty of English language staff- Quality of food throughout was good, including the buffet breakfast and room service. I understand there are some very high quality restaurants in the hotel which many local non-hotel guests frequentCons:- Rooms are old and dated, particularly entry level rooms. I think there are some renovated rooms, others not.- Food, even for room service, was incredibly expensive. Best to head to the Family Mart nearby

Excellent Hotel Visit. .Have stayed here on four occasions. Service is first class. We always take the Intercontinental Club daily option as it gives us access to the Club Lounge where there are relaxed breakfast.Non alcohol drinks all day. High Tea in the afternoon and wonderful finger food and Alcohol drinks in the early evening.If you are not particularly hungry then this is often sufficient alternative to an expensive evening meal.

. good location, very nice room and excellent eating facilities but the most impressive thing was the excellent and kind service by the hotel staff - like Julian the Lobby .manager and othersHighly recommendedhotel

Spent a week in Tokyo on a business trip. The ANA Intercontinental hotel was awesome with very friendly staff and in a very central location. The hotel is always extremely busy and wait to get a table for breakfast can take a while. The rooms are good and well appointed.

To begin with, ANA InterCon Tokyo is a nice hotel in a prime location - not as nice as Ginza but close to everywhere you need to go and with very easy access to subway. I chose this hotel to attend an event near US Embassy so this hotel is very convenient.Hotel is massive to say the least and as many people pointed out, depending on what room you get, it can be nice or just fair. I stayed here a couple times before and as a premier member, I received an upgrade so my room was a bit better, newer with a little more space so absolutely no problem at all. Staff is very well trained and professional, a plus there as well. However, similar to many other InterCon properties elsewhere, you don't get any premier member benefits like free breakfast or lounge access at this hotel unless you are willing to spend a lot more money (the lounge access at this hotel will cost you a whopping 15,000 yen a day additionally which I found it a bit absurd). InterCon group really needs to re-think their policy before losing too much business to Marriott/SPG Group where I get all these benefits free as a premier member. Overall, there is no doubt this is a nice hotel but very expensive. Without the additional premier member benefits, I will always be somewhat reluctant to consider it my first choice in Tokyo.

Location was great, there was a 24hour convenience store (Family mart) nearby, and is right by the train station (Tameike-sanno station - Yurakucho line). It is possible to walk to the Ginza line, Marunouichi line, and Namboku line, but Marunouichi line is about a 960m walk from this station.Visited as a business traveller during the Sakura season in Apr 17. Beautiful row of Sakuras right behind the hotel. Convenient to visit during the day (during lunch) and night (after work).However, note that some hotel room views face the cemetery of the Buddhist temple opposite. When the staff asks if you would like a view of Tokyo tower or Roppongi district, do not choose Tokyo tower - if they assign you a low floor, because your view will be blocked by other buildings in the way, and you will only have a view of the cemetery.Room wise, it was spacious for Tokyo standards, considering the fact that it right next to a couple of office buildings (i.e. Ark mork building). However, toilet looks very old. Service was 5 star standard and extremely quick to respond. I had a room facing Roppongi district, and had a lovely view overlooking the rows of Sakura trees. This was after requesting for a change of rooms, as I was assigned the cemetery view (Tokyo Tower view - they said) room at first.Overall, a pleasant stay.

It's an amazing hotel lots of facilities the restaurant has Michelin stars. There was a wedding Japanese ceremony at the hotel and it was a fine ending for a beautiful tour as We stayed there for only a night before returning home. It concluded our journey with a taste of more... we'll be back!

This hotel is really large and centrally located in Roppongi.The hotel has various room categories at first I was booked in one of the Standard rooms and these rooms are close to be in-acceptable. My room was extremely small, stuffy and with massive mold around the windows. It is so stuffy that I was not really able to sleep.I complained with the Managing Director and was nicely upgraded to a premium room which was much better.In a nutshell only book a room there if you can afford a premium room that is newly rennovated.

- Great hotel with amazing polite staff.- Very clean room.- Great Breakfast buffet.- First hotel in the world during my stay I never hear any noise of housekeeping staff or carts in the aisles of the hotel. - the most soft bed and pillows. - The only bad thing about the hotel smoking is only allowed in a very tiny small room in the ground floor very stinky and no ventilation " smoking is not allowed around the hotel or outside" -

This is a real nice hotel. Huge, kind of reminded me of the top quality hotel you'd find in Hong Kong. It has everything you need. The rooms are spacious, and the service, professional. If the price were right, I'd stay there again.
user_name:
Robert B
Malmö, Skåne Län, Sweden

review_body: This was the fourth time I stayed at this hotel. Is was already excellent but it improved. More English speaking staff to help you out proactively and to point you to nice places in Akasaka and Roppongi. Maybe it were the pink blossoms but this was the best stay so far. Excellent breakfast and superb restaurants in house.

We were booked here for couple of days before our cruise. It is very much a business hotel although there were families here too. It's next to a subway that serves four different lines so is convenient for getting around but not too attractive for walking locally. You can walk up to Roppongi Cross in ten minutes where there are dozens of restaurants ( check out Ippodo) and there is a restaurant area beside the hotels for cheaper snacks (hotel breakfast 3000Y against 1500Y next door). The rooms are a good size and come with a minibar, tea/coffee making and lovely linen. If I was selecting a hotel there are cheaper ones a lot closer to the tourist spots.

The rooms are spacious with very modern bathroom and fixtures. Cleanliness is superb like most Japanese hotels. Beds are fantastic with great linens. The staff is very well trained and customer focused. I used the fitness center twice in the morning and was able get on a cardio machine of my choice. Rather limited on free weights.My only complaint is the $29.00 breakfast not included in the $300.00 / night price. There is Starbucks just outside the front door to the left if you wish to save $29.00 each. Great breakfast but wow.

Rooms are very small and the bathroom has very dirty grout in showers - looks moldy and it a real turnoff. Closet is small and hard to open. Positives are that the beds are very comfortable and there are plenty of easily accessible plugs. Staff is very helpful and great English skills. We were promised an early check-in, did not materialize.

ANA Intercontinental is a hotel that effortlessly combines class with convenience is the mystic city of Tokyo. The first thing that impresses you about it is that the airport shuttle has a dedicated stop at the hotel which is very convenient considering that due to the distance of Narita, most people will use the airport shuttle. They have a lounge and waiting area for those who want to board the bus from hotel to Narita as well. Also there are numerous dining options in the vicinity of the hotel suitable for all possible palates. The location is not too far from the happening district of Roppongi, if you are so inclined.Apart from the convenience, this hotel offers you a classy and yet efficient atmosphere. The rooms are of course on a smaller side, which is not a surprise for Tokyo, but are well appointed with all the amenities including a Japanese toilet that takes the hygiene and convenience to the next level :-). The size of the room does not compromise on the experience as there is a very efficient use of the space. The hotel has a Michelin starred restaurant on the top floor and in case you don't want to indulge, there is a fantastic bakery by Michelin Starred chef that serves fabulous pastries. The concierge is very influential and the best source to book local sightseeing tours. The breakfast is scrumptious and you will find enough options for your choice.ANA Intercontinental is mostly a business hotel, close to the office areas and I could walk to my office in less than 15 minutes. I would definitely stay there again during my next visit.

My wife and I stayed at the ANA for four nights in mid April. This is a large, sprawling hotel catering to business people. We stayed in a junior suite with club lounge. I was somewhat concerned about booking this room, because the photos on the hotel website were inadequate and the visitor photos I found on the internet were not the best. Anyway, I had reason to be wary. The suite is oddly configured with the bedroom and living room not really separated by a door or room divider----sort of railway style. Room was clean but furniture and furnishings could use an update---or better yet, a complete renovation. There was a curtain---not a door---separating the bedroom and bathroom----really!!! Comfortable bed, but small closet and inadequate storage place for clothes on a long stay. TVs in bedroom and living room. Two swivel club chairs and desk chair in living room Inadequate lighting throughout. Unable to read after dark. The ANA considers itself first class hotel and prices itself that way----very expensive even by Tokyo standards. While the hotel services are first class, the rooms (at least from my experience) simply don't measure up.The club lounge is huge. It is superbly managed by Junko Kano and the staff are friendly, professional and excellent at their jobs. There is a large area for dining and another separate large area for relaxing. Breakfast is superb. Large buffet plus a multi page menu for custom ordered western and Asian/Japanese dishes----all perfectly prepared.Evening drinks and canapes are also excellent. Again, a large buffet and you can order freshly prepared Asian and western set plates, each with three small bite items.There is a bartender who will prepare your custom ordered drinks and the premium selection of champagnes, wines and spirits is quite fine. The only negative about the lounge is the very poor lighting. unless you are using an electric device, it is simply impossible to read after dark.We ate at the hotel's steakhouse as well as the buffet restaurant. The steak house meal was great-----but very pricey. The buffet had great variety, but too many dishes were not replenished in a timely manner and were not available or too stale to eat.The hotel has many other restaurants, but visitors would be well advised to walk a few steps to the complex next door. Tremendous variety of restaurants and coffee shops. Much better pricing as well.The hotel is not in a tourist area, but there is a metro station just a few steps away and you can get pretty much anywhere in Tokyo comfortably and inexpensively. Signage in English and you can download an app which gives directions if you know your beginning and ending station----your concierge will tell you if necessary.

We paid about $270 night to stay at this property for two nights. I know hotels in Tokyo are expensive during cherry blossom season but this was a big waste of money. Location is not as near to Roppongi as I thought; it is really in a business district with a lack of good restaurants, bars, and sightseeing. We could have gotten over that if the room itself was nice. Unfortunately the room was extremely dated, especially the bathroom. It felt like we walked into an 80s Marriott. Wouldn't waste your money here!

This hotel was average. I had a good stay but I was concerned about the rooms. They were very old and the bathrooms were not modern. This hotel is supposedly 5 stars and it was more like 3. They offered a great breakfast buffet with traditional Japanese and American style food options. However the lunch options in the restaurants were not as familiar. There is a grocery nearby and a bakery so it is easy to get bread and drinks. A Wolfgang Puck Pizzeria was nearby so I enjoyed that. The best part of this hotel is the penthouse bar. I enjoyed the view from the top of the building and the lounge area.

We stayed here for 2 nights and was not very impressed. Service was not very friendly and they didn't seem very happy to have us as guests. It's a nice hotel but it could use a face-lift specially the rooms. Breakfast was pretty good but very expensive. Area is nice with a lot of good restaurants and shopping around.

My son and I were here and have enjoyed the time so much, the building is old and the room was not a typical 5* kind of room in other south east Asia such as in Indonesia or Malaysia. Nevertheless the service was good and the facilities were not bad. We were as Ihg Ambassador there but unfortunately they didn't give us the access to their club lounge as we only use vouchers as payment. I would definitely come back if there will be another chance to visit the city in future.Rosmery R

I loved the hotel and its services and location too. A train station nearby, market, atm, and more. The staff is so nice and always smiling, and the junior suite ( which I stayed in ) is good and very clean. Great variety of restaurants and lounges, and offer different kinds of food, including Halal food for muslims, and I appreciate that :-)I recommend it for anyone who looks for luxury and comfort.

We loved staying in the Intercontinental. Its a hotel that does everything just right and leaves the guest completely satisfied. The hotel is very conveniently located and close to two metro stations. Rooms very modern and spacious. The breakfast buffet in the lobby is extensive and leaves no room for complaints. Service is swift, efficient and polite and we were never left waiting. Concierge servive is super. Restaurant Pierre Gagnaire is spectacular with a fantastic view of Tokyo Tower. If you want a convenient 5-star hotel in Tokyo with very good F&B we would recommend this highly. Its only about an hours bus ride from Narita on the airport bus.
user_name:
anild
Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

review_body: Everything is goodService very good can speak english Room good, big space clean niceLocation is ok, a bit far from station and no elevator(exit 13) you must got to exit 11 for elevator(more 5 min from hotel)Supermarket and convenient store besides hotelLimousine bus to/from airport stop at this hotel, you can make reservations in hotel

Very well located and covering all the basics you look for in a hotel, the ANA Intercontinental it is a great option for your visit to Tokio. There is a shuttle service from the airport to several hotels, you can take it directly in the terminal and the ANA will be the first or second hotel in the route (and you will save a great deal by avoiding an airport taxi).

There is no doubt that this is well located and a first rate place. We thoroughly enjoyed our stay. The bar, breakfast, spa and Michelin 2-star restaurant are al first rate. The hotel is right next to the diplomatic area, and adjacent to the cherry blossoms (in season). We were in prime cherry blossom season, and thoroughly enjoyed it. The metro station is close by, but takes 10 minutes to reach the trains through a very long tunnel. It is all convenient for all of Tokyo (Ginza Line).

Well located hotel in Tokyo, took the limousine bus from the airport and got off at the entrance of the hotel. The staffs are very cordial and efficient. The reception floor looks great and the check in process was smooth and fast.I booked the room for one night with IHG points as a platinum ambassador member. I was told they couldn't upgrade me because it's a booking with points. Then I called IHG customer service to clarify the situation. And later the hotel's manager said they're sorry and then upgraded me to another higher floor room. I'm not sure if this is because I'm a female solo traveler or what. Appreciated for the upgrade, but it'd feel better if they could've done it right at first place, not until they got call from the IHG ambassador service center.As to the room I stayed, I believe it belongs to the areas which haven't been renovated yet, didn't feel like a five star hotel room for me, dated furniture and design. Still, you have everything you need for a good night sleep.But will I pay for three, four hundred dollars for a room like this? I doubt about it!

The ANA Intercontintental Hotel was a surprising confluence of huge hotel and extraordinary personal service. From the moment of our booking, the hotel's communications were terrific. An e-mail to the concierge resulted in a seamless airport transfer to the hotel. Stops at at the well staffed concierge desk inquiring about local restaurants, resulted in detailed handouts of a broad variety of recommendations, across all prices ranges and within walking distance. An inquiry about assistance with a train booking resulted in tickets being ordered from a local travel agent and delivered to us at the hotel. The room size was one of the largest we encountered in Japan, mid-way up a 30+ floor tower, with great views, nice amenities and easy access. Room service was quick, menus tasty. There is a small mall of shops within the hotel that offered florists services, a variety of food and beverage and other products. Breakfast (included in our plan), was perhaps the most extensive buffet (both Japanese and Western) styles, all warm, flavorful and for some dishes, cooked to order). We could not have been more pleased with our stay.

Hubby and I have stayed more than once in this hotel. The location is quite good as it is very near to Roppongi so there are a lot of places you can go to to eat. I like this hotel because they cater more to the idea of "western comfort" i.e., bigger rooms and beds. Areas for improvement would be 1.) the bathroom since it is a bit small 2.) the check-in services since it takes quite a while due to the long cues that form per receptionist...especially during holidays...

I have stayed at the ANA Intercontinental in Tokyo on many occasions now and every visit has been fantastic. Excellent location and very attentive and friendly staff. My room has always spotless. The executive lounge is a nice retreat for breakfast, high tea or a drink in the evening. Well worth a visit!

The staff are pleasant and try hard but this is more of an overpriced 4 star property than a luxury 5 star hotel. Our first room was tiny (25 cm between the bed and the wall). After I complained I was told this was ‘one of our smaller rooms’. Given that I am a Gold Ambassador and we stayed as a couple for 11 nights I’m not sure why we got ‘one of the smaller rooms’. I guess the lesson is, complain if you want a decent room.
