Our second room was 4 square metres bigger but the vanity had no space for toiletries for 2 so we needed to use the bath for storage.At breakfast dirty dishes were seldom cleared and being offered a coffee refill was rare. The breakfast queues were exacerbated by lack of staff. At 06:50 one morning when there were plenty of empty tables I waited for 10 minutes whilst the single reception person dithered from receiving guests to collecting payments.Housekeeping was good, especially considering the lack of space in the room and the service line responded quickly to requests for foam pillows.The room came equiped with a Bose speaker but it didn’t sync with my phone - I suspect the bluetooth was broken. The best feature was the electric toilet seat. The in room internet speed was slow compared with most quality hotels.

An enjoyable stay. Room was good. Ate breakfast twice. Hotel was very busy but they have an excellent system to minimise the wait by sorting out room number and coffee/tea choice while you are waiting for a table. Excellent buffet and well laid out.

I was here for a week on business and the hotel was everything you would expect from a good quality Japanese hotel. The service is outstanding. The hotel is next to a street of cherry blossoms as well which were in blossom when I was here which added something special. The decor is a little dated and dark but I find that an appealing part of many good hotels in Tokyo. It is just like the taxis, appealing in its dated but secure feel.

A short couple of days at the ANA. Club Room Junior Suite, upgraded to full suite with IHG Ambassador Status. Everything you expect from an Intercontinental Hotel in this (steep) price category, coupled with Japanese service and hospitality. The Club Room is simply superb. Thanks so much to the staff there, especially the Manager who made every visit a delight. Well located hotel, near metro, with various eateries and a SUPERB concierge service. Thank you so much to Imke for arranging Shinkansen tickets and luggage transfer services that saved us time and stresses at the start of our trip. Rooms get a mixed review on Trip Advisor: Ours was faultless; cool, calm and stylish decor with a great bathroom and comfy bed and seemed recently renovated. Although I agree with one of the reviewers here that the level of condensation on the windows in the morning is surprising but probably down to environmental factors beyond the hotel's control, Housekeeping cleaned off the condensation as a matter of course when servicing the room. The service here is incredible and the Club Room is superb. Would recommend and definitely hope to return on my next trip.

Excellent hotel in perfect location to business district and Roppongi nightlife and shopping! I arrived during the Sakura/Cherry blossom week and it couldn't have been more beautiful. Directly adjacent to the hotel was the most beautiful garden in full bloom! Check in was flawless, my room was large and well appointed (on 28th floor) with terrific city views and a Nespresso machine!! I adore the heated toilets with built in bidets offered in Japan! The executive/Ambassador lounge on the 35th floor is one of the best. The breakfast offerings are wonderful and the hostess and entire staff are beyond cheerful and accommodating. Every evening they offer delicious cocktails and tapas commingled with amazing evening views of the city . Oh and the coffee options!!!The gym is awesome - I believe that it is a Reebok gym...great equipment for a hotel and always immaculate. I ordered room service on the first night as I was in China prior for 10 days and only ate Chinese food - the seafood linguine was fresh and delicious! I was so busy that I didn't get a chance to visit any of the hotel restaurants - next time.The staff is super with many English speaking Westerners who are beyond helpful with recommendations for anything - the last day I realized I seriously over-shopped and needed an inexpensive suitcase. Got the best recommendation and ended up with so much more! I took a taxi from Haneda airport to the hotel but upon departure the hotel suggest a non stop Limousine bus to Narita which is almost 2 hours away and $170.00 USD cheaper than a taxi and super comfortable and convenient! Love this place and actually missed it when I left! Will only stay here on future Tokyo trips! Highly recommend! The five stars are well earned! Kudos guys!!!

We stayed at this hotel strictly for cherry blossom viewing which as you know, is a big deal in Japan. The close proximity to some of the key viewing areas made this location perfect. I highly recommend it.

Nice hotel, very well located. Excellent place to stay during Cherry Blossom week. Very nice gym. Room was very comfortable but bathrooms are showing their age and could benefit from a makeover (especially brighter lighting over the bathroom mirror). Good selection of restaurants in the hotel.
user_name:
mcsc-squared
New York City, New York

review_body: Located in expensive business district. The bathroom was dirty. We had a view of the highway. We could here the elevator and other people from our room. If we didn't get a corporate discount on the rate I would have felt ripped off by the price of the hotel. Everything in the hotel is super expensive and it felt like Las Vegas - smoky, dated decor, grimy rooms. I would not stay here again. When we asked the concierge for an inexpensive sushi recommendation she directed us to an expensive restaurant. Other than that the service was friendly.

This very tall hotel is situated in the center of downtown, right next to a subway entrance and lots of shops and restaurants. There is a 3500 yen bus to/from Narita and Haneda airports which is comfortable and convenient.The room was clean and spacious with a king size bed, a couch, and hanging storage space for clothes. It included shampoo, conditioner, body wash, soap, and several other toiletries. The service was exceptional. The breakfast spread, while expensive, was very tasty and offered a lot of options and variety.

I normally stay at the Peninsula at Tokyo, and had to stay at the ANA Intercontinental on account of non-availability at the Peninsula. This stay was for about 2 weeks and I was expecting a mediocre experience as compared to the Peninsula. The first difference was the Lobby manager, Julian Cole. In addition to welcoming me, he struck me with his authentic demeanour and genuine concern for my welfare. Multiple times during these 2 weeks, my interactions with various staff at the ANA Intercontinental helped me understand the difference - their ability to put heart behind their efforts. Another person who makes a big difference is Bernadette, who welcomes everyone to Breakfast - again very genuine and committed. This 2 week experience has now made me an Intercontinental Ambassador, and I look forward to staying at the ANA again. In addition to these great people, I forgot to mention their prime location, connectivity and amenities around. Keep up the good work, ANA Intercon, Julian and Bernadette!!

I stayed several times in the ANA Intercontinental for Business. Best thing about this hotel is the location. Rooms are ok, but dated, in need of a refresh and not very clean (found hairs in my bathroom etc.). Service ok but nothing special. The MIXX bar is disappointing - great view, but mediocre and very expensive food and drinks, slow and unattentive service, and it stinks due to the heavy smoking everywhere...suggest to avoid.

High end hotel but worth every penny for a special night out or romantic weekend. Very busy and clean, lots of action in the lobby, rooms quiet and well maintained. Loved the breakfast and went to the bar on the top floor. Expensive but to be expected for a high end hotel.

Unfortunately My agent make 2 reservations: 1 is for wed night and the other is from thu to sun. It took the reception on IHS desk 45min to combine the two and find one non smoking room which I hope not to change room on Thu. In the end, in order to get one nonsmoking room, I have to change room. Total waste of time for their inefficiency. I should suggest i accept changing rooms in the very beginning. As an IHG member I totally did not expect this happened with intercontinental. Terrible service.

Stayed 3 nights with my daughter and grand daughter. We had a lovely room overlooking a beautiful view of the Tokyo 'Eiffel' Tower. The beds were so comfy and the room sparkling clean. There was every kind of convenience you would ever need. We did not eat here except for Coffee and Croissants. The entire staff were friendly and helpful. Would stay here anytime.

Nice business hotel in the Ark Hills section of Tokyo near Roppongi. Traveled for work in the first week of March. Pros:Western sized rooms with standard amenitiesGreat breakfast buffet included with room rateNice fitness facility onsite popular with expats working off jetlagCons:Bathroom could use updating - jade green tub, pink tilesSmoking area immediately outside hotel driveway

Great hotel in a very good location.My room was very spacious and comfortable. Great service as usual from Intercontinental. Location is very good for walking and local restaurants. Really nice French Brasserie next door , feels like Paris !Hotel a bit pricey but good for location in Tokyo. First time at this hotel, will definitely visit again

I loved the hotel. Beautifully made with attention to details. Good breakfast and even ok gym which is rare to have at the hotel. Ah yes, located at the top of skyscraper the view is to take breath away.

It was our second stay at the ANA Intercontinental, my friend Helen's choice coz of the convenient location. We were here four years ago and the room was a bit worn out, guest room bathroom disappointing and service not so friendly nor flexible. Back then we had to pump shampoo and shower gel from the big container on the wall! We picked the hotel again this time coz of its location and convenience. But it came as a pleasant surprise this visit, not only was the room renovated, bathroom amenities improved, their service deserved our heartfelt compliment. Julian the Guest relations was polite and friendly, while Concierge Y Simona was simply the best, with her patience in following up with reservations, side trip recommendations as well as sincere advices on restaurants, giving us one of the best experiences we had in Tokyo. We were really impressed with the service improvements and overall guest room upgrade and maintenance. We will certainly be back again, not only coz of its location, but to enjoy this business hotel and its friendly service.

This is everything you would expect from the Intercontinental in a city like Tokyo - quality and attention to detail, but not cheap! There is lots nearby, the staff were friendly and helpful, and the breakfast buffet is well worth a visit.

This is a very good hotel, but average for the Intercontinental brand.The hotel is well situated near Rappongi and Akasaka, with convenient metro access. Rooms are compact but larger than many Tokyo hotels. In terms of food quality, we were disappointed with breakfast - both in terms of variety and quality - so did not try any of the other restaurants in the hotel during our stay.The hotels service is, of course, very good and friendly.All said and done - probably not worth the $500/night.

The one reason I don't give this a 5 star is the same reason some other people said. We got a special weekend rate 25460¥ a night including a wonderful buffet breakfast. But as an Intercontinental Hotel I would expect individual amenities in the bathroom and not the pump bottles of shampoo conditioner and body wash in the bathrooms.I did understand the superior rooms do have these .But the room was wonderful also we had drinks on lobby bar and Mixx Bar on 36th floor. The service was great but rather pricy in both bars.The concierge were very helpful and the metro is just steps away. We took the Limo-Bus 4500¥ round trip. It's 90 minutes at least from Narita to hotel.There is a Wolfgang Puck pizza restaurant next to hotel and we ate there 1 night. It was very good and reasonable. We loved the buffet breakfast.Although it was January the pool was closed but it looked nice.Supermarket and Starbucks next to the Pizza place also right downstairs.

Hotel catered well for families, small and compact rooms, excellent breakfast (always busy), staff super helpful and loved to engage with the kids, wide range of services such as luggage delivery and airport shuttle all at reasonable prices.

this is a decent hotel in tokyo...location wise...it close to a metro station(with lots of stairs and no elevator for those with lots of luggage) but far from JR Rail...the hotel its self is huge...i had a hard time locating the front desk as its on the second floor...i had a corner king room facing the tokyo tower...room was kind of small and everything seemed to be aging and out of date...the rooms need a do over...but aside from that is not bad...bed was decent and the room was clean...highly recommend for those on business...but leisure wise there are better hotels in tokyo...like the park hyatt..
user_name:
therealasim
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: The location of the hotel is great. You step outside and there is the metro entrance to some major lines like Ginza line. Roppongi Hills is at a walking distance but a short taxi ride is more convenient. They have a great breakfast buffet, so I recommend you get the room with breakfast covered. I founf the hotel family friendly. The only issue we had is that they offered us 2 twin bed for 2 adults and a kid, however, twin bed was too small to take an adult and a child. Getting an extra bed was quite a bit of aignificant addition to the room rate. So, don't expect too much from twin beds.they appear larger in the photos. Overall, we were very satisfied with our stay and would recommend the hotel others or stay there again.

Travelers: Family of 4 (3 year old & 4 month old)Room Selected: Double Twin RoomCheck-in: Upon arrival, we were greeted by a friendly, English-speaking representative and routed to an open staff member for a smooth check-in experience. A service member carried our luggage to our room and reviewed the room features. Room: As other reviews have mentioned, the hotel has very updated and spacious rooms, despite it's age. We did not notice any smells or age-related problems mentioned by other reviews. The beds were quite comfortable. We were very pleased to be able to set up my daughter's crib without needing to move any furniture. The layout and amenities were very nice as well. Location: The hotel is well situated, close to the Tameike-Sanno station (exit 13) and within walking distance of several points of interest. Hotel Food:Our room rate included buffet breakfast. The lobby buffet had a wide array of food choices from traditional Japanese, Western, and Chinese. Everything we sampled was excellent. The service from the staff was also first-rate. Overall:My family would definitely consider the ANA InterContinental again on future travel to Tokyo.

Its a Good hotel, not great considering Intercontinental prices, rooms are small & still with OLD carpets (now it stinks, not fresh). Worth mentioning about Great Breakfast spread and i was lucky to have Breakfast at 35th Floor with my friend in Club Lounge. excellent view of skyscrapers & FUJI mountain. In room even Basin is cracked and not replaced, is it Intercontinental style?? Hot water tap in wash basin is really hot, i just burnt my palms. Need to be careful.

We recently stayed for 4 nights - it was our second stay - and we will always love to come back. While it was a business trip for me, my husband had some leisure time, the staff gave him lots of very useful advice so he could move freely and feel quite at home. The rooms are very comfortable and the underground station is very close by, as are some convenience stores and various restaurants. May I mention the fantastic breakfast again...

I was there for 5 nights as part of business trip. This hotel is delightful. Excellant service.rooms are well equipped and tidy. Breakfast is great. The rooftop bar is great! The steakhouse was great. I think that the only thing which was very surprising on a negetive way was the lobby capuccino price of around 14$!!. Please consider of lowering it down. All on all, i will come back for sure

We stayed for two nights in the Intercontinental ANA Tokyo. My partner is a Gold Ambassador and we were upgraded to a very well appointed, large suite. The bedroom, lounge and bathroom were all excellent; good size and facilities. We also had access to the Generously large Clubroom. The food, drinks and customer service were all exceptional. The Club was managed by Junco and her able team. The were incredibly attentive and never invasive. Perfect hosts! The only downside to the hotel is the overwhelming smell of flowers throughout the public areas - no good if you have allergies like me. That aside, a perfect stay and I would definitely stay at the hotel again.

This ANA/Intercontinental hotel is a classic Asian Luxury Hotel with all of the expected service and amenities. The room is spacious by Japanese standards and the bed is firm with a wide selection of pillows. The bathroom is well-appointed though it shows the age of the hotel as the fixtures are not totally up to date. No issues, however, and well-maintained.Internet access is ubiquitous and speedy. Plenty of outlets in the room to recharge your devices. Staff are friendly and English is passable. No issues with communication.The gym is outfitted with good quality aerobic and strength equipment. Food quality at breakfast is excellent (as expected), but is not included in all room rates.The location in the Akasaka area makes for easy walking in the park and other tourist and government locations!Highly recommended.

Our stay was initially for business purposes but then became a pleasure trip. The room was very comfortable and clean. Amenities provided were very useful and replenished daily if you used them. The bathroom is tight but had a very good and useable bath with the shower over it. Japanese toilets are always fascinating with the variety of things they can do! The heating was set at a very pleasant temperature and we neither roasted nor froze in the room. We had a lovely view out over a city that seems to go on for ever. The buffet breakfast had a lot of variety and was priced at a level to be expected in such a hotel. The concierge staff were fantastic and spoke excellent English. They were incredibly helpful even ringing around shops to check if they had certain items in stock to save us wasting valuable time looking ourselves. The bar on the top of the hotel had a wonderful view out towards Mt Fuji and a great selection of cocktails to choose from. The hotel is located a short distance from Metro gate 13 on the Ginza line so even in the worst weather you can access the train system easily. While not located in a touristy area it worked for us.

Coming directly from the Intercontinental in Yokohama, I was initially surprised how small the room was, but then again, I remembered I was in Tokyo.The hotel itself is convenient enough if you're traveling by cab, or have business with the government or financial offices nearby, but have to walk a little to the subway station, which is the main mode of transportation in the city.Getting back to the rooms, I was OK as I'm not that tall (5'7" or 170 cm), but I could see taller people having trouble with the smallness of the rooms. Maybe better to request something larger than the "single room" if that's the case.

Aged hotel but very spacious for a city like Tokyo. Pricing wise, not cheap. Service is good, staff speak English fluently so it's very convenient for business arrangements. It would have been perfect if there were more shopping Malls around

The property is a bit dated, but overall it meets Intercontinental standards. The service is great and the buffet breakfast is awesome.Check in was easy and fast and as a IHG member I was upgraded to a bigger room with was perfect for Tokyo standards. The room was classic and traditional. The hotel is more business oriented. Location is very good although probably not the best one if you are there for leisure. Close to Roppongi. Metro is just steps away.

Let's start with the positive things, location is very good and quality of food and variety in restaurants is superb !!!! 9/10. Service in all hotel areas is also amazing) people is more than kind and totally devoted to make you feel as if you were at home 10/10Unfortunately the negatives are very strong ( first let's talk about room cleanliness!!! 1/10, carpet was a mess ! The bathroom is small and not comfortable.The worst part came with the bed ! Wow pillows were the worse ever!!! And the mattress was hard and uncomfortable as a stone !!!! I have a terrible back pain since the first day there, they need to learn about other hotel chains signature beds.I will return but just to eat in their restaurants but never stay there again.7/10 overall

The rooms do not match the hotel brand. You do not expect to see an old room in an Intercontinental hotel. Even more so, the bathroom was rusty and looked even dirty. I went to Tokyo to run the marathon, and afterwards, with all my tiredness and the big need to rest my legs, I did not put the hut tub because it seems so dirty and rusty and I was grossed out. Again, definitely something you would not expect from a Intercontinental. In other aspects, service was below average for the brand. And the English level of the telephone operators is quite poor. To make them understand that I wanted hot water and a lime was a triumph. The lobby is beautiful, and the sky bar is very nice.

I am an IHG Gold Elite and this this the first time at this hotel. It’s one of my companies preferred hotels. It’s in a great location. They put me in a room on a high floor with a nice view, however; I could never see out the window because there was so much water buildup on the windows. I had to keep using the bathroom towels to wipe them off. For this being a Business Hotel, it really needs to be updated. There were no USB connections and not many plugs. The Internet was also the worse of any I have experienced at a hotel. It kept going up and down the two days I stayed there. I also couldn’t get the thermostat work right. The room would get hot and then cold.I ate twice in the Atrium Lounge. The first time the food came out pretty fast, but the sandwich was just ok. The second time, it took forever to get my food and it came overcooked. I told the woman it was over cooked and all she said was sorry. When I went to pay and told the cashier about the experience and all she said “sorry”. We all know it’s very expensive in Tokyo, so when the food isn’t good or a there is a problem they should make adjustment.Overall the staff is very nice and helpful, but when I am back in Tokyo, I would think twice about staying here.

Beautiful hotel, centrally located. Few minutes walk to metro. My room had a great view of Tokyo Tower which is beautifully lit up at night time. The room had 2 double beds, large room for Tokyo. Bed was very comfortable and room was spotless as was the bathroom. Décor is a bit dated and could do with a spruce up. 1st room I stayed in had a terrible smell in and I was moved immediately. Breakfast had great choice and very fresh food. Staff were very friendly and helpful. There are several bars and restaurants to chose from and if you are a coffee lover there are 2 starbucks within walking distance - also a small supermarket.

Fantastic bar on level 36 Mixx Bar but the highlight was at eating Pierre Gagnaire Two Hat Michelin restaurant with a fine degustation menu with some sensational wines to match - absolutely great fine dining at its best

Hotel Location is really fantastic as the Tokyo Metro is just less than 5 mins walk away. Interconnected to the hotel is beautiful complex; Ark Hills, where you can find delightful restaurants, eateries and bars to chill. Or for the ladies there is a simple hair & nail care shop and a male grooming shop. Opp the hotel is a golf outlet and a foot relexology plaid. (There's no fancy shopping malls around here)The service level of the hotel staff was great, esp the doorman, concierge and the nice ladies from the laundry room. The check in was fast and efficient.Hotel breakfast buffet spread has a nice healthy variety and was tasty. However, the bedroom was kinda disappointing... it was aged and the deco, furniture & carpet was really quite old. I was pleasantly surprised that there are no basic amenities like international charger, complimentary drinking water or bath robes (till we requested) and if u need ironing for your work shirt or dresses; u need to be very patient as the iron needs to be charged for at least a few hours to be fully functional or fully "heated" up. The only thing we really really don't fancy was the bed which was soft and the pillows were unbelievable flat and soft as well; totally no support for our necks. We requested for firm pillows on the 2nd night, and was kindly informed that the hotel ran out of firm pillows then. However, the housekeeping mgr was kind enough to pass us 3 in the evening when the firm pillows stock return.On the bed's mattress - it was not firm and not well-supported: example: whenever I toss & turn at night, my partner will be woken and vice versa. aka zero "motion isolation" we can feel each other "tossing" We went to work not fully rested.We have been to other IHG chain of hotels ard the world, we felt ANA Hotel Interncon may want to put some work on their beds and pillows. Observed that most of the guests are business travelers, a good night rest after a long day of work or conference is only essential. It may really help with better pillows and bed mattresses. (Our room is a std room, perhaps an upgraded room may have better amenities, mattress and pillows.?) This is just our thoughts, for travelers who like soft mattress and pillows - this hotel will be ideal for u.

Stayed here with my wife on business. Overall a pleasurable experience but very pricey. Breakfast buffet pricey too at $40. I would suggest Bubby's next door in court yard area. Nice central location to all the Embassy's. East walking distance to Tokyo Tower. Rooms nicely decorated. A lot of local restaurants nearby and I believe 6 to choose from inside hotel. I believe the hotel caters to primarily the business traveler.
user_name:
paulenich
New York City, New York

review_body: Returning to ANA Intercontinental for the third time. Staff at the club floor iwere very efficient. Compliments to Yuki and Yuko for recognizing me as a returned guest. I was also recognized being recognize as a SPIRE Member. They were excellent and are very patience.My special thanks to Miss Kayoko Kitamura -PA of Mr Markus Platzer. She has assign the same room to me and everything in the room is perfect. As I am a SPIRE member, I was upgraded to an executive suite.Please extend my compliments to all these great staff. I am so happy to be back here.

Before arriving, contact the hotel for requesting King-size bed as we will share bed with a kid. No kid's bath kit is ready in room when we walk in the room.Upon 1st check-out, need to specifically remind the hotel preparing kid's bath kit and more towels. Bad experiences are more towels missing still when I come back for 2nd check-in.One good thing is hotel listened to my complaint about ambassador member's room upgrade and give me a more real upgrade later on.Bell captain services are excellent but remaining staffs are not impressive.

Very nice hotel overall. Professional staff. Nice rooms. Primarily caters to business traveler and is in a less-touristy area. The buffet is excellent and offers a wide variety of high quality Japanese, Chinese, Western and other items for breakfast, lunch and dinner.

Stayed at the ANA for the first time and the hotel is very nice. Room was really nice and the room amenities were great. The lounge offerings were pretty good but I have had better at other international hotel lounges. If you like to hit the gym while traveling, this gym is fairly equipped with most fitness equipment you would need. In all, I would definitely return to this hotel.

Stayed for two nights at the ANA Intercontinental Hotel (IHG). The staff were lovely, all spoke English well, there was no barrier. There is a two star Michelin restaurant on premises as well as a number of other restaurants and a bakery. Two gripes, as an IHG platinum member I was not granted access to the lounge, it was an additional fee. In addition, there was also a fee to use business center. I found the bed to be very comfortable. I would stay here again next time I am in Tokyo.
user_name:
MandP111
New York City, New York

review_body: Had a very good 5 day stay. Access to the club lounge was a real bonus and you get very well looked after in there. Many different restaurants and bars, although we didn't sample many. Very handy for exploring the city and a bus to the airport right from the hotel. Gym decent too. All in all can recommend it thoroughly.

Indeed location is great, central and with a metro station just next to hotel. A busy leisure area short walk away with many bars and restaurants. The hotel itself is very classy, rooms are comfortable, clean and include all necessary amenities. Very polite and courteous staff.

We enjoyed our five day stay here. For Tokyo the room was a nice size. And the bathroom was also a good size. We had a nice view and were on a high floor. The staff was super attentive. The location is good as there is a Starbucks nearby and a few restaurants as well. You can get to subway stations but be prepared for long walks to the actual trains. You'll be underground and out of the rain with the stations are 400-500 m away from the hotel. Still excellent access to the underground and easy travel around Tokyo. PS. We enjoyed the all you can drink champagne option at the champagne bar!

This was our fourth stay in Tokyo and wanted to stay in the Roppongi area this time. The Intercontinental fitted the bill.We opted for the executive lounge upgrade and were extremely happy. The service is top notch. The breakfast, afternoon tea and evening cocktails were perfectOur initial room was noisy but they happily moved us to a room on the quieter side. The housekeeping was discrete.Can not fault this hotel.

Location: right next to a Metro Station (direct line to Ueno, Ginza etc.); 10 to 15 minutes walking distance to Roppongi. A 24 hours small supermarket on the left, 2 convenience stores on the right. If you are willing to walk for 10 minutes, there is a local Japanese supermarket (24 hours) too. A French bakery with nice coffee at the lobby.Room: Reasonable size in Japan standard. Clean and comfortable.Service: Special thanks to Julian Cole - Lobby Manager and Obana - Concierge. Very warm welcome by Julian as I was staying for 1.5 weeks. Great restaurants suggested by the people at the Concierge. Especially Obana, she was patient in listening to what I wanted (which I wasn't even sure what I wanted) and provided the best recommendation she could ~ that recommended restaurant become one of my favorite restaurants in Tokyo. THANK YOU SO MUCH!!!

The hotel is ideally located close to the subway line and has spacious rooms with good views of the city. The staff and in particular the concierge are very helpful and informative and gave excellent restaurant recommendations. We had a great arrival experience and the service was very personalised.

Have stayed here several times while accompanying my husband on business trips. The hotel is well established and it must be said, furbishment could do with an update and is slightly dated, but a very sound choice for staying and an obvious favourite spot for business meetings in the several bars and restaurants. Staff are polite and helpful, check in and service is smooth. It always seems busy in the lobby, in a good way. It is certainly in a great location, close to Akasaka and Roppongi - classy neighbourhoods with the best of Tokyo a stroll away. I can't really comment on the value for money factor as I'm not an expert for Tokyo but this is definitely a pleasant, but by no means luxurious place to stay.

Spent about a week here and have to say this is an ok hotel. Rooms are decent in both size and ambience. Staff was friendly and helpful. Very long queue at check in and check out, with very confusing queues.Restaurant was quite good for bfast but way too pricey imho.Location wise, it's a short walk to the heart of Roppongi so it may be a good pick for ppl able to pay the price.

It was a stay on points. The room was big enough but when entering the bathroom i was send back to the early 70's. A shower curtain and high end Sisheido shampoo in the cheapest dispencer you can find.Not 5 star at all. That said the hotel has very helpful staff and they speak fluent English.The hotel is located on the Ginza line so easy to get everywhere. You can buy a day pass for the metro with the conciërge. We both our breakfast at the pastrie shop.Realy good.

The hotel staff was very welcoming. We were given early check in with out even asking them and were upgraded( I suppose a the room was fairly large) on arrival. What sets this hotel apart is the conceigre services, very proactive and helpful.

Stay for a week for business. Will stay again.Highlights:1. Room updated, modern and clean (but looking at the reviews, it looked like some rooms may be outdated2. Very friendly front desk and fluent English. Did not even feel like i was in a foreign country. Very helpful with all the questions asked3. Subway right by the hotel. You can pretty much get anywhere in Tokyo from there4. 20 minutes walk to Ropongi hills. Enjoyed the walk every morning into the office. A little of different things to see along the way5. Good sized room for Tokyo6. Friendly house keeping (and 2 cleaning a day if I remember correctly). And you don't need to worry about tipping. It is already part of their pay and they do an awesome jobLow lights:1. Subway entrance is close but still 5 min walk in the tunnel just to get to the boarding platform2. Breakfast buffet looks good but on the pricier side, but I wouldn't blame it on the hotel. It is reasonable comparing to similar places. Just didn't want to eat there since it looked pretty western not much different from what I can get back home. Nonetheless there are 7-11 everywhere for a quick breakfast and taste of Japan

Been staying at the ANA Intercontinental for almost 6 years on the trot. I have always been impressed with the level of service from the front counter staff, concierge, and bar/lounge servers. The Japanese restaurant (not the Teppanyaki place) is also good, but a bit expensive. Not that surprising given that it is a hotel restaurant in the nice part of town. The rooms, however, are getting dated. I have stayed in multiple room types and I must admit that as compared to other ICs that I have stayed at, the quality of the room is lower. A simple thing such as a universal power plug is not available, and USB chargers are also unavailable. Seems strange for such a high-tech country like Japan. On the positive (apart from the service which I am always happy with), the coffee shop is good for a quick breakfast (better value for money than the lounge or lobby restaurant). It is very convenient to the Roppongi, Omotesando and Akasaka areas which are full of excellent food choices and nightlife. From a work standpoint, my meetings are spread out between Shinjuku and Marunouchi so I usually take taxis to save time. I do think of the ANA as my home away from home when in Tokyo but I may look at other options. Saying that, as an IC Ambassador, I'll probably stay loyal....

After changing to another hotel for when I am in Tokyo (I am generally there once a month), I tried the ANA Intercon again after a 12-month break and I am glad I did.The level of service is faultless and certainly world leading.They have taken feedback on board and you can see changes which is a sign of an exceptional 5 star hotel in my opinion.Rooms are very clean and the beds/pillows are incredibly comfortable.Food is very good along with many options available to you. Very good location.I will re consider where I stay on future trips based on this last experience.

My husband and I recently spent one night at the ANA Intercon Tokyo.We paid the extra for the upgrade to the Suite, and I was slightly disappointed with the suite - it was a bit worn, and could do with an upgrade. The room was clean and very spacious - especially for Tokyo standards!Good location - near different metro lines.Buffet breakfast was quite good - as expected from an Intercon.Having stayed at many Intercon around the world, this is on par with my expectations. Could do with a bit of a renovation to make it exceptional.I would stay here again if I am lucky enough to be in Tokyo again!

Steakhouse restaurant- not pleased. Service started out attentive then just disappeared. Single diners seated away from main area. Food disappointing - expensive is ok if good but this was not good. Nice live music, though.

Stayed at the Ana for 4 nights at the start of our stay in Japan! the hotel was very lively (we arrived on the 1st Jan). The room was lovely and the staff were fantastic! After a small misunderstanding (my fault) they organised hypoallergenic bedding, and even left a bottle of complementary wine for my husbands birthday! We got a room facing Tokyo tower- which we had requested on booking! The concierge was was very helpful and called our next hotel in Nikko! I would say check where the hotel is, it is closer to the Roppongi-itchome metro station! We forgot to check and it was quite a walk from Roppongi lol A lovely start to a fantastic holiday! We highly recommend using the suit case delivery service (a lot of hotels are part of this)- the luggage staff filled in the form and sorted everything for us- makes travelling so much easier and was about £11 to send one large suit case to our next hotel after Nikko.

I have been to Tokyo a handful of times before but never on my own. So I wanted an affordable upscale experience with solid concierge support and this hotel delivered both. The room was comfortable, spacious, not huge, completely renovated with excellent furnishings and luxury bedding. I spent 10 days at the hotel and the enormous club lounge, well worth the cost, provided excellent full breakfast, pleasant staff and top notch concierge assistance. Head concierge Junko Kano helped me enormously, providing great suggestions for restaurants and places to visit. These were not just pulled out of a brochure but were personal suggestions based upon my preferences and her great personal knowledge of Tokyo.Her help definitely increased the value of my experience exponentially and I would recommend the same especially to any first time visitor to Tokyo. The hotel has a gym and sauna which is pleasant and sufficient but no pool or hot tubs. However, Kano-san directed me to a lovely Onsen type amusement facility in Tokyo, not far away, which more than made up for no pool at the hotel. Restaurants in the hotel are excellent but pricey, room service is actually more affordable. Did I mention that the cost of this hotel was very substantially less than other highly rated Tokyo hotels, so for the bang for the buck, it was definitely a good deal!
user_name:
nytravelerp
New York City, New York

review_body: This property is brilliantly located and has wonderful onsite facilitie. With a two star Michalen restaurant, a fantastic Teppanyaki restaurant and a champagne bar with views to die for, this is only the start. The entry level rooms are fine but when we returned to the hotel after skiing, we enjoyed a junior suite and this was divine. There is a metro station next door with access to the Ginga line (shopping in two directions) and plenty of small local restaurants to walk out to if you want to venture beyond the restaurants in-house. Wonderful staff who understand service and guest satisfaction finish the picture. Spoil yourself. If the weather behaves you will be treated to a fabulous and clear view of Mt Fuji.

Great hotel for business and personal travel alike. Grand hotel with multiple top notch restaurants ranging from steakhouse to traditional Japanese cuisine. Small shops on the ground level incl. antiques, cigars, clothing, and delicacies. Few minutes walk to the subway as well as the Akasaka dining district. The top level Sky Bar offers perfect views of incredible Tokyo lights at night and as far as Mt. Fuji during the day. The jazz bar offers a great escape for a night cap. Defintely worth a stay when in Tokyo.

Quick post-Christmas trip to Tokyo for some downtime. It was a good stay overall. My room was a Premiere King Room on the 31st floor with a view of the Tokyo Tower. Things I liked about my room/stay:-- the view of the Tokyo Tower was a plus and the hotel honored my preferences for rooms located on higher floors away from the elevators;-- the complimentary 2x bottled water per day; -- electric blinds and bedside control panel for lighting, etc.;-- bath had very, very strong (absolutely glorious) water pressure;-- the water heater just worked;-- this being Japan, the toilet had a built-in washlet (bidet) with the controls located on the wall beside the toilet;-- port hub (that's what I'm calling it) on the TV table featuring USB (powered and able to charge your device), AVI, HDMI and other connectors;-- desk level electrical outlets on the bedside tables;-- the expertly positioned pin light which ensured that a usable part of the bathroom mirror does not fog-up while you're taking a shower;-- complete toiletries (shampoo, conditioner, body lotion, toothbrush, sewing kit, cotton buds, etc.);-- breakfast was great. Staff were international/multi-lingual (one was absolutely Filipino and another was likely Nordic) and quite efficient in getting diners seated quickly. Requests were also handled quickly. Food variety was great, from American to Continental to Chinese and Japanese breakfast staples. I loved the Museli and juices + the crispy bacon on offer. Things I didn't like, annoyances:-- Combination tub and shower. I think all Intercontinental Hotels should offer a separate bath and shower, even in the lowest room categories (and mine was only a step-below the Junior Suites). But if I can't have that, I'd rather have a stand-alone shower;-- the shower was a handheld unit. (I would rather have both a fixed and hand held hower.)The water pressure was so strong that the torque caused the shower head, if it was in its cradle/holder, to move towards the right (facing the wall), thereby somewhat negating the glorious pressure;-- the sink counter-top didn't exude an expensive feel (more like 3-1/2 star Holiday Inn);-- bathroom walls ring thin/hollow when you tap on them (a pet peeve of mine);-- at 28 sq. meters room size was on the small side;-- pillows sank way too low;-- interior design of the room was "ehh", not bad, mind you, but nothing stands out. Notes:-- unlike lower category rooms, my Premiere Room did not have those bolted on shampoo, conditioner dispensers (which I think should never make an appearance in a 4-5 star hotel);-- the in-room safe is built in to a cabinet located below the TV and opens from the top;-- WiFi worked. I got a little bit les than 20 mbps on download, if I recall correctly;-- mattress was firm but not overly so (the most firm I ever had was in a hotel in China) and I slept well enough;-- it was so cold outside at night (compared to the comparably comfortable 22-24C of my room that condensation formed on the inside of my room window;-- the toilet has a small LCD TV and remote;-- Premiere Rooms have Keurig single serve coffee makers and mugs;-- I also had a tea pot, tea cups and saucers on a bamboo mat, if you prefer tea;-- the hotel is close to a subway entrance/exit (Exit 13, Tameike-Sanno) but be aware that it's a long walk (about 300 meters) before you actually hit the first subway line.The hotel is right beside an elevated expressway. I did not explore the area opposite the elevated expressway or, for that matter, any of the immediately surrounding area. Hence, have no advice or inputs to offer on that.

We so enjoyed our stay at the hotel. The service was above and beyond. The food was fantastic and we absolutely love the accommodations. The hotel is very accommodating and helped us with many activities. With specially like the convenience of the hotel but more than anything, felt comfortable and safe. We cannot wait to return and to recommend to all of our friends and family. Thank you to such a wonderful staff for making our first day in Japan a wonderful memory.

Note that this is at roppongi-ichome, though seemingly near to roppongi but their train lines are separate. Dated hotel and the rooms are telling though generally well kept, toilet shows signs of wear and tear but still clean. Was a comfortable stay. Do pay Pierre Gagnaire's bakery a visit, and the restaurant itself if you can get a booking!Their shuttle to Haneda airport saved us alot of trouble lugging our luggages.

we were in tokyo for a week on the new years and stayed here. rooms were clean and comfortable. easily accessible to metro/subway/taxi to get to roppongi,shibuya,shinjuku. straight bus from narita airport. decent breakfast. loved the music in lounge in the night. i did get to have a little conversation with couple of the front desk staff and they were very nice. thanks!

Stayed here for 1 night in January 2017. The hotel is very high standing. The rooms are very spacious (esp for Tokyo standards), comfortable, and have great views. The breakfast buffet was excellent and there is even a 2-star Michelin restaurant on the top floor. The bar of the hotel is just amazing with great cocktails, cigars, and sweeping views of Tokyo. Perfect place to catch the sun setting over the city and over Mount Fuji!

Like any decades old hotels in the CBD of a major city, this hotel had a great location and staff, but the rooms and facilities were small and dated--especially the bathroom. However, the proximity to Roppongi was a plus with lots of places to eat and visit. However, there were not very many places to eat in the immediate vicinity of the hotel.

it's decent hotel itself, staff is friendly but cold. Typical Japanese style. They will apologize for any inconvenience you encounter but will do nothing to correct it. Extra charge for the pool?! Really?? No recolonization to plat members.

Located at the heart of the business district, surrounded by ministries, agencies and embassies, this classy hotel offers comfortable rooms and great service.Right by the hotel there is a famous street lined with cherry trees, which is very popular during sakura season. The check-in took some time, as the hotel was very busy when we arrived. My room was small but comfortable and with all the necessary amenities.Breakfast is exceptional in terms of offer and quality of the food!The staff was professional and helpful.

Great location , awesome service. The hotel is quite close to Haneda airport , though about 70 kms from Narita Airport you have direct limousine (bus) to and fro to Nrt airport.Well connected with Metro And as well few Indian restaurant near by .

We stayed here a couple of nights at the end of a three-week holiday. The staff, from the check-in desk to the concierge to the bar staff, were all very friendly and helpful. It's a business hotel and it has that type of atmosphere, but the rooms are very pleasant. The gym looks ok and the pool was a nice bonus. The concierge staff were great in helping us pick a restaurant for our last evening, really listening to what we had in mind, and than making the reservations.Furthermore, it's within walking distance of the Rippongi area with loads of restaurants and bars and just above a metro station. We had a great stay here.

I enjoyed my short stay in Tokyo in the Ana Intercontinental! Staff was friendly and especially enjoyed the breakfast :) a little expenisive even for drinks such as tea but I would gladly come again!!!

Had a fairly delicious high tea, but was totally put off by the attitude of the staff and the price. 1200¥ for a Coca Cola ... Not ok. I wouldn't recommend going, and it is really out of the way from the buzz. At least high tea was nice!

It's clean and tidy and everyone is very pleasant but it lacks any vibe and the rooms, although well equipped, clean and tidy look a bit dated and old. Bed was ok, facilities were ok, two restaurants and big breakfast area as well as a bar. It has a gym and an outside pool. It's got all the right stuff but just a bit dated and lacking vibe. I wouldn't be upset to stay here again but neither would I be excited. Breakfast was good, plenty of choice and as I had travelled from the UK i was pleased to see breakfast started nice and early.

We are just completing a 6 night stay at the Intercontinental. We have 2 rooms as it is my husband and I and college age sons. We have all thoroughly enjoyed the hospitality and the club room experience here. As other travelers indicate the rooms are small when compared to other hotels (we have stayed at the Tokyo Station and its rooms are larger).The club room experience is fabulous and the service is truly amazing by all. We have enjoyed breakfast, tea and happy hour on different days from the club. The views and spectacular and all service staff are extremely gracious. In particular we have enjoyed the service provided by Yuko and Yuko. We would definitely stay again at this location.

Stayed at ANA Intercontinental Hotel after Christmas for the holiday break and staying in this hotel is worth Located very near the subway, concert halls and great restaurants nearby. Rooms were spacious, bathrooms amenities are replenished daily and English newspaper are delivered in your room everyday. The staff are all friendly and very professional in their work. Being an Spire Royal ambassador was a bonus. Access to the club lounge was extended to us and once you're inside, you'll be relaxed. The lounge space is huge and food selection during the day is superb. If you're going to Tokyo for a business or leisure trip, staying in ANA Intercontinental hotel would be the best choice. Enjoy Japan, enjoy ANA Intercontinental hotel hospitality and friendliness.

Although the location was perfect for my business trip, everything else was pretty average. Intercontinental hotels are supposed to be the highest star of this operator brand but not this ANA Intercontinental. The hotel is very very dated. The hotel needs an upgrade. It felt like staying at a 4 star hotel. The carpets were smelly and old. The rooms very ordinary and old as was the bathroom. Pretty bad for an Intercontinental hotel brand.

Overall people were helpful and service was great. Good location as it's only 2 mins to the entrance leading to subway. It's about 7 mins walk to the ticket machine though. Breakfast on Xmas eve and Xmas day wasn't pleasant they were over crowded and quality was definitely compromised even though 2 restaurants were opened to cater to demand.

I've been to this hotel many, many, many times over the past 15 years, and I have to say it's due for a refurbishment.It is in many ways an old-school business 5-star business hotel. The rooms are functional with a kind of spartan elegance, but not really luxurious in the way, say, Shangri-La hotels can be. Some (if you're lucky) offer a view to Mt Fuji on a clear day. But they are a bit tired... simple things like the lack of international power points, rather dreary soft furnishings, and my personal bugbear - the stupid & ineffective cordless iron - result in a rather "blah" in-room experience.Another particular irritation from previous visits is that they charge guests to use the pool: 4,000 yen per day! (that's about $40...). The hotel is convenient to a number of metro lines, has a range of (very pricey, but great quality) restaurants, is next door to Ark Hills & its selection of restaurants and concert halls, and a short walk to the Akasaka restaurant & business district. I'll be staying there again, but hope that the guest experience can be improved in warmth and depth.

Excellent breakfast!!Room is a little small and regarding the standard in Tokyo, the hotel could get some renovations. However it is in a great area and the staff is very helpfull at all times. The other restaurants are not the best option in Tokyo.

A welcoming lobby and extremely helpful staff at the door and reception. The hotel is very central with the subway station steps away from the hotel. Nice shops and restaurants around the lobby.I booked a standard room and the size of the room was comfortable. However, the carpet was dated and the closet door creaked. Bed was comfortable. The bathroom was cramped and the tiled floor and walls were dated and looked worn down. Amenities included shaver, shaving cream, toothbrush and comb / brush. However, shampoo, conditioner and shower soaps were in a dispenser on the wall next to the tub. One would expect such amenities in tubes and bottles in a five star hotel?Buffet breakfast was wonderful with a variety of selections.Overall a bit below standard for a five star hotel north of $350 per night!

I stayed twice in two weeks for business in December 2016. Before my usual pros and cons, I will write two complaints, which led me to a low grade.I wanted to have a room with a nice view, as this affects my productivity when I have to work in a hotel room (which I had to). I asked a lady at the reception that I want a room with a nice view. Probably she thought a room on a relatively high floor (with the price I pay, the highest floor was 21st I think) is good enough. The view from the room was not good at all. I complained about it, and was told that I might need to pay $60 per night more for a room with a better view. judging from the conversation, I am not sure she knew which room has a better view. Very disappointing experience, for a relatively luxurious hotel ($250-300 range). After the initial (negative) review, I got contacted by somebody in the customer relations but they did not do anything actively. Just told me to contact them. They should have done more actively if they could do something.I think I was told when I checked out of my first stay that they remember my email, name, etc. so that they can accommodate my preferences the next time. I checked in again a couple of days later, but I wasn't informed of anything. Maybe they did adjust to my preferences without telling me but it would have helped that they actually remembered my name as they told me.In the second time I stayed, the bathtub was sort of clogged. It took about 5 min to drain the water when I was taking the shower. Not feeling well for an expensive room. In general, the furniture, and the interior, is old, for the price range.Once I went running and left my running clothes beside the window to dry them. After the daily cleaning, the clothes were moved away from the window.In the end, I think you can do a lot better for the price range of $250-300 per night in Tokyo. I don't think I would stay again. IO say this for the first time for a luxurious hotel in Tokyo.Pros:(1) Location is great, close to Roppongi, Akasaka, Ginza, etc. A lot of restaurants nearby (like 5-10 min walk)(2) Quiet area.(3) Good service in general.(4) Luxurious feeling in the reception area, with multiple bars/restaurants and piano played in the evening.(5) Large room for Tokyo standard(6) Free wifi (you need to sign up with their frequent customer membership)(7) Nice bar on top of the buildingCons(1) Not superb service for the class (see the beginning of my review)(2) Room interior and furniture feel old and depreciated.(3) In general, cabs going in and out of the hotel drive very recklessly. I almost got hit by a cab which did not stop at the stop sign (to get out of the hotel quickly) a couple of times.(4) Maybe the price is different, but the receptionist did not ask me how many keys I need. I was surprised that they did not ask it.Overall, it's not a bad hotel by any means, but for the class ($250-300), you can do a lot better in many other hotels in Tokyo. For the price range, so far the worst in my experiences so far. I am not sure I would come back. Definitely not my first choice in the future.

Stay there in November for a week for a business trip. The rooms are clean and well maintain. Tokyo skyline view is great. Staffs are well trained. Some staffs can speak very good English. Buffet breakfast had a good spread.

This was my third stay at the ANA Intercontinental in Tokyo. I chose it because it is old school - a hotel with everything, that is oriented to foreign business travellers, and where everything works. Location is good US and Australian Embassies, government ministries and of course, firms in the adjacent Ark Hills complex. The big draw here for me is service -- it is genuinely friendly and really world-class. I booked a junior suite for 2 days of business meetings and was upgraded. I appreciated being able to check in 3 hours early and when I mentioned that I had a conference call about to start, there was no problem getting into the room ten minutes before the 12.30pm room availability. The business centre was also fast and flexible. We entertained a business guest in the Karin Chinese restaurant in the hotel and the food and service were flawless.Feeding the team was easy because the hotel connects through to the Ark Hills office complex, which is fully of lunch restaurants, as well as a Starbucks, Dean and Deluca and small supermarket.Depending on your taste, the hotel decor is either charmingly retro or a bit outdated. My suite was very spacious, but the carpet and furnishings needed an overhaul. The gym is well-equipped and spacious. The Thann Spa is less than a year old; its pristine and the massage I had was outstanding, and well-priced for Tokyo.Low points? The breakfast buffet is a little old-fashioned; surely even travelling Americans don't eat donuts for breakfast these days? It is heaving with people and quite noisy, so not an option for a breakfast meeting. But that shortcoming aside, this is still a great hotel. The prices reflect that, but as the Japanese say, the 'cospa' (cost performance) is really good.

Amazing hotel, staff are attentive. Yuko in the club lounge has gone above and beyond and her service is what you look for in great hotels such as the ANA. If you have club access I would suggest the chefs breakfast, it's yummy!

Stayed here for 3 nights in November, had a pleasant stay. The rooms are a bit small but they did their best to accommodate special requests. The concierge staff was very helpful in getting us around Tokyo via the Subway.The hotel is super close to Roppongi and the variety of food, drinks, and entertainment.

Excellent location very close from the subwayRooms are a little small but ok you are in TokyoService is very nice and helpfulNice view from the bar on top floorBreakfast can be very crowded in the morningGood 5 star classic intercontinental

Staying at ANA Intercontinental Tokyo this time made my husband and I so happy. Even we stay for only one night for the 1st stay in this trip. We got a nice room on 20th Fl., maybe renovated one as it looks different from the one we stayed last year.All the hotel staffs are very helpful and courteous. The 1st receptionist (I could not read her name tag) tried to get us a room before check-in time as she knew we may need to take a shower or use the bathroom, quite thoughtful and caring. Unluckily, the room was not ready yet. We told her that we would like to leave our luggages only and then come back in the evening for check-in later. She informed us about the promotion, to get 600 points or 1 welcome drink for this stay which we were in a hurry to JR train station to reserve the seat to Nikko and Hokkaido. She even repeated asking to keep our benefits for this promotion when we told her that we will decide later. Moreover, she also noted in the hotel system that this trip is for my birthday celebration. When we came back to check-in, the 2nd receptionist told us that the room is ready with a birthday cookies (Godiva). This surprisingly exceeded my expectation as I am not the Spire elite holder myself, my husband is. Since I am also another top tier of the other hotel chains like Accor (Platinum) and HHonors (Diamond), only the cardholder would get the birthday gift (other benefits such as drinking water, upgraded room, lounge access, breakfast and evening cocktail here for a free night are not complimentary and automatically provided like the other chains though). Anyway, I guess it is the chain policy, not the hotel itself. What the staffs did is already quite impressive and made me reconsider on choosing IHG for our next leisure trip. We once fell in love with Intercontinental Osaka 2 years ago, by a warm welcome from the door to the room, now we did here again. The room is nice and spacious, compare to others in Tokyo. Only a little thing is the pillows are too flat for us (included a spared one in the closet). If the hotel has a thicker or firmer one or the pillow choices like other IHG hotels in some areas, everything here would be completely perfect. The access from Narita airport to this hotel is quite convenient by Narita airport limousine bus which costs 3,100¥, for round trip only 4,500¥. Just be aware of the subway station access. It is Tameike-sanno, exit 13, the entrance is a few steps from the hotel but no escalator, no lift nearby and the distance to platform is around 500 m. For any traveller who carries a light luggage and businessman who has a pick-up service, this hotel is definitely recommended. Otherwise, should directly checked with the hotel as I may not know the best way.Sadly, we had to check-out in the early morning. So, I have no chance to take the any photo of our room. Will soon do it during my 2nd stay after coming back from Hokkaido.

an awesome 4 nights in the hotel with grandeur service and courteous staff. I see multiple country people come and visit. The Breakfast is lavish and wow, what an options to select. Very centrally located.. Its awesome

I stay here most of the time I'm in Tokyo. Normally an in unbelievable experience. Not this time. Just average. Now average is fine for a Holiday Inn but this is super high end and almost $500 a night for two twin beds. As a Spire level IHG member I normally get an upgrade. I think there was a Dell convention so didn't get anything this time. I get that. The breakfast buffet is pricy at $26 at the discounted rate but as buffets go this one was outstanding. When you check in if they don't offer, as for a discount card or pre pay for breakfast at about $24 if possible. Just make sure you plan on breakfast everyday. Decent location with Roppongi Hills up the street a mile or so and there is a metro station right outside. Bus service to Narita is a available right from the hotel. I guess my main gripe is the price. If they are going to charge $500 for a twin bed, this Intercontental may not see me again.

It has been a while since I last stayed at the ANA Intercontinental and have always booked Club rooms previously. On my most recent stay (a work trip) I was booked into a standard room. The room, whilst perfectly comfortable, was quite tired and in need of refurbishment. The location is very good with a subway station and several stores and restaurants nearby. Staff were friendly and professional.

It is a terrific business hotel. The Narita airport shuttle drops you off directly at the hotel in about 60-75 minutes and from the check-in on, it is a soothing experience. The rooms are very well appointed and comfortable and very business friendly. The multiple common areas are great and even when crowded, the hotel doesn't feel crowded. The basement meeting rooms are also well appointed. I would definitely stay here again for its central location and comfort.
user_name:
rnarisetti
New York City, New York

review_body: This hotel in the center of Tokyo is great for business and leisure use. Good service, friendly staff and super restaurants. Try the kobé beef restaurant on the 36th floor. Finally go for a drink at the MIXX bar at 37th and enjoy the view!

I´m currently business guest at Ana and will stay here alltogether for 7 nights. My company has some contracts with this hotel, so that we preffered are booked in here, acutally don´t know why. The price is around 300 Euros per Night for a standard room, for me it wasn´t possible to get a single room with a Kingsize Bed (non-smoking), I had to choose between small "children"-bed and a smoking-room. In the room is only one European socket, so not really good for working and needing electricity, even more knowing that this single socket is placed in the bathroom. There is no real shower, its a bathtube with old, discolorated shower curtain and a small hand shower. My room is very dusty with unsatisfactory cleanliness, even more knowing the price of 300€ and have been visited already a few 4&5* Hotels private and due to business trips.Its really bad that I make so bad experience with my room, because the first impression of the hotel was very good and also the gym and restraurants look nice, but acutually under this condition I can not unterstand why this is a partner hotel of the company I´m working for, knowing their standards and even more knowing the price they paying. Knowing that I will come now more often I will suggest to look for other parnter hotels as well to have at least the choice to avoid to come back, still hoping and thinking that not everyone of my colleagues made so bad experience, because otherwise the hotel would have been already switched.

A really great hotel in a good location near Roponggi. The hotel has a great choice of restaurants including an excellent steak house and a two star Michelin restaurant . The dinner buffet in Cascade Restaurant was excellent as was the breakfast buffet. there is a great gym and pool in the hotel and rooms are well appointed and clean. as you would expect in Japan, staff are excellent an the hotel is very well run. Special mention to Julian Cole the lobby manager - a gracious and knowledgeable host who is friendly and helpful. I really enjoyed my stay in the ANA intercontinental Tokyo and will return when I visit beautiful Japan again next year.

I stayed her for Business in November and have to remark that the whole experience was fantastic, from the courteous check in service, excellent room and huge selection of Restaurants and Bars which are all of world standard. I was upgraded and had an incredible Night Time View of Tokyo. Having just recently experiencing the terriible Intercontinental in Malta, this was a good reminder of what a world class Hotel should be like. I will be staying here on every visit to Tokyo in future, thank you

You cannot stay in a better place for business than the ANA InterCon. The service was just ok. Not bad. Not great. As a Spire Royal Ambassador, I got a nice upgrade, but I should have been able to check in @ 8am. I arrived @ 1130am, and my room was not ready. I had a 12pm meeting, so they were accommodating to allow me to change and shower in the lounge.I emailed to arrange a ride from the airport, but I got no response, and no ride--- had to take a taxi, which isn't bad, but I prefer the comfort of not having to deal with getting a taxi.The Club InterCon is the best I've seen. Good drinks. Good food. Great view. The only comparison is the InterCon in Pudong China. All in all, I will stay here again, but I expect better service the next time.

Traditional hotel with very high level of service in all areas from check in through check out. Breakfasts are amazing, lounge service and food excellent. Many restaurants and queer meeting areas for small business meetings.

Great service, gym and in-hotel restaurants. Rooms are functional but could do with an upgrade. Direct cheap limo service to and from the airports (Narita & Haneda). Have stayed there six times in the last 18 months and will probably stay there again because of the location, gym and breakfast buffet.

The hotel is nicely positioned near the metro (just a escalator away) and within walking distance of Roppongi. The lobby is great for a relaxing drink and the hotel has a nice diversity of restaurants. Furthermore the skybox offers a tremendous view over the skyline of Tokyo. The rooms are clean and spacious.

Came here after a short stay in Yokohama. This hotel is very close to the Roppongi train station. The building itself is a little bit old, but maintained well.It is a little pricey here. The package I got includes breakfast, but not free wifi. Hotel staff suggest that I joined their member so they will give me free access to wifi....which I did.There is a supermarket at B1 level Many restaurants are located behind, and/or across the hotel. It is also close to the old palace where you can walk around in the morning.

The good- Great location, breakfast is crowded but well run, nice shops/restaurants attached. The not so good- I found the rooms to below standard, in particular the bathrooms need to be refurbished. The staff often seemed rushed (maybe overwhelmed) with a few notable exceptions.
user_name:
N8463SBjimg
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: The Hotel was very clean and the rooms were spacious and had all gadgets. Meals looked very nice but were a little expensive. There were a few eateries and bars near by.The people in Japan are soooo friendly and will help you if you get lost. The only negative was that we had to pay extra if we wanted to use the pool which we thought would be in with the price.

I have only stayed here and at the Royal Park hotel in Tokyo. This is more luxurious. The staff are the usual excellent Intercontinental standard. Good english spoken by everybody from the taxi guy to the accountant.Rooms are large, for Japanese standards. This place has been upgraded in the past few years whereas the Park Royal is tired, in a faded glory sort of way.I have not really explored but there is a Tokyo Metro stop about 100m from the front door so you could get anywhere from here.

Style is quite outdated, but it delivers clearly what a five star stands for. Wonderful breakfast, all frills, rooms are very well taken care of. The view we had from 31 floor was great. Very conveniently located to go anywhere in Tokyo. Very good service. The hotel pool is outside, and there is no spa, hence my 4 stars.

Loved the food festival by award winning and designer chefs - everyday breakfast was an experience of Japanese cuisine and from different area.Liked the service abs accessibility to all transportLocker room and extended service was commendable

Well, the title explained why I couldn't give it a full rate.I exchanged my IHG points for one reward night in this hotel, and paid extra to upgrade to a Junior Suite for bigger room.The most luxurious part of this hotel locates in its lobby. When I arrived, I was initially told that my room was a Classic room, which was the type you can use your points for one free night reward. However, I did fill up the upgrade system while I booked this reservation, the staff afterward found that my room should be a Junior Suite (and I confirmed it again).The room was spacious, despite the decor was a bit outdated. It was not exact the same decorations shown in those pictures on their official website, so well I guess it was my bad luck that I got assigned an unrenovated room because basically the layout was pretty the same. However, I still think it is worth of these extra money, for nearly double the space and late check-out time until 2 pm.The service was good, not that kind of Park Hyatt, The Ritz-Carlton, or Conrad good I've ever encountered in Tokyo, but more enthusiastic and helpful than The Strings by InterContinental, which is also within this hotel chain. Worth a try, but don't expect it to be a luxury one.

Went for a business trip , the location is great and views of Tokyo and Tokyo tower are great. The service is good and facilities and good really nice. Would definitely stay there again, the only concern is the cost

I arrived with my colleague one hour after the 3 pm check in time and the room was not ready, which I find inexcusable. We had an event to attend and a short time frame. The front desk receptionist had absolutely no answers other than apologizing. Horrible service! On top of that, the room was tired and in need of an update. Unbelievably bad.

We stayed here for a week in October and we really had the perfect stay! This hotel has a good location, there are many nice restaurants for both breakfest and dinner close to the hotel (in addition to all the options you will find inside the hotel). The staff was great and the rooms were spacious with a good view of the city! Loved the bar at the top floor.

Really good experience here. Property is a bit old school Tokyo hotel but everything really went well. Efficient pleasant check in, good clean room with queen sized bed, good WiFi, lots of food and beverage adjacent and one train stop or short cab from Roppongi. Breakfast was especially good. Transportation to Narita via limousine bus is non stop. Can buy tickets at front desk and travel desk in small room off ground floor motor lobby. As you would expect in Japan 5 star service was flawless.

I stayed here for just one night on a short business trip. I really enjoyed the place. It's great especially if you are an American business traveler. The staff were top notch. The hotel itself was beautiful. I had lunch at their restaurant and was very pleased although I thought the international breakfast was exceptionally good for the price. I would definitely stay here again.

I've been to Tokyo more than 5 times now and I have had the chance to stay in different hotels but nothing compares to when I stay at the ANA Intercontinental.ROOMSThe best part of the room is its very comfortable bed and pillows! When staying overseas, it is most ideal to find a hotel that gives you the most comfortable sleep you can get. The rooms may need a little bit of updating but for me it suits me fine. FOODBreakfast at the Cascade Cafe is a highlight of our day! The staff at the cafe is courteous and attentive. Food has a very good variety and everything tastes good. You can see how much they put effort in quality.STAFFCourteous and attentive for all our needs. They always serve with a smile!LOCATIONThe hotel is very close by the Haneda airport so coming and going is a breeze. The hotel is situated near top spots and is very close by one of the train stations. Unfortunately since this is a business trip I was not able to go around and check all their amenities.All in all, I would recommend this hotel to anyone looking for a good place to stay in Tokyo. It may be more expensive than other hotels but you get your money's worth. :)

Central location and walking distance to many eating areasBe aware of the cost of using the swimming pool $120 Australian for 2 people each timeVery good express Limosine Bus service from the hotel to Narita Airport for a reasonable cost

You know there's a comfort, cleanliness, and location standard when staying at most Intercontinental hotels especially one in Tokyo. The ANA Intercontinental lived up to all of the standards that I look for when booking a hotel, especially cleanliness, friendliness of staff and location. You can tell the hotel was built a while ago but everything inside has been updated more than most newly built ones. It's big with a lovely lobby cafe, a few hotel shops and a convenience store 2 mins. away. The staff is so friendly, as with most Japanese, and will try to accommodate you in any way they can. The location is very good since it's in the very central and expat area of Roppongi. Many stations are a 5 min. walk from the hotel and cabs are easy to find.Would definitely stay here again for its value and comfort and would recommend it especially for first-time visitors.

I recently stayed at this hotel. The rooms are large for Tokyo and comfortable although the decor is a little dated. Breakfast is excellent. My partner broke his leg (not at the hotel) during our stay and the concierges could not have been more helpful. I was very relieved to be staying in a hotel where people were able and willing to help me with arrangements and translations.

If you're looking for a cheap, small or intimate hotel, this isn't it! The ANA Intercontinental is however a big, super well run and organised hotel providing impressive facilities and lovely quiet and well appointed rooms. The staff are all exceptionally friendly and the whole show runs like clockwork, from smooth check-in to military style breakfast....I loved it! Arriving after a 32 hour travel/working day, what I wanted most was to get to my room, shower, eat and sleep....and this was all done with minimum of fuss. As an existing Gold Elite card holder, I was bumped up two levels on my originally booked room (thank you ANA). I had room service on my first evening, which was quick, tasty and piping hot. As already indicated, the room was very well equipped with everything catered for and it's been a long time since I've slept as well...nice and quiet and an air-con unit that didn't sound like an Airbus 380 landing...well done! My only niggle...and I'm struggling to find one, is that feather pillows are damn uncomfortable...the option of foam filled would be appreciated. Other than that, I stayed 4 nights and I can't fault it! Good location too!

The trouble with Japan is that it has set its own bar so high that my expectation is more exacting than it would be for any other place. We are frequent visitors to Japan so I guess we have become accustomed to a certain style and quality of service. This hotel provides professionalism with none of the warmth that one expects from Japanese hospitality. The check in service was thorough and efficient but the wait was long and the staff were not apologetic. A lot of the attention was given to the IHG Rewards members (we are not members) so we did feel a little 'dismissed'. Now for the rooms: the size was great - much larger than the average Japanese room. The bed was a little lumpy and saggy, probably needed a new mattress? The pillow was very disappointing - it was literally a deflated lump. There were little signs of wear and tear everywhere so the hotel is probably due for an upgrade. The room wasn't cheap but it is located in the business district so you get a lot of restaurants, cafes, two subway lines (the Namboku line and the Ginza Line) within walking distance and it is also walking distance to Roppongi, for the nightlife. The breakfast was very good. The selection was impressive and my eggwhite omelette was cooked to perfection. The hotel is not for me personally but it's not a bad place to stay, especially if you are in Tokyo for work or if you are an IHG member.

Stayed in this hotel during recent business trip. Hotel is very close to multiple metro stations so easy to get around. There are couple of coffee shops around as well as Starbucks.
