Area is not very touristy but walling for 10 minutes gets you to busy streets with lots of restaurants. Room was not big but good for Japanese hotel. Everything was clean and comfortable. TV has only several English channels - rest are Japanese. Everyone is very friendly and accommodating. Being a Hilton diamond member as well as IHG SPIRE I was somewhat disappointed with not getting much at Intercontinental (no complimentary breakfast or lounge access as in Hilton). I guess I will need to pick another hotel chain next year to collect points at.

First impressions were that this was a smart, upmarket hotel, it became apparent quite quickly that this was on the surface. although staff were efficient there was very little of the warmth and welcome that we'd experienced in a similar quality of hotel in Kyoto. The location is probably fine for business - it is very well serviced by taxis and is just a few steps from a subway station (although getting to the line that goes to Tokyo station is a km walk underground). There is little in the way of restaurants in the vicinity and it is very quiet at night. The decor is, as other reviewers have commented, quite dated and tired but the room was a reasonable size. Our main gripe was the cost of food and drink with even a basic coffee costing 1200 Yen (around £10 at the time of writing).We wouldn't stay here again and we wouldn't recommend this hotel for people on holiday.

Stayed 4 nights in a King Bed Premier Room on 28th floor with a view of the Tokyo Tower. Room was fine for us although not large. Service was good. We found we could walk to Ginza for shopping and Tokyo Tower from hotel. If going on an organised tour this hotel is on the free pick-up list avoiding the hassle of finding the coach station.Several restaurants and bars nearby to supplement those in the hotel. Most important of all were the staff. As you would expect in Japan they were very helpful and always smiling. Indeed, they made our first trip to Japan a memorable one. We were pleased we made the right choice of hotel for us.

Having stayed at this hotel the last few times in Tokyo, this trip did not live up to the experience of previous stays. Check in was disorganized. I was unable to get an after work drink with clients since tables were reserved for tea even though tables remained empty. Breakfast was a mad house (not the hotels' fault) and I wound up seated in the way back - the smoking section. No smokers, thankfully, but the smell lingered from the night before. As others have said, the rooms are a little dated. That being said, it's still a great location, very close to Hibiya Park and the Imperial Palace. The Palace is a great place for a morning run (~1mile from the hotel).

In the centre of everywhere you need to be and very close to trains. On the Ginza line. Rooms are clean and cosy with fabulous views. Sad they allow smoking. Good breakfast buffet. Very friendly staff.

I stayed at the ANA for the first time, given we had meetings with the government 15 walking minutes away. I liked the hotel, as it had everything I needed. Room on the 25th floor had nice views, but was very small; no nightstand. The tiny room layout was functional though. Bathroom lacked good lighting and magnifying mirror for shaving; water pressure of shower was good. Internet speed was fine. The breakfast buffet was exceptional, and service prompt. Check-in and -out were fast (faster than at the Imperial where I stayed the last time), although the staff at check-out was a bit difficult to understand.Location is excellent, with good subway connections to anywhere in Tokyo.
user_name:
SGECHAMPION
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Its 10 minutes to walk to roppongi where are a lot of clubs and bars. Also the metro station directly in front. Rooms nice and big. A lot of (expensive) restaurants in the hotel but small shops and restaurants at the corner.

a late post since i'd been here on May 2015, but still a good memories remain:)Location is great, close to roppongi hills and downtown tokyo. i love to go to convinience stores when in Japan and i found many close to the hotel.found a small street full of small restaurants close to this hotel where i can feel the ambience of being a true japannese.the hotel is tipical western type, lobby is big, and since i came with a huge group (almost 15 busses), it shows that their check in service was just great. all smooth and easy.Breakfast was good and no issue of them handling huge group.the room is good and i can enjoy the city lights.Recommended for those who wants to enjoy Tokyo.

The hotel is very old, not old fashioned, but outdated. This especially applies to the bedrooms. The carpeting and bedding seem old and so do the bathroom fixtures. The hotel is not good value for money both in terms of room rates and f&b. However, its an excellent and convenient location with plenty of dinning options in the next door Ark Hills and Izumi Gardens and good transportation access to two train stations and several supermarkets. The conseirge is probably the best of the hotel services. The hotel selected TV channels have a good selection of English channels which is rare for Japan.

The location is very good, and you can walk to Roppongi hills or midtown within 15 minutes. There are convenience stores and supermarkets and you can get the drinks or snack just either across the street or in next building compound. The room size is quite spacious and clean. With this hotel, i have experience to share. I checked in around 2 o'clock in the afternoon, and i requested for the room with view of Tokyo tower. The reception told me the room would be ready at 4, and she mentioned that i would only see the tower on the right side of window. Unfortunately, when i went to my room, and tried to locate the tower, there was no such thing. I think the reception needed to know if the room has Tokyo tower view or not. Otherwise, they disappointed the guests.

Stayed in ANA intercontinental during the second week of Oct. Location is excellent. Just in downtown Tokyo. All the Tokyo attractions are near by including offices, Tokyo tower which are just in walking distance. Excellent transport facility from both Narita and Haneeda airports. Views from the rooms are excellent especially rooms with Tokyo tower views. Staff are excellent. Always will be there to help you. But food rates in the restaurants are little bit exorbitant. But we have several restaurants and food courts near by. Also management should take care of replacing the old sofas and mattresses in the rooms.

We recently stayed at the ANA Intercontinental with our for two year old for two weeks while moving into our Tokyo home. The hotel is very large with an expansive lobby. You'll enjoy the plentiful buffet offered at the main lobby restaurant and there is also a fantastic bakery located on the main level as well. Our room was a Junior Suite which the perfect amount of space for our family throughout the stay. The bathroom is impressive, large tub & shower area and luxe amenities (bathrobes and pajamas) are provided. I particularly enjoyed the doors which closed off the bedroom to the sitting area, so that if our toddler was napping we could comfortably hang out and watch TV, work, etc in the other room. The only downside for this room is that the bathroom is located through the sleeping area. The sitting area houses a desk, dry bar, small sofa with coffee table and tv. The room is definitely worth booking if you need (or just want) the extra space. We had a view of the pool and general city. Curtains can be controlled by bedside which is fun and useful! The club lounge is really great at this hotel. The breakfast is extensive and you can enter anytime of day for NA drinks and fast concierge service. Additionally, the appetizer service in the evening with drinks is quite extensive as well. There is also a light tea service mid day as well. I highly recommend it, the staff is very friendly and happy to assist with any needs you may have. Generally, service here is good, the housekeeping is a bit different than what you'll encounter in the US. By that I mean that the room is cleaned however, let's say you leave your ironing board out, it stays out. If a half full soda is left out, it will be there when you return. I get the sense that this is normal here as the room was extensively cleaned elsewhere but just something to note. The gym is bright and has a variety of equipment for those traveling. The biggest plus to this hotel is the outdoor pool, great for families as they have a separate kid pool as well. We stayed in August and the pool got very crowded as some locals have a membership. There is an additional fee for the pool, be prepared for that if you plan to use it. Overall, we enjoyed our stay. It's a great hotel for families with many amenities and attached to Ark Hills for shopping and restaurants. The hotel is also close to Roppongi Hills and Midtown.

Stayed 5 nights. Great location - easy to get trains. Great concierge service for restaurants and an english guide. Buffet breakfast awesome. Room was a pretty good size for a standard in Japan but that said cushions and decor tired. Hall way to room over heated and carpet in urgent need of cleaning. So room great but getting to room not so great. Gym - not big enough for busy period as simply did not have enough equipment for weight and space for hand weights. Outdoor pool area very tired. Good value mid tier Intercontinental. Free internet was fast and a welcome bonus as we could have unlimited devices signed up (or at least 6)

Hi there, it is a nice and clean hotel with good restaurants (especially Steakhouse).Staff is welcoming. Room cleaning is good.Laundry is returned same day which is nice for travelers. However, there are too few sitting arrangements in the lobby. You have to go to Cascade (restaurant in the lobby). Smoking room is tiny and also have no place to sit.

A massive hotel, connected to a small shopping center and just 5 minutes away from a train station. Had couple of nice bars and restaurants on the top floor & i think one of them was a Michelin star restaurants. Rooms were old fashioned & desperately need updating. Breakfast buffet was good however the room service menu was a disappointment. Overall stay was comfortable.

I rented a king deluxe room for 3 nights. Likes: staff, lobby, bars, location and cost. Worth noting: the staff is exceptional. Everyone was very friendly and helpful and tolerated my 2nd grade Japanese. Dislikes: bathroom was tiny. Instant coffee I the room. No berries at the breakfast buffet (i know it's minor but should be there). Also wish the gym / spa had a steam room and more amenities. Overall I'd recommend it as a quality alternative to higher priced peers.

Stayed for a month in this hotel and it was very good. Professional and accommodating, luxury hotel. This is where I will always come back. Direct transfer from airport and excellent resturants, close to everything including metro. Most staff speak english.

Last night tonight of a 7 day stay. Perfect location near Roppongi Hills and walking distance to the Imperial Park and to Ginza. It is a fair stretch, but very possible (did it today).Luxurious hotel, extremely clean and nice rooms. Very nice staff.Great selection of good bars and restaurants at the hotel, tried several and all were good. Special mention to the two jazz musicians at the Da Vinci bar; they were very good!Stayed at the Mandarin Oriental last year, location at the InterContinental is better and to be fair: the hotel is priced better. Nothing can fault the Mandarin Oriental but it is not worth twice the price.... (although, visit "The Pizza Bar on 38th floor" there, magical pizza!)So nothing wrong at the ANA InterContinental? Yes there was one thing. The Concierge desk. Staying for a week it would be nice to utilize the Concierge desk, but sadly no. There is one, but with only one person working there and a constant line of people waiting it wasn´t worth waiting for me. If you are reading this IHG, make it better!

It was not my first stay in this hotel and I can honestly say that this is my favorite hotel on the planet :-) I like everything about it. The location, comfort, great staff, amazing breakfast and nice restaurants with amazing views. And of course the parfum when you enter, it is like an addition.

First-class hotel in central Tokyo with comfortable rooms, a 5-star, 5-continent breakfast, easy transport access and lots of life around the hotel. I come here often. Good internal restaurants and health club.

The rooms are good and the bed is very comfortable, and the location is very convenient, but what blew me away was the level of service in the Executive Lounge. A lot of lounges prepares a very average breakfast buffet, but here you could choose from a menu and enjoy freshly prepared eggs (Scrambled, poached, fried etc) with a choice of salmon, bacon and sausages, pancakes, etc etc. Very delicious. In the afternoon there is afternoon tea with a very delicious tray of sandwiches and various sweets, and in the evening there is drinks and tapas. The staff has a very high standard. The lounge itself is spacious and comfortable, and the internet connection is very fast.

visited the ANA several times since 2012, very fiendly, customer oriented Hotel at a perfect Location. The gym is just awesome, perfect for a Jet laged traveler. Never ate there, there are many Restaurants in the Close vincinity. The Restaurant Prices in the Hotel Restaurants are very high.

I checked in along with a business group at 20:00. I Booked single classic room.Reception was professional but rigid not as usual Japanese kindness. I requested double room and she mentioned she has only twin which was annoying when you are solo and have to sleep with other empty bed in your room. After a while and me insisting, she went to consult another colleague, she mentioned she can shift me next day to double room. Unfortunately she shifted me to smaller room! Bug shame but didn't make a fuss, since wouldn't keep changing more. Check in took too long i don't know why but the lady seems little confused. During my short expirence in japan they usually make everything ready before you show up, i showed up 5 hours after check in and that wasnt the case. The lobby is awesome with modern decoration -First Room 1232, good size , specious, classical furniture little old, clean and well kept, bathroom had rust and mold in corners. Big big shame.-second room 1224: small in size classical furniture and the same bad condition of bathroom!!-View from both rooms was not worth it-Tv is offering 2 english channels but weren't entertaining, but i was grateful they can lend you dvd player for free :-) -internet wifi was so good-breakfast is awesome, great selection of everything and the staff are lovely, i would like to compliment the egg station chef for his awesome job :-)I think the hotel is making good use of his old legacy as well known hotel and didnt renovate rooms and bathroom because of that. Big shame for international chain and for the value of money.

For such a highly rated hotel, I was severely disappointed. No slippers. No free bottled water. Wifi was on the slower side. Room was very small. Good for those on a budget, I suppose. The common areas are huge... service was excellent though they have a lot more people to serve as it seems there are wedding banquets and such to host. Nice farmer's market on the weekends in the adjoining court, and a great nondescript sushi restaurant next door, but the room is disappointing.
user_name:
vacationsy
New York City, New York

review_body: This hotel is a reasonable distance from Haneda airport and very conveniently located in Tokyo. An entry to the subway is just a few meters from the hotel but it is a slightly long walk to actually get to the trains. Nonetheless, the proximity to a subway entrance is a nice plus. The public areas are very welcoming and comfortable. There are numerous excellent restaurants and bars on site including one by Pierre Gagnaire. Several of these establishments are on higher floors and have spectacular views. If you prefer not to go out, room service was prompt and made up for the somewhat average food on their all day menu. I would definitely consider staying here again if I return to Tokyo!

I am currently in Japan on business and I try to stay in hotels that provide amenities for business purposes. This hotel not only provides this but also provides an environment to relax and feel at home from the stresses of doing business, Its overal facilities are great and the customer service is exceptional. If you can get a room on the upper levels it will provide great views of this fantastic city.

This hotel is the perfect balance of location and quality. Rooms were very spacious for Tokyo given the price point. Navigating the city your first time could be a terror and choice of this hotel was very wise: 5 minutes walk to Nobu, 10 minutes to Roppongi and directly ontop of two major metro lines. Also, the sky bar is fantastic spot to wait for friends and have a drink before the night out.

I really like this downtown hotel. The rooms are always clean and the bed is comfortable. The bathroom amenities are plentiful if you have forgotten something. One great thing for a US traveler is every front line employee speaks good english. The lunch buffet is pricey by US standards but reasonable for the location and offers a great selection. There are many great pubs and restaurants within a 10-15 minute walk.

Not a huge fan of large chains, but being in Tokyo and having the traditional high level of Japanese hospitality during our stay made this hotel stay enjoyable. The access to the executive lounge is the key. That simple oasis to relax and be a living space away from you smaller quarters is perfect. The staff at the lounge were perfect! Extremely helpful and accommodating. The hotel is close to Roppongi/Minato area for evening entertainment and restaurants. It is a quick 10 to 15 min taxi ride to Ginza or Omotesando and Shibuya area. It is very close (5 min walk) to the Ginza line train stop if you want to brave the Tokyo metro system.

This hotel is beautiful and located in the heart of the city!There are several great restaurants in the restaurant and the Mixx Lounge of the 36th floor has incredible views of Tokyo and Mount Fuji in the distance!The rooms are spacious and comfortable.The staff is friendly and prompt. Whatever we needed the staff was there for us.We will certainly stay here again!
user_name:
TravelingGuyfromDC
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: I had never been to Japan or Asia and was feeling overwhelmed by the hotel choices. This place turned out to be perfect. It is in a excellent walkable location, and the staff is fantastic. The hotel restaurants and bar are also very good.

Near public transit & the train station·Near the city center; shopping & sightseeing nearby·Easily accessible by car and we appreciated the friendly, professional staff I recommend this hotel for a relaxing weekend

Beautiful Hotel in Akasaka located between the Tameike Sanno and Roppongi Itchome subway stations. Next to the Ark Hills building which has numerous bars and restaurants. A short walk to the Roppongi district. Very nice, comfortable large rooms. Excellent breakfast Buffett.

Checked yesterday @ 6.30am after a long flight. Lucky we were able to bring our check in time forward to 11am instead of 3 pm. So, we left our luggage and ventured out. The concierge was very helpful and spoke good English. The metro system was easy and convenient to,use and is right on the hotels doorstep. Breakfast at the hotel is very expensive and very shocked to be informed that to use the pool we would have to pay 4000 yen p.p. Even being a Platimun Elite customer has no advantages here. Every where else in the world this status means something and you get some benefits. So basically after a busy day in Tokyo, unless you are prepared to pay a rediculous charge for a relaxing time by the pool ..forget it! Now looking forward to our cruise and staying at the Hilton on the way back for a bit of lost relaxation!

It was my first visit to Japan and I stayed in this hotel more than 10 days. I was with my wife. This hotel was very high tech inside out. The food was very good. The service was great. Our room was in one of the highest floors. The view of the tall buildings was very impressive and nice. Our room was a suite and the living area was very comfortable. The staff of the hotel are very friendly and multi language speaking staff. The one thing I did not like in the room was the street voices can be heard from our high floor room. Have a great trip and best regards. Dr SD 2016.

Fabulous high end hotel. Spotless and efficient . Good sized rooms with excellent facilities. . Food outstanding in buffet. Chocolate fountains a real bonus! Great location for Tokyo sightseeing as out of the noisy city but a metro station literally on the door step allowing excellent travel to wherever you wanted to go! Good local places to eat close by too!

Liked this place a lot, lovely big room and comfy bed. Found the proximity to VERY LOUD tourists at breakfast rather grating so recommend earplugs or itunes...appreciated the refectory style seating for those of us not LOUDLY discussing what to sight see for the day.Really enjoyed my stay, especially bumping into a certain touring rugby team...the only thing I didn't appreciate was a mystifying lift and floor numbering system which meant I never actually managed to see the pool, or the sky bar place which was apparently lovely. Perhaps I should have asked someone! Service was great, but remember folk can smoke in certain bar areas so ask to seat elsewhere it was no problem. Handy for the business district I was working in, and generally speaking if you have to be so far from home on your own this place made it way nicer.

We have enjoyed our 4 days in Tokyo at the Ana Intetcontinental and we leave today to continue our trip. The staff is super accomodating and the concierge is a big help for first time visitors who need help with transportation and local sights. The 7 -11 next door is convenient for snacks and bakery. The breakfast buffet is excellent and the Mixx on floor 36 has excellent views. Take the metro right outside the door to all the sights.Express bus to and from Narita airport is great and brings you tight to the door. Don't miss Shibuya Crossing.

The ANA Intercon in Tokyo is a decent hotel if you're in town and are looking to be somewhere within walking distance to shops and restaurants but not right in the middle of the busiest parts of Tokyo. It's close to the subway, with Roppongi being the closest station, and there are always taxis ready to whisk you anywhere you need to be in the city. The hotel itself is pretty standard in comparison to any other big hotel. There is a big lobby and check in and everything else seems to be relatively impersonal. Staff were helpful, but as a whole seemed to be missing the warmth that other hotels might focus on. Room was a decent size by Tokyo standards, bathroom amenities were nice and the bed was comfortable. It did feel like the room needed a deep cleaning but I'm not sure if it was just my room though.I did not eat at the restaurants in the hotel, but I will say the prices for a coffee if you were to sit in the lobby were exorbitant. 12 USD for drip and 14 for a caramel latte. That is a little too steep even when considering it's in a hotel. I did grab coffee and pastries in the morning at the french bakery in the shopping arcade attached to the lobby and those prices were much more reasonable; just too bad the hours are limited. The ANA Intercontinental is not a bad option, but there are a lot of other options in Tokyo at a similar price point that are just as good, if not better.

A high class 5* hotel with all the trappings one should expect at this level. The room was a good size with armchairs and ample clothes storage. It was provided with coffee and tea-making facilities and all the usual extras (robes, slippers etc etc.). The bathroom is well appointed, though the shower is the in-bath type, albeit of good quality. As befits this kind of international class 5* hotel there are numerous restaurants and shops. It is very well located, about 15 minutes’ walk from the Imperial Palace and, more to the point, just a minute or two from stops giving four lines on Tokyo’s unnervingly efficient metro system. It is also next door to the Suntory concert hall. The breakfast buffet is top class and comprehensive, though a queue can form at weekends. The view from the buffet area breakfast is of overhead roads and passing traffic - but this is central Tokyo. The only reservation is price. If you are being paid for or lashing out then it is a superb hotel. For Europeans on any other basis it is expensive. There is a pool, but like many Japanese hotels this charges even for hotel residents, and at nearly £30 per person per day the fee is ridiculous and prohibitive. We didn’t even contemplate using the pool at this price and one wonders if this kind of pricing is counter-productive, though it is not unusual in Japan. In sum an absolutely top class hotel, well located, but priced at the top end too.
user_name:
europtraveller
Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom

review_body: It's located close to train and bus stations so you can avoid walking or taking a cab. Service is excellent. We faced a problem with our credit cards and reception staff was really patient,polite and helpful. Food is great but expensive. Room view is fantastic but does not compare with the view from the bar on the top.

I travel a lot and use intercontinental as it has the best city locations for my needs and I have to say that ANA InterContinental at Roppongi is the best run hotel I've been to. The staff are attentive, Quick and understands a business traveler's needs from a leisure one. I'd like to call out Satomi San from guest relations as a person of amazing warmth and utmost efficiency; I had an urgent event I had to attend in Tokyo and she helped me attain my old room without breaking a sweat under a high occupancy situation. Rock on guys and I'll see you next month

Super close to multiple train lines so you can get anywhere in the city easily. Probably the best part is the airport bus that leaves from the lower lobby daily to Narita. Food is a bit expensive, so I usually hit up a convenience store for breakfast. Rooms are nice, spacious and some have great views of the city.

This property is large; with a lot of restaurants and bars. The rooms are good sized as compared to similar hotels. The location requires you to catch a taxi, or walk to the metro; as there isn't a lot going on in the neighborhood surrounding the hotel. There is a good view of the city from the Mixx bar, and the staff there were very friendly. Overall it is a good hotel for business travelers, and I would stay here again depending on the price.

I have been travelling extensively for the last decade for both business and pleasure and hold elite status for a number of hotel & airline groups. Having stayed at Intercontientals in various countries in all corners of the world I know its always great to be staying at one of their properties. Staff are very friendly and efficient and the concierge was very helpful, but I didn't expect anything less and didn't experience no less in other hotels when I was travelling through Japan. What outraged my wife and me was that as a luxury business hotel they charge for their fitness and pool facility. $40 per person!! This is just outrages and have never come across something at any hotel. Even small hotels who don't have the facilities have arranged for free gym access in the local neighboorhood. This is not something I expect from the IHG Group. For the same rate there are many other options in Tokyo!

A very, very typical, run-of-the-mill, business hotel. Everything is efficient, and a bit on the pricey side. Rooms are typical Tokyo: small! Even if you are upgraded - small! The shower room is especially on the smaller side. And don't expect a free upgrade - again typical IHG property. Hotel is generally very clean.Service is good; - respectful and efficient, impersonal, restrained-smiles, and certainly don't expect any empathy. The hotel maybe too big (in terms of number of rooms) for its own good.The top floor bar is well stocked - on the pricey side, and again, impersonal.It has a great location going for it.

The hotel provides all amenities needed for a tourist e.g. electric cattle, mini bar, toiletries, electric iron, etc. The breakfast buffet is wholesome and well laid with enough space to move around with very pleasant staff.The front desk has mix of smiling and happy people with some not so smiling but hardly any one can be found who lacks famous Japanese politeness.The rooms have varying shapes. The L shaped rooms are not very convenient and pose difficulty in movement to bathrooms. The hotel has an exchange ATM which does not offer great exchange rate (Ginza is a place where you can get better rates) but also has ATM to withdraw money and my forex card from India worked there.On the week ends hotel has some events of music which are pretty enjoyable. The lobby has less seating area than needed for such a big hotel.The surrounding area has lots of eateries and metro station is nearby.wifi is now free and fast :)Overall great experience !

I simply adored this hotel - clean, close to public transportation, taxis always present, many good restaurants at walking distance, great service and helpful staff, excellent bar at the top with great view of Tokyo. What more do you need? First time for me, but definitely not the last - I will use this hotel every time I am in Tokyo.

The friendly and efficient staff made a four night stay in the ANA Intercontinental Tokyo into a good visit. From check-in, to concierge, bars and restaurants all staff deserve 5 stars for all aspects of the service. The room was acceptable, although upon entering the accommodation for the first time there was a slightly unpleasant odour, as if the room had not been aired for some time. This created a disappointing first impression, but was remedied by the excellent air conditioning. Overall the decor of the room was a bit tired looking. Food was good, with a superb collection to suit all tastes. Great location, convenient to the Metro, which as you might expect in Japan is excellent. Five star staff and good food, let down by the accommodation - a pity.

We stayed here in Mar '16 for 10 nights and had a very pleasant stay. The rooms are a good size and although a bit dated, they are very clean and well presented. Bathrooms (mainly shower) could possibly use an upgrade.The hotel seems to cater mainly to business guests and is laid out accordingly. From our perspective (we were on a holiday) it's deceivingly well connected to the metro system as the entrance to the subway is just below the hotel. The Asakusa area is obviously not as buzzing as some of the other parts of Tokyo however still has plenty of dining and drinking options. We also loved the meal at the Pierre Gagniere on top of the hotel which had a fantastic views and simply superb food. The room service menu also allows you to order from the other restaurants in the hotel, some of which are of a very high standard. Breakfast was the usual but had a large offering.Staff was always courteous and the health club and spa at the hotel is fantastic.

Stayed 5 nights in this hotel with my husband. Check in went smoothly. Received an upgrade to a Superior Room due to the Ambassador status. Beds are comfortable, bathroom adequate (with lovely shower). Wide choice of food during breakfast. We had dinner in the steakhouse one night. Lovely food, great service however slightly on the expensive side. There is indeed a pool charge -even for guests- as the hotel cannot accommodate for everyone since they have 900 rooms, which is somewhat awkward but understandable I guess. Small issue with a staff member re her attitude but this got resolved by the front office manager in a very courteous and professional manner. I would certainly return to this hotel and would recommend it to others without reservation.

Top quality service, very accommodating and made us feel welcome when we were halfway around the world. We had the included breakfast and enjoyed having a vast variety of both asian, fruit, pastry and salad options for every morning. They had my latte and hot chocolate for my husband. They even had crispy bacon which is rare outside the US.

Ana interconti is not just great to be at they have the best buffet and breakfast spread.They have a well heated pool and charge a bomb!!Again being in tokyo...we need to understand space isnt cheap anywhere in the city.Thank god for the helpdesk else finding Bic camera store would have been tuff!!

Their club lounge on floor 35 is great for meetings. I didn't actually stay at the hotel, but I used their club lounge for a couple of days. Overall I'll say that their club lounge is way better than the overall outdated feeling of the rest of the hotel.Their complementary buffet breakfast has everything you need. The hotel itself might not be as luxurious as other hotels in Tokyo but it has covered all the basics right.

+clean room and comfy bed.+good selection of pillows.+very friendly and helpful staff.+envious friendly bulk shampoo and shower gel dispenser in the the shower area.+very good collection of Amenities.+fast room service and very good quality of food.+good location close to the metro station.- armchair in the rooms is old and need change.-toilet area is very small.

The service staff was great. Arrived on a Sunday night and needed help to get dinner. They have a nice one pager to point me to where and what food to go for.The room was nice and comfortable. Didnt get the chance to use the pool as it was during winter.

Beautiful hotel with efficient staff. Most clients they have are mostly business travellers so the ambience is quite and clean. The lobby looks elegant too. 7:11 shop is just right below so it's east to buy last minute stuff that you need. The location of the hotel is not bad as well. We can see the tokyo tower from our window and it's beautiful at night! Hope to come back here one day soon

The hotel is really getting old. I am not talking about the lobby, which truly has a 90s feeling (but it's still charming). The room is alright, very clean, but the bathroom looks a bit tired, and is not marvelous.However, the perfect service makes up for the rest, and the staff made everything easier and pleasant.I don't really like the location, it's very calm since it's a heavy business district so it's quite dead in August. But thanks to the metro, nothing is really too far away.Free internet for IHG members.

We were very well looked after at the Intercontinental - welcoming staff, great breakfast buffet, the best outdoor pool in Tokyo (I think), good sized rooms, very helpful concierge. Expensive, but then so is everything in this crazy town. The kids loved it and are now thoroughly spoiled.

We have stayed at the ANA several times now as we visit Japan annually. The rooms are a little dated but very comfortable and quite large for Tokyo. They include lots of little extras in the toiletries which is nice. The airport shuttle departs directly from here which is really convenient and it is a short walk to the train station. The staff are lovely.

Tokyo was our first stop for our honeymoon trip. This hotel really enhanced our experience of Tokyo and Japan! It is located very near Akasaka which is a really cool neighborhood with lots of shops, malls, restaurants and bars. The metro station is half a block from the hotel so its really great for a tourist to move around tokyo having a metro station nearby.We stayed here for 4 nights and we got a nice suite. They size of the room was ok and the view too; however, my wife and I spent most of the day out getting to know and enjoying tokyo.The buffet breakfast is something we really enjoyed. It is a bit pricy but the food is delicious so i felt it was worth it. The staff is very friendly and welcoming and the room service is fast (15min wait).We hope to be back in Tokyo in the near future and stay here again.

Went to The Steakhouse restaurant at Ana Hotel with a friend and had char-grilled fillet of King salmon and asked to change the potatoes for asparagus! It was a super reasonable price ¥2,900, considering it was dinner in a hotel in Tokyo! Definitely will come back!

If this neighborhood suits you, I'd say the ANA is an ok hotel alternative. But what it misses is any real sense of Tokyo or Japanese culture and hospitality. You could easily be staying in any generic city in the world. Upon arrival, you enter a large high ceilinged lobby that houses a lounge, restaurant and reception, with many other restaurants on the Mezzanine and a small shopping area adjacent. There is a very unpleasant smell throughout the hotel...like old cigarette smoke they have never successfully cleaned out of the carpets and curtains. Reception was reasonably efficient, but did not really have the charm of Japanese service. Join the IHP loyalty club for free internet. I stayed in one of the "classic" rooms on the 10th floor. The corridors are low ceilinged, narrow, and have worn carpeting. The rooms was fairly small with 2 twin beds (no kings were available) and a view of a small neighborhood shrine. The furnishings were not new, but not terribly worn. There was just enough closet space, a small desk, and a small refrigerator and water heater for coffee/tea. The bathroom was very old feeling, with a small tub/shower with a lighweight shower curtain that clung to me in that creepy way of hotel shower curtains. Overall it felt dated and cramped, but clean. Breakfast was in the lobby restaurant...a giant buffet with many options....but none of them especially tasty. Pastries were rather heavy, prepared eggs wet and rubbery, and all the food tasted the same. On the plus side, there was tasty crisp bacon, which I appreciated. There was a French bakery in the small mall, and they had a couple of good takeaway sandwich options. There is also a good Starbucks and a small grocery store in the building just adjacent. Overall, this is just an OK hotel.

The hotel is conveniently located. Our room was spacious and luxuriously furnished. The service was efficient but communicating with the staff in English was a little difficult. The tariff was pretty steep. Like in many hotels in Japan, breakfast is not included in the tariff.

This venue is an excellent choice for travelers who seek not only a nice location (shops, entertainment, attractions within reasonable distance) but also for those with discerning needs. The hotel has striking features, a welcoming atmosphere, a huge lobby. Check in was done pretty fast, the room was cozy, with all the amenities this brand is expected to offer. View from room was very nice indeed (facing the Imperial Palace). Club Intercontinental lounge offered a high quality options for both breakfast and evening refreshments, but also the breakfast buffet at the cafe in the lobby was really nice. Check out also fast and smooth. All in all I recommend this venue for its top quality services.

Stayed 2 days for business. Close to many attractions. Nice area to walk after a busy work day, especially the near by Izumi Garden. Also some local restaurants are close by in the attached plazaBreakfast can get busy with lines waiting for custom cooked eggs. Also always seemed to be a short line for check-outConvenient comfortable bus service for a fee back to Narita airport

I have stayed at the ANA Intercontinental for twenty five years -- sometimes as much as three times a year. It is the most efficient, quiet and convenient hotel I've found in Tokyo..with over l00 trips (as US government employee,now as a private consultant). Room is modern, perfect service (the only time I have used the work "perfect" on trip advisor). The breakfast buffet has to be the best in the world. Location is very convenient. The staff are amazingly polite and efficient and smart. And the price is reasonable. Early on I used to stay at the Okura..but found that hotel "too old." ANA is alive and sometimes one is lucky enough to see a bridge and wedding. One final tip: the champagne bar offers give glasses of champagne for $90...I've eaten at all the restaurants in the hotel and all are good.
user_name:
William M
Havre de Grace, Maryland

review_body: It is wonderful to experience the consistency of customer focus when I stay at an IHG (Intercontinental Hotel Group) hotel, wherever I am in the world. ANA Intercontinental is no exception ... This is the second time I have stayed here and I will be back. Lots of restaurant options in and around the hotel - although less so for vegetarians like me! Also lots of options for walking to see sights and close to major shopping and other major restaurant areas in Tokyo. Always feel very welcomed when I return to Tokyo where I did my first year of university at Sophia Daigaku in 1974!

There are a lot of quality hotels in Tokyo, what stands out about the Ana is the service and the food in the breakfast buffet. I am always surprised when this detail is overlooked by the more expensive hotels. It could just be Japan, where the food rarely disappoints. But to my point, the food here is very good, the restaurants also are of a very high standard, I tried the steakhouse, it was a better steak than I've been surved in Australia, same with all the meat in Japan. Having said that I really recommend you get outside and explore some of the great sushi restaurants within a stones throw if the hotel. Rooms are very comfortable, Internet is good, and room service also scored well. I have no hesitation in recommending this hotel and giving it 5 stars. Enjoy your stay in Tokyo, it's a great city.

The restaurant is located on the 37th floor of the hotel and you can enjoy great food (teppanyaki) with superb views of the city. I recommend going there for dinner. Don't forget to book in advance as there is a limited number of seats. Bon apetit.

Service here is consistently high. I like the fact that the Limo bus serves this hotel directly (both Narita and Haneda airports) and the bell staff are well used to handling passengers and luggage. My room was comfortable and quite large with an enormously wide bed! I was upgraded due to Ambassador card status so had a sitting area also. Everything worked in the room and again there was an easy interconnection for HDMI to the TV. It seems quite modern.Room service was fast and efficient but I had the fish n chips and recommend this be avoided! Go for something more local or at least a fresh fish! There is a luxury shopping precinct as part of the hotel. I'm sure there used to be a convenience store also but that seems to have gone in favour of another luxury clothing store; this is disappointing when there are things that one lacks upon arrival after a long flight. I didn't try the restaurants or bars this time.

This hotel located at Minato-ku! I found this located very convenient! The subway station is only 5 min away by walk and it is only 3 stations away from Ginza shopping district ! We also took a cab to Tsukiji fish market which cost us 1400 yen ! On the last day we took the cab to Tokyo station for the Shenkensen line to Kyoto! That cost around 1600 yen ! The only complain I have is the small bathroom, I've stayed in Hilton and Keiyo plaza in Shinjuku and cerulean in shibuya and all of them has much reasonable size bathroom ! I do like the hotel Buffet breakfast which has so many selection including Japanese and western style and very good service!

Comfy bed, spacious room, very quiet, very modern. Love the toilet, it washes your bits and is fun. I was sick and they made me chicken soup not on the menu which was awesome and just what I needed to feel well. Their location is great, just around the corner from Roppongi for food and Ginza for shopping. Breakfast is also good in the Atrium restaurant. As well, the Champagne bar for cocktails and the bar on the top floor for late night partying with friends is superb. The atmosphere is amazing and the views are spectacular.

First time to Tokyo for me and my family... there is always a lot of pressure to start the trip off on the right foot. Reading reviews, blogs, asking friends and investigating way into the night... I have so much I want to share about Tokyo from a practical perspective but I will focus on this hotel during this post.We opted for the easiest ( in our mind ) way to get from airport to hotel and after a very long passport immigration it was almost midnight... we chose a cab which looking back is easy in thought. The line or que was so long. The fair was expensive but to be expected. about $45 USD or 5000 yen (2016). I always use Google maps to make sure the driver is heading in the right direction. We pulled up to the hotel and it was awesome. Most hotels don't have massive curb appeal because of how things are set up here. I am not saying it isn't beautiful just a bit more spatially challenged. We were met immediately with bellmen and doormen at midnight and the bags carefully whisked away. We were met by Russell who is an Australian working in Tokyo for IHG and was an exceptional steward of this hotel. He made sure we had the best option available as we were only at this hotel for two nights. He did everything to accommodate an upgrade to make it special but alas with some rooms being smoking and it late, we stayed with the room we had reserved. The room was normal US standard size but the details were spot on. It is a beautiful hotel room with five star bath soaps and coffees. The bedding was European down and very comfortable. The AC functioned great especially in the summer humidity. Ok so we wake up and head to the breakfast. WOW! It was an orchestra of food set on the second floor of the hotel with lots of light coming in through the windows. Food was Chinese, Japanese, English traditional breakfast (yup limp bacon! yuck) French and everything in between. I had the cold Soba noodles, Chinese dumplings, croissants (excellent French croissants) meats from Europe like Jamon Iberica and fruits and salads. We did this for two days and did not tire of the excellent quality of food and service. It was part of our room package and I would recommend it when booking your room.But wait ... it gets better... around the corner there is a small in-hotel shopping area is a cafe.. not just any cafe. Pierre Gagniare has set up a European pastry shop to die for! His desserts and pastries are a must try... and we did stop in so many times. The ladies that work there are gems... They became family in our short stay. Go for the desserts but the service is special too! (There is a two star Pierre Gagniare restaurant on the top but we did not try as we were traveling with kids!)... But we did try the in-house steak house. We were still tired and jet lagged so we couldn't make the trek out to dinner so we stayed in... It was very good but not exceptional (I think they are shooting for exceptional). The steak I shared with my wife was a wagyu thinly sliced and grilled perfectly. I think it was very tender but this cut did not show off the quality of the meat. And from where we come from we like it big and thick. My kids shared a filet and it was perfect. The service was excellent especially in those awkward moments (granted we don't speak Japanese so I can't complain) but my wife ordered a cosmopolitan to drink. They did not know what she was talking about but they left the restaurant (I watched them) and went downstairs to the bartender and they made one... That is special service, albeit awkward sometimes. Everything to this point is spot on. Here are some stand out things. Russell at the front desk tirelessly checking on us, the concierge who don't take tips but give the best service I have experienced in the world, the staff that come out and wave goodbye as you drive away. First impression lobby and greeting. ExcellentService at check in. ExcellentRoom. Very GoodBreakfast. ExcellentHotel Amenities. Very GoodPool. GreatLocation. GreatConcierge. ExceptionalCheck out. Almost makes you cry

Choosing where to stay in Tokyo is not an easy task as it depends on many factors like the area , your budget etc. I am glad I finally decided upon this hotel. Location is in Roppongi/ Akasak area and the hotel is just a few meters away from the Ginza line metro station. There are many restaurants and convenience stores like Family Mart & 7-Eleven next to the hotel. Reception was well manned and had a separate queue for check-in for IHG Elite Members. We had a corner suite along with 2 Premier Executive Rooms nearby. As expected the rooms are not those sprawling large ones but are well furnished and efficient enough. We had a great view of Tokyo tower right in front of us. Staff are extremely good in every aspect. The bell desk also efficiently arranged for Takyubin- the luggage transfer service which is a great way of sending your luggage to another city rather than dragging it with you in the train station.My only complaint would be the breakfast buffet was totally the same for the entire 7 days we stayed with no changes. We faced an issue but the staff were apologetic and did everything to please us.This is a great place to stay and I am sure to return to the same place again.

The very best executive club in Japan! Amazing service standard, genuine staff's approaches and professionalism. Amazing !Décor, amenities and services, simply the best in Japan if not in Asia! Best meeting places, even delicate choices made for amenities such as choice of wine, drinks... and unlike other intercontinental hotels, allow kids to enjoy the club with parents...
user_name:
trvlsoftend
New York City, New York

review_body: I spent few days in Intercontinental Tokyo and need to say the Hotel is excelent.Great location, just 2min walk from Subway Station.Great Facilities but you pay for everything(Pool, Wifi)Food is great but expensive.Consigliere very helpful.

The hotel is located 20 minutes walk south of empire palace. Very easy to access Tokyo metro. As a spiral member, I got an upgrade on a bigger room with two big beds. The room is very clean and well set up, it gives you a luxury hotel feeling. The air conditioning is quiet, you can sleep without earbuds. The concierge is also helpful to give directions but you still need to do your own research, if they are trainees also new to Tokyo, they may not always have better suggestions.

So the location for business is good and close to Roppongi but as a guest staying a week for about €300 per day, you have to pay another €40 per guest per day for using the pool?!?!? The staff is great the rooms are what you would expect from a standard 5* hotel but charging your guests and on top of that so much to use the pool is OUTRAGEOUS. It's as bad as a hotel charging for Internet nowadays! Besides that, it is a pretty average 5* so that is why I would have given it 4 in terms of rating but it got knocked down to 3 due to the pea counting charge to use the pool. I mean, REALLY?!?Oh, on top of all that, there were wine/blood stains on the blinds in the bathroom, the iron was broken. The staff was extremely nice about it though and quick.

Maybe its wrong to expect a hotel to have a wow factor but some InterContinental properties have it, this one does not. That is not to take away from the fact its a good hotel and we did not find fault with in on a 3 night stay. It's well located, 10 minute taxi ride from Tokyo Station or, if you are coming from Narita, it's on the Limousine Bus route. Room was a good size by Tokyo standards. We did not eat in the restaurants so can't comment. Its a short walk into Akasaka where there are lots of restaurants of every choice

Excellent service and nice rooms ; breakfast is excellent and various , nice sky bar at the top of the tower .Only missing point is a warm lobby !!!Confortable and quiet roomwith good insonorisation ; this hotel in ROPPONGGI AREA is really perfect for business

I love inter continental, you know what you'll get- great service, clean well appointed rooms and locations that are easy to get to ( and around ). The rooms are different sizes and I got a club floor room so slightly larger and a coffee maker. A shower + bathtub is somewhat of a luxury in Tokyo city center. The bath amenities were great! The room had a queen sized double bed, typical IC comfort and option of pillows, something I always appreciate and really helps the sleep quality! The breakfast spread is more than what you can ask for ( as always ) specially if you have dietary restrictions there's always something. Location is great as well, In the consular area but a few train stops away from shibuya and shinjuku so you can get around or also the roppongi area affords good places to eat or a more colorful nightlife if that's what you're looking for.  However, for everything you get the place is steeply priced. Almost 300€ a night? Okura next doors is equally good ( although a lot of construction on right now ) but at least 40-50€ cheaper a night. If they managed their room pricing a bit better ( for early bookings at least ) would automatically become the best premium option. However they're already always full so I guess they can afford to be the priciest. All in all will always go back for everything else above!

Excellent service and nice rooms ; breakfast is excellent and various , and ã nice sky bar at the top of the hotel Only missing point is probably a warm lobby !!!Confortable and quite room with perfect insonorasation, this hotel in ROPPONGGI AREA is really perfect for business

This hotel experience in Tokyo is absolutely amazing. Impressed with food, staff and location. Room is very clean and tidy. I will certainly come back and stay at this hotel. I also recommend this hotel to anyone travelling to Japan.

Modern, cosy beds with great showers! Staff are friendly and customer service relation staff were very helpful. Disappointed that as a guest, you had to pay to use the swimming pool, or just relax beside the pool side. Gym however was free...

Beautiful hotel located in a great central area of Tokyo. Buffet breakfast is incredible, staff very polite & accommodating. Good shops & eateries adjacent to hotel. King bed was massive. Traditional turn down service which is so lovely however becoming a thing of the past I find. The highlight however was the shower !! WOW !!!!! About 7 jets hitting all parts of you all at once. Would definitely pick this hotel again, just for the shower !!

Staying here 2 nights due to the convenient location for business. However am very disappointed with the standard of decor. The room is dull and pretty flaccid decor but worst of all everything is stained and grubby looking. Having lived 3 years in Japan, I am sure it is clean but the chairs have marks, the carpets are stained. The place needs a refurb. I am due to return in August and now reconsidering because given the prices I am frankly hugely disappointed

We booked a junior suite and were very happy. Big bathroom with excellent shower and separate bath. Bed is very large. There is a two seater couch in small lounge area. we had a corner room which is slightly different shape but no problem. Visited the club lounge which was excellent bUt you have to pay a lot more for access. Breakfast is excellent. Every range of food available. We had dinner in steakhouse which was average so suggest elsewhere for dinner. On top floor is a bar with fantastic view but it's a smoking bar!! This is a good international quality hotel we would return to as handy to most areas and helpful staff There is laundromat across from the hotel. Go via underground walk way and turn left as you come out Walk past the golf shop and turn right at next Block. You'll need coins but there is a drink dispensing machine next you can get coins from if you buy a drink. Tokyo is great city Very safe

This Hotel was like any other good business hotel. It has all the amenities that you need to make sure your trip is hassle free. It is not about charm or local character which is something that I look for. That's the reason I gave it 3 stars - not because there was anything wrong, I just thought it was average. One complaint - there was quite a line for breakfast, so my first morning I was forced to go without as I did not have time to wait.

Shame the trip was so busy that I didn't see much of the place. Excellent views from one of the tallest buildings in the centre of the city. Very good location to see the city at its best with Tokyo tower only half a mile from the hotel. Rooms much bigger than some of the cheaper hotels in the city.

Wow, what an amazing hotel. This is truly a 5 star hotel, and the level of service in the club lounge made it more like a 6! We stayed here for two nights in June 2016. Upon check in, we were given a complimentary upgrade and had a great view of the Tokyo tower. Unfortunately, when we checked in, our room had a strong unpleasant smell. We spoke to housekeeping and they provided a air purifier which was helpful. We spent a little time exploring the hotel. There are a lot of restaurants, and the buffet looked top notch. We didn't actually eat at any of the restaurants, because we spent most of our eating times up in the club lounge or out in the city. Speaking of the club lounge, the hotel will tell you that they have the biggest hotel club lounge in Tokyo. The best part though, was the level of service. I would argue that they have the best club lounge service! I can't praise the manager, Junko, her assistant manager, supervisor, and rest of staff (including intern, Nao) enough! Besides helping us book a spa appointment the same day, book the airport limo bus, recommend restaurants, what we really enjoyed was getting to know them as people. It was great talking to them about their city, their travels, and what they love about their hotel. When it came to the food and drinks at the lounge, these were truly delicious and presented very professionally! We tried the breakfast, which was almost like a full buffet, as well as the happy hour, which was basically a dinner. There are also snacks and non alcoholic drinks in the afternoon. There were always plenty of drinks to go around, whether you wanted a custom cafe latte in the morning, or special cocktail in the evening. One tip though is to get there early, because the best tables next to the Windows tend to fill up first. However, the couches were very comfortable for lounging. We did book a massage treatment and while not a big facility, it was still very relaxing and a nice way to end our anniversary trip. We also spent some time at the gym. The facility was pretty impressive, and had all the weights and machines I would expect from a high end hotel. We were surprised that there was a fee to use the pool. It wasn't pool weather when we were there, but we did walk around and check it out.I look forward to visiting this hotel again! Tokyo is a fantastic city and I would highly recommend staying here if you can. Oh, and do yourself a favor and visit the club lounge. The view is awesome and you'll get to meet Junko and her team!

This was a very unhappy experience and I have many issues. 4,000 yen to use swimming pool. Service attitude very low. Will never use again. Room was poor quality and was not cleaned correctly. Breakfast very good and I give them one star for the quality.

An international hotel chain with the service that you would expect of these kind of hotels. Very good rooms, nice breakfast buffet, a lot of very good but pricey restaurants to choose from and the fully proactive staff at reception and especially very helpful people at the concierge. However the service in the breakfast area lacks a little speed and attention, such as watch for fully loaded too small tables with empty plates, or me asking for something ... They have a nice drip coffee maker in the room whereas I would prefer the Nespresso type but that's more if a local taste. Surely the room prices are on the higher side but it is Tokyo and not a provincial place. Not my first time here and I will still return again.

I stayed here for work last week as I have previously and had a pleasant stay. The hotel is nothing special with clean ( but small rooms) rooms, average food, standard service and a good gym. It's close to many restaurants and the metro to get around Tokyo. Although quite expensive and it doesn't stand out like many other hotels in Tokyo its a good solid hotel that is convenient to base yourself from.

A beautiful upscale hotel near the Ginza subway line. A spacious lobby with helpful concierge, world-class restaurants, and a breakfast bar that caters to travelers from all over the globe. There is a shopping plaza in the hotel for individual wishing to purchase gifts of leather, clothes, liquor, and food as gifts. The "economy" rooms are smallish, but well appointed with a snack and liquor bar. There is a small safe and an umbrella for guests to use. The toilet is the best example of Japanese technological know-how - a combined bidet/toilet with a wall full of instructions on its use!

I redeemed my points and booked it two months ahead, asking for a king bed. When I check in, the reception said there is no kind bed today and even I am Spire Elite member, there is not any upgrade or different treatment. I discussed for several times and finally they agreed to upgrade the room. And there is no complimentary water in the room. But the hotel itself is very good, good location and clean room. Just the service of reception could be done better.

Room: Big esp in terms of Tokyo standard. Bigger than most other hotel rooms I've stayed in Tokyo. Wifi: Reliable, fastLocation: Very good, next to metro line. Value for money: Quite an expensive hotel, but since it's a business trip, I didn't have to pay for it.

I got a chance to go to Japan last year and was fortunate enough to not have to pay for a hotel. My wife was staying with her company, and I got to tag along.This is Hotel is absolutely five stars! The staff is friendly and so very courteous. The lobby is incredibly beautiful and grand. The room in which we stayed was slightly smaller than I'm used to. However, when you're not paying...who cares! HA! It was still large enough to fit two beds (twins) and on most nights, I used the other bed, instead of sharing a twin bed.The room is immaculately clean and efficient. The amenities they provide, i've never been provided elsewhere...Like a hair brush. They give you this fold-up hair brush (which I still carry with me when I travel). They provided tooth brush and all the normal toiletries. Now, it was the first time that I've ever experienced a toilet that washed your private parts and at first I was not sure if I'd use it's full range of functionality...However, I highly recommend you take advantage of it! I wanted to buy a seat just like that when I got home. We were on a fairly high floor with an amazing view (see photos).The breakfast buffet has a wide range of choices, from American food to Asian. I was amazed with the spread and variety of options, as well as the quality of food.I would stay here in a heartbeat! Even if I was paying for it!It's located within walking distance of Roppongi, which is a great spot for a bite to eat or to hit a dive bar! The subway is a half block away and this hotel is a major stop for a bus service that can take you to and from the Airport.I love Japan!

Hotel in really nice location with an access to public transportation and metro line in the heart of the city (9/10). Hotel is very clean and tidy (9/10). Furniture in very good condition except beds the pillows not comfortable at all (7.5/10). Food is quite nice but the buffet choices are very limited and there is not a lot of traditional choices (7/10). Staff are really friendly and professional. They are approachable and very helpful (10/10). Over all rating (8.5/10)

very comfortable hotel. Especially for business trips. Good bathroom, bed and very clean. very luxury lounge and friendly staff. Can be easily reached with the airport shuttle bus from the airport. Near metro stations and easily accessable.

Great central location in Tokyo for both work and tourism. Rooms are much larger than most in Tokyo. Check in staff was great but bellhop and concierge were not helpful. The additional fees however were crazy even by Tokyo standards, the hotel charges in-house guests 4000 Yen per person for even access to the deck of the pool. Unbelievable and ruined our experience.
user_name:
sunny11xi
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Have stayed on many occasions due to meetings nearby, and it's still a good choice.Plus points:- Close to subway - Coffe shops (Dean Deluca, Starbucks etc) close to hotel, as well as convenience store- Some higher rooms has very nice views of Tokyo towerWhat to know:- Some rooms facing towards Roppongi crossing has more noise from the streets- Breakfast area can be very crowded at times

The ANA Intercontinental is located in the central business district and is on the main airport shuttle routes from both of Tokyo's international airports. The hotel is modern and well maintained. The rooms are spacious (by Tokyo standards) and there are a number of excellent bars and restaurants to choose from. The staff are friendly and helpful. This is one of Tokyo's best hotels.

This was my second week+ stay at the lovely Ana Intercontinental, and I will return again when I'm in the area. The hotel is near the foreign embassies with easy access to trains. The large Ark Hills complex a short walk away offers many choices in restaurants, and there is a market next door. The bed is very comfortable with nice linens. The breakfast buffet is one of the best!

Enjoyed our hotel with the best access to the underground trains and rail system. The location though is not for travelers but for business as restaurants outside the hotel was far and in between. Great rooms and fantastic amaenities. Food was great inside the lobby restaurants.

As a Royal Ambassador received complimentary upgrade to corner suite. (No club access though). The hotel is about a 30 minute cab ride from Haneda Airport (try to land there if you can, the other Tokyo airport (Narita) takes at least three times longer to get there. Hotel is very close to the easy to use subway system. Surrounding the hotel are several restaurants. It's not in a busy/touristy part of Tokyo though but easy to get there using the subway. Breakfast buffet has an excellent choice including several fresh juices, Asia and Western style. All in all a pleasant stay in a great country.

The hotel and rooms are super classy, and the room was large (not sure what room type we had but I think they said we got an upgrade). The views are quite lovely too, we had one of the imperial castle.But if you're not a business traveler and are in Tokyo to spend time gallivanting around the city I suggest you skip this hotel and get a lesser place in a busier (buzzier!) location like Shibuya or Shinjuku. You're doing a lot more subway transfers if you stay here and there are less choices for local non-hotel restaurants and such.

So this is my third stay in about a year at this hotel. I am a gold elite member with IHG . Each time I've stayed here in a club category room I have found the room setup to be different, this time I was on the 31st floor and found the room to be smaller than the one on the 29th floor from my last visit. Not too happy with the way the bathroom was in this room... Guess it's a personal choice as well as no space to put up the suitcase while unpacking. No electrical plug points in bed side which I think these days is a must.Overall great location for business as well as connections on subway. Food is expensive and a-la-carte portion sizes are quite small. The room service menu needs to be a bit more tuned into today's business traveller who I assume makes up a large part of the clientele, menu is extremely large and "boring" with healthy options not really there. I will most likely continue to use this property in my future visits but it is more so due to my loyalty with IHG and not due to this hotel per se.

located in ARK Hills just by Roppongi Hills and right by several train lines so access to the city from here is very easy. It was 60 minutes from Narita on the Limousine Bus which drops you off at the hotel. Large hotel with many restaurant offerings that will cater to any taste- rooms are very comfortable and spacious - specially for Tokyoget the breakfast plan- the buffet in the morning will satisfy any diet and get you good and full to explore the city. all the staff were very helpful and easy to communicate withThe MIXX bar on the top floor has dramatic views of the city and a wonderful cocktail program. i recommend

For my first trip to Tokyo I decided to stay at the ANA Intercontinental due to the location of the hotel and the cost of the rooms.The hotel is located in Ark Hills which is very close to both Roppongi and Akasaka but in a quiter area of town. The nearest metro station is Roppongi Icchome with an entrance right outside the hotel but be warned, multiple lines run to this station and you can walk miles underground, the Hibiya line is nearest to the exit.As with most Tokyo hotels, check-in time is quite late and they can be quite strict allowing early checkin, on this trip we arrived in Tokyo at 9am and did have to wait until 12pm. The room I stayed in was a Premier Room located on the 31st floor. I have no complaints with the room, it was large had all the typical amenities and had a very nice bathroom. Its a little different from the typical ICH room where the entrance to the bathroom was in the room itself and not the hall way, the shower/bath were separated from the toilet. The kingsize bed was very comfortable and there was plenty of space to relax. Wifi was included as I am a ICH member but I believe there is a charge if you are not (which is unbelievable now days especially in Tokyo). The hotel has multiple restaurants of which I only tried the Japanese, the food was fantastic but on the dear side, I would recommend eating out. The hotel also has a swimming pool of which, when I looked (in May and very hot) no one was using it.Both Roppongi and Akasaka are within walking distance so you do not need to go far to find restaurants and bars. I did read that Roppongi can be a little seedy or dangerous side but I did not experience this. Ark Hills itself is fairly quite with a few bars and restaurants in the shopping mall.For a base to sight see Tokyo, the hotel is ok, the metro station entrance is right on your door step but as previously mentioned, depending on what line you want, the walk can be rather long as although you may see directions to other lines, you are in fact walking to another station.I would recommend the ANA as it is a lovely hotel but it is primarily geared up for business guests then leisure. The staff are very friendly and will assist you with any questions that you have. The main reason I have not given the hotel 5 stars is that the restaurants are experience and although the location is good, you can do better in Tokyo. My other main gripe is that you can not book club rooms with club access, you need to book club access seperately and at over £100 per person is outrageous.

Hotel near subway station.clean but room rate a little be high.My wife and me did not see any service in hotel just only stay in from front door to room.reception check in busy cause only one person in.

Excellent hotel located about 5mins away from Tameike Sanno train station. The service from the warm and friendly staff at club lounge was top notch. Evening cocktail with the variety of drinks and finger foods was a great choice. Sadly a good coffee barista was missing. The club room was very comfortable and a great view from the 30th floor and also from the club lounge. Bus service to Haneda Airport not available after 12pm up until 8pm, which was disappointing. Overall a fantastic hotel at a great location.

Our room upgrade to Premier type due to this is our honeymoon trip. The room is clean and bed is very comfortable. View from 29F is quite amazing as well. Room service is as you need as request. Gift of chocolate and card to bless our weeding. Also enjoy the buffet breakfast, I really like the omelet. Oh, hotel can also help to receive the package for you, the service is very hospitality.

Well located, even though there is nothing really outstanding in the area.Metro is just in front of the hotel (station tameike-sanno) and connects to 4 different lines. But be cautious... After you have reached the metro entrance, you will have to walk between 400 and 900 more meters (depending which line you need to use) to reach the train itself. Quite convenient in case of rain, but much more than the 100 meters advertised on the hotel website.Other than that, the hotel is perfect. The staff is very friendly and accommodating, making all efforts to communicate in English.The breakfast is upscale quality. Tons of options, all with fresh and quality products.The rooms are large, clean, very well maintained. King bed is huge and comfortable.The fitness room is large, very well equipped and clean.Several bars and restaurants are available (some of them being the best restaurants in town, on the expensive side of course). Try the Sky Lounge bar at the 36th floor. With nice views on the city, you can enjoy happy hour on cocktails at sunset.Maybe only one negative feedback: all 4 pillows provided were way too soft for me. One might consider that as a detail, but it turned out to be quite detrimental to my sleep on that week (in addition with time difference to Europe of course...).

The rooms are larger than expected. Super clean. Disappointed on the concierge food recommendations but was able to find our way to good food. Conveniently located and they provide a airport shuttle service (additional fee) to Narita International Airport

Awesome hotel with good location. Very close to the local train station as well, The rooms were super luxurious and very clean. The view from the hotel was amazing. Overall Quite expensive but worth it!

We're in Japan, service is always going to be great. Good location within 2 train line & some decent places to eat. Hotel is in dire need of renovation though...Otherwise, cant complain, you get what you pay for!

Points accrued by my husband paid for a luxurious stay at the Ana Intercontinental. Although we were receiving free lodging we were treated as well were we paying $$$ nightly. The hotel is gorgeous. It reminds me of their Jakarta location. Everyone is very professional, helpful, competent. It makes staying in a foreign place seamless, especially when needing to find an off the beaten track Owl Cafe, or requesting a room change (too loud near freeway; change went perfectly and new room an improvement). The beds and bath are very comfortable. Slippers and 3 choices of lounge wear offered: fluffy bathrobe, takata, nightshirt. Fresh fruit upon arrival in room; daily for those wishing to pay for Club status (we passed this time). Several fancy restaurants and bars to choose from if you want the hotel dining experience, and an excellent cafe (croissants and coffee to go, more our style).

Room was very comfortable and spacious. Understand it was renovated not too long ago.Location is good, right next to the train station. Restaurants available in the vicinity as well. Walking distance to Ropponggi crossing.

Hotel was great. Accommodations were clean and comfortable. Great scenic bar on top floor of hotel. Restaurants were a bit pricey but breakfast buffet was great. Lots to pick from. Would recommend hotel and would stay here again. Location was convenient.

It was my yearly golf trip to tokyo & osaka and this trip, we chose ANA Intercontinental. Hotel, which was centrally located near Roppongi Hills. The hotel room is quite outdated and my trip started off on a sour note. my first night, the a/c didnt work properly, it was just hot air coming out and due to that, i had barely 2 hours of sleep before my golf game the next day. the hotel staff made no apologies when i complained however the a/c was fixed when i got back from my game with some godiva biscuits for the mishap. wouldve preferred credit for the 1st nite......the so called michelin star bakery on the ground floor was average, breads were only average; could be lighter & fluffier......all in all, my trip was awesome. i love tokyo and the many cuisines you can check out around town....the hotel is centrally located, about 5-8 min walk to the subway and most conveniently, theres a bus that takes you to haneda & narita at the hotel....

I am rating this hotel ignoring the price, which we found extremely high, even for Tokyo. We did book a Club room, which offered access to a large Club Lounge on the 35th floor. Here you can have an excellent complementary breakfast, and cocktails with snacks in the evening, including a good quality Champagne, and all complimentary. We stayed for 7 nights on business, although I left for two days touring Japan. The room was clean with a fantastic bed, great linen, a small but well equipped bathroom and storage. What makes this a five star review is the amazing level of service we had in the Club Lounge. The staff were exceptional and really couldn't do enough to help. They researched placed for visits, and train times amongst other things, and were so friendly I thought I'd known them for much longer than a week!

The hotel is very well located in the central part of Tokyo. The room are nicely equipped. There is a wonderful out view, when you are located at higher level, at best 21 and higher. If you are lucky, there is the Tokyo Tower just in front of you. It is nicely illuminated in the night. There is also bar and restaurant at the top looking over the city. The fitness room is fine, but might get crowded early in the morning. There is unfortunately only outdoor swimming pool. The Midtown Tokyo shopping center ins in walking distance (15-20min).

Enjoyed the hotel. Not the largest fan on location as I like to be more in the mix. This was in a more business area, so if you have a full fixture for work it is perfect, but if you want night life look closer to Ginza.Overall would return for work.

This is my first time in an ANA hotel in Tokyo. The hotel is centrally located and you can visit many sites by using public transportation. Taxi's are always available. The room was comfortable and functional. The price paid for the room reflects the location and the quality of this establishment. The service at the front desk, the restaurant and the lobby lounge was excellent.

This hotel is well-located in the Akasaka area with easy connections around Tokyo. Rooms are not large, but well-appointed with comfortable beds and many have great views of Tokyo Tower. Breakfast is a highlight at this hotel in the atrium lobby with great selections. Service is also consistent and efficient.
