The IHG hotels is my normal home away from home and the Ana Intercontinental Tokyo is no exception. No surprises here, everything, as usual, is as it always is. Staff are polite and try their best to make you feel comfortable; at home. Rooms are well appointed and of course, spotless.

I suppose it's to be expected in such a prime location in Tokyo, but the rooms weren't much more than a desk and a bed--comfortable bed though. Also, the price of drinks at the bar were very expensive. Hardly anything under $20. Otherwise, a really great stay.

My wife and I recently spent 2 weeks in Japan with Samurai tours staying in Japanese guest houses, bathing in onsens, and having Japanese meals three times a day. While we had a fabulous time and would do it again it was wonderful to get back to a western hotel with beds off the floor and western breakfasts. We spent 2 days after the end of our tour at the ANA Intercontinental and it was like a lovely oasis in Tokyo. We hope to go back to Tokyo one day and would definitely stay there again as great location and amenities.

This was my third time in Tokyo and stayed in ANA for 2 weeks, service and staff were very helpful and efficient, Check-in was smooth, room service is superb, the hotel restaurants were good as well. Airport Limousine has a stop here in ANA that makes the transportation really efficient. I had to change rooms during the middle of my stay and it was easy breezy because their staff took care of everything. Some tips for travelers: sign up for IHG membership, this will give you free WIFI, daily English newspaper and late checkout, otherwise you'll have to pay about -+1500 Yen per day for the WIFI and ask the reception if they can give you a room overlooking the Tokyo Tower.

Stayed one week for a HS class reunion. Can't comment on hotel cost/rate since this was a large group rate but cost was reasonable for Tokyo. Location was next to Ark Hills business complex with many restaurants, close to 2-3 subway stations, walking to distance to both Roppongi Hills and Mid Town shopping/restaurant complexes. Cost of breakfast is sky high so don't consider eating there. Cheaper locations outside at Ark Hills.

This property always bring smile to my face. Great IHG property easy excess to mostly everywhere in Tokyo by Tokyo Metro. Hotel staff were amazing, from the greeter, check in agents to the luggage handler that help our luggage to our room. Refused our tip makes this property even more respectable and stand above standard of luxury.As an ambassador club member, unfortunately we are not been upgraded to the suite as we priorly requested in celebrating our anniversary.

We stayed at this hotel––a typical high-rise, corporate contemporary hotel designed for business travelers and large tour groups––because we were part of a dreaded tour group. My wife and I usually prefer small independently run places, and in fact we had just spent five wonderful nights at a delightful ryokan in Asakusa before coming here to join up with the group. It was in some ways a welcome respite from the spartan surroundings of a traditional ryokan. This was particularly so with regard to the beds. It was good to have one again, after five nights sleeping on a futon on the hard floor. The restaurant where we had breakfast was also absolutely top class, with a huge selection of asian, japanese and western style breakfast food. The concierge service was incredibly helpful to us in planning our free time, both with respect to restaurants and also sightseeing. If you prefer contemporary accommodations, you absolutely can't go wrong with this hotel.

one of the best rooms i have seen so far in hotels , my family was delighted . next to train station and catching a bullet train was just so easy ... the quality of hotel is so deserving to be a 5 star .The room we had was quite roomy for Tokyo standard and had a beautiful view .Service was discrete, welcoming and professional, the room was tremendous: quiet, well-appointed and furnished, with very good amenities (toiletries of good quality, and quantity, well furnished in-room refreshments including kettle tea and coffee, and a very comfy bed and pillows. Kudos to the very professional and helpful staff.

We stayed one night before going to Kyoto (ANA Crowne Plaza) and returned for a second stay of 3 more nights and enjoyed a consistently top quality experience throughout. Service was discrete, welcoming and professional, the room was tremendous: quiet, well-appointed and furnished, with very good amenities (toiletries of good quality, and quantity, well furnished in-room refreshments including kettle tea and coffee, and a very comfy bed and pillows. Kudos to the very professional and helpful staff. They are knowledgeable and helpful and very impressive in their follow up and recollection of our faces, our interests and our taste. After the experience of several many-starred hotels, this one measures very favourably, and I would not at all hesitate to recommend it both to tourists and business travellers. It is a very comfortable, well-run, and luxurious hotel.

We arrived at the hotel for check in quite late around 11pm and the room assignment was a bit delayed (10 min wait) which we didn't mind. However, when we got called by the front desk again, it was the manager that came and apologized very politely about the delay and even gave us his card to contact him if there's any issues with the stay. The room we had was quite roomy for Tokyo standard and had a beautiful view of the Tokyo tower. In terms of accessing the hotel through subway, it's actually quite easy, the best way to get there is to take the Ginza line and get off at Tameike-Sanno and use exit 13, the hotel is right outside. As mentioned earlier, staff are very polite and friendly, there's an easy shuttle bus going to the airport for $30 if I remember correctly. But make sure you make reservation ahead of time!

I stayed at the hotel over the Easter weekend and the week after. Was lucky to catch the full bloom of cherry blossom during my stay there. The surrounding area of the hotel (Ark Hills) was beautiful and they even had lights to illuminate the trees. It was a pleasant stay because i get to see beautiful cherry blossoms right outside the hotel. The buffet dinner (Hokkaido buffet) is well worth the money. The rooms are very comfortable and i like the fact that they have a thermos flask in the room. So i can have hot water all day long.

For those who prefer simplicity with style. Location is central to the business district. Very good service. Good to stay with family too. It is the hotel of choice for all our trips. Rooms are small. Request for higher floor. Can see Mount Fuji in the winter from floor 30 onwards

I stayed here on my own for four nights in April during the cherry blossom season. The location of the hotel is great, right next to the underground - however please note there isnt much going on directly outside the hotel so not much choice for food and bars outside of the hotel itself. The restaurants in the hotel all stopped serving around 9 or 10pm which was not ideal. The room was large for Tokyo standards, but a little dusty and could do with updating. The concierge at the hotel was fab and really helped me plan my stay in Tokyo. The hotel let me leave luggage with them for two weeks whilst i traveled Japan, this was incredibly helpful. I took an airport couch to and from Haneda airport - really easy and good value for money. The airport couch stops at a couple of hotels along the route and takes around 45 mins.

Stayed at ANA Intercontinental during my recent trip to japan for 3 nights. It was an amazing experience as the service offered by the hotel is excellent. The location is just perfect as its very close to Ropongi & a metro station is right next to the hotel. Also, i happen to find couple of great Indian restaurants neareby as well :)Rooms are decent in size & amenities with stunning view of Tokyo tower. the concierge girls are worth a mention for their amazing customer service.Overall a very happy & pleasant stay.
user_name:
Anuraj N
Dubai, United Arab Emirates

review_body: I stayed at the ANA Intercontinental Hotel for three nights in April to attend a business meeting. The hotel room is comfortable, quiet and reasonably priced. The hotel staff was friendly and helpful. The concierge helped me plan my follow on trip, making sure I understood how to get to proper train station and which train to take. The personalized service and comfortable room made my business trip easy. If you business location is nearby, stay at the ANA Intercontinental. However, be sure to book early they sell out often!!

Busy business hotel. Front desk staff are very efficient and helpful, club rooms are modern and spacious with all modern amenities. Comfortable beds and pillows. Fantastic selection of bars and restaurants, shops and cafes inside the hotel. Walking distance to some Fab noodle houses and Starbucks! Breakfast buffet had a great selection. The bus shuttle to the airport is very handy and reasonably priced.

I stayed at the ANA InterContinental Tokyo for a week in April. This is a good selection for a business traveler but there may be better options. The lobby areas are fantastically large with many selections of restaurants/dining/bars. The staff is bilingual with good English; service was very good in the restaurants and bars. Beware that the restaurants in the hotel are expensive but there are less expensive options in the office building next door. Also the multiple lobby areas are always full of people...lots of American businessmen, pilots, government workers, etc. The doormen were extremely helpful with cabs and giving directions & addresses to the drivers. Airport limo bus service was easy and inexpensive. Watch your time...it can take up to 1 1/2 hours to get to Narita airport to/from hotel. The pool costs $40 daily fee to use and is only open in summer; the gym is good and free. Spa was nice but they don't speak much English!Now to the rooms; the rooms are small and the beds are hard. The carpet is worn. No bottled water supplied in the rooms like I am used to at luxury hotels worldwide. The bathroom was small but clean. The toilets are Japanese [heated seats, lots of buttons...google how to use!]. Hairdryers & irons in the rooms. I would recommend upgrading to the executive floor and paying the $80 for the executive lounge....the rooms are better/bigger, the breakfast is almost as good as downstairs and if you have more than 1 person traveling you will save money b/c it's free in the lounge. There are also lots of seating areas where you can conduct meetings, unlike the lobby which is always crowded. Wish we had figured this out before our final two days! I would consider staying again but would research additional options as well.

Stayed at ANA Intercontinental for 5 nights, everything worked and service was good. The room and bathroom are on the smaller side but adequate for one person. I was provided a room with 2 beds, I had reserved a single king. The beds are small and the mattress is not as comfortable as I expected. Other amenities in the room are fine. Breakfast buffet is also good. You can walk to Ginza but it is a long walk, about 30 minutes. I would stay at the hotel again.

I stayed in a single room which was very clean and like most Japanese hotels they have all amenities you will ever need- even PJ's!The bed is very comfortable, but the room and decor is small and outdated. If you are traveling alone or visiting Tokyo for the first time the staff will help you with virtually anything!It's in a great location, near Roppongi, Midtown, Aoyama. The limousine bus picks up and drops off on site. There are tons of restaurants nearby, post office, many cafes including two Starbucks within 5 min walk. It's right around the corner from the US Embassy as well.
user_name:
Rosie2158
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Service: EXCELLENT. From front desk to the club lounge to room service, it was excellent. Room: Excellent. It was so spacious and clean with a really comfortable bed. The hotel is located right next to a subway station but don't be fooled it is "close". Once you get down into the station there is still a fair bit of walking to get to the platforms. The club lounge was amazing - good food and service. Everything about the hotel is nice and clean.

Stayed on 31st floor for 4 nights. Room was spotless on arrival and kept the same throughout my stay. Room amenities are average, and somewhat dated (nice Bose speakers, but iPhone5 and prior connection). One unusual issue was of the 4 clothes drawers, only 1 was not full of something (room safe was in one, and robes/yukatas in other two). Note that when using the yukata, it was replaced with a fresh one each day, which was very nice. Room wi-fi was good, and offers a 72-hour sign in option so you don't have to do so each evening (select from the sign-in page), but I could not connect to same in the lobby at all. The lobby restaurant breakfast buffet was included in my rate (approx $35 US if purchased separately). It had a very large and diverse selection of eastern and western choices. Staff was friendly and helpful throughout my stay. Only slightly negative comment, there were very few seats in the lobby area to have conversations with business colleagues. Although there is a large seating area in view, it is completely reserved for the lobby restaurant use. Behind the escalator there are 8 seats, but no others. Final note, when getting back to hotel late, there is a small market next door, and two others within a few blocks, that offer packaged sandwiches, noodle bowls, drinks and fruit.

This was a really impressive experience. The Rooms were spanking clean and comfortable. The Staff extremely friendly and helpful. Took pride in their work and showed complete dedication to what they were doing, but still managed to remain humble and friendly. I have travelled a lot on Business trips to the Mid-East and Far-East, but the service offered here was even better than what I have received in places like Hong-Kong and Singapore, which I thought were the best before I stayed and dined at ANA Intercontinental in Tokyo, Japan. Keep it up. You are doing a great Job!

The Classic rooms on the lower floors should not be considered 5-star accommodations -- more like 3-star. Those rooms are bookable through major travel websites and therefore get much more traffic than their Premium rooms, which must be booked through the Intercontinental website. That said, even the Premium rooms are just about 4-star. Hotel was probably a gem of the Tokyo business traveller at one time, but is now starting to show its age and a refresh of the property is due. Service team is about 4-star, unless you encounter an issue, in which case they do try their best to make things right. The breakfast buffet is a good deal and very convenient if you prefer get a meal in before heading off to work or your next grand adventure.

A hotel with very good facilities and service. OK (but not more than OK) rooms, somewhat outdated and in need of refurbishment. Comfortable beds and pillows. The breakfast was excellent with a lot of choices regarding hot and cold food, and of course also Japanese breakfast.Good choice of restaurants in the hotel and a direct shuttle bus to the aiport made our life comfortable while staying at the hotel.

I travel a lot and stay here with my company. It is a very nice hotel with an excellent staff. Rooms are reasonable size. Bed is a little stiff but normal for Japan as far as I can tell. Nice equipment in the gym but it gets busy - go early or late if you are still on a different time zone and avoid the wait for a machine. I tried the breakfast buffet and thought it was very good. Large selection of Japanese and standard (Western) breakfast food. Have taken a look at the lunch buffet and it looks very good too. Food is expensive in the hotel but it is very convenient. The Pierre Gagnaire Pains pastry shop is excellent for a quick bite. Easy walk to the Imperial Palace and the Tokyo Tower. Rappongi is just up the hill to the left when exiting the hotel if you want night life. Akasaka is also an easy walk and has probably a hundred (or more) restaurants.I am a reasonable traveler. Luxury is nice but what I need a clean/quiet room, a reasonable gym and a nice staff to help if I need something. This hotel delivers.

I've stayed here probably 100 nights. I prefer the Tokyo Grand Hyatt, but that is way more expensive. The rooms here are very different so you can get a small room or a large room. The concierges are hit or miss, I've had some great restaurant recommendations and some really lousy ones.The gym is 24x7 which is great. Its location is really good if you need to be in Akasaka. This is a great place to stay for a night or two for folks that only have a couple of days in Tokyo.

Rooms are OK but carpet is old and tired. If you can get around the stains in the lobbies just don't try a meal at cascade cafe. Yesterday at 11:30 was told - we are full. Ok - for all of today? For next week? I can't wait for a table? No. We are full. Thought it might be a fluke but this morning greet staff again rude. And paid 25$ usD for undercooked omelet and coffee that arrived 3/4 way through meal after three requests. I would give this hotel a pass for sure!

I stayed 5 nights at this hotel for work. The room was nice with good views but the bathroom was very small. The service was good and the staff was efficient and friendly. The location is OK - very close to the Metro. Overall it felt more like a 4 star hotel.

Rooms are standard IHG Intercontinental hotel, smaller than usual perhaps because it's Tokyo. We were checked in at a higher floor, so we had a good view at night. Check-in was efficient. There was a slight mistake in our booking, but they were able to correct it without any bother to us. Staff were all very nice, especially the concierge. It was our first time to visit Tokyo and they were very helpful. We made a mistake in buying a Tokyo-wide pass ticket for 3 days only to learn that we won't be able to use it in the metro train stations. The concierge called JR East and arranged a refund for us even though the start date has already begun (we never got to use the ticket on our 1st day). They also gave us access maps of nearby areas in the hotel as well as train maps. I would have made this a five-star review, but on our 2nd day for breakfast, there was a long line already before 6:30am. (Breakfast starts at 6am). Most people who filled the breakfast table were the "men in black" mentioned in other reviews here. When we finally got in the buffet area, there was very little food left. For example, typically they have two types of bacon:crispy bacon and simply bacon. During that day, only the crispy bacon was left (at 6:45am). Most of the pastries were gone too. In fact, most of everything was gone. They were able to refill the buffet spread, but that was a lag in their service. It's understandable to some extent since the area is near a lot of embassies. But if this is something that happens often, the hotel should have addressed this already. Other than that, everything else went as we expected in an Intercontinental hotel. It was a very good experience, but it didn't blow our mind or exceeded our expectations.Once you go outside the hotel, Tameike san station of Ginza line is below it. Airport limousine buses from Narita make a direct stop to this hotel so it's very convenient.

It is quite convenient to travel from and to the airport that limousine bus offer door to door service. However, it takes nearly 30 mins to wait in the queue for check-in. Big room but the facilities are quite old, and the bathroom is out to date.Nice view that it is able to see the Tokyo tower from the room.Overall, it's not a bad choice for travelers, but here will be some other better choices in terms of the location, services and facilities for the same price.

I have stayed here a dozen times for business, and the hotel is very comfortable. The public areas are nicely upscale, with a very good variety of options for food, drink, even a cigar. Reception, as is anything with employee contact, is very, very good. The staff are very attentive, very professional, and very friendly. I really can't say enough, from Russell at the Concierge to every waiter in the lobby cafe.There are several excellent choices for dining. All are very pricey (par for Tokyo), but none will disappoint. If you choose to eat a meal in the lobby cafe (Cascade), I recommend taking the buffet option unless you don't want to interrupt a business meal. The menu will be much more expensive, and you will not have nearly the variety of food choices (all of which are excellent) if you order off of the menu.The rooms are well appointed, but lacking in light switches. A master controls the room, but then each light is operated individually. There are no wall switches to control groups of lights, which is both curious and a little annoying. There are, however, lots of lamps and wall lights to choose from. There is an excellent desk with lamp, but power is a single wall socket with only two plugs. A major disappointment is the WiFi, which is very slow. any web intensive work will become annoying.The bathrooms are small by American standards, but very normal by Eastern standards. As in all Japanese hotels, most foreigners will want to spend some time with an instruction manual for the toilet, which has as many controls as a small jet. The sink has plenty of counterspace. The shower is a bit tight, but with wonderful water pressure. As in much of the Orient, all bathing supplies are installed in pump containers mounted in the shower. Inexplicably, the bathroom floor is very worn and shabby.Cigars are very expensive in the lobby shop (bring your own), but there is a wonderful bar on the second floor to relax with one and a good scotch. There are a variety of shops and restaurants within walking distance, both to the left towards Rappongi, across the (very busy) street behind the golf shop, and across the street to the right and up the hill (go around the left of the "ATT" building, then up and down a small hill to a very "bourbon street" area with great food and drink. A short walk to the right out of the hotel will take you to the Imperial Palace in about 15 minutes.Located in the Embassy area (behind the hotel), there is easy access to rail for trips around the Tokyo metro.

Clean and comfortable rooms. IHG upgrade got us one in a high floor with nice views. Location is good, conveniently close to several underground stations. The small gym is open 24h, so one can take advantage of the jet lag. They have a bar and restaurants in the top floors

Date: 8th - 12th April 2016Room: 2 single beds Executive room Intercontinental ANA Tokyo hotel is located at Akasaka area. 10 mins walking distance to Roppongi. The hotel is a 37th storey building. It is about 60mins away by the Limousine Bus from Narita International Airport.Check-inThe main hotel lobby is located on the 2nd floor of the hotel. Appoint entering, I was greeted with a large grand lobby! We proceeded to the check in counter where Ms. Mariko served us! She was really very warm and welcoming! We took awhile for our check in as we had 2 reservations .. One with the Ambassador Weekend voucher while the other half was on IHG Points! She even helped us to get the best room with the View of Tokyo Tower and with a Corner Renovated room! Rating: 10/10Room:So We got Room 2611, the executive room. As I opened the room, it was a nice average size! The room consist of a 37"! LCD tv, a working desk and a 2 seater couch where you can admire the amazing Tokyo tower! The toilet was abit small thou but it had a bathtub together with the shower! The toiletries brand were Agraria, same brands as other intercontinental asia hotels I have stayed. The room is really very comfortable and so are the beds! The pillows has a choice of soft and hard! Overall, the room is good and clean! Rating: 8.5/10Services and facilities:Gym: the hotel gym is located on the 4th floor! It is quite big and has all the required equipments one need to stay fit! The only thing that can be good was if there was a Personal trainer / hotel staff to take care of the gym! This is because there are times when the Water machine could not dispense any more water and there was no one around that could help! Maybe another alternative is to provide mineral water bottles ? Gym Rating: 8/10Services: the housekeeping team that cleans my room has really done a great job! I would like the compliment both of them (sorry I didn't get their names but it was an elderly lady and a Indian/Spanish lady).The concierge team was also very helpful. She provided every information that was needed with a smile and patient.We didn't manage to try any of the hotel restaurants.Overall, i enjoyed IC Ana Tokyo! I will definately come back here again to stay and will try the Club Intercontinental as I heard it's really very good! Thank you IC Ana Tokyo for the amazing memories and making Tokyo ever so wonderful :)) Overall rating: 8.5/10

Our first stop on a three week tour of Japan included four nights at the ANA InterContinental Tokyo. This hotel is conveniently located to the bars and restaurants in Roppongi and has two metro stations nearby serving four different metro lines - very handy. Concierge is excellent and can help you out with any question - we had great local restaurant recommendations. The room we had was quiet and spacious and very comfortable. A great hotel and would stay here again.

For a five star hotel, the ANA performs very well in terms of location, quality of service, on site restaurants, views from higher floors, quietness of the rooms. But the bathroom is well under par, with a curtain for the shower and rust in the sink. This is good for a 2-3 stars hotel. Definitely in need of some refresh. For a combination of business and pleasure, certainly worth considering. For business only, hotels closer to the TCAT might be a better option.

ANA Intercontinental Tokyo is my regular hotel for business travel in Tokyo. I just love the look and location of this hotel. It's right about in the middle of the Ginza line with the subway station just 50m from the hotel.There are lots of dining options both expensive and cheap ones around the hotel. The rooms are pretty large with top class amenities. Service is top-notch as well. All-in-all, it truly is a five star hotel.Highly recommended hotel!

As many of the previous guests already pointed out, this hotel falls a little short of 5-star standards. Rooms are very dated, with old furniture and facilities that needed replacement ages ago- the bathroom just lacked style with the brownish-hued bathtub and lack of amenities- conditioner, soap and shampoo came in pre- filled industrial size bottles. No complimentary water. The noise isolation between two connecting rooms consisted in an old, horrible looking sponge. The location is good if you're in Tokyo with business, if you're travelling for pleasure you might consider another district. It is close though to the Ginza line which has good connections in the city and also connected to the Marunouchi line for which you'll have to be prepared for a 1 km stroll through an under passage. Upper floors have a good view of the city, we stayed on the 16th floor and our views of the Tokyo Tower were half blocked by another building. All in all, it was a decent stay, but I would consider staying in another hotel next time I'll visit Tokyo

We requested for a room facing the Tokyo Tower hoping to see the fireworks but there was none. But the view of Tokyo Tower was enough to captivate you. The hotel in strategically placed. It is a skip and a hop from the train station. Staff are very friendly and helpful.

We stayed here for few nights. The hotel is not close to any major touristic attraction but is easily accessible thanks to a tube station around the corner. Rooms are comfortable but a bit small. The breakfast buffet is the best as the Chinese restaurant.

I have stayed in this hotel on numerous occasions.Well located.Impeccable service.Outstanding French restaurant..Very very rooms and well planned.The staff is outstanding so efficient and agile.If you would like to stay in central Tokyo and get outstanding value for money then this is the place for you.

Recently returned from a pleasant stay at this excellent Hotel centrally located and well run with helpful staff and spacious rooms. You may encounter a problem with some staff not understanding English but majority do. However at the Concierge desk there was really only one person ( a young lady whose name I do not know) whose knowledge of English was excellent others were only so so...Also she gave very detailed and helpful explanations . My only regret was not asking her name as I would like to commend her.

I am currently an in house guest in the hotel. I am very disappointed at the service standard of this international hotel that purportedly has a 5 star rating. When I arrived to check in, I was greeted by a guest relations officer at the check in counter (ambassador check in) , she didn’t bother much to explain my room facilities nor did she bother to explain what my room package was to offer. She told me in a curt way that the room was not available and I should just head to the gym to shower to freshen up should I want to, I asked her what time the room would be available but she told me that she cannot confirm as the guest inside the room was a VIP though I explained to her that I was offered to check in earlier by the chief concierge as my flight to arrive was earlier in the morning. Nonetheless, I agreed that since the hotel was full and I had no choice but to shower at the gym and go out till a later time. I went out to have my meal with my clients.Usually as a priority guest in the other hotels (SPG- my rooms would be ready. KEIO plaza hotel as a normal guest, my room was ready as I arrived in the same flight in the same season).The experience was made worse when I wanted to obtain the luggage form the concierge/ bell personnel. The gentlemen at the counter wasn’t courteous, was rather impatient, he passed off some Japanese remarks at me, which I couldn’t understand. I thought that he was universal in behaviour however; to my shock and disbelief he was very courteous to another person who was American! I found this unbecoming of a hotel!I returned to the hotel at 4pm, I proceeded to the Check In Counter again and my room was ready, I was just passed the keys to the room and I was not directed to the room, and I was made to wait for 45 minutes for my luggage with my clients in the room as the documents that I needed to pass to them was inside my luggage. I have no clue whatsoever on how they are in they set their service quality standards or why they are practicing preferential treatment in regards to the nationality of guest. I am a Singaporean Chinese and I don’t believe that I have been rude to any of the hotel staff at all.This is highly disappointing and unbecoming.

Still got another half day or so to go here at the ANA Intercon, but thought I'd draft the review anyway. Have stayed at the Intercontinental hotels lots of times so am a Platinum Ambassador and as such managed to get a 5 night stay pretty much all on points here. Started brilliantly with my wife asking if we had a refurbished room (had read from previous reviews that this was the way to go) and being told that we had been upgraded and just got better from there onwards. We had chosen to take the Club Intercontinental package as part of the stay, and let me say as a tip it's totally worth it! Breakfasts - fantastic, afternoon tea - lovely, evening cocktails and canapés - outstanding. Not many places give you champagne as part of the Club package - usually good sparkling - but they do here and it's great. The food is beautifully presented and tastes delicious, with a really wide variety to suit all tastes - kudos to the kitchen team. As for the staff in general, outstanding! The concierge gave us loads of ideas for our time in Tokyo and was spot on with where to see the cherry blossoms, the team in the Club Lounge were all excellent and looked after us really well, and our room was always looking first class with the room service also being spot on. The stay was finally capped by a bottle of complimentary champagne being delivered to our room as part of our anniversary / my birthday celebrations. Sounds like I'm raving, but seriously this was a 6 out of 5 stay (and don't forget to take the Club package)!

i stayed in the Tokyo ANA Intercontinental for a week. It is very conveniently located around the CBD Area. It has a lot of places around to explore especially the happening places like Roppongi which has lots of restaurants around the area. It is easily accessible by the Tokyo Metro Service and has approximately 3 stations around the hotel. It is an excellent location for a business traveler. The Hotel staff is very polite and extra helpful with any needs that you may have. They have a concierge desk which is very knowledgeable and guides you with the must-see places in Tokyo

the hotel was amazing. we went every where in tokyo and it was so easy for this location. the staff did everything we asked of them.. we loved the 36th floor bar with amazing veiws. would definitely stay here again even with our kids..

Hotel looks very dated from the outside and it's a case of being able to judge a book by its cover. Rooms are dated, with soft beds and service was below average for a 5 star hotel in Tokyo. The real issue I have is how they scrimp on small things that are very standard at other 5 star hotels I've stayed at before in Tokyo (Mandarin, Conrad).When I got to the hotel after an 8 hour flight I asked for a bottle of water at check in. They told me they cannot give me a complimentary bottle of water. There are also no complimentary bottles of water in the rooms or the gym. Another annoyance is no free wifi, no even in the communal areas. Hotel is extremely poor value given the sub par service, dated rooms and the fact that they scrimp on low value items. I would not recommend this hotel.Positives:- Good, convenient location- Fitness facilities have been renovated. Good functional 24 hour gym- Nice Tonkatsu in the Ari Building next door (Tonkatsu Wako on 3F)

Stayed two nights in this hotel on a business trip. Its in Ark Hills/Mori Towers but if you're not on business it might be less convenient. The staff are professional. There are several dining options nearby and its not far from Roppongi by taxi, which are always in attendance. Rooms are cosy. The club lounge has great views and feels like a club, rather than the noisy creche one finds at some hotels.

beautiful hotel with great dining facilities. great location. rooms are small by american standards but remember the price of real estate in tokyo and even given the size, it had everything i needed for a great stay. friendly, helpful staff. clean and beautifully appointed and run. thanx for a great stay!

The rooms are clean and efficient, the bathroom welcoming. There is an iron and board in the closet. The property is close to the subway and has every amenity. The only downside is the morning breakfast -- which is an utter mob. 10 people queuing for an omelette. At certain times having to wait even for a table. Lots of choices but people everywhere jostling for everything. You are better off walking to a nearby restaurant or coffee bar.

With its excellent location this is a well serviced and friendly hotel. Lobby and social areas are very welcoming, staff are superbly courteous and everything is to a very good standard. Rooms are totally functional, though decor is looking a bit dated - not worn, just in style, but this is a minor issue.

This is a nice hotel but pricey. It is too far from city center but there was a small area about 20 minutes away where you could see a Temple. That part was enjoyable but overall the hotel's location was only sufficient for the overnight stay. We accidentally checked one guest and when we checked in, they increased our rate for the second person. Breakfast was okay except for the incredible runny eggs.

If you are traveling for business, yes this may be a good choice. However if you are going to stay with your loved one, family and looking for quality time i would not recommend it to anyone. ANA Intercontinental was the wrong choice for me.So crowded with business men(company paid rooms), ignorant, loud, foul mouthed (i was so surprised) western embassy workers (hotel is surrounded with embassies) and some military types. And you have to have shoulder to shoulder breakfast with this clientele as breakfast lounge is very small and tables are so close to each other. You need to wait in the queue to have breakfast as well. Rooms are very small but clean. I have no negative comment for staff as they are doing their best in this condition. it is very natural for them not to smile.You can not blame them. As i said good for current clientele, may be for friends and solo but not for couples or families.

Excellent service at reception, great fitness center and a ton of good restaurants inside. Awesome breakfast selection with both japanese and western options. There is a nice small park behind the hotel that is great to strech your legs and refresh yourself.

Our first time in Tokyo. Great location and excellent service throughout our 2 night stay after 8 days skiing in Niseko. We were so looking forward to a change of pace and were not disappointed. Well taken care of with access to the Club level for breakfast and evening Champagne and canapes. A real treat. Highly recommend this hotel.

Well situated hotel with ample facilities. We stayed there 3 nights after a cruise and everything was great. The breakfast is buffet style and as much as you can eat. The restaurant is a quite noisy especially with some younger guests. It can get quite hot nearer the Japanese food section. The room was clean and well maintained. The beds were very comfortable and the toilet shower quite interesting! There was no noise apparent from other guests in nearby rooms. We had a standard room on the 12th floor and it was perfect for our needs. there was tea and coffee making facilities in our room. The restaurants in the hotel are quite expensive and we ate out at Ark Hills next door.

I had a great four day stay at this hotel. The buffet breakfast is excellent! The staff is very courteous and can speak great english. The lobby is beautiful with its great big waterfall and the fitness center met all my needs. Rooms were nice and I had a fabulous view.The two cons I have are the American feel and the charge for business center use. I am from America, so I'm not anti-American hotels by any means...but if in Tokyo, Japan, I feel like I would want more of an authentic Tokyo feel. But, if you are in the country for the first time and feel very uneasy about it--this would be a good "home base." I was disappointed that I had to pay for my 15 minutes of usage in the business center--while using my 15 minutes, I w as allowed to print a max of 10 pages-black/white.Overall, great stay.

Well located in Tokyo near to Roppongi, and convenient from Narita using the Limo Bus, this is a great business hotel. Breakfast is good, I never had a problem with taxis either from or to the hotel, and the room was comfortable and clean. The wifi was also good.

Business trip stay and was not disappointed. Rooms are very nice with every amenity you'd expect and need. Very large breakfast buffet to suit anyone's taste. The hotel has a number of restaurants and I did try the Steakhouse, which was just okay. But beware that it closes at 9:30pm(!). The Mixx Lounge has good drinks and spectacular views. There are numerous restaurants just outside the door of the hotel, and a Starbucks (but you can use your US app, so no stars for you). The hotel is located very close to the Tokyo Metro, which is surprisingly easy to use. Wifi was very reliable, which I need for business travel. I'll be back in the future.

This is a very American-style hotel that looks like the interior was designed in the 1970s. A lot of brown and beige. It is comfortable, and the room was very quiet. It is a convenient hotel if you are staying on business but holiday-makers should consider other options that have a Japanese flavour.It is located less than five minutes' walk from the entrance to the subway station; once you get inside the station it's about 5-10 minutes' walk to get to the actual platform. There's several convenience stores within easy walking distance to the hotel, including inside the subway tunnel.I think I was on the smoking floor (level 19); despite there being no ashtray in my room, the entire floor stunk of cigarettes as soon as you stepped out of the elevator. This was the case for the entire 5 days of my stay. Very unpleasant!The breakfast was OK. A little bit of everything, with the quality being fairly 'average'. The internet access was very expensive. I would expect a hotel like this to provide wifi free of charge, this is 2016.

This is a great Hotel in Tokyo, there is a limo bus service from the Narita airport directly to the Ana InterContinental. Subway is next door and from there you have Tokyo at your reach. Breakfast buffet is great with both Japanese and western food, close walk and you have great dinner options too. I highly recommend this hotel.

Good central location and moderne international hotel. Nice and very comfortable rooms. Ask for Tokyo tower view it's just fantastic. Fitness center and outdoor pool available. Big breakfast buffet. Many restaurants available, have a last drink at the panoramic bar at the 36th floor. It's just disappointing, when you choose and stay at this hotel for you and your colleagues every year since 18years and at the checkin they ask you if you come for the first time ... Don't they have a kind of data base ?

My second visit here on a company visit. Last time was a great visit so decided to stay here again. Booked a non-smoking room, on arrival was told that the only non-smoking room available is a twin room which I did not want, so insisted on giving me what I had booked. After going back and forth for about 10 minutes the receptionist finally gave in and provided me a king room in the next available category. Now I am a gold status member with IHG and give them about 20-30 room nights a year. So I was expecting this service to be provided directly without any issues. However those 10 minutes of negotiations after a long haul flight does leave a bad taste.However I would imagine this to be a one off instance... I will be back soon as this is a great location for my business needs. Room Service Menu could be better though.

We have stayed at the ANA InterContinental Tokyo twice, in Jan. 2014 and April 2015. This is an excellent hotel with a great location. Just a few stops from the subway, so a perfect launch pad for exploration of Tokyo. Hotel interiors (lobby, rooms, etc.) were lovely. The staff was extremely pleasant and helpful. Concierge was a huge helping plan various activities. Breakfast in the Cascade Cafe was exceptional. Would recommend highly!

Hard to find anyone but Americans in this hotel. It is a huge complex in middle of Tokyo with medium sized rooms that we're just ok. The breakfast buffet was awesome and opens at 6:00am, which was especially good for those who can't sleep! If this was a vacation I'd probably want to stay at a more "Japanese" hotel.

Second time staying at this point. The last time was upgraded to 22nd floor (Executive Floor) and it was fantastic. This time in room 1528 and it's a world of difference.The carpet in the corridors and the room all look dirty, gray, and stained. I DO hope that they have plan to refurbish the floor and just haven't gotten around to it.Despite being a non-smoking floor, the room smelled smoky.

We ate dinner at ANA intercontinental Tokyo. We went buffet style restaurant. It had a lot of kind food like seafood, meat, and sweets. They have many kinds of macaroni and it looks amazing. Also Seafood is pretty great and I would like to visit again. Hopefully I can stay at this hotel as well.

On my way to Singapore spent the night at Intercon for early morning meeting. It a vey good hotel, I received complimentary room upgraded and the room and facilities are in very good state. Service and the breakfast was very good and certainly worth a compliment.

Generally satisfied with our stay. Great check in experience as staff who spoke Mandarin from Taiwan and tall Caucasian man was excellent and warm, that made a great start and impression. The guest services for electric adapter man was excellent as well and housekeeper too!The only one fault I would say was that the executive lounge has a price to enter and even if you are platinum or in executive room. Otherwise, service excellent! Room service food was tasty as well. Rooms well appointed and clean! Thanks to the staff of hotel for a very nice stay!

it is a nice hotel that located very convenience close to the subwaythe room is ok but old and good size. you have to pay for the wifi while it is free in most of hotel in tokyo even in 4 stars hotelswhen we checked in around 11pm and there is no room ready so we are being adviced to be back later to collect the key and we really request for the room in the same floor but when we are back at night to collect the key and we are given different floor and the staff said that we are full and no requesti start to think that intercontinental is not my preferable hotel or choice any more since i had a bad experience in intercontinental stanford hongkong before and now in tokyo.we choose this hotel since we have no more option during the new year holiday and this is the only hotel that available despite of my bad experience with this brand previously

Let me start by saying that everywhere we went and everywhere we stayed in Japan was just superb. This hotel was not an exception. Located right next to the subway and just a few stops away from the Shinkansen train stop and downtown Tokyo this was just a perfect location to stay in Tokyo. You've got a mini mart 5 minutes away, a Starbucks ( :) ), small local eateries, etc. Rooms are very nice and clean, there are restaurants inside the hotel as well, just everything you'd expect from a premier hotel. I'd recommend to definitely consider this hotel when planning your trip to Tokyo.

We came for a Valentines holiday. We were blown away about how great the hotel is. The staff is so helpful and the manager is very involved with the customers and personally asked us if there is anything we needed. The steakhouse is amazing with a great wine selection and the room has a nice view and good size with a great bed. This is the place to stay if you want a hotel that is close to the subway and surrounded by many attractions to see!

This ANA location is prime in Tokyo with easy walking to Akasaka and Roppingi areas and also close to the Imperial Palace. You are also very close to many embassies including the USA Embassy. Access to subway and trains very easy.The hotel staff are unfailing friendly and at your service.The hotel gym is excellent and the restaurant selections are plentiful. The hotel is frequently busy with business conferences and weddings.Some hallway areas and rooms in the hotel are sorely in need of refurbishment needing new carpet and upholstery which is the only reason to not get a higher rating from me. Beds and pillows are very comfy and air conditioning is whisper quiet.Wifi is reliable and fast. I have stayed here many times in the past three years and will continue to enjoy this fine hotel.

Great service, excellent rooms and easy to find. Asked for a late checkout - accommodated at no charge and without fuss. From bullet train its one change a and a 30 second walk - want to submit this but it won't go unless I use 200 characters so ............

The hotel is in a great central location right in the heart of Tokyo and the Tokyo Tower is close by.The staff are exceptional and in my 3 stay they have always been exceptional. English speaking staff are very common throughout, making life easy fir those who don't speak another language. Plenty of restaurants to choose and the one's I've tried have been great. That is except for the buffet breakfast and this was my complaint some months back on my last stay. It's disappointing to see feedback (from many it seems) does not get addressed. Room service is first class as the food is very good and HOT which often is not the case even in 5 star hotels - cheese burger is very good as is everything I've tried including from the specialty menu options.Rooms are very clean and beds are extremely comfortable. I either stay here or at Intercon Tokyo Bay and I'd suggest ANA Intercon is more central, better restaurants, yet Tokyo Bay enjoys a much better outlook over the bay.Overall very good but if they don't address the buffet breakfast, I'll stick with Tokyo Bay Intercon next time I think simply due to very poor breakfast at ANA.

This was a last minute trip and not many choices on hotels but what a stroke of luck. We stayed over Christmas so it was busy. Located right next to metro station. Walking distance from tons of restaurants in the neighborhood. The room was large and enough space for my husband and son as well. Modern decor and very comfortable. Bathroom large and very well equipped. The one big thing I will miss about this hotel was their buffet. Omg! We ate there every morning. I guess decadent comes to my mind. They had everything I would want from western food and Asian food. A little expensive but worth it compared to some hotels I stayed at.

The InterContinental ANA is an excellent hotel. The rooms are most comfortable - and quiet - and the larger rooms are equivalent to what most Westerners would be accustomed to. It has a great location and you are within walking distance to many restaurants. A short taxi ride will take you to some serious shopping areas. The hotel gym was well sized and had roughly a dozen aerobic machines (cross trainers, bikes, and treadmills) and also weight lifting equipment. The lobby restaurant puts on a good, albeit it somewhat expensive, buffet breakfast. There is no reason to go away hungry. There are other bars and restaurants within the hotel for those who don't want to adventure out. The rooms and the hotel were kept immaculately clean. WiFi was free, but I think that was because I am a member of the IHG club.

PositivesClean and tidyGood service response and approachConvenient for central TokyoNegativesNot well organized for families with small children: Additional bed charge for small children unreasonable (@US$ equivalent 100 per night)Limited towel drying hangers in bathroomNo complimentary water provided (although you can drink tap water, as advised by staff)

ANA Intercon is my favourite. I've stayed at all the other Intercons in Japan. The upkeep, service and hospitality has been impeccable all these 30 years since I first came to Japan and stepped foot into ANA Intercon. We've been to almost 40 over countries and stayed at major top hotels of the world including Intercons as well. It is only a Japanese-run hotel and Japanese staff who can pay attention to details and maintain excellent housekeeping and cleanliness. The hotel itself is dated but every inch very clean. We are appreciative. We visits various parts of Japan at least 3 times annually and have always been impressed by Japanese quality and standards. This trip is about eating Japanese food and staying at ANA Intercon, even though we have our own apartment in Azabujuban. Great job ANA Intercon and kudos to the Japanese team!

My second stay here, and I wanted to return. Room was spacious, and utterly quiet<most important. Very clean. Gold member check-in took minutes & unafiliated friends lodged next-door. Starbucks (so important for quelling jet lag!) steps away to the left, subway stop steps to the left. Various grocery stores and many restaurants in the Ark Hills complex (Tsukiji Sushiko & Okonomiyaki of Toda Wataru both terrific, will review next). Walked to the Imperial Palace, to the Tsukiji fish market, various gardens. A pleasure! I will return to this hotel.

ANA is one of the most average hotels with really poor service. I am a Gold member for IHG yet the service was bad. I asked for water and they said it is not free. It is only when I told them that I had options to stay at any hotel and I was a gold member they said sorry and sent the water. Bathtub was really small.

It was the second time we stayed at ANA intercontinental and again as the photos show the room and especially the bathroom were extremely dirty. Shocking; especially compared to other hotels in Japan. This hotel is in desperate need for updating the interior and introduce better cleaning standards. For the same price you can get much better quality in Tokyo. Hotel is now more being used for flight crews, large tour groups and conferences.

To save the time of the readers I will start with the only drawback they have - the windows don't open. So, if you are sensitive to the absence of frsh air, find some other option.All the rest is very, very good if not perfect. The rooms are of reasonable size with climate controle which works very well and is not noisy at all. Quite spacious bathroom with variable toiletties and perfect towels. The breakfast area is very big and buffet is bountiful with variety of choice to satisfy all tasts. The location is great - 1 minute of walk from the metro station. They also have their airport limousine bus service. So, I can recommend this hotel for different purposes of stay.

What can you expect from Japan…. warm welcoming. From the moment you step in the airport its like you travel to other dimension. The people dear are just lovely, the staff in the hotel are great and the rooms are wow, bed is very cozy, bit hard just perfect in my case. The bathroom is a bit small but has everything you need.The hotel facilities are very good and not to mention the food, breakfast was amazing everything was fresh and tasty also the room service.The location is great and the facilities as well, the hotel is a great place to stay if you are in Japan you wont be disappointed.Greg Black

We went on vacation to Tokyo in October and stayed at ANA Intercontinental.We found the hotel staff to be very efficient, friendly and helpful. We were worried before wearrived, about the language issues we might face. We faced none of it. The staff spoke great English and if they didnt, they took pains to get someone who spoke.Concierge was also superb, helping to sort out travel arrangements for our Tokyo day trip as well as trip to Mt.Fuji. We were made to feel comfortable at all times.The breakfast buffet at this hotel is great. Large spreads and a huge hall with lot of space. My wife and son loved every bit of the stay.Tokyo Metro is right next door. Tamaika-Sanno station is probbaly a 5 minute walk. Although the platform is a bit of a walk. The good thing with the stations in Tokyo is that you get free wi-fi. The hotel doesnt provide free-wifi, which i thought was a bit of a downer. I think an international chain should provide free wi-fi.Overall, I will recommend this hotel to my friends and colleagues.

The service at the hotel was very good. We had a 4 year old and the cleaners gave him at least 4 pairs of cute colorful children slippers, toothbrush and sponge during the 6 days stay. He was very happy! The hotel is conveniently located near a MTR, local supermarkets and restaurants. I was disappointed with the standard of the rooms given it was a 5 star hotel. The decor was dated, especially the bathroom.Room service was standard although would have been good if they had more Japanese food on the menu.The views from the rooms differ depending on which side you were in. We had 2 rooms on the same floor, one on the corner looking down to a graveyard and the other facing the Tokyo Tower!Overall i think it was a nice hotel and comfortable stay but its a bit pricey for what it is.We had corporate discounts up to 50% so it was worth it but wouldn't pay full price.

The ANA InterContinental is a solid 5 star business hotel in an excellent location (Ginza line from adjacent station takes visitors to most places of interest). Rooms and public spaces are in a good state of maintenance with attractive décor typical for such high end chain hotels.Staff was exceptionally friendly, helpful and very accommodating when we had a special request.Rooms are of good size for Tokyo and comfortably appointed, offering a great value for money.The bar on the top floor has amazing views and great drinks.

We chose the ANA for its Hilton Honors points, and were given a nice corner room. The hotel is right on a highway over pass, so it's not that nice from the outside, but it's close to many subway lines and restaurants - continental and local cuisine. The room was big for a city - with a nice view of the courtyard and hills. There was some street noise, despite being on the 28th floor. Amenities were standard Intercontinental. The toilet was Japanese style, but not a newer model.The mini fridge had room to stash a few things - yogurt, etc. There was a kettle with tea, but only instant coffee. We bought the single cup 'pour overs' from the grocery nearby and used those for our wake up coffee.As HH Honors members we got free bottled water every day, and some fruit part way through our stay. There were more US visitors in the hotel than most other places we visited in Tokyo.

It wasn't impressive at all because the hotel was pretty old. We stayed in a double room. The room was very old style. The toilet was not great at all. I expected more from an intercontinental hotel. The food at the steak house was alright, but honestly, not as good as how much it was cost though. Only outdoor pool and opens only during summer period. It'd be nice to have an indoor one. The room would only give you free wifi if you were IHG member, luckily my husband was. If not, it seemed you needed to pay for wifi. However, they provided with Shiseido shower Jel, shampoo and conditioner, which was nice. Locationwise, it located in Roppongi area right above Tameiko-sanno station which made the trip so much easier (however, you would get to the train after walking through the station for around 5-8 mins, to me it's not too bad, at least there's cover when it's raining). Only a few restaurants around the hotel. But you could find many restaurants when you walk around 10mins towards the Toronmo area. There's a street full of restaurants. it's only one station away from Akasaka-mitsuke station and only needed to change to the opposite platform for the marunouchi line to Shinjuku station. It took only around 15 mins to Shinjuku! Moreover, you could go to Shibuya station from Tameike-Sanno station directly for only about 10-15 mins by Ginza line. Walkable distance to Roppongi Hills and Tokyo Midtown, which would be nice for people who want to do some shopping there ( but these two malls were boring malls for me, as they sold only western brands, not as fun as in Keio/Mylord/Odakyu department stalls). And yes, it was easy to go to Ueno station, again by Ginza line. It took around 20mins only.The hotel staff at the reception and the information area were very nice and helpful.Stayed at this hotel for six nights. Before we left Japan, we went to Hakone for three days. ANA intercontinental hotel was nice enough to let us leave our luggage at the hotel after checkout. This made our trip to Hakone a lot easier.We came to the hotel by limousine bus. Cost around 3100 yen per person. We did the same back to the airport. However, I reseved the return trip limousine bus tickets three days ago at the ticket booth on the second floor of the hotel. I saw the staff wrote down my room number and my name for the reservation and he also confirmed the reservation was made. When the time we got back our luggage and went to the ticket office on the first floor, the staff couldn't find our reservation. Luckily there were still some seats left for us!! But it's a bit annoying. This bus took around 1.30 hours to and from the airport. The first stop from the airport was ANA intercontinental hotel. Very easy. Hope the above helps.

I stayed here 12 months ago, and after viewing the website i was disappointed when I was put into one of the old rooms!. This tii was given one of the newer refurbished rooms which was very nice indeed, so if you can try and insist on a new room!The location is excellent, the service superb, the breakfast is good, and as ever nothing is too much trouble!All in a all a good business hotel!

When visiting Tokyo last month I had the good fortune of staying at the ANA Intercontinental Tokyo.From the moment I checked in I realised that "attention to detail"is core policy.Nothing was too much trouble for the staff,indeed they anticipated my needs as if I was a frequent guest,which I wasn't.My room was very comfortable with great views of downtown Tokyo but the jewel in the crown was the Club Intercontinental lounge.Possibly the best VIP lounge I have ever used,certainly the best staff!.If you ever have the opportunity of staying at this hotel,upgrade to "Lounge access",you will not regret it.One other highlight of my trip which must be mentioned was dinner at Teppanyaki Akasawa on the 37th floor.The best teppanyaki I have ever eaten and over the past 50 years I have tried them all!!.I will be returning to this hotel and highly recommend it to anyone travelling to Tokyo soon.

Centrally located and 5 star, there is not a lot more you could want. My room was good clean, spacious but a little dated. The breakfast buffet was very good and I recommend that you try to book it as part of your room rate to get it at a reasonable price, because if you are at all like me and you wake up hungry as the norm then its great value! The bars are good and there are some superb restaurants here including a Michelin-starred restaurant. To get the best views ask for the upper floors and facing the Tokyo Tower if you can get them its worth it.

Very nice room and comfortable facilities, helpful staff. Very conveniently located, close to shopping places, malls, restaurants, coffee shops, MRT. Easy access to Limo bus. Just can't ask for anything more.

Fantastic hotel, centrally located.A very busy hotel, staff are very attentive and extremely helpful.Huge thanks to the Assistant Front Office Manager who went to great lengths to arrange shipment of my wallet that i left in the in-room safe.Many thanks to the whole team, we had a fantastic time in your hotel!

It didn't compare well to other ICs across Asia - the service was good along with the location, the lobby area is spectacular but the room was very average and tired. Maybe other floors have already been upgraded, but mine certainly needs. Also very expensive car from Haneda stinking of cigarettes and no water or wifi. Clearly spoilt by other Asian ICs.

Fantastic Japanese hospitality, stayed at the club room. Nice view, with average room size. Location of the hotel is very good as Tokyo has all to do things scattered around the city, this hotel is right by the subway and you can get to any corner easily. Club lounge is excellent. Great variety of all drinks and food with good quality.Room: Very cleanLocation: Very good,Service: Excellent,Food: Awesome

The hotel room is a bit old style. But the location is super! Close to two different mtr lines. Has airport bus access. Walking distance to Roppongi. However, there is nothing around the hotel other than familymart/7-11, and some small restaurants.

It was our first trip to Japan and the ANA Intercontinental Tokyo was our first accommodation during our trip in the summer of 2015. Location wise the hotel was ok, more or less near the metro station and within walking distance of several restaurants. The room was clean and the service was what you could expect from a business hotel in the city. A major surprise, unpleasant so to say, is that after a hot day of sightseeing we decided to cool off in the pool. Here we learned that we had to pay 4,000 yen per person!! Being a family of four we would have to pay almost €120! That's really outrageous, as the room itself costed around €250...the kids were so disappointed. Overall, I found it outrageous that guests have to pay for the pool, but I found it even more disappointing that we weren't even granted complimentary access to the pool, although we had a Ambassador Gold card from Intercontinental! Very disappointing...

Last evening I returned to my room to find my bathroom door was jammed shut. I phone the instant help and friendly member of staff came and tried to help. I left him in the room to rectify the problem whilst I went for a late evening meal. When I returned 2 hours later there was a team of locksmiths working on my poor door. They soon repaired the lock. In true Japanese courtesy the team apologized many times and offered me a small gift. I want to thank the hotel for their efforts and courtesy. The team minimized my disruption and apologized.This marks a great hotel. Any hotel can look good when there are no issues. A great hotel shines when things go wrong, so thank you ANA Intercontinental

Last minute travel, got tickets 5 days before arrival over Christmas, so not my first choice hotel/neighborhood but was really hard booking something decent/well located for first time in Tokyo. I always like InterContinental Hotels, they are good and is usually decent value for 4/5 stars.Room were fairly big (pay a little extra travelling with 1 Kid), but room were OK, Bathroom were old and need refresh, room was not a remodeled one I think. Great view of the city. Very friendly staff and excellent quality service (it is Japan). I did not tried the restaurants in the hotel, except for the morning buffet which is an amazing!!! So many different items east/west style breakfast, really great. Location is OK,, a lot of restaurants to go to within 15 minutes walk, metro station next to hotel with 2 stops changes to major lines if needed, of course 7/11 store and mini mart next to hotel. Price was high but decent for Tokyo. Good for family.I will stay again here, even if many other great hotels in Tokyo in this price range.

This hotel was a fantastic compromise for the price. For some reason, hotels got booked out very fast and prices were astronomical compared to the year prior during this same time. Saying that we went with Intercontinental and found the stay very pleasant. The check in and check out service was very pleasant and efficient. There are a few great restaurants in the hotel including a French 3 star michelin. The location was close to all the action of Roppongi Hills , but far enough away for peaceful rest. Be sure to make your reservation through the hotel directly to ensure a nice upgraded room. I understand some rooms are not upgraded which could explain some negative reviews.

I didn't have much choice on the hotel as we needed to stay in Tokyo over the new year period when all the hotels were booked out, so I booked using a corporate travel agent. The hotel is quite dated now and although the rooms are very big for Tokyo, the bathrooms are in need of renovation. The location is not great as the Oedo line which is in the closest station doesn't really go anywhere nice that I would want to go to. Outside of the hotel is a major road with a freeway going over it so it's not nice to walk around. Behind the hotel is the US embassy, so again, not much to do around the area. One positive was the gym which was small but modern and functional. Also, the bakery on the lobby floor was very nice. I would stay in Ginza the next time for all the restaurants, or near a Yamanote-line station which is a more useful line that takes you to all the major areas (Shibuya, Harajuku, Yanaka, Tokyo, Shinjuku etc).

Easy to reach with the limousine bus from Narita airport.The location close to Rhoppongi entertainment area is a plus if one likes it.Easy access to a closeby underground train station.It is a quite huge hotel.Staff is very professional and mostly very friendly.Rooms are with a good size for Tokyo, where rooms ar often very small.Room design of the standard rooms is not most modern but absolutely ok.Nice, clean and very functional bathroom with a big shower area and a bath tube.The breackfast is really great, slection of almost all kinds of excellent food, don't miss it!Can recoomend this hotel, would stay there any time again.

We stayed here partially for business and partially for leisure. It was very enjoyable and checked all the boxes. The rooms were clean and in excellent condition. They were quite roomy by Tokyo standards. We had a great view of the city from our window. The staff all spoke excellent English and were efficient and courteous. Also, the business center was well-equipped and easy to use. The location was great--central, and the Ginza line stops right outside the hotel entrance. It is also easily accessible from Narita airport by the limo bus service. There was only one slight irregularity: Our stay was split into two segments of two nights each. As a result, we stayed in two different rooms, for which we paid identical rates. The first room seemed renovated and immaculately made up, and featured excellent bathroom amenities (individual bottles of shampoo, lotion, conditioner, etc). The second room was slightly older but still comfortable--however, the bathroom had a dispenser on the wall for all the shampoo and conditioner, etc. It was not a huge problem, however, it was slightly disconcerting, considering we had paid the same rate for both rooms and I don't usually encounter wall dispensers in hotels of this caliber. Overall, though, it was a very nice stay.

We (2 adults and 1 kid) took a double room with an extra bed in Dec 2015. The hotel is a typical big hotel with a big lobby and many outlets. It is also right next to several office complexes that have many restaurants. The subway station is within a minute walk from the hotel. There are 3 convenient stores and a local coffee shop nearby. Unfortunately, WIFI is not free.The hotel's breakfast buffet is impressively BIG that serves both Western, Japanese and Asian dishes.

I like this hotel and have stayed here twice. Once on business and once with my family of 5. The location is right next to the Ginza subway line and had 6 or 7 restaurants in-house. All different and interesting. The breakfast buffet is amazing. Service is top notch. The only issue could be there is not much within walking distance - although everything within a short train ride. I recommend this hotel. Its a great value.

Stayed here 7 nights, nice room, quite large for Japan standards, good location too, nearby trains/buses easy to get around Tokyo.Room service meals were of quite a high standard.I have a feeling there was no free wifi, but free lan connection internet.Small but good enough gym to use. (Tattoo is okay.)You get what you pay for, and it is quite good.Bad thing is that even though you are paying to stay at this hotel, you still have to pay an extra fee of around $40AUD pp/day to use the hotel pool...!!?!?!?I have come to notice it is a weird Japanese custom to charge pool usage at hotels, but maybe ANA should take the lead and make pool usage only open for use and free to use to their hotel guests (Like it normally would be 99% of the world).

First time in Japan and so far have enjoyed our first night here . We are completely in the dark re culture and language but have found staff to be extremely accommodating and friendly . We are traveling with 3 kids 8,5,3 and in a busy period . We had an issue with additional bedding in our corner suite 3121 with gray views of the city which was resolved in 30 min with extra beds provided for s small surcharge , a communication breakdown when I booked but easily resolved by caring concierge. We have been welcomed to the club lounge with great views and free drinks and gourmet canapés 5.30-7.30pm. A charge of $100usd a day gets you breakfast and lounge snacks and drinks. Well worth it. Looking forward to the rest of our stay .

I have spend about 100 nights a year at this hotel every year so I can say without a doubt that its not what it used to be. Its a nice hotel, and in a great location. Easy to catch a train or bus and close to just about everything you want to do outside of the office.The service is good, but not 5 star, the food is excellent in all the restaurants. the bar has a great view.The rooms are not what you would expect for the prices they charge, and frankly they have some serious issues with the fact that they run at 100% all of the time these days. I have spoken to the management there and they know that they have shortcomings, and they cant fix them all, which is understandable. That said they did indeed listen to some of my suggestions on how to make their top customers feel better about the day to day life of living in a hotel and they have put some of them changes i suggested into practice, which is nice to see.I stay because its on my company list and its not crazy expensive for me. but if i was paying normal rates i may have started to choose a different hotel as their are others that provide better overall service for the same prices.

Stayed at the ANA InterContinental for three nights. Service was great and friendly. Breakfast offers a wide range of Japanese as well as western dishes. Rooms are very big (for Tokyo) and tidy. Also the hotel has a great view from the high floors. I would strongly recommend for both business an tourism.

Executive floor has been recently renovated.It is recommended the executive floor if stay.Fitness is perfect except that there is no pool.Fitness is not the Asian non-Japanese.It's a big hotel but wrapped in silence and entering the room to finish the check-in.Hospitable service, such as the Ritz-Carlton can not be expected.However, it is possible to receive a courteous service.In the club lounge, it is possible to take breakfast and light dinner.Meals high in the hotel, but can be a relatively cheap meal if Ark Hills and Izumi Garden.Access within 5 minutes, but not directly connected to the subway station.Narita Airport limousine bus is accessing.Convenient taxi to Haneda and bullet train station.Boulevard side is very noisy, but the opposite side of the green is beautiful.Club lounge available at ¥ 10,000 up to 2 people.Recommend the use if there is room in the budget.

My non smoking room reaked of tobacco, so I had to change room. Room was pretty small, especially the bathroom, with rusty metals and poor quality toiletries. wOrst of all was no comp mineral water! That's outrageous when spending 52,000 yen a night! Cruel discrimination against those of us who need to take medication!dIsappointing that they had not organised my bus tickets to airport next morning, as requested at time of booking.Heavy condensation on room window.

I stayed here for 3 nights on business. Whilst my room was fine (if somewhat small) and all the common areas of the hotel clean and functional, I found the experience lacking in the personal touches.The hotel is VERY popular with flight crew, who I would imagine supply a lot of their business.Having stayed at The Peninsula previously, this doesn't come close to their standards.

Hotel has comfortable rooms with working wifi. Service is good, staff is courteous. Reception staff are quite efficient in check-ins and check-outs.Many dining options available in the hotel, although these are mostly full in the evenings. Would recommend booking in advance. Check out Teppen Yaki option.

The ANA InterContinental is well situated for business, located very close to the US Embassy in a good part of the city (though admittedly it appears that almost all of Tokyo is a good area). I found it very easy to move around the city via the subway stop just outside the hotel, even in the very hot and humid conditions of late July.The public spaces are very good - large lobby with several restaurants, excellent shoe shine service and a small assortment of high-end shops. Of particular note is the whisky bar on the mezzanine level - it has a fantastic selection and quite exceptional service.Unfortunately, my room did not live up to my expectations. As an IHG Spire Ambassador, I was upgraded to the next room level; while I was expecting it to still be small, I did not expect it to be dirty, but the area behind the sitting area (where the magazine rack is located) was thick with dust and had clearly not been cleaned for some time. The bathroom was clean (though very small) - the toilet was fitted with the usual electronic features expected in Japan, but the shower screen was a curtain, which is uncommon in IC hotels, which usually have a glass screen (the glass is highly preferable).Breakfast was a major disappointment - there is no a-la-carte option, with both the steakhouse and the buffet in the lobby serving pre-prepared food. There were no live cooking stations and the selection overall was poor. I opted to have a pastry in Pain et Gateaux de Pierre Gagnaire, also in the lobby (shops area), which was much better quality but did not offer any cooked options, as the name would suggest.Overall, I would likely stay here again due to the location and the good bars / restaurants, but I expect the service levels to improve if my business is to be assured.

Currently staying here. Lobby looks great. Outside looks great. Disappointed with the room on the 20th floor. Looks old and worn out. Small room and the light pink tiles in the bathroom makes it look even older. I couldn't find a lock box either. Stayed at the Grand Hyatt earlier and this place doesn't compare.

It was unbelievable to wait for 20 mins to check in. There were just 2 stuff on the reception, and a long line waiting for. Moreover, we didn't get any info that wifi is charged until we check out. The stuff of front desk didn't mention, and there was also no any reminding when u key in the room number and last name to connect the wifi. We were just like compel to pay for it as soon as the stuff print out the invoice and show front of you. It was very inadequate service process, and impossible to happen in a international starts hotel. Otherwise, as everybody says the room needs to be renovated and it's far from the metro station.I can only say I was very disappointed for the experience staying here.

This time we chose comfort. When people asked me where we stayed in Tokyo, I proudly say, we stayed at ANA Intercontinental Tokyo. The hotel is so nice, there is a nearby subway station, surrounded by government offices, embassies, so we feel safe and the staff are very accommodating especially the concierge. It really helped us in getting around Tokyo since we decided to go on our own. And the suite we selected was fit for a family of 4 and it was cleaned daily. Breakfast is good, my children loved it, so are we, likewise the restaurants inside the hotel. Since we got this Tatami Suite, it's a bit pricey, but no regrets, since this room is what we need, it is so complete. Wished we could have stayed longer.

Arrived at ANA Intercontinental Hotel - third visit to this hotel - at 6am.
