I was appointed a room on the 8th floor, however, as soon as I opened the door I knew that I couldn't stay in the room - it was smokey! Second room they allocated me (again on 8th floor) was equally smokey. Receptionist told me that "all rooms are no smoking so I was wrong"....... In addition old bathrooms (avocado green no less!) and old single beds. Eventually negotiated to stay in a very small room on 27th floor (which is where I stayed before at the same rate as this visit). This room has carpet which is peeling away from the floor - however, doesn;t smell like someone has chain smoked in it all night. So I guess I should be grateful for small mercies.Recommend to check the floor level you are being assigned first.

As an Ambassador Member, I expected room upgrade to be more spacious than it was. Our room was rather small compared to the Hilton at Tokyo Bay. Comparing service, we found Hilton to be fabulous, always obliging and helpful, whereas Intercontinental was perhaps 'reserved' and it was sometimes a struggle to get the help we required, having a young six year old with us. Room looked out over the Palace, location was fantastic. Room was small, as mentioned, but clean and modern. I also don't wish to imply staff were not friendly, they were, only service was not as efficient as Hilton. Foyer was cluttered and initially not easy to locate service desk. We enjoyed our stay but I would probably choose another hotel next time we visit Japan.

An impressive physical facility, within walking distance of a subway station with an excellent breakfast buffet. The staff were pleasant with many language skills available. The room was very comfortable with an excellent view of the city from the 27th floor. The club lounge has some excellent city views and the selection of snacks is very nice. An excellent place to stay in Tokyo.

ANA INTERCONTINENTAL Tokyo provide great services and is centrally located near shopping and restaurants in Aksaka and Rapongi. Hotel has many amenities and the club services are top notch. The staffs are courteous and very helpful. I had never had during my stay.

I have stayed in ANA hotel several times and every time it's a real pleasure. I just love it here. Firstly, the hotel is simply beautiful, nicely decorated, especially before Christmas. The live music in the lobby, amazing breakfast and great bar on the top floor. Room are spacious, excellent quality of sleep. I cannot get enough of this place.

Comfortable hotel with quite spacious rooms in the heart of the city. The bathrooms were equipped with top class modern fittings and amenities. Hotel staff were courteous and helpful. There is a general physician's chamber in the hotel building. However he is not available on Sundays and public holidays. The breakfast buffet is a sumptuous spread with Western and Asian cuisine. The only hitch is that complimentary water bottles kept in the room are very small and not sufficient. The staff are unwilling to provide more. In many 5 star hotels in Asia, complimentary water is also provided a second time in the evening. But this was not the case here. Cabs are available easily and the imperial palace is a ten minute cab ride from the hotel. The view from the window is of flyovers and glitzy cars plying over them.

I stayed a week at the ANA InterContinental Hotel in Tokyo for a business trip. All the staff were helpful and facilitate my arrival. The room was big enough (especially for Tokyo standard) and well equipped with a nice bathroom, TV, confortable bed, etc.The breakfast buffet was enjoyable and provided a lot of different choices. I have also tried "The Steakhouse" which as you can guess serve some pretty good piece of meat in a quiet atmosphere. The hotel is located near a train station, however you might have to walk quiet a bit depending of which train line you want to use.

We arrived at the hotel at 2 pm and were met with a young lady at the front desk. She took 20 minutes to allocate our rooms ( we had 3 rooms) and in the end informed us that all of us would twin bed rooms. Upon protest as we were all with our wives I was stunned to hear her response which was outright rude. I was quite astonished by it. Didn't expect a response like that from a hotel staff, specially in Japan.We had no choice but to accept it , with a promise to be moved later to a king bed room.the room we checked into was quite old and jaded....highly disappointing and we were resigned to a poor experience.Later they moved us to a king bed room on a slightly higher floor which to my surprise was quite modern and plush. we really liked this one.the rest of our stay was very comfortable.The location of the hotel is decent as its next to a station though there is very little in its vicinity.

We have stayed at the ANA many times and it just keeps getting better. The staff in every department is friendly and helpful. The food is especially good - they have a great chef, Francesco Bettoli, who is creative and operates with high standards. We definitely recommend the ANA.
user_name:
Tim H
Burlingame, California, United States

review_body: I have used this property for several great company events and dinners, and participated for several years in excellent large wine fairs at this hotel, so when I was told that my regular hotels in Tokyo were full, I did not hesitate to order at ANA Intercontinential. However I was really disappointed about the rooms and actually most of my stay at ANA intercontinental. Rooms are old fashioned, and really need an upgrade. As an example the ring inside the sink is rusted. Room desk etc is really not nice or 5 star but rather run down, and honestly something I associate with one or two stars less brands. My room was booked relatively late, but the high expense (and knowing the Tokyo market well) was in no way met by a great room. One of my biggest disappointments (apart from the oft occurring habit in Tokyo of breakfast not being included in a 500 dollar night room) was that there was no bottled shampoo, soap and conditioner. Intercontinental in Japan normally provide an excellent brand - called agrara or some thing similar. Here I got from that brand a bar of soap, and cheapo wall mounted dispensers for industrial quality shampoo etc. This is not going to cut it for someone who needs to look presentable in the office the next day. Also missing from any 5 star lineup - moisturizer. Again an excellent brand is provided in other Intercontinential hotels in Japan. Overall I did not feel at all that my needs to be clean and look good was taken care of. The room itself was clean but there was a think layer of dust on the back of the bathroom shaving mirror, and the overall feeling of the bathroom was old fashion, impractical and not particularly clean or at the very least yellow with age. The checkin staff was well presented / looked good / spoke English well, but made little extra effort, despite the over average rate, high IHG status, I guess the place was full. There is a cool bar with good service and great views on one of the top floors. Maybe the location of this place is something great, and I know their events are really well managed, but for just staying there I do not understand what I just paid for relative to other 5 star properties in Japan.

Excellent Customer service we got, Ambience of hotel was so amazing, facilities provided was awesome. food was so yummy , we gathered wonderful memories from there. I will recommend to my friends also.

That hotel is near roppongi and near train station. Rooms are small for family but they offer rooms with two double bed. Service is up to intercontinental standard but staffs are not as friendly as other branches. We had to stuck at check in counter for 30mins due to the staff can't really communicate well in English.

I stayed there for 2 nights. the room is so simple and a bit old. the door knob is old style, it's always clean but a bit dissapointed.HP says it takes "only 2min" from Tameike Sanno station by walk, but it is not true. actually from the hotel to station exsit is really close like 1 min, but from the exit to the gate is far. it talks 8-13 min depends on the line.

We made this our base in Tokyo during the Sakura in April. The hotel though a chain had a friendly staff. The rooms are big compared to the other hotels we have stayed at in Tokyo. There are lots of dining places nearby. There is a breakfast cafe just outside the main door and convenience stores are a few steps away. Easily accessible through the metro. I will not hesitate to stay here again in the future.

We arrived very late (around midnight). Receptionist initially tried to give us a smoking room (on a smoking floor) as no other rooms left. We said we really didn’t want this. Reluctantly agreed to go and see the room. The room and whole floor did smell of smoke. We returned to reception and explained no way we want it. Fortunately we stood our ground as magically a non-smoking room was suddenly available. So really felt they were initially trying to palm us off with an unsuitable room. Not a good start. Internet not free! Approximately £10 per day. So disappointing some hotels still trying to charge for Wi-Fi. Especially very expensive hotels. This hotel is relatively well priced compared to other high-end hotels in central Tokyo, so that is a plus. Rooms are ok, though really nothing stand-out about them. If I could find another 5* hotel similarly priced for next visit, would probably try somewhere else. Overall fine, but again, nothing about hotel that would really make you want to rush back.

I had a great four days here. Super helpful staff with great English. The fancy French restaurant is awesome. The regular restaurant on the first floor was quite good. Loved the bar at the top of the hotel. Great location. Near Rippongi. Definitely more of a business hotel, but super nice.

This hotel is conveniently located in the center of Tokyo: it's walking distance from Roppongi and many subway stations, convenience stores, and grocery stores. Standard rooms are not large, but clean and well equipped, and have comfy beds. Breakfast is very good, so are their room service. I've often stayed at this hotel and have recommended to my foreign friends as well.

Nice hotel, well-trained English speaking staff. Good view of the city and Tokyo Tower. Safe spot to stay in the heart of Tokyo. Expansive breakfast. Rooms were well cleaned, spacious and neat. Wifi included for IHG Rewards Club members. Toilet seats have seat heating :)

The ANA Intercontinental is a standard cookie cutter hotel - nothing more and nothing less. The hotel is well located and a 5 minute walk to the closest underground station. The lobby is huge, warm and welcoming. Apart from a slight slip up during check-in (despite the check-in time being 3pm we only got out room at 6.30pm) the service is outstanding.Rooms - initially we were given a room on the10th floor which was old world, classic, shabby and downright awful. Fortunately we were moved to a room on the 30th floor and what a difference! Modern and contemporary, nicely lit up, and very comfortable. I could not find any fault in this room whatsoever. The stand out points - the in room safe nicely tucked in the drawer, the espresso machine, bedside plug points for your phones, a wonderful view of the city and excellent shower.Though we did not try any of the restaurants in the hotel I understand they are suppose to be excellent. We had the breakfast which was a huge spread and everything I ate was very good. The bar on the 37th floor was super and a must visit.Overall, a good cookie cutter hotel - if that's your style then this is perfect.

Hotel is located in a very good location, about 30 minutes cab ride rom the airport. Just 3 minutes walk from the Ginza line metro station, it gives one an easy and convenient reach to the many popular areas like Ginza, Shibuya, Akasaka and other must-see sights. The room were relatively large with al the necessities provided. Very clean bathroom, room has no smell. The comfy bed and the black out curtain ensured quality sleep. The free wifi was fast. The Hotel restaurants offer good selection on their menu. Lunch buffet at the Cascade restaurant was excellent. The Club lounge at the 35th floor serves nice breakfast and evening canapes/drinks. Impressed by the quality and flavor of the food at both restaurants. On top of all these I really loved the service and attention given by the staff – attentive at the lounge, helpful at the concierge, prompt at the checkin/checkout, to say the least. Highly recommend for both leasure and business stays.

Very focused place. Felt like I could get a lot done here. Also it's adjoined to a mall with outdoor food places and restaurants. Great spot and close to the main areas that I love like shibuya. Drinks can be quiet pricey but overall it's worth it for a business mtg as most people know where the hotel is. In the evenings someone is playing piano in the main restaurant lobby area.

ANA INTERCONTINENTAL TOKYO is a luxurious hotel located in Akasaka area. It offers the comfort and luxury that is expected of the Intercontinental Hotels chain. Service, of course, is extremely satisfactory. Rooms are well designed and stocked with all the necessary amenities that provides for a comfortable stay. Prices are appropriate to this 4 star establishment.

We had an amazing high floor double room, quite and very comfortable!The service was excellent , with a very attentive staff and helpful transportation desk.We arrived as part of 100 people group and they were able to accommodate us perfectly.

We stayed here for 4 nights after a 5 nights stay at Osaka interContinental. I was disappointed after what we have experienced at Osaka. The reception staff: Although we reserved a double room the staff checked us in a twin room. They asked us to wait for couple of nights to get a room with double bed. It took my husband 15 minutes of arguing to finally get the room we paid for.The house keeping staff are superb. They made sure to get us a voltage converter.Concierge staff: Very special thanks to Ms. Hiho Obana. She was very very very helpful and helped us beyond whats expected.
user_name:
DrNouraA
Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

review_body: Despite bing a pretty large hotel this never felt crowded or busy during my entire stay. Everywhere looks well cared for and maintained and not surprising therefore that it all worked.My room which admittedly was an upgrade had plenty of room, a very comfortable king sized bed at the centre of an organised and pleasant space. As much a reflection on other hotels is that it was a pleasure to find the control panel at the bed clearly marked, and all the controls worked to operate lights around the entire room, AC and even the curtains. Just below a plug to use for those who like to charge their phone and use as their alarm clock although a simple traditional alarm clock was provided as well and this along with many other simple little touches raises the ANA above many other hotels.Staff are polite and courteous without being intrusive, rooms are well cared for and room service very efficient and consistent. Wireless was great, food excellent, location good, sleep quality excellent.My first choice of hotel in Tokyo.

Hotel was perfectly and conveniently located right in the center of Tokyo, walking distance from many important things such as train station, grocery store, Tokyo Tower and Imperial Palace. Hotel is approximately a 20 minute ride from Haneda Airport and an hour ride from Narita Airport. Staff is very helpful and pleasant. Hotel lobby very high end and classy. Elevators nice, and timely. Hallways well kept, rooms well kept. Nice Amenities and comfortable beds. Was able to get a fan for night time since hotel controls AC and rooms get warm overnight. Enjoyed my stay here very much and can't wait to return and stay in the center of Tokyo again.
user_name:
ExpertTravelCritic
New York City, New York

review_body: Great hotel, conveniently located in the heart of Tokyo, over 840 rooms. Standard rooms are not large, but well equipped, shower in the bath. Ample lifts. Perfect service, always taxis at the front door. Breakfast is overwhelmingly good. Very enjoyable stay.

This is a very good business style hotel, good facilities, everything works well and is very well situated for the tube and for central Tokyo. The rooms are large for Tokyo, everything is good quality and works well. The staff are keen, efficient and courteous. Good, reasonable value brasserie style ground floor restaurant. Did not try other restaurants, seemed very fancy with prices to match.

It is the most comfortable hotel in Japan that I have ever been to. I love the bed and the blanket that they are so soft. The bathroom is also big. The location is near the metro which is like 3-minute walk. The hotel also have the bus sending you directly to the airport and depart often.

Great hotel with customer focused staff! Rooms are reasonably sized with all the features! Breakfast is brilliant! Close to train station and airport bus goes to the front door! Recommend this for business and wifi is free and throughout the hotel!

This hotel is a very good for business travellers. I stayed there with a group of colleagues recently. Easy to get to from the airport via the limousine bus service. We took breakfast every morning which I found very good with a wide selection of food choices. I used the gym which was busy but was well equipped. My room was pretty small and I would have expected bigger for the price we paid.

The hotel was booked by the company which invited me to Tokyo, so I had no idea where it was and what surrounded it, but indeed, in three words: location, location, location. With a Metro entrance (Tameike-sanno, with Ginza and Namboku lines) right by the door step, and both 7-11 and Family Mart (24 hours, naturally!) next to this entrance, I truly was not want for anything. On a small street across the road is lined with small eateries - mind you, local fare, no English menu, no pictures, barely enough English, but very friendly, so all well. They know when I wanted another ‘birru.’ :) The room itself is cosy in a Japanese sense (not much room to swing cats), immaculately clean, toilet seats are warmed, laundry picked up and dropped back as ordered. Concierge staff readily lent me an extra power adaptor, reception informed me that if I join the free IHG hotel chain club, I get free internet and late check out. Most professional and helpful staff! Breakfast buffet selection was international, naturally, Japanese, Chinese, Continental and American - covers all ground and some in between. It is perhaps not the cheapest place in town, but when one travels on business, and just want things to work and get around quickly, strongly recommended.

ANA Intercontinental is very centrally located and is accessible by the subway and other public transport. There are some good restaurants a short walk away from the hotel. The in-house restaurants are good, however are on the expensive side. The rooms are well-maintained and the service staff is great. I spent 14 days at this lovely hotel and didn't regret my choice even once. The airport limousine is a convenient service, this bus takes you directly to the airport terminal. Tip: Try to book rooms on the higher floors. I stayed on the 32nd floor and the views to the road facing Roppongi hills was great. You could also ask for a room facing the Tokyo Tower.

I have stayed at the ANA Intercontinental Tokyo a few times now. It was on this last visit that it hit me. What a nice hotel and perfect location. Since I keep coming back that must say something about the hotel and staff. Definitely 5 star with 5 star service. Thank you everyone for making me feel so special while I am there visiting Tokyo. For this last visit I want to give a special thank you to Concierge. What would I have done without you :) You found a Dr. when I needed, You provided excellent restaurant recommendations for a first date and you translated everything for me when necessary. Great Service from the Concierge Staff. Thank you!! I would definitely recommend staying at the ANA Intercontinental Tokyo if you are going to Japan. The location, the friendly and respectful staff, the ambiance of the hotel, the quality of the room, and most importantly the higher standard of service is what separates the ANA Intercontinental from other Tokyo 5 star hotels. I look forward to seeing everyone and my new Australian friend when I return to Tokyo.

ANA hotels are generally great to stay in and the service is always out of the top drawer. The rooms were excellent and breakfast great. The Restaurants in the hotel were a bit expensive, but quality was fantastic. Good mixture of tourists and business travelers in the hotel gave it a relaxed but formal atmosphere.

We have just spent 5 days in this lovely hotel and I can honestly say we could not fault it - apart from charging £7 for a glass of milk when we arrived!. Our bedroom was clean, twin beds as requested and an interesting view of many roads outside. Couldn't hear a thing so excellent glazing and always something to look at.

This is a very nice business hotel with easy access to lots of Tokyo's attractions. Service is quite good but book well in advance as they are often full. My only grumble is that IHG, and Intercontinental specifically, is very hit and miss for loyalty offerings. Sapphire Ambassador, you might get a slight room upgrade but that's about it. No lounge.

A great very central location in Roppongi but the hotel does feel a bit tired. All amenities were fine, nice restaurants, friendly staff etc but the rooms feel like little has been done since the 70s. I'll admit a lot of Tokyo has this feel but I felt it stronger here.

Stayed at this hotel during a business trip. Probably could find a cheaper hotel but since we were there for only 2 nights, it was best to stay centrally with quick access to the Tube Station.The hotel ambience is excellent, service is top-notch.Only slight complaint i have is at check-in. We got to the hotel around midday , but were told we could only check-in at 3 pm! This is surprising, as an IHG Platinum member I was under the impression that we could check-in earlier than permitted. (At the Crowne Plaza in Amsterdam, i was afforded a check-in at 7 am!)Was hoping to shower and work before attending our meeting. Ended up working in the lobby and left our bags at the concierge.Apart from that, the breakfast was plentiful and tasty.

Might come as a surprise but Japan has plenty of smoking permitted venues - restaurants, hotels, cafes, etc. While most places in the West prohibit smoking indoors, it is normal in some places in Tokyo. But I would have never expected to be stuck on a smoking floor without the option to change rooms or floors. The stench was unbearable - all my clothes smelled for my next day's business meetings and I could not get rid of the headache. Appalling for a venue of this caliber.

Excellent hotel with brilliant staff. Nice and high-standard restaurants and bars. Mrs. Junko Kano and her staff at the executive club lounge are unbeatable. Great evening cocktails and superb breakfast buffet.

I stayed at this hotel for a business trip to Tokyo. This is a well maintained hotel but be careful what floor you are on since some floors do smell of stale smoke. The floor and room I had was nice and did not have that smell but someone traveling with me had to deal with that. The have a really good breakfast spread but it's pricy. There are a lot of choices for food in the hotel. The exercise room and enough equipment to get a solid workout done which is not always the case at hotels. The location is ok but about a 10 minute cab ride to the Tokyo station.

Nice lobby, good location but rooms don't live up to the Intercontinental brand/standard. We have been to Intercons and have come to expect a high level of quality from them. However, this one is just average as a regular hotel. Service is good. Room is okay size for Japan but decor is dated and older furniture/color patterns. Good access to area restaurants and businesses.

i love staying at the Intercon . You can always expect above service, facilities and rooms. We were pleasantly surprised with the size of room , which adequately had room for a roll away . The king size bed was very ample , slightly hard but still comfy. My only complaint is the pillows , super soft . Breakfast buffet was nice , nothing spectacular. Concierge was helpful booking dinner reservations and explaining transportation options with directions . Intercontinental hotels will always be on top 3 choices of accommodations .

ANA was recommended as I had business meetings nearby. It is terrible!I first checked into a 'classic' room on the 8th floor. The smell of stale smoke make me feel like puking and I clarified that I would prefer a non-smoking room.I was moved to a room on another floor and although not as strong, the smell of stale smoke was in that room too. I clarified and was emphatically told that this second room was non-smoking.The Housekeeping staff brought an airpurifier which I appreciated, but after I returned to the room from a three hour meeting, the smell persisted. Imagine feeling like you need to throw up all the time.What I don't appreciate is being lied to.Finally, I asked again and for the third time, was moved to a floor where there were non-smoking room signs. I could settle for the night.I realised that the lowest category of rooms sold are in a bad condition. The non-smoking rooms are in a higher category of rooms.But I had stayed at another hotel in a different district a few days before and paid half the price, got a bigger room with a better view.Is there a better alternative if one has to attend a business meeting there again? I'm sure there is..

Centrally located, decent (though not great) sized rooms but then its Japan, decent service (though we had a few glitches particularly at breakfast), subway right below. In a nutshell, decent business hotel, but I wouldn't stay there for a holiday.

I can't fault the hotel for anything in particular , except for just a few very small things:We arrived early in morning (6am) but room would be ready till 2pm. We had to ask if maybe we could use a shower after long flight perhaps at gym, the hotel obliged but it a shame such a late check in .(I would note that majority of Japan places have 2pm or later check in, and it not 12 or 10 am I have encountered at some other places ) They offer at additional cost breakfast which is quite a nice spread . It has jap and western options . Can't fault it but it is pricey - but that is what you pay for .We sampled the champagne place and the sushi place- amazing (photos included) On lover levels. There is also a whiskey bar - amazing array . And also a cocktail bar at the top of building - nice views .You can easily stay in and try different foods for at least 4 nights .The room is slightly small , but clean - so overall very happy. Concierge were helpful and even sent out bags ahead of us to the next destination (check out Yamato) ... Which is handy if you don't want to drag big bags with you through stations ... If you are planning on using bullet train. Handy service (external) but you need to have jap person fill out paperwork for you .Note:The train station although entrance is near, the corridor to the ginza line is at least 15 min strong walk. If you are after other lines they are prob 20. That is not hotels fault but something to note .

This was my first visit to the ANA hotel in Tokyo. It’s a mega-hotel, with more than 30 floors and built with a convention center in the lower levels. It’s a very upscale hotel. The lobby area is actually two floors, with an elevated bar/lounge that often has live music (piano and sax) player. There’s a large ground floor lounge, adjacent to the main restaurant on the ground floor. Breakfast buffet is about $30, and offers a very wide range of foods, both European, American, and Asian. It’s all very good with a lot of choices. Also on the upper level is a wide range of upper-end stores that are probably beyond the budgets of most people. Just outside the hotel are restaurants and shops that are part of the Ark Hills development. These are much more affordable than the restaurants in the hotel. There are a couple of great stores connected including two coffee shops, a Lawson market, and a small grocery store. There’s even a couple of banks connected. Getting to the Ginza line takes a bit of walk, probably at least 10 mins underground to the get the Metro. A bit long for my tastes. The workout area is good, with two elliptical, six treadmills, and a set of dumbbells. The cardio machines face outside, so it’s a pretty good view. Six weight machines round out the facility. The hotel has an outdoor pool, more of a lounging pool than for swimming laps. In general the gym is good. Not the best in Tokyo, but pretty good. The top floor has a lounge with a great view and great vibe. The concierge team was very helpful, and recommended some nice restaurants that were new. The lobby has a cool money exchange machine. You simply put in a wide assortment of paper money, and the machine spits back money in Japanese Yen. Didn’t have a chance to check the exchange rate, but the convenience of the machine is pretty cool. The room amenities are good. The rooms have more drawer space than most hotels. Rooms have a bathrobe, morning paper, pressing station, teapot, shoe horn, toilet kit, and lots of good shampoos. The shower system is good but wasnt very hot. All in all, a good upper end hotel. Depending on the rate available, it could be a very good. The walk for metro access is a little long, but some travelers don’t use the Metro.

Intercontinental Hotels are not consistent in terms of the accommodations and upkeep of the Hotel. Recently I was in Manilla at the Intercontinental it almost caused me to cancel my stay at the ANA Intercontinental In Tokyo. I am glad I did not, what a nice well run location this is. The rooms are nice size, the lobby is large and comfortable, the breakfast area is large and has well prepared and organized offerings. There is a nice lounge and bar on the top floors with great views. Shopping is near by in Roppongi Hills at the mall, they have unique stores and offerings. I strongly recommend this location and look forward to staying here when I return.

I stayed three nights and overall the experience was positive. However, this is not a hotel that differentiates itself in terms of luxury or "pluses".The room was rather small, no bottled water, in-room dining not tasty at all, no business lounge to work in (the business center is a place with small cabins where you can print documents), breakfast could be improved (especially in terms of the quality of bread/pastries), TV channel offer is quite limited (in terms of European channels). However, service was attentive.

A nice hotel. Good service and staff. The breakfast buffet had a decent assortment. The rooms are small, but that's standard in a city like Tokyo. The rooms was well stocked with all the necessities. Housekeeping did a nice job. Room service was efficient. Limo bus to airport was easy. Not far from the shopping of Shibuya. Overall a solid hotel.

The hotel lobby and common areas are large and spacious but my room was not. I measured my room and it was 8" by 10" with one corner cutoff not including the bathroom, which was 5" by 5". This is crazy small even by Japan standards. The room had standard amenities but be aware there was a sign stating that during shoulder season they they would either have heat or air conditioning but not both. Which means in spring/fall you boil if the weather is on the warm side. If you are a westerner I suggest you pick a different hotel for your business trip.

It was my first trip to Tokyo and I chose the right hotel to stay. Even though I arrived Narita Airport at 6:30 am and checked in just after 9 am, the got me a room and I was fortunate to get some good rest.What is great is that you can get a Limousine Bus ( cheapest way to travel ) from Narita Airport that stops at the lobby of this hotel, door to door service.I'm not too sure but I think the hotel has been around for a while as some part looked dated but well maintained. The service in this hotel is excellent, from the doorman to everywhere to go in the hotel. I must single out the Club Lounge Manger, Ms. Junko ( hope I got her name correct ) and her team at the Club Lounge. I'm always made so welcomed each time I'm there and Ms. Junko is forever so super helpful and I really think she live in the Club Lounge as I see her in the early hours of the morning and late at night, so hard working and dedicated. The staff at the Club Lounge made me so welcomed, like they have known me for years. It made my stay so comfortable even though it was my trip to Tokyo.You can see Mount Fuji from the Club Lounge. Unfortunately it is not winter yet, so there is no snow cap on it but still majestic.I had a corner room with a great view of the city and like any InterContinental hotels, the rooms are super luxurious with all kinds of amenities such as your own coffee machine. The size of the room is large compared to your average hotel rooms in Japan. The greatest part of the room must be the walk in shower. The shower has an in built body spray and together with the overhead water jet, I don't want my shower to end each time. With the high pressure water together with their shower system, it is like having a water massage, what a feeling.There is a subway station within 2 minutes walk from the hotel and you can get everywhere easily and Roppongi Hills is just about 15 minute walk. The breakfast and evening cocktails at the club lounge is fantastic compared to many club lounges in the world.I have stayed in so many hotels and not many I will go back again because it is my nature to try different hotels in each city so that I get to experienced as many as possible but the next time I am in Tokyo again, I will stay here. The staff made me so welcomed, it feels like family.

Based on my experience I would highly recommend people not stay in this hotel. This feels like an old and dated hotel throughout. I was initially put in a room that reeked of smoke so badly that it was almost difficult to breathe. I asked for a new room and was given a room with a bathroom that hadn't been updated since the 1980s and also had mold in the bathroom. These rooms were not consistent with expectations for the Intercontinental brand. I haven't stayed there but I would expect more at the Holiday Inn. I finally offered to pay more to be put in a suitable room and even after paying for this "upgrade" it's easily the worst room I've ever stayed in while in Tokyo. There's still mold in the "upgraded" bathroom. I implore anyone considering this hotel, please look elsewhere based on my experience. On the plus side the location isn't bad. On the negative side, well there's just too much to list. Look elsewhere based on my experience.

I stayed in this hotel for 8 days while visiting Tokyo for the first time. The rooms are large by Tokyo standards, and very comfortable. The hotel staff are all very friendly and accommodating and the lobby was always bustling yet quiet. While it was a bit of a walk to Roppongi Hills, its restaurants that we ate in were great.

The hotel is a bit of a walk to Rappongi, but manageable. The stand-out feature of the hotel is the club lounge, the food choices are great. Room service good, staff attentive location close to Metro.

I LOVE the ANA hotel - it is so beyond my reach in my personal travels, but when I am working, it is home from home in Tokyo. Best features - whisper-quiet night air con, fabulously comfortable beds, the friendliest, most helpful staff on the planet.

As a Japanese national living in North America, I recommend this hotel to anyone. Service is wonderful at the time of check-in. If you stay at the club level rooms, you will have a access to the lounge where you will have a wonderful services including drinks and food with a view! Easy access to JR Shinbashi by a bus, and reasonable rate by taxi to go to any major places in Tokyo!

[CHOOSE THE CAPITOL HOTEL, 10% MORE BUT TOTALLY WORTH IT!]Usually, I do not be this cynical. But feel like need to say something. My partner and I stayed in the Capitol Hotel (EXCELLENT HOTEL TO STAY, COMPARE WITH THIS INTERCON), but due to its availability, we had to move to this Intercon on the very last day in Tokyo. Thinking of leaving the hotel very early the next day, I decided to use my points to redeem one night. Sales girl on the phone, said even if the website only provided twin beds, certainly we could manage to ask the reception to change to a queen/king size bed. But when we check in, the answer was no. Ok, not a problem for us. But then we said we would rather check in late, but prefer to have a smoking room. The girl at the reception typed for a while and replied no again, no room available… (exactly like CAROL in Little Britain “No… Computer says on…”). It was like 9am in the morning, just say it you want to keep the rooms for those who pay, and do not care a member who redeems his points (after keeping choosing IHG hotels!!!) Sorry, maybe it is true that that day the hotel was fully booked, but the fact she did not even try to make efforts really make me uncomfortable with the way how you treat your members. The answer was just a No with few words, it was really like you do not pay, you only get what we offer. That's all...BTW, a bit more info. before your decision.For those who say the hotel is nice, the facilities are at least 30 years old. For those who say the hotel has good shops, restaurants, please you are in Tokyo, anything is available. You want to eat in hotel restaurants???For those who say the hotel has a good location, a subway entrance is really close, BUT YOU HAVE TO WALK UNDERGROUND LIKE 500M-1KM to get onto one platform.

This hotel is fair. Being a regular guest of Intercontinental hotels and also a big fan, this one was a disappointment. There is nothing much around the hotel in this area, unless you walk or take a cab to Roppongi. This property also did not stand up to the standard 5-star service as there was no turn-down in the night throughout my 5 nights of stay and also I was only given one body towel per day (note that in every other Intercontinentals you get spare towels in the morning and in the night when they exchanged them during turn down service). But not here. 1 towel per day, no turn-down service. It was strange as I also stayed at the Intercontinental in Yokohama and the Strings in Shinagawa Tokyo and they both did have plenty of towels changed twice a day.

The overall service is good and looks like the hotel was recently renovated or just kept well. The lobby is a bit dark and not appealing to me, but still it is clean and nice. Rooms were good size and looked renovated. Location is ok if you want to be in Roppongi. My only issue is with the breakfast buffet which tends to be fair and more Japanese for my taste. I was also upset when i asked for eggs from the menu and they asked me to pay an extra 1,200 yen ( 10 usd ) for toast, I have never heard of such a thing, eggs always come with toast, Don't be cheap and rip off your customers, and a cafe latte for 1,200 yen ( 10 usd ) are you crazy ! BIG rip off ! And i love the intercon brand and i am an Ambassador Platinum member at IHG. Restaurant manager i would change things here, I would not come back to this hotel because of this, sorry. Overall if you don't eat breakfast in the hotel i would say this hotel is ok and not bad for the price. I still prefer The Strings Intercon at Shinagawa Station.Also the WIFI is not good in this hotel, actually it's super slow and usually doesn't work well, other guests were complaining too. Another reason i would not stay here, this is serious intercon, get it fixed.

This hotel has a good location and a fantastic staff...second time we stay for a longer duration and had the club privilige room...the club is the best I ever have used and the main reason we came back again, and we just have stayed in five different hotels in this segment in the last two months in different major asian cities, and no one can be compared to the service and quality level and varity that the club in ANA provides.But the rooms are a bit dated now and needs a refurbish soon, and the gym needs a bit more equipment = free weights.Also 2 water bottels in the room pr day would be a nice touch and usefull also in the gym.I know tap water is fine to drink, but still two complimentary bottels a day is a small gesture to provide when you pay this amount of money pr night.As a member of the IHG program I waited in line to chech in at the members check in counter, but when a normal frontdesk check staff became free before I was asked to use her and she was a bit to cold in her attitude and not so welcoming, even to a member, but she maybe had a rough day ?, so if you are a member keep your place in the line and use the members check in....but the rest of the staff in this hotel in top notch..Othervise this is the best place to be in Tokyo.Recomended.

The hotel is perfectly situated in the city, close to the subway. Service is very good. They have a nice top bar with a nice view city view in the evening.Only drawback is that we got a room with a bath tub, i don't know if they have any rooms with a shower.

I have travelled to Tokyo several times over the past 10+ years but cant forget my first visit in Jan 2004 when I had an opportunity to stay at ANA Inter Continental from 29 Jan to 7th Feb 2004. Reached late in the evening, NARITA Coach dropped me right at the doors of Hotel and it was a warm welcome. Its one of the most expensive Hotels in Tokyo and very well maintained. Its massive and there are several Restaurants and Bars that one can really spoil himself / herself. Rooms were very spacious and they also provided internet connectivity. I really had a very comfortable stay of 10 days and I could focus on my work completely. There was no disturbance of any kind at all despite the fact that its centrally located in Minato district and its a happening place.

spent three nightsthe good- location is fine. multiple metro line, and business restaurants around- efficient staff- the view from the room. little one didn't want to leave- bathroom is nice- comfy bed- good size bed room- super fast internet- quiet roomthe not so good- rollaway = $$$ (at the end - we've got upgraded - so free)- have to pay to use the pool- missing pod coffee machine- didn't have time to taste all the cakes from the shop- had to leave

Great location in a relatively quiet area of Tokyo near to Roppongi. Metro train stop right downstairs. We received an upgrade as my wife is an IHG Platinum member. Room size was great for Tokyo, bed comfortable & pillow choice excellent. Wifi great as was choice of TV channels. Had breakfast & afteroon drinks in club lounge, which was excellent. Service in Club lounge was top-notch & very helpful, Junko was a delight as were all the staff.

We visited this hotel for an overnight stay prior to joining a cruise ship in Yokohama, and this hotel was selected as part of our cruise package.We arrived mid-morning after a long flight from the UK. The staff at reception were extremely polite and efficient, as is the Japanese way. We were told that they did not have any rooms available of the standard that had been booked for us, as they weren't serviced yet. As we were IHG Loyalty club members, we were immediately given an upgrade to an Executive Room.The room was on the 24th floor with a great view towards Tokyo Tower. It was a superb room with every amenity a visitor could need, with toiletries second to none.The room was spotless, the bed exceptionally comfortable and spacious.We had breakfast in the hotel as we had a limited time before being collected for our cruise.If you couldn't find something to your taste on the breakfast buffet, then you have strange tastes! There was an extensive selection accommodating every taste, including European continental, full English, curry, noodles, salad,sushi and much more - I was in heaven! During our brief stay, we discovered that we had left items on the plane. I asked the Concierge if they could help us contacting British Airways to enquire about our items. The staff went above and beyond to help us, in their usual polite and efficient way, contacting us by email several days later (sadly, British Airways refused to discuss the matter with a third party, and as we were on a cruise for ten days, we were unable to phone ourselves) The hotel staff expressed their disappointment at not being able to resolve the issue for us.I would return to this hotel if I visited Tokyo. It is superb.

We spent two nights here, and really enjoyed our stay. The room was fine, with a great view over Tokyo tower. The position of the hotel is also really good, few minutes from a big metro station that will connect you directly to four metro lines. The lobby looks a bit old, but it is the only minus side. The best part was the access to the Club Lounge, were both an excellent dinner, breakfast and snacks are served during the day. Probably the best I have ever seen in a hotel, even with ready made cocktails. As a royal ambassador and spire member, they promised me an upgrade to a junior suite, but did not consider that also the previous guest was a royal ambassador, so his check in was very late. In the end we preferred to skin on the upgrade to do not change room several times, but they could have planned this better. I also believe that, due to my status, they should offer the lounge automatically, instead we got it just as a compensation of the lack of the upgrade. This attitude (common to many IHG hotels), really does not help to keep customers loyal.

Trustworthy brand lived up to, in luxury, quality and service. Easy access from airport via limo-bus to the front door. Good choice of eateries in the hotel. Excellent service throughout. I needed some business cards made quickly and concierge walked me to the nearest place and helped me place my order. Great.

Location good but rooms are very out of date. Bathroom can barely fit one person and looks like it hasn't been updated since the 80's. Plus the room smelled like mildew. We were celebrating our anniversary on the trip and was told they might be able to upgrade us as a gift but when we got here they said we needed to pay the difference...instead they sent a tiny box of 5 crackers for our anniversary, thanks.

Excellent 5 star Intercontinental standard. Stylish, Western interiors with Japanese touches. Comfortable rooms with good views and large beds. Powerful shower. Impeccable service, especially concierge. Location is good and taxi rank quick. Only gripe is slow checkout queue.

Had three nights here prior to boarding a cruise in Yokohama. Handy for several Metro stations and the nightlife of Roppongi. Could not fault our room on the 28th floor, had all of the expected facilities for it's price and the bed was as good as anywhere else we have stayed in Japan at this price level.Restaurants were the usual International fayre so we ate elsewhere but within walking distance.If only staying for a few days, we would look at this first next time.

We ran a large event at this hotel during high season and I have to commend them on their attention to detail, lovely food selection and location. The event was for 100 people and everything was handled very well .... that being said, I was frustrated by the constant additional charges for any small change. With everything being relatively expensive, this made the organizers seem fairly inflexible.The décor is exceptionally clean and the rooms are nice. With this, you can still tell that the bathrooms and rooms haven't been updated in some time. This is a vibrant hotel during the week because of its location. Good place to stay for business.

This hotel has a very good service, the rooms are extremely clean -even if a bit old-fashioned. However the hotel is so large that you do not get that "homey" feeling. It's a pity that you need to pay extra to access the pool and that only the men's changing room have a sauna...Easy access to subway lines - but some of them are more than a kilometer away walk in the underground path.Better subscribe to the loyalty program as you can then get free wifi.

We stayed a week while in Tokyo on business and there are many good things and several difficult things as well.The rooms are large but the bathrooms tiny and uncomfortable. The TV only gets a few english channels which surprised us for a western hotel. The internet is good but must be re authenticated daily. The pool is cold and expensive, no one uses it and I am sorry we paid for it.The lounge is way overpriced. I have always wanted lounges when in Asia, this one only offers evening food and drinks for two hours. The food is good for breakfast and cocktail hour but it isn't worth over $100 USD for breakfast and a drink.The concierge is worthless, they are slow, confused and never once did we get helpful information. The location is central to to subway stops but a cab ride from most restaurants.The restaurants in the hotel are needlessly over priced. We had Chinese for lunch for 2 and the bill was well over $200 USD, the food was average compared to other restaurants in Tokyo.

We stayed at this hotel because it was one our travel agent chose for us when we wanted to add Tokyo to the end of our China Tour. It is a very nice hotel. It is not really close to markets or tourist attractions. We took a Greyline Tour one day but just walked around the hotel area the 2nd day since it was rainy and I was not feeling the best. The area around the hotel had tons of restaurants but not many shops. The American Embassy is right around the corner. There were 7-11's and small convenience store down the block. We had free wifi and late checkout with our IHG club membership. Breakfast was included in our package. It was a huge buffet that had both Western and Japanese food. We got as far as the reception desk for the pool when we saw it cost money to use it. We didn't check it out any further so maybe that was just for non-guests????? But I would not pay to use a pool at a hotel.The concierge was helpful when we had a problem with our shuttle service.I would recommend this hotel.

With 2 subway stations nearby it is a convenient location even if it's not at the central area. Many convenience stores and restaurants around the corner. Concierge is very helpful and competent - Had our dinner reservation done before we arrived. The rates are very good too and we were given upgrade on our second stay which was really lovely.

Enjoyed my stay at the hotel...here's what I liked about this hotel: + Walking distance to 2 metros on Namboku line. Take Tameiko-sanno metro if you want to hop on the Ginza line.Airport limousine bus stop/pick up every hour, 3100 ¥ one way. Next to 24 hrs supermarket and Ark Hills for dining options. You can find Starbucks here for your morning coffee fix.Free wifi and wired connectionFree international newspaper for IHG club membersWill accomodate late checkout to 2 pm for IHG club membersClose to Roppongi if you want to have late night snacks or drinks!Hotel seems a bit dated but service was impeccable and with all the above plus points highlighted, I can't recommend enough

Stayed in the Ana 4 times this year. What strikes you when you enter the lobby is that this is a plush hotel. It is but for me when you look closer some cracks appear. The smoking floors are not nice and everything costs a fortune. 32 euro for breakfast and no decent coffee is a bit of a joke. You'll notice that after paying 400 for a night you're expected to pay extra for the WiFi and pay 40 euro to visit the pool....if you want to be close to Rippongi and you have the cash then go for it but you won't get the 5 star feel for your 5 star money.
user_name:
Adrian J
Burren National Park, Ireland

review_body: We stayed here during a conference earlier this year because our favorite Tokyo hotel was full. We have visited Tokyo many times (and lived here for 10 years) but never stayed here so this was the first time. The location is pretty convenient and the staff were mostly very friendly. The hotel in general are pretty 1970s but the rooms have been refreshed recently so are pretty good. We looked at the bar on the top floor but didn't stay...there were no other venues in the hotel that tempted us, which is good because there are so many great spots in Tokyo that we wanted to try...

Meeting requirements were very well covered which demonstrated the hotel's experience and its staff. Staying a few days meant that you could get tired of the food so thankfully there were options with the cafe and Mixx, the latter providing a nice Italian spread with pasta/risotto servings. I also liked that there was a deli at the lobby level where you could have quality coffee and pastry to go for a change from the breakfast buffet. There is a 24-hour family mart (and 7-11) that's a few minutes walk from the hotel for snacks, quick bites and anything you may have missed packing. The hotel is also close to Roppongi where you can uncover several eateries.

My wife and I recently visited Tokyo for the first time and not knowing much about it, here is what we can say about this hotel and Japan. ANA Intercontinental is a beautiful hotel, elegant, upscale, modern and quiet. Is not a typical tourist hotel, is more of a traveling business executives place. Is very large and with all the typical amenities, spa, gym, pool, several upscale restaurants and shops, business center, etc. Pool is out doors with a beautiful setting, nothing spectacular but nice. Rooms are (to my surprise) very spacious and comfortable, nothing spectacular or luxurious but simple, sufficient, clean and always superb service. Is a top 4 star hotel and it can be pricey but you can shop for good fares though the usual suspects sites (Expedia, travelocity, etc.) and get great deals. Our room is typically $225 US and we got it for $145 US. The service is amazing but this is no surprise as all Japanese people are super friendly, respectful and honest. Their #1 priority is to give great service no matter what store, restaurant, place you are. There is a 7Eleven and a small supermarket about a block away. There are more restaurants about half a block from the hotel and the Roppongi district is only a 15 minute walk with lots of shops and a big night life trend.Overall the ANA Intercontinental should not disappoint you no matter how picky you are. Great hotel! Tokyo is a huge city and very similar to the size and feel of New York. Tourist attractions are spread out through the city so there really is not "best zone" to find a hotel. No matter what part of the city you stay, you will have to take cab/ subway, to get to other attractions. Tokyo is a very large city and you can take cabs (expensive due to the large distances) or take the subway. BELIEVE ME, the subway is the EASIEST way to get around and soooooo simple to understand. The Tameike-sanno station of the Ginza line is literally at the corner of the hotel. All stations are named in japanese and have the english translation below that. All the machines have English display information. If you have any questions about subway use, please email me.
user_name:
Artied1976
New York City, New York

review_body: Nice hotel, good location, good service!I was there for business and have experienced the hotel as a very good alternative: close to my office, friendly people, price in line with Tokyo standard (EUR 260/nght).

We stayed at this hotel for 8 nights on our most recent trip to Tokyo. It's a beautiful hotel, the lobby is very impressive and the decor is modern and well done. Check-in was easy, the rooms were fairly quiet, and the elevators were VERY fast! We never waited more than a minute or so.Positives:It is difficult to find a hotel that will accommodate 3 adults in one room, but the InterContinental was great about bringing in an additional rollaway and rearranging the furniture for it to fit. Rooms are large by Tokyo standards. The bathroom was awesome, with a great soaking tub and an adjustable height shower head. This hotel is right next to a Metro station that is a hub for many of the lines, so traveling was simple. If you want to be able to get places quickly, this is a great place to stay.Negatives: The beds were extremely firm/hard, which I guess is standard for Tokyo, but it made sleeping difficult at times for us. There really isn't an inexpensive restaurant/food option in the hotel, especially for breakfast (and no "gift shop" selling food items). The restaurant in the lobby only does buffet, which is way too much food. Luckily, there was a Starbucks and a market in the complex next door.

From check in to check out I was constantly impressed with the ANA Intercontinental Tokyo. Service was excellent throughout, especially the reception team. The breakfast buffet offered an extremely wide choice, enough to please the pickiest eaters. Rooms were very comfortable and spacious with a really good bed and good shower. I also had a view looking towards Tokyo Tower which was great. All in all a very enjoyable stay. I would be more than happy to use this hotel for any future visits to Tokyo. Highly recommended!

Stayed here for a week and found the location great. It is quiet by Tokyo standards, but that was really nice and it was still convenient for getting around. It is a high standard and the service is very good. The rooms are nice, but the bathrooms are strangely very very small, but they have the best - cure all jetlag - water pressure in the shower.

The hotel wasn't the cheapest, but it was of the highest standard in service and comfort. The breakfast was very good, and I was pleased with the airport bus service. The hotel was conveniently located, walking distance to a number of stations. There was also a well stocked convenience store a stone's throw away, and a number of cafes and restaurants in the same complex. Also walking distance to Roppongi Hills and the Roppongi crossing areas.

Very nice hotel. Wonderful staff. Great breakfast buffet and exercise room. Very nice hotel rooms. Very central to many interest points in the city. Nearby 7-11 store and small food mart. Restaurants in walking distance.
user_name:
MFTFamily
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: spacious (25sq) room with wall lenght window; bathroom with glass wall onloking into the room, could do with some fittings improvement, but otherwise good.Very nice sky bar at 42nd floor with magnificent view of Tokyo.

Very close to tube stations, great service, clean and comfortable. Good breakfast with many options (continental and Japanese). Many dining/drink options around the hotel. Would be happy to stay here again.

I loved this hotel. It was comfortable, had all the amenities one would expect for a hotel of this category and was very clean.Location is good in the centre of Tokyo and with one metro station at its door step and another one a short 3 minute away, one is not far removed from any of the city's many attractions.The gym is a dream, both large and almost fully equipped (a pull up bar would have been nice).Hotel staff are friendly, polite and helpful.We did not use any of the restaurants or bars but there seemed to be enough variety for everyone, including a lounge, a bakery and coffee shop.Ask for a room in a high floor (or pay for one). Well worth it.I would definitely recommend this hotel as it ticked all boxes (comfort, cleanliness, facilities, services, food & beverage outlets and friendliness/efficiency).

Best part of the ANA is that it is right at two Tokyo metro stations serving two lines. It's also a stop and pickup point for the airport bus service making the whole travel from Narita/Haneda to the city and back very easy.The hotel is walkable to Roppongi quite easily (actually even to Ginza if you have time and energy to spare). The rooms themselves are good though nothing uber luxurious... just well appointed, clean and comfortable. There are a few dining/drinks options in-house but easy enough to just seek options around the hotel.

We stayed 9 nights in the ANA Intercontinental and had a great stay. Whilst a little tired in places and the bathrooms are a bit dated we had asked for and got a quiet room (light sleepers). The staff were friendly and helpful and I'm not sure if it's because we're IHG members or not but my husband had his birthday while we were there and we had put his birthday cards up for the day (transported in the bottom of my suitcase) and the hotel left us some treats to mark the occasion and also some fruit half way through our stay. Location is hard to beat with lots of sights nearby and good areas to explore within walking distance (for us anyway as we tend to walk everywhere). For those who want to use the underground there are a couple of stations near the hotel.Despite the dated bathrooms etc I'd still highly recommend and would be happy to stay there again. One point to note - if you want to use the pool the charge is quite steep at ¥4000 per person per day for guests - more for non guests (seems to be common practice in Tokyo). We had too much to see and do to warrant use....luckily! Would still revisit nevertheless.

My favorite hôtel in Tokyo for 20 years now Always up to date ! Sometimes it's quite long to checkin or checkout The breakfast choice is huge but the staff tells you straightaway at what time you have to leave ...Some sideboard to the bed need to be replaced (scratched) Free wifi, fitness room, external pool in summer time, bar with nice view at the 36th floor, different restaurants and shops available It's annoying to change lift when you like to to the fitness or poolAsk for a room with Tokyo tower view Close to Roppongi Main Street by foot

I spend 10 days in this great Hotel and I really wish to be back very soon!Great Breackfast and extraordinary view and restaurant on the top floor!During my stay i try also the sauna and fitness center!All was perfect!!!Very near Ropongi is an ideal place to have quality and high standard place to live, enjoy the city and get the real international test of Tokyo!

Stayed at the hotel for 5 nights for a work trip in late June, not a great month to visit Japan, rained almost every day but the hotel was great, breakfast was very good, so much variety you can eat just about all breakfast options, rooms were very clean and comfortable, English channels were a bonus. Only disappointment was the charge to use the pool, at 4000 yen for a swim I thought was way over the top, no wonder it was empty all the time. But hotel is in a great location and central to all things with easy access to the subway.

The staff welcomed me as i stepped off the bus from the airport and I immediately felt liked a welcomed guest. The rooms were well appointed,comfortable and quiet. The concierge lounge was magnificent. All the staff was very helpful and friendly. I hope to return to Japan again.

We had an outstanding time at ANA Intercontinental Tokyo. The hotel is very well located with metro station, restaurants and mini marts within walking distance. The room was spacious and very comfortable for the four of us, two adults and two kids (9 and 4). Brilliant and very courteous staff. The concierge is so well informed that we really benefitted from their suggestions and had a great time exploring Tokyo. We spent a total eight nights and immensely enjoyed every minute. Definitely worth for families with kids as they really give you personal attention to your requests. Thanks ANA Intercontinental Tokyo for a great time.

I spent two nights at this property in April. As it is in the downtown business area, don't expect a vibrant nightlife in the neighborhood. There are a number of restaurants walking distance from the hotel. If you are a vegetarian, there is an Indian restaurant very nearby where vegetarian options are available. The staff are courteous and helpful. The breakfast spread is generous and good. Rooms are small but clean. Great place to stay if you are only on business.

This hotel is located in the heart of Tokyo - 5 minute walk to Roppongi, across the street from Akasaka and a half mile from the Imperial Palace. The service at the hotel is outstanding, the rooms are big, clean and have all the amenities that you'll need. There is no shortage of restaurants in the hotel, next to the hotel and in the area. There are so many places to eat, shop and explore in the area and the subway station is right next to the hotel. There is also an outdoor pool, exercise room and indoor sauna area. This is a great place to stay for business or pleasure and the staff is very friendly and helpful especially when it comes to directions and things to do.

Luxury international hotel, not outstanding nor beautiful itself. Better options available in the same hotel category. Location also not the best. But maybe we didn't choose properly as we were doing a family trip.

Stayed here for 3 nights last week on a business trip. Conveniently located good quality hotel with clean reasonably sized bedrooms.Good stuff- fast east checkin and checkout- wireless reliable and ok speed- bed comfortable- relaxed uncrowded continental buffet breakfasts in the Club Room on 35th floor. Fresh eggs!- Mixx bar on 36th floor has a good vibe ( DJ playing English dance background music) in the evenings with great views across the cityThings to improve- Service at the Mixx bar always slow. Only one bar tender means that as soon as a guest orders a cocktail everybody else has to wait longer than is reasonable...- temperature in Mixx bar too cold both evenings I visited for a night capI would visit this hotel again. I liked it overall.

A metro station within the block + an easy 10-minute taxi to Ginza and Roppongi, makes this place an ideal accommodation. Service is impeccable --- very helpful and courteous staff and turndown service is top-notch. Food is another strong suit. Breakfast buffet is varied slightly everyday which is a good thing if you're staying for more than two days. You know how it is in most other hotels. This is one property that will make you appreciate your IHG Reward/Ambassador membership. The room upgrade, welcome gift, fruit platter and fruit plate --- nice little touches that contribute to a nice stay.
user_name:
Xavier Y
Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand

review_body: Myself, wife and 18 year old daughter stayed at the ANA for 11 days in July this year. Our check in was smooth (I was welcomed as an IHG member instantly) at around 830 am and we were given an early check in but on the smoking floor. The room we were told was non smoking but there was an ashtray in the room and the smell wasn't pleasant. The room was only set for 2 people and had tiny beds and when I requested a change in room, the Assistant Guest Relation Manager (Russell) took charge and had a new room made available for us on the 20th floor (with a great view of the city), allowing us to use the smoking room to freshen and rest up. We had a Classic room similar to http://www.anaintercontinental-tokyo.jp/e/room/classic.html and this was big enough for 3 adults.All of the front desk staff staff were amazing and looked after us really well. Concierge and baggage service was first class. Our only disappointment was when eating in the hotel Cascade Cafe Restaurant. Myself and daughter had the buffet which although excellent we felt was very overpriced (as is the wine), but the main problem was the poor service we received. We had to request our ordered drinks on several occasions and used plates were not cleared away, so we were eating dessert with our main course plates still on the table. We had to ask to have them removed. We received zero attention from the waiting staff and had to chase them down when we needed anything. Very disappointing considering the hotel is an Intercontinental and when you are spending a lot of money in a restaurant you expect better. This black mark unfortunately pulled down my service rating.We also went up to the pool which was very nice and very empty. We were wondering why, and when we noticed that it was £20 to use the pool, we realised why.To recap .. hotel was excellent, staff were excellent apart from awful restaurant service (we didn't eat in again), room was big enough for 3 adults and had a great view, location was great due to the metro next door and plenty of good restaurants nearby. I would definitely recommend the hotel and stay there again when I am next in Tokyo on business or family travel.

Large hotel in Roppongi area, served by Tameike-sanno Tokyo Metro station (5 minutes walking). Room, situated on 34th floor, was confortable and quiet, also it offered a stunning view of the district. Breakfast was rich and various, only you couldn't choose where to sit. Staff were all friendly, but more helpful than most was Ai Mayanagi, who always provided us with accurate information. Highly recommended accommodation.

Very good hotel , with a perfect service as nearly always in Japan .Rooms are a bit small but Tokyo is like that .Nice breakfast , excellent outlet for food , french cooking with PERRE GAGNAIRE and nice JAPANESE but a bit expensive compare to the level of food .Convenient location close to Roppongi .

ANA Intercontinental Hotel is not a new hotel, but it is in impeccable condition and very functional, which is not a surprise for Japan. I always stay in this hotel during my business trips to Tokyo. Everything works. At least some rooms have recently been renovated, though they were in a good shape before that too. Internet works well. Breakfast is excellent. There is a good steakhouse on second and Pierre Gagnaire's fine dining restaurant at top floor if you get bored with sushi, sashimi and other Japanese treats during your visit. Getting a taxi is easy. During busy hours, sometimes a line emerges at reception but everything is very orderly. Gym is "just" OK.

Checked in on July 16th till 19th (3 nights) 2015. Its a family trip booked 3 rooms.  I'm an IHG gold member and I have stayed in many hotels all over the world. I was having high expectations but upon arriving I was not identified as an IHG gold member. After the process at the reception I asked the reception if she was aware that I'm an IHG member and she said "i know".  The room was very compact and small. After the breakfast when entering the room, I noticed the cleaner was coming out from the washroom and quickly left the room without saying anything. When I walked into the room I noticed my bag and my wife's bag were opened. I had a few country currency in my bag. I noticed my Myanmar currency was at the washroom. I immediately went out to tell my brother and I noticed the cleaner was staring at me at one corner. Later I reported to the management and they did some tracking and also spoke to the cleaner but she did not confess anything. Finally my case was just left like that and my whole vacation was spoilt as I was disturbed. I requested the management not to clean my room for the 3 days I stayed as I was worried. Hence I stayed in the room for 3 days without having it cleaned. It was the most unpleasant experience for me and my wife.  Another shock was the swimming pool was chargeable. The hotel was already so expensive and they are also charging for using the swimming pool. I checked and there was no one in the swimming pool. 6 of us rushed to the sky bar to get the happy hour. And we doubled up our order thinking that we are getting our happy hour promotion as the front guy told us that happy hour is still on. Only after ordering we were told that the happy hour is going to end in 10 minutes and we are not entitled for the happy hour price. Most of the staffs don't understand English. The hotel is so expensive and don't have a 5 star quality.

This hotel is regarded as a good value for money upper end hotel in Tokyo. It is functional 5 star hotel with no extra frills. The rooms are adequately large by Tokyo standards. The bathroom is a little jaded and the tub did not inspire me to take a soak in it. I had room service breakfast everyday and the choices are very limited. I would recommend the omelette which they manage to make rather well. The metro is a ten minute walk from the hotel. The hotel charges for usage of the pool which is rather ridiculous. While the front desk is adequately nice, the concierge is efficient but extremely curt.

For a supposedly five star hotel I am disappointed. No free wi-fi, 50 $ to use the pool and not even a free water bottle in the room (6$ for a small bottle). The location is good close to a subway station and with walking distance to Roppongi. Beds are nice but not five star. Restaurants are not bad but overpriced. Nothing is really five star except for the pricing.

I stayed here from the 21st until the 30th of July 2015. The standard room was very spacious by Tokyo standards. the bed and pillow were comfortable enough to be noteworthy. I also enjoyed the little kits of things you might have forgotten to pack in the bathroom, including cotton pads, cotton buds, nail file, shaving cream, etc. breakfast buffet is pricey but very well stocked, if not always hot enough. Had a less than perfect experience in the MIXX bar, stuffy man at the door did not want to let me in saying there were no seats, even though there were several seats available I pointed out. He told me those were reserved for luggage. I stormed towards the elevator and another staff member guided me to a nice seat with a great view. Noel is a jerk, but every single other member of staff at this hotel was beyond accomodating. Hotel is well located near a metro stop in central tokyo near the business I had to do while in tokyo.

Great welcome, the greeting and service from Russell front Office manager set up a wonderful stay and experience . Then followed by a very good lunch at the restaurant Pierre GagnaireRoom .. Junior suite ...was the best we had in JapanAll round this hotel was a very good . ( slightly dated decor and style )However we would stay here again , thanks to the team and room quality ( normally a boutique size hotel is what we gravitate to )

This was my 3rd stay at this hotel. Though I didn't necessarily plan to stay at this hotel due to my previous experiences, I ended up staying here as my other preferred hotel was full occupied during those dates.1. Location : Its pretty well located, quite nearby to a metro station. Decent walk away from Roppongi and nearby to other attractions as well. 2. Connectivity to airport : It has got a direct Airport Limousine (bus) connectivity fro m the Narita Airport, and that is a very good advantage. Its super convenient to connect to the Narita Airport , though as the airport is far it takes around 70-90min if I remember well.3. Rooms : Rooms are decent. They are quite spacious unlike other hotels in Tokyo. I know how small other hotel rooms could be , so this one a big plus point for this hotel. The mattresses are comfortable, and decor is decent as well.4. View from Room : First time the view from my room was very nice, however last 2 times I wasn't that happy about it (even though I was at 21st floor)...maybe because I kept comparing it with my first experience at this place.5. Technology in Room : Wifi was good , no complaints..I had complimentary wifi due to my membership to IHG. The lighting could be controlled by a central panel next to bed, however the curtains had to be manually adjusted. TV didn't have many English channels from what I remember, but still comparably better than what is offered in other hotels. Lighting was proper in the room.6. Bathroom in the room: Bathroom wasn't too big, though there was a bathtub, the whole bathroom seemed extremely small even for one person. The shower pressure, amenities, etc were good. 7. HouseKeeping : Room was kept well whenever I came in, no complaints from that side. 8. Other for Room : This was my only complaint - There were no free water bottle provided in the room. Paying a premium over other hotels, free water bottles should be the least expected from a 5 star. I dont like drinking from tap water, and certainly don't like paying 5 times picking a bottled water from the mini-bar. I didn't like this part of cost cutting from ANA.9. Restaurants : I ate breakfast at the Cafe at Lobby level, and the spread was ok. It wasn't lavish , neither was it too shabby. I would have expected a better variety spread from Intercontinental though, so wasn't highly impressed with the offerings. Some international food items were under cooked and taste of few items brought a shame to the legacy of such items ( such as Tandoori Chicken).10. Gym : Gym wasn't too big , the free weight options were very limited ( there wasn't even a curl bar), had only one bench. I could notice lots of people waiting to use the free weights but there wasn't enough space nor options. If someone just wants to run on trendmill , it should be ok, as I think they had around 5.11. Steam / Sauna : There was no steam room, which is a big miss. Had a Sauna room in one corner. Overall a decent place, however I would look to try another hotel next time.
user_location: National Capital Territory of Delhi, India
user_name:
PuneetB_99
National Capital Territory of Delhi, India

review_body: Having stayed here previously and had some issues with food and service it was a shame to see nothing has really changed in several months.I stayed again simply due to location, however next time I may simply stay at The Hyatt and travel the extra distance. Being an Ambassador member you (should) get priority check in and check out and although they have a sign for this, that is it. You still line up in the one single line and get no priority and when busier wait 20mins.I found the bed on this stay just terrible and pillows that are so soft they collapse into almost thin air, so hence, not one good nights sleep.We had the buffet dinner one night which was ok, with some very good dishes and some very poor. The few dishes that were very good were being emptied within a minute of being refilled so you often waited 10mins to get the dish you wanted which is not good enough.The Mixx Bar is very expensive even for local beer.Staff I have always found to be very friendly and helpful. All in all, it may be time for a change I think.

I usually don't leave a review.However I felt I should drop a line for future customers.I usually visit Tokyo more than 3 times a year and this was the worst hotel I have ever stayed in Tokyo.This hotel is even worse than a small business hotel or a boutique hotel and I don't have to mention about other peer hotels such as Conrad, Westin, and Hilton where I have very good experience.The room was old and not clean with very small and smelly bathroom.Amenities...oh come on...Housekeeping and reception people are not friendly.They even charged internet which I never asked and used.Be careful and check your invoice before you pay for it and ask them to give you one in English if you cannot read Japanese.
