Ambassador check in was atrocious and unbelievable.Suited managers around but doing very little.It took me 30 plus min for check in on ROYAL status.But we're the biggest InterCon in the world was the excuse.Other problems, the Management then checked us into the Club lounge and everything went fine.Wouldn't stay again though!!!!Wouldn't recommend it either. Not friendly at all.

Rooms are very clean and spacious for TokyoBreakfast is good, but very "rushy" and hard to find a quiet cornerService is professional and friendly.Pool is nice that it is outside, but paying 5 Dollar for the usage? It's the first time I had to pay as a hotel guest for the pool. Not acceptable.Apart from that a good stay.

I stayed there 3 nights and really enjoyed it. The hotel has big bedroom for Hotels in Japan. And it also has big lobby and good breakfast. The location is also near to the train station which makes it easier to go everywhere. And it also has a bar on the 36th floor where you could see beautiful city view in the evening

Superb location close to Roppongi and Akasaka. Good standard for the rooms and impressive lobby. A bit pricy for the breakfast, but excellent lunch buffet. The area is a bit lean on good casual izakaya unless you want to climb up the Roppongi slope, but there are very good restaurants in the hotel.

I stayed 2 nights at the Ana Intercontinental Tokyo, in the context of a short business trip to Japan.The hotel's location allows to reach most parts of Tokyo with a reasonable taxi ride. The hotel has an "aging luxury" atmosphere compared to some modern 5-star competitors. My bedroom's design was a bit "dated" but this was not at the expense of comfort (the bed was excellent and both the room and bathroom included everything you can expect from a luxury hotel; only the airconditioning could have been slightly more quiet but this was not a problem for me as I sleep with earplugs). One colleague who was traveling with me had a renovated room and its design and equipment had definitely a more contemporary feeling. This being said, the hotel is very well maintained and perfectly clean. Wifi service was not perfect as I experienced several connection issues in my room. I had complimentary wifi but I understand that standard rooms do not include such service and I believe that this is not a good commercial policy in today's world.The Ana hosts a large number of (very) high quality restaurants and this does add value for the customers. I enjoyed the Sushi Kenzan & Steakhouse for dinner and lunch, respectively, and both were a very pleasant experience (food quality & service). I also enjoyed some pastries from the Pierre Gagnaire shop in the lobby.The hotel staff was extremely professional and helping in every way and this is in line with my expectations of Intercontinental standards.I can only recommend to consider the Ana Intercontinental for anyone planning a visit to Tokyo and I will probably return as a tourist next time

Pretty rubbish overall. The seating in the grand lobby is threadbare and shabby which I found surprising. The pool is 4000Y ppn ( yes no child rate!) so it cost us about $100 US to go for a family swim for an hour. Really took the edge off our 4 night stay here, we had planned to do a lot of sightseeing, then to come back and have a dip to cool off. You cant pay for any shorter time either, so a whole day fee for an afternoon dip. Rubbish. Tip, if you are a member of their loyalty club you get free wifi ( like who charges for wifi these days, but this will save you quite a bit if you are already an IHG member which we are)The poolside bar is tiny, there is no pool side service which one might imagine for that cost and no changing areas, only lockers and showers. Unremarkable. Gym is large and very well equipped.The steakhouse is tasty, and unlike most else here it is reasonably priced, there are two much swankier restaurants we didnt try as we had a tired 7 year old in tow. The rooms are an OK size by Japanese standards, but we wouldn't rate this over the Hyatt Regency or the Hilton so we wont be back. Poor show for an Intercon too which is a chain we have used before and thought was OK, this is not.

For some reason it is very busy in tokio at the moment so we did not have a lot of choice and paid a lot of money.When we arrived at intercontinental Ana we were told that the Rooms were not next to eachother and on a 'smoking' floor.We could not accept this as we travel with children and one of them had long problems.We would like to cancel but that was not possible and after waiting a lot time we are now still waiting for the second room.So conclusion so far at 17.38 ;1 room available The room is dated and that is an understatement but clean and that is about the only good thing I can say about this huge hotel.First and last time intercontinental Ana

The Intercontinental is located near a train stop, but it is still a solid walk to the actual platforms, so the location is not a plus. The hotel is your typical large property with rehearsed spiels from the check in staff. The rooms were pleasant but nothing special. The buffet breakfast was the highlight for us. As a tourist I wouldn't choose to stay here again.

Typical business hotel set in a good location near to 3 different metro lines. However, it stops at about just there. Service was okay but not comparable to the likes of Okura Hotel or Imperial Hotel.Locale-wise, close and within reasonable walking distance (15-20min) to Roppongi but otherwise far from Marunouchi/Nihonbashi/Otemachi CBD area

The rooms were very good in terms of size and cleanliness. Staff was usually helpful but sometimes needed prompting to help solve problems. Fitness center needed some touching up but the equipment was solid. Given the cost I'm not sure the value is there overall. Logistics with the shuttle was needlessly rigid and complex.

Great location, fantastic staff, didn't want to leave.Room had a fantastic view of the Tokyo Tower. It was very clean and modern.Breakfast was of a very good standard, everything you could possibly wish for.We used the conceirge a couple of times, very friendly and knowledgable. Although beware, if you're wishing to use any thermal springs whilst in Tokyo, beware, they do not allow anyone with tattoos. This some what spoilt my birthday plans...Plus you have to pay extra to use the leisure facilities. Embarrassingly, we were told to leave as we didn't know....we refused to pay the extra money to use it as we had already paid a lot of money for the room in the first place. This didn't dampen our spirits to much but it's the first time we have ever been asked to pay to use a hotel pool!However, the bullet train soon made up for it!This is a terrific hotel and you really can't go wrong with it!

Very central location if doing business in or around Roppongi. Staff are all very nice and friendly, with good level of English (helpful as my Japanese is terrible). Whilst not a cheap hotel, would you expect anything else from a hotel that can arrange a helicopter from the airport, the costs are about average for the area.

Many of the stuff are good looking.But their attitude were the worst.It's not worth staying.If you have such a big money to stay here, It's better so select other hotel.I'm sure you can find better place to stay even with cheaper price.

Visited with a group of friends and all members of staff were exceptional in terms of service standards - we tried the champagne bar which was great as well as the Pierre Gagnaire pastry shop.One small disappointment was room service: on the first day we ordered a club sandwich around 4pm and the quality was not good, bread poorly toasted and it did not look appetizing, on another day we ordered noodles and the member of staff forgot to bring it in the hotbox.But this is a massive hotel with 800 rooms, therefore these very small glitches are natural - they have a fantastic concierge who assisted in making our full itinerary over 4 days

Excellent location, great reception and concierge staff, one of the best buffet breakfasts, useful gym and swimming pool. The direct Limousine bus connectivity with Narita further is a great comfort. Will come again and again.

The location is good--quite convenient to the subway, although it is tricky to find it the first time, and if you miss it, you could go around in a circle. Very good service at the hotel and reasonably spacious rooms for Tokyo. There is a good yakatori place nearby and the hotel restaurant had a fabulous breakfast spread every morning, with just about every food, Eastern or Western, you could imagine. Very easy to get cabs. Only problem was when they halted the elevators for 90 minutes after an earthquake, but that was only done for safety reasons. Unsettling at first to be swaying for a solid 60 seconds, but then you realize they have earthquakes pretty frequently in Japan and with all those skyscrapers, the builders must really know what they are doing. Everyone spoke English and was unbelievably courteous and polite. We were an easy walk to Tokyo Tower, and close to the historical Hotel Okura, which we wanted to glimpse before it was razed. No fantastic sushi places nearby, but you can find many a short cab ride away. Would easily stay there again.

The staff were always helpful and courteous, the facilities fantastic. Location great, close to many restaurants and the subway. There were no language problems, we aren't versed in japanese, which can be a major obstacle in other cities we later found. We would definitely stay again. Judi, Australia, visited July 2015.

Hotel is about 15 mins from Roppongi and subway is 2 minutes away.  We had a suite room which was spacious enough.Food is reasonably priced for a hotel. Just outside the hotel courtyard there are a few restaurants which was good. There is a convenience store downstairs which was well stocked.Shower is strong and loved the Japanese toilet. They have Shiseido toiletries.The duvet is very, very warm but light so we had to put the a/c on really cold. Buffet breakfast was awesome. Fantastic selection. Would stay again

I like this hotel as I usually stay here every time I come to tokyo. However, I am also every time frustrated at the fact one has to pay for the pool to get access. Management response is: "All hotels in Tokyo do the same". So I guess that makes it ok? 4,000 yen (which is about $40) to go to the pool for 1h or 2, is excessive. When you already pay $300 per night for a room, and that is 30 degrees outside, you should at least receive free access to the pool. VERY disappointed in that.Otherwise, it is a great hotel. Make sure you get at least the luxury rooms as the standard ones are unpractical, with tv at the side of the bed (instead of in front), and outdated bathrooms.Service is good, and the breakfast is quiet amazing. Location is average, but you are only 20 min walk from Roppongi Hills.

Our first hotel in Japan so we were pleasantly surprised to be immediately upgraded and "checked-in" at 10:30am. Typically, the rooms aren't overly spacious but everything's there although the lighting could have been brighter.

The hotel is very big and the higher floors have amazing views over Tokyo. We really liked the restaurants and the wait staff... food was great and prices cheap compared to Dubai. Next door there are lots of other restaurants in an open air courtyard which we wish we'd found earlier... and the bar on the 36th floor of the hotel was lovely for drinks and nibbles.Easy to get a taxi from here to anywhere in Tokyo... everything we went to seemed to be about 15 mins away... so was fine! The bell boys really helped with telling the drivers where to go but everything was generally easy anyway.The rooms are fine... we'd upgraded to a Junior Suite and wish we hadn't bothered- we'd got an older style room and I was really unhappy with the furniture... but hey ho- the bed and bathroom were fabulous... was just annoyed the extra bit I'd paid fro wasn't the same standard as the pics on the websites. The room was always very clean and the hotel has L'Occitane toiletries, the shower was very powerful.Check In staff were ok- they are probably not as strong in English as the wait staff though- didn't accommodate my request to move to a more modern room and tried to charge a credit card 3 times when I told them not to- leading to my card being blocked... luckily I had another one with me.Also be aware the pool has a charge for usage- it's not free to hotel guests.I would recommend this hotel- especially for a business trip- there were a majority of business travelers there from the looks of things but for a more leisurely, luxury type holiday I wouldn't stay again and would try somewhere like The Palace or The Peninsula.We had an amazing trip to Tokyo and loved every minute of the city... if you go have a great time!
user_name:
Gail P
Dubai, United Arab Emirates

review_body: The room we got was slightly more roomy than an average room in Tokyo. Everything was very clean and nice. A lot of guests were there for business, as I noticed. They had a conference going on the last day I was there. The staff was friendly, for the most part. The free breakfast I got as part of my room was great. I ordered in room dining on one of the days, and went down to the actual buffet the others. There are definitely more choices down there. The beds were comfy, and the space for lounging is limited but nice. The only thing that would keep me from staying here is the location. It's a bit of a walk to get to any restaurants or other areas to walk around. Our group often used taxi or subway to get anywhere. The subway station was very close, though, so that was helpful.

Stayed here 3 nights and it was a prefect hotel for my needs. it was close to where I was doing business and close to the subway station. It was clean, modern, excellent food, gracious staff and an overall excellent

One of the best hotels in Tokyo (though hotels in Tokyo has smaller rooms compared to other countries). What is great about this place is its location, its not on the busy places as it is in the business district and yet near strategic places like train stations and malls.

Good location with a few if the major tourist sites within walking distance. Close to a subway station. Good by american standard. Great wifi , free for IHG members. Extremly expensive pool. OK breakfast. Easy access by bus to Narita

Stayed here for 4 nights to explore Tokyo. This hotel has made my stay in Tokyo and was an absolute pleasure. The hotel is very well located to get around Tokyo. Very close to the underground transportation.The bars on the top floors have awesome views of Tokyo. This is a quality hotel and the staff are all very helpful and polite. The staff went the extra mile with me. My room was just luxury.I only have one complaint - it rained for my duration at the hotel. It was warm and the hotel provided umbrella - THANK YOU for a great stay.

If you can swing the additional $100 per night for the club lounge you get a value for money deal with great breakfast in the morning thown in, and canapes in the evening. The lounge is the best iv'e had the pleasure to experience, its very spacious, with great views over the city and Diet building, very helpful staff, and the hotel itself is on the less expensive side of $300 per night. Finally, its next to the subway system.

This was my first stay at the ANA Intercontinental, and I have only positive things to say. The service was efficient, the room had all the necessary comforts, and the large outdoor swimming pool (big enough for proper length training if you are so inclined) is a particular bonus. I only walked past the gym, and it looked good. The buffet restaurant was very good at breakfast. I will certainly consider staying again.

Centrally located, clean and great service. Stayed for a week on business, staff were efficient and food and service were great. Rooms are small but everything you need was available and staff were only too happy to help. Have stayed in this hotel on several occasions and wouldn't stay anywhere else when I travel to Tokyo

I was impressed upon entry into the hotel, it is a very pristine and shiny reception area although after a few days the artificial clean smell in the area did start to annoy me. The staff are also very good on reception, upon reaching my room I was disappointed. The room was fairly small although given this is in the heart of Tokyo it isn't too surprising. The carpet did not feel clean and was very old and faded. The bed itself was comfortable although the pillows were fairly pathetic in their fluffiness so I don't think many people would be able to sleep with just one. The air conditioning was good, black out curtains were great. Mini bar is well stocked. Bathroom is tiny, shower over a beige (small) bath but the shower curtain and the area was clean. Products supplied in the bathroom were okay but no body lotion which is unusual for a hotel of this calibre.The restaurants are all pretty decent in the hotel, I never tried the breakfast though. the gym is small but decent, clean and well air conditioned. The pool was disappointing, limited opening hours and the pool itself is showing its age. The tiles are faded, the pool is grubby, there is nowhere to get food or drink nearby. the loungers and sun shades are reasonable but it was very underused when I visited. The pool is a good temperature though.I would visit again if on business as it is a decent location near the metro and restaurants but disappointed.

If your after Friendly, this hits it out of the park, location is terrific for government closeness and great walking, restaurants, train station,ect. The place is clean, well managed and up to date. Highly recommended as a place to stay.

My daughter and I stayed at the Ana in Tokyo for 8 nights. What a wonderful holiday experience! We would go back in a heartbeat.The service is impeccable. Our room was very spacious and quiet and it had all the amenities we needed. The location was very close to the subway which we used often. Taxis were always available and staff were extremely helpful. We were able to navigate on foot, bus and subway quite easily. The hotel restaurant is pricey and we treated ourselves a couple of times but there are a wide variety of restaurants and cuisines nearby, within walking distance.

Service in this hotel is excellent. Club Lounge provides good spread of breakfast selection and service is excellent. Staff will helpful and very friendly too.The check in experience was very warmth and friendly. We were greeted the moment we get out from the car.

The concierge is outstanding, helped an incredible amount with traveling in the city and planning events. Ordered bus tickets and gave restaurant recommendations as well as reservations. The room is clean and well maintained but beds are small, not too small but smaller than American ones. Area has easy access to subway-practically on top of it, so easy to travel to other locations- limited sites and restaurants near hotel but many consulates.

Just stay for 4 night and I have to say it is really very very great hotel. Very clean and new. Bed is soft and comfortable. Pillow is a bit too soft but still OK. However my colleague stayed on a lower floor (24th) complained that her room is old and dusty. I stayed on 31st floor. I guess the higher floors are newly renovated. . Breakfast is only OK. Variety limited. But you have to try the bakery shop at the lobby... very tasty pastries!Location wise is not that bad. Hotel is located in between 2 station and they r walkable.

I have the pleasure of staying at the Ana Intercontinental this month. I have stayed here many times before and always found the staff friendly and courteous. This time however I experienced why this hotel is a great place to stay. It is not a cheap hotel, however is does go the extra mile for their customers. On this trip I had the misfortune to have my CPAP machine fuse. As this is not available at an electronic store I ask the concierge to help me communicate. Simonis spent several hours following leads and contacts until she located a loan machine. The amount of effort is above and beyond what I could have hoped yet the concierge team just said it is our job I would recommend this team to anyone

I wanted to spend a couple nights at a really nice place at the tail-end of my trip, and so I chose the ANA based on name recognition. Overall, I would not stay there again. The location was very inconvenient. There was NOTHING around the hotel, and the train station is ridiculous. We had to talk forever just to get on a train, and the lines that go through there are not convenient. We had to transfer THREE TIMES to get to Disneyland.The concierge was very helpful in getting us reservations at a restaurant and making local recommendations. In addition, the room was clean, but it was overlooking a cemetery. The bathroom could definitely use some updating.

This hotel is located in the center of Tokyo on the map, however, unless you plan to use taxies to get around, it is not so convenient as the two closest train stations are at least 10-minute walk away. Also, there are not too many restaurant choices within short walking distance. You can go to Roppongi or Akasaka, where you’ll find many high-end and low-end restaurants, but both locations take about 15-minutes on foot. But other than the location, it is a nice hotel and you will get the services you would expect from an Intercontinental.

The ANA Intercontinental Tokyo is located in Asakasa, near Roppongi, a convenient location from which to travel to both the west and east sides of town. The bad: The room (bathroom in particular) is small compared to other five-star hotels. Also, it is at least a 10-minute-walk to either of Tameikesanno and Roppongi Itchome stations, and nearly 20-minute-walk to the Roppongi crossing. I would recommend taking Airport Limousine Bus to the airport. The good: There are plenty of convenient stores and a 24-hour supermarket nearby, a reportedly good Club Level, and not to mention the famous nightlife in Roppongi. This hotel has some shortcomings, but it is affordable (five-star) and centrally located in the heart of town, great for the cost-conscious traveler.

We stayed in this hotel for 3 nights.It's a real 5 star hotel catering to your every wish, the beds a really comfortable, although I must add one negative ... I hate showering in a bath! I much prefer separate showers.The hotel is very well located and whilst I usually prefer taxis, you must use the underground, it's dead simple, clean and cheap. A day pass is a quarter of the price for the London equivalent. The station is a mere 100 metres from the hotel.We had a late check out and decided to pack, have a late lunch in the hotel and then go to the airport. The hotel buffet lunch is spectacular, catering for every cuisine and very reasonably priced.

Since my two prior visits in 2013, I've stayed three more times and sent my adult daughter and son there. And I'd return! Why so loyal: Flawless service, wonderful concierge, comfortable rooms, easy bus/shuttle connections to Narita and Haneda, great location, walking distance to Imperial Palace (good place to run), and nice hotel features (pool, exercise facilities). Downside: Lack of free Internet (unless you are a club member or book a room at top pricing tier); on major holidays, the restaurant may run out of capacity so book a reservation if you plan to be on site for dinner). For non-Japanese speakers, access to an excellent concierge is vital to satisfaction, and Ms. Momoi deserves her golden keys designation. She has good advice (always), makes great restaurant recommendations (and facilitates reservations), and has a good understanding of what tourists can and can't handle with respect to subway/train. She makes visiting Tokyo a wonderful experience, even for travelers who lack local language skills. The hotel is connected to Ark Hills with many shops and restaurants, and is walkable to the lively Roppongi district. Special shout out to Russell, who seems to be everywhere at once, often on hand to help.

Tokyo was our first getaway overseas. Intercontinental ANA was our first pick due to it's history of having great rooms and service. Both of us have stayed in Intercontinental in Melbourne and realised there's one in Tokyo. As per usual, throughout our stay, it was a great and a memory that we'll never forget. We started with the classic room for the first few nights and then progress to the executive suite?. There we noticed how the rooms differentiate and how much nicer it was. Besides that, the service with all the hotel staff was great. They helped us in such a way that was heart warming. We loved staying there and in the future we'll come back and stay there again! Thank you Intercontinental ANA for the memories and we'll see you soon.

Stayed in this hotel for a week, my pleasant surprise, this time front desk were more friendly as compared to my last experiences, they even allowed early check in and upgraded room as I was IHG member .... So recommendation is that become IHG member before you checkin and get few benefits like late check out, free Internet etc.Staff are friendly, specially c

Visited this hotel in March-April 2015. The hotel is located near a metro station which connects you with other metro lines.Food is good and service is fantastic specially at the Intercontinental Club Lounge. The hotel hosts Pierre Gaignare restaurant which is fantastic. Our suite room was not ready and we were given the presidential suite. What an experience

Overall, this is a typical business hotel - connection to ANA makes it highly geared towards Japanese business travelers and groups, with very poor English levels throughout.However as typical as it is, there are some major flaws with basic service delivery and some very poor room design choices - considering the options in Tokyo this is therefore an easily avoidable hotel.Checked-in by the front office manager was pleasant enough - he made a big deal of walking me to the lift and announcing that I was given a "wonderful room with a great view of the Imperial Palace"... imagine the surprise to walk in a tiny room with a view of an overpass... good start.The hotel, due to its sheer size, has very little character - my room was no different.Bathroom however is not just small but also terribly poorly designed - no ventilation, a very hot heated mirror, a crazy shower (optional front shower jets but no glass partition in front of them - open this and you basically shoot water across the bathroom and on the wash basin - see picture...).Toilet is of the obligatory Toto electric version but with an incredibly hot seat (the warming function must be set to "toasty")... impossible to regulate as the instructions are either erased or in Japanese.Most annoying - no complimentary water in the room - after a long flight, having to pay 6x the already marked-up price for a tiny bottle of Evian is outrageous. This could be where the local hoodlums get trained on extortion techniques.Finally, get ready for breakfast - long queues, approximate service and fairly average-to-poor food quality make for a very unpleasant experience. If you arrive near closing time, at 10.30am, hang on to your hat - at 10.32am there were already half of all items removed by staff on what seemed to be some sort of race to clear things as fast and as noisily as possible.Overall, a very basic and very large hotel with some flaws...

Stayed here last month for four nights either side of a weekend at Fuji speedway. Really enjoyed my time here. Was in room 3208 which had great views of Tokyo tower and the city. The hotel definitely caters for westerners so if you are looking for a more Japanese experience this might not be the place. Can't say I was bothered though. The Mixx bar has awesome views over the city and is cool to watch the sunset from. Staff were great and room service was exceptionally quick. Hope to be back soon.

Good location from where we could visit shrines see shops and the Manga culture. Built for the 60s Olympics so large rooms. Very clean. Good mix of food if rather dear. Fabulous view over spectacular gardens as you eat. Service excellent.
user_location: Bury St Edmunds, England, United Kingdom
user_name:
Elizabeth M
Bury St Edmunds, England, United Kingdom

review_body: Beautiful hotel with superb service. Right next door is a series of restaurants and a supermarket, if required. Roppongi and all the shopping it offers is only a short walk away. The Airport bus stops at the hotel, other buses leave from out the front of the hotel and it is an easy walk to various train stations.

Great central location and one of the best Club Lounges in any hotel worldwide Very spacious , great views, good food,drink and service .Worth paying more for this club lounge for sure Rooms are good too Good selection of restaurants in the hotel

The hotel itself is very nice. Great restaraunts and shops are located in the hotel and it's location affords one access to local shops and restaraunts as well. The customer service is excellent with very attentive and friendly staff.The only downside is that the rooms are somewhat dated and could use a refresh. Others have commented on this as well. The rooms are clean but just in need of a remodel. This is a great hotel for business travel but I don't think I would bring my wife here since there are other hotels in the area that are more romantic.

The hotel location is pretty good not far from Shibuya and other interesting locations. The service in the hotel is excellent like the teppanyaki restaurant which I have found very expensive. The rooms are getting a bit old and the bathroom was small and not functional.

We arrived after traveling for more than 20 hours from the US and as soon as we got there (after 3pm), she said our room wasn't ready. Just when we worried that we would have to wait, she upgraded us to a higher floor room and gave us an awesome view of the Tokyo Tower! The level of service and hospitality there (and in Japan in general) was outstanding. Everyone was so nice to answer questions and help out in any way. The rooms were very nice and clean and the hotel was in a great location to walk to a lot of great places to eat and shop. And cabs were readily accessible. We had the breakfast buffet twice and it had just about every type of food from all over the world so definitely a great option. Ask for a higher floor room and if you are a rewards member wifi is free. Sign up before you go.

Stayed here recently for 5 nights on a business trip and I really enjoyed it. the room was comfortable and service very good. They kindly gave me a 3pm check-out as I had an evening flight home. The staff are super helpful.There are many restaurants - my only gripe many close too early compared to the standard in an international city. Closing at 8.30pm is too early - as some do - and then many at 9.30pm. When I arrived at the hotel on my first night - at 10pm - i was hoping to get some dinner - but nothing open - 10+ restaurants and not 1 open. They directed me to the bar - but so many people smoking it turned me off - and no Japanese food - just burgers, fries etc. It was a bit disappointing to find myself on my first night in Japan forced to eat American fast food. Other than that - great. Great location - easy walk to Roppongi Crosing and Roppongi Hills.

Stayed 4 nights at this hotel which did not disappoint . The services provided at the Reception Desk and in the Restaurants were great and food choice especially in the buffet style area was excellent at breakfast and dinner . The local metro station entrance/exit (just outside) and the Metro lines provide easy access to the whole network and City but take a map from Hotel Reception before travelling and be prepared to walk some distances underground once in the systemThe hotel rooms were more than adequate if a little dated but were comfortable clean and quiet.

The ANA has a great location, good eateries and a topfloor bar with an amazing view. The rooms are spacious, breakfast caters for all tastes and the gym is a decent size. The only thing that keeps this hotel from being top notch is the fact that it stock in the previous century and is in need of a facelift. Nonetheless, I almost always stay here when in Tokyo.

I stayed in the hotel for two nights during my business trip. My room was quite small, but some of my colleagues got corner rooms which seemed much bigger than mine. Those are very decently sized especially by Japanese standards. Also I heard weird noises during the first night in my room. The room was clean. Wifi worked fine. The staff were helpful and understand English well.The hotel was very well located. I took taxi to go there from Haneda airport which cost me 7300 yen. They have regular shuttle bus going to Narita airport which took me 1 hour only to get there.I had a one person dinner at the Pierre Gagnaire restaurant on the 35/F of the hotel. It's one of the best French restaurants I've ever tried. As I was alone, the Italian sommelier Alesso kept me company and made the night really enjoyable. The other staff were also very polite and helpful. They have a special menu for hotel guests. Worth a try.

I have stayed only for 1 day for a meeting. Check in counter was crowded, but staff were very efficient so it did not take time. There are always taxis waiting for you so no need to worry about transportation. Also If you are into night life, Roppongi is only 15min walk. I came down for breakfast and it was packed. Wide variety of selection av available. Also Staff are very attentive there too. They always come to you to clear your plate or replenish coffee right on time! I must say this is a very nice hotel for business people and tourists as well since location, service and facilities are amasing. I am defeniately coming back to this hotel!https://youtu.be/hekKiy_Rjr0

We stayed at the hotel during the busy Sakura season weekend. The front desk staff was helpful and accommodated our request for early check in. We arrived at the hotel at 6am plus and went sightseeing. Front desk staff asked us to return at 10am but when our room was not ready, the hotel kindly arranged for a vacant room for us to shower and rest until our room was ready at about 11am-12pm. We had lunch at Pierre Gagnaire and it was good experience. The food was delicious and the set menu was affordable. We were seated by the window and had great views of Tokyo. Our room was clean and comfortable. The size of the room was spacious for 2 people.The location of the hotel was very central and very near to the subway/train station so it was convenient to explore the city.Finally, a big thank you to Ms. Miho from Concierge for helping us to book a tour last minute. All the day tours from Tokyo were fully booked but she managed to find a day tour for us. We will definitely stay at the hotel again if we return to Tokyo in the future.

Arrived early for check-in, about 11am, they promised my room would be ready for 1pm. After having a coffee I strolled up to the desk at 1pm & the desk clerk recognised me & said your room is now ready & we have upgraded you.The buffet restaurant served a very good variety of food, Japanese, Chinese, Vietnamese, Indonesian, Malaysian & European. The food was excellent along with the service. However the beer was expensive 1,100 Yen for 330ml draught. ( very close to the hotel there are 3 local supermarkets where you can but beer for a fraction of that price).Breakfast has an excellent selection of food. Again Japanese & western. The service is fast & efficient even at busy periods. A pot of coffee turns up almost as soon as you sit down.The hotel room was very nice, good desk & plenty of sockets for charging. The WiFi was very fast 13Mb download, 14Mb upload 17ms Ping. No problem with Skype.The airport limousine bus stops at this hotel. Again a very good efficient service 3,100 Yen each way to Narita.

Concierge Ymke Simmons is an absolute dream who provided exceptional service. We will fondly remember her many excellent recommendations and the wonderful experiences we had visiting them. Ms. Momoi is great too.

Great & Friendly People of Japan there is no doubt in that if I say it!Impressive how they conduct themselves in congested areas & guve way to all in a polite manner. Not a very common thing in many big cities.Very organisesd infrastructure & a great place to learn manners!Tasty Sushi where ever you go.

For a 5 star hotel, the room is normal with a generous bathroom. Housekeeping service was fast when we asked for an extra bed and extra drinking water.Front Office staff took a very long time to solve our bed arrangement problem when we arrived. We asked for twin beds but they arranged a king bed. Problem-solving skills of the staff is mediocre.Concierge tried to help me with my mobile phone docomo SIM card issue but could not (I do not blame her but wished she could have directed me to somewhere who could).The hotel is located near roppongi hills where there are many nice international name restaurant.

My company booked a block of rooms for us here. Out Tokyo office is in the Ark Hills tower next door. We had three days to ourselves so I can review the Hotel from both a tourist and business perspective.The service is very good. On par with the previous InterContinental I've stayed at. We arrived at 5am and they accommodated early check in for us. Early checkin was priced almost a much as an additional nights stay. Breakfast is good and almost identical to the breakfast buffet at the JW Marriot in Seoul. Very good food that caters to almost all people. Everything from an omelette station, to shumai, to curries. Must be standard fair in asian business hotels.The rooms are on the small side. It's not so much a problem, except for the bathroom. I was ok, but if you are a big American guy, you might feel cramped. The desk is sufficient for getting work done. The gym facilities are not very large. The pools was not open in May. The locker room facilities were clean and looked brand new. I was able to use the gym showers after checkout and before my late night flight out of Tokyo.The location is perfect for business travelers in the area. Close proximity to the major office buildings great access to the subway system. As a tourist you may want to be more in the heart of Ginza, Shinjuku, or other district. The pro is this location is very central to all districts. You will just have to take a taxi or train to almost everywhere you want to go. Ginza is a 15min train ride away. Shinjuku, a 15 min taxi ride away. Keep in mind Taxi's are very expensive in Tokyo- at least in comparison to New York City or San Francisco.The concierge was very helpful and clear in their direction. They suggested some great restaurants and had great info regarding sumo, the fish market and other activities. They were able to get us a last minute reservation for Sushi at Kyubey. It was very good and highly recommended.Lastly they were very accommodating with a late checkout. I was stuck in a Taxi in traffic on the way back to the hotel. I was either going to miss checkout time or miss our very expensive reservation at Kyubey. They understood the situation after explanation and gave me a few extra hours. This is not something I would count on as they did it as a favor at the time. It was greatly appreciated.This was my second stay at an InterContinental. My stays were pleasant and consistent and will definitely stay with them again in any other region.

we choose this hotel because it was close to our business appointment. At the Intercontinental chain I am Ambassador Platinum member. That means you are regular guest in this chain. They promise a lot: separate check in (no one there); newspaper (did not come) etc. etc.We complained about the way the hotel as well as the people in the restaurant treat us and after long discussions they gave is a bigger room as compensation. Why: do what you promise then you don't need to compensate.

mid level hotel in a good location in the Anasaka area of Tokyo. great service, nice workout room and very good breakfast buffet. fast wifi comfortable rooms. bathroom tends to smell but placing a washcloth over the floor vent will solve the issue.

Stayd 12 days in this very nice and high quality hotel and enjoyed the perfect location and service level, all staff just so nice, helpful and service minded.Breakfast very good and club room a must, extreamly good selection of food and bevreges, wifi and more.Perfect location to the metro and all types off very good local resturant nearby.Room big to be in Japan and nothing to complain about at all.Will use this hotel again.

Stayed at the ANA on a recent work trip. From check in check out I felt very looked after. The room was comfortable, clean and well serviced. The concierge was very knowledgeable and helped us find our way around quickly. The shops downstairs were lovely with the little bakery having some yummy desserts. Breakfast was very busy each day but the selection of food and service was excellent. I enjoyed dinner at the buffet on one occasion and whilst it cost a little more than I would usually pay, the food was fantastic and I loved the dessert bar with the chocolate fountain. I would definitely recommend this hotel to others.

While on a business trip to Tokyo, I decided at the last minute to spend a couple of extra days there and chose to stay at the ANA InterContinental. The hotel was able to meet my last minute accommodation request with no issues whatsoever. Prior to checking out of the hotel I was staying at previously, I contacted the ANA InterContinental and requested to check in approximately four hours early. The hotel immediately accepted this request, and upon check in I was instantly upgraded to a suite on the 28 floor with a spectacular view of the Tokyo Tower (which I suspect was due to my IHG platinum status).While headed to my room, I was greeted by several members of the floor's house keeping staff who inquired as to if I required anything to make my stay more pleasant. Once arriving in the room, I was actually impressed with the overall size and layout of the room. When the hotel staff arrived to deliver my luggage, I was again asked if there was anything I needed and if the room was to my liking.After settling in, I returned back to the lobby in search for something to eat for lunch. The concierge staff suggested I try the Cascade Cafe. Upon entering, I immediately noticed they were very busy with what appeared to be the business crowd also enjoying lunch. I had the choice of either the buffet or to order off of the menu, in which I chose the latter. I was greeted by one of the waitstaff members and immediately noticed that he seemed to be stressed by the amount of tables he had; which was also later evident by the poor service I received by this young man. I ended up ordering the carbonara pasta and two Japanese beers, which left me with a bill of about $40. It was pretty pricey for lunch, but I did enjoy the food.After finishing lunch, I decided to venture out into one of the business districts of Tokyo. The advice given by the concierge staff was absolutely wonderful and spot on. The concierge staff is really one of the main reasons that I really enjoyed my stay at the ANA InterContinental.Upon returning to the hotel, I decided to book an in-room massage. The options were either a 60 or 120 oil massage, or a 60 minute Thai massage. I opted for the 60 minute Thai massage which ended up running me well over $100. The massage it self wasn't bad, however the spa specialist who was giving the massage was not the most courteous. Approximately 10 minutes into the massage, her phone ragn and she began to carrying on a conversation try to booking another massage immediately following mine. She stayed on the phone for a little longer than five minutes and immediately apologized. This issue happened twice during the span of the 60 minutes.Upon check out, the front desk staff were extremely efficient and had me completely checked out in less than five minutes. When I walked outside the hotel, I informed a staff member that I requested a Taxi to take me to the Hamamatsucho train station and he ushered me to the taxi that he had standing by for me. Upon entering the taxi, the staff member informed the taxi driver of my destination and thanked me for visiting the hotel.Overall, I really enjoyed my stay here. It is VERY pricey, even for Tokyo standards. However, you will not be disappointed! Make sure that if you're not an IHG member, you sign up for the program at check -in. Doing so will allow you to dodge the $15/ day wi-fi charge.

This hotel is very comfortable and adequate without being excessive, and priced accordingly.The hotel's location is very convenient for the tourist who only has a few days to see the sights. It's also located adjacent to the Ark Hills complex, which has an impressive selection of restaurants for any budget. For getting around, it's only a short (~1200JPY) cab ride from Tokyo Station. There is a subway entrance right outside the hotel, but it can be up to a 800m (0.5 mile) underground walk to get to the actual train. If you're trying to get to the airport, the airport's shuttle-bus has its last stop here, so it's nonstop to the airport after you get on.The rooms are a little bit worn, but still have a modern style. The rooms are spacious and feels very clean. It's not over-the-top luxury but it is certainly adequate. The hotel's most pleasant surprise is its rooftop bar. Even though the hotel isn't particularly tall (37 stories, I believe), it provides great views of the city. Drinks are a little pricey, but I can't imagine a better setting for an early-evening aperitif.

Loved our two nights here, rooms large, beds comfortable and bathroom clean. The staff were friendly and helpful and the breakfast food was exceptionally good. We found the hotel well connected to train metro so we were able to get around Tokyo easily. Recommended.

I have been there recently, Japanese are very polite, and I have had a bad experience with this hotel, I would not recommend it to anyone!They were neither friendly nor helpful!You would rather spend your money elsewhere!Small room only fit for Japanese!

Large hotel, close to steps down to subway although a 5 min walk to actual station. Lovely hotel in good location. Excellent facilities and extremely helpful staff who could not do enough to help you. A number of restaurants nearby & a Starbucks just around the corner. Would recommend to others.

Essentially this hotel is for business travellers however we found a good deal online and jumped on it. We were immediately pleased with the friendly staff and after a long journey they were kind enough to store our bags until our room was ready. After experiencing our first day sightseeing we realised we were not in the normal tourism area (subway/taxi ride necessary) and once in our room, the view of layers of highways. The room was in the 30th ish floor, king bed, shower over bath, heated toilet seat, kimonos, robes, essential beauty items in the bathroom all of a high standard.Breakfast was included in the rate and it was excellent, catering for us Aussies but also for many others - everything you could want and more. We ate out in the day and night so I can't comment on the restaurants or bars however there is a small shopping centre next door with additional cafes which are accessible by foot and meals at great prices. Thank you to the room and cleaning staff who turned down our beds each night, it was a kind addition to the already high level service.

just stayed in tokyo for 4 nights and booked this hotel again for following reasons.good location as next/walking distance to Rapponggi, which is great for food and bars.Also great gym, all new equipment and has a sauna for men only by the way.the steak house is good,the tempanyaki is a little expensive and not a lot of atmosphere.We met Russell, one of the guest relations team and he made our stay really worthwhile,if he is there when you go,ask him for places to go nearby and what to do,he was very helpful.if you fly to Tokyo, go to the Haneda airport, as only 25 mins from the hotel,dont go to Narita, as 2 hours away!!Only bad thing was the use of the club floor, is only by payment and they wanted around 100usd a night,just to use it,not worth it for sure!!their is a starbucks just next door and they make great coffee there,hope this helpsdave

I was only in Tokyo for two days/one night, but this was a great place to "call home" incredibly wonderful staff, a nice quiet room, and convenient walking to where I needed to go. There is a convenient bus from Narita airport that takes you straight to the hotel. I was able to walk to the Tokyo Tower easily from the hotel, and saw just how beautiful this part of Tokyo is. I can't wait to go back

This is a fantastic hotel, has the wow factor as soon as you walk through the doors. It's located in the business centre but the underground is very easy to use and the underground station is a two minute walk (if that) from the hotel entrance, so you can easily zip about. Tokyo is definitely an active holiday - lots of walking, lots of food to sample, so bring good trainers but note: everyone seemed very well put together when we went there so you may want to step it up a notch! Doutor was great for a continental breakfast, there are plenty of places to eat lunch/dinner nearby but it gets better if you get a cab to the Grand Fresca Hotel and go North East (£4 cab). Note that apparently for the first 2 km 730yen (£4) is the standard charge, it then ticks up thereafter. We took a cab from ANA to Haneda and it cost in total £70, so even though you hear taxi prices are expensive, the taxi prices in the city (non-airport) are the same as London.

We are an older, active couple on holidays but want a comfortable bed, a quiet room and good service. We found all this (as we expected with this brand) with this hotel with emphasis on a comfortable bed and pillows and the exceptional cleanliness of everything. The service and attention from all staff was excellent and in particular from Junko and Satomi who took particularly good care of us. The location of the hotel, while not exactly in the centre of Tokyo, is only a short taxi ride from Tokyo Railway Station but more importantly it is very near a subway station on the Ginza line which we found to be very convenient as we could reach all parts of Tokyo very quickly. The surrounds of the hotel are pleasant and offer good walks and exploration. We would highly recommend this hotel.

Stayed in the hotel for 2 nights. First night we were given a lower level with no views and a rather dated room. I spoke to the receptionist that we are Ihg member and immediately got a higher level room with view of Tokyo Tower. The rooms were of good size and the beds were firm and comfortable. There was no complimentary bottled water and everything hasto be paid for. The subway is just down the escalator on the ground level. Very convenient to travel anywhere around Tokyo. There are the convenience shops 7-Eleven and Family Mart along the same side of the road 1 min walk after the subway. We bought the 1 day subway ticket from the information desk in the lobby and the lady there was very helpful gave us a subway map and indicated the places of interest we can visit. We visited most of the places with the Y800 ticket each to see the Meji Temple and a short walk in the forest,the palace grounds, Sibuya to see the statue of Hatchiko, lunch in Ginza and then Tokyo tower early in the evening which light up at 620pm. We also went to Roponggi to see the giant spider and dragon. The Mori Tower was closed for viewing of tokyo on the top floor. The walk back to ANA was about 15 mins downhill. There were shops along the walk so didn't feel that long. Just follow the overhead carriage and hotel is on the right up the footbridge after the gym. Enjoyed the stay, staff are courteous and efficient. We'll come back again.

We stayed in Tokyo for two nights and had an outstanding visit. The rooms are brilliantly clean, linen excellent, and size of rooms very good. Fast elevators, unbelievably fast WIFI connectivity, super friendly staff and rooms away from the Tokyo noise. Close to subways, nightlife and excellent restaurants the hotel is ideally positioned to all that is needed. Great for an extended or short stay I highly recommend this hotel. The only downside was I found the buffet very expensive comparatively speaking but with so much variety in Tokyo this is barely a reason to complain.

Stayed here for 5 nights. I would say this hotel deserves 5 stars. It is pure luxury. Everything was so clean, the staff were all very respectful and all were very helpful if you were in need. The food was top notch. I tried the Japanese restaurant at lunch time, a really pleasant atmosphere and very nice food, I also tried the steak restaurant and must say the Japanese steak was the best steak I have ever tasted. The breakfast buffet was good with plenty of choices from cereal to full english and Japanese style. You could eat as much as you liked.The Club lounge was good. Had breakfast there once and also went for cocktail hour were you can sample all sorts of different snacks and have what ever you want to drink all included in the club room price. Cocktail hour is actually two hours. Also has a brilliant view over the city. The Mixx bar is pretty cool with comfortable seating and also a fantastic view.I stayed in an Executive deluxe room on the 25th floor and must say there was plenty of room. The room was well organised and spotless. The bed was extremely comfortable. Again with a great view.All the hotel staff were very polite,respectful and friendly. If you needed something you only had to ask.Location was great with a metro entrance on the doorstep. Also close buy to other restaurants and shops.The only negative was having to leave.Would I stay here again? Oh yes!!

The hotel deserves its stars, but it's not as luxurious as I would have expected it. The Japanese love standardization and I found the staff efficient during my stay, which leads to an overall pleasant stay.

From the warm and yet extremely polite welcome we received by the doorman to the friendly smiles and phenomenal service we received across every aspect of the hotel, we would have no hesitations in recommending it to anyone visiting Tokyo. Requiring adjoining rooms for our two children (aged 10 and 8) the hotel was extremely compliant in understanding our request. Although it was a little disappointing that due to this requirement the “parents room” had to have two king single beds due to the fixtures/configuration of the room however we were advised of this prior to our arrival. Our view over looking the cherry blossoms and Tokyo Tower was very pretty both during the day and night and the location of the hotel in Ropongi was perfect for restaurants and fabulous street ambiance. The bathroom was a little “neat” and the shower was located over a very deep bath which may be quite difficult for some guests. The concierge staff, particularly Ymke Simonis was exceptional. Although exceptionally busy due to peak Spring Season, she was friendly and knowledgeable taking the time to understand our requirements whilst providing “local” knowledge. She did not simply provide us with the “standard” tourist excursions but offered some “quirky” alternatives, which was refreshing for a 5 star classic hotel. The restaurants were also exceptional understanding our sons allergy requirements and being extremely diligent and accommodating. We simply could not have asked for more.

Meets expectations as a 5-star hotel. But rooms are very expensive although it came with breakfast which is reasonably ok. Service is ok too but 'robotic', lacks personal touch. So, to me, it is just a comfortable place to stay in and leave when you are done with your business there. I will go back for my business trips though.

This luxury hotel is well priced and very well located near the Rippongi area of Tokyo, within easy walking distance of many things to see. The rooms are large and comfortable, and the in-house restaurants quite adequate although later in the evening it can be difficult to find something to eat--such as on arrival from the airport. The in-house breakfast in the lobby cafe is excellent. We would stay here again given the chance.

Perfect choice in Tokyo, right in center área, ellegant design and full of hightech-details and services. Room with great comfort and extra sise beds. Ammenities súper incluid y kymono and sandals...great experience. I definitelly recommend it.

I prefer to stay at nicer hotels when travelling for pleasure but I'm still interested in a great deal. I booked two rooms for five nights at this amazing hotel for my family of four including two teenage boys. The place looks and feels like a 5 star hotel but for whatever reason it costs about 30% less than similar hotels in the area. We signed up for the Club Lounge and the food and service were fantastic. They also have a really nice fitness center with state of the art equipment and a wonderful atmosphere. The Japanese quality of service was also first class. The hotel concierge staff booked restaurant reservations, arranged Disney Tickets, Sky Tree Tickets, Baseball tickets and provided daily assistance with suggestions, directions, train and taxi information. I felt like I had an entire team dedicated to making our vacation absolutely wonderful. The location was close to the trains and taxis are lined up and ready to take you anywhere at a moment's notice. There's also plenty to see within walking distance. If I ever return to Tokyo, for business or pleasure, this is where I will stay!

Stayed 5 nights recently with my 17 yr old grandson at this beautiful hotel. Perfect location. A short walk to Roppongi and lots of restaurants to chose from nearby. Hotel staff were exceptional in all ways, spoke good English and concierge most helpful. Hotel restaurant was excellent. My only gripe is paying extra for wi fi. In 5 cities throughout Japan this is the only hotel that charged for wi fi. Our room was clean and roomy. We will stay here again.

Spent 5 night in this hotel in April. Staff very helpful and rooms very comfortable and well maintained. The hotel is close to subway and a short train or taxi ride to shopping centres. Breakfast each morning, either western or Asian was very good with plenty of choices. Restaurants in hotel very expensive but also had plenty of little restaurants and coffee shops attached to hotel so really not a problem. This hotel is very large, about 800 rooms I think so you need to be mindful of which lifts you use otherwise you could be wandering around for a while trying to locate your room. It is close to lots of different restaurants as well, one of which was La Rochelle which was French inspired Japanese and absolutely wonderfull. All in all a good place to stay if you are wanting to check out Tokyo in general.

We enjoyed our three-night stay at the ANA Intercontinental Tokyo and were happy to have booked the nights as IHG Reward Nights.The positives:-excellent location with access to the metro just a short walk away (be sure to go to Roppongi-Itchome and NOT Roppongi which is a much longer walk).-stunning lobby and lounge area with live jazz music in the evenings-concierge was friendly and helpful, (even when we arrived with sopping wet luggage)-they were very accommodating about putting an extra bed in the room for our daughter (a bit of a tight squeeze and a $50 charge per night which I found a bit steep).The not-so-positives-the rooms are quite outdated with very old bathroom fixtures-cigarette burns on carpet (on non-smoking floor)-we had free wifi as IHG members however the wifi charges are a bit steep for others- they may want to consider free wifi (since the rest of the world seems to be moving in that direction-:)All in all, we were happy with our stay and would recommend to others, especially if plans are in place to refurbish the rooms to the InterCon standard.

Stayed six nights at this super well located and stylish hotel split into blocks of nights at the beginning and end of a fabulous holiday to Japan. Great location close to subway, the city and a medium walk to Rappongi, the exciting downtown nightlife area. Shops, culture, city and clubs plus main railway network all easy reach. Great facilities and very helpful staff. Large well appointed bed rooms with great citiscape views. Also limosine bus to and from airports. Amazing tepanyaki restaurant on 37th floor and lots of other bars and restaurants in house if you want. Outdoor pool. Spa. Room prices cheap by London standards. Very well worth using as holiday base - they will keep left luggage for you if you are returning, allowing backpack forays uncluttered by big bags. Fab fab experience. HHx

This hotel was in the perfect spot for my wife and I to use as a jumping off point to see Tokyo. Close enough to the subway for our day trips and and just down the street from the Roppongi for our nights out. Our room was very nice with very good views of the city. The bus to the airport conveniently departs from the hotel and took only about an hour for us to arrive.

Located directly between the up and coming Toranomon district and Akasaka, this hotel offers all mandatory services expected from a business hotel, accompanied by the - typically japanese - always smiling and friendly staff. Size of the rooms was acceptable for Tokyo-standards.Restaurants are all pricy, compared to those located outside, but offer high quality food.

The hotel's room are kinda old. The staff are friendly and helpful though.It is a nice place to stay when you want to roam in the heart of Tokyo because it is located near Roppongi. You should try their bar, the wine selections are good.

We arrived by the airport bus, which took about 1.5 hours from Narita (the return was 2 hours). Upon arrival the door staff took our bags, and we proceeded to check-in. The check-in experience is just okay as there can be a 30 minute wait, but once we got there it was very efficient. The room was comfortable, great bed, nice view. The bathroom was very good, but a bit small - there will be no brushing teeth at the same time with your partner. The Japanese toilet is always a pleasure. Toiletries were good, the Agraria IHG brand in our room.Room service was very quick, we ate several meals in the room and we felt the price/value equation was a bit off - even for a five star hotel we felt the food was expensive for what we got. The buffet breakfast is adequate, plenty of selection, and did not "wow" us.We enjoyed tea in the lobby, the coffee was very good. The patisserie in the lobby has a wonderful prawn sandwich.Fitness center was modern and well equipped.Housekeeping came later than we expected, but they did a good job. The staff are all efficient and friendly, we appreciated the extra steps the airport transfer desk took to ensure we were able to get a seat in the bus to the airport, even though it was fully booked. They found a cancellation for us, that was great.A very good hotel. Great choice for Tokyo. They can improve the breakfast buffet a bit, but that's about it.

The hotel offers several bars and restaurants, i bit pricey though, compared to other restaurants outside the hotel. But great service and most staff members speaks English fairly well. Nice room w view over Tokyo Tower, our room was on the 24th floor. Minibar with everything you might need. Great breakfast buffet with Western and Asian alternatives. Bring hotel business card w address info when going out, most taxi drivers don't understand English very well.

We stayed for 5 nights mid-April, initially on a club room executive (upgraded as being an Ambassador member) on the 28th floor but change to the 29th, 2 days after as the view wasn’t the one I requested (Tokyo tower).The room are relatively big, however they seem a lot smaller that we one we had previously at the Intercontinental Tokyo Bay. The reception staff at the 35th club floor was very attentive and managed all our requests, thank you very much.The foods and the drinks at the club were of good quality and selection; however the young staff needs guidance from more experienced personnel. They seem to be left on their own especially during the weekend, and unable to serve a limited number of guests.A good and well located hotel with plenty of restaurant options, especially the Pierre Gagnaire one ! A must in Tokyo.Thanks for the nice stay.

This is a large but stylish high-end hotel. Note that reception is on the second floor if you arrive on the ground floor. Room was tastefully decorated (see photos) and a good size. Good range of amenities in bathroom - and of course the ubiquitous high-tech toilet with heated seats. Good location: about a ten minute walk to Roponngi and it's large choice of bars and restos. Also about a 15 minute walk to the Imperial Palace. Close to Tammeikesanno and Roppongi Itchome metros and about a ten minute walk to Roppongi metro.MIXX bar on the 36th floor has great views of the city - although is expensive as you would expect - about 1000 yen for a small beer and 2000 yen for a cocktail. There is a 7-11 close by where you can withdraw cash with foreign cards. There is also an ATM and an exchange machine in the hotel lobby. Just a couple of negative points: the check-in was very slow even with the IHG priority check-in available and the Wifi connection in the room wasn't brilliant - it worked with some devices but not others. Apart from that a great hotel for a stay in Tokyo. I stayed here twice during my last trip and would definitely stay here again.

We booked a room with lounge access and were not disappointed! Lovely and extremely helpful staff in the lounge. Room was OK but need some renovations. The lounge was very relaxing in the evening after long days of sightseeing. Champagne, drinks, really good food and excellent views. The only negative was the breakfast egg menu. The presentations and finish on the dishes were terrible. Would expect something better from this hotel. But apart from that we had a wonderful stay. The hotels also offers a direct shuttle bus to the airport to an extra cost which was really convenient.

Travelers have too many top quality hotel options to count in Tokyo. The ANA should be among them. What should you expect?Service: Always attentive and professional. A helpful employee lurks around every corner. Concierge Services: A+ service here. Several different concierges helped us over email before we arrived. They found us great options and even noticed and corrected an overlap between restaurants that was very helpful. They did an outstanding job.Rooms: decent size. Clean. Well appointed. Noticed a little mold in the shower but nothing serious.Location: Very close to a large subway station with access to several main lines. Plenty of cabs at the front of the hotel too.Food: Enjoyed the large buffet breakfast. It’s not cheap, but if you want cheap what are you doing in Tokyo? Room service was very prompt. 30 minute promised delivery time showed up early on two occasions.This was my second visit to the ANA and it did not disappoint.

We stayed here for three nights in March. Check in went smoothly; the staff spoke English well. Our room was on the 38th floor with a good view of the city. We liked to pull our chairs over to the window and enjoy the lights. During our visit, the hotel was quiet at night. Our room was surprisingly large and the bed was quite comfortable. The hotel is far from Narita so travel from the airport was time consuming and expensive.Breakfast was the only meals we ate there and the food and service were good.

We have stayed here twice and it's been a high quality experience both times. All the basics are done well as expected for an IC, but the concierge service stands out here. Many thanks to Ymke Simonis who got hold of some difficult to obtain Kabuki theatre tickets for us at short notice, and without being asked provided us with some valuable background information on the performance.For a leisure trip to Japan we've found that a good concierge makes a huge difference, since if you can't read Japanese then trying to find, book or pay for things on the internet is a tortuous process.The hotel has clearly invested in good staff and we will definitely return here on our next stay.

My husband and I were there for a few days before a cruise and it was a good standard hotel with all the facilities one might expect. The location for holidaymakers was OK as it is near the metro but it is in a business area rather than near the main tourist sites. The public areas are very attractive with lots of space and nice features. The room was spacious and well equipped with a good view of the city centre, tea and coffee making facilities, good bathroom, and comfy beds. The staff were friendly, helpful, and polite. Buffet breakfast was excellent - huge number of choices for all nationalities from Japanese to western, and all well cooked and served hot. Evening meals in the restaurant in the lobby were quite expensive but very tasty.

The ANA is in a great location next to a subway line. Besides the hotel restaurants (which we did not try) there is a 7-11 nearby and a Starbucks. The MIXX bar on the 36th floor is really nice with sweeping views of the city. We stayed in a Premium Room which was quite roomy - large California King bed and huge bathroom with a tub and a shower.It seemed like most of the cab drivers also understood and recognized the ANA Intercontinental - which definitely helps in Tokyo.

ANA Intercontinental is everything you would expect from a large high-end, business hotel. It is well decorated. The staff is excellent and very accommodating with special requests. All of the lobby staff spoke very good English. The concierge was extraordinarily patient with non-Japanese-speaking guests asking really basic or occasionally stupid questions (that's us!)The time of year (Feb/Mar) precluded trying the pool. The exercise room was very modern, with a nice array of equipment, but for the size of the hotel, it was not that large and in the pre-work/after-work hours it was frequently full up!There is a Members Lounge for IHG members, but is limited to Platinum level and pretty zealously restricted. Nice place, though, based on my one visit. The hotel is in what is basically the Embassy district. It is also located very near a subway line, which gives access to all of Tokyo. It was also a pretty easy walk to the Rappongi district with its infinite variety of restaurants. The restaurants in the hotel are very nice, but Very High End (read $$$$) and there are relatively inexpensive (it IS Tokyo after all) alternatives next door at the Ark Hills shopping plaza. Oh, and there is a coin operated laundry just across the street if you are on an extended stay and don't want to pay big money to wash your underwear!I would not hesitate for a moment to recommend it to a friend or stay there again.

I have been staying in Ana Intercontinental Hotel a few days and unfortunately I've asked them in the evening for a wake up call at 7:30 am because i have a flight to catch at 12 am , they wrote it down and they made me the wake up call at 13:00 to let me know that i was supposed to leave the hotel at 12 am !!!!!! so i lost my flight and had to buy another one . But what really surprised me its when i said to them i need a solution for their mistake they said no sir sorry . so this hotel for me and the staff its poor and not respectful .

Metro station really closed, there is a mall with restaurants and shops very convenient, meals are not expensive at near restaurants. the upgrade to executive lounge was the best, breakfast was spectacular, and also snacks and drinks at the afternoon, definitive we will come back.For us sharing a room with the kids (2) was good.Cafeteria at the lobby, huge and food it's not as good as hotel services

This location is near the government sector of Tokyo and right off the subway line. I do have to give the staff credit for accommodating me for 1 night during my stay that I couldn't book prior to arrival due to the Cherry Blossoms festivals. I stayed a total of 11 nights. Check-in was easy and nice for Rewards members. Lobby really small for hotel size with virtually no seating. Long lines for buffet restaurant. The Mixx bar made for a nice view from 36th floor. Concierge was superb and got me everything I needed. I do feel the housekeeping was lacking in only doing minimal cleaning. Not the service I've come to expect from IHG hotels. Many restaurant choices nearby. There is also a Shinto shrine near for visiting.

Stayed with my wife who was on business. Great location to explore Tokyo as metro is only a few metres walk form the hotel. Staff on concierge were helpful with my queries as I had never been to Japan before. The bars are great, staff friendly and attentive. Drinks aren't cheap but they do have an happy hour. The bar on the upper floors is very cool & trendy and offers great views and good service. Also close to Roppongi so the nightlife is just a short walk away

Nice staff but not a 2015 service hotel. Lined up to get breakfast but took too long and eventually went to starbucks next door. Plenty of empty tables and seats beside the dining area but told ' this is a separate coffee area '. Bar on L36 completely smoking - come on this is 2015 and smoking in bars is offensive, i had part of one drink and left. Tried to book a meeting room for a conference call but nobody manning the business centre

I have stayed at the ANA several times in the recent past. Today, April 5, 2015 I am here again, for 6 days. Twice I was upgraded to the KING JUNIOR SUITE (very nice room). This time they charge me for a deluxe room and "upgrade" me to a "premier" room but there is actually NO upgrade. Previous to my arrival I confirmed my upgrade to Jr. Suite BUT I did not take the man's name to whom I spoke. WOW - this is a HUGE let down and disappointment and I would go so far as to say it is false advertising. I am AMBASSADOR Gold (I paid $200 for it) level and I paid for upgrade... I do not consider a bottle of water, turn down service, espresso machine, and shoe shine service and upgrade. I want a better room. When I stay in the IC in Ho Chi Min City, Frankfurt, Tele Aviv, Bangkok, and others I always have a NICE room upgrade . . . I love Tokyo and I love Japan . . . Come on InterContinental you can do it. This is one of the greatest cities in the world.

Being an Intercon platinum member I generally do first look to stay at an Intercon if possible, so be lucky enough to have stayed at many (business and pleasure) across many cities this one in Tokyo is not one I would call memorable.Staff: Faultless and incredibly welcoming and friendly along with all staff I came across had good English speaking skills.Rooms: Very comfortable, clean and well appointed but nothing special as such and TV's certainly need updating considering you are in one of the tech capitals of the world.Food: The buffet breakfast needs serious attention and is letting the hotel down. One of the joys (at least for myself) coming to Asia is the food experience, and I am not sure why so many Asian hotels feel their buffet breakfasts need to be aimed at an American/western expectation!First of all, their western style buffet breakfast is the same as everywhere, ie hash browns (never hot here and never crispy) bacon (just not great) scrambled eggs (uneatable and not hardly resembling or tasting like good scrambled eggs) and so on and so on....Venture down the buffet line to the end and you find a very small section of Asia breakfast items including dumplings which were sensational, and every time they filled the steamer up with say 20, they were gone in 1-2mins.... Surly that should tell the management something!*Whilst the terrible eggs and hash browns sit for 30 mins...I did dine in the Chinese restaurant (Karin) for a lunch and I must say it was exceptional in service but quality and taste of food and reminded me of quality Chinese food you get in Hong Kong.Some major attention to the buffets, and some minor attention to the rooms this could be a great hotel.I am not sure for my next trip to Tokyo will be at this hotel.

When I walked in to the check in counter, the impression was good. I booked and paid in advance for my room through internet. When I checked in, the lady asked me to pay more because I requested extra bed. I explained that I already specified clearly when I booked, and I even sent emails to hotel to confirm, however I got no reply. This was unfair if I was told to pay any additional charge when I checked in because I got no choice. They finally agreed to give me free extra bed and free extra breakfast. The room was old and small (probably with the extra bed). This is absolutely not the same quality of other InterContinental hotels in Osaka or other part of the world. Therefore, do not expect the same InterContinental quality here. The bathroom is small and old, just like other old Japanese hotels where you need to pay around 50% or 60% of the price. I was very unhappy with the rooms, therefore I probably will not stay in this hotel in the next visit to Tokyo. Breakfast is okay but not good. Breads are cold, choices are limited, there does not even have a egg-corner where you can get freshly prepared eggs. What made me feel bad is that when I checked out, the counter asked to pay for extra breakfast again. I was really unhappy because it proved to me that there was no communication within the front desk staff.

This is a very large hotel. The entrance and ground floor are rather gloomy ( We were told a complete makeover is due , more light is needed and less wooden panelling )Reception was "hit and miss " with on occasions six people waiting to check in and out with two staff dealing with clients. Russell Shepherd came to our rescue on several occasion and was excellent.Bedrooms are dull and old fashioned. An enormous all singing and dancing loo takes up 30% of the bathroom space ! There was no shower in our bathroom.The breakfast buffet was excellent, the Steakhouse less so, the lamb chops first came very under done and when asked for a further minute under the grill they returned burnt ! If we had not been so tired they would have been returned.The Chinese dining room was very busy and the food good.At the Concierge desk sits a most excellent person, Ymke Simonis. She takes her time to explain everything you need to know and is most helpful with suggestions for restaurants, help with the Metro.....nothing is too much trouble. Ymke really is a "star"

I love visiting Asia because of the luxurious feeling that international hotel chains achieve. The ANA Intercontinental is an example: From an inmaculate and comfortable room, to an outstanding breakfast, piano music every evening... True luxury.

Stayed here on two occasions, once alone on business and on another occasion with my wife for 3 nights. When checking in with my wife, they upgraded our room, which was delightful.The hotel is large and very nicely run/ managed. The staff is polite and efficient and our stay was very comfortable.
