The metro station is very close to the hotel and taxis were never a challenge. The hotel has several restaurants (7 I think) including a Michelin star restaurant. We had the Sunday buffet lunch at the Italian restaurant, which was first rate. I also had dinner at the Tippenyaki restaurant which was brilliant, although expensive. The hotel is walking distance from a host of restaurants and nightlife.The Narita bus has a stop at the hotel, which is super convenient.Excellent hotel for business or leisure stay,

Given the overwhelming positive reviews by others, my room may have been the exception. It was not ready when I checked in at 4pm so I had to kill an hour or so after a long flight from SF and car ride from Narita. When I finally went to the room it smelled moldy and wet, as if the carpet had just been cleaned or the shower had been left on. Anyway I couldn't wait to leave in the morning. The breakfast buffet, however, was quite extensive and good, so not all was lost.

This is where I stay in Tokyo if possible. It is right on the subway line and close to the Roppongi area. Great restaurants and bar. Good size rooms and very accommodating staff. They also have a bus that will take you to Narita airport

One of the best hotels I've ever stayed in.Great and friendly customer service, the staff are polite and helpful. Hotel lobby is beautiful and location is superb! Ideal for business or pleasure stays. Love the room they give me as they always go out of their way to upgrade me to a suite when I visit. Recent stay was in a suite and the room is comfortable, very spacious and I love the toiletries they prove from LÓccitane. Would highly recommend, there are bars and restaurants in and nearby the hotel area.

The ANA Intercontinental lobby is impressive with its many bars, restaurants and streaming waterfalls. The staff is polite and efficient. The room size is what one should expect from a standard room in Tokyo, not too small but certainly large enough for a 3 day - week stay.Of the many choices to dine within the hotel we found the sushi restaurant to be quite good. There is also a bar on the 36th (?) floor that provides a nice view. A short walk will take you to other restaurants and we walked fairly late at night and felt safe.While this hotel franchise usually services business travelers we were touring on vacation and found that the hotel met all our needs.

I was very pleased with my stay at this hotel (even if they had only smoking rooms available while I booked a non-smoking one...). It is located in a very good area of Tokyo (close to both Akasaka and Roppongi) and very well connected (the metro is right in front of the hotel). The hotel itself is modern, efficient and with very good services (I had a stunning view on the sunset on Tokyo from my room). Rooms are bigger than Japanese standards, the staff is very kind and useful. I will come back for sure when in Tokyo.

Lots of other options in this price range. This is a business hotel,adequate for an anonymous overnight stay .Could be anywhere. Service is poor, and english-language skills of staff are basic. They seem programmed/robotic, rather than listening to guests. Though my reservation was for 1 adult and a teenager, the front desk insisted the room was booked for 1 person, even though my 6' tall teen was standing next to me. No flexibility to offer two twin beds instead of a king bed. Insisted that a child should not get a separate bed. And insisted I was upgraded, even though I had booked a suite as an ambassador platinum member of their frequent guest loyalty program. Rooms are functional, but not luxury. Won't be back.

Excellent hotel and wonderful service. I would definitely stay here again. I'm a Platinum IHG member and therefore received a wonderful upgraded room in a very quiet area. The service at this hotel was excellent!We were able to buy stamps and get maps and directions from the concierge and it was excellent to have English speaking staff available to help.Yuji Koike, the Chief Bell Service was notable as a great staff member. He really helped me a lot and he always had a big smile on this face! Thanks Yuji!!!!

I had 5 nights in Tokyo and stayed in this great hotel with some friends of mine. The hotel had a very friendly staff and several good restaurants. The room was clean and got what you would expect from a hotel in this price range. The breakfast buffet was very good and the lounge area in the hall where cozy. The skybar has a good view of the city at night and the prices are resonable for a place like this. I would like to stay here again someday.

ANA Intercontinental is a great place to stay in Tokio. You have confort and a 5 star hotel Close to Ropongi and a lot of interresting places. Nice view from rooms and everything you need in a hotel! Confort, very good food, security and the best smiles! Don´t forget to go upstairs!! and look the great view of Tokio they have! I would return to ANA Hotel!!
user_name:
jorge b
Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic

review_body: My fiancee and I stayed at this property for our one week vacation to Tokyo.As an IHG Platinum member we got a room higher up in the building, however we were not granted an upgrade to a higher room category.The hotel lobby area is huge and very stylish. Our room was nice enough, albeit a bit small - which is not too uncommon in Tokyo. Everything was nice and clean, and the sound proofing was excellent with no noise to be heard from neighbours or from outside of the hotel.We had sushi at one of the hotel's restaurant and the food was quite simply excellent.We also tried the breakfast buffet a couple of mornings however found the members of staff / waiters to be too busy and not overly attentive, hence ended up waiting quite a bit before we e.g. would get more coffee.The area around the hotel is nice enough, with the nearest underground station just 150-200 meters away.In terms of value for money I would however most likely not stay at this hotel again (we paid approx. 130.000 JPY for five nights).

We visited japan last year and stayed at this hotel. We were given a smaller room on arrival however on reporting to the staff they rectified the mistake and we were given a lovely room with good view. very friendly/ helpful staff. Very good location too. Few mins walk from the subway. I would recommend this hotel to anyone.

I stayed at this hotel twice for a total of 6 weeks, and it never got old. I stayed on the 23rd and 28th floors. The room on the 28th floor was an upgrade, but was slightly smaller than than the regular floor. On the other hand, it did have a larger safe and a heated toilet seat! Both rooms were very nicely appointed with comfortable beds and decent but small bathrooms and good sized closets and dresser drawers. The gym is one of the better hotel gyms I have seen -- lots of space and lots of aerobic machines, although most of the weight machines are geared towards the upper body.The staff is excellent -- everyone I encountered was friendly and warm. I didn't eat in any of the restaurants at the hotel. There is a coffee shop -- Doutor -- next to the hotel (and a Starbucks as well) suffices for breakfast. The hotel is located just next to Ark Hills, which has a grocery store and lots of restaurants that serve meals at decent prices.The hotel was perfectly located for me -- it was close to my work and right next to the Tameike-Sanno Metro station, which made visiting all the tourist attractions quite easy. The small side streets around the hotel are lined with cherry trees which in bloom are quite lovely.

A very good hotel, the rooms were a good size with a king size bed with quality bedding, spacious bathroom. Panoramic views from large windows on 32nd floor . The staff were very helpful and extremely courteous .All the staff spoke English. Not as cheap as some hotels but you get what you pay for. Very close to metro

This is a nice hotel. It is not a five star hotel. Four star is fair. As usual in Tokyo, the management is made up of Australians and the workers are Japanese. Upper Management is very nice, as usual. Workers and middle management seem to nearly all have the "Tokyo attitude" that is short, less than friendly, somewhat lazy as they will not go out of their way to help and will tell a lie to get out of something they did do wrong. On this occasion the phone reservationist told me that the limo bus from Narita airport was to be free for our visit when we spoke over the phone the nite before. When we try to get this service at Narita, everyone tells us there is a 3,000¥ per person charge. I call the hotel and argue with them. I finally get a middle manager, that seems to be Serbian, and she tries to talk over me the entire conversation. The woman that told me the lie on the phone the nite before now denies she ever said free limo bus. (Apparently afraid for her job) The Serbian woman is excessively rude. I advised her I will speak to the hotel manager upon arrival. (This is all going on while the two rooms we have are going to cost me over $1,000 USD). We take the bus and pay the 3,000¥ per person for three adults and two children. A manager, Mr Shepherd, greets us as we get off the bus. Extremely nice young man. He personal checks us in an gives me a $30 price break for my problems. I just spent five times that for the smelly bus we just rode that was told to me was to be free, and, I am spending over $1,000 for two basic rooms at his hotel. Nice jester, but, not much of an offer. I needed assistance with an ANA flight change also. He said for me to come back down, after settling into our rooms, and the ANA staff will do this for me. I do, and he does. The young lady is totally full of herself and the "Tokyo attitude". She actually just dials the ANA flight agent and just gives me the phone. She said she does not do this for customers. I take care of the arrangements with the flights as the girl does nothing. During all of this going on, another lady comes over to tell me my wife is on the phone. It seems my Okaasan has locked herself out of the room. I am on the phone with ANA flight still. I tell the young staff lady what has happened and that Okaasan is 81 years old. She said to me "she can just wait outside at the door for me, can't she." I said NO. I ask that she get someone to go let her in. She reluctantly did go to another counter to ask someone to let her in. This is a nice looking hotel. Clean for the most part. (Although there is mold in the bathroom). It is WAY TOO EXPENSIVE for what it is and for what they give in "service". St Regis in Osaka totally leaves this ANA property in the dirt when it comes to, well, EVERYTHING. We hope to not have to come back here again.

Big rooms, extremely polite and helpful staff, located right downtown, steps from subway, near restaurants and pubs, there's not a lot wrong with this place. Best if you're traveling on business as it's not cheap. Breakfast buffet is fun and worth every penny.

Being next to Suntory hall, this is a brilliant location if you are on tour and have a concert there. The breakfast range is fantastic, catering for everything - don't miss the fresh health boost drinks by the orange juices, a different one each day! Lovely little coffee shop in arcade too if you need a caffeine and pastry fix.

A very nice business hotel, locating in the center of the City. The room sizes are good with Tokyo standards. Close to Rappongi area but also in close drive to other major Business locations. The breakfast is very rich and lots of varities. Concierge is also very good help. The bar at the very top is avergae.The hotel is highly recomended.

Great hotel for business visit as it well located and the staff very helpful, along with good facilities. Only niggle was the stuffy and warm air temperature within the hotel. At one point we decamped from their lounge to the local Starbucks to get better quality air.

ANA Intercontinental at first glance appears to be what it is - a huge typical business chain hotel. We stayed there for 4 nights in February. Our room was decent sized and though didn't appear recently renovated, was quite good. Housekeeping did a good job everyday and we had absolutely no complaints. The hotel is very well located with easy access to the Tameiki-sanno metro station giving access to 4 subway lines. Tokyo is a huge city and attractions flung across in all directions - having a hotel as well located as this was a blessing. There are many restaurants in the hotel - we tried the sushi one and it was quite good. The bar on the 36th floor has a great view of the city - you can even see Mt. Fuji from there! The staff was smiling and eager to help. It's worth appreciating that even though it's a chain hotel, the staff is mindful of Japanese courtesies and mannerisms. The Ark Hills complex adjoining the hotel was a little added boon - though really not much of a choice of great food there. Recommended for a stay in Tokyo.

We stayed here for a week while on vacation. The lobby area is quite grand, and the staff were all phenomenal! Incredibly great service at this hotel! There are some cute shops within the hotel, and a nice bakery. The rooms were a little small but larger than other hotels we've stayed at in foreign countries. The rooms were clean, and the bed was comfortable. The water temperature and pressure were fantastic. I only have 2 gripes about this hotel...1) There's only a very tiny open lounge area for guests to sit in the main lobby area. You can go down a level for a few more seats, but, when meeting tour guides near the concierge desk or meeting friends for the day's outing, it'd be great to have more open seating on the main lobby area. There's a huge sitting area at the Atrium Cafe, but you have to order something in order to sit there. (The soft drinks were around 900 yen! Crazy when you could get one from a little shop inside the hotel for 190 yen!) 2) Yes, the hotel is located near a subway ENTRANCE, but you still have to walk quite a ways to get to the actual subway LINE. I only mention this because, from reading others posts, I was under the assumption that the line itself was very close. With that said, access to the Ginza line was great because we managed to stay mostly on that line for most places!All in all, we'd definitely stay here again, and I'd recommend it to others.

Stopped here for two nights, in the business district of Tokyo.Hotel clean but the rooms were looking very dated and tired.Staff expedient if not overly friendly.All the restaurants in this hotel are obscenely overpriced and a meal at another restaurant walking can be had for for quarter to a fifth of the cost here.Ok but instantly forgettable stay.

My husband and I went to Japan to celebrate my birthday this March. As an Ambassador member we decided to start our Tokyo trip by staying at the ANA Intercon. Initially we were given an older Junior Suite, and after calling the Club Lounge lady, she moved us to a much newer (and nicer) Junior Suite. Our room was a nice size for Tokyo and had the best shower! Breakfast and evening cocktails were always lovely at the Club Lounge and the Club manager was always very helpful sorting out our itineraries, dinner reservations, even luggage shipping to our next destination. Overall a highly recommend this hotel.

This is a very good business hotel, nice quality, modern rooms and particularly comfortable beds. Very pleasant to stay in if a single female business traveller. Be warned that the restaurants close quite early (as do all the local restaurants in the vicinity). My one criticism is that you could be absolutely anywhere (not even in Japan), and there is no much in the local area if you want to walk out and explore on foot. Great bathrooms and internet speed. Slightly odd room service menus. I would not stay if not on business as very staid / no atmosphere in the bar etc. I recommend getting the airport shuttle bus (it is the first stop on the way from the airport) and much cheaper than a taxi, and easy to catch the shuttle back. My criticisms: (1) it took for ever to check in/out (and I am a platinum elite customer, so theoretically get priority, but it still took 20 mins in both directions). (2) I have been twice and both times had to wait until late afternoon to check in, with no internet access/changing facilities for several hours, which is hard when you have flown in overnight.

I stayed two times already in Ana Intercontinental and I have to say it is a really nice hotel. The room is spacious and the bed really cozy. The toilet has a bath-shower and it is always bery clean. Theroom service is good, but the portions are really small. The breakfast buffet is really good, with a lot of options from fresh fruits to different egg styles, however, I find it a little pricey. As I stay for 24 hrs in Tokyo every time I go, it is really convenient staying at this hotel since it is very close to some of the remarkable areas of the city: Roppongi for restaurants, Shibuya for fancy shoping, the famous Tokyo tower is also very near. Moreover, the metro station is only 2 min walking from the hotel: really next door! All in all, I had a great experience staying at this hotel and I'm very glad my co pany allocates me on this convenient hotel where the staff is always corteous and helpful.

Parts of my stay here were good. The rooms were spacious for Japan. Despite having an advanced booking, the check-in process was long winded.Reception staff seemed welcoming but the rest of staff (apart from one smiley guy at the Breakfast bar) seemed disinterested. Perhaps smiling is not encouraged. Eating and drinking in the Hotel was outrageously expensive. What's that about? Do they want you to drink and eat elsewhere?Disappointingly most, was that I asked for new pillows as the ones in room were too thin ( hurting my neck). I asked for some others. You would think in a hotel of this quality that it would be an easy request to satisfy. I am still waiting.Advantage: close to the sky train and quiet air con

Good hotel with very good location, close to the activities in Roppongi. Very good overall facilities, excellent breakfast and good gym - one room that I stayed in was renovated and in very good condition, the other one (in a visit 2 weeks later) was already a little bit dated but ok.

Second visit. Very close to the metro and adequate rooms. I didn't eat at the hotel this time, so I can't comment. Room was alright ... a bit small and only twin beds were available. The bathroom was "tired" and somewhat dated, especially in comparison to a recent visit to another Intercontinental property.

I have mixed feelings about my stay in the hotel. I liked this hotel, but didn't love it. Pros:-Excellent concierge and check-in staff. Very efficient breakfast area - the staff really know how to get you in and out quickly.-Attractive combination of bars and restaurants. The Mixx bar on the 36th floor has great views of the city. Kenzan, the sushi bar on the floor just above the lobby serves very fresh sushi (sit at the counter) and there is a steakhouse restaurant also in the hotel in case you don't like Japanese food (my work colleages did not).-All employees speak English well.Cons:-Wifi was not automatically working for me when I arrived in my room. I had to call for help three times and wait about an hour before I was told that I was 'registered'.-Part of that was due to the time of year of traveling - during or just after Chinese New Year and the hotel lobby and rooms were smoky. I also had a smoking room which wasn't my choice.
user_name:
DougJ25
New York City, New York

review_body: Extremely comfortable beds. Very nice rooms with sitting area and desk. Several lounges and restaurants from which to choose. Fast, free wi-fi. When you book the hotel, book it with the free breakfast option, as it will save you a lot of money. The staff is very polite and helpful, and they speak English well. Nice location.

I've stayed here at least three times. It's always the same. Very good service and everyone speaks English. Safe, clean and tidy. But a little stuffy, IMO. The restaurants are super expensive, especially the breakfast buffet.

We stayed here for a week, and we where more than pleased. The service is amazing, and anything you need they will make sure you have. The rooms are fairly big, and the location is perfect, as it is next to a subway station with four different lines. The only negative is that you have to pay 1680 yen a day for wifi! But otherwise it is a great hotel.

I stay in many hotels and forget most of them fairly quickly. Only the ones that are exceptional or terrible, I remember. In this sense the ANA Intercontinental is forgettable. The hotel is nice and does nothing particularly bad or particularly well. POSITIVE: rooms are large (for Japan). Internet speed was excellentNEGATIVE: breakfast buffet was tasteless. Pancakes that were pre-prepared, then reheated, and then sat around under a heat lamp. Poor fruit selection, etc. The staff seemed not well trained for a hotel that aspires to luxury. My table at the buffet was cleared while I got up to get more coffee and fruit. There were lots of these very small inconveniences.If you don't care about exceptional service, you may actually like this hotel. It is clean, rooms are large, and overall fairly efficient.

Personnel was extremely helpful and polite (as most Japanese!) as soon as we arrived we got upgraded to a better room on floor 25th with a great view and access to the Club Lounge for breakfast (best quality ever!!!!) and nibbles/snacks/cocktails until 5pm...(which actually filled us leaving us with no space for dinner!)Location is very convenient as it is in Minato Ku, a more business area, but close to the underground and some good restaurants. Very easy to go everywhere.There are also very good restaurants in the same building on different floors. We tried Pierre Gagnaire’s Restaurant on 36 floor that award 2 michelin stars. Will come back for sure!

just want to comment their front desk staff, Ms Kyoko Sowa for being so professional. in explaining to me how to get to Haneda.A good staff for sure, five star services.will recommend to friends to stay if visiting Tokyo.

I've been contemplating the merits of my IHG Platinum Elite Status for a while now. My experience today was the straw that broke the camel's back. My red-eye international flight touched down in Tokyo early in the morning. Exhausted, I made it to the hotel by around 8am. The lady at the counter greeted me with the mechanical "thank you for your loyalty" before proceeding to inform me that though the hotel wasn't full and that I could not get a room till 10am. "Policy". Doesn't platinum elite status allow for late check-outs up till 4pm? Yes. Instead of a late check-out at the end of the week, I'll check out 5 hours early, so can you let me check in 4 hours earlier? No, sorry.When a traveller is tired and is just looked for a little flexibility and compassion, something ostensibly trivial and petty very quickly destroys all the positive experiences built up over time. Sorry IHG, but you had your chance. Time for me to move on.

Spent a handful of nights at the ANA in early january of this year. Great hotel - the staff was very hospitable and I don't have a single bad thing to say about the service. Bars and restaurants were also great. No free wifi. Close to Tameike-sanno subway station (two minutes) however I found other hotels on my trip to be more conveniently located especially for going out late.

Probably one of the best hotels i have ever stayed. Great location, amazing service, loads of food options, the staff is very caring and rooms are wide and comfortable. Expensive, so normally business people stay in it. So if money is not an issue foe your trip this is definitely a good option. Ah, enjoy the breakfast or have a drink in the last floor with the view to Tokyo. Just amazing. The hotel is as great as the country and its people.

Perhaps it is due to the proximity to so many embassies but this hotel is bland. It isn't even really luxurious and there is no sense that you are in Tokyo or Japan. The service was standard except the bellman who were funny and very nice especially Yuji was great! The junior suite was nicely set up for working but didn't have any interesting touches. Bed and shower were fine, nothing exceptional. The douter coffee shop is right around the corner and much tastier (and more reasonably priced) for breakfast. It is also right next to the metro stop.

actually it's located conveniently to government offices and embassies. A good location in central Tokyo using cab, but a bit inconvenient for public transportation though metro "tameike sannou" station is close.A very nice accommodation. Service is great. Breakfast Buffet at the lobby restaurant is very good. Actually the buffet was often very crowded: we were turned down one lunch time,

Recently spent two nights at this hotel on business. I used the orange limo bus to and from Narita with ease. Clean and decent size rooms. The gym was a highlight. If you do use the gym, try the shower and sauna in the men's changing room. Five minute walk to subway. Starbucks two minute walk from ground floor entrance. Lots of places to eat near by as well.

I visited ANA Intercontinental hotel for business trip. It was just 10-min walk away from Roppongi Hills. Internet speed was fair enough and breakfast buffet was so nice. Room was neat, hotel staffs were kind, so we could stay convenient at here.However, transportation to HND was not satisfied. I heard there was only one airport bus per day. Alternative transportation? Tokyo taxi is well known for its expensive fair, and it was hard to take subway with luggage. I think accessibility to HND should be improved.

our stay here was for three days in sept 2014. its a beautiful lobby and extremely helpful staff. we had forgotten a cellphone in the cab that got us to the hotel and the hotel staff arranged everything and we had the phone back in 30min. The lobby is amazing! the rooms are big for tokyo standards but the bathrooms are dated.

This is the second time I have stayed in this hotel over a week. It is a well run and well located corporate hotel which has many restaurants and bars as well as a very efficient concierge service in the hotel. Rooms are decent sized and well serviced the staff is professional and helpful altough some of them are leaving the impression that it is best to avoid them. At this occasion, I have the sense that some cost cutting measures are put into the effect particularly at the restaurants. Moreover, for some funny reasons the staff changing the location of coffee machines very often and which is annoying. One should also keep in mind that this is a popular and busy hotel and that it can be annoying at certain hours. The free internet service provided and is very efficient. The breakfast is also good. Overall, it is good value and is highly recommended. I will not be hesitating booking this hotel again.

I have always been a fan of the Intercontinental Hotel Group product, which is why I subscribed to their Ambassador program. My recent stay at ANA Intercontinental is a testament of why exactly IHG is such a good brand and why I continue to frequent their business.This past New Year holiday my family traveled to Tokyo and decided to stay with ANA Intercontinental. We were a group of ten, which also included my grandmother who needs the use of a wheelchair to travel long distances. Even before we stepped in the hotel I experienced stellar service from their reservations group through Goro Takechi. Imagine the difficulty of booking multiple rooms of the same class on the same floor at the most competitive pricing during the peak New Year holiday. Goro and his reservation team helped make it possible for me to book the best-priced package that would accommodate our group.We once again enjoyed the fantastic service of the hotel upon checking-in when one of our rooms, not covered by the Ambassador membership, was upgraded. This was definitely a welcome surprise after a lengthy flight. Plus, my handicapped grandmother appreciated the gesture for our family. Thank you, So Hyun Park! It was the start of an amazing stay!Although this was not our first time in Tokyo, it was however our first time in Tokyo during the New Year. Unlike our home country or some western nations wherein New Year's is very lively, it was a very different type of celebration in Tokyo. There were no fireworks and a lot of restaurants close during this period. It was definitely interesting and a fun time to bond with the family. I credit the concierge team for enlightening us on these traditions. Ymke Simonis and Ai Mayanagi were amazing at assisting my family with restaurant reservations and logistical arrangements. Arranging meals for big groups in Tokyo can be a bit of a task, and doing this short noticed was an even greater achievement. We were able to rely on the concierge team for restaurant suggestions, as well as book places that we researched on our own. The restaurants in the hotel are quite note worthy, but in case you are on a tighter budget the general area of the hotel has a good array of choices. The hotel is also a short distance from Roppongi (Roppongi Hills and Tokyo Midtown) and the subway station is very ideally located. Coming from Haneda you can either take the monorail or a taxi and it takes less than 30 minutes to and from the hotel. So in addition to impeccable service, the hotel is also very convenient and centrally located. I highly suggest this hotel to first-time visitors to Tokyo or any visitor who wants a hassle-free experience. My family has already expressed returning to Tokyo for this year's Christmas-New Year holiday because of the perfect experience and the fond memories from this recent trip.

I stayed at the ANA Intercontinental for a little more than 2 weeks.My room was a Deluxe-Room on the 28th floor with a breathteaking view to tokyo tower.I can only say best about the ANA, it is a very high class Hotel and the staff is always very friendly, professional and helpfull.I enjoyed my stay and recommend the ANA to everyone who wants to spend a relaxing time in an amazing environment in a busy city like Tokyo.

Stayed 4 days fro business trip and I must say I have really nothing bad to say about this hotel. Well trained and very polite staff (we are in Japan!), even when the hotel was rather crowdy during the busy morning hours or evening hours, everything seemed to be under control.Room size was average with a nice big shower, bath tub (of course we are in Japan!) with a small tv set and all the comforts you need, included a beautiful Kimono. I really don't understand why WIFI isnt' free of charge. Will definitely not complain about the breakfast buffet that really is "à la hauteur": Asian, American,Japanese, Continental...you name it! There are plenty of restaruants on the different floors of the hotel including a spectacular teppanyaki on the 37th floor - famous french chef Pierre Gagnaire has a restaurant and a beautifull patisserie too - plenty of shops too! Gym room is complete and well equipped. Conveniently located just next to the metro station (tameike sanno) or at 10 minutes from very busy Roppongi.Will definitely be back!

We enjoyed our stay here. Beds were nice and we were lucky enough to get a view. Suite room we stayed in lacked the usual finish you expect for a intercontinental hotel. Layout was awkward and was a bit of a let down. Buffet breakfast was quite nice. Good selection of food. Albeit a little cold. Staff were helpful and assisted as much as they could. All in all an above average hotel but you expect that for the price

The ANA Hotel has been a classic landmark for the Minato-Ku/Ropponggi area for a long time. The building offers great views of the city in almost every direction thanks to it's three-pointed star shape and tall structure. Any room above the 22nd floor is going to offer a treat for any newcomer to Tokyo. Upwards of the 30th floor the views become spectacular.However, the hotel is an older structure and some of its limitations become tangible only when staying for more than a couple of nights. Rooms are above average size for Tokyo, and customer service is impeccable, but bathroom size can be an issue in standard rooms (they are larger in superior rooms in the upper floors).The Concierge Lounge serves a discrete breakfast and has an open bar in the afternoon. The restaurants in the hotel are very good, but their prices are a bit high even for a 5 star hotel. The gym is very well equipped, and the pool and SPA facilities are very good.The area surrounding this hotel is known for the beautiful blossom of the cherry trees during april. The street nearby where the Spanish embassy is offers some of the best views in Tokyo.

Whilst the ANA Intercontinental offers large bedrooms and impeccable customer service, bathrooms are tiny and poorly equipped. Sound insulation is terrible with traffic noise being clearly audible despite the roads being more than 20 floors below. Breakfast offers a decent selection although the breakfast area is too small and far too busy. Average compared to other Intercontinental hotels.

Enjoyed my stay in the hotel as the rooms were spacious for a Tokyo hotel. Rooms were clean and my stay was comfortable. While it is within walking distance to the subway, it is a pretty long walk through the tunnel to get to the station. Nothing very outstanding about the hotel as it is pretty typical of a business hotel.

Very efficient and helpful staff right from the doormen, front office and concierge.F&B team not very switched on. Ordered room service once -chinese food no condiments provided, ordered a pork dish with literally 4 tiny pieces of pork for about 25 usd. Don't mind paying top dollar but at least let the portion size be normal. Weirdest of all was the position of the TV. If you want to lie in bed and watch TV forget it. The tv is placed on the edge of the TV beside the headrest. The rooms were well appointed with above average size for Tokyo.Would I repeat. Yes for the special price that I get.

I stayed at the ANA in December 2014 as tourist. Regarding the location, it´s central, but not in a hot-spot (if you´re into nightlife). Still great as starting point for doing the major sights of Tokyo. The room (executive) was nice/comfty and offered some good views of Tokyo, though nothing really special. On the other hand, the bathroom was small as hell. The gym is ok for doing standard workout. A big disappointment was the long line before breakfast. Before getting a single seat, I had to wait for 20 minutes, which I hadn´t experienced at InterContinental before… Summarized: If you are a tourist, it´s okay to stay there, if you get a good deal and want to do the major sights of Tokyo.

Initial impression was poor. My husband is a priority club member, so we bypassed the , huge, standard check in queue. An American member of staff immediately intercepted us. I did, possibly incorrectly, assume this was because we looked scruffy, having arrived in jeans and sweatshirts after a long train journey. The same chap was also slightly sarcastic when we were leaving. Other members of staff were great. Otherwise fantastic- great room. Beyond that one chap, I couldn't criticise this hotel. Great location near several subway stations. I would stay again.

The hotel is comfortable and clean, and well equipped. Service is very friendly, as in most places in Japan, and staff generally speak English, unlike many places in Japan. The hotel is right by a metro station where several lines cross and conveniently located within walking distance for visitors who have business in Kasumi gaseki, i.e. the government complex. However, there are other nicer hotels in that area some of which have more cachet without being more expensive (the Okura in particular).

This is a very elegant hotel with unsurpassed service and an ability to see every detail. Incredible pleasant and accommodating staff. We were very happy with the room and the lovely city view from a large window.

The ANA was a great place to stay in Tokyo - free huge buffet breakfast, free wifi, close to the subway - starbucks down the street. The room was a little tight so don't bring tons of luggage - but we had a great time and the concierge was great on email before we got there helping us book train tickets etc

This hotel is located in a very central area. It was our first trip to Japan so were a little apprehensive but the concierge of this hotel is very helpful and with them we were able to plan all our sightseeing. From the airport there is a direct limousine bus to the hotel. Five minutes away from the hotel are nice eateries,coffee shops, underground station and supermarket. Fifteen minutes by taxi is the Rippongi area which has very good restaurants serving authentic Japanese food, entertainment and pubs.All in all it was a pleasant stay.

Overall, the hotel offers excellent service and rooms. Check- in was smooth and easy. We were given room 3012, which looked more or less westward. If not for a building in the way, we would have had a view of Fujisan. Some of the rooms have this view so check with the desk before reserving as we understand that they can sometimes block a room with the Fujisan view. The elevator banks were partitioned into lower and upper floors. Despite being on the 30th floor, the elevator rarely made more than one extra stop, so it was quick to get up and down.Room 3012 was large and had two picture windows. The sitting area / desk could be partitioned from the bedroom by means of a large sliding door, so when I had a midnight conference call I did not have to disturb my wife. It also had an independent temperature control from the bedroom. There was a well- stocked minibar and complementary coffee from a Keurig machine. The bed was very comfortable and the linens, towels, etc. were all top- quality. The amenities selection in the bathroom was more extensive than in most hotels, and included soaps, shampoo, etc from L’Occ___ There were two sinks and a huge shower / bathtub room. The shower featured a spray wand, a vertical array of sprayers and an overhead “rain” fixture. The water temperature was controlled by one knob, and then the volume through the other fixtures via other knobs. The spray intensity could easily be set from gentle to take- off- the- rust. I really appreciated that this overhead rain fixture did not drip once it was shut off, not one drop. Others have plagued me with a cold drip- drip- drip.Breakfast was very good, with a wide variety from which to choose, and high quality throughout. The pastries were noteworthy. There was a variety of seating, with table, booths and table with chairs on one side and a curved bank seat on the other. The coffee was good, but on the third morning it was notably weaker – someone goofed up. At any rate, it was excellent overall.The hotel – although not cheap - is highly recommended.

Visited here as a family and stayed in two rooms on upper floors. The front desk staff were outstanding as were the concierge staff in securing reservations for us - top notch service. On our first ever visit to Tokyo, the location of this hotel was a bit of a puzzle - the entrance is near an elevated highway and the surrounding area seemed to be office buildings. The first night we went out for food and it seemed like a wasteland. As can happen, we had simply gone in the wrong direction - the neighborhoods within a couple blocks are rich exploring grounds and it is easy to get to and from the station for this hotel. A good exercise facility is available and the in-hotel restaurants are bustling, though we sis not eat at them.

While the location is not bad (not far from the business' area, on one side, and from shopping areas, close to an underground station and with direct limousine bus to Tokyo airports), it is an old hotel where some essentials are missing, considering that you are paying more than 220 euros/night for a small King room (I wonder what's the size of the standard room...).Wifi is available by free, but only if you are an IHG member.Yes, there is an outside swimming pool, but where outside temperature is below 5 degrees, it would be good to have also an in-door swimming pool.Breakfast at the business center located at the 35th floor is great, with an extensive choice of food and beverage. I missed, however, some international newspapers or magazines.

Older property, but excellent location and surprisingly affordable. I would definitely recommend this for location and cost, not one of the best hotels in tokyo, but service was excellent, room nice, bathroom dated, but clean. I would say overall, you get what you're paying for, but solid. Ate at buffets with my family of 4, 2 girls and they liked the selection.

Hotels in Tokyo can be expensive, it's a fact of life. But when I'm paying over £200/night I expect comp mineral water, free wifi, adequate supplies of tea/coffee, and milk to go with them. Not here!I booked here to get miles on my ANA card, but you don't get them - you have to join IHG scheme. Once you do that they give you free wifi. So here I am Lost in Translation style typing in the middle of the night and gasping for a coffee or a water.My King room wasn't that big either, and bathroom too small.

The ANA is not the pinnacle of high luxury, but it is exactly what it claims to be and more. I have never been let down by the InterContinental brand, of course, but this was a pretty special place even by their standards. It is very well designed, had several wonderful restaurants, and the rooms were extremely comfortable and amenity-packed. The view (of Tokyo Tower) was magnificent. The staff was friendly and helpful, and the overall service experience was top quality.I would absolutely stay here again, and I will always recommend the InterContinental brand!

I stayed at the ANA at the beginning of the week, left for Kyoto, then returned in the middle of the week. The first room I stayed in was a little outdated. However, the room was a decent size and was very quiet. The bed is a little harder than I'm used to but I couldn't sleep more than 2 hours in any event due to jet lag.Upon returning to the ANA, I specifically requested an upgrade. The second room was updated, bright, and was also very comfortable. Many amenities are provided in the bathroom. Room service dinner was very good. Service at the hotel is excellent. The staff try to remember your name and are very helpul with answering questions regarding directions, express bus and train travel. If you are an Intercontinental Group member, wifi is free and I believe you are able to check out late.The buffet breakfast offers a wide variety of western and Asian cuisine. Everything is delicious and freshly prepared. The cost is high (approximately $35 USD but a little less if you have a coporate account).Overall, this hotel provides a great value in an expensive city like Tokyo.

When booking this hotel I thought that it would be perfect but this stay was far from perfection. Walking in it looked great and booking into our rooms was easy however from the moment we exited the lift the first thing I noticed was an awful musty smell, when we arrived at our rooms we had a bigger shock in store unfortunately. The musty smell was even worse in the rooms, the carpet was dirty and had hair on it and the bathroom towels had yellow bits stuck on them, yep that was a shocker. My friend's room was not better as her bathroom smelt like a sewer. We showed them pictures of the mess and asked for the rooms to be cleaned and this was basically a guy spraying the air. I could go on forever but basically we spent over 4 hours waiting in reception for our rooms to be cleaned and after all of that plus losing our first day in Tokyo as we had to wait for our rooms to be changed we didn't get an apology needless to say this is one hotel I will avoid on my next trip.

We are just completing a 3 night stay here and would definitely choose to stay here again. Originally on check in in the evening there had been an issue with providing a large enough room (as booked) as there was a miscommunication from main reservations re the fact there would be 3 of us for the last 2 nights of our stay. Our son and his partner were also staying in another room at the hotel and this was a family trip for the 5 of us. As the hotel was full the first night they arranged that we would change rooms for the last 2 nights and very kindly provided an upgrade to a traditional japanese suite room at no extra cost. Our first room was okay for 2 people but our suite for the remainder 2 nights was beautiful and we would definitely think about booking one of these in the future although I know it owuld be quite a bit more expensive. We had a beautiful view of Mt Fuji. THe hotel staff were very polite, helpful and friendly. We also visited the Club floor one evening which we would definitely pay to take advantage of on future visits. Great value, excellent food and lovely cocktails. All in all the extra mile the hotel went for us has made our first vist in Tokyo extra special and we definitely hope to be back and stay at this same hotel. We also were prov ided with free internet and newspapers with our IHG Ambassador rewards program.

Stayed at this hotel over Christmas. Clean, modern, and renovated rooms. Superb value. Great location (close to Roppongi district). Airport bus stops at this hotel - very convenient.. Attentive staff. Would definitely stay there again

It's near my office, short coach ride from Haneda airport and footsteps away from underground station - extremely convenient. The ambience is good, as expected of Intercontinental hotel.The ladies at concierge desk speak excellent English.The hotel reception can be busy as it appeared to be used by a few airlines for their crew.

The Akasaka ANA Intercontinental is located in central Tokyo. It is reachable by limousine bus from both Narita and Haneda Airports. The hotel is within walking distance of Roppongi and Akasaka districts and within a cab ride to many places around Tokyo central. I typically stay at the hotel 3-4 days and do so around 4 times a year on business. I stay based on the location, the good view and modern clean amenities, the friendly staff and the breakfast buffet which is more than you’d expect. All make for a very comfortable visit.

Lovely hotel. Close to the Ginza line (1 minute walk). Hotel has everything you could ever want/ need. Buffet breakfast was beautiful and had something for everyone. Hotel gym was fantastic, fully equipped. Hotel room was lovely however I think I was expecting a little more for $4000. Few stains on the couches and the carpet was in need of a shampoo. There even was a little bit of mould growing in the shower. However our overall stay was fantastic and we would recommended this hotel.

I was there in the summer 2013.This Hotel is in a vibrant location in Tokyo.Tube station is minutes walking and one of the most beautiful concert Hall is minutes walking as well.The Hotel itself is extremely well managed with very nice bars and restaurants.

Classy and very high standard hotel ... but in Tokyo, where service is unbeatable and where high standards are the norm, you can probably get better value for $ in other almost any other hotel in Tokyo.Good point about this hotel is that its walking distance to the attractions. Its hard to find staff or service thats bad in Tokyo so nothing really stands out. Toilets are nice and have good fixings but again ... in Tokyo, I've yet to find a toilet that doesn't have an automated bidet and nice toiletries.

We stayed here for a long weekend and overall had a good experience. The hotel itself is very impressive in the public areas and is conveniently located. We were dressed casually for our entire stay as not there on business and I never had any of the service issues that other reviewers have mentioned. All interactions with the staff were good - I never felt that they were offering me lesser service than the business travelers. Check in and check out were very smooth, any time we called down to the front desk the staff were polite and helpful and room service was quick and friendly.Aside from ordering room service once we didn't eat in any of the restaurants but we did enjoy a happy hour at the champagne bar one night (impressive selection of champagnes) and every morning I got lattes and pastries from the little shop off the lobby - all of which was SO delicious. My favorite was the roll with bacon wrapped throughout, super tasty. I will go back here for breakfast on my next visit to Japan even if not staying at the ANA.There is a good size pool but I couldn't use it as was too cold out and the pool isn't heated, looks great for a summer visit though. The gym is spacious and has really nice, new equipment, definitely worth packing the gym clothes and working off the breakfast pastries...The only aspect of my stay that was just average was the room. To be fair, I was there on a corporate rate and had booked one of the most basic rooms so depending on the room you stay in the experience could be different. My room was a good size, especially for Tokyo, and was very clean. The bed was ok - all beds in Japan are too hard for me - and we couldn't hear any noise from the hall or outside so had no issues sleeping. It did seem like the room hadn't really been updated since the 80s but I wasn't bothered by that as overall it was in good condition. The two main drawbacks were the tv and the bathroom. The tv was a big flat-screen but was in an odd location on the left side of the bed in front of the window. So not only did it block out some of the light from the window, you couldn't really lay in bed or sit on the couch to watch it comfortably. Not a big deal as we didn't spend much time watching it anyway. The bathroom just felt really old - it was very small, had bad lighting and the shower wasn't great. Kind of feels like I stayed in a 4 star hotel with a bathroom you'd find in a 2 star motel. Other rooms may have more modern bathrooms though.Regardless, think this is a solid choice and would likely stay here again.

Great location in Tokyo. Extremely high class, modern and amazingly kind staff. Clean rooms with everything you may need. Highly recommend.Also connected to a mall and "food plaza" that serve delicious authentic Japanese cuisine.Amazingly wide range of breakfast with Western and Japanese style food. Highly recommend!!!Free internet if you're an IHG member. Join for free! Well worth it! www.ihg.com

I was a bit apprehensive when I read that the normal rooms were old and small. However, I am very pleased with my king junior suite room. ( am still staying here) It is wonderful! The layout is great with s separate living room, bedroom and I do love the bathroom so much! I like how the room is partitioned out giving lots of space to the guests. The bathroom is great with 2 wash basins, separate bidet room and a shower room with a bathtub( with tv) and a standing shower that has great shower pressure. The standing shower even offers water jet sprays for your back! Bed was comfortable and just right ( not too hard or soft). Location wise, some might say it's too far but I guess it's ok for me. The station ( tameike-sanno) is to the right of the hotel lobby ( abt 5 mins walk). It serves 4 main lines to everywhere including the popular ginza line. It's only 4 stops to ginza direct and I think it's great. Exit at 13 to the hotel at this station. I've booked and am going for a teppanyaki lunch at the hotel later which seems to get rave reviews. I hope I dun get disappointed later! All in all, I would prob stay at this hotel again ( but still would book a junior suite for my next stay).

Stayed at ANA Intercontinental twice so far, as it is very close to our Tokyo office. The hotel is well maintained, so are the rooms. I dislike the pillows as they are so flat and soft.The restaurant is pretty pricey though for dinner buffet which I paid 7000 Yen plus for 1 pax. You are better off taking a taxi elsewhere for dinner.

I Stay 10 nights with my Family in this hotel, i got upgraded to the next room type without any question for being a frequent guest of IHG chain of hotel.Room is big and comfortable and the location with the train station just a stone throw away, i use a lot of the GINZA line which link to many places, and there is a nice and cheap eatery (Sandwiches and coffee) just beside the hotel if you have enough of hotel breakfast. The Club floor and Lounge have a wonderful view of Mount Fuji. Just ask the Lounge Manager to let you in to have a photo taken if you do not have access to the Lounge.Remember to get direction and help from the "concierge" they are very helpful give very good advice which help u save time and sometimes money. Train is not always the way to go for a family ask them for the best option most of the time a mix and match option is better way to arrive ur destination (Taxi and Train and Subway).As for the better service - Front desk was a little impatient with no Japanese speaking and non suit wearing Guest, found that they are unwilling to go the extra mile even the bell Boy team, as it was raining went there to borrow an bolly, very unwilling to "dish" out the bolly to me and not sure if it is by mistake one of the bolly have hole and not working well. Breakfast area on the lobby, again if you are not in suit you will get different service (not so polite type of service) as i have observe, When i was in Suit for some of the days i get much better service and greeting.I will still stay in hotel, as it is near to Tokyo MidTown nice place to have nice dinner and Shopping, it is just an short taxi ride less then 1000 Yen or an 15 minutes walk from Intercon.Just hope they can improve on some of their service.

We stayed at the Tokyo ANA InterContinental hotel on the last days of our vacation. The hotel is conveniently located next to the Tameike metro stop and the room was of a good size, it was actually the biggest room we had on our trip to Japan. The service from the front desk was unfortunately a real turn off. Without being openly rude, the staff was nonetheless unfriendly, almost disdainful, probably because we were wearing casual clothes when we checked in. The man waiting in line behind us, dressed in business attire, was on the other hand warmly greeted. That type of attitude towards non business travellers was not something we expected, such a sad contrast to the very good service we had at Osaka Cross Hotel where the reception staff was welcoming from the moment we arrived. We hope not all InterContinental hotels have this type of customer service but we definitely won't come back to this one in Tokyo.

I spend a night with my mother over the other day ! Everything was almost perfect!部屋は少し古いですが特にベッドが気持ち良く十分気に入りました！夜はラウンジの軽食とお酒で十分お腹いっぱいで夕食はいらないくらい（＾ν＾）窓側の東京タワーが見えるところがオススメです(￣▽￣)洋書も置いてあった。ちなみに国会や霞が関、アメリカ大使館が近くて私は良かったけど溜池山王駅からは遠くて母は疲れてました。。。

While the location is fantatsic, after arriving on JR, it was quite a walk from Hamamatsucho station ( JR ) I believe there is a limo bus from the station every 20 - 30 mins, but its easier to get here from the Tokyo Monorail as it's right beside Takeshiba stationCheck in was friendly and very easy, room was spacious and very well equiped, cant want for anything here, great views of Tokyo bay.lots of shops and resturants nearby, especially the Pokemon centre, handy for present buyingwould definately stay again

The hotel is very good interntional standard. The rooms are spacious and clean, the service and reception works fast and efficient. The gym is well equipped and open all day. Nearby is the empepors palace. If you look or a smooth and convenient stay oin that area that is a good choice.

I stayed in the ANA Intercontinental Minato for 3 days before starting an 11 day cruise to Siberia and around Hokkaido and Honshu. It was advertised as mainly for business travellers with great conference and internet facilities. On arrival we entered the hotel through the conference area on the ground floor and had to travel up to the first floor/ reception area to check in. It was an impressive double height space which also contained a large dining area, bar, shops and office areas. Check-in was very straight forward although our rooms were not together as promised. When we brought this to their attention we were upgraded to executive rooms across the hall from each other. On entering our rooms we realised that we were on a smoking floor. The hallways smelt very strongly of smoke and nicotine which came through the air-conditioning system and under the door into the rooms. As we were only staying for 3 days and had already changed rooms we decided to live with it but regretted this when we started to get sore throats after the first night.The room was very clean and comfortable with a modern bathroom that had a large window between it and the bedroom space. The large mirrored wall in the bathroom was heated from behind so that even after a hot steamy shower it remained clear. The toilet was heated and had all the extras that you expect in Japan and the view from the room was beautiful, taking in the Tokyo tower.Breakfast was not included in the price so we paid for the buffet breakfast each morning which was quite expensive although I have never seen such a huge choice of dishes. It was available until 10am and was cleared away with military like speed, so don't be even a minute late or you'll miss it! The outside pool looked very inviting but at an extra charge of about £20 a day we gave it a miss.The Internet is only free to business guests but if you register with the hotel chains reward system online before you travel you can get round this and also use it without charge. Just take your membership number with you.The staff were very helpful and most spoke English and checking out was fast and straight forward. Taxis are always available and there are a couple of Subway stations nearby. I would recommend taking the Underground as it is very clean and straightforward to use but don't be fooled by some of the entrances as once you enter, it can take another 15 minutes of walking before you actually reach a train platform and after double hip replacements my mother found some of them a struggle.

Everything was good. The hotel is Located in Akasaka close to the metro station.Rooms are clean and bigger then the japanese standards. Breakfast was delicious.Good selection of japanese and internationalrestaurants. Very nice skybar on the top.

I liked this hotel when it joined Intercontinental but returning after some years now I was disappointed how tired the hallways and room looked. Wear and tear everywhere and bathroom is very small and feels very 80s. As a platinum number you do not get any water in the room, and the front desk refuses to upgrade. A stark contrast to the Intercontinental Osaka we had stayed a few nights earlier. The location is not that convenient, with rooms old and unfriendly service, there's no reason to stay here any more.

I decided to book this hotel due to the great experience I had back then at Intercontinental Osaka. Unfortunately, the overall experience here in Tokyo did not quite meet my expectations. There is no doubt that it is a decent hotel with all the facilities and service. However, I simply thought they could have performed better given their Intercontinental brand and the price I have paid for! 1) Room - The safe box in the room was not functioning well and so their staff literally spent at least half an hour fixing the safe box whilst I have just checked in into my room without having some time to relax. Turned out that the safe box could not be fixed but required to be changed into a new one, and there again spending more time in changing one.2) Washroom - it was user-friendly but could have been more spacious.3) Ambassador programme - I actually signed up for the ambassador programme meaning that I should have been upgraded to executive floor automatically (which was confirmed through email correspondence with the staff prior to arriving to the hotel) but I was told when checking in that they could not do so as all the rooms on executive floor were fully booked. This was really frustrating and they should have better planned. Given this not-so-good experience, I wonder if I would return again but stay in other five star hotel options in the Minato areas (e..g Ritz Carlton and Grand Hyatt)

I have been a frequent client. ANA hotel is well located for my business. Unfortunately this is only a business hotel like many others cheaper in Tokyo. No friendship attitude, it's only a money machine, that's all. Yes, you have to step away from the sofa in the lobby at around noon even if you had your breakfast there. The restaurant is too small to welcome many guests at the same time. Sure, you are paying your stay but at lunch time the waitresses kindly ask you to go away. It's unacceptable. It's uncomfortable and unacceptable if you have invited people for a business meeting. A huge range of prices are applied based on the occupancy and the period. Prices are changing day by day. The guest must strongly negotiate for everything better (room, newspaper, wifi, etc.) otherwise the basic accomodation is very poor. Many rooms are not spacious and the furniture is quite worn. Above all it's a good solution for holiday. It will be probably refurbished for the 2020 Olimpic Games.

Good centrally located hotel in Minato. The rooms are quite and spacious. The staff was attentive and friendly. Stayed here for about a week and at some point had my clothes spread out in the room, service staff neatly folded on the couch. Nice touch. The Wi-Fi was fast. The bar on the top floor has nice views of the city. Close walking to Ropoonji and Tokyo metro stop. There is a starbucks across the street for the must have latte fans. The neighborhood around the hotel is cool too. Can't really go wrong with much in Japan.

I have to preface this by saying that this was my first visit to Tokyo, so I am not aware of any specific benchmark standards in the City. The hotel is big, shops, restaurants 4 lifts, 34 or so floors....and it isn't a cheap option either. Check in was quite protracted as they had misspelled our names and thought the booking had not been made. The language was a barrier, and the person who checked us in had a little difficulty in understanding our issue. But of course great with all the pleasantries. After we showed them, on a laptop, the actual confirmation, we were checked in on a high floor, city views, very nice. The room was small, but had what you would need for a couple of days. However we were there for 5 days and I did find it a little tight. Especially the bathroom, very small. But everything immaculately clean, well serviced and with a great comfy bed. The restaurants in the hotel are expensive, but so is Tokyo. We paid £420 for two in the top floor Tapenyaki restaurant....it was good, but expensive. The breakfasts are amazing, huge buffet and fresh produce. And generally, the service was of a good standard. I did wait for over 15 minutes to see a concierge on a couple of occasions and everyone seemed busy. I would stay there again, good location, if a little sterile, but for business it's a winner.

Excellent service, great people, great hotel.Close to Roppongi. Had a great stay during my business trip.Breakfast was good.On the upper floors you can get a good visibilty of Mt. Fuji on a clear day.

It is the second time I've stayed at this hotel. The last time was almost exactly a year ago. The hotel carpets are filthy and the decor is old and drab. The public areas are well cared for but once you have penetrated the facade the long corridors to the rooms are covered in grit and grime. There is no reason for an intercontinental to allow this in its stable.

This hotel is located near Rapungi district; very convenient for people who have business dealings. Hotel is very quiet; especially for the middle of downtown Tokyo. It is very close to a subway stop and restaurants all around. Rooms are spacious with amenities such as slippers, hot water kettle, refrigerator, etc. The bed and bedding is comfortable (not rock hard like in some Japanese hotels). The bathroom is a little small and stuffy. The water and shower are great, but the shower curtain needs updating. Good workout room and great but expensive restaurants.

I was here for business and stayed for five consecutive nights. The hotel is spotless and the rooms are nicely modernized. While the bathroom wasn't large, it did have a window in it that looked into the room giving it the impression that it was larger than it was. Very good location next to Ginza 6 station. The climate system in the room was highly effective. Recommended, especially for business travelers.

My inaugural trip to Tokyo and I can highly recommend this hotel. Centrally located, close to the subway and the facilities within the hotel are excellent. The Teppanyaki restaurant on 37th floor is a must - awesome views combined with a superb dining experience.Ticks all the boxes for a business hotel - yet does cater for the tourist due to its location.

I stayed here for two weeks while on business. It has all you would expect of a five star Toyko hotel. This being my first trip to Japan I was keen to explore. It is well placed to do that. There are a lot of great restaurants to the south (around Roppongi) and the hotel sits nicely between two tube lines. The standard rooms are a little small. The breakfasts are great and the seer ice is top notch.

First class hotel. Very good location, at the Embassies area of Rappongi Hills, a high class district of Tokyo. Two metro stations nearby, at North of hotel the Ginza orange line and at South the green line. A variety of restaurants nearby to choose from, also three shopping malls with a lot of shops, a very nice area for tourists. The hotel has 3 or 4 very good restaurants, a little expensive, but with high quality food.

This was a great place. It had a beautiful lobby and rooms. The view from the rooms was amazing. It was decently close to everywhere we wanted to go. It was right next to a subway line and there was a line of Taxi waiting outside ready to take tourists where they wanted to go. Additionally, every hotel we went to had really firm beds (probably because the Japanese normally sleep on Tatami mats), but the Ana actually had soft normal western style beds.At one point, on a whim, I bought a pair of Katana (Japanese swords) at a flea market. The ANA shipped them to me in the states and they arrived two days after I sent them (I had to pay for the shipping of course).My only complaint was that you had to pay for the internet.

As many of the previous posters mentioned this hotel has great personnel, good location, and provides very good serviceThis hotel made my birthday that much special after a long flight from Europe when we came tiredPeople do try to provide a great serviceI would come back here

Stayed for 2 nights on a short business trip. Service level was up there like how all Intercontinentals should be. Was expecting the usual Japanese-style tiny bathroom but was pleasantly surprised! Plus my room had a view of the Tokyo tower. Excellent variety served during breakfast. Did not get a chance to explore the surroundings but i noticed a Metro station right next to the driveway. Noticed that majority of clientele were business travellers, perhaps due to the close proximity to Haneda Airport. Will return again if i have the chance!

Location: In the middle of Akasaka, Kasumigaseki and Roppongi areas in Tokyo, for government agencies, financial institutions, banquet/entertainment districts.History: Built 1986, Renovated 2009.Interior Decor: Very high luxurious standards of sophisticated contemporary design. Lots of marbles.Exterior Appearance: One of the skyscrapers near the expressways.Outside view from the room I stayed at (3325): National Diet Building, Emperor Palace, clusters of tall buildings in Shinjuku area. Excellent.Room Size: Approximately, 30 square meters. Adequate. Room Cleanness Spotlessly clean. Great job!Noise Insulation: ExcellentOther Room Fundamentals: Lights switch near bed - plus!; Carpet+wood floor combo - plus! Lighting - plus! Condition of furniture - very goodPrice and Value: Got a reasonable (still expensive) discount that came from breakfast and upgraded room on high floor. Very good.Services: High standards.Bathroom: Luxurious marbles. Good size of bathtubRestaurant for breakfast: Huge selection of food and they are well designed! Very congested.Amenities: Very good.Bed: King size, medium softness. Great night sleep!

I stayed here for a week on a business trip. The hotel was very clean with courteous staff. The breakfast buffet was very impressive. The selection of food was enormous. I also tried the sushi restaurant (very good) and champagne bar (awesome selection of top quality champagnes). I would stay here again.

Why this hotel- member of IHG rewardThe good- location is ok. Not as good as Shinagawa, but closer to Roppongi- friendly staff. - nice room. not huge, but nicely decorated. good size bathroom- quiet. I could see the motorway, but barely hear it- comfy bed- occitane shower gel and shampoo. it makes a nice differenceThe not so good- location is fine, but not that convenient for the airport- hotel looks like from the 80/90s, but very well maintained. (everything is spotless)Will i come back: likely

I like the ANA InterCon Tokyo and have stayed there multiple times for both business and pleasure. It has maintained a very high standard over the years. Good sized rooms and typical high cleanliness standard for Japan. Very professional staff. I personally love the proximity to Ropongi, restaurants, Metro and definitely look forward to future stays. Recommended.

The lady in the concierge desk was rude and was never willing to help. It was just the worst concierge experience we've ever had. The rest of the hotel is amazing, and staff are usually very nice. Their restaurants are really good and they offer a big variety of food.

rooms fir single use are very small - 17sq. m. only , better to take double rooms - they are a little bit bigger. Smoking rooms are cheaper, but they are very old, and hard smoking unpleasant smell. Anyway all the hotel facilities are wonderful - hotel shops and restaurants are very good !!! The area nearby is very pleasant, possible to walk around, very good restaurants in the Arc Hills building. The staff is very professional. Breakfast is large, but not enough fresh fruits

I visited Tokyo as my birthday vacation in July this year.We traveled by the red-eye flight via Singapore airlines and arrived at the hotel at 9am.We were unable to check into a room as it was too early, but given access to the lounge to rest.The lounge is one of the better ones in Tokyo according to my online research.The lounge breakfast is the best I have had so far. The range is so wide and almost like a full buffet breakfast in other hotels.I have to really compliment the staff, especially those at the lounge.Everyone was warm and helpful, although check-in was slow because of inexperience (which didn't matter much since a room was not ready.)The staff at the lounge always greeted us and even made a birthday cake with fruit decoration and sang me a birthday song! That really made my night and the entire stay great.I remember Rei and Takagi and hope the hotel continues to be excellent or even improve!http://goodhotelreview. blogspot. com

The pros of this hotel were a high standard of service, a clean modern room, nice city views, easy access to metro, a grand lobby amongst others.Cons were mainly not getting WiFi included at this price mark is not unusual, but always disappointing. I did not take the breakfast, but did see a sustained queue to enter the dining area for this meal. I'd certainly stay there again, but would also check out other similarly priced options as well.

I used to stay Grand Hyatt in the same area whenever I go to Japan. This time we have a try in ANA InterContinental due to a friend's recommendation. The price is relatively cheaper, but the hotel building is not as modern and stylish as Grand Hyatt. Good points 1) fair price2) very good breakfast!!3) excellent location, with only a few minutes to subway, and link to restaurants/bars buildings in the area, many convenient stores with a minute walk. 4) large space in the room5) great restaurants in hotel and near hotelWeak points1) no complimentary bottle water provide in the room2) need to line up and wait for a long time for breakfast on weekend (weekdays is fine)3) I use the business center meeting room, only 1 receptionist was there to serve, and sometimes when she is busy that you can't find anyone for help in the center. 4) The WIFI in room was not stable, sometimes it is fine and fast, sometimes you can't even connect...overall was a good stay, I hope they can improve the WIFI connection which is a very important point for me, as a business trip.

Stayed at the ANA Intercontinental for a few nights for business. Facilities were very good and room was excellent as I would expect for a hotel of this standard.Price for the room was reasonably good value for money for the quality of the hotel service and location. However, I felt like the hotel was trying to make up for the good room rate by charging a lot for various extras.As a diamond IHG member I was a little surprised that the best they could arrange for a late checkout for me was 2 pm, and that staying to 3pm would be 30% of the rack rate extra, and 4pm 50% extra. (I was hoping to have a quick shower just before 4pm after some meetings.) Perhaps this is normal but it isn't what I've got used to with SPG or HHonors and the staff seemed a bit unfriendly about it too, as though they were doing me a big favour to even offer me paid late checkout.Likewise, when I checked in I was given an option for using the Executive Lounge. I didn't catch the price very clearly (my fault, I suppose) but said yes and it ended up being 12,000 yen ($120), which I didn't realise until checkout. Again, having become used to free use of exec lounge I felt this was rather a steep charge - though at least the lounge was very pleasant, quiet and spacious, so I ended up doing some work from there rather than in my room.Swimming pool looked inviting from the lounge, so I got changed and headed down for a 10 minute swim before heading for another meeting, only to find there was an additional charge of 3,000 yen ($30) for the pool, which the staff there told me I should feel thankful about since it was "half price" of the usual fee of 6,000 yen. At $3 a minute I decided not to swim - but felt quite disappointed since I had specifically chosen this hotel based on the pool looking good, and wanting to swim a few laps during my stay.

This hotel, as with most Intercontinental Hotels, is a fine business hotel. As a business hotel there is nothing to disappoint. However if it some luxurious leisure you are looking for there may be preferable hotels. There is a fine selection of Japanese, Chinese and Western restaurants and the food at these restaurants was most pleasing. The hotel is clean and very comfortable. I enjoyed a Junior Suite room. Beware there are two configurations of these rooms. One is long and narrow. I was in such a room first. I found it a little odd and unpleasant. I was moved to the second style of room and found this most satisfactory. I am not sure about the location of the hotel. I am not familiar enough with Tokyo to really express a view on this. We seemed to be able to go everywhere we were interested in by taxi or subway very conveniently. However there may be preferable places in terms of taking a stroll on the street.

I stayed 4 nights at the hotel, and they were a dissapointment from check-in till check-out. Check in was a 25 minute disaster, for 3 rooms with the lady at the counter unable to coop, eventhough we were the only once at the check-in counter, my luggage was delivered full 40 minutes after arrival, and all to one of the 3 rooms. My complaint was acknowledged and a bottle of Roederer champagne offered, which I accepted but regretfully it was only the beginning of a bad experience. The next day concierge did not return a call but 50 minutes later, breakfast was a mess because the hotel can not accomodate guests when fully booked. Same for concierge, understaffed, which is an unusual experience in Japan. The worst however was the bar, with a water serving ice with something when ordering a French75 too my wife and worst of all his racist behavior by refusing to acknowledge us on leaving ( my wife is from Hongkong) as he did do for other Japanese clients. For those who think I am difficult, I am going to Japan for 30 years, have lived there once for 6 and for 1 year. Yes, according to european standards the hotel is very good, to Japanese standards they are totally inadequate and unacceptable. The duty manager apologies where totally insincere on checkout. I was joined by 2 more of my clients so had a total of 21 roomnights and I regret each one of them. The only just reaction would have been a reimbursement of our entire stay, according to Japanese standards.

The ANA was an excellent hotel for access to the sights of Tokyo (near the Ginza line). The rooms are nice and have all the amenities you need. The entire hotel is clean and contemporary. The workout facility is well stocked with modern equipment and is open 24/7. There are very few restaurants in the area since it is a financial and embassy district. The breakfast buffet is very complete, but expensive. I would recommend to buy a hotel/breakfast package when you book. That way you get a discount on the breakfast. Otherwise it is around $35-36 each!!! You need to pay for WIFI also. That surprised us since the hotel was fairly expensive.The ANA hotel is on the expensive side compared to many hotels in other areas of Tokyo, but many of those do not have workout facilities.

Convenient hotel with good breakfast and fast servicesIf you have a big room you will enjoy it. Be carrefull to not get smallest room when checkin as they are very smallWent various time always good and close restaurants and traim stationIdeally located for visit and businessOnly bathroom look very oldNice to have a drink on the top floorPlease avoid chinese restaurant which is not good at allSushi restaurant is average...okFrench restaurant is fantastic...

The hotel is very upscale and all the staff are friendly and helpful. Our room 2716 was nice. A deluxe king room. A bit on the small side but I hear most hotel rooms in Tokyo are. Was enought room for the two of us. The breakfast buffet was really nice. One of the best we've had. Lots of variet and quality foods. You get free wifi in your room and late checkout if you are a IHG member. Free to join. A few restaurants around the hotel. The Wolfgang Puck Pizza Bar was really good. The hotel is a bit away from the main downtown area of Tokyo and tourist sites but lots of taxis available. Taxi prices are high in Tokyo. We took the airport limousine bus from Narita airport. Costs $46 canadian return ticket. Buy your ticket at counter at airport just after you clear customs. Takes about 90 minutes from airport to Ana Intercontinental hotel.
