We also booked the Hop on Hop off Sky Bus. Only $25 Canadian for 24 hours. They have 3 routes and you can see all the main areas and sights.

Used the ANA Intercontinental in Minato on Business as part of an ISO Standards meeting at the SJAC (Society of Japanese Aerospace Companies) very nearby (5 minute walk). When arriving I was impressed by the grandeur of the lobby and the greeting given by the employees. The check-in was straightforward and although it might take a couple of times to confirm things, due to English - Japanese translation, generally very good and always willing to help. Was offered an upgraded king bed room as the size I had booked was not available. I actually swapped with a colleague who was there with his wife and ended up with a twin bed, though to be fair the size of each of the twin beds were also very impressive. The room consisted of the normal writing desk, luggage area, Flat Screen TV, Mirrors plenty, coffee bar and minibar area, good sized wardrobe and small bathroom (though adequate for me). The bed was very comfortable and air-con worked well. The shower was powerful and all other amenities were very acceptable. What really makes the hotel stand out is the quality of the bars on the ground and 36th floor. The ground floor bar is very comfortable and relaxing and you can sit with a drink and smoke if you wish, as is the case with the 36th floor bar also. The drinks at both bars are not cheap, but you have to remember that you are in the middle of Tokyo and like any major city you will be paying more than other places. Great to use the ground floor bar (Floor 2 in fact) before heading out for a bite to eat and the 36th Floor Bar for a nightcap or two. The view from the 36th floor is very impressive and especially when captured between two verticals of japanese whiskeys which are great (Yamazaki 12 year old is one to try - or the Hibiki). My friend had a fish and chip supper in the 36th Floor bar when we met also and he seemed very happy with that. Its easy to get around from the Imperial Palace to/from the Tokyo train station, from which you can reach Narita airport in an hour on the Narita Express train, though Haneda airport is closer and I think will also come into Tokyo station. The hotel also sports a mini parade of shops, including a great little one tucked away for very reasonable priced traditional gifts for the family. There are some restaurants also to be located out through the shops. And in fact I just remembered alongside the hotel there is also a parade of shops and restaurants, which I did not get to explore.The Tokyo Skytower (mini tour eiffel) is also very nearby and on a good day you can see Mount Fuji from the 36th Floor Bar.One other thing is that there is also a champagne bar on Floor 3, which is just above the lobby floor and which you can see from the lower bar. Great if you can afford it, but we could not.All in all a great hotel which I very much enjoyed. It is not cheap, but from the large hotels we looked at in the similar area they are very similarly priced and again it is in central Tokyo.Take a look and enjoy.

Great location, walking distance to Roppongi and shopping area, great service from the concierge, great staff, clean, great bed and shower, excellent breakfast. The bar on th 36 floor is also very good.I would highly recommend to stay in this hotel,

We spent 6 nights here and had a great experience staying at this hotel. It is conveniently located (about 2 minutes) walk from the Tameike-Sanno station on the Ginza Line. The staff and concierge were very helpful. They all spoke English quite well so it was easy to ask them questions. We couldn't find a lot of restaurants to eat in the area so we generally took the metro to Shimbashi instead. There is a little cafe and a 7-11 near the hotel on the way to the subway station. We bought a 1 Day Tourist Metro Pass from the concierge. It was 600 yen so it was a great value. The room was nice and clean. We got a room with a view of Tokyo Tower but it also had a view of a small cemetery :(.

To be fair, the hotel was completely booked for an entire month and we were able to secure a room by way of help from a local. The room was about the size of a large broom closet. We were here only for one night. I can't really speak for the junior suites and suites (the type of room we more typically stay in) so it is possible the rooms are nicer than our experience. Also we were on a club floor and due to some confusion due to a language misunderstanding, we ended up paying for breakfast downstairs when we could have had a breakfast on our floor for "free". Apparently their definition of "continental breakfast" includes cooked food whereas traditionally I believe it generally applies to bread and coffee.

Staying at the ANA Intercontinental for 7 nights gave a very good insight to the workings of thislarge hotel. The whole Japanese experience was first class, but particularly made by the staff in all areas. The eye for detail and the desire to please goes a long way.Whether it was the lack of the Japanese language, or complicated requests, we found the Concierge desk a fountain of information. In particular we would like to commend Concierge Shinobu Momoi who went out of her way to assist us and succeeded !The ANA Intercontinental is centrally located and I cannot recommend it enough, whether you are a first time visitor to Tokyo (like us), or a seasoned business traveller, your every need will be more than adequately catered for.John MacDonaldBrisbane

No problems at this property. They know how to care for the guests. From the front desk to the restaurants to the maid service and concierge it is a top notch property. Will stay there every time I come to Tokyo. Very close to Haneda airport
user_name:
climber c
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: We spent two nights at the ANA before moving down to Yokohama for our cruise. We arrived on a busy Saturday night on the Limousine Bus from the airport and the hotel was a buzz with people going in all directions. It didn't take long for us to be checked in and soon we were on our way to our lovely room which was on the 29th floor. We had a wonderful view over Tokyo. I am an Ambassador member and we were upgraded to a good room. Next morning we awoke to the consequences of typhoon Phanfone which meant we were unable to leave the hotel as the wind and rain were tremendous. We spent the day walking around the hotel and spending time in our comfortable room. We were unable to see anything outside the window as the lovely view had just disappeared.We had two good breakfasts in the hotel and one dinner which was fine. As we couldn't go outside I am not sure if we were close to anything though I know that the nearest station was only a block away.We found the staff to be very pleasant and helpful and they all spoke excellent English.

Was at the ANA for 3 night for work recently. Loved the location as its just steps away from the metro and walking distance to several of the places I had meetings. Hotel is itself is very nice, very clean had everything I needed. I didn't sign up for the breakfast package so can't comment about food. They did by mistake put me in a smoking floor, but within minutes of calling the front desk moved me to a non-smoking floor. One thing to note though is, the area is not typical Tokyo...its more the business district and closer to very high end (Ginza?) shopping and dining areas. So finding a hole in the wall ramen joint for example...that was tough, granted I had a v hectic schedule so didn't do a lot of sightseeing.Hotel itself, will I stay again for work, most definitely, will I stay there when holidaying, probably not given the location.

I stayed at the ANA Intercontinental for 2 nights this past October. The hotel is in Akasaka right across from an elevated roadway. The room was very small, had low ceilings, was cheaply furnished (chairs had worn corduroy slip covers, one of which had a cigarette burn) and had multiple attributes that would prevent it from being a luxury hotel:1. No one escorted me to my room (or even asked).2. Thin towels3. Shampoo, conditioner, body wash in pump containers attached to the shower wall. 4. Thin white fabric shower curtain5. No body lotion6. Hot water kettle was nice but there was only cheap tea and instant coffee and creamer. (The only other Intercontinental Hotel I have stayed in was at the Johannesburg airport and at least that had a nespresso maker)7. No robe8. I could hear footsteps from the room above.9. Only 5 TV channels all only in Japanese.10. One could order room service from the hotel restaurants but only until 9 p.m. The only thing that was acceptable was the bed, duvet and pillows, which were white and very soft down. All in all, a disappointment.
user_name:
MiffysPillowBook
New York City, New York

review_body: Come March and i was summoned to Tokyo, Japan. Being an Intercontinental Fan, i scouted for the IHG properties in Tokyo and learnt that the ANA Intercontinental Tokyo is the biggest in terms of rooms in the world. So biggest it was to be and i land up at the Intercon to be warmly greeted by the hostess in a Japanese dress. Not sure what it was at that time, but felt very nice The hotel is BIG, really big. I entered the Lobby which was on level 2 and boy oh boy, the limousine ride unto the lobby was an experience onto itself. Rooms were clean, the japanese sakura touch and lovely flowers view from top of the hotel. My shower even had a TV and it was fun to soak in the tub while watching tv. Another high in life. I was there for about a week, and felt great. The best part is the view of Mt.Fuji from the Club Lounge and some of the rooms. How much more awesome can it get.......The Hotel is so convenient to reach by the train network in Japan (which actually looks like an electrical grid diagram) that i began wondering if ever people walked on the streets in Tokyo. If you are a walking buff, then this place is about a 20 minute walk from the Tokyo Tower. The rooms were very spacious, and yes the USP in Japan is the toilet. You have to see it, feel it, to believe it. Warm experience. Literally. The concierge needed to upgrade themselves, but then the GM of this property, Mr.Markus Platzer was a very cordial and gem of a person. Having known him from his earlier debut, he did ensure all was well and in place for me. His level of sincerity comes from the level he extends to his guests which are his primary concern.

Checking in was very fast and front desk staff was helpful throughout our four night stay in October.Room was quite nice and with an interesting view (28th floor). Service in all areas was excellent. If you are a pleasure traveler and want a less expensive breakfast or dinner, go to the Ark Mall, which is out the entrance by the shops. The hotel was centrally located and there was never a shortage of cans if we wanted one. The metro was also very close and easy to maneuver around. The free wi-fi for being a hotel club member was also an important bonus.Management is very savvy in terms of handling emergencies. I had pre-paid for five nights, (non-refundable) but could only spend four because of super typhoon Vongfong delaying my cruise arrival by one night. I e-mailed them and they gave me a choice of a full refund or using that money to my expenses at the hotel.This and the Intercontinental Yokohama Grand were complete surprises (good, good, good) after the bad experiences I had at Intercontinentals in Cairo, and San Jose, Costa Rica.

Do try to stay here.Its well located, well appointed and the service is truly first class.The location allows a 15 minute leisurely walk to Roppongi Crossings a wealth of restaurants and bars.Quality rooms and the staff are happy to assist

If you want drink or eat in Tokyo do not look anywhere. This place has it all!! Veru good breakfast in Cascade and floor 36 and the best champagne bar. Gym is very clean and nice. The pastisserie of Greignard is simply unbelievable

I have stayed in many Japanese hotels but this one is convenient and pleasant. It has many amenities and the rooms are well appointed. Room service is superb and it is in walking distance from my favorite Yaki tori bar. Best of all the room I chose gave me a fantastic view of the Tokyo Tower. So remember to ask for that view which has a spectacular ending as the lights on the tower shut down at midnight.

Stayed recently for 3 nights on a business trip. Location is very convenient and hotel even though seems to be fairly old is kept in very good shape. Rooms are nice though beds are tiny. Showers are great. Breakfast buffet was also very good. My main issue was service which I found quite poor. Checking in was a nightmare. I told the front desk I was in a hurry as I had to shower and change and run to a business meeting. What I got in return was a painfully slow check in process. In the time I was checked in by the front desk attendant the attendant next to him checked in three different people. Not only was it slow but they could never spell my name correctly despite them having a copy of my passport and me spelling it out for them. As a result I was never able to get internet access as the system said my room number and last name did not match. I repeatedly ask them to fix it and they never did. I also missed an important phone call for the same reason as the caller was told I had not checked in. One on the telephones in the room did not work. I asked for it to be fixed but they never did it despite assurances it would be taken care off.

I arrived at this hotel before the check-in time. The receptionist checked me into a room on the 25th floor, but said the room won't be ready for another half an hour. I went for lunch and after I got back, a new receptionist was there. He told me I have a room on the 8th floor. I complained that the previous receptionist already assigned me to a different room on the 25th floor. Long story short, it took the receptionist and his manager 15 minutes to resolve this, and gave me a different room on the 25th floor. Now I'm in the room, and it's sooo small, much smaller than what can be seen in the pictures. I won't stay at this hotel again.

Hotel is very conveniently located in central Tokyo with easy access to the neighboring districts. Rooms are clean, spacious, nicely furnished. Bathroom is clean. Everything is up to a great standard. Hotel staff is very polite and helpful, one of the best!! Also I absolutely recommend to go there for breakfast, it is excellent, wide choice and very tasteful.In overall I don't have a single bad word to say about my experience and I m already looking forward to stay there again.

...stay here. The hotel has 600+ rooms that are a bit tired. Good size rooms for Tokyo that have had minimal refurbishing. Overall an okay hotel in Tokyo, but there are smaller, better ones around for the same price or less.Pros:- great breakfast buffet- great concierge- central location- good bed- all the taxi drivers know it- right by the metro (but what isn't in the heart of Tokyo)Cons:- some staff attitude in the restaurants- tired bathrooms and carpeting- mega hotel where finding your room can be an adventure

Stayed at ANA Intercontinental during a business trip, the hotel is easy to reach from Haneda airport by train (1 change to Tokyo Metro) (Narita airport is a little further out of Tokyo, but can also be reached by 1 change). Location is excellent, only a short walk to Akasuka office, with lots of restaurants and shops around. The hotel is comfortable, good beds with different pillows, a little desk and a nice seat. We had wifi included in the hotel package and its fast and reliable! Reception staff was very friendly and helpful.Requested a non-smoking room, but unfortunately it was on a smoking floor, so there was still some smoke smell (I don't think someone had smoked in the room, but the smoke smell came from the hallway).

My stay was very convenient, although the checking in was a bit busy. The rooms are fair, the toilets are clean but not that spacy. The breakfast is marvellous, very rich , cosmopolitan & more than enough. The location is nice, with an easy access to Shibuya, imperial palace & asakusa by metro from Tameike-sanno station with exit 13 just at the back of the hotels door. AKA hills is a nice complex just next door , where u can find a lot of cafe's & restrnts & it also has the famous Suntory hall.There also u can find a flea market just infront of the Suntory hall every sunday. At night you can walk daily to the famous Roppongi dori for every kind of nightlife activities including an Egyptian cafe serving Hookah in Tokyo !!

This is a first class hotel situated in central Tokyo. Excellent location, superb staff, great breakfast buffet. Walking distance to restaurants and grocery store. The rooms are clean, cozy and quiet. This is a truly five star hotel in the heart or Tokyo.

The ANA Intercontinental Hotel is perfectly located in central Tokyo. Access to the business district and sight seeing is extremely convenient. The hotel also provides access to the subway. Which is easy to use and provides access to many of the attractions in Tokyo.The hotel staff is always helpful and makes you feel like they appreciate your business.

I spent 6 nights at the ANA Intercontinental hotel in Tokyo for work purposes in Sept 2014. It is a very high quality hotel, with helpful and friendly staff. The rooms are well furnished (though if you are traveling from Europe it's worth noting smoking IS allowed indoors, so be sure to book a non-smoking room) and have great facilities. There was an excellent mini bar with fridge and although I did not buy anything, I did make use of the fridge to store water, etc. The shower was excellent, hot and with good water pressure. Also, the hotel has the famous 'Japanese water toilet' which can wash you if you so desire! I was on floor 15 and the view was great. I guess the main downside was I was quite near the lifts and they were very loud (I am a light sleeper)The room was well equipped - 2 beds, desk & chairs, fridge, good sized wardrobe, kettle, iron, etc. However please note the only television channels were Japanese. Breakfast buffet was excellent, a good spread of international food. The hotel is conveniently located for the underground and some superb restaurants, so get out there and explore Tokyo!

Great check in service, excellent buffet restaurant, great rooms, morning newspaper, free wifi with Intercontinental membership, super courteous and helpful staff, nothing to complain about.Did I mention senior citizen discount (65+) at their buffet restaurant (great food)

Had a dinner scheduled in Roppongi so decided to stay at this hotel. Had an early arrive to Haneda and took the airport limo bus to the hotel.At the check in counter they offered me a paid upgrade to the club -- it would also give me an early check in time. I took the upgrade, mainly to get the to room. On arrive in the room, it was nice, slightly worn, and smaller that normal in Tokyo.The room had a mess of cables under the desk that were falling and many things in the room were dusty. Over all, a basic IC hotel room.The club lounge was great. The first thing that impressed me was the size -- very large and great views -- even had a rare clear shot of Mt. Fuji. Breakfast, snacks, and appetizers were great, but the level of service was even better. Well worth the upgrade.My one small complaint is the distance to the metro -- about a 10 minute walk even though the entrance to the station is only 50 yards away.One note -- make your airport limo reservations early, as some of the times do sell out, but the bus departs basically every hour. There is an Airport Limo office on the ground floor.

I have stayed at the ANA several times, in fact it is now the only hotel I stay at in Tokyo. A few months ago my team closed a very lucrative deal over an 11 course meal at a nearby Sushi restaurant. I decide to treat my employees to a celebratory drink when we got back to the hotel. We went to the MIXX Bar and Lounge for a drink. The tab came to more than $85 for four drinks. Well worth it given both the spectacular views and our business success that evening, but rather pricey for anyone not on an expense account. Hotel service as excellent, as always. the front desk was quite helpful in arranging my departure transportation to the airport. FYI, in the Japanese custom, there was no tipping expected on the drink tab.

I have stayed here many times, and I am always delighted with the service, the care taken by, and politeness of the staff. Location is excellent, amenities are great and the views over the city, and on to Mt. Fuji, top off a great hotel. Always relaxing, and no task is too difficult for the team. # ichiban

My partner and I recently visited Japan for a long overdue holiday. Where possible we stayed at IHG hotels but unfortunately there weren't many Intercontinental hotels outside of Tokyo. On our last night in Japan we stayed at the ANA Intercontinental Tokyo. The room was relatively small but very well appointed. The Club Lounge on the 35th floor was fabulous with sweeping views over Tokyo. The range of food and beverages was great - including French champagne and dumplings, two of our favourites.If you don't get automatic access in your room rate then ask about the cost to get access to the Club Lounge - it's well worth it. The lounge staff are very attentive and courteous.

I was in Tokyo for business but also had the weekend to enjoy the city. The staff was amazing at making me feel welcome and helping me to see as much of the city as I could. My room was huge with an amazing city view. I had been on the road for almost 3 weeks so I needed all the space I could get. The bathroom was great with an awesome shower. Being close to Roppongi is great because there is so much to do after work. I had tea at the hotel one afternoon and it was so lovely. The pastries were amazing and the tea selection was so good it was almost overwhelming. Being able to come back to this hotel after exploring the city and working was such a great respite. Just want you want in a hotel!
user_name:
jlperez13
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: We're fans of Rappongi so chose to stay near it and what a great choice. Our family room was large enough for 3 queen-sized beds and storage space, and had an amazing view of Tokyo. The breakfast buffet was almost overwhelming, serving everything from continental, English, American and wide range of Asian dishes. There are several bars (have a night-cap on the top floor for a stunning view), about 6 restaurants and of course you've got Ark Hills and Rappongi Hills on your doorstep. They charge for use of the pool, something that seems standard in Japan.

Close to the City center and other major Tokyo business centers, close to Roppongi for a good relax after business and if you want to stay in - there is lots to do.  With at least 8 restaurants ranging from 3 Michelin Star to a bakery, cigar bars and roof top views you can get anything you want at the ANA Intercon. Rooms are Intercon style with everything as it should be.i would recommend highly.Club lounge is one of the better ones I have been to.Well done!!!!

A very nice hotel in the Minato area of Tokyo. Staff were generally helpful and polite, but due to the sheer size of the hotel, be prepared for long queues when checking in, checking out and at breakfast.Great view over to the National Diet Building and beyond from my room.Room was spotless, with great facilties.

Nice rooms, all very quite. All have great views.Hostility of staff is excellent. I always get a kick out of the bathrooms in this hotel. There must be more technology in that bathroom than in my entire house.... computers included. Given I am happy with an outhouse and cold water.... these are mindblowing.
user_name:
LastSecondTraveller
New York City, New York

review_body: Having stayed here for the 3rd time, it's been consistent in all the trips. Silent rooms with great city view, not far away from the local flavors, convenient to reach by many diverse travel options. Remarkable staff, who are very attentive from the concierge to the front desk or any of the dining places. The way they would connect and reach out to understand is commendable, as the languages are not native for them. Ofcourse, the Japanese finesse is not lost here at any point, which is a nice blend to experience. The breakfast spread is not to be missed, though one will see that its restaurant is quite popular, with seats getting filled early.

Staying here for 3 nights last year during Tokyo Motor Show Business Trip. The Hotel is very nice, the room is pretty big and location wise was superb. Perfect Hotel for a business trip in Tokyo as in right in the centre.

I hadn't been to Tokyo for several years and I remembered the hotels as not being great. I was pleasantly surprised by the Intercontinental. I booked a Deluxe room but was told on check-in that they had upgraded us to a higher standard of room. For such a standard of room, it was quite small and not exactly luxurious but still well appointed with lots of gadgets. The toilets in Japan never cease to amaze me! The staff and service were superb.

My wife and I stayed at one of the suites and was very impressed with the hospitality and room arrangements. It was very comfortable and clean. The view of the area was something i liked waking up to. The food was top notch especially the green tea fondue! The staff was helpful and sincere. I can go on and on about my experience, but i would definitely recommend this place again.Job well done!

Hotel in an excellent location, the hotel staff is very friendly and assistants, but the disadvantage of lack of hotel room cleanliness and the amount of accumulated dust on furniture and under beds..

I have visited this hotel ( one of our favorable hotels in Tokyo ) from 25th August to 1st September 2014 with my husband Félix. What a wonderful souvenir that we have had especially with the total manangement team. Shinobu Momoi san from the head conceige department always cares about us and tried her very best to get involve on what we concerned as a travaller from the other country ! Really thanks a lot her professional sensibility on the custom service. Motoyashu Seki san ( manager of the Cascade Café ) always gives us a big smile ( just like old friend ) each morning when we take our breakfast - Both my husband and me feel comfortable everytime we take our holiday in Tokyo. Once again thanks so much and surely we will come back soon !

Stayed for 3 nights in one of the newer rooms and the service is impeccable. Was given a room immediately upon check-in even though it was only 9:30 am, way before check-in time. Service at the club lounge is fantastic especially with the great drinks and snack selections. Basically it is really like having dinner at the club lounge during cocktail hours.Definitely have to pay extra to gain access into the lounge but worth every cent.Housekeeping was great - replenished all amenities daily and made sure the room is ready by the time I return in the early afternoon.Access to Ginza or Shinjuku took less than 20 minutes with the subway station just 3 mins away from the hotel but the way into the subway gate takes a bit longer.Overall excellent stay and will definitely return.

Stayed here for 3 nights on a Business Trip. The hotel is located quite close to a metro station with pretty good connectivity. The room was small but had all standard facilities. There are a couple nice restaurants in the hotel. The staff is very courteous and polite. The breakfast buffet spread is brilliant - do not miss this if you are staying here.

I stayed in Intecon ANA tokyo for 2 weeks. During the first week, I stayed using my points (and was given an unrenovated room). I was extremely disappointed at first, however, hardly paid attention as I was busy exploring Tokyo and surrounding areas.During my second week, I was upgraded to one of the refurbished rooms (being a Royal Platinum Ambassador) - and I must admit the rooms were quite good (attached pictures).- Hotel grounds are very well kept and maintained - and there are tons of restaurants in the hotel area.- Breakfast was well diverse and catered for all tastes. Great breakfast I must say (orange juice was definitely NOT fresh though!)- The location of the hotel is ideal - being less than 30 seconds away from the nearest metro entrance.- The area is quite safe and well lit during the evening.- There is a big inviting pool at the 4th level (cant remember ?) but I was disappointed that we had to pay $30/ person to use it (despite being residents of the hotel).- Gym facilities are much better than many other Intercons and Crown plazas that I have been in.- Check-in and Check-out - I was not very keen on those. The experience was a bit slower than usual.- Concierge was very helpful and patient with us (as one would expect).- I was very disappointed by Housekeeping. They never seemed to really clean the room. Only made the bed and cleaned the bathroom - and in many cases I don't think they vacuumed the carpet (as I see crumbs/ other sorts that I left in the morning). They also never renewed the complimentary water bottles unless I called for them (I assume they want me to drink tap-water).Overall, a pleasant experience. I would definitely stay there again and recommend it to others.

As an IHG Platinum member, I was upgraded upon check-in to a larger, renovated room with a nice view of the skyline. The room was clean and non-smoking as requested, and it smelled clean and fresh (no lingering odor as some have experienced).This hotel is serviced by the Airport Limousine Bus from Narita, which was convenient. If you purchase the roundtrip "return voucher" from the bus company at the airport, you receive a discount at 4500 yen roundtrip (~$45 USD) which is one of the few deals you will find in Tokyo! There is a bakery steps from the lobby where you can get pastries/rolls in the morning which is convenient, and they accept credit card so you could probably get by without too much currency exchange.
user_name:
Lauren L
New York City, New York

review_body: Room a bit on the small side compared to other hotels I've stayed at in Tokyo; found the bi-lingual concierge, front door staff to be most courteous; wish the lobby restaurant had a light snack menu during the afternoon hours; breakfast buffet was quite good; wifi consistent, dependable. Hotel location is convenient to nearby subway stations (by Japan standards).

As a Western traveler, I found everything I wanted at the ANA. Multiple restaurants, outstanding breakfast in the morning with food to serve 4 different cultures, and a well-appointed hotel room.I was upgraded to a larger room on arrival. I found the bathroom to be very spacious and the shower excellent, with premium product. The room had a comfortable desk to work from and a couch. The lights and curtains were automated, making it easy to create a "black-out" against the city lights.While I was there, Tokyo experienced the aftershocks of a 3.9 earthquake in Chiba. I woke up to bottles clinking in the refrigerator and my bed swaying gently. A little excitement, but no sign of serious damage!The guest services are eager to make your stay comfortable. I found the service overall to be very professional and happy to please. I would highly recommend staying here.

This ANA intercontinental is my home away from home, three to five nights per month. The rooms are quiet, clean and comfortable. The breakfast buffet is outstanding. The wifi is fast and signal strength is consistently strong. The best feature of this hotel is its staff. They are genuinely friendly and helpful. Quick with a smile and always go the extra mile. I really look forward to returning here each month.

I stayed at this hotel to celebrate my anniversary with my wife. This hotel is in a great location. As other reviewers have said it’s right next to the US Embassy and a very short train ride to anywhere you want to go in Tokyo. This hotel has a great club floor with really good food and wonderful views of the city. The club room overlooks the Japanese Prime Minister & Diet buildings. MY issues with this hotel are with the comfort of the beds and pillows. The beds are extremely hard. The pillows are either extremely soft or extremely hard with plastic pellets inside. Nothing in between for the firmness. I had asked on two separate occasions for a medium density down pillow and was given the same extremely hard pillows both times even after explaining the previous pillow would not work. I asked to talk to a manager about this and he listened to me and said “what do you want me to do about it?” When you’re staying in an almost $400 a night room and am a top tier member of their loyalty program, that’s not what you expect to hear and in my opinion you shouldn’t be treated in that fashion. I had to leave this hotel early because I could not sleep in these beds or with the pillow provide without pain. I ended up using a bath towel for a pillow to get some sleep, but very little. Unfortunately this was the worst sleep I have ever had at any hotel I have stayed at previously. That includes the budget business hotels in Japan. I expected more from an Intercontinental.

I stayed here midweek for 4 nights and also attended a conference here. The check-in staff, concierge and bell desk staff were fantastic, extremely helpful and courteous... as most Japanese people generally are! I was told that 80% of their guests are westerners, perhaps because the US Embassy is right behind, so it was never an issue communicating with staff in English! Buffet breakfast was good, as expected. We ate at Akasaka on 37th Floor which was amazing, a little expensive though. Also at at Kirin Chinese restaurant on level 3 which was good. The conference and event staff and facilities were fantastic! Housekeeping was not of the highest standard I expected. They made the bed and changed the towels daily, which was fine. But usually at this level of hotel you notice the little things, like tidying the bathroom and restocking the toiletries daily, which they failed to do. However, the room size was quite generous by Tokyo standards and the bed was super comfy!

It s a very good hotel located in a central area. 5 minutes to reach the tower of Tokyo. Breakfast is very rich with big choice of western and eastern food . The hotel also got several restaurants and bars. Service is good, rooms are very functional but comfortable. High level for high prices but it s worth!!

Very good service of fount desk staff , and thank you for arrange a good view of my room, last but not least a convenient traffic connection that make me catch the fight on time.Moreover, the breakfast buffet was providing a various of choice that sound so good for me, as a good breakfast is a good start of a day.

Three night break in Tokyo, hotel well appointed for short stay. Corporate in feel but clean comfortable room large bathroom etc. We had access to the executive club floor and the food and snacks were outstanding!

This is IMHO one of the best business hotels in Tokyo for a number of reasons:- English speaking staff. Even housekeeping speaks decent English, front desk is perfect, in some other business hotels even people at the front desk struggle- Perfect location. Walking distance to Asakasaka-mitsuke or Roppongi yet without all the crowd. Walking distance (well, a longer walk) to Chiyoda park, where I'm running every now and them. And the Tameike-sano station has 4 subway lines to bring you everywhere you want- Good, quick service for housekeepnig (e.g. laundry)- Free WiFi for corporate guestsNow, having said all this, be aware that for a backpacker this is a really poor choice - prices are high (or even extremely high)

I had been stationed in Tokyo for 11 years previously and indeed stayed in the Roppongi area. The funny thing is I had never been into this hotel other than to take the airport limo bus to Narita at the front entrance. As a family we decided to try this Intercon in comparison with others that we had stayed. The hotel is dated; been here since the 80s. The bed was comfortable; no bad pain or headache. Spacious, no smell. Windows sound-proof. Pool is relaxing. Breakfast spread was sumptuous and delicious. That a dated hotel building can be maintained and sustained after so many years is due to in no small measure to the Japanese team effort and culture to maintain quality. I have no complaints. At checkin, it was a little messy due to the peak hour but hotel staff soon came forward to assist. Their English was fine, and manners were pleasant consistent with Japanese hospitality.. I had stayed in many other Japanese hotels of around the same age, and I would give it 4.5 star instead of 5 star mainly because many upcoming newer hotels have caught up in infrastructure and décor. Location is great and one could venture to not only Roppongi but most part of Tokyo via subway. Japanese are generally very helpful if you needed directions when lost in this huge metropolis. Luxury shopping in the adjacent buildings as well as via subway to Ginza. Don't forget to tryout a fantastic restaurant Seryna (Kobe beef) nearby.

For first timers like myself in Japan it was good to know that this hotel is located near the Ginza line station. Now in order to see and go to the main attractions this is very useful as you can use the subway to go to all attractions.The hotel is not new, and the rooms are quite small compared to other hotels. We got a junior suite and i think if not for the furniture the room would have been bigger. There are plentiful of delicious dining options in the hotel so that was a plus for us. Breakfast buffet was big and had many choices, overall the food in this hotel was great. I am a gold ambassador and usually we get our dedicated floor to check in however there was a person on the reception floor and it wasn't a big issue.The concierge at the hotel was very helpful and very detail oriented so the trips we booked from there went smoothly and we really enjoyed their recommendation.Please note that around this hotel there is not much to do, as the nearest thing might be Rappongi Hills which is a 15 min walk from the hotel so if this is important to you then you need to look elsewhere. However if you don't mind using the subway then this shouldn't be a problem (subways are the best mode of transport plus very safe at night as well)A huge downfall is that the internet wifi is not free! However as an ambassador i was entitled for free internet, but for the rest it wasn't free

Stayed here one night in March. Great location. Concierge was very helpful in getting me reservations at a steakhouse that serve waygu beef (even recommending I take a picture on my phone of the restaurant website with its logo since there were no signs in English). Room was clean, with a great view. The place is not cheap, but if you want high quality, I recommend this hotel.
user_name:
Mo M
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Beautiful design lobby, hallways, rooms. Perfectly clean rooms and throughout the hotel. Perfect beds... the most comfortable of any hotel I have stayed at. Bathroom is large with all amenities including heated toilet seat. Best bathroom I have every experienced in any hotel.Restaurant buffet dinner has very large selection of items and variety of food types. Excellent tasting food and deserts.Very big gym with many machines, music headphones, televisions on machines. 5 minute walk to the subway. 10 minute walk to the active part of Tokyo where the night life is exciting and lively (bars and restaurants). Very safe to walk the streets at night.Hotel staff is VERY friendly and helpful. They made me very happy during my stay. They showed me all the details on how to get to Disneyland by Subway including maps.I will stay at the ANA InterContinental every time I go to Tokyo.

Having stayed in Tokyo a few times before, this hotel is very good compared to some of its competition. Room spacious enough , bed comfy, bar pleasant enough (but really pricey!). Down sides are number one: pool fee. A guest at a hotel of that stature should not be charged a fee to use the house pool - that is not acceptable frankly. Down side number two - it is not a very vibey area. If you like to get out and about and sample the local life and local bars, this is not the place to stay. We could find nothing in the immediate vicinity.For a business trip, a good hotel. For a holiday - maybe not.

Convenient rooms for Tokyo standards, however only couple of Japanese tv channels and thats it regarding the tv (not even CNN).Pricey hotel and quality is not up to price level.The hotel even dares to charge USD 30 per person per visit to the swimming pool. Outrageous for a hotel where you pay over USD 300 per night and unnecessary irritating for hotel guests.Average buffet lunch and dinner.

A bit of a haul from the airport but once you got there all was forgotten very grand hotel with good locations to all of Tokyo from there.As my office was next door I found it very good.Great view of the city

Stayed here for 2 nights post Fuji Rock festival 2014. Given we spent three days at the festival in 30 degree heat we were looking forward to a dip in the hotel pool only to discover that a dip was going to cost us 30USD each! We discussed our views with Hotel management and they gave us a one time free entry and told us that pool use was free for 'Corporate Guests' (but not those on Holiday!). Never the less none of us could believe the cost for hotel guests to use the hotel pool. Apart from the pool charge, the staff were incredibly friendly and helpful while the rooms were great value and well appointed.

I was very happy with our choice of hotel for our four nights in Tokyo. The ANA is classy and modern but with Japanese elements in the corridors and rooms. Being part of the Ark Hills complex there is a good choice of Japanese and Western restaurants close by including Starbucks if you don't want to queue for breakfast (it always seemed to be busy at the hotel). As with all big international hotels prices for drinks, coffee, dining etc are high however service and quality are fantastic. We ate at the Tempanyaki restaurant on the top floor which was an experience! There are also great views of Toykyo Tower from the bar on the floor below. The executive room was spacious with good storage. Beds were comfy but pillows were hard. It is a 5 - 10 minute walk to the subway station for the Ginza line with other lines also accessible here. My only complaint is that they charge approx $30 PER PERSON to use the swimming pool!! I have never heard of a charge for the pool and even a 'resort charge' is usually per room.

This is a good place to stay. Staff is friendly, hotel is very clean and well organized. The rooms although small in size have everything you need, and are quiet. The breakfast is stunning with a broad choice of Western and Asian food.... Definitely worth the price. This hotel overall is a good choice for a stay in tokio.

Good decent business hotel, rooms a good size (which is unusual in tokyo) and service was all round very good. Didn't actually eat in the restaurant so unable to comment on that.Two bars (that I visited) were both excellent. The lobby bar was nice and informal and the sky bar on the 36th floor was also good.Breakfast was, to be honest, a little bit disappointing for this grade of hotel. Buffet style and not very fresh with limited western options however plenty more choices so not a big deal.Hotel is very much downtown and is probably excellent for business users but we wanted to get out and find a little local bar and restaurant and it isnt really that sort of area unfortunately - cant blame the hotel for that.Lovely roof top swimming pool but why on earth must we pay Y3000 to use it as residents... Now that isnt right. Almost cost a point here to be honest. GBP18 for a swim... hmmm

Recently, on our trip to Tokyo, my husband and I stayed at Ana Intercontinental. It was our home base and we travelled back and forth to it as we made our way across Japan. Our first impression was that the hotel and room were very clean and the hotel had a north American feel. With Ambassador status, the check-in was very easy. We also had full access to the club level which was spectacular. The views overlooking the city were beautiful and the selection of food was always interesting with a variety of continental and Japanese cuisine. The pot stickers were the best I've had! The staff was extremely knowledgeable and polite and helped us from hotel. As it was my birthday, and my husband was attending business meetings, they even came out with a birthday cake and everyone sang happy birthday. It was above and beyond my expectations. They even arranged the best way to get to and from our planned locations. We travelled by Shikensen, Monorail, subway, bus and taxi (with taxis being the most expensive). All are easily accessed expectations. A special thank you to all the staff on club level, Junko Kano and her staff (Yuko, Kenichi, Seiki, Yuka, Kana, Mayuko, Sara and Ayaka) made our vacation a smooth and unforgettable trip. We hope to visit again some day! Also special thanks to Russell in guest services who went out of his way to ensure our visit was exceptional.

Have stayed in this hotel several times, best part of hotel is breakfast, rooms are not as per intercontinental standard, staff are super friendly and helpful, guys handling reception could improve their friendliness, rooms on higher floor have better views than lower onesOverall good place to stay

I have but one 'complaint' about this hotel and that was the size of the rooms. OK the room size was good FOR TOKYO (every trip to Tokyo I have ever had the hotel rooms have been small). If this was an Intercontinental anywhere else I would have been seriously upset at the room size. But in Tokyo the room size was actually pretty good. I stay in Intercontinental hotels a lot so I do get upgrades and obviously I expected something more impressive that I got.Apart from that rather lengthy negative comment for a relatively minor issue... The hotel was excellent and the staff were top notch. Had a bit of a problem with the Business Centre (arrived and there was a sign advising us to go to reception; went to reception and was told to go back to the business centre and someone would attend. They didn't. It took another trip to reception to get any assistance. The food choices were excellent (though this doesn't seem to extend to room service which was quite a restricted offering). So eat in the restaurants and you will be spoilt for choice.
user_name:
Christopher G
Immingham, England, United Kingdom

review_body: Stayed in this Hotel earlier this month. Great Hotel, similar to our Intercontinental Hotels. Travelled in a group with more than 15 people. However, check-in was a breeze. Was in the Lobby, checked-in and was in room within 5 minutes flat. Room was decently sized considering that it is Tokyo. View from the room was great. Breakfast spread was great and there were enough options for a vegetarian like me. However, the menu was repeated every day, which after a couple of days became boring. They should have some variety in the Menu. Overall, a great stay.

the suite from the size is really nice but it is definetly lacking design style…still it is very clean and well looked after…mini bar have moet champagne and swiss red bull…gym have all you need for a week stay…outdoor pool nice too but close already at 7pm！breakfast also lacking detail like all should be fresh juice as i know from other intercontinental and had to quee up when hotel was full…many tourist as well stay here…location best for night life shopping restaurants only can be better in newly grand hyatt！！！

Our very first Tokyo trip and we have chosen the Ana intercontinental hotel. We arrived at the haneda international airport. You have few options to get into this hotel. Taxi / airport buses and monorail. Taxi here is extremely high cost and the monorail option is you take from the airport and ride to the station call Hamamatsuo station. From there you catch cab about 15 minutes to arrive the hotel. The monorail cost ¥490yen and the 15minutes taxi cost below ¥1500yen. We have chosen the cheapest and most comfortable way from the haneda airport to Ana intercontinental. The airport bus, cost ¥1130yen per head and it takes you from Haneda airport right in front of the Ana intercontinental hotel. We arrived as early as 0900hrs and fully aware that the hotel check in time is at 1500hrs. We approach the reception to register ourself and surprisingly the polite and friendly reception staff allow us to check in at 1000hrs. Truly appreciate her very kind assistance and the considered on our situation, as we were extremely tired and sleepy after the long flight.The hotel overall looks grand and huge, room was in acceptable size approx at 30sqm. Super loves the bathroom amenities as they are providing shiseido products and most delightfully was there arefull big bottles of body gel, shampoo and conditioner. Unlike the other hotel provided those with small tiny of body gel which consider one time use. Room was clean and HSKP staff are friendly. We also approach the concierge at the lobby for the tour information, concierge staff were knowledgeable and friendly however we have to wait for quite sometime to our turn as there are only one of them on duty at the desk and they were plenty of guest is making inquiry. The hotel staffs are friendly and do speaks English very well. The hotel location was ideally as 5 minutes walk to the train station where you can access every where to explore the city. Overall we were happy with this hotels and the service provided.

The hotel is at a very easy location at the Roppongi neighbourhood with access to metro and taxi at the hotel front is plentiful as well. Room is in alright size with all you needed both leisure and business wise. Staff is very friendly.

We stayed at ANA Intercontinental for a week. Hotel was warm and inviting and would stay there again. Staff were all lovely, breakfast was yummy and staff very helpful when needed. We were upgraded to an Executive floor room which was a good size.The subway entrance is only 1 minute away but be aware there is a walk underground to platform. We tended to use subway in morning when fresh and then cab home when tired of walking. Only 1700 yen cab ride from main Tokyo station.We found some nice eating places especially in the little food area called Ark Kitchen. Twice we went to the Okonomyaki restaurant. Loved it.

Ana intercontinental Hotel is a great 4 stars and 1/2 located very close to Roppongi, the train station is Taimeke-Sanno which is in from of the entrance/exit 13. The location in very convenient and sometimes I walked from Roppongi Crossing to the Hotel, it is actually only 1,4km so it's a walk worth as it is a nice journey. Hotel is a big tower and rooms are quite big to be in Japan and very clean, you can get room service cleaning until 6pm. The toilets may need a refresh but they are very good anyway and standard is high, in the bathroom you can find branded shampoo, conditioner and soap. The price is fair as compared to the other structures at the same level ANA is cheaper. There are also nice bars and restaurants all around the building so you can even do not go out from the hotel and in the meantime do many things anyway!

Just spent a week in this hotel and must commend their staff on the service we received. Nothing was too much trouble. The hotel is very well presented and the rooms are a good size. The restaurants are quite expensive however a 2 minute walk to the neighbouring ark hills building and there are plenty of alternatives. Train station is very close. Great stay in Tokyo overall.

There is so much to like about this hotel: the location is great, the bed is really comfortable, the shower is seriously good, the bathroom amenities are useful and good quality, the housekeeping is consistently excellent, and the staff (mostly) deliver excellent service. And the aircon is seriously good and quiet - just what you need in a hot, humid Tokyo summer. And this is one of the very few hotels that have got the door-closing mechanism exactly right so that the door closes firmly but slows right down just before it closes so that it is nicely quiet. Sadly there are a few areas that let the hotel down: the smell in the bathroom of my room was awful - probably because of poor drainage from the wetroom arrangement, and not helped by poor ventilation. The room furniture (except for the bed) is small and the sofa is hard and not very comfortable as it has a low back. The food is just adequate - not as top notch as I had expected. The lobby restaurant buffet was mediocre and set up for snacking from bits & pieces - I didn't feel that I could create a coherent meal on a plate. And an expensive plate at that - 6000 Yen for dinner. The room service hamburger was fine - nothing special, but served in 20 minutes. I went to two of the restaurants in the hotel and was both times put at the worst table despite the places being about 70% empty. Service grew less friendly when I asked politely if I could sit at another table.

I have stayed here a couple of times on various trips to Tokyo. Located very close to Roppongi crossing/Akasaka business area, its pretty convenient (also with direct bus connection to Narita/Haneda airports). Having said that - the hotel itself feels quite old and rundown: the rooms are tiny and often smell smoky (even for non-smoking rooms); and the overall furnishings are badly in need of a revamp. There are better options out there in this price range.
user_name:
Jeremy R
New York City, New York

review_body: I stayed at the ANA; I cannot say enough about the staff - very helpful. The Bell Captain went out of his way to make sure I got where I was going (walking) that first day.I guarantee that I will stay at the ANA Intercontinental when I return to Tokyo.

The hotel is accessible by two subway stations "Roppongi 1-chome" and "Tameike Sanou", and is connected to nearby shopping centres with some restaurants, which is extremely convenient. The area is more of a business area with office buildings around. There's convenience store across the road, which is great for mid-night snacks. The room we were staying was not really huge but comfortable enough. Bed was comfortable, although the bathroom was a bit small and setting not really looked like a 5-star hotel. Breakfast was great and we enjoyed that very much every morning. Overall services had been good while staff at the front desk have been helpful too. This place will be on our list if we visit Tokyo again.

This hotel needs to update its business practices if it wants to compete. Charging over Y1600 for wifi? Check!Tiny and old bathrooms? Check!Extra charge for 3 hour late checkout? Check!Small selection of television channels with very poor picture quality? Check!And finally.....charging Y3000 per 'guest' to use the hotel swimming pool? Yes, that's what the ANA InterContinental considers hospitality. All up, it's a 3star property that gouges patrons at every opportunity. There are better places to stay in Tokyo. Would not recommend.

I stayed at this hotel for five nights a couple of weeks ago. I usually stay at Marriott or Sheraton hotels while in the US, and I must say that the Anna Intercontinental Hotel Tokyo is much better than those while being in the same price range. Rooms are almost the same size as rooms in the US, which is an exception in Tokyo. Rooms are nice and clean. The staff at the hotel is simply fantastic, particularly the tall Australian guy handling the luggage who helped us a million times and firmly refused to accept any tips (explaining us that it is not culturally appropriate). The location of the hotel is great, with a metro station right on the front door. From there you can get anywhere in Tokyo within a few minutes. It is within walking distance from Roppongi so you can walk there for dinner. Another plus is that you can get to the hotel from Narita just by taking the Limousine Bus for roughly 30 us dollars. It is quick and simple, and you forget about the stress! The only downside: avoid the breakfast, it is too expensive!

i was lucky to take a short week holiday in japan to see my daughter in a show.i booked this hotel on reviews given by other travelers.this hotel is first class top notch hotel. we managed to secure a great deal through dial a flight. cant reccomend highly enough.first class service,staff and facilities.

Stayed 5 days for business. Hotel is not new, and you can see it in details like the bathroom with a bathtub and a curtain, but everything works ok. Rooms a little bit smaller than standard for American hotels, but bed size is ok and they have a nice desk for working. Breakfast very good, with almost all choices possible and a very good service. Staff very friendly and helpful. Value for price ok. Location good, next to two different metro stations.

I stayed in this property for 4 days on business and was very pleased. It was beautiful, very clean and service was outstanding. I only give it four stars because of value but this is Tokyo, but I depending on your needs it is very worthwhile.Location was excellent to my office and just a short walk to Roppongi. There is also a convenience store across the street and a market in the adjoining building.I did not try any dining options other than room service the first night, which was good(Japanese curry). The buffet looked very good, but I cannot see myself spending $65.00 for any buffet regardless of what they were serving, but this is more of a personal choice.Overall Great Stay.

We stayed here for five nights while staying in Japan. Everything about the hotel is top notch - the rooms are big and comfortable and have everything you need, the restaurant and bar are really good, concierge very helpful and the location is great as it's right next to a tube station. I cannot fault this place and would recommend to anyone looking for a place to spend a few nights in Tokyo.

luxury hotel... take a high floor room to get good view.. located at the metro station and many indian restaurants nearby... at the best ... many restaurants available in the hotel itself.. the room size was small may be due to japansese standards

My husband, myself and our 3 college kids stayed here while touring Asia. We are from Chicago so we know big prices and we have traveled all over the world and stay in only 5 star hotels. This hotel was. Rey nice and the staff was extremely helpful, but we did not like that wifi was not included in the room price. We ended up getting the executive package that included breakfast in the executive lounge and free wifi. We had 2 rooms so it was 1309.00 usd extra for 5 days, which is a lot for breakfast and wifi. A room service pizza was 26.00. The hotel was beautiful and the room was nice and clean, not large but comfortable. We were a 10 minute cab ride to Ginza for shopping. The ana intercontinental is in more of a financial district vs a shopping or nightlife business. They do have a knowledgeable person at the business office who was able to ship our packages back home to the USA. They also have a cash machine and currency converter machine in the lobby which was wonderful and the teppanyaki restaurant was delicious.

At first sight this is a nicely decorated hotel, but a further look and a long stay shows lack of attention to details and average service. - Room was dusty, and sheets were stained. - Bathroom walls have yellow stains. - Concierge is very average in knowledge and kindness. Hospitality does not seem genuine. - Room key constantly broke. - Steam room available only for men, and they do not think that's a problem!- Mediocre room service. I ordered a curry, portion was very small and I found a hair in my meal. What they called Naan bread was dried pita. Japan is known for great hospitality and food, shame that the ANA does not keep up.
user_name:
TravellingSkirt
New York City, New York

review_body: I'm currently staying here with my boyfriend as we needed one week accommodation before we move out of Tokyo (so I am writing this as someone who lives in Tokyo). We chose this hotel because it was close to our offices and previous apartment. Also my future mother-in-law also stayed here for a few days in a different room. Her room was smaller and cheaper but still nice enough.The overall look and feeling of the hotel is nice, lovely lighting and ok perfume smell as you walk into the hotel. I'm a sensory person in this way and it is always a nice feeling of relief when I come back "home". The finishing looks a bit dated though; carpet is not very nice and the bathrooms in the rooms are plasticky and budget feeling for the price you pay.The staff try to accommodate and give good service, but seem limited in their problem solving ways until we went to someone who seemed like a Manager.For example, it took us three tries to check in due to some mixup with our reservation. We couldn't get a double bed, ok, sure, two beds is no problem. They then put us on a smoking floor (19th floor - even though it is a non-smoking room, it was very strong smoking smell...I mean we're on a smoking floor!). We asked to be changed to a non-smoking floor and the room (12th floor, I believe) looked like a downgrade, despite being the same "type" of room (smaller room, smaller 2 beds), which is pretty disappointing for the price, actually. We went down again, and being our third try and exhausted, went straight to a very polite manager-looking gentleman and he sorted us out right away with an upgraded room on the 24th floor, nicer view, one large bed for the both of us. The quality, space and room was noticeably better, but theoretically costed more than what we were already paying (and if we had to pay it, just doesn't seem worth it).Location-wise, it is convenient if you want to stay around Roppongi and your office is nearby. There are two stations close enough to walk to if you want to take the train to other areas, and taxi's aren't that painful if you need. A couple things that really bother me: * No sauna for women. It clearly states on their English website that there is a 24 hour fitness room and sauna facilities, yet the sauna apparently is only for men. I asked why and the lady at the front desk said for "security reasons" which does not make sense to me. It is false advertising and a huge disappointment, not to mention backwards and sexist feeling. Perhaps there is a good reason why this is, but they should have a better explanation prepared as to why.* Internet is not free and costs over 1600 yen for 24 hours. While our room apparently was included, it was not included in my mother-in-law's room, which I find silly that a luxe hotel like the ANA would make a fuss over something like internet. If we stayed at a budget hotel, fair enough, charge for any little additional thing, but internet at a very nice business hotel? =/* The pool is not free for hotel guests. It costs 3000 yen to enter the pool area for guests and 6000 for outside visitors. At least this is mentioned on the website but I would not bring a family here.Overall, it feels like a nice business hotel that is a bit dated and definitely overpriced for what it is (especially with internet being extra). You're paying more for location convenience if your office is nearby and a gym if you have time. I wouldn't stay here for a romantic or on a family trip (as taking any kids to the pool would be a ridiculous expenditure).

ANA Intercontinental is an extremely well-known top-of-the-line hotel in the heart of Tokyo. Its location is fantastic -- close to Roppongi and Ginza -- and has few of the best restaurants (including a Michelin Star one) in Japan's capital city. But I will remember the hotel for a few small things which go a long way...1. I was in urgent need of a adapter for my smartphone charger. I expected that I will face difficulty in explaining the thing to the staff but lo! The lady in question not only understand what I wanted in a jiffy, I had the adapter in my hand within a few minutes. I was relieved because I needed to speak to my family. And the adapter was with me for the next three days. Thank you.2. I didn't eat at the Michelin-starred restaurant. But I had dinner at Karin, the Chinese eatery, and I can say I perhaps had the best dim sums and Sichuan rice noodles outside of China or Singapore. It was really really good. And I didn't pay a bomb.3. The breakfast spread at the fantastic Cascade Cafe was superb, one of the best during my international stays. But I would like to thank the staff at the cafe who always greeted us with a smile, wished us well apart from delivering some of the best sausages, hams, breads and desserts. The smile and greetings made our day.4. I missed my designated bus to the airport on the morning of my departure, though my luggage. The lady concierge assuaged me, placated my frayed nerves, put me on the next shuttle and told me where amd whom to get my luggage from. For an Intercontinental group hotel, it is more than expected that rooms, facilities and amenities will be excellent. What prompts people to recommend friends to stay and repeat stay are these little personalised touches.Thank you

Have stayed at the ANA several times and really enjoy each stay.The location is central and if you are into jogging it's an easy run to the Imperial Palace, at night your a short, but roundabout walk to lots night life and restaurants. The hotel gym is good with everything you need.Getting access to the concierge lounge is worth it as the complementary food is first class and the view is nice....the bar upstairs also has evening Jazz and city light views.Ok...lots of good stuff, however, the rooms just are not on par with the rest of the hotel, they are comfortable for sure but on par with the nicer hotels in China.The staff is fantastic and I will continue to stay here in the future.

I had to give this hotel only three stars instead of four due to an issue I had before checking in, despite my overall pleasant stay here. Before my stay I had some issues with their online reservation system. According to the hotel staff, my reservation for two classic rooms (one for me and one for my parents) was confirmed, but whenever I checked my reservation online at the IHG site, only ONE of the rooms was confirmed and the other was CANCELLED per their central reservation system. Of course, I never cancelled any rooms. I brought this up with the English-speaking IHG customer service, and they kept insisting that I had reserved only one room instead of two. The Japanese hotel staff, however, always confirmed my reservation for TWO rooms whenever I called them. Unfortunately this issue was NEVER resolved before my check-in...the Japanese reservation agents on the phone couldn't understand that I couldn't find my reservation online. I got really tired going back and forth between IHG and ANA Intercon's hotel reservation staff, and decided that as long as I had the confirmation letters from the hotel, I would have those two rooms. For me, this issue was a really big minus because it showed a clear lack of communication between the ANA Intercon staff and the central IHG reservation staff. Thye should really work on this and not the guest burden him/herself with trying to figure out why their reservation isn't accurately reflected in the online system. Now for my actual stay. On the day I checked in, there was no problem whatsoever with my reservation. Lucky for them!!! ;) I was allowed to check in before my parents did, well before the regular check-in time of 3pm, which was considerate as I was exhausted from a long week and wanted to rest. The rooms were spacious and elegant, albeit a little dim even with all the lights on. My folks complained a bit about the airconditioning being too weak, but I found it OK. We all had a good night's sleep - great mattresses and linen. The bathrooms were very clean, although the fixtures were a bit dated. Nothing was lacking at all. We had the breakfast buffet at Cascade cafe in the lobby during our whole stay. Very substantial breakfast spread, although I think the Japanese breakfast wasn't a strong point. What we loved were the fresh fruit and veggie smoothies prepared every morning. My only suggestion for improvement would probably be the attitude of the staff at Cascade (the ladies in white uniforms, who were not servers). Sometimes they were slow to catch on to some of our requirements...that or their English listening skills were not very good. Other times they were standoffish and not as attentive as we had expected. A bit more fine-tuning is in order, I think! We ordered room service once and the staff who brought it to our room was extremely professional. The food was excellent too. If I would base my review mainly on my experience with their reservation system, I'd have to give them only two stars. Fortunately, our stay was very pleasant and we were overall quite satisfied! TIP: There's a small 24-hour supermarket (Seijo Ishii) in the ARK Hills complex of the hotel, should you get the munchies at odd hours. Good liquor selection, fresh fruit and microwaveable meals.

I must admit we were a little worried after reading some of the reviews. We had nothing to be worried about. Everything from check in, our room, concierge service was 5 star. The location is perfect for getting around Tokyo. The concierge helped us with anything we needed. If we were waiting for more than a couple of minutes another staff member would come up to help us. Thank you for making our first trip to Tokyo so memorable!

Stayed at the ANA Intercontinental Tokyo for a vacation. Rooms are not so clean, and eew! Bathrooms have a wet brownish stain on the side of the toilet. Bathrooms are very small. But the concierge service is wonderful! They are very helpful. Im not sure which concierge helped us, but i think Shinoubi Momoi was the one who helped us very well! Top score for you! I would suggest that you would stay at this hotel. Very close to anywhere! Just take the underpass and a supermarket is there! And also in Ark hills, many resto's there, also yummy! Oh by the way, very near the Tamieke-sanno metro station. Enjoy your stay here!

A nice hotel! Some previous reviewers complain about it being somewhat dated. I could not agree less. Really nice and clean rooms (with an unusually quite air conditioner). The executive lounge is definitely worth the extra money. The view and the service in the lounge are amazing (if you are lucky you might be able to see the silhouette of Mount Fuji from one of the windows in the lounge). I have only two complaints: There is an extra charge for the Internet and the front desk is not very efficient (strange mistakes that are hard to explain).

Very customer service focused, staff were extremely helpful and pleasant. Room was very clean and well appointed as is the rest of the hotel. I would recommend this hotel for service, location and great staff!

We choose this hotel as the location for our Tokyo stay this May. We stayed five nights and very pleased with the choice. A little downside is the size of the rooms, even the business floors we got upgraded to did not make the room bigger. The pictures on the hotel website flatter here. Luckily housekeeping forgot the baby bed rooms are too small but bed was big enough for all the family. A 1.5 year old tries to get into parent's bed anyway. Front desk and concierge are professional and friendly as are the main restaurant staff. We were extremely happy with the very kids friendly crew of the Japanese restaurant. by the way the chef and his cooking is equally good. Getting to and from the hotel is easy with public transport on the doors step.

I first got a smoking room which was terrible but then got exchange it for a non smoking room.Room was clean and well kept.Location is very central and close by the train station.Staff is not very helpful but they try

The hotel is located in between to train stations. It takes between 5 to 10 mins to walk to either. One of them has an excellent espresso bar in the underground shopping walkway to Roppongi Itchome which I would recommend. There is also a french style bakery in the shopping complex next to the hotel which I went often.Service at the hotel was excellent, rooms were clean and well-furnished. The exterior of the hotel may look a little old, but the interior is elegant and well deserving for the InterContinental brand.I really enjoyed my stay!

Located a stones trhow from the Tameike-Sanno Subway station offering three lines, the Ginza, Namboku and Marunouci Lines you can reach pretty much anywhere within 15-20 minutes. A short subway tide away is the famed Shibuya Crossing and Shipping District, the Upscale Ginza Shopping District, 20 minutes to the Tokyo Dome for ball bames and 20 minutes to Shimbukuu.Make sure you exit the subway through exit 13 or you will be walking a long way.The rooms are large for Japanese standards and actually fit in the Western Style rooms with King Beds, Flat Panel TV with CNN, BBC and American Channels like Fox, Work area, A/C. and daily paper. A much needed amenity after a long day out in Tokyo. Convenience shops located nearby and the Minato Twin Towers offers a food court next door if you do not want to eat in the Hotel.Located not in the mess of things but just a short subway ride (very safe) away from it all.Get a PASMO card and charge it up so you can ride buses, subways, trains and even shop at 7 Elevens with it, sort of like a charge up debit card.The staff is awesome and the amenities equal to or superior to any standards in the West. Make full use of the Concierge as they can direct you to anything you need, I even ordered Baseball tickets through them and they were waiting for me when I got back from sightseeing.I would definitely stay again.Carl (Redondo Beach, CA)

Big fan of this place. Check in was easy but wi-fi was not free unless you sign up for their rewards club (which we did at check in and was free and easy to sign up). The area is mostly business but is about a 20 minute walk to Roppongi and a 20 minute walk to the Imperial Palace. The 7-11 around the corner has a lot to offer (including green tea kit kats!). There's a Starbucks and Doutor nearby for coffee and sandwiches in the morning. Also the hotel is really close to the Tameike-sanno subway stop which took care of most of our transport needs. Pros:-The room is spacious; easily accommodates two people with an American style king size bed (though called a double bed when we booked).-The room and surrounding area is really quiet. Like, really quiet. I'm a terrible sleeper and normally have to sleep with earplugs. At this hotel it was so quiet I was able to ditch my earplugs and I slept like a baby. -The drinks at the bar on the 36th floor were very expensive but very good and quite creative.-The room's water pressure in the shower is great.-The bed is comfortable.-The A/C worked quite well.-The fitness center was spacious and had a lot of cardio capacity.Cons:-The lobby smells like old cigarette smoke which has been covered up with perfume. Gross. -The hotel bar on the 36th floor is nice and has a great view but is quite warm (no A/C?) and the service is pretty slow.-We only tried the eggs and sides breakfast once (not the buffet) and it was expensive and just ok. Nothing to rave about and the service was a little slow. Would definitely stay here again and would recommend it.
user_name:
redjillo
New York City, New York

review_body: The hotel itself is great. The rooms are generous for Tokyo. Location is close enough to railway system although not the JR line. But the worst thing I ever had was the service from the front desk. We were in Tokyo for a wedding and the rooms were already pre booked and paid for us by our generous hosts. But due to a spelling issue, they refused to give us our room. This would have easily been sorted out by telling us this, but they made us wait there despite our insistence for at least 1.5 hours. We explained the situation but they were unhelpful and not very dynamic in trying to get to the bottom of the name spelling inconsistency. The lady was also very rude when I asked how long will it take. They kept looking at us with impatience and frowning at us saying just wait!. Really? I have never met front desk people that rude. I refused to make scene because I did not want it to ruin my day. But really there is something wrong when you cannot figure out a simple check in procedure. You do not make your guest stand there forever and be fiddling with your computer without an end in sight. Our host eventually called and it was all sorted out by that. They could have called, but they decided to be rude and let us wait instead. Even if they give me a free room I will never stay in that hotel again. I hope nobody has to go thru that kind of service.

Older style hotel in a business district.We stayed here for the last day of our trip in Japan because of the close proximity to the fish market.which I have not seen during my previous visits.Check in was reasonable. Waited about 15 minutes for a room to be ready. We were checking in before the standard 3pm start. Offered an upgraded room on 23rd floor. Great views. Even better views from the club lounge on 35th floor.Staff on the club floor were wonderful.Room was clean and in good condition considering the age of hotel. Power outlets seemed lacking. Power outlet for the laptop used on the work desk is behind the TV, some distance away.Internet has reasonable but not brilliant speed.Club lounge had great offerings during cocktail hours and wonderful breakfast catering for locals and Westerners.One of the concierge team seemed really pushy for us to take hotel transport back to the airport at what seemed to be an excessively high price. Opted to use a taxi to Tokyo Station and catch the Narita express using our Japan Rail Pass.I would stay here again only if there was a need to be in this location. Otherwise would look for something in Shinuku Shibuya Ueno or Harijuku.

This is my favorite hotel for my business trip. Stayed at the executive floor with club lounge package. Room is a bit small considering its price. Use of the meeting is free of charge which is nice. Very friendly service in the club lounge. The lounge is quite large and relaxing. Snacks at happy hours are plenty and delicious. Excellent breakfast selection too. Have stayed there many times and will stay there again too.

This is a terrible hotel. The room was filled with cigarette smoke, and when I asked to switch, they told me non smoking was not guaranteed and they would do me a favor this time. From there it was downhill. I had breakfast with a guest who only drank coffee, and they tried to charge full buffet price. Not a luxury hotel....
user_name:
cmsknyny
New York City, New York

review_body: The ANA Intercon in Tokyo is a perfect home base for visiting Tokyo. The rooms are very high quality, although not fancy or opulent, the hotel itself is well staffed, and the location is very good.
