All-in-all, while its not a Park Hyatt or similar luxury experience, it fits the bill for a very good stay at a very decent rate, in a very expensive city. I highly endorse it.

This hotel was really special. Our room overlooked the Tokyo skyline and at night was spectacular. The service at the front desk was really helpful and nothing was too much trouble. We decided to eat in the Pierre Gagnaire restaurant...very special but be warned...very expensive! It really was an experience of a lifetime. The higher up your room, the more expensive it is, but so worth it for the views.

The service is always impeccable at this very classic Tokyo hotel . The restaurant selection is huge but I especially like the Top floor bar which has a really cool view and also the Japanese restaurant where I had the best traditional Japanese meal.

ANA is a great hotel with excellent restaurants. Had a great experience at Unkai Japanese restaurant where we had a truly enjoyable business dinner. I recommend it as a great option for a bit more upscale Japanese cuisine.

Exactly what you would expect from a top 5 star hotel in one of the world's major cities. Very clean, room a little small but that is often the case in Tokyo, seriously comfortable bed, and excellent polite and professional service. Close to the subway system. The buffet breakfast was worth every yen.

Very helpful and friendly staff..went out of way to help in booking resturants as we are vegetarian. Rooms were not up to mark. Desk top was chipped.if we ignore that, concierge , staff all were extremely helpful,polite,which made our 4 nights trip worth staying

Location of this hotel is pretty good. Short distance from the subway and Ropponggi Hills and Tokyo Midtown. As an IHG Platinum, I received an upgrade to a room on the highest floor (under the Pierre Gagnaire restaurant). The room is small-ish, but lovely. The bathroom is a bit on a small side but they managed to cramp in a tub, a shower, toilet and a sink. The shower fixture is nice, washlet great, but the finishes of the bathroom do not feel 5 star.Biggest disappointment is sound proofing. Even though I was on a high floor, I could hear sound of cars passing by all the way down from the high way. The internet speed is disappointing for Tokyo standard (Hyatt Regency Shinjuku takes top prize for this!).Service is impeccable.

This hotel is excellent all around! It is on the same block as the nearest metro station and is only a mile away from prime Tokyo destinations like Ginza, Tokyo National Museum, Tokyo Tower, the Palace and many more. The concierges are excellent at providing recommendations and the customer service is second to none. The meals are expensive, but there are stores downstairs where you can grab small pastries and such. I had the buffet breakfast at the hotel one day and it was the perfect combination of local food and food for all cultures. The rooms are easy to navigate, well updated, and expertly kept. The ANA InterContinential is worth every yin!

Great location, nice gym, but the room I had (18th floor) was in serious need of some updating. However, for the money, a solid deal in Tokyo. The staff is very friendly, and knowledgeable about what to do in the area. The restaurants at hotel are also good.

Great décor, good service, good sized rooms and bathrooms. Thankfully not as big as the other major hotels in Tokyo, so it takes 2-3 minutes to get from front door to your room - as opposed to the common 10-minute trip in the other hotels. The eight large elevators help, as the wait is short or non-existent.The cleaning staff do respect the "Don't disturb" and "Please clean" signs, a plus!Breakfast was good, with fresh ingredients, but not as complete as the competition: it only had a small "eastern breakfast" section.

Stayed here during a quick stop in Tokyo, and what a great base to explore the city, so close to Roppongi, the nightlife area... and only 5 metro stops to Shibuya... What more could you need... The hotel itself is large, with a great selection of restaurants and bars, the rooms are small and modern, bathrooms are a little dated, but have been maintained so you don't really feel it... Large selection of room amenities are offered.... All staff are more than helpful, able to answer many questions about Tokyo... Use the local knowledge! Will definitely return if I'm back in Tokyo.

Stayed for a full week at the ANA. Great location for business travellers, great buffet (dinner and breakfast), gym facilities and pool. Rooms are on the small side but standard for Tokyo. Staff generally have strong English skills and are very friendly and helpful.

I stayed at the Intercontinental for two weeks ending last Friday. The service and the facilities were excellent. Location was in fashionable Akasaka, very close to government buildings in Kasumigaseki, Roppongi nightlife, and also to trains to everywhere. The staff at the hotel were very hardworking and the service was excellent. The laundry service was extremely expensive, but very well done. Restaurant breakfast buffet was very nice, and had enough variety to eat every day for two weeks. The only downside I experienced was that my room, while very modern and convenient, was quite small - only about 6 tatami-mat sized, plus a tiny bathroom. I understand that hotel rooms are typically small in Tokyo, but this was smaller than expected for a business hotel. I'd stay there again without hesitation, but if room size is important to you, this is something to be aware of.

This was my second stay at the ANA Intercontinental - so I guess that says I like it.It's a very good hotel, well located, as you might expect for the price and the fact that it is an Intercontinental. The rooms are relatively spacious by Japanese standards and very well turned out, all the facilities you'd expect and nice clean bathrooms. (Small moan the corridor outside the room was very warm, but the room was fine and the air conditioning no problem).The hotel has a wealth of restaurants, and if there isn't something you like in the hotel, and you don't feel like wandering too far then there are a good number of restaurants in the complex in which the hotel sits. There are also supermarkets and shops nearby.There's a fabulous roof top bar, and if you want to impersonate Bill Murray in 'Lost In Translation' it's great place to sit and watch the sun go down, and indulge yourself in the 'all-inclusive' cocktail special. Careful though, it looks great value, but after your fourth martini you will definitely decide that having a pizza (extra charge) is worth it!Breakfast is buffet style catering for most tastes, and is very good.My only complaint is the hotel's attitude to Wi-Fi. I think I should state my starting position that all hotels should provide fee Wi-Fi, or certainly those that are charging a few hundred pounds for a night's stay! My booking said that 'Wi-Fi was included' but I was informed when I checked in that it was not. There was an attempt to get me to upgrade my room, on the basis the Wi-Fi would be included, which I refused. I was eventually told that if I joined the Intercontinental Member Club (free to join) I'd be given Wi-Fi free. This I duly did. What annoys me is that the Wi-Fi was not included in the (fairly steep) room price, there was a transparent attempt to get me to upgrade and then a capitulation to sense and reason. Note as well that if you don't stick to your guns technically the charge for Wi-Fi is PER DEVICE, so if you are traveling with your partner both have a laptop and a smart phone or tablet, you could get hit for 4 (or more) charges. At the rate they charge that could be heading north of £50 per day! Whinge over.Apart from that no real complaints, a happy stay and by-and-large helpful staff.

I recently stayed for a few months at the Tokyo Ana intercontinental. Overwhelming excellent service from the staff the knocks out a few small challenges with the hotel.Positive:- staff service level is perfect. They are always available, always smiling, without being in your face all the time. Exceptionally polite. They made the stay. As an example, I wandered up the club lounge when I was exploring the hotel (but I was not staying in a club room.). The receptionist commented quietly that it was not very busy, and invited me to stay for breakfast. (And, by the way, in the future I would recommend a club room for access to this lounge. Very peaceful.)- central location for this part of Tokyo. Easy to get around, and for runners, there is a nice run to the imperial palace. About a 7-8 mile run round trip.- everything in the hotel worked.Areas that were not perfect:- overall, the hotel is old, and it shows it. It feels 1980s in terms of style, and while everything works, it is a bit worn down. It could do with a facelift.- the gym was odd. It was certainly small for a hotel of this size (and was quite busy.). On top of tut, the way it is set up make the gym experience feel cramped and a bit unpleasant. Really needs to be in a bigger, brighter space. This felt more like a "check the box we have a gym" type of hotel gym.I would certainly stay here again.

We stayed for two nights and thought the location to be very convenient. It is close to a subway exit, Starbucks and a small grocery store. The room comes with a refrigerator, safe and free water every morning. It is a very safe location as it is right in the heart of all the embassies. The metro system takes you to any place in Tokyo in a matter of minutes and is cheap. The concierge staff were fantastic and went beyond duty. They told us about the Fish Market, a all day pass for the Metro, a special event at the Imperial Palace and even helped me mail a postcard back home. Thank you for all the great information and help in making our stay more pleasant.

I have thoroughly enjoyed 4 stays over the past 6 months and while it's not the most luxurious option in Tokyo (see Park Hyatt, Shangri La, Peninsula etc.) the service is friendly, the location is relatively convenient and rates are quite good value. As an elite member of the IHG Rewards Club I was impressed that various staff such as the Concierge and Club Lounge knew my name and extremely grateful for little things that staff kindly did for me such as noticing me in the line to check-out (knowing that I had a meeting to get to) and inviting me to a separate counter to complete formalities. Suite rooms are spacious and the upgraded amenities are thoughtful (TV in the bathroom, espresso machine etc.) Food options in and around the hotel are sublime from a decadent champagne bar in the lobby, to Tokyo's best Teppanyaki and then directly adjacent to the hotel a myriad of formal and casual dining options. It's a 10 minute walk to Roppongi or 5 minutes to the subway station. There is plenty of greenery around the property and hence plenty of jogging and walking options.

We went to Tokyo for an holiday and we found this very nice hotel. Very close to a tube station, the lounge was excellent, the room nice and the view amazing, especially by night. It looked like the movie blade runner. Very good breakfast, one of the best moment of the day.

I had high expectations for this restaurant, but found extremely high prices and small portions. Save your money and eat Japanese food in nearby restaurants. You can get much better meals for much less.

I felt compelled to write about ANA Intercontinental, Tokyo after our stay - in a good way! The room was a bit small by U.S. standards, but larger than most in Tokyo. Hotel is conveniently located near Roppongi area and the rooms are comfortable. We had one on 30th floor with great view, and the bed and linens were excellent quality. Bathroom is small but luxurious with top-of-line Toto washlet, powerful shower, and tub. They supply high-quality bath amenities also, a rarity these days. There is a huge buffet breakfast on the lobby level if you want that too. I liked the plentiful staff and they were well-trained, courteous and helpful. The only suggestion I'd make is to expand the Concierge desk a little to handle more guests, since that got very crowded at times. There are meeting rooms too but the hotel never seemed to be "overrun" by conference attendees. The subway station is close by for commutes. We did not sample the in-house restaurants. The hotel was quiet, and I especially appreciated the soft closing doors! Maid staff was shy but did a good job too. Air-Con in room super quiet. A big improvement since my stay 3 years ago: Free wireless throughout! I'd easily stay there again and recommend it. Price is reflective of the more luxury chain.

Quite simply this is the best business style hotel I have ever stayed in. I ran The Tokyo Marathon in February and chose to stay here. The manager Markus went out of his way to come and say hello and wish me well, the staff follow his lead when it comes to elite level service, nothing is too much trouble and efficient doesn't get close to describing the level of detail here. My room was always clean, had every facility I needed and had a magnificent view. Talking of views, Junko in the Club Lounge will not only provide you with top level hospitality but also THE greatest view whilst eating breakfast you've ever see in a city hotel. Access around the city is great as The Metro (with English signs) is 200 yards away. All staff spoke excellent English in this hotel. Then there's the food, wow. Choice, quality and worldwide cuisine were in plentiful supply here. If you want a guaranteed high quality hotel which has the ability to make you feel relaxed in such a busy city, pick this one. You won't be disappointed. Ian

This is my second review of this hotel. Last time I was here in summer and wrote about the crazy expensive pool policy. This time it is Spring and so I had hoped to relax and watch a movie in the room. No such luck!! This is probably the only high end hotel I have ever been in without a dedicated movie channel. So I decided to work on my PC with the wifi provided. Japan has one of the fastest broadband networks in the world, but this hotel's wifi was very slow. Maybe I was just here at a busy time, or maybe they need to upgrade. Other than that, the room is very nice and comfortable and the hotel is in a good location. Staff are very friendly. However, one gets the sense that they are trying to cut costs. This hotel seems to be fine unless you like movies or working wifi. For a movie lover like me....I will not be coming back here until they introduce decent in-room entertainment.

My husband & I stayed here for 5 nights as he is a ambassador member we had a very nice view from our room, also had use of the club lounge, throughout the hotel the staff were extremely helpful & we eager to ensure guests enjoyed there stay.

Terrific stay. The location is fantastic. It is walking distance to the famous Roppongi district. The room was very nice. There was a cool frosted glass panel between the bed area and bathroom that allowed natural light in the bathroom. The concierge was great, and helped me plan some touring in Tokyo on a very tight timeframe. I would highly recommend this hotel!

Spent a week here on my recent trip to Tokyo, and had an amazing time. Staying at an Intercontinental feels like coming home, and this hotel is no exception.We stayed in rooms with Club access and the staff in the Club were fabulous. Professional yet unobtrusive, eager to help and assist where ever needed. The offering in the club is great, how any one below could complain of the food offering is beyond me. The breakfast offers a selection of everything you could want, and drinks and canapés are a great way to finish off a day of site seeing. Try and be back one day at 2.30 for afternoon tea so you can try the divine hand made chocolate cones.Rooms are well equipped, the TV in the bath is a nice touch, particularly as I got into the swing of the art of bathing Japanese style.The location is perfect , on the door step of a subway station, and convenient to every where. Truly recommend.PS Thanks Junko- your team are amazing!!

Great spot to stay, rooms a little small but normal for Tokyo, very comfortable with charming staff. Just a short walk from Roppongi and with two subway stations very close the city is easily manageable.

We were there on a 5 days businesstrip. My husband did the business and I was a tourist. We bought access to the lounge on 35 th floor. That was a really nice and friendly place. The staff was the best, smiling and helping all day long. The breakfast was delicious, cakes and cofee at teatime very nice. And the small dishes in the evening was soooo good. Quality all the way! We tried the other restaurants in the hotel and they were all good. The room was nice and comfy, clean and big for Tokyo. The fitness center was also very good with the very best equipment. A short stroll to the metro. All in all a perfect stay. We will be back!!

Intercontinental Hotels are always great and rarely,let you down but this one is exceptional. The hotel was one of understated elegance in a very handy location. We stayed in a junior suite with club access. Club staff were exceptional, made us feel totally at home without ever being intrusive. Nothing was a bother - maps, directions,recommendations etc. Junko and her team are to be congratulated on their efforts in club lounge - service, food and beverage, offerings, ambience are second to none. They minded our bags for a week while we tripped around, when we returned our suite was ready for us with bags inside, - absolutely no fuss. Check in and out were seamless - all done in the exclusivity of the club lounge. As Ambassador members, our amenities were delivered to our room ' on arrival' - something that hasn't always happened elsewhere.Thoroughly recommend this hotel- have a splurge and go club- these experiences stay with you a lifetime.

This is my 2nd trip to Tokyo but first time at ANA InterContinental. I traveled with friends and family of 18 people. We stayed for 4 consecutive nights. Hotel is located on Roppongi area. Room facilities, decoration is nice. Breakfast buffet line is superb with all kind of foods one would imagine. Our group had a dinner at one of the hotel Japanese restaurant and it was a great meal. A must try if you stay here, authentic Japanese taste with nice Japanese garden view.Strongly recommend this hotel if you are lucky enough to successfully make a reservation because it was 100% full when we were there.

Stayed here is part of a three day trip to Japan. The staff was friendly helpful and spoke very good English. Most importantly the da Vinci bar had very good cigars and a very good selection of scotch. Location was good for being close to metro was easy to get around on foot in a very safe area.

Try to ask for one of the higher floors where you should find the rooms are renovated and much nicer. I've stayed here a few times for work and holidays and the room this time round is on one of the lower floors (10th) and a bit dated in terms of fittings, there is also no complimentary water in these rooms and the shampoos are those attached to the wall in large bottles. TV has hdmi ports but no usb connection. Air conditioner is one of the quietest I've experienced. Power points in easily accessible places, including next to the bed so you can charge your phone and keep it in easy reach for the early morning alarm. All up, not a bad room but better options for the same price on levels 20 and above which come with complimentary water and premium hotel toiletries.

Our room had a splendid view of lovely cherry blossoms all over the block right behind the hotel and a stunning view of the Tokyo Tower directly in front of us.. While that was great, they had a really weird glass window between the bathroom and the bedroom! It did have a Venetian blind inside, but at an angle, we could still see each other! As we were a couple, it didnt bother that much, but I was still a bit uncomfortable that I didnt have 100% privacy in loo! The location was quite good with a nice shopping mall next door.. The train station was under the shopping mall which made it very easy - however, note that only the Nomboku line calls at this station so you will need to change trains for most touristy places. Also, if you are planning to get to the Haneda airport in the morning, plan well ahead! Their shuttle bus to Hamamatsucho doesnt start till 8:30 AM or so - so you will need to book a taxi to get there and then take the monorail to Haneda Airport.

I stayed 3 nights. Located in Roponggi District. The hotel is 5 mins from the subway thus, it is easy to get around, There is also a limousine bus service at the hotel to Narita Airport which is convenient especially with big luggages.The staff are friendly and helpful. I was hoping for a bit more for the breakfast at the lounge on 35th Floor. However, the lounge was a good place for business and the view from the lounge was good. The room is quiet with very fast wifi connection. The bed is comfortable I had a room facing Tokyo Tower. Would stay here again.

Ana Intercontinental Minato Tokyo was an absolute treat. Its proximity to the metro connecting to all lines is anything from 2min to 5min walk. Roppongi is also the new night life district and walking to the bars/restaurant area is another 15min walk. Having said that, the staff were great. The lady behind the concierge desk was the really helpful. She recommended things to do according to the time of day and the crowds. She even provided us with maps and metro routes. You can buy the day pass to the metro from the concierge which is cheaper than buying it at the metro and super convenient. The place was 5 star from the time we walked in to the time we left. The view from the room was facing the Tokyo Tower :) The hotel is very affordable as well. Would definitely stay here again.
user_name:
Munira H
Dubai, United Arab Emirates

review_body: The staff was friendly and helpful even in the hotel's and city's busiest period -during IMF meetings. Breakfast was good. And the bar at the roof was an attraction. It is a well designed, beautifuly constructed, good 5 star hotel with Perfect location in Tokyo.

I stayed 4 nights for business. I had not told the hotel I was a non-smoker but they moved me without any complaints and sent the bell boy to help.Breakfast was excellent, coffee pretty good.I walked to my office and several restaurants.Close to subway and Roponggi district.If you come from Narita airport use the limousine bus service. Superbly well organised, cheap and very easy.

I stayed in this hotel for 3 nights in April on a business trip. The location of this hotel is well placed, subway entrance just at door step and attached to Ark Mori building with lots of restaurants and cafe.However, this hotel's interior requires a major upgrade in order to keep up with times. Over a span of 10 years, I stayed in this hotel several times and it looks the same. Some examples:1. Taking a shower in the bath tub could be acceptable 10 years ago but today, it is really annoying.2. Asked the house keeping staff to put away the ironing board but 3 hours later still seeing it in the room. That is not acceptable.Hope to see a major uplift in my next trip.

It is interesting that Hotels although carrying the same name are that different after all. I booked the club room with lounge access. The breakfast, happy hour etc. selection in the lounge is poor. Portions are somewhat pre-set and tiny. (There are only 4 pancakes at a time on display etc.). Facilities are aged but maintained. Service was efficient but did not leave any impression. I would come back but not because it was great but because it was not bad. Flexibility does not exist in this Intercon as well. Happy hour is until 8. At 8:01 there is no chance of getting another drink.

The location is not too bad.Some of the staff are nice and some are just a pain.Will probably stay at the Keio Plaza Hotel in Shinjuku next time.There is a 7-11 almost next door as well a subway connection.The breakfast is not too bad if you can have it included in your rate.I tried to use my Ambassador Gold membership for a free night with the certificate they sent me but was told I could not use it, so I ended up using it in Seoul

This is Hotel is always my choice in Tokyo.An Excellent Hotel and great service1.- Executive club is a good choice. Great view, good attention and multiple choices in food and beverages. Breakfast also very good, In case you don´t have access to the lounge (which was my case this time) the breakfast at the lobby is also fantastic. Chef will prepare in front of you your choice in eggs as you wish2.- Very good location and close to main tourist attractions. My favorite sushi restaurant in the area is 2 minutes from the hotel (in the same block) : Tsukiji sushiko jin3.- Good gym, even though I miss a good spa with indoor pools and wet sauna. They only have one sauna.4.- Rooms are quiet, options for pillow and comfortable bed. Air condition is also in good condition and not noisy5.- Internet connection (wired and WIFI) very fast. Good connection6.- Great views from the rooms (see pictures)Personnel is great and willing to service, Oriental kindnessPlease click in "yes" if this review was helpful for you

I stayed here two nights while in town visiting our our office in the Tokyo Midtown building. Normally I stay at the Ritz Carlton there because it so so convenient and our corporate rates at these hotels are not that different.There were huge differences in the hotels, and as the review says this one was nothing special.Pros:Breakfast was good and 1/2 the cost of the much nicer one at the Ritz.Comfortable bedQuietI enjoyed the morning walk to the officeCons:Tiny roomExpensive internet that worked only so-so for me on my brand new laptopMediocre and expensive foodLow bed - I know it's an Asia thing but this is a western hotel. I think they keep the beds low to make the room seem bigger than it isFailed at the basics - iron didn't work properly and no English instructions, window badly fogged all the time, so-so staff (how many times do I have to ask for coffee with my breakfast before I get a cup?)Overall, just very uninspiring to me.

The Intercontinental in Akasaka has slowly been gaining a reputation as a bastion of food innovation. And I don't doubt that for a bit. I have been dining in some of the restaurants [there are 11 in this hotel], and I must say it's quite an experience. And for those of you searching for a culinary experience like no other, look no further than here. Among all the restaurants, the simplistic beauty of the food at The Steakhouse shine, the dishes were executed perfectly, and the bright colors of the ingredients made it a feast for the eyes as well as the stomach. At the Teppanyaki restaurant at the top floor is all about absolute respect for the finest of ingredients, and if the food itself is what you love, this is a must visit with unequalled qualityWe visited MIXX restaurant where they are offering Italian buffet, featuring appetizers, pasta dishes cooked a la minute, mains, desserts…..the buffet is offering traditional Italian cuisine and there is where we spent our weekend too, they do have Mediterranean brunch on Saturday and Sunday….

Do not expect to be WOWed at this hotel, and do not ask the concierge for assistance.If you do find yourself asking for assistance, be sure that they will give you incorrect directions and send you to buy necessities at the next door super market which is at least x 3 the price. It is a crowded business hotel, with no personal touch and 800 rooms, located off a noisy and busy highway. The plus side to the location is that you will be 10 minutes walking distance from Roppongi Hills which has some great restaurants.Yes, it is clean, and they will replace your soaps every day (and even trash the used ones, for waste?) but do not expect a touch of Japanese hospitality.
user_name:
TravellingSkirt
New York City, New York

review_body: This hotel never disappoints, staff are helpful, rooms are clean and modern. Club lounge is fantastic in every way. Only downside is its a little further from the railway station, its a least a 1km walk underground. The surrounding area is OK, but not a lot near by.

Everywhere in Tokyo are people friendly. So the hotel staff is not an exception. Rooms are a decent size and ours included wifi and breakfast. Wifi works perfect and breakfast has something / plenty for each taste. We tried 2 restaurants, the Unkai and the Steakhouse. In both cases, we were disapointed. Our waiter at the Unkai could not speak english and we did not expect him to. But the hotel should provide an english version of what you eat. It was good but not to make a detour . We experienced an authentic japenese restaurant later during the week and I must admit that Japenese cuisine at the high end of it is not a favorite of ours. As for the Steakhouse, the plates are not dressed in an appetizing manner and served dry. Our waiter there was just perfect. The subway station is right across the street, very convenient. The hotel is just close enough and just far enough to always have a 15-20 minutes walk to somewhere/ anywhere. If I were to return to Tokyo, I would chose an hotel closer to the Tokyo Train Station. And if you prefer taxis, there are always plenty at the front door. A word for the concierge service : very efficient.

After staying for years, I'm saying good bye to the Park Hyatt Tokyo... and hello to Intercontinental ANA. Why ??? 1) The service at Park Hyatt has wained, they do little to go out of their way to assist you with special requests. Even non challenging requests are met with a stone faced " I'm sorry!"... Versus ... IC ANA ... smiling, finding solutions, and a true effort to make you feel at home. 2) Location... sure Shinjuku is king for department stores shopping, interesting restaurant's and vibrant night life... but IC ANA located in Akasaka... to the right of Roppongi and left of the Ginza is a undisputed wonderful location for food, night life and culture. 3) The rooms... the IC ANA have all the same trick features(auto shades,wonderful bathroom features) and while the ceilings or floor levles may not be as high... but scoring a room at IC facing the Imperial Palace, garden and the various ministry buildings is far superior to PH's rarely visible, mostly obscured view of Fuji, I've been a regular visitor to Tokyo for 30 years and I have no idea what took me so long to discover this value for this top notch property in a sea of over rated/priced competitors.

This is an excellent option for Tokyo city. I have stayed in many hotels in Tokyo, being in the city in moderate frequency for business. Hotels I have stayed in have either been extremely expensive or lacking facilities. ANA intercontinental offers great facilities, good location at a reasonable price. Location is very easy to navigate (in Akasaka area, near Roppongi), and all taxi drivers will know it. A couple of subway stations are within 5 minutes walk. Facilities are complete, with a gym, restaurants, etc. Hotel wifi is good, and very easy to use. Try to get breakfast included in your room as this is not normally the case. I would come back here.

I stayed here for four nights on business, and can recommend it as a good but expensive hotel for central Tokyo. Staff are well-trained and everything is done efficiently, from check-in to departure. Rooms are spotlessly clean and comfortable, and come with all the usual creature comforts. Breakfast is a splendid array of foods with something for almost everyone. There are several other restaurants and bars, which are all pretty high-end and expensive - you even need a reservation for the bar on the 36th floor (at least for seats by the windows). It's about 10 minutes' walk from the main street of Roppongi, and also only about 3 minutes' walk from the nearest metro station. I can't really fault this hotel, and it's certainly great for the business traveller but I probably wouldn't stay here for leisure - I would prefer somewhere smaller and a little more personal.

I ended up booking at this hotel simply because there were no other hotels available in central Tokyo due to the Cherry blossom season. Stayed here fro 2 days, the breakfast was delicious, the bed super comfortable, the bathroom and the amenities were really nice. Over all nothing bad to say about this hotel really...the only downside is the location...unless you tend to stay in Roppongi or like the area i wouldnt recommend...But i think its a personal preference, i like to stay closer to Shibuya but thats just me...Roppongi although really nice, it lacks on things to do at night unless you are going clubbing...But i had a really nice stay for 2 days and have absolutely no complain about service or the hotel itself :)

Between the sewer smell on the end rooms, and the terrible air freshner they use to mask the back flow drainage problems, I'm not sure how anyone can stand to stay in this hotel. Our company must get a real deal at this hotel, as many have complained about headaches we're still using this hotel. Like most high rises, you can't open the window or get any fresh air.

While the room was fine and the location is good, I had several horrible and unhelpful experiences with the concierge there. Unlike everyone else that I met in Japan, the two different women that I spoke to there were incredibly unhelpful - refusing to provide recommendations for restaurants ("If you walk down these streets you will see lots of restaurants, just pick one.") or helpful directions to locations ("streets don't have names, you need to just figure it out."). I understand streets don't have names, and that there are lots of restaurants but you turn to a concierge to help provide guidance in these situations. Further, each time I had a question for the concierge, I had to wait while 3-4 other guests were ahead of me in line. Clearly understaffed. Same thing was true of check in and check out.I spent a lot of time debating over which hotel to stay at and mistakenly chose this over several Japan hotel chains that were significantly cheaper (over $100 less a night). I write this review so that others know not to make the same mistake. If you are there solely on business, or your itinerary for your trip is completely taken care of, it may be a fine place to stay. But, if you are looking for any guidance or help during your stay, avoid this hotel at all costs.

Large hotel very close to Roppongi and other central Tokyo locations.In line with the rest of Japan the staff are always very efficient and friendly 99% of the time. I had a king size bedroom which is a good size and very comfortable bed and spotlessly clean. The Cascade restaurant is the main hotel restaurant for breakfast - get there before 7.45 am otherwise you will have to queue to get seated and could end up a long way from the buffet. They do serve a great buffet with a selection of western and local dishes. I didn't try the other restaurants although the Mixx bar on the 36th floor is a cool place to get a cocktail especially if someone else is paying!They have a good gym which is open 24 hours - no rowing machines though!A tip - if you arrive at Narita airport and don't have too much luggage and have just missed the shuttle bus to the ANA Intercontinental take the shuttle to the Hotel Okura as the two hotels are 5-6 minute walk apart!

Good location though it took 2 hours from Narita by train/tube (better option on the way back was the coach transfer, under 90 mins). No issues with the hotel and wouldnt hesitate to recommend it.though expensive, the breakfast was pretty good and served close to the impressive lobby.

We stayed here for a week when we went back to Japan .As we used our mileage point ,We didn't spend much.The room was cosy and spacious enough for two people.And the view from our room was nice.It's very convenient to access Ginza,or Yurakucho area for shopping.

I had a chance to return to the ANA after several years of not being in Tokyo and i was once more quite happy with my stay. The rooms are comfortable and decent size for Tokyo. The bed is excellent. The executive rooms are a bit larger and much nicer (especially the bathroom) but costs an extra 6000 yen. Breakfast is excellent but costs over 2500 yen. The lounge on the 36th floor is nice and has great views. The lobby is comfortable and has lots of restaurants and lounges. Location is convenient to various restaurants, supermarkets, cultural sites and other activities and there's a subway station near by. So this is definitely a good choice for a Tokyo stay.

Poor heating so it was freezing in room! Got a photo of condensation on my window it was so cold. When was the last time you saw this in a hotel room? Shows How poor the insulation is here. Rooms are quite small so It's really a business hotel

I came to Tokyo on business and we stayed here at the ANA Intercontinental. There are plenty of amazing restaurants within the hotel, plus it's either a quick taxi ride to other neighborhoods or a quick walk to the subway to get elsewhere in the city. The first floor cafe was amazing. Out first night we had the buffet and tried all kinds if dishes. The rooms are spacious, especially for Tokyo standards and the staff were always available to answer out questions. My only caution would be to make sure to ask for a non-smoking room if that's important, as one of our party had a smoking room and it was choking.

It was my second time to stay at this hotel and the previous one was about 6 years ago. I remember my stay then and thought that if every I had meetings in the area in the future, then this hotel was very likely where I would be staying. It just so happened that the next meeting happened last February. I think the hotel is still very good in terms of service and the staff were very helpful in arranging for our transport to the airport. It is try near the metro stations so it is a convenient location especially for post seminar or post meeting activities to explore Tokyo or do some shopping. The only thing I can criticize the hotel about is perhaps their pillows. I did have a good sleep every night but it could have been better if they had firm pillows rather than the flat ones that seemed to have seen better days (or nights). It is time to change them for the benefit of clients. Still, overall, I think the hotel is very good and bordering on excellent.

First visit to Tokyo & this hotel, though I've stayed at many Intercontinental Hotels elsewhere. Great location, great room & great service. VERY helpful arranging transport and advising on local sights.

After staying in other great hotels in Tokyo, wanted to try something new in the middle of Roppongi. Big mistake. For the exorbitant prices they charge, I could have had 2 nights at the Okura for every one night at the ANA, with better service and more personal touch. Thank god for Russell the guest relations manager, who at least would help with alleviating some of the lack of "service" provided by this place. Lesson learned, next month in Tokyo, back to the tried and true.

My boyfriend and I stayed here on Christmas Eve. The room was cozy, but the bed was gorgeous. The view of Tokyo Tower was also breathtaking. Their breakfast buffet had a more-than-expected variety of food. They even cook pho on the spot for you!And we bumped into Santa Claus on the elevator... he gave us a candy cane.

I stayed here recently for 6 nights with my husband. Taking a cue from some of the previous reviews i requested a newly refurbished room high in the building and was given one on the 28th floor. The room was comfortable and quite spacious. One of my colleagues was unfortunately given a room which smelled of smoke and had to be relocated to a less salubrious room to avoid this. This is a very busy hotel with people coming and going in the lobby all the time. I found the Concierge staff to be excellent especially as this was my first visit to Tokyo and they assisted me with restaurant bookings and directions. On a few days breakfast overflow was relocated to the restaurant high up in the hotel and this was fun because you could see Mount Fuji as the weather was clear and fine. The pastry shop was excellent and served a good take away coffee and excellent pastries and some salads to take away. The Unkai restaurant was disappointing and there is better food to be had in Tokyo. The conference food was very fresh and tasty. The metro is about a 10 minute walk away but the system is a fantastic way to see Tokyo. I also arranged to have my suitcases couriered to the airport and the system worked fantastically well for around 2000 yen per bag it is called takyubin and the Concierge and the bell desk did all the paperwork. Overall a very good stay with lots of plusses

Customer ServiceExcellent! simply put Japanese are very polite, all the time, during my stay I never met a Japanese that was rude to me, but at ANA they take it up a notch (or two), they really excel at this and they go out of their way to help you with anything. Example, I was at the lounge in the lobby and was running out of battery on my laptop... I asked the waitress if there was an outlet nearby and she went running to her station to find a power chord and brought it back, pulled the outlet out of floor and connected by charger..(amazing).I've traveled quite a bit and I had never ever experienced such level of customer service, and it was refreshing and absolutely delightful.Sleep QualityThis is where the Hotel suffers a little bit, at least on my room on the 18th floor facing east, the wind seemed to tap a wire or something causing a knocking noise outside the window only a few nights... but it was bad enough to report it to front desk, sadly they were fully booked that night and later I just didn't want to bother packing and unpacking again just to change rooms.Other than that beds are comfortable and big, although they have no linen under the cover, which I found weird but I had no problem with it.DiningRestaurants are good, and the Cascade Cafe has an excellent breakfast buffet (for lunch and dinner not so good in my opinion).In the Steak House the food is incredible and the service, again over the top.MIXX Bar and lounge... the views are breathtaking, the bartenders will remember what you drink.Concierge service is excellent, taxi service is excellent... actually the only thing that was kind of disappointing was the Fitness Room, which seemed a bit too small for my taste, but since I injured by calf running the first night I got there, I had to forget about the machines for the rest of my stay.Overall, the hotel is very very good, and as usually is with good things... it comes with a price tag, but it is worth it.

Having stayed at this hotel many times, I discovered the rooms on upper floors have a better motif and eye appealing decor. The 25th floor, for example, has newer furnture and lighter colors, a positive move away from the brown and orange on the lower floors. The room sizes are the same but the motif, a more modern Japanese feel, is definitely more appealing.

ANA Intercontinental is in a perfect location: a short taxi ride away from Tokyo station and walking to Roppongi with tons of great restaurants. The hotel itself is in a fair condition. The room is fairly big by Tokyo standard. Housekeeping and maintenance are great. Staff are very friendly and helpful too.

I would definitely recommend the ANA Intercontinental if you are planning on staying in Tokyo. The location is great. The train station is a little far (about 15 minutes walk) so don't be fooled that the entry to the train station is quite close because you will be walking underground for ages. The location works because you are going against the peak flow of morning commuters so the trains were usually pretty empty. The hotel facilities are 5 star and our room had an excellent view of the city. Definitely more for couples than families. Order the tiramisu from room service (it is to die for!).

Stayed there for 2 nights, good location. Large lobby and staff are nice. Rooms are a bit older, amenities are great. Beds are very nice and soft!! Staff speaks English.No free wifi in lobby or in room. You can pay $16USD per day for in room wifi. I hope they can improve to this since so many other hotels offer free in room wifi or in the looby. Will probably stay at another hotel since there are so many options in Tokyo.

ANAI is a very nice hotel and they pay attention to the little things which made my stay more enjoyable - Keurig coffee machine, cosmetic mirror with light, ion hairdryer, bathtub pillow, L’Occitaine toiletries… I was lucky this time to get a spacious room with a good view (vs. a small room with an odd layout last time.) Room service was fast and the dinner buffet at Cascade was quite good. The staff was attentive and very eager to help. I think I made them feel bad when I insisted on carrying my luggage to my room! Its location in the westernized business district is not my favorite, and I prefer Ginza.

I stayed just one night, and wished I was booked for longer. The staff was attentive, the standard double room was superb, and they met my request for a high floor. The hotel location is extremely convenient, very near the Ginza subway line. The room was clean, and very well-equipped, with free wifi (I am an IHG member), free coffee and biscuits and two bottles of water. the concierge's desk was always staffed and there were free maps and free advice. I took an organised one day trip around Tokyo which I thoroughly enjoyed.

Hotel room was very nice, clean and comfortable. Staff was very friendly and willing to help. Sea salt for bathes was a nice touch after a day of walking. I also had a very nice view of the Tokyo tower from my room. My big complaint was the breakfast buffet. First of all, their was a long line to get seated for breakfast then I was not impressed with the selection or perhaps how it was arranged. I had to get up from my table and ask for coffee service. This was the cascade cafe. It was the only restaurant open for breakfast in the hotel.

I've stayed here a few times, and it's generally a solid experience. Located just a few blocks down from Roppongi, it's got a great location, and nearby immenities like Starbucks, restaurants, supermarket which make it a nice option for business or family - well, if you're entertaining your family at the hotel. Service is consistently first class, at all touch points. The little squeaks are things like the water isn't hot enough, and sometimes you can't get the room you want so you're sleeping on a double bed. But, dollar for dollar, can't really beat it if you need something of this calibre in a central location. BTW, I haven't tried the restaurants because there's so much stuff nearby - from fast-food to ramen, so step outside to save a lot of money and probably have a better meal. I'm a bit harsh on this one, unnecessarily so - because i do really like this one.

This hotel is in a reasonable hotel, close to the JR line (5 min taxi ride) and a subway station is directly outside. As we stayed in early January we were aware that there would be some limits to restaurants outside of the hotel due to new year and as a result we ate quite a few times in the hotel. Unfortunately we thought the quality of the food did not match the high prices.We were also quite frustrated on check -in as there seemed to be a problem with with our room (booked through the Ana intercontinental website), and the staff member at the desk spoke quite limited English. It was the assistance from an Australian staff member who saw we were tired and waiting a long time at the desk who stepped in, fixed us up with tea and coffee and an upgrade on our room. This was much appreciated. The room was lovely and well appointed with a good view of Mt. Fuji in the morning. With our upgrade came free wifi but if you were in a cheaper room it was around $15 a day. This was the only hotel that we stayed in Japan that charged for wifi.The concierge desk was fine and helped with reservations, but we did fine it a bit amazing that for such a large hotel, that were was often only one person at the desk to help the queue.

The best part of my stay in ANA intercontinental is the staff. All speak good english and all were helpful. I booked the room one month in advance and asked from the Concierge their help in booking 2 tough sushi places (Mizutani and Jiro). They were able to book the two sushi place for us! This was the highlight of our trip. On the day we were supposed to go home, Delta emailed our flight was canceled. The Concierge (specifically Mayanagi-san) called Delta and help us clear things through. (the US leg of the flight was canceled but ours will push through with a different flight code). The rooms are ok! We stayed at the Jr. Suite. Its a big room with modern touch. I am an ambassador member so internet was free otherwise its another USD15 per day.There is a train station (Ginza line 06) beside the hotel but there is a bit of a walk underground. (7 min) to reach the train.There is nothing much to see in the area but its a walking distance to Roppongi area. There is an office building next door with a few restaurants and a supermarket but closed on weekends.Again I will stay here because of the great staff.

Consistent and always the same as expected. I have been staying here since 2011 and have found the hotel excellent. Breakfast is a little busy and can be avoided by having it delivered to your room. Step in bath shower is not ideal as the water overflows into the designer drain. Moisturizer is not available in the room according to my female colleague. A great hotel. I will be back.

A pretty safe bet, lPro'sGreat bedVery good breakfastGood locationChampagne bar and restuarants, including Michelin.Con'sHad to move rooms as ventilation vibrations in room, the helpful lady who moved me advised this was common on a couple of floors ( sorry I do not remember the level) .Room's, very plain but newish, at 175 pounds a night in Tokyo it's acceptable.

We stayed at the ANA InterContinental for a 3 night stay before heading to Hakuba. We stayed with 2 other families. The service was impeccable all of the staff spoke ok English so all inquiries were handle well.As all of us were travelling with children we had to all book 2 rooms each , we were very happy when they were able to offer us connecting rooms.. made our trip so much more enjoyable!!The restuarants were lovely and the wait staff were all very friendly too. It seemed to be more of a business type hotel.. as we were the only 3 families I ever saw eating at the buffets at dinner and breakfast.As much as I did enjoy the hotel and its staff , I would probably look for somewhere more family orientated next time, as I felt like I had to keep more of a hold on the children to give respect to the business men that were staying at the hotel.The bathroom goodie pack is the best I have ever seen in my whole time of travelling!!

the hotel is very great, excellent service... but is expensive, when i go to japan i just sleep in the hotel, so next time i prefer to pay a cheapest hotel just to sleep and take a bath... if you stay in the area of ginza is better location.

I stayed in this hotel early last year, and had a very good experience, this time was slightly different.The room I was given was small, pretty old, and the bathroom smelt awful. The hotel isn't cheap, so hopefully my frustration isn't misunderstood.As ever here the service was excellent, the best breakfast buffet I have ever seen, and the location is A1.Do yourself a favour though, make sure that you request one of the newer refurbished rooms of you're staying more than a night.

Modern clean and Western. Typical US/European size rooms. Great service. In-house restaurants are very very good. Skybar is a great place to relax after a long day. Pricing but convenient. Near nightlife and outstanding dinning. I have stayed that all the top Tokyo hotels & I prefer ANA.

We stayed here over the New Year holidays so probably not the best time to enjoy a peaceful break, but the hotel was constantly busy. We queued for about 20 minutes to check in (partly because airline 4 pilots cut in front of us without even a look of shame, let alone apology), but as we approached the desk, we were told that, as Priority Club Gold Card members, we could have used the Ambassador fast lane. The room itself was nice and bright, modern and with a great view of the city. It had one of those features of some modern hotels that I don’t understand – a window between the bathroom and the bedroom. Other than that, there was also a very nice walk-in shower with multi jets, as well as the bath tub. The breakfast buffet was extensive in size, but incredibly busy. We waited a long time to get access, then a long time for tea and coffee to be offered, and longer still for it to be delivered. The food was ok – standard fare but a little bland in taste. But the jostling crowds made it a little unpleasant. The staff were very efficient and friendly, although in a slightly reserved way. Location was excellent – very close to the entrance to the metro system, although it take 5 minutes of walking metro tunnels to actually reach the first station.As this was New Year, I think that allowances can be made for how busy it was. I visited friends staying in the Hyatt and they had exactly the same situation there. I would choose to stay there again.

The hotel is nice and amenities are top class, staff is friendly, though as in much of Japan, language is a challenge. The room was spacious for a space constrained city like Tokyo. Happy to recommend the hotel to visitors to Tokyo.

Recently stayed at the ANA Intercontinental for a few days. Very nice property.Consistently smooth and accommodating valet / bell / front desk service. As everywhere in Japan, communication is an issue (the people who anywhere else in the world would be fluent English speakers struggle with English, and the people who anywhere else would have passable English for service roles, speak none at all), but they are quick to address any issues that this might create. My room (xx21 on a high floor) was spacious with all modern updates and a beautiful view. Typical Asian business hotel automation of shades and lights. Few English language television options but compensated for by video and HDMI inputs so you can source content from your tablet or laptop. Fast WiFi. Extremely responsive room service, laundry, etc. Attractive lobby, diverse range of restaurants and bars. (I sampled only the lobby restaurant breakfast and the tepanyaki restuarant up top; both excellent, although crushingly expensive in the latter case.) The executive lounge on the 35th floor is superb; and depending upon your room rate and requirements it can be a real value -- at least for me it cost 100k yen a day (approx $100 at recent exchange rates) but offers two full-ish meals a day, full self-service bar, free wifi, and two free hours of conference room utilization in a beautiful meeting room. Note that the front desk "sold" me this for my entire stay without my realizing it; I only needed (and used) one day, and they gladly refunded the balance.Did not use gym, concierge or business center, so cannot comment on any of these services.

Such a great hotel, from the moment you enter the lobby. We arrived early on New Years Day and did not expect our room to be ready but we were offerred an early check-in, bliss! We stayed for 2 nights and observed it to be a very popular and buzzing hotel with many guests. Every morning we waited in line for breakfast, but the line moved pretty fast as they are prepared with many staff. It runs like a well oiled machine! The staff are fantastic.AdvantagesGood quality breakfast with plenty of choicesSpacious rooms and great bathroom amenities – we stayed in contemporary classic, non-smoking roomRestaurants/bar :Sushi Kenzan – so yummy, but priceyMIXX Bar and Lounge – lovely view, great staff and delicious drinksTeppanyaki Akasaka – outstanding, must try if your budget allowsVery comfortable lobby to relax in whilst waiting for the Narita Limousine Bus to take us back to the airportStaff are very friendly, helpful and always availableQuick and affordable taxi ride to Roppongi HillsDisadvantagesThey have a metro entrance very close to the hotel, but it’s a fair walk once inside to the actual metro platformsIn-room internet access comes at a daily charge. For the room rate price, I really expected that internet access would be complimentary

First time I stayed in this hotel in December 2010 for New Year holiday we spent in Tokyo and returned now for a short stay while in transit in Tokyo in January 2014. Both times we enjoyed the hotel big time - the service is excellent, especially the concierge who helped us great deal during the first stay to get last minute reservation in great restaurant on New Years eve and helped us to plan where to go for New Year celebrations in Tokyo.Even though the hotel is not very new the rooms are very well appointed and clean. There is great bar on the top floor where we went few times during our 2 stays with nice view over Tokyo. We didn't visit the restaurants in the hotel nor had breakfast there so cannot comment on that. Tokyo being a huge city the location of the hotel depends what you're there for. It is very close to a metro station Tameike Sanno on Ginza line. Ropongi station is 10-15 min walk from the hotel.

I stayed at the Ana for four months - six trips of two weeks on, one week off. Instead of calculating the rewards points based on dollars spent, they give you 2000 points per stay. So I walked away from 84 nights with 12,000 points, not even enough for a free stay somewhere else. Insulting! The hotel itself was quite nice for Japan. All the amenities you would expect. My other complaint is that there is nowhere in the lobby that serves coffee before 9:00 on weekends. Not great for a jetlag situation.

Stayed recently on a family holiday. Arrived v early on overnight flight from the UK, we were allowed in to the health spa are to shower and freshen up while they got our room ready for 10:30.The concierge desk was very helpful with arranging bookings and advising on local attractions.All the staff were very friendly and helpful.Although we only stated on 7th floor overlooking the elevated motorway ther was no intrusive noise at all.The only bad thing is the internet which is charged at Y1600 per 24hrs which seems like a money grabbing exercise. There is free wi-fi in all Starbucks in Tokyo (however you have to register before you go for the first time ( http://starbucks.wi2.co.jp/sp/sma_index_en.html ) and I have not been bombarded by spam mail. Although the metro entrance is close to the hotel the actual platforms are quite a walk - the nearest, G line, about 300yds and the furthest, M line, about 1/2 mileThere are a number of good places to eat in the Ark Hills complex adjoining the hotel so if you are on a budget you do not need to eat in the hotel itselfThe Roppongi area is only a short taxi ride away (it is uphill there and downhill back so we tended to taxi there and walk back) where there are many places to eat ranging from a Hard Rock cafe through to the traditional Japanese restaurants (see other of my reviews for two good ones).We would definately go back.

I have stayed att InterContinental in other citys around the work and this is the one i did not like. No free wi-fi. It is not included in the price and that feels so anncient! What high class hotel does not include free wi-fi! The room was not perfectly cleand and we had to inform the hotel. The location is great but you can probably find better hotels around the area in Tokyo.

I stayed at the ANA Intercontinental while traveling on business to Japan in September. Having never been to Japan and not knowing the language, I found this hotel to be the perfect place from which to base my stay.Located next to a subway entrance, this property was very convenient and allowed for easy access to the many trains that crisscross Tokyo. Getting to my meetings was never a problem. There are a few convenience stores and restaurants close by and it is also within walking distance of the Roppongi district.I enjoyed the breakfast buffet each morning. The food was excellent and the variety allowed me to try many different types of cuisines, including traditional American and Japanese foods. We also enjoyed a traditional tea during the afternoon hours.The staff was wonderful and could not have been more accommodating. From check-in to check-out, their professionalism really showed. I was placed in a room with an odor that was bothersome to me. While I waited for my new room to be available, they offered a complimentary entry into the Club Lounge on the 35th floor. They were also very helpful in giving advice as to where to explore and how to navigate the subway when I had the opportunity.I would highly recommend this property and look forward to returning there in the future.

From arrival to departure the ANA Intercon Tokyo was a wonderful experience.The staff was professional and went above an beyond.Room clean and well appointed.Centrally located.Try Mixx Bar and Lounge on the 36th floor. Well worth it.Definitely a great choice when staying in downtown Tokyo.

This is the best hotel I stayed in while in Japan. Location is fantastic, right next to the metro station in the business district. Best part of the hotel was the personal ramen chef at breakfast where you can choose exactly what you want in the soup. Rooms are typically compact however clean and nice. Internet is expensive so try to have it included with your room.

Have stayed here at least ten times and it is like "coming home"...truly wonderful. Esp when one is in Tokyo for business. Comfy beds. They really go the extra mile to make a stay albeit short or longer, an excellent experience. Personally, the best hotel in which I have stayed during my trips to Tokyo.

i think it is my 2nd stay at this hotel. Last was with family in March this year.This time round, came with 5 other friends, booked 3 rooms.I arrived on a red eye from Singapore on 18 Dec, touched down just after 5am, reached the hotel by 6am, registered and was told the room would be ready by 7am. Not bad for a Tokyo hotel. Went out for breakfast with a friend in another hotel, back by 9am and checked in.Not the newest rooms, but well maintained. spacious room. Bathroom a tad small, shower over bath, soap/shampoo/conditioner dispenser very functional, though not the most presentable for a 5 star hotel, but served its purpose well. Hot water works very well. Bathroom floor not heated, unlike The Ritz-Carlton Tokyo.Beds were comfortable, pillows a bit too flat for my liking though. AC control in room functioned well.Late check out given free at 2pm if sign up at Loyalty club member, 30% charge for 3pm check out and 50% for 6pm check out.I like the location, nearest subway station is Tameike-Sanno on Ginza line, Exit 13, which is 3 mins walk from hotel, there is still a 5-7 mins walk from exit to train platform. Ginza line brings you to Asakusa Temple and Ueno Park on one end and Omotesando and Shibuya on the other. One stop away at Akasaka-Mitsuke one can change to Marunouchi line to Shinjuku.ARK Hills next to hotel has some good restaurants and a Starbucks for coffee. it is also within walking distance (15 mins) to Roppongi Hills (Grand Hyatt) and Tokyo Midtown (The Ritz-Carlton). Will be back, if rates are good. As it is a relatively large hotel, do not expect personalized service. But the concierge gave great advices, assisted in restaurant reservations and are friendly.

Whenever I am in Tokyo I stay at the ANA Interconti. I like the rooms, the view is not extraordinary, but great. This time I was upgraded to a conner room with a fantastic bathroom. The lobby is great for tea and some sweets. In walking distance you find good restaurant for all budgets. The TEPANJAKI in the Hotel is absolutely fantastic, just close your eyes when you get the bill ;-). We had a marvelous chef preparing our seafood and beef as ordered. From the Hotel the next subway station is the Ginza line witch brings you to many spots of tokyo, including business district.I am looking forward to stay again at this hotel.

Arriving tired and in a rain storm, it was incredible to be greeted by name as I got off the bus from the airport! We were helped with our bags and taken directly to our room for an orientation and comfortable check-in on a tablet. Really a first class way to arrive after a long flight.The hotel itself has everything you could want: multiple restaurants, bars, shops, ATM, well-appointed rooms, and an incredibly helpful staff. Getting help with directions was easy and getting back to the hotel was also easy, as it is well-known and in a central location.You'll want to do the incredible breakfast once, but it's too expensive to do regularly. It's a very short above ground walk to the Tameikesanno Station, but be prepared to walk a bit underground once you enter the station.This hotel is a bit more expensive, but the amenities and service are superb.
user_location: Grosse Pointe Park, Michigan, United States
user_name:
JimNader
Grosse Pointe Park, Michigan, United States

review_body: Rather a mature hotel in style, it served the purpose of location quite well.Managed to have a comfortable stay & the club lounge service, views & offerings are superb.Service standards are very high & professional throughout the property.

I booked this hotel for a 6 night stay in Tokyo, and arrived on 19th November. I rejected the first room we were offered, it was dirty and in need of renovation. We were then offered a refurbished room

I've been staying at the IC Tokyo and the IC Strings Hotel for several years. I tend to prefer the Minato location over the Strings Shinagawa due to the location.The hotel property is located in Akasaka, and is very close to Roppongi and the ex-pat Azabu-juban area and of course the bars and restaurants of Akasaka. This is a large hotel with a variety of rooms. Its located in the Arc Hills complex so if you get in late, you can make a left out of the door and hit a good sushi bar 50 meters away. The complex has a few (though not notable other than the sushi bar) restaurants and there is a high end grocery next door where you can stock up on supplies.The hotel has a direct airport bus link so you don't have to mess around with the Narita Express if you arrive into Narita.The scope of the hotel is large including a big lobby. There is a nice bar on the top floor which is perfect for a smoke-friendly evening cocktail. The concierge team is top notch and the floor managers are also very good. I'm a repeat customer so I probably get somewhat better service since I know a few of the staff but I would suspect that they handle virtually all requests seamlessly.There are a variety of room types and especially in Tokyo, you get what you pay for. The standard rooms are very nice and big by Japanese standards but are nothing notable. If you spring for a better room you will get a better value. It depends on your willingness to pay, but this is Japan and nice things are expensive. I'm a good global Intercontinental customer so I get some type of an upgrade automatically. The Jr. Suites are worth asking for and/or buying. I'm attaching a panoramic picture - this room looks like something out of a James Bond flick. There are plenty of outlets and the work space is adequate. Plenty of decent water pressure in the bathrooms and of course the obligatory Toto automatic toilet. There is an elevated highway in front of the property, but the building insulation filters out the noise pretty well. The wireless internet connection works well. Top tier loyalty program members get it free, otherwise it's for pay. I do eat breakfast at hotels in Asia and the IC morning buffet is solid. It's on the higher end of whats out there and the room is large enough to handle the number of guests that use the restaurant. Subway stop (Tameike-sanno) is close.Overall the service level at the IC is extremely high and the concierge team stands out. If you chose the correct room, the combination of service, location and room quality is hard to beat unless you spend significantly more money.
user_name:
CS_NewYorkCity
New York City, New York

review_body: Stayed 2 nights. Direct limo bus from Narita airport; about 80 min. 3000Yen each way. Bus arrived at the ground floor and check in was on the 2nd floor. Was warmly greeted upon getting off the bus and guided to the lobby. Check in was smooth and was given a room on the 14th.The room and bathroom were clean. The room carpet color was dull which made it look old. The bathroom had a in tub shower and overall an older feel. There was a comprehensive set of amenities and it was clearly well maintained. There was both wired and wireless internet access. It was included in my rate. Weren't any complimentary bottled water and the in room safe was in a drawer so it was too small to fit a working laptop.The hotel had an arcade and a number of restaurants nearby. Tsukiji Sushiko was fantastic.Check out was smooth and my bag was waiting for with at the bus stop.Overall, while it's an older hotel, it was well maintained and the staff were very warm and friendly.

I came to Tokyo on a business trip and stayed at the ANA Intercontinental for 5 days. It was the perfect location and my office was a 3 minute walk down the block, so the location was perfect. The rooms are spacious and comfortable and the staff was incredibly friendly. The concierge was a great resource for things to do around Tokyo and they even made our dinner reservations. I found the dining to be a little on the high side but we were able to find options outside of the hotel. I will definitely be staying at the ANA when I return. My only complaint is that I am highly sensitive to smells and the lobby area is overly fragrant. I also wish they had bath robes.

As a platinum member I was upgraded to the executive room at 23rd floor. Services are exceptional from check in to check out. Great hotel to choose from if you must stick with IHG properties. Full of culinary destinations around the hotel, even if you are hungry in the middle of the night and you declined to use the in room dining option, there is a 24 hours japanese join call 'sukiyaki' which serve a Japanese fast food options (gyudon or even ramen) great taste with exceptional price.

Stayed in Ana intercontinental for 2 nights in October and it was a very satisfying experience. Some of the prominent pro's are the spacious rooms (especially considering other hotels in Tokyo), the lavish breakfast spread, the strong wifi connection in the rooms & the location of the hotel which is seconds away from the metro station. Its quite convenient to use the metro to all parts of Tokyo and this certainly makes it a lot easier. The shuttle service to the Narita airport is also very helpful and can be arranged with the help of the friendly hotel staff.A very good experience & if you can afford the rates, this is a very good accommodation option in Tokyo..

I have stayed at this hotel a few times and have found it to be excellent, the only thing that has made me mark it down to a 4 is the fact that the reception will not allow you to get a cash advance on your credit card (Amex) and when the ATM situation in Tokyo is the way it is you would expect a 5 star hotel to offer this service. Apparently they used to but stopped :(Apart from that the hotel is fantastic, eating in the hotel is rather pricey but with a 5 star hotel comes 5 star food and 5 star prices. I have eaten in the hotel a few times and found the food to be the best I have ever had. So you get what you pay for.The staff are very friendly, go out of their way to help in any way they can, it is so Japanese. You are greeted in the evening by a very pretty Japanese lady standing at the concierge desk in a traditional Kimono, who has the most beautiful smile that just makes your evening start great.I have tried to find a negative thing to say about this hotel but I just can't find anything except for the cash advance.... Good work guys, I will be regularly visiting Tokyo for the next 6 months and I will certainly be making your hotel my first choice.

I was in town for business for 1 week. My company gave me a budget of a hotel of under $250 a night and booked my room. They accidentally booked me on the smoking floor and it smelled like one big chimney and bathroom was 'so-so"! I upgraded immediately and they gave me a room on the 20th or 21st floor that was fully renovated and non smoking. If you are a non-smoker or you want a modern shower and furnishings, definitely upgrade! It was easier to take meetings at the hotel because there are so many options for restaurants mostly they are 4-5 star restaurants and Mixx Lounge is a good place to have business drinks with a great city view. Going around for meetings was easy. This was a great location with no hassles. Other: Printing things in the business center is a bit pricy.  There is a convenient airport shuttle to and from hotel - It's about $15 each way.I would stay here again if I were to come for business.

I stayed in the Ana Intercontinental in December 2013 for 3 nights and initial impressions are very good. The hotel is on the popular shuttle bus route from the airport, with the dropoff at the hotel. The main lobby, reception and restaurants are well decorated and are grand.As for the rooms I was disappointed. The fixtures and decoration were not up to the same standard as the rest of the hotel and came across as tired.

As expected, the ANA Intercontinental delivers on all the expectations. Very clean, tify and well put together! Rooms comfortable, gym well equiped and there is a nice pool area outside with a small garden. Restaurant serves good food, and there are lots of local places to eat withing a couple of minutes walk. Hard to fault, really.

We've spent one night here. Was a bit disappointed, not as good as we expected the intercon to be. We've been given a classic room, the room is a bit old, clean tho... The lobby itself is luxury, has a nice cafe and helpful staff at the reception area. The location of hotel is good, central area, easy to access Haneda airport and Tokyo station. A subway entrance right in front of the hotel and with about 5-10mins walk can reach 3 different subway lines. Quite convenient.

Second stay at ANA Intercon. Well located, nice views, clean and efficient, great value for money. Not luxury, but good for a business trip. Used the Club lounge extensively for meetings / cocktails etc - excellent service, food and drinks. Smallish bathrooms.

Couple staying in Tokyo for three nights. Chose this hotel because it was central and near two Tokyo metro subway stations. Service and presentation of the hotel is as expected from an Intercontinental hotel, very good.Room was on the 18th floor with TV, study, couch and decent view of the city. Room was clean, modern and quiet. Get a good rest after busy days exploring. Health centre/ gym was located on the 4th floor (needed to change lifts to get there) which was free to access and had numerous treadmills, machine and free weights. A treat for anyone looking to work off extra ramen/karage weight. Took the hotel limousine (coach) transport to Narita airport which was convenient but comes at extra cost.Concerns- There is no free wifi, not even in the lobby area which is disappointing. Even cable internet from the room costs money.- Tried the room service on the first night (late check-in) and found the portion sizes to be rather small, poor value (expected) but also rather average quality. - Both subway stations near this hotel are not on the JR network. Clearly not a fault of the hotel but foreigners who are buying JR passes might want to consider another hotel on the JR network for convenience/ avoid paying twice for transport.
user_name:
Daniel C
New South Wales, Australia

review_body: In May, 2013 I stayed for several nights at this hotel in one of their basic rooms. It was okay, but the room definitely felt tired and seemed worn (carpets had stains, wall paper was dirty and torn in places, etc). I stayed here a few days ago and was given a complimentary upgrade to a higher quality room and it made a big difference. The carpets and wall paper was newer, and the bathroom was more modern. However, the bed still wasn't very comfortable. For location-related reasons (closer to scheduled meetings) I moved to a newer, but cheaper and much smaller hotel (remm Hotel) which had a more comfortable bed.I hope ANA Intercontinental refreshes their basic rooms soon. I also look forward to the day when cigarette smoking isn't allowed to foul the air in the lobby and main restaurant.If you have time, walking around the rolling hills of the neighbourhood is time well spent - but bring a good map. The streets twist and turn and it can feel like you are trying to navigate a maze. Special Note: Russell Sheppard, assistant Guest Relations Manager at ANA Intercontinental, does a great job.

AllI would echo what others are saying here. Excellent value, central.A couple of things to highlight that haven't been mentioned:1) The Cafe Doutor (next to Exit 13, just steps to the east of the hotel) has an outstanding breakfast options for ¥500-700 per person. No need to pay up in the hotel2) Laundry was inexpensive (about ¥700 per shirt same day service). This is a great hotel if you are carrying on and need to wash clothing on the road3) I needed a shoe repair and they sent me to Mr Minit in the building to the west (about 50M from hotel). It cost ¥400, a fraction of what it cost at home.

We stayed here for two nights, a great IHG property but very busy, Staff was accommodating, and went well out of their way to help us. Rooms were modern, very clean and refreshing. Overall highly recommended.

Very nice hotel n Tokyo and reasonably priced. Also very convenient access to subways and landmarks throughout the city. The hotel also has a small mall located next door with different restaurants, shops etc, that can help break up a busy trip.Rooms were very well done with modern amenities. Friendly courteous staff, and exceptional service - Highly recommended!!

I stayed here for a few days last week and it is a lovely hotel with a very high standard of customer service, food and choice is excellent. I think the only thing that lets it down was the room, old fashioned and in need of updating.

I was recently in Tokyo for a business trip and I stayed at the Ana InterContinental. The hotel is quite nice, and the service is definitely top notch. A few things bugged me - I booked the hotel from IHG's own web site and was offered a special price for booking and paying ahead of time. I did this. When I got to the hotel, they told me my package did not include breakfast and wireless internet. Both these were features of the hotel, but because I had chosen the special it was removed, which I was unaware of. Not a big deal - I paid for breakfast and bought internet and neither was very expensive but I was surprised by it. Other than that, the hotel was a good example of typical 4/5 star hotels. Having just stayed in an excellent hotel in Hong Kong I think these old style hotels will be gone in time and wlll be replaced with more modern hotels.
