For sure this is not your boutique & charming hotel where you expect uniqueness. But sometimes even corporate hotels fail and this one certainly does not. I have stayed in other places in Tokyo and this was a very good sized room, amenities ok, temperature control, quiet enough, everything up to standards. I did order room service and that left a bit to be desired in terms of how food was described and what was actually delivered. Breakfast however was really great! Lots of choices, fresh juices and good service. There is a champagne bar and plenty of restaurants and I think the location is ok but definitely taxis are needed.

İt is situated in a business district, linked well to the popular turist attractions in Ginza or Shinjuku areas. There is a metro station nearby but we have to use taxis particularly at night. There is also restaurants and bars around the hotel. Efficiently run corporate hotel with Japanese hospitality; staff are helpful; hotel facilities from internet connection to the restaurants and bars are quite acceptable: the rooms are not big but good size and clean. The hotel provides traditional Japanese kimonos so on for quests as well as coffee and tea facilities in the room. However rooms on the left side gets 24/7 traffic noise from the motorway down below. The breakfast is just good. There is also direct bus link from the Narita airport to the hotel, If one does not mind staying in a large corporate hotel, it is all fine, however if one does prefer smaller hotels with a personal touch should look elsewhere in Tokyo.

Great, friendly property close walking distance to Akasaka business area and close to numerous subway lines. Numerous restaurants within a close walk along with a fifteen minute walk to the Roppongi entertainment area. Excellent hotel, excellent location with friendly and accommodating staff.

Stayed here twice this year. Got upgraded due to my Platinum Ambassador status with IHG. Especially the renovated rooms on the higher floors are very nice, clean and provide a stunning view. The bar on top is awesome, but expensive (also amazing views). Subway station is located just around the corner. Would def coming back.

Everything is expansive in Tokyo but Ana Intercontinental in roppongi area is reallly expansive for small rooms and for some offre them very old especially for bathrooms ,Food is Good especially breakfast and service is professional as far you don't ask for something special as always in Japan !

October 2013 was my 3rd time at the ANA in Tokyo and it has never disappointed.The service, location and overall experience is superb. The hotel location is great for either business or pleasure as located near many embassy's and business areas as well as being on a underground line (Ginza Line) and 5 mins walk of tourist areas of Roppongi. If you are arriving from Narita the hotel has a direct Limousine bus service direct from the airport for only ¥3,000 compared to a taxi at ¥200,000. The bus only takes 1hr 15. The hotel has many fantastic restaurants and a great sky bar on the top floor. This is the same service and drinks as in the hotel lobby and offers great views of Tokyo and a real relaxed yet modern feel.There is a great champagne bar as well on the first floor in the lobby area looking out over the reception and restaurant.Breakfast offers a fantastic buffet in the main lounge/bar area and caters for all international cuisine. The rooms are a good size, especially as you are in Tokyo. Other hotels can be a little compromising on the room space. All rooms have everything you need plus more, even the cheapest rooms available are a good size. Rooms are quiet and peaceful, so if you want to sleep in or get over your jet lag then you can close the curtains and you wouldn't think you were in the middle of Tokyo until you open them again and look out your window at the impressive Tokyo Skyline. On foot you can walk to the Imperial Palace in about 25/30mins, likewise the shopping area of Ginza. If your feet can't manage that, the underground is outside the hotel and both places are only 3 stops away. In the other direction past Roppongi you have Shibuya which is 'Tokyo of your Dreams'. Neon lights, the busiest trains station in Tokyo (probably the world) and the famous Shibuya crossing where you should pop up to Starbucks, buy a coffee and watch 1000's of people cross the road when the lights turn red. This isn't really walking distance, but only 5 underground stops away in the other direction. There is a brilliant food market at the bottom of the Station at street level offering Asian food delights. Make sure you are not hungry before you enter or else you will buy the lot!The leisure facilities at the hotel are top notch, but no indoor pool means swimming is a no go in the winter months. The gym area and spa are really good though. Overall the ANA offers everything you will need for an amazing stay in Tokyo. If it's your first time for pleasure or you've been to Tokyo on business before then you should definitely try the ANA, you will not be disappointed. It maybe one of the higher priced hotels on offer, but if you want the location, quality, service and good room sizes it's actually good value for money. Being part of IHG you can also claim your Priority Club points which is an added bonus.

Relatively fast check-in at 11pmPolite staffRoom 3303High and quiet floorThe room was clean and simply elegantWifi was available and free in my corporate packageThe bed was ready for sleeping and the window blinds closed nicely at a simple pressure on the central console on the bedside tableNice TV with a only a very few non Japanese programsHalogens reading lights on both sides of the bedGood and discreet air conditionerJapanese air blowing toilets and simple elegant bathroom with a frosted window to the roomVast breakfast place with a good choice of Japanese and continental breakfastOverall a pleasant and reliable address

Stayed one week at ANA and it was a great surprise. The rooms are very big for japanese standards are the services are very good, from concierge to people at breakfast. It is not a hotel to travel on budget, but If you have the money, it is worth staying at ANA InterContinental.

It is a top Intercon hotel so we expect supearb service (and indeed got it) and all the luxuries that go with it. Staff checked us in very early despite the hotel being almost full with the tail end of a typhoon drowning the city and stopping people checking out. The room was great and the bed what you expect from IHG, but the bathroom was disappointing and seriously old.Charged for wifi (when will they drop this ridiculous ripoff) leaves a bad taste in a $400 room,Location is pretty good with it being a 15 minute walk to the busier parts of Rappongi, though I guess the fact that it backs on the US Embassy means it feels a bit like an annex at times. there is a plaza next door with some good bars and cafes that was busy after work though it empties pretty quickly later.All in all great service but a little tired.

At firsti was kind of disappointed because the ShangriLa was completely booked with the film festival. I was with my dad and wanted him to have a great trip in Tokyo. Well, the ANA Intercontinental turned out to be great. The location in Roppongi was excellent and the hotel lobby kept my dad busy and while I had some meetings. I will stay here again. Great for Business hotel.

Being a Royal Ambassador with Intercontinental, the stay was a bliss. Upgraded to suite at the club floor Great restaurants and champagne bar and the lounge at top floor was a magnificent experience for me and my wife.... On site shopping is selected and most than adecuate and the sushi bar featuring Uni, Otoro and Chutoro was the perfect culinary treat. My son ate 8 plates of Otoro nigiri under the very happy look of the chef. The Gym, Day Spa and pool were great (non elite members have to pay a fee to access gym , spa and pool). All in all (including a faux pas at the Ladies Bar) was a unique experience.

I stayed at this hotel based upon a recommendation of a friend and I was very disappointed. This hotel is very dated and needs a renovation in most areas of the hotel. The rooms were satisfactory and the staff was efficient. There are lots of high rollers checking into this hotel and it seems that if you are just an average Joe, that is the treatment that you will get from the staff.Next time in Tokyo, I will stay somewhere else...The Marriott!

Convenient booking thru ihg.Full-service hotel with pool, gym and a good variety of restaurants. Italian food at the MIXX bar for lunch, happy hours at the Champagne Bar, and patisserie at the ground floor deli are enjoyable and reasonably priced. Easily accessible-- direct limousine bus from Narita & Haneda airports, 20m from the Ginza, Chiyoda & NAmboku lines of the Metro), cabs right along the hotel driveway, situated well in Roppongi.Staff speak polite English. In-room dining available 24 hours. Clean room. Suffered from dry cough for two evenings and INstant Service Dept installed a humidifier in my room instantly. Concierge is friendly and helpful with confirming flights, making restaurant reservations and providing transport information.Stayed in more than 15 hotels in Tokyo and will stay in this hotel again. Highly recommendable.

Great stay. Very nice & centrally located. Easy walk to the metro and very simple to get a cab at the ground floor. The gym is pretty nice and was empty whenever I tried to use it. Lobby is high quality and concierge was helpful.
user_name:
Luke M
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: It is a terrible experience staying in ANA InterContinental Tokyo! We booked one room for 2 nights stay (12/10/13 - 14/10/13) and another night on 19/10/13. The booking was confirmed. The first two nights were under “friends & family rate” since one of my friend is working for IHG group. This trip was a high school reunion trip for us with 2 from Sydney and the other one from Indonesia. We were supposed to meet in the hotel on 12/10/13 since we would arrive at different time. The facts are:1. One of my friends arrived around lunch time and found out the room was not available for us on 12/10/13. She couldn’t contact us since we were on 10 hours flight from Sydney to Tokyo. She was asked to be flexible by the GSM Manger since the room was under “friends & family rate”. He told my friend that we would be re-located to Metropolitan Hotel due to “urgent thing” happened in the hotel and I guess we were the “sacrificial lamb” for the convenience of the hotel!!! 2.She was offered breakfast complimentary for the day which finished at 11.30 a.m and she arrived after that! I am wondering whether they know the time! I actually wondered whether they know what they are doing!!! She ended up having lunch and paid for it.3.bShe was then offered the cab charges to go to Metropolitan Hotel and meet us there. My friend told the GSM Manager that we were on our 10 hours flight and there was no way she could contact us then. She has advised him that we would still be arriving in the hotel at night time and he needs to explain the situation to us in person! My friend then heading to Metropolitan Hotel.4. Two of us were then arrived after 10 hours flight and 1.5 hours trains to be told the same thing. “Please be flexible and we needs to be re-located to Metropolitan Hotel. We were standing in front desk having this conversation after long flight! I actually asked them to arrange 2 nights in Metropolitan Hotel instead of coming back and forth since we had tight schedule just to find out NO as an answer. We were asked for our flexibility whilst no compromise offered from the other party??? We were offered complimentary breakfast for the next day and club lounge access which we didn’t get a chance to use!! We were then took the cab to the Metropolitan Hotel.The issues which I considered as insults:1. The Australian GSM Manager told us to be flexible since the first two nights were under “friends & family rate” which were cheaper rate and he assumed we all work for IHG. Did he actually understand the meaning of “friends & family rate”? It doesn’t mean we all are working for the hotel, only one of my friends is!! I would expect a manager to know his working place and policy better than his hotel guests. He gave me an impression of we were the second class of guest since we paid cheaper rate! If the hotel cannot honour their offer, they shouldn’t have given the offer in the very first place!2. We were having this discussion in front desk at night time. Didn’t they think it would be much better to have this discussion in one of the private office? I think this is the very basic manners which all professional in service industry should know. I think the hotel should consider re-training its management team properly! I even feel an insult to write this thing and have to remember the whole bad experience!3. I then asked to arrange us 2 nights in Metropolitan Hotel instead of coming back and forth since we had tight schedule, which we were told it’s not possible. We were asked to be flexible whilst the hotel offered none! The hotel was quite a bit of distance and the room was very small.4. The most important thing was they could have email us notify the “urgent thing” and we then had option to decide!!! This whole bad experience could have been avoided which the hotel fails to do so! If the hotel does not understand this simple manner, then they don’t deserve to stay in the service industry, leave alone to be under 5 stars hotel.5. The GSM Manager should have come with more humble approach while notifying the bad news due to the inadequate of its hotel instead of keep asking us to be “flexible”. It is the hotel who fails to honour its promise not the other way round. I don’t think any of us deserved to be treated in this way.6. When we were back on 19/10/13, we were not receiving any good intention from hotel to restore its image as a 5 stars hotel. As a matter of fact, the GSM saw my friend and said “You are back, is there anything else I can do for you or help you?” I wasn’t there when the conversation happened, otherwise I would have replied “We are back not because of the cheaper rate or because we want to. We paid the commercial rate for the King Bed premier room. We stayed here again because we have made the booking and we are women of our words! We honour our promise and commitment. We say what we mean and we mean what we say. We are all professionals and we used to deal with professionals in a professional way.7. I would NOT RECOMMEND ANA InterContinental Hotel Tokyo to anyone.
user_name:
Yuliawaty L
Sydney, New South Wales, Australia

review_body: The rooms are nicely done. There are on the smaller size but remain decent. Breakfast buffet is really good. The Kenzen sushi restaurant is very good. Service at every level is excellent, very polite and efficient. The gym is below the level of this hotel, simply too small and crowded. However, you can do a 7 miles run from the hotel and loop around the Imperial Palace! Not bat at all! I would certainly stay here again.

Really good service from the concierge with arranging tours. Due to the language barrier, we really needed their assistance. The location of the hotel is great- close by to Roppongi Hills, an upmarket locale.

Definitely a top end intercon that I'd expected (I've stayed in quite a few and occasionally there's a tired and average one or two out there). This said, I've always liked the intercon style - dark modern interiors, good quality restaurants (try the mix bar up on L37) and for this place the rooms were a good size for tokyo along with great location both exploring the city as well as accessing the airport. They really made my night by upgrading me to the executive floor after having a really terrible long haul flight. Ill be coming back to this intercon, for sure.

After the easy bus service direct from Haneda airport we arrived around 0700. Polite and direct service from the start. Twin bedded superior room on the 31st floor is clean, modern with an excellent fully featured bathroom. Wifi is complimentary ( due to my IHG membership ). Turn down service and constant room refreshes most welcome. A pleasant modern experience. I did not eat here.

This is Hotel is always my choice in Tokyo.An Excellent Hotel and great service1.- Executive club is a good choice. Great view, good attention and multiple choices in food and beverages. Breakfast also very good2.- Very good location and close to main tourist attractions3.- Good gym4.- Rooms are quiet, options for pillow and comfortable bed.5.- Internet connection (wired and WIFI) very fast. Good connection6.- Great views from the rooms (see pictures)Personnel is great and willing to service

Stayed here twice -- once in August, once in September, 2013. Consistent quality, super-great internet speeds (could easily watch videos without pauses), and next to shops, little restaurants, etc. The only downside for me, as a very frequent traveler, is that they have no "executive lounge" or any other real perks for loyal travelers.

We were so grateful that they had a room for us when we arrived at 7.15 am - jet lagged and completely shattered. It really made a difference to our Tokyo visit. However we also really enjoyed the hotel. We had booked using rewards so had a standard room but liked the Club - lovely breakfast, nice evening snacks/drinks and cool ambiance.We also enjoyed the rooftop Mixx bar and took out a loan and had a fantastic Wagyu steak in the Steakhouse.Some of the floors need a refurb and our non-smoking room was very basic and smelled of smoke but overall an excellent experience and would definitely stay again.

Excellent hotel, fantastic breakfast & good location for our first time exploring Tokyo. We had two rooms, on our return after going to other cities they gave us adjoining rooms. Helpful with English speaking concierge.

Nice hotel with good amenities .... good central location ... was close to a couple of subway stations. Buses available to and from the airport, making location very accessible. Only complaint is that Ala-carte food is ridiculously expensive ..
user_name:
Phxmafia13
New York City, New York

review_body: It's a good hotel, good location, the club upstairs is beautiful, the restaurants are good. Had a pretty good experience... Rooms a bit tight but all and all a nice ace to stay and if you book in advance the prices are sensible as well.

Stayed here for two nights with my husband and we received a room upgrade as I am a Platinum member and it was my birthday. The room was very spacious and comfortable but we could here a little bit of traffic noise from the outside. There was a coffee machine in the room with free coffee capsules and free Godiva chocolate biscuits as well. The toiletries provided were from the brand Loccitaine and they were replenished every day without fail. The bathroom even had a mini tv but the channels available were all in Japanese. The traditional Japanese bamboo foot massager was surprisingly good for the feet.The hotel lobby was impressive and the elevators even had a seat inside for weary guests to sit on!The hotel is a minute walk away from a Tameike-sanno station exit. The Tameike-sanno station is on the Namboku and Ginza lines which made travel to places like Shibuya and Ginza convenient.I would definitely consider this hotel for my next trip to Tokyo.

I transferred to the ANA for three nights after a disastrous stay at the Keio Plaza (see my review of that night listed separately....). The ANA is well located, very comfortable, well appointed rooms, good gym, decent breakfast (although WILDLY over-priced food - why is breakfast in Tokyo so expensive??), lively upstairs bar and if you're interested in exploring it, within 20 minutes' walk of Roppongi Crossing. The staff were all pleasant and helpful. All in all a good stay, and I would definitely stay here again.

This is one of the better InterContinental Hotels I've stayed at. Lounge is superb. Both breakfast and evening happy hour are of great variety along with superb service. Room we got upgraded to was also very nice. Location wise, it is right around the corner of a subway station. US Embassy is within walking distance. I got my passport pages added right there in a matter of an hour. If we ever return to Tokyo, this hotel is it!!!

Looking for a hotel in the centre of the action, that's good for sophisticated tourists as well as business boys and girls, that has sufficient entertainment and F&B venues that you don't have to leave the hotel foe a week? This is it.

Very goog value for the price, central hotel in Tokyo. Nice restaurants and breakfast, may need some refurbishment but nothing too bad. Spacious bedrooms. Extremely clean hotel, excellent service. Late 80's still hotel but everything works perfectly. Breakfast actually quite unbelievable

Hotel is a nice property with well appointed rooms and attentive service. Dined at several of the restaurants (Cascade, Sushi Kensan, and The Steakhouse). Food was average to disappointing, most disappointing wasThe Steakhouse. Ordered and received a drink, but not offered water. I was offered bread but it never came, noted next table got bread after entree was delivered - no butter. Ordered a cheese board for an appetizer and the Waygu sirloin came with the meal, both arrived at the same time, the cheese came without crackers or bread. The sirloin, ordered medium, came well done and was only 1/2" thick (or less); had better steak at Longhorn. Sides were spinach, grilled vegetables and mashed potatoes, all well below par. Sat for a while until I could get the servers attention and asked for crackers to eat with the bland cheese board. Ten minutes later I had two slices of bread, and no offer of another drink, water, or dessert. Front of the house seemed disorganized.

Our second hotel in Tokyo after Westin. Very different! Much busier and business like, more traffic and general city life. But room was quiet, all right but on the smaller side, same said for the bathroom. We did not eat in the hotel...expensive..and ventured out ...great small korean restaurant in the opposite street(and cheap) and great prime beef restaurant opposite the hotel(and expensive but worth it!). We did go to the champagne bar for the happy hour(prepare yourself for japanese prices) as the drinks were half price. And that was nice and welcome. Starbucks across the road for breakfast did just fine and tube station right next to the hotel. If you need water or snack there are plenty of small shops around.

In my last review I stated the check in and out was efficiently fast but this time it was the opposite. It was 30 minutes for me to check in. Well partly it was my fault as I did not brought my agoda voucher and partly apparently Agoda had my name as Da Garcia Da Garcia. Mmmmm... I guess it is much better than a flight attendant on my return flight from Osaka to Singapore wherein she addressed me as Miss Gaga mmmmmm...This hotel still remains my favourite because of the gym (but of course) but also the locality especially to Haneda Airport. Roppongi is a definitely a great area and one can run outside on a good day.

We stayed in this hotel for 10 days for our honeymoon, and we loved it. Very nice rooms. I don't know why some other reviews call them small, but we certainly didn't think so. The service was excellent, with someone always available to help you out, or speed things up, or answer questions. I didn't meet any members of staff who didn't speak good English. We even got a bottle of Champagne sent up to us on our first day because it was our honeymoon.The location is good, with an exit of Tameika-sanno station on the Ginza line a very short walk away. Granted, it's then a long walk to the track once you're in the station, but there's a FamilyMart along the way which made supermarket shopping on the way home in the evenings easy. There was nowhere in Tokyo we struggled to get to from here, and we travelled about the city a lot.There are plenty of things in the immediate area as well, with Roppongi and Akasaka in walking distance and plenty of restaurants and bars. A couple of British pubs too, which suited us as we don't speak Japanese.The room we had was a king executive room on the 21st floor. The view was great, not very noisy, well airconditioned with a comfortable king size bed. Internet was free in an executive room, and easy to use. I guess a tiny complaint is that the benefits of the executive room we'd prebooked weren't explained on check in, so although we thought we knew, we had to call and check about the internet. We were a little confused, because we thought executive rooms all had TVs in the bathroom, and ours didn't. This is obviously something we weren't bothered about (didn't need the TV on at all while we were there) but it was odd that the website said we should have it.The only real fault with the hotel is the price of eating and drinking there. Food was very, very expensive, whether you ate in your room or the restaurants. We drank a few cocktails one evening, and you expect those to be more expensive anywhere, but other normal drinks were also very expensive. We had the breakfast buffet for a few days, which was alright, but so it should be at around £22.50 a person. At least it was better value than ordering a single breakfast meal, since you could have as much as you wanted.The price of hotel services is the only thing that would stop be visiting this hotel again. I genuinely thought it was a really nice place and enjoyed my stay. Just not so much the bill. If the dining was better value, I'd have given it full marks.

I stayed for 1 night in a king room on the 25th floor. The room was a good size with king bed, small lounge area, desk, TV, fridge, etc. The bathroom was relatively small and cramped, the shower is over the bath tub. I found the room to be very quiet and I was not bothered by any noise that you usually find in hotels (banging doors, flushing toilets etc). The service in the hotel is wonderful, all the staff are exceptionally pleasant, helpful and polite. I had access to the Club Intercontinental and found this to be a very relaxing and peaceful oasis. The hotel is not located close to shopping areas etc, so if this is your priority another location may suit you better. The limosine bus from the hotel to NRT is very efficient and well organised at a cost of JY3000. I received all the Ambassador benefits during my stay at this hotel.

it's a nice hotel to stay near our office in the business district... i had good sleep and i like the bathroom. my room was big enough. the district is easily accessible by Subway溜池山王站 and it's safe at night for a solo traveller.

It is my first ever trip to Japan. I am a stranger in a strange land but the welcome from the staff is amazing. The courtesy and sincerity in everything made my trip so welcome. I arrived early and had to wait for almost 4 hours before I could check it. I felt that the 3pm check-in was too late. The staff offered newspaper and free 2 hour Wifi access, and made my wait less painful. The room was welcoming, well-equipped, although a bit small. They had a full HD large screen TV, and half-height fridge, which was good for me. I like to get some groceries during my stay. Everything was clean and picture perfect. It's going to be a 6-stay for me and I think this first-class customer service is something I can definitely get used to :-)

i realyy enjoyed styeing here , lovley hotel , warm welcome and very clean at every thing . but the room service need some smile on the face the price is very high , and the welcome dish is so cheap. i dont think i will go back couse it was so expinsive. . .

We had the unpleasant surprise of learning that we were getting twin beds instead of one king at check-in. Our discontenment was immediately noticed by one of the senior staff who approached us and inquired into further details. We were told that the hotel was fully booked for the first half of our stay but they would move us to a different room for the second half. We also appreciated that the Guest Relations manager contacted us in the morning to apologize and confirm the change for us. The rooms were quite spacious and clean although my skin did react to the bedsheets. I cannot really hold this against the hotel as I do have a tendancy to develop a rash if the detergent used is to harsh...There are also many restaurant in the surrounding area that offer affordable meals and delicious tasting may I add.It is unfortunate that the hotel does not offer free internet. This would probably be the only reason why I may not consider staying at this hotel again.

The hotel is not likely to impress you or depress you. You stay there becasue its convenient, not because its great.The rooms have seen better days and somewhat like the old Tokyo Nissan taxis, can still do the job!The best reason to stay is the Pierre Gagnaire restaurant on the 36th fl - THATS worth the stay!

Second time I stayed in this hotel (last time was 2008). At that time the room was spacious and well appointed,and my expectations, probably far lower. For my second stay, this time around (September 2013) the hotel's age has really started show, especially in the design of the lobby and public areas. It just feels very 1990s or so - the lighting, the design, etc.I got a "single" room booked by my travel agent. Warning - in a number of places this just means single occupancy in a regular room and hopefully you can get a king bed. In this hotel (and in other certain countries), this means a much smaller room (my mistake). You get what you pay for (I did get a special rate). So my room was very small as was the bathroom, which didn't have a fan, or much room to ventilate, so things got steamy when I showered.Bed was comfortable, a queen size and the room adequately appointed. Service was nice, check in was swift and smooth. Breakfast buffet was just fine. The bar at the top of the restaurant affords a great view of the city and the bar tending staff is kind. A bar on the second floor is tended by my Yoko Ariga, who was recommended to me by a cocktail specialist bartender in Hong Kong where I live. I was unfortunately unable to try her drinks as I had shorts on and there is a dress code for the second floor bar - though I plan to next time! Location is the key. It's close to a number of subway stations, a short walk from Roppongi, near the US Embassy as well as a number of businesses and there are lots of little restaurants, bars, and cafes near the hotel so that one can explore a fair bit.

A lot of my colleagues really like this hotel, however I am not sold. I find the service highly impersonal. One quick example: When I arrived there was no train or TCAT service at Narita. There was a 300 person line for cabs arriving 3/hr (don't worry, this is NOT typical - only after holidays with typhoons). Anyway...called the hotel to see if they could help. Not a chance. They would not call a cab company nor provide names of companies I could call. I even called back a second time to make sure I did not misunderstand. Nope...they were not going to help in anyway. Okay no problem, I just arrived at the ANA at 3AM after having landed at 9PM. This situation probably will not happen to you but I feel as an international traveler I want a hotel that can be my go-to resource. Beyond that little deal, the bathroom blew me over with mildew smell. I could not open the closet door because it was broken and had to put my clothes on the bed instead. No lotion as an amenity. Industrial shared containers of body wash and shampoo in the shower. I did not like the breakfast buffet. It was also over priced. Things I did like: location, pastry shop with great coffee and A+ pastries. Although I have stayed in this hotel several time, this is the first time I walked "out the back door". What a treasure! A beautiful waterfall you can sit under and many, many places to eat and drink. Do not try the French place though. I waited around for them to seat and tried 2 different entrances, and they just ignored me. The hotel concierge needs a new map. Although she was quite nice and helpful, the map she provided from the hotel was truly a joke causing me to ask for directions along the way. Good luck to you in finding a better place...

Good for business trip because of its central location. Rooms are spacious which is a luxury in tokyo. Automated FX machines, ATMs all within premises very convenient. Gets too crowded at breakfast buffet and queuing needs to be better managed. Excellent in-house food options and room service available 24x7. But very less restaurants outside the hotel, you may have to walk till Asakasa. If you need to move around, the MRT line is not so easily accessible. Though the Ginza line entrance is a minute away, you need to walk atleast 800m. Hei shrine at a walking distance from the hotel. Apart from that you see only coporate offices, govt buildings. Stayed last time in hyatt shinjuku - For a more lively atmosphere & entertainment Shinjuku location is recommended for personal travel & tourism

I stayed at Intercontinental Tokyo ANA after having a dissapointing stay at Intercontinental Tokyo Bay. As I entered the hotel, theres a queue of people checking in and as i waited patiently, the guest relations officer approached me and told me she can help me check in. I was able to check in in less than 10 minutes and she even called me to see if i am satisfied with the room that she gave me. People were helpful and very polite. The hotel is near the Ginza line which is not part of the JR network so you have to pay extra if you have a JR Pass. They also offer a limousine bus service to Narita Airport for 3000 yen. Overall, they exceeded my expectations. The quality of service that they provided is excellent. I would love to stay in this hotel again

This is my first time in Tokyo. As an ambassador platinum I enjoy my benefits of the program. I got my upgrade to a suite. I was extremely happy with the room and the overall experience of the room, it was just what I needed after spending a week in small japanese business hotels outside of the big city. The bathroom was large with a super powerful shower.. (loved that!). The bed.. was the most comfortable I have slept on. Linen was so soft. I didn't want to get out of bed the next day. Some of the other great things was the MIXX bar. Love the bar and a couple of martini's hit the spot. Great staff. Lunch the next day was pricey. I thought that 900Yen for an iced tea that was not offered to be refilled, was a bit extreme. But then again I ate at the hotel. Next time.. I will not have lunch there but outside somewhere. Very conviently located close to many popular areas like Roppongi, which is in walking distance about 15mins. I would definately stay here again. What a fabulous hotel!

My second visit to this hotel and I would happily make it a third. The service is 5* and the amenities on offer are extensive.The rooms are a good size and the champagne bar always makes the stay a tad more pleasant. The courtyard behind offers lots of restaurants and options for breakfast.My only negative is the fee you are to pay should you want to use the swimming pool - even as a hotel resident.Other than that it truly is a great place and I will no doubt be back soon.Sx

Great room, excellent staff. Very pleasant place to stay. Highly recommend the hotel. I felt that the restaurant was overpriced and not great food, but other than that would highly recommend this property.

One of the best hotel in Tokyo for frequent business travelers in Tokyo. Stayed almost 25 nights there in 2013 and was never disappointed. Very friendly, competent and courteous staff. All necessary facilities including high speed internet available. I recommend this hotel for business travels and for sure also for pleasure trips.

A recent business trip took me to Tokyo and the only place I could find available for under the company limit was the ANA InterContinental. It's a beautiful property, the room was comfortable, the gym is very nice, the toiletries in the room were great. The biggest issue is I think that unless you have a ton of $ or your company allows you to spend unlimited amounts of cash there is no way you can afford to eat any meals here! We went to the bar on the 36th floor, for a "Chicken Ceasar Salad" and a drink it was $45! And the salad probably cost less than $2 to make, you needed a magnifying glass to find the chicken, won't do that again. And the breakfast buffet is over $35! Considering I only get a per diem, we ended up leaving the hotel every morning and stopping for coffee on the way to the office. Luckily there are several Starbucks and Tully's within walking distance. Also, after many days there realized there is a Hawaiian Bar/Restaurant just around the corner from the Family Mart and out the other side of the hotel on the 2nd floor of the building there is a beer garden and several outdoor seating areas and restaurants that are very reasonably priced. It's too bad I had to leave the hotel in order to get a meal for less than $50!

Stayed with my Father on August 31 for 1 night prior our departure in this hotel, since I read somewhere that this is one of the best Intercontinental Hotels in the world. Well according to my opinion it isn't.Once checking in I was told that we would receive an upgrade to a suite and complimentary minibar usage since I hold the Royal Ambassador status, which was very kind of the hotel, but also was informed about the fact that Club Lounge Access will be 10.000 Yen/night and the receptionist kindly changed in front of me the white Club Intercontinental key cards into black. Second strange thing was the usage of the pool, which costs 30 USD(!!!) for a five star hotel where I paid using advanced saver tariff already €200 for a room (Tokyo Bay was €140 and although they don't have a pool, the Lounge access is included - see my related review to that). Nevertheless we went up to our room (alone) and were really satisfied with the view over Tokyo Tower and that the room was quiet large and clean (besides the floor which came a bit in the ages and had some sort of different dirt on that).Upon making us comfortable in the room we wanted to arrange our Limousine transfer to Narita Airport for the following day (which is 3.000 Yen and runs till 16:30 and I found it comfortable). Once at the Concierge desk I asked if we could make a reservation and they said everything is fine, and we could pay than at the reception. I wanted to pay in cash since didn't want to keep my Yens with me and went to the reception saying that I want to pay our transfer for tomorrow now if possible. The answer was that reception is open 24 hours a day I could come back later (no I can not - I want to pay it now and have my vouchers in my room since for e.g. my father left in the early morning and didn't want to go there with his luggage again). I have never felt such an arrogant answer from a receptionist although have stayed already in a few hotels in the world.I definitely would give for this the terrible rating but since the room, the view and the rest of the staff was kind they get the poor result (I can't give any better since the pool is not included and this I can not accept for a 5 star hotel).All in all it was an experience staying here but as said in the title I would rather take the Intercontinental Tokyo Bay.

we were well looked after typical japanese hospitality.food was exceptional and the room was pretty big as i was told rooms are pretty small.food was very,very good.their club lounge is vey good with lots of goodies.worth staying. good value for money

In 2011, I booked for my family to stay at the ANA Intercontinental Hotel in Tokyo during July 2012 and pre-paid our accommodation at the beginning of that year. However, shortly before we were to depart Australia, my elder daughter was hospitalised and placed in inteive care due to having developed a chronic case of pneumonia that required her to be placed on life support systems and remain in the Intensive Care Unit of Royal North Shore Hospital for 3 months.Obviously none of my family travelled overseas that year. Unfortunately I had not renewed our travel insurance by the time my daughter became ill.Nevertheless, I received refunds from the various airlines and other places that we had booked including some bookings that I had made with the IHG Group in London (Crown Plaza, St James) . I was initially told by IHG's reservations section that as I had pre-paid for the ANA accommodation, I would have to write directly to the ANA Hotel management and request that it provide a refund as it was not legally bound to do so given the terms and conditions that apply to pre-paid accommodation bookings. Indeed the lady from your international reservations office with whom I spoke doubted if I would get a refund.I nevertheless sent a letter to the ANA management explaining my family's position. Not only did I receive a full refund but I also received the most heart-warming message of good wishes for my daughter's speedy recovery and a wish that she would be well enough to one day travel and stay with all of my family at the ANA. That message (from the Senior Room Reservation manager, H. Iino) deeply touched every member of my family and our many friends who I have advised of such a warm and wonderful response.After 6 months of rehabilitation my daughter greatly improved. We decided to therefore travel to Europe last year to visit her younger sister who was an exchange student during 2012 in Italy. Because of the wonderful gesture of the ANA Hotel in Tokyo, not only did we make sure that we stayed at that hotel (where we booked 2 rooms on our homeward journey) but we also decided to stay at your other Intercontinental Hotels in Rome and Berlin.Therefore, Mr Iino deserves a wonderful expression of gratitude. I also should add that when I made the booking at the ANA Hotel in Tokyo last year, I received considerable assistance from Mr Goro Takechi who also deserves praise.Their respective acts of selflessness have not only touched the hearts of my family, our relatives and friends but has lead to many of them deciding to stay at your hotel group and for a number to also become Intercontinental Ambassador Members - including Victoria Sewell and one of my friends from student days, Mr Greg Kelly, to whom I refer in the following postscript. Each of them also made their own reservations at Intercontinental Hotels around the world last year, with Mr Kelly having stayed at the Intercontinental Hotel in Chile late last year and Victoria having booked (& stayed in) rooms at the Adelaide, Rome, Berlin and Tokyo Intercontinental Hotels during the course of last year, in addition to the rooms that I also booked.It has been remiss of me for not writing earlier to express my gratitude to Messrs Iino and Takechi. However, the lateness in doing so does in no way diminish my gratitude or the sincerity of my appreciation of what was done for us by the staff at ANA Intercontinental Hotel in Tokyo. As stated above, all Intercontinental hotels have benefited from those gestures of sympathy and understanding.The stays at all those hotels were special. However, the ANA InterContinental Hotel, Tokyo was (and will always remain) very special to my entire family.

I was travelling for Business and the ANA gave us a great deal. Further, given the location it was real value for money. The rooms are suprisingly big (I have heard horror stories abot rooms in Tokyo) and the service was excellent. Ordered in room service a few times and the local dishes are exceptionally good. I would definitely recommend this hotel to for Business travel.

Stayed for a night with my family for a short break in our won city. Check-in and check-out was hassle free, so fast and efficient. Despite some 10 people in the lines, I can get my room key within 5 minutes since I stood in the line.Booked two rooms for the 4 of us, but unable to get ones with connecting door.Room is standard, not bad but not great. Furniture is not funky, old style but kept well and clean. Outdoor swimming pool is small and expensive 3000yen (but we are with kids and pool is a must) and the exhaust of the kitchen is just near the pool so basically you smell curry air while swimming.Location is within walking distance to the Roppongi crossing. Hotel is connected to nearby station building which has some restaurants and Starbucks.If you are not looking for modern deco, fancy stuff, this is the place to stay. I bought the room in Priceline for 14,000yen per night per room, which is a bargain for this level of hotel in Tokyo.

After a long day of traveling, we stayed at the ANA InterContinental. Check-in was extremely efficient and the staff very courteous. As soon as we exited our bus, the staff took our bags and told us that they would be delivered to our room--even before we had checked in. Somehow, they just ended up there which was fantastic. I had reserved a king-sized bed, but was told that there were no rooms available so they upgraded me to a junior suite. A lovely room and I wish I could have stayed there for the rest of my trip! The room had a small sitting area, a bedroom area, and then a large bathroom with walk-in shower room which also included the tub. The toilet was located in a separate (albeit small) room. Lighting in the bathroom was dim, but the room was very clean. The shower in the suite included an all-body function in addition to the rain shower head, which I loved after a long day. The room included robes, kimonos, slippers, a small ironing board and iron, a Japanese foot massager, and L'Occitane shower and lotion products. In the morning we went to the breakfast buffet which includes both Japanese and American foods, so if one was hesitant about the food, they would be covered. We really enjoyed both styles of food, so I'd recommend giving it a go. The bed was the most comfortable one I had in Japan with the right number and softness of pillows and a perfect mattress. I would definitely stay at this location again.

The review depends on one's own perspective. If you look at things in absolute, then the pluses are that it is central, easy to get to from airport (bus), and handy for most visiting business people. But if one considers that the price is five star, and paying for what one would expect from a global chain like Intercontinental, then you will be dissapointed. Those who travel often, who've stayed at other Interncontinental hotels, and who expect premium service and ammenities for a premium dollar (yen), then I'd suggest keep on looking. It is obvious that this hotel is on a cost cutting campaign, yet haven't cut the charges. As a long term visitor to the ANA Intercontinental, I doubt I will stay here again. Sad really, as it once had a great charm.

This hotel is located in the Akasaka district of the Minato ward of Tokyo. An entrance to the “Tameike-sanno” and “Kokkaigijido-mae” subway stations is located just outside the hotel, this is exit number 13. Note that there is no elevator at this exit, just an escalator that is mostly running in one direction (upstairs). If you are travelling with suitcases and want to make use of an elevator, I recommend to use Exit 11 instead of Exit 13. This exit is located just a 3 minute walk across the road from the hotel and is quite convenient. Note that those exits are nowhere near the subway, the closest platform (Ginza line) is at about 350 m walking from Exit 13 while the farthest platform (Marunouchi line) is at about 1200 m walking; inbetween those two platforms are two other platforms (Namboku and Chiyoda lines) as well. Altogether, most major landmarks can be reached by one of these four subway lines either directly or with at most one transfer. The connectivity from this hotel thus is excellent. We arrived at Tokyo Haneda Airport from our flight from Osaka. There are numerous options to get to this hotel from Haneda Airport but the, by far, most convenient option is, in my opinion, the airport limousine bus (from the company Airport Limousine Bus) since the bus just drops you off right in front of the entrance of the hotel. The bus ride from Haneda International Airport to the ANA Intercontinental Tokyo takes approximately 45 to 60 minutes to complete, depending on traffic situations. A single journey ticket will cost you 1100 JPY, which is reasonable in my opinion. There, however, is one big letdown and that is the frequency that this bus runs: it just runs four times a day which is really scarce. You thus just have to be able to catch the bus otherwise you are dependent on one of the other options of travelling to the hotel. Tickets can be bought at various points in the arrival lobby (at the first floor) of the airport and bus stops are located outside the arrival lobby. There are many options to travel to Narita International Airport as well. You can either travel by subway, train or bus. A train ride using the Narita Skyliner from Ueno station will cost you 2400 JPY, and then you have to travel to Ueno station by subway as well. You can travel to Narita Airport by the Airport Limousine as well, but this will set you back 3000 JPY; one pro is that is runs more frequent that the one to/from Haneda Airport. The hotel offers a shuttle bus, which runs quite frequent, as well but this will set you back 3000 JPY as well, I actually guess that those two buses are the same. Even though the hotel mentions that it will cost you about 3000 JPY, regardless how you travel to the airport by public transport, there is, however, a much cheaper option to get to Narita Airport which saves you about 1500 JPY. There namely is a Keisei train that runs from Shinbashi station to Oshiage, as the Asakusa subway line, and onwards all the way to Narita Airport. These trains depart at .07 and .47 past the even hours (e.g. 10 am, 12 pm, 2 pm, etc.) and at .27 past the odd hours (e.g. 11 am, 1 pm, 3 pm, etc.) from Shinbashi station and are either Access Express or Airport Limited Express trains; however be sure to check Hyperdia.com beforehand to verify your train departure. The trip from Shinbashi station to Narita Airport will take about 70 minutes and will cost you 1280 JPY. You can get easily to Shinbashi station by taking the Ginza line from Tamekei-sanno station, which will take about 5 minutes and will cost you just 160 JPY. Total will thus be 1440 JPY which thus saves you 1560 JPY compared to traveling by bus or Keisei Skyliner while travelling time is about the same. Transfer at Shinbashi is rather easy as well. Accessibility of the hotel from both airports in Tokyo area thus is excellent and quite convenient. Since Tokyo has such an extensive subway system and most needed transport in Tokyo can be done by subway, I recommend buying a PASMO card for simplifying the mass transport in Tokyo. PASMO can be purchased at one of the ticket machines at a subway station. PASMO can be used for the above described journey to the airport as well. The hotel is located in the Akasaka district of the Minato ward. This district is full of offices and accommodates quite a lot embassies and most government related buildings (it hosts various ministries as well as the prime minister’s official residence). The district thus is quite quiet and relaxed, since there aren’t that many tourists in this district. There are various convenience stores and supermarkets (7Eleven, Fresco and Lawson) located at a walking distance of the hotel. Quite a lot coffee shops (Starbucks, Doutor, Tully’s Coffee, etc.) and some restaurants are located in the direct vicinity of the hotel as well. Plenty of the above mentioned stores can also be found at the underpass towards the Tameike-sanno station or at the ARK Hills complex in which the hotel is located. Shopping malls in the Roppongi district (Tokyo Midtown and Roppongi Hills) can either be reached by foot (about 1 to 1.5 km) or by subway. The close location of the hotel to the subway station, shops and restaurants thus makes the location of the hotel excellent.We arrived at the hotel around 03.00 PM, which was check-in time as well. Upon arrival our suitcases were directly taken by the bellboy and an employee welcomed us and walked with us towards the grand lobby. She kindly asked how we were and when we queued for check-in she asked whether we were a member of one of the IHG loyalty programmes. When we replied that we were she directly took us to the Guest Relations desk and she checked us in by herself. We thus were helped directly and didn’t have to wait in the enormous queue at the front desk. The woman checked our reservations and verified our preferences. Check-in took somewhat longer than usual but this was because she wanted to give us a good room that fit our preferences. After about 15 minutes we were checked-in and she handed us our keycards. Furthermore she mentioned that we could make use of the internet connection throughout the hotel free of charge, which will otherwise cost you 1575 JPY for 24 hours per device, since we were Priority Club members which was very nice. I think this is rather expensive for internet access and I even think internet access should be included in every stay or should be available at a much lower fee. During check-in she was very polite and kind. She even directed us to the elevator, of which there were four; there were four other elevators as well which would take you to the executive rooms and swimming pool. In order to get to these areas from your room you thus have to change elevators at either the lobby or at the 21st floor. The lobby was enormous and is really spacious. There is many seating space in the lobby, furthermore there are some small shops and a business center as well. There was such a nice scent in the lobby as well, I loved it. In the evening music was played in the lobby and you could enjoy a drink there. We booked a Two Bed Classic room and, since we are with three persons, requested an extra bed. The room was about 30 square meters in size and featured a desk, two armchairs, a side table, a LCD TV with plenty of international channels (CNN, BBC, etc.) and a closet, which also featured the safety deposit box. There was a minibar corner in the room which featured of course the minibar, some snacks, some miniature liquor bottles as well as a water dispenser (which can either be switched to cold or hot water). Instead of distributing complementary water bottles to hotel guests, housekeeping completely refilled the water dispenser every day. My compliments for that. The hotel provides you with some thermal glasses as well, which are very nice in my opinion. The room featured one air conditioning unit of which the settings could be adjusted in numerous ways. In contrast to some other reviews on Tripadvisor which mention that the rooms look rather dated, the rooms don’t look dated at all. The design and furniture is quite timeless and neutral and don’t give the feeling that it’s there already for many years. Rooms were quiet and neighbors or people strolling through the corridors could not be heard, which is a pro as well. The view from the room was okay, it was not that special, our room faced some office buildings. I think we were lucky that our room didn’t face the highway which is running in front of the hotel as I think this can be quite noisy. Wired as well as wireless internet is available, at a charge, in all guest rooms; wireless internet is available throughout the whole hotel. The availability of wired and wireless internet is of course a plus, however, as mentioned before, the charge for using the internet is way too high which is obviously a con. It’s a pro however that Priority Club / Rewards Club members can use the internet for free. The internet connection was quite stable and internet speed was good as well. Since the plugs in Japan are different from the European plugs, the hotel offers free converting adapters; this is a pro as well. The beds were a little bit hard but were okay to sleep on. The linen was good and was replaced by housekeeping whenever you place a particular card on your bed. Each bed featured two pillows, just a regular one filled with feathers, which was too soft for me. The second pillow was filled with feathers as well but had a central area which was filled with kernels, this pillow was extremely comfortable and is definitely worth a try! Housekeeping was good and the rooms were cleaned and restocked properly each day. Since we were a Priority Club member we received a complimentary newspaper each day, which is a pro as well. The bathroom was quite spacious, and thus offered quite some personal space, which is a pro to me. In the length of the bathroom a large mirror covers the wall and a marble countertop with a sink is put on the wall. There is a typical Japanese toilet which is equipped with a bidet with an extensive range of options to clean the backside, which is a big pro. There is also a bathtub with a shower in the bathroom. The shower was okay, but a little bit low for a tall European guy like me, which is a minor con. Amenities provided by the hotel are excellent, the bathroom was stocked with many different towels as well as a small amenity kit for each guest (which featured a toothbrush, shaving kit, etc.). The bath and shower amenities (shower gel, shampoo and conditioner) are provided by the famous Japanese brand Shiseido and are superb, they smell really good and plenty of amenities are provided in dispensers which are refilled by the housekeeping. There was plenty of room in the bathroom to dry three towels, which is excellent. A con is the fact that the bathroom looks quite outdated in comparison to the room itself. The bathtub, tiles, floor and toilet just look old. If I check the pictures of the Executive and Premier rooms I see that the bathrooms in those room look more contemporary and new, so I assume the hotel has updated those. Maybe they will update the (bathrooms of the) Classic rooms as well…in my opinion this should be done since the bathrooms look quite old fashioned.As mentioned before there is a small shopping arcade at the lobby level of the hotel which features numerous shops. There is a business center at this level as well, which can provide you with various services like internet, printing, copying, etcetera. There is a ATM at the lobby level as well, this ATM, however, does not accept cards with the Maestro or MasterCard, which is a con to me since I expect from a large hotel chain like Intercontinental that, if they provide an ATM, it will take all cards. Note however that many ATMs (except the ones from Citibank and at post offices) do not accept Maestro and MasterCard cards. The fitness center and the hotel pool are located at the fourth floor of the hotel. The fitness center looked very modern and nice from the outside and can be used free of charge as a hotel guest. The hotel pool is located at the roof, and features a major con which is the humongous fee of 3000 JPY per visit as a hotel guest. I think it is ridiculous as a hotel to charge the guests (almost 30 EUR) just for swimming, in my opinion this should already be included in the quite expensive hotel rate. Opening times of the hotel pool are rather limited as well, just from 10.00 AM to 07.00 PM and only in summer season (end of June till half September). I understand that it isn’t reasonable to go swimming in the winter but I assume that it will be nice to take a dive in spring or autumn as well, which isn’t possible in the current situation. Maybe the biggest pro of the hotel is its staff. The staff are so kind and helpful but stay polite at the same time. The staff always greet the guests and try their best to help the guest with any inquiry. Whenever you’re in the queue, either at the front desk or at the concierge, a staff member will come by and ask whether he or she can help you, the staff is really pro-active, which is a big pro to me. Another big pro is the concierge service of the hotel. There are mostly two staff members at the concierge counter, which will give you any information or tips about Tokyo and are glad to help you with your inquiries. When we asked for the location of two airline offices they immediately searched the internet, called to the offices and gave us directions, which is superb. One minor con is that there may be some queues at the concierge desk at some times when various guests have inquiries at the same time. I think that two concierges may be too little at some times. Since we left early in the morning for our flight to Seoul and we were a little bit scared of long queues for check-out, we arranged an express check-out the day prior to our departure. So we paid the bill the day before departure and we had just to hand in our key cards the following morning. This express check-out was quite quick as well, thumbs up for this. So, to wrap up: this is an excellent and spacious hotel with good rooms and a superb service. The staff at this hotel is its main selling point and the biggest plus, the staff are so kind, polite and pro-active. While the price/quality ratio may not be that high (due to the high room rates), it’s definitely worth to stay in this, good located, hotel. There are however some cons at this hotel, which makes that the rating of this hotel will be 4 stars in my opinion. I, however, would recommend anyone to stay at this hotel!Pro’s:+ Good location, close to a subway station with 4 lines+ Easy reachable from both airports in Tokyo region+ Plenty of convenience stores in direct vicinity+ Extremely friendly, polite and pro-active staff + Very good concierge service+ Spacious rooms+ Cleanliness of the room+ Good linen+ Excellent pillows+ Quiet+ Free internet for Priority / Reward Club membersCon’s:- High charge (1575 JPY / 24 h) for internet connection for non-members- Beds are a little bit hard- Bathrooms (of Classic rooms) look rather dated- Ridiculous charge (3000 JPY / visit) for a visit to the swimming pool- ATM that does not take Maestro and MasterCard cards- At sometimes there is not enough staff at the concierge counter

We stayed at the intercon for a period of 7 days in July. It was an extremely busy hotel with tour groups, airline crew and business travellers. the rooms were clean and spacious (deluxe room) however the bathrooms very small in comparison. service was rather poor, i had to ask for complimentary bottled water countless occasions and it never came. my laundry went missing, and the staff were rather inattentive. there is also nothing much happening in the area. breakfast was the same spread for the 7 days i stayed there, which became a bit boring after the 3rd day. the bar however was pretty nice with good views and much better service. l'll not consider staying there again if i had a choice.

I have stayed in many Intercontinental Hotels around the World , I have been a Platinum Member of the IHG group and a Royal Ambassador with Intercontinenal since 2002 , but this hotel exceeds all expectations , I cannot find a fault with them ! Room service was excellent , their breakfast buffet was superb , rooms superbly service , I have nothing to complain about other than they charge for using the swimming pool , which is never done in other parts of the World especially when you are a paying guest !

The hotel is a typical Intercontinental quality, not their best but certainly very nice. If this is your home for your first visit to Tokyo it will suit you quite well as the staff is extremely helpful and multilingual and the hotel has a plethora of places to eat and drink. The rooms are a typically small and depending on what you get can have a good or somewhat awkward layout with the placement of the bathroom and bedroom. The rooms are a little dated but still extremely clean and generally well appointed. We personally thought the bed was a little uncomfortable compared to another Tokyo hotel we had just stayed at. The views from the room are better higher up -try to get above floor 20 and the higher the better. Below 20 the view can be OK to GOOD but not the nice skyline views you get from the higher rooms which have some redeeming value. The service as a separate note is some of the best I've experienced. Everyone is extremely polite and the front desk is literally amazing. I had somehow managed to mess up the arrival and departure dates and despite being nearly sold out on a night I needed to stay they quickly figured it out. In addition the representative who checked us in seemed to have a deep concern for making sure we were taken care of which was very nice.Normally I would give this hotel an Average 3* but the service level puts it at 4*. I think as a ratio of price to quality it's average, if it was cheaper it's easily a 4* or 5* but it could use a little updating on the furnishings and general appearance of the lobby. It's still a very good hotel by standards of cleanliness and overall accommodation. If you have time be sure to try the MIXX bar on the 35th floor as the views especially as night or on a clear day are fantastic.

The rooms are your typical Japanese first class hotel, fully functional, expect the only downside was the fact that hotel guest will need to pay for internet linkup. The breakfast was quite overwhelm, more than enough for one's appetite. If you have time to go for a nightcap, I would highly suggest the bar. Great scenic night view of the city, with an extremely contemporary lounge setting. Good for a date...

Had great stay here 2 weeks ago. The Hotel is very central to everything and within walking distance of great food. I was disappointed that they wouldn't include breakfast into our room rates but the internet is fast and reliable. The Rooms are clean and the staff is very friendly.

I've been here so many times, and have to admit that there were good rooms and okay rooms depending on whether it had been renovated (I have only stayed around 2002 - 2004 and could be wholly renovated now).Its a modern spacious room - a bit older than peninsula or grand hyatt or ritz nearby but what I love about this hotel is that they have a great deal bars in the hotel which serves a exciting drinks and restaurants are amazing. I have prob been to "akasaka" (teppanyaki) for over 10 times but by far one of the best in Tokyo with its view and layout of the restaurant. Its funny as its not the very best luxurious hotel compared to the competitors in this location - but I do love their restaurants including Italian (closed), Teppanyaki, Sushi. Restaurants are not over priced as those in hyatt or ritz. Its somewhere affordable within your own budget.

I stayed at this property on two occasions whilst in Tokyo for business and found it to be a very reliable hotel. I also found it to be good value for money as I got an attractive corporate rate - much cheaper than other hotels in the area that are far worse in terms of quality. Some other points:Location - The hotel is located close to Roppongi-itchōme Station. It's also within walking distance of several bars and resturants (more as you go towards the Roppongi area, which is within walking distance or one stop away on the metro). From my perspective, the best thing about the property's location is that it is in a more quite area, though you don't have to go far to find the hustle and bustle of the city. You can't really complain!Rooms - The rooms were very clean. Dring my first stay I was in a "normal" room and during my second stay I was upgraded to an executive room. The executive room was recently renovated, but was smaller than the room I was in during my first stay. Both were nice. In general, the bathrooms are very small. Also, I should note that the AC worked really well. Service - Top notch...friendly, efficient, etc. when I arrived for my first stay, they gave me a smoking room by mistake. They quickly changed my room when I discovered this and were extremely apologetic. Room service was delivered quickly and it was to a high standard (note: I never tried the resturants or bars on site). General - The wireless works well, though you have to pay for it. There is an outdoor pool, it's easy to get a cab at all times and the rest of property is just as clean / well maintained as the rooms. Finally, all of the staff spoke very good English. In the end, I would stay at the ANA again. It's not the newest hotel; however, I was happy with what I got for the price I was paying.
user_name:
legacytraveler1
New York City, New York

review_body: My partner and I stayed here on our final 2 days in Tokyo. It was perfection. Great service, a range of lovely restaurants and the room was fantastic, spacious, comfy bed with a view over Tokyo and a luxurious bathroom. We had a delicious lunch at the Champagne bar for a really reasonable price and cocktails at Mixx Lounge and Bar on the top while watching the city lights. Top place to stay.

We had no problems with this hotel: the service, the room, the views etc. This is a first class hotel.We had specifically chosen ANA Intercontinental, because it has one of the few outdoors swimming pools in Tokyo. August is very hot in Tokyo (especially this year), and we were hoping to spend a few hours resting at the hotel pool.We were very shocked, when we were asked for the equivalent of $30 per person per day for pool use. When I booked the hotel, it was not clear that there were extra charges, certainly not the amount requested.Despite the hotel's overall qualities, it was a disappointing experience.

This was my third stay in the hotel. This is one of the best business hotels I have stayed. Great Service, Good food and nice and comfortable rooms with plenty of Food & beverage choice. The Airport transfer from the hotel is a great addition to the services. Hotel is close to the subway station and that makes even more attractive to stay in this hotel

This hotel is one of the better business hotels I have stayed at. I spent two separate trips at this hotel and each experience was great. The service was spectacular. The location is great, just a quick walk to Rappongi. The rooms were very nice and clean. This hotel is the ideal business hotel if you are working in the Rappongi area and would like restaurants and bars withing walking distance.

Wish we stayed here longer than the two nights we did, but it was a perfect stay none the less. The view from our room was absolutely amazing. The hotel room itself was impeccable. The staff was very friendly and helped us get directions to Disneyland the next day. It's very close to the subway station which made it easy to get around. Would definitely stay here again.

Arrived at 11am (having landed at 5am after a 12 hour flight) and was able to check in to the room immediately, which was helpful. The receptionist took the trouble to apologise that she couldn't offer an upgrade as the hotel was fully booked, which I appreciated. The room (on the 14th floor) was pleasant, peaceful and just about large enough with a view towards the Tokyo Tower. The bed was extremely comfortable. Didn't have any meals in the hotel, so can't comment on the food, but did have in a drink in the bar on the top floor, which was breathtaking, both in the views it offered and its prices! The hotel is conveniently situated in a very pleasant district of town with a metro station just outside the door - it's actually two metro stations (Tameike-sanno and Kokkai-gijidomae), which are linked underground and the walk from the Maranouchi Line to exit 13 (near the hotel) is a long way. The hotel whilst not exactly cheap represented good value.

The hotel location is just perfect. It's right next to the train station ( one-minute walk from the subway Exit 13 at Tameike-sanno Station). It's walking distance to Roopongi Hills, which is a great upmarket nightlife place. The price is high at $250 / night but is well worth it. The staff is courteous and very helpful. The food is amazing and the rooms are neat. Free Internet services as well. Definitely recommend for luxury travelers.

We had the pleasure of recently staying at this hotel for a total of 6 nights. The Room:We were situated on the 29th floor and had breathtaking views of the city. Especially at night. The room itself was quite small but the use of space was very good. The room had everything we needed including a traditional foot massager. Service: Housekeeping and in room dining service was great. The bed linen were always changed when we left the card on the bed and the towels were replaced regularly. the room was always fresh and inviting. In room dining was always prompt and food was very delicious and hot. Portions were a little on the smaller side considering the price. Unfortunately there were a couple minor things that placed a bit of a hinderance on our stay. 1. We en-counted an incident were I was asked by staff to go back to my room and change as a result of me wearing a singlet to the buffet breakfast. I didn't think twice about my choice of attire as we had a jam packed day of tours and sightseeing ahead of us and being summer it only made sense to wear something cool. And must I add, I wore a singlet twice before this incident happened and was not told about the dress attire. Was a little annoyed to have to go back up to my room and change. I wish this was sometime we were told about upon check in. 2. Upon arrival we were advised by the man at the front desk that there was a 1 off fee for the use of the hotel pool of $30 AUD (Which I think is ridiculous, the first and only hotel ive stayed at were you have to pay to go swimming) and then we could use the pool facilities at will. Incorrect information - upon my second visit to the pool I was advised by the staff that I had to pay again, to which I explained the information I was given from the front desk. eventually I was let in and given complementary access to the pool. I didn't use the pool for the rest of my stay as a result of this. 3. last but not least. we were charged for our stay twice. When we arrived the hotel took the money out of our account and held as per usual hotel procedure (Which we were more than happy with) upon checkout they charged us again. which put us out of pocket approx $3000 until the money that the hotel held, had been released back to us 3 days later. VERY VERY annoying, especially when that effected the remainder of our second stay in bali. Tokyo is an amazing city and we thoroughly enjoyed our time and stay at ANA. would definitely stay again.

The hotel is perfectly located a few blocks away from Roppongi, with easy access from Airport with Limousine buses. It offers a great service and large, very comfortable rooms. The staff is obviously trained and friendly. Perfect value for money in expensive Tokyo.

This hotel was a very pleasant place to stay two nights in Tokyo. Unlike the airport and numerous offices I was in, they had the air conditioning on at a comfortable level for a hot, humid late July spell. Service was great and discrete; the facilities are first rate; the food was very good. The Club on the 35th floor offers a very decent complimentary breakfast and has services equivalent to the business center, so spring for it if you can put it on the old expense account.

Moved to the ANA Intercontinental for four nights after a two night stay at the Intercontinental Tokyo Bay. Reason being this hotel had a outdoor pool so had somewhere to unwind after a day of sightseeing. there is a charge to use this facility. Front desk staff and concierge were very helpful and polite, escorted to the lifts by duty manager after check in. Always enquired after to ensure everything was up to the standard I expected. Rooms are of the standard expected, slightly smaller than the Tokyo bay, Bathroom well appointed, but no separate shower, only over the bath. We had a room on the 22nd floor with a good view of Tokyo Tower especially at night when it was lite up. Pool area was large, nice pool and plenty of sun loungers. Plenty of restaurants to choose from, lovely view from the bar on the 37th floor, Food and drink is expensive but we ate out all the time. Ideal location close to two metro stations (Roppongi-Itchome & Tameike-Sanno) for getting around Tokyo and its sights, We arranged two visits, one to Nikko National Park (Complex of temples and Shrines dating back to 8th century and one to Mount Fuji (returning by the bullet train). Used location to visit other areas of Tokyo, Imperial Place East Gardens, Ueno Onshi Park, Toshogu Shrine to name a few. The hotel is only five minutes walk from Roppongi which is the centre for night life and numerous restaurants. Also spent a day at Tokyo Disney World/ disney Sea, 320 yen(£1.20) trip each way on the metro changing to the JR line at tokyo station.

I've stayed at a lot of hotels all over the world. The ANA Intercontinental Tokyo ranks in my top 5. I'm a fan of the IHG brands; the Intercontinental line is one of my particular favorites. I stayed at the one at the top of the Spanish Steps in Rome (Villa Rosa I believe) as well as others in the US. The ANA takes those incredible experiences and tops them by quite a bit. I was amazed at how welcome I was made to feel. The hotel staff, across the board, were polite, respectful, and incredibly accommodating. I never realized I was missing some portions of a top notch service experience until I stayed at the ANA. They did things to stage my room that other hotels do, but don't do nearly as perfectly (clean up, arrange, set out, etc.) This property was spotless and well cared for. The restaurants were top notch and ones I look forward to visiting again. What more can I say. I can't wait to go back.....take my wife with me this time so we can both enjoy this experience.

Stayed here for 6 nights in May. First time in Japan for me and my hubby. The hotel is clearly catered for business clientele, but I would recommend this for tourists as well. The rooms are decent and big (for Tokyo I think it is!), the concierge was very helpful, the location is great with convenience stores, coffee shops and restaurant choices nearby (and Roppongi Hills is a not that faraway), Metro is about 300m away. Haneda airport is less than an hour away by limo bus. We loved everything about Tokyo and it was nice going back after a long day of sightseeing to ANA Intercontinental.

Certainly the hotel is gorgeously appointed, its rooms generously large and comfortable, the views attractive, the food excellent and the location hard to beat... But what surprised me in a 3 day stay and another 2 day stay was IMPECCABLE service.We decided to enjoy the split of red wine provided in the in-room bar and asked for another. Not three minutes later it arrived.If I waited less than a minute for the concierge, someone always noticed and offered to help. When the hotel was full to capacity with a long wait for all the restaurants, Russell arranged for my husband, son and I to have a reunion over tea in the club lounge (an amenity worth considering). Junko, in the club lounge, made sure we were well taken care of. Ms. Momoi, the head concierge, helped us to resolve a problem with a missing train ticket and investigated some touring options while we took a jaunt to Northern Honshu and Hokkaido.Service staff was friendly and serious about getting it all right.
