Someone is really paying attention to all the details here. And this westerner appreciated the choice of pillows, harder bean-bag style being more common in Japan. Arigato gozaimashita!

Decent hotel, accessible by airport limo service from Narita Int'l Airport, as with most hotels. Room size are comparable to typical hotels in Tokyo, which are fairly tight, but okay for single traveler. Had a king size bed, with several pillow options. (Side note: I was surprised to find hotel rooms in Osaka are much larger, and more comfortable - ref. to my recent stay at the Swissotel Nankai Osaka) Hotel staffs are friendly and speak good English. Front desk staffs are really nice and helpful. One dislike is distant to the subway station is a good 10mins walk away despite the entrance is right next to the hotel.

We stayed 9 days in this hotel. We booked a normal non smoking room. The room itself was outdated a bit and very small. If you want to have a bigger renovated room you have to pay more (which we did not want to). The bathroom is also small with no ventilation. However, the bed was amazing. We had such a good sleep. I wish our bed was as comfortable as this one. The hotel staff is very nice and helpful. They helped us in whatever we needed. Breakfast buffet is very big and does not leave you with any additional wish. Every morning we received the daily newspapers as well. That was a nice touch. The gym is small but has the necessary basics. The only thing that was not ok at all is that hotel guests had to pay 35 dollars a day to use the pool. The reasoning behind it was that otherwise there are too many people at the pool..... weak reasoning and I understand that the pool needs control but not in that way with such a high rate. Furthermore, in todays technology, I find it also silly to charge for the use of the internet connection. This should be included in the price as I am sure that the cost of what you have to pay is way over what it costs them. Overall I am satisfied and I would go there again as the hotel is located very centrally with very good connections (metro).

Service was great. Pretty much every employee speaks English, which is convenient. Maybe a half mile or so walk to the Roppongi area, which is full of restaurants, bars (and as I discovered, a number of strip clubs.)

The hotel was fine, the location was good. The rooms are small but efficient, this is Japan.I was really disappointed by the housekeeping so will not return. I requested extra towels due to a flood in bathroom. When i was out the dropped the towels on my bed, but forgot the old towels and did not take away my completed pom service tray. Another day they took down the shower curtain but did not replace. A little surprising for Tokyo where service is supposed to be so good. Gave another star for the good concierge.
user_name:
elle d
New York City, New York

review_body: The location are perfect for who would like to visit art museums, the room are a little bit small but for that price I suppose is the standard for Tokyo. Front desk, concierge, was really efficient, several time they help us for different things... we spend nights in shibuya and shinjuku too but roppongi are defenetlly my favorite till now. 5 minutes walking from subway restaurants shops and art museums. Good price!! Highly recommend for that price..

I stayed at this hotel for 4 nights on a business trip. The service throughout was outstanding. Room was clean and had everything that I could need. Would comment that the bathroom though was tiny and the room was definitely much smaller than my room at the Westin hotel in Tokyo. The breakfast buffet was extensive and the food was excellent. I also ate at the Teppanyaki restaurant, which was outstanding. There's no spa but you can get shiatsu massage in your room. I did twice-- both times it was an older woman-- one was excellent and one was average. The hotel is quite large and definitely caters to a more business crowd and an American clientele. English spoken throughout is good. I would recommend the hotel, but in terms of personal taste/decor and having a larger room, I'd probably choose the Westin again over ANA, but I had a good stay with no complaints.
user_name:
GlobalGirlz
New York City, New York

review_body: For anybody who would have to work in Akasaka or wants to visit concerts at suntory hall, the Ana Intercontinental Hotel is the place to stay. Of course , the Okura has more renommé, but the Ana is the far better hotel ! It is quite new, well maintained and you'll find all the convienences of a modern hotel.the rooms are modern, well designed and mostly have a stunning view onto the traffic highways which never stop guiding cars trough this crazy city. So the rooms are also a bit noisy, at least you can hear the traffic all night.The rooms are well equipped, You will find everything you might ask for. Even a foot massage barn made of bamboo.Room service is excellent, also room cleaning is very careful and keeps everything needly and clean.The breakfast restaurant on the 2.floor is spacious and offers a great variety of food from western style to japanese style breakfast.There is also a pool and a fitness center.Service at the reception and bell service is good, but due to so many guest you might calculate some waiting time.

I had not tried the ANA InterContinental so I was really impressed with the hotel, it's staff, the range of facilities and its sheer convenience for the Ginza district and much else. I was there for one week so tried a range of restaurants. The Teppanyaki Restaurant on 37 has breathtaking views of Tokyo and marvelous food prepared by your own chef. Mixx on 36 is super for the last drink of the evening again with stunning views and friendly staff. There is a great sushi restaurant on 3, again prepared before you. Not to be missed. The lobby lounge is a busy place for locals and guests with buffet breakfast and lunch. For me, the signature facility was the Club Lounge on 35; fantastic breakfasts and evening drinks with a friendly and willing staff. My room had everything one would expect in Tokyo although some international TV channels would be nice (CNBC?). All in all, I really enjoyed my stay. Location just perfect for taxis and underground.

I have stayed at the ANA Intercontinental twice in the last year and would highly recommend this hotel to others traveling to Tokyo. I find the location great, with easy access to the Tokyo metro. The hotel is walking distance to Roppongi Hills which has some very good restaurants and bars. The room sizes are comfortable, there is a great pool, and the services has been first class during my visits.

I stayed there for only one night and was pleasantly surprised when they upgraded me to a suite.The suite was not very big but very luxurious for one person. By Japan Tokyo standards it is very nice.The bed was comfortable but pillows are too soft for my liking. Love the L'Occitane toiletries that were provided. There was also the nespresso machine which was good. Overall a pleasant stay.

Recommend highly. 10 mins from Tokyo train station, close to imperial palace, great hotel for evetyone especially for business travellers. The steakhouse restaurant not he best, but their are lots to chose from in and near.

We are still at the hotel now and everything is so for so good. Consierge, reception, housekeeping etc. etc. View of the hotel is also so beautiful. I will write again after our trip ends. Visit mixx bar at 36th floor. Because of the hotel's nice location, it is very easy to walk many places. Roppongi area where the hotel is located is very nice neighborhood.

Standard, run-of-the-mill big hotel. Good location. Room a bit dated, but in good condition - kind of like the taxis and most things in Tokyo. Service decent, but paying for wifi. Next time if skip for something more unique.

Stayed here twice since my review. The one thing I've noticed about check-in is that depending on who helps you, the service can range from great to just average. It also seems to range depending on what I was wearing that particular time. Other than that, I have no big complaints about the hotel. Would be nice if they had a small shop inside to purchase small items. The carpet and sofa inside the room also looked a old and dirty.

Very helpful staff. Perfect location. Rooms great - everything you could need including iron, ironing board, umbrella, tea making facility, fridge, great toiletries including razor, sewing kit hairbrush. Very clean and comfortable. Bakery in hotel great. Really close to the station. Short walk to roppongi. Lots of nice restaurants right outside the hotel. Vending machines with cheap drinks close so don't need to purchase expensive mini bar prices. Concierge happy to help with anything. No need to get taxis as the underground system very easy to use to go anywhere in tokyo. Short walk to tokyo tower.Would stay here again.

I recently traveled the first time to Japan and stayed in this hotel. The welcome experience was superb and efficient. The rooms, although not as large as in other InterContinental hotels, were clean, charming and comfortable to work in. The hotel has impressive choices of restaurants and bars and I enjoyed late drinks up on the top with great view. I was able to enjoy the Club InterContinental with a excellent choice for breakfast and evening drinks and on a clear day fantastic view to Mount Fuji. The location of the hotel is great as metro station is just next to it and accessibility to all parts of Tokyo easy. As a runner I specially enjoyed the proximity to the Imperial Palace where a running circle around from the hotel and back is exactly 10 km. The highlight of the hotel is the Concierge - Jerome. His passion and knowledge of Tokyo is just incredible and he know a story behind each place.

I loved this hotel. It has large, western style rooms which is out of the norm for traditional Japanese travel where it's in a ryokan. The room and the way to it was always kept clean, service was polite and courteous and it was nice for a non-Japanese speaker to have some of the better English speaking people employed there. They do have a restaurant which we did not eat at but I heard good things. Would definitely stay there again if I had the monetary means. Only downside was having to pay for internet in the room but such is the cost of traveling.

The staff are so polite and happy to help! The rooms are luxurious by Tokyo standards - and I loved how comfortable the beds were. My sleep quality was far better here than in a heavenly bed recentlyTips: 1) Catch the T-Cat from airport to ANA Intercontinental (3000Yen) and vice versa. The T-Cat (limousine bus) runs perfectly on time!2) There is a great supermarket next door at the Mori building3) There are great food shops in Mori building - i had a great ramen for 700Yen4) Taxi's are plentiful, subways metro are easy and you can easily walk to Roponggi

This is a grand looking hotel, in a useful area for sight seeing. The lobby and restaurant look good and are well maintained.Didn't eat in the restaurant, as breakfast was equivalent of £27, but there are plenty of nice places next door at Ark complex, and a 24hr supermarket. However, the bedrooms are average,and smelt of smoke in both rooms I was offered. They are too small, particularly the bathroom, where there isn't room to turn around. Beds large, but too low, mattress uncomfortable and the pillows ridiculous- they disappear when you lie on them, even three didn't do the trick. Had to use the ( smelling of smoke ) cushions underneath them for support. The bar on 36th floor was also rather unattractive, not very big and, unsurprisingly, expensive. Staff were ok, but not overly helpful. Overall, a disappointing experience.

I stayed quite a few IHG hotels before and honestly, most of them disappoint. This stay proved my loyalty to be worthy. In terms of customer service, this property should be a role model for all Intercontinental hotels. From getting off the taxi, checking-in to getting room service. They raise the standard of luxury accommodation. The hotel may not be brand new or flashy, but the staff are truly amazing at what they do. I would argue this hotel could possibly win over a Ritz Carlton. They know the drill, they know how to impress, handling your luggage the right way, taking over at the right time. I didn't get the "anti-foreigner" impression some had experienced. Front desk was extremely courteous and over archive his role. I felt professionalism, got thanked of my loyalty, checked if my requests were met etc. Even though I said I wouldn't mind, they insisted on the welcoming gift, they actually cared about the tiny details.I assume the line wasn't busy as the operator even had the time to have a little chat with me, asking how my day was and if arranging transportation was necessary the next day. At a busy hotel, it's hard to add personal attention but they did it. There is a mix of leisure and business travellers, as well as flight crew as this is an ANA hotel so the lobby sets an ambient of both luxury and comfort.The room itself was spacious (gorgeous for Tokyo standard), living room had blu-ray player, large working desk, well-stocked minibar and room was well lit. Their duvet was heavenly, I believe you could order one home if you wish to. The location of the hotel is a pity, as it is indeed a 15 mins walk until you reach the train platform, but the nearest underground exit is only 2 mins walk from the hotel. The only thing I can complain about is that they're doing it too perfectly, it lacks the feeling of being in a foreign country. If you're looking for that awkward language barrier when asking for a wake-up call, it wouldn't happen; they all speak fluent english.

Very nice hotel. Stayed 2 separate nights. The first night had an amazing view of the old tokyo tower from my room.The beds, I would describe as firm, but very comfortable. The old tokyo tower is about a half mile walk from the hotel. Many good restaurants in the area.

The hotel is well located. The rooms are relatively clean but unpleasant, too old and need major refurbishing. The service can be good or bad, depending on the employee. The food is average or slightly below average. The hotel is a typical business hotel but with really unpleasant rooms and inconsistent service.

This hotel is very foreigner-friendly. The rooms were large and comfortable, and the staff was friendly and very helpful. The location is pretty convenient. The breakfast buffet opens at 6:00 am, which is great if you're up early because of jet lag.

If you put aside the high price of everything (face it, if you accept the fact that there is a $27 room service burger, then you accept the pricing), this property is lovely. The staff is unfailingly polite and helpful. Beds: big and comfortable - I had a king, which can be a treat in Asia. The room is big enough and well appointed. Bedding, towels and amenities up to snuff. The ability to get a decent amount of hot water and a nice soaking tub. An external coffee shop with the desserts of a French patisserie. I managed not to indulge but was up against it repeatedly. Missing: in room free water. It's not a requirement, but it is a nice to have. Very cosmopolitan feel, and well appointed, clean spaces (of course, this is Japan, so what did you expect - as an example, I left my room key outside during a conversation - someone turned it in and then tracked me down...safe, lovely, kind...)When you want to eat, and don't want something nearly as pricey, you have 10 or more choices right out the lobby door and in the little mall next door.You don't even need to drink the $6 bottles of coke from your mini-bar, as there is a 24 hour grocery store out the first floor and across the parking lot. (I am not cheap, I just prefer to spend my money on better things than overpriced hotel food). There is good Chinese and Soup Stock Tokyo. There are other hotels nearer our offices, but this one is in my top 5 for Tokyo.

I decided to go to this hotel, for a change, in one of my rather frequent visit to Tokyo. I was definitely not impressed. The first impression is good, the hotel is well connected with both airports and the lobby is nice. However, at check-in a very rude Japanese employee showed me a totally negative anti-gaijin attitude. I booked the hotel through a very famous web site, and set some preferences (such as non-smoking). I was told that a room as I wanted was not available, or it was but with a $60 supplement per night, as the preference setting was non-binding. The attitude of the employee made me feel to leave the hotel at once, but the situation was saved by another employee (not from Japan, this time) that in a flash found a room, supposedly according to my preferences.I spend around 200 nights/year in hotels, since almost 10 years, and this is the first time I had such a bad experience at check-in. The room was modern - in the eighties, maybe. Very cramped for that level of hotels (New Otani, Hilton, Sheraton, I mean ...). There was no place where to put my suitcase, just to tell you. The bathroom was tiny as well. As I minor detail, I couldn't find any English channels on the TV, and the channels did not correspond to the printed notice, where the usual CNN, BBC etc, were listed. Breakfast was decent but not exceptional. Oh, and Internet is $15/day. Enjoy. Overall, a disappointing experience. In Tokyo for the price I paid there are much better options. Definitely, will not recommend.

best location, extremely near to subway. crazy generous spread of selection for breakfaststaff are always friendly and helpful rooms are nice and very comfortable however typical of japanese hotels they are really small highly recommended!

Stayed here in April for a few nights and I have never experienced such hospitality as in Japan it is truely something different than Europe. In a good way that is. The check in was very fast and they upgraded me to the Corner Suite as it was complimentary in my royal ambassador membership. The food from room service was tasty, breakfast was superb and location was excellent. However, taxi in Tokyo can get quite costy, but they managed to get me a good deal with a taxi driver for a sightseeing tour around Tokyo. A special thanks to the lady at the Concierge desk for making my stay so great.

Service,service,service. This is what this hotel offers. Excellent service,friendly staff and a fantastic atmosphere. The cocktail bar on the 36th floor with its spectacular views and with there 6pm to 9pm special " All cocktails.wine.spirits and beer " for just 4000 Yen. Thats just $ 40 Aust Dollars for an all you can drink... Fantasitc. And fabulous rooms, great steakhouse restaurant,The champange bar and many more features make this a must stay hotel.

Huge room with a king size bed and clean bathrooms. Though I felt that Wifi is charged at exceptionally hefty price. Breakfast was good. They have a limo bus service from the airport and vice versa, which is extremely convenient. Couple of stations for you to get around too.

This hotel is located 10 minutes walk from Roppongi station, and 5 minutes walk from Roppongi Itchome. There are a few other stations around, Akasaka and Tameike-sanno but we never needed them :) It's great to be close to several stations, different metro lines are run by different companies so your ticket may not always take you to the right station. It's good to have a few to choose from that are near the hotel! We had a great first night in Roppongi and then it was just a short stumble back home for a great nights sleep. The hotel itself was almost perfect. We had a good sized twin room for the two nights we were in Tokyo. We didn't try the restaurants or gym, but apparently they are of a good standard. We had access to free wi-fi which is a huge plus. They DID ask for 100 yen to print out two boarding passes, but 100 yen is nothing, so it was a minor (really minor) trifle. More just the principle of the thing... All in all a beautiful hotel with really friendly staff. When we arrived we had been assigned a king room by mistake which they changed to a twin room for us, no hassle. On the last morning the staff let us stay another half an hour after normal checkout time with no extra charge which was really nice. The NORMAL check out time is noon, which is already pretty generous :) I will definitely be staying there again and would recommend ANA Intercontinental to others traveling to Tokyo.

Nothing negative to comment on, not even a minor thing. Just stayed last week for 3 nights, which was probably my 15th time at this hotel in the past 4 years. Staff always available and friendly. Rooms great, and gym re-furbished since last time. I always arrive early morning, and even if the room is not available, you have access to the showers, changing rooms etc. Convienient location for Mid-Town Tower/ Roppongi area. Serviced by the friendly limo bus from the airports.

Folks I have to tell you that this is the property to stay if visiting Tokyo!Where do I start. Okay, who about upon entering this property, every staff member sincerely greets you with a big smile and a cultural bow. It doesn’t stop there. The FD will provide you a warm towel from your long flight. Every part of this property is spectacular! The rates are reasonable compared to the Ritz. I truly enjoyed my stay there and will be back in October. Arigatō

The Limousine Bus from Narita to ANA took about 1 hour, the staff at the hotel welcomed us at arrival. Hassle-free, we were shown in and to the check-in counter.In the waiting-line, counting 4 people, the staff was chatting with the guests in order to make them feel welcome - which is a pleasant surprise.The room, situated on the 10th floor, featured nice air-condition, big window, and excellent bed.Complimentary bottles of water were replenished every day during our stay, which counted 8 nights. The room showcased a water boiler and a truckload of teabags and coffee tasters to boot.The bathroom, of older origin (imagine light brown tiles), boasted an array of neat amenities like toothbrush, paste, combs, hairdryer, bathrobes, slippers, Shiseido shampoo/Balsam et al.The staff were helpful if we needed to find a place, ordering a table etc. The concierge recommended a ramen eatery in Shibuya, which was just awesome (thanks for the tip!).We tried no less than 5 of the restaurants in the hotel. You're thinking why ? Well, after several hours of tubing, walking, stalking, shopping and stargazing, the body will no longer adapt to the shoes other than those wanting to go just a few meters to the nearest eatery. The ANA offers a wide variety for any palate. Sushi, beef (Wagyu), Michelin starred cuisine just to name a few (the latter of which the chef himself was visiting at the moment and shook hands with the guests - not bad !)Location ? The ANA is located right by a three story freeway but the sounds did not affect our sleep (our room was pointed in that general direction).The first few nights we did only encounter business men and women at this hotel. Generally speaking the neighborhood consists of office-buildings, coffee-shops, and the odd smoking-island for the most avid smoker.The Metro is located just a few meters from the hotel, from there you have access to a host of different subway lines to and around the city.A 10 minute walk will bring you to the hip Roppongi, with shops, eateries, bouncers and the general noise and feel of this huge city.We were lucky enough to arrive during the start of autumn and the cherry blossom were starting - for each day that passed, the nearby trees burst with color, smell and delight.Oh, the general state of the city (yes, we did go all over the place) is that it is by far the cleanest city I've been to yet.And the people in general were the most helpful we've encountered thus far.Thanks to ANA who made the whole trip generally an unforgettable experience.

I spend lots of time in Tokyo on business and always stay at the ANA InterContinental. The rooms are very nice and spacious for Japan and the hotel is located in a very nice and convenient location. The hotel is also regularly serviced by limo buses from Narita or Haneda. The staff is very attentive and professional and the restaurants are very good, especially the Chinese and Japanese restaurants.

This was our 2nd time in Tokyo and the first one wasn't a nice Hotel experience at the Prince Tower near Tokyo's Tower...we arrived at 6PM and our room was in the Club Floor...at the Registration we were told that we could go to the Club Lounge for drinks and snaks untill 7.30 PM...we were arriving on a 40 hours flight (including the stops at the airports)..We were warmly received at the Lounge by the Manager, a very kind lady..The service was wonderful, wine, sparkling wine, drinks etc and nice snaks and petit japanese dishes...wifi and the wonderful view of Tokyo from the 35th floor..The room looking to the Tower was comfortable and modern with all the amenities you should need and like.Sure I'll be back to Ana Intercontinental on our future trip to Tokyo.

Although the size of the hotel is initially daunting, you soon realize that the staff is trained to provide impeccable and attentive service- fast and efficient check-in, comprehensive travel advice, etc., and all that matter for a pleasant stay. There was always someone available at the lobby (standard procedure it seems), proactively trying to be of assistance. We stayed for eight nights, and we can genuinely say that we were not disappointed at any stage.The rooms are decent in size by Japanese standards and all toiletry and comfort items are provided for. The breakfast, served in the restaurant on the lobby level, is sumptuous and caters for most styles and tastes- Japanese, Asian to Western. We appreciated the healthy and innovative smoothies (pineapple and spinach, for example) that was freshly prepared and served at the juice station- a real personal touch at such a large eating venue.The airport limousine (bus) stops at the hotel, making it very convenient in that respect. The Subway is nearby, thus connecting one to the rest of Tokyo (and Japan), there is no dearth of dining choices around the hotel, and Roponggi (A major entertainment district) is just stroll away.

I stayed at the ANA for 3 nights whilst on business in Tokyo. The hotel is central in Akasaka with local restaurants and convenience stores in easy walking distance.The hotel lobby areas are bright and well maintained. Unfortunately the same cannot be said of the bedrooms which have a decor scheme from the 70's. Also, I found other areas of the hotel dirty with the hallway carpets near the lifts were particularly filthy and stained on my floor (14). One morning there was a pair of ladies tights just left lying on the carpet at one of the lifts....The hotel has easy connection to Narita and Haneda by limousine bus which may account for its popularity for short business trips. The lobby has a 7/11 ATM which was a godsend as regular travellers to Japan will understand.  It's unlikely I'll stay here again and certainly not until the hotel enjoys a much needed refurbishment.

I love both hotels but here is a comparison based on my own experience:Intercontinental ANACheck in/check out: Quick and fastTaxi Stand: Just outside the lobbyRooms: Clean and slightly smaller but livableGym: Well equipped and even at 3.30am you are bound to find some one or a group of people exercising. The gym is located on the 4th floor and apart from the main lobbyRestaurants: Several within the hotel but if you prefer to eat out Shimbashi is closestIntercontinental StringsCheck In/Out: Fairly slowTaxi stand: Located on the ground floor whilst the lobby is located on the 6th floorRoom: Clean and largeGym: Sufficiently equipped and fairly quiet at most times. It is located on the 6th floor and one needs to walk across the lobby to go to the gym.Restaurants: Whilst there are some within the hotel it does offer lots of choices in the adjacent buildingBoth buildings are close to the train stations.My personal favourite is Intercontinental ANA but you may have your own preferences. Hope you love this comparison

My business decided to put us up in Downtown instead of by the Narita airport. Every employee seemed to go out of their way to provide exceptional customer service. The hotel is located close to numerous restaurants, bars, and grocery stores.

This is by far the best choice in Tokyo, not only for the traditional good service of the Intercontinental chain but because this Hotel is at the highest level.Close to everything and in the middle of the city in AkasakaMy advise for you is to take CLUB option since the club service (free) from 17.00 to 19.30 is serviced like dinner with Japanese specialties and your will be more than fullClean rooms and silenceI´ve got an upgrade to a better room since If I´m member of Ambassador The personnel at the lobby an every where was willing to help and when I´ve asked to the front desk manager for something I thought it was wrong during my stay and very fast got an answer and a solutionTHE PLACE TO STAY IN TOKIO

Beautiful place, atmosphere and PEOPLE!!! What a service! Enjoyed every second in it. Everybody was so helpful. Jerome was very professional, accurate, calm, understanding, great guy. Japanese people are the sweetiest, a real pleasure to visit Tokyo.

Very much a business hotel - but I was surprised how small my room and bathroom were, even for a japanese hotel. the "corridor" to the bathroom was really narrow and if you left the wardrobe doors even ajar you couldn't get out of the entrance door!The room itself was comfortable and I slept very well during my stay. Stayed on the 16th floor so didn't have much of a view either but I understand rooms on the higher floors do have great views, so would recommend asking for one of these if you do stay here. Otherwise the standard of service was very good and can't be faulted, staff polite, helpful and friendly and the breakfast buffet has a wide selection but can get busy during rush hour when the waiting staff seem to then struggle. Good for a business stay if you need to be in this part of the city, but perhaps not for a leisure break as you will need to use the underground and/or taxis to get to the tourist areas.

Our group of 25 arrived by bus and they had our group reservation all ready....we only needed to pick up the envelopes with our names on it and off we go, no lining up, no hassles.Rooms nice and spotlessly clean, nice scent throughout the hotel. 36th floor bar is nice. Outdoor pool wasn't open in May even though it was perfect pool weather (some bizarre Japanese law that states that all pools attached to public places can only open for about 2 mths between July-something and August-something). Concierge is fantastic. Front desk also really good except that for me on checkout day, I encountered a problem with my Visa chip and they took 30 mins to "finally" use the magnetic stripe...really? Anyway, good breakfast buffet. Next door is an office tower with a bunch of restaurants on the lower floors...good happy hour pubs, cafes, starbucks, patisseries, sushi bar and even a mini supermarket (good price on Glenfiddich) and Suntory Hall. Ask the concierge for a good ramen joint about 5 min walk away, called Jangara Ramen.Hotel is about a 1-min walk to the Ginza Line (Tameike Sanno stn, exit 13), but it is still a 10 min walk to the actual train track. The hotel is also a 1-min walk to another line (Akasaka?) but I didnt use that line. It is about a 7 min walk to the main Roponggi bar/restaurant area, and the Roponggi Hills shopping area.

We were lucky enough to spend about 7 days at this property. Location is pretty awesome. Everything about our stay was great. Check in was super easy. Rooms and key packets were ready as we arrived from the airport. A nice way to start after you have traveled for about 20 hours. Directly up to the room and away we go. The room was nice and spacious. Plenty of room to lay my bags around the room and settle in. The bed was super comfortable. I slept well each and every night. The room was nice and quiet. A huge bummer when you can hear a bunch of racket in the hallways and from other rooms. I rarely heard a peep. I rather enjoyed the bathroom as well. The tub was very large and deep. A great spot to soak my weary bones and relax. If you are lazy, you can even wash your hair while taking a bath (the shower head is portable and you can rinse your hair out while lounging!). We had internet included with our package. The internet was very stable and efficient. There were never any problems. The location of the hotel was as good as it gets. It was a short walk to the Roppongi District. Plenty of options in that neck of the woods for food and entertainment. Within a few short blocks away from the hotel, there were tons of restaurants to choose from. Lots of noodle houses, yakitori joints, sushi places, etc. We were never at a loss for a place to eat. Our favorite was a tiny little Thai place called Basil which was in an upper floor room behind the Starbucks. It seemed to be a wife and husband running the very small restaurant. It was as good as it gets. And very reasonably priced (900 yen for a solid lunch). I love having the Japanese hot water makers in the room. The water stays hot all the time and it is ready to use when the need arises. I make iced tea in my room for my drinks. Every time I called down for ice, the response was very rapid. Never more than a 5 minute wait. Service was always good. Each employee was nice and helpful throughout our stay. We asked the concierge a few times for train information and the directions were perfect. You can't really get much better than this.

The hotel reminded me of an old horse or mule that has worked hard and now after years of loyal service needs retirement badly. Putting aside that the hotel is not attractive, rooms so-so, and the food average, one must however acknowledge that the concierge service is excellent. Each staff member gave great advice.
user_name:
DCMomInChief
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Stayed here for Business ,the room,staff and location were great. The location is good for exploring all the lane and ways around the hotel, which seem to have an abundance of small bars and restaraunts. Keep an eye out for Russell (the assistant guest relation manager) very helpfull guy, you wont miss him as he is about 7ft tall.

Room interiors were fine, bathroom fittings were really untidy and not up to the mark for a luxury hotel. Food is ok nothing too exciting. And it is quite expensive.I stayed here in the month of April for 3 days. It was some holiday time in Japan and they were overbooked. I asked them to extend my stay but they refused saying that they are fully booked. I went to my room and booked a room for same duration through one of the popular site and the booking went through just fine. When I contacted the staff, they said we are overbooked and can only offer smoking room even though when I have booked for Non-smoking. And it was not the only bad experience regarding the service I had, even for the breakfast staff seemed to be too confused. After filling your plate when you come back to your table you have a surprise somebody else is sitting on your table. This happened with me twice and both time got apologise.

What a fabulous hotel. Outstanding Service, friendly multi-lingual staff . Very western friendly. Great restaurants and lounges with lots of variety This hotel immaculate and beautiful. My rate did include breakfast and wifi. I would recommend being a IHG Priority Club Rewards Member.

My friends and I arrived at the buffet at 6pm. The server told us the restaurant was full. They could not take any people. There were plenty of empty tables at the restaurant. When we cam e back to the hotel at 7:30pm. The buffet place was 70% empty. The server was very discriminant. The hotel front dest was not helpful and rude too.

We Stayed 2 nights here room was at best average service was average and pricing ridiculous. 1500 yen a day for wifi at a 5 star hotel, i expect that a hotel of this standard would include this in the room price. All you get at this hotel is a bigger room if your not worried about the room size stay across the road at the apa roppongi itchome its half the price the rooms are newerand cleaner and it has free wifi. I will not be staying at an intercontinental hotel ever again.

This hotel is convenient, if you have business in the area. And it is not too far from main attractions (and close to the metro) if you are a tourist--but it is not really "in" a traditional "hotspot" like Ginza, or near the Palace. The hotel itself is clean, with a very Western-friendly staff, all of whom speak good English. Rooms are average size and quality for business hotels in Tokyo (i.e., small and a bit worn). But the price was also reasonable (about $250 a night). This doesn't compare to the Four Seasons, Shangri-La, or Ritz Carlton. But it is half the price too.Overall, I will stay here again when I have business nearby. One note--for about $100 more (10,000 yen) you can get access to the "club floor"--a very nice space on the 35th floor that features a buffet breakfast, light buffet appetizer dinner, and drinks. This may not be worth it unless there are multiple people in your room, you really need an open work/meeting space, or you plan to eat and drink an awful lot. The hotel is overall reasonable, but this was pricey.Lastly, I would avoid the steakhouse in the hotel. Neither the food nor the service matched the price--there are plenty of better offerings nearby. The bakery/cafe off the lobby is quite nice, and the bar at the top of the hotel is acceptable--nice views, but not cheap!

Stayed there this April. The staff is extremely polite and friendly. They go out of the way to help you. Excellent location close to a subway station.Beds are very comfortable. Didn't try food but I have read good reviews about their tepinayaki.Overall excellent stay.

We did not stay at the ANA Intercontinental. We stayed nearby at a small, affordable hotel. But we visited the ANA for the breakfast buffet and because our friends love the ANA. Let me state up front that the staff is absolutely wonderful. You will not be disappointed with the superb service and the sweet friendliness. If I could afford it, I would stay there. That is to say, if I can afford a $37 breakfast buffett plus a $10 cup of coffee, then, yes, of course, I would stay there. Yep, that's right---$10US (approx) for a cup of coffee! Well, if you can afford that then you can afford the ANA, and I am happy for you. Seriously. We choose to spend our travel budget in other ways, however, and even though we did not stay overnight at the ANA, we did use it as our hub because our friends love it so. Thank you, ANA, for letting us in, even though we cannot afford you!

This hotel is designed for travelers from OS, especially for business travelers. If you want to be close to bars etc then try something in Ginza. If the price is too high here and you want to stay in Roppongi then shop around for more traditional hotels like the Okura or small newer/ boutique places in the neighborhood such as Hotel Villa Fontaine or APA Hotel. In terms of getting to and from the hotel, you can get a taxi from either Haneda or Narita airport but the hotel has limosine bus Y1200 one way Haneda and Y3000 one way Narita which can be prebooked (if at other hotels, you can use this service also). The hotel has the Roppongi-Itchome station right outside. Shopping mall is 7 min walk up a gentle hill http://www.roppongihills.com/shops_restaurants/shops/en/various/. Inside the elevators are efficient. The rooms are modern with good space and wireless internet. Rooms with King bed seem to have a better space configuration. Bathrooms have shower over bath with hand shower option. Japanese style toilet with press button bidet. Gym - 4F standard equipment - very complete but no rowing machine. No surcharge for guests. There is a garden pool - no open on this visit. There is a small Swedish style sauna in the mens changing rooms. Food options abound. There is a three meal a day buffet option at cascades lobby level which has good variety and quality if a little expensive. There are several other restaurants of quality and significant price. Of note is the French restaurant and champagne bar on the upper floors - worth a glass of champagne at sunset. For more basic needs, there are a 7/11 and Familymart in close proximity about 100m down the hill - turn right at the entry and good down a set of steps. There are eating out options in all price ranges and the concierges, Euro and Japanese can advise - food question from solo white guy - first response, basic or fancy, mainstream or exotic? Mos Burger at 3am near the Ibis Hotel is a jet lag saver http://www.mos.co.jp (In Japanese)

The reason I choose this hotel is it was located at Roppongi and we thought it would be near to the bar area but it's not. We have to walk a long long way to the centre of Roppongi. So it would be more suitable for business purpose as it's very expensive compare with other hotel around. Also be careful about the wifi service in room as my friend was overcharge. You better go outside for food as it's not worth to eat inside the hotel.

The hotel is centrally-located in Tokyo, so it is relatively convenient to business districts as well as shopping areas; however, in the immediate neighborhood, there isn't much around. Roppongi Crossing is about a 10-plus minute walk up the hill. Ginza is about a 10-15 minute taxi ride, and business areas of Kasumigaseki and Toronamon are somewhat walk able 5-15 minutes. The hotel and the rooms are sizeable by Japanese business hotel standards, but compared to 5-star hotels such as the Palace, Peninsula, Mandarin and Grand Hyatt, the hotel is a full notch below. Rooms have been refurbed, but overall the hotel design is a bit tired. For a larger hotel and a feel of old-style Japan, stay at the nearby Okura which has the history and larger rooms.

Was recently in Tokyo on business and found this hotel to be conveniently located in Roppongi, have very attentive service, very good breakfast for about 20 US, comfortable beds and rooms while not overly luxurious perfectly adequate, even had irons and ironing boards, etc. I had to move to the intercontinental Tokyo Bay my last night as the ANA was fully booked and while the room at the Tokyo Bay was nicer - I was upgraded to a newly renovated room on the exec floor with a great view of the bay - the location was not as convenient.

I stayed here on vacation last week. The lobby and first floor bar/ dining area is quite grand and busy, a bit overwhelming but the look of a busy high-end hotel. The concierge staff were super helpful and accommodating, and they deserve kudos! The high-floor bar, Mixx, has great nighttime views of Central Tokyo so it might be worth popping in for a drink. The gym was very nice and what I would expect from this level hotel. The room I was in felt a bit worn and dated, from the external door to carpet to the bathroom decor. I was a bit disappointed with the room given what I expect from the Intercontinental chain and being a Platinum member of IHG.Having said all that, I would stay here again. The location is very convenient to walk to the Imperial Palace grounds, metro/ subway access is right next to the hotel, and it is walking distance to the nightlife in Roppongi (be prepared for the cheese factor there).
user_location: New York, New York, United States
user_name:
Sanjay S
New York, New York, United States

review_body: My wife and I returned to the ANA after staying here last year and sure glad we came back. The service continues to exceed expectations and the rooms were extremely clean with fantastic views. The breakfast buffet is one of the finest we've ever experienced. A must when visiting, you will not be disappointed. The staff goes above and beyond to help. Jerome at the concierge desk was spot on with his recommendations and won't let you down. I would stay here every time if I could. Enjoy!

We got this hotel on last minute booked, and wasnt sure what this hotel would be like, when we arrived, the front desk was very busy but someone escort us to sit in the lobby coveniently, gathered all of our passports and help the check in. although the hotel looks old but I must say they maintain it very clean and provide best service. The staff are great and very helpful, the breakfast is perfect with thousands of options. We were pleased with the services and would like to recommend to others.

My husband and I have spent about 8 weeks in the last 6 months at this hotel and will be returning again. The service is fabulous - with enough English speaking staff to help you with all of your needs. The restaurants are also good. The MIXX bar on the 36th floor is a must do -- though drinks are very expensive. The bartenders are friendly and have invented many of the cocktails themselves. The rooms are large for a Tokyo hotel and very well equipped. Access from the airports is great. Getting around Tokyo from ANA is easy -- Ginza, Chiyoda, Namboku lines are easily accessible from the Tameike-sanno station a block from the hotel. Walking distance to Akasaka area where you will find a number of fabulous restaurants. The office tower next door also has a number of restaurants to choose from if you don't feel like venturing too far.

Great hotel in a good location which will suit both tourists and those travelling on business. Comfortable rooms with every facility that you could possibly need. The hotel is next to Tameike-Sanno subway station so you are within easy reach of Omotesando,Shibuya and Ginza. It is about a 15 minute walk up to Ripponghi but that area is best avoided in my opinion!If you are not keen on Japanese food there are restaurants in the courtyard by Suntory Hall and a very good supermarket next door. If you are determined to find a Starbucks (yuck...) there is also one next door.See my other reviews for good Tokyo coffee!

I have stayed at Ana a couple of times and really recommend it. Great location with some amazing view on Tokyo Tower. Rooms are very clean and well equipped. I truly enjoy breakfast at ANA, the choice is a great. My favorite place the MIXX Bar & Lounge on 36th floor with the breathtaking view, especially at night.

A total hassle free and enjoyable experience. Is a perfect 5 star hotel. Rooms are clean and well equipped, services are top rate, staff helpful. Breakfast is a nice mixed spread ofJapanese and continental. Rates are steep, but it is worthy it. It is also very conveniently located, easily reachable from Narita airport though the Limousine bus (is actually the first stop) and just next to the subway stop.

We booked this hotel last minute and were very happy with our decision. It was convenient to the subway and there was a Starbucks and a 24-hour grocery store next door. Our room had a great view of Tokyo Tower. A fabulous bonus was that the cherry trees were blooming and we got some great pictures just outside the hotel.

I stayed here recently, and it was a very pleasant stay, Subway was within easy walking distance, Breakfasts were great and the view from the breakfast room on the Executive Level was excellent. I needed a Japan to Germany Plug Adapter, which i was easily able to borrow from the front desk with no bother at all, sometimes its the small things that matter.The service, as ever in Japan, was exceptional, and you get the same level of service from the chamber maids, the front desk staff or the management, very respectful, lots of bowing, but still very nice to see.You've gotta love this place!

I stayed here recently, and, as you would expect in Japan the service was excellent. We had access to the executive level for breakfast, the choice was more than adequate and nothing was too much trouble. The view from the breakfast area was great, you could see over most of Tokyo.The room was also very good, nothing too big, but again, you come to expect that in Tokyo. I also needed a Japanese to German plug adapter which was no problem, sometimes its the small things that make a difference.Location to the Subway was great, with the nearest exit bringing you out basically underneath the hotel.All in all a very pleasant four days, and i would not hesitate to recommend this to my colleagues.

Sometimes it's not about what goes wrong, it's how you put it right. That was certainly the case at the ANA Intercontinental Tokyo.We arrived stressed. Our flight arrival time from the UK meant that we'd missed the hotel shuttle bus and there wasn't another for two hours (we got this on our return trip and it was excellent) so we travelled in to Tokyo on train and subway - which was first class and SO clean compared with the UK. However when we arrived at our station we had to walk underground for 10 minutes with our luggage until we re-emerged - thankfully to within 100 metres of the hotel.On checking in however the hotel did not have what we booked - a double interconnecting with a twin. I have friends who can stamp their feet in these situations and get an instant upgrade, I however can't do that effectively clearly as I had a 'groundhog day' conversation with an incredibly polite but not completely multi-lingual receptionist who constantly went back to her manager to reappear with the same message - they did not have what we had booked.We went to lunch in the hotel while they tried to rethink the situation. The first restaurant on the ground floor - an open plan buffet affair - told us there was a 40 minute wait. Stress levels rose. Only one restaurant on the floor above had space for us, and thanks to a very calming manager, a private space and a reasonable burger (not our first choice but hey) we started to relax.On checking in for a second time the manager apologised profusely for not having the rooms we had booked - he could only offer us two interconnecting twin rooms but would push the twin beds together in one (albeit in front of the wall fixture containing the bedside table, severely reducing our space to walk round the bed and making the room look a mess). However in return he gave us complimentary use of the executive lounge on the 35th floor during our stay.What this brought us was complimentary breakfast in the lounge each morning, cocktails and nibbles early evening and coffee of an evening when we returned to the hotel after dinner, free wi fi and fantastic skyline views of the city.I haven't calculated the saving this brought us during our stay, but it was certainly worth the inconvenience of having a scruffy double room!We'll definitely be returning to Tokyo, and to the ANA Intercontinental - only this time booking Executive Rooms with access to the Executive Lounge!Importantly, the hotel is in a great location - there are wonderful restaurants in Roppongi which are walkable (and which I have reviewed separately) and the staff after our initial check-in experience couldn't have been more helpful.

Everything is top notch here. Room was superior to my expectations.The only negative, and Im nitpicking, is the staff in general doesn't seem to be english proficient in general. It's not a big problem but it could be in an emergency such as an earthquake.

We stayed here as a family (two adults and one teen) in a standard room.The accommodation was somewhat smaller than we were expected but was clean and well equipped. It fitted with other Intercons in terms of room layout and design we have stayed in previously.The location is excellent. The hotel is right beside an underground station and there was a great selection of restaurants and bars in the area.What sets this hotel apart was the fantastic concierge service. My wife and I were very impressed with the team who were able to able to provide detailed and clear information on a city which to a first time visitor could potentially seem quite intimidating.It should also be noted the Executive Lounge facility in the hotel is excellent value and provides great views accross the city.In summary we would recommend this hotel as a great place to stay to discover Tokyo.
user_name:
Andrew T
Dubai, United Arab Emirates

review_body: This hotel has everything you need; fantastic view, great restaurants, shops and nice big rooms. The service is fantastic; the rooms are clean and well equipped. The only thing this hotel lacks is charm. This hotel is well suited for big conferences or similar. Next time I will look for something more intimate.

My hisband and I stayed 2 nights in this hotel. Nice rooms and very professional services. Check-in smooth as silk, Our rooms was ready before the official check in time. Nice big room with good bed. Bathroom is rather standard but nice bath products from Shiseido. The hotel is very close to the underground which is very convenient. One day we had lunch in The Japanese restaurant which was really very nice. Next to the hotel are several office buildings with very nice restaurants and a nice small supermarket. But we really want to thank the consierge Ben Johnson. He really took all the time to explain the underground system, where to go if you have limited time, where to eat etc. His very profesional help made it a great impression on us. Following his instructions it was so easy for us to know Tokyo so much better.

The staff couldn't be nicer. The hotel is very dated though. The first thing I did when I got to my small room was check the hotel's website photos as the rooms look so spacious on thier website. After checking the features were all the same, there was obviously rick photography on their web page to make the rooms look bigger. Great location if you dont mind the small rooms. I'll go back to the Park Prince Tower as the rooms are much larger, even if the location is not as convenient.On Saturday morning the breakfast service finished as 10.30 and you MUST leave the dining by 11. No option to linger over your coffee and newspaper.

We stayed here for our honeymoon for our short two nights in Japan. We had told them it was our honeymoon when we booked (we booked a regular suite). When we got there they presented us with the Imperial Suite on the top level! We were so thrilled. :) The room was beautiful, and the hotel was great. We went to the MIX bar at the top to have cocktails and its got a great view of the city at night. The hotel staff is extremely friendly and they go out of their way to make sure you are taken care of. We walked in and were immediately shown to the front desk. When we would head out, they would go out of their way to come over and make sure we knew which way to head to the train. Service was fabulous. I'd absolutely stay here again!

Stayed here for a weekend in Tokyo to do some sight seeing around the area..Hotel is a little bit older than we expected. Rooms are a bit dated, but service provided by the staff was outstanding. As the Hotel is located close a subway access point this makes, getting around Tokyo very easily.

A good but not spectacular hotel. Nice, albeit small, rooms. Good service and an impressive choice of restaurants should one want to eat in the hotel rather than explore the area.Fantastic location to do most of Tokyo on foot, assuming you like to walk. Roppongi is relatively close and easy to get to, so good nightlife is nearby. Shibuya is just a little further in the same direction. In the opposite direction is central Tokyo, including the Imperial Palace, Tokyo station, Ginza and all it's shopping and the Tsukiji market. As a result you can take an awful lot in without having to consider the Metro, taxis or buses. We did it all without any form of public transport, just remember to bring comfortable shoes!

Was located here on work purposes for three nights, and I can't fault the hotel much. It's a typical business hotel, but well maintained, and had a nice stately vibe about it. The Aurora ballroom was starting to show its age a little though, or perhaps its just the yellowish lighting. My room on the tenth floor was quiet and roomy, with comfortable amenities. Instant service was brisk, and I received the sewing kit and adapter that I requested for in good time. The Pierre Gagnaire bakery is a good place to drop by, and I'd recommend the chocolate au pain. Location is good, a literal stone's throw away from the subway station that brings you everywhere. Walking straight down along the main road mindlessly leads one to the effervescent Roppongi, always an interesting stop in one's itinerary. Perhaps the only recommendation I'd have is to include the business hours of the hotel's restaurants and bars within the directory that's located inside each room. I ended up looking for the closing times via the internet.

Despite having a subway station next to the hotel, overall location isn't terribly convenient. There is a connected office tower with several restaurant choices, but options are limited. Not too many shops around the hotel, so be prepared to use the subway.Rooms are average, but overall hotel is showing its age despite being very well kept.

Stayed for 3 nights, paid for the club floor which was excellent, with a comprehensive breakfast, good high tea and evening canapes. All the staff were very attentive, took an interest & were extremely helpful, particularly the club Floor manager who went out of her way to help me with tours, maps & local advice. The room was well appointed with a fantastic view, and hotel is very easy to get to directly from the airport using the Friendly airport Limoisine service which stops within the undercover pull-in by the hotel lobby. The Tokyo Subway is a 2 minute walk away, if you want to explore, but there is a lot in the local area with in walking distance, as well as a number of very good restaurants, and if you like 'Global chains' the Hardrcok & TGI's are within easy walking distance. All in all a well situated hotel, with all the facilities for a very comfortable stay, with top quality, knowledgable, helpful, friendly staff.

My friend and I stayed at the ANA Intercontinental for five nights during our first trip to Tokyo and chose the hotel primarily based on guest reviews. We booked an advance payment rate that included a full breakfast which turned out to be a smart move since it kept us going through the day and we didn't need to eat again until evening. Other than breakfast we did not eat any meals in the hotel because there are better and much less expensive options within all walking distance. Our company has an office in Tokyo and one night we met a colleague at the Grand Hyatt for cocktails and dinner and all I can say is now I understand everyone wants to stay there. Overall the Intercontinental is not a luxury hotel but it is definitely better than average and a good central location from which to explore the city.

Yes, the rooms are not large. Yes, the bathroom needs updating and is TINY (the property is very old but remodeled...whadaya gonna do?) But the rooms themselves are smartly appointed for business. The bed is very comfortable. That's 90% of the business battle there. The decor is also modern throughout. The lobby, champagne bar, and restaurants really are very beautiful and well designed. If you have a problem with the public spaces, then you must be an incredibly hard to please person. They're superb. The rooms, hallways, and common areas are all very clean as well, as you would expect at a 4 star property in Japan.Also the service is very good. The PBX is quick, efficient, and responsive. Rooms service sometimes had issues with English but someone would always come online to help translate. I ate the after midnight room service twice and would not advise. Not good either time, but the restaurants all looked nice and the after midnight selectiosn aren't on any of the restaurant menus. So there is that. I think where some of the negativity comes from is that we often get so spoiled with 5 star hotels in Asia. Or one sometimes expects 5 stars out of an Intercontinental property. This is not a 5 star hotel. On some websites it is listed as a 5 star property and on some websites as a 4 or 4.5 star property. I would completely agree with the assessment that it is not a 5 star property. But it is a very good 4 star property in a very good neighborhood. Think: good Marriott property and less Four Seasons/Ritz-Carlton and you'll have perfectly set expectations.

I have stayed here many times and it does the job very well. Very comfortable beds but not pillows as they are quite Japanese in style with the little balls in them which make it too hard for me. Everything in the hotel costs quite a lot but it is in a good area near subway and many good restaurants in walking distance. If you get a high floor the views are often excellent.

I had 3 nights at the ANA Intercontinental. It was a good experience, but nothing remarkable. The rooms were comfortable if a little pedestrian in their décor. The restaurants were excellent and in common with Tokyo, ridiculously expensiveBreakfast in the atrium was fine – the buffet was good and varied and the service was acceptable given the volume of guests. It is a good business hotel, centrally located and with pleasant and professional staff.

I stayed here on two occasions in 2012 and again in Mar 2013. Convenient for the Narita Limousine bus (1st stop). They have changed the system from my previous visit in respect of the 'Club Floor'. Now you choose your room type and can buy access to the Club Lounge. I think if you will use the Lounge in the afternoon/early evening and for breakfast it's worth the 10,000Y for two in a room. Overall I like the Ana. It's got the balance of offerings/ cost about right for Tokyo. It's service is very good, its comfortable, familiar farther like a comfortable pair of favourite shoes.

Spent three nights here recently. Great location and the staff was helpful without being too "pushy". No charge for using the gym (unlike other hotels in the area). AC was actually nice and strong! Breakfast buffet which others have mentioned was average at best to me (around 3000 to 3500 yen if I remember correctly). Room service was prompt but extremely pricey (one item I ordered was the boneless fried chicken...which ended up being 4 bitesize pieces of dark meat for a price of 2000 yen I believe). Loved the bakery on the 2nd floor...I will have dreams of the rosemary and sea salt focaccia bread. There's a small grocery store and two convenient stores within 200 feet of the hotel. The limo bus from Narita comes straight here. Would come here again.

Just spent two separate stays at the ANA. One for three nights, then another one night stay a few days later. AS expected in Tokyo, the rooms are not huge, but they are reasonably appointed. I stayed in the lowest room type on one stay, and was upgraded up one class on the other.But I do want to give a massive thanks to the Concierge team and to Ben Johnson in particular. they helped arrange restaurant reservations (at 3 star Michelin no less) as well as car hire and advice on specialist stores to visit. Without them, the trip would have been a lot less fun. Much appreciated.

I stayed several times at this hotel.I can tell good location for business, decent facilities, spacious rooms and many.Front clerk were kind and polite, but not efficient.And club lounge has poor variety of food presentation, so I choose not to use club lounge the other times.But I like Intercontinental chain hotels, and likewise ANA Tokyo

Great hotel, central to great food and music venues (check out B Flat Jazz club). Transport options are too easy. Great champagne bar. Staff are excellent, interested and abundantly helpful. Well done.

I stay at the ANA Intercontinental every time I am in Tokyo. Overall I like the hotel. The rooms are a decent size, however the bathrooms are small (but well stocked with amenities). My stays are usually limited to 2 or 3 nights so I can overlook the small things. I have never had a bad meal in any of the hotel restaurants and the breakfast buffet serves both eastern and western foods. The concierge is very helpful with restaurant suggestions and transportation needs. The one thing I think they can easily address is the television. There are very limited English stations and most of these are news stations. So if you are accustomed to relaxing in front of the TV you may want to consider this.

I stayed in the hotel for about 4 weeks in month of Oct - Nov 2012. Hotel is conveniently located near to metro station , with lot of super stores near to it. For night life people can walk up to Ropongi . Quality of sleep was excellent. I an a Indian and vegetarian , there are 3-5 Indian restaurants located near to hotel. Food in hotel is bit pricy , but worth the quality.The rooms are good with nice facilities even if they are a little small compared with others nearby; service though is very attentive and overall atmosphere is relaxing and a welcoming.

This is a great hotel to stay for business. It can be pricey unless you know the secret - join the Intercontinental Ambassador's club. It costs $200 per year, but I made this back with one stay at this hotel: VIP greeting, complimentary upgrade to a junior suite, 1 free breakfast, fresh fruit upon arrival, mineral water in room replenished daily, in-room gift, extended checkout—up to 4pm, dedicated Ambassador check-in area, one complimentary pay-TV film per stay, complimentary newspaper delivered daily. The food at the restaurants was all delicious and priced to what you would expect in Tokyo (ie, expensive). Rooms include LCD television, refrigerator, iron, mini bar, scales, hair dryer, bidet, toiletries, bathrobe (28-35th floor), safety box, high-speed 100 Mbps internet access (JPY1,575 per day) and massage services 10:00a.m. - 2:00a.m JPY5,250up / 45min and JPY7,000 / 60min. I have stayed at many hotels in Tokyo including the Grand Hyatt and this one is my favorite.

This hotel is in a great location near to numerous bars and restaurants, which is good since the hotel bars are a bit pricey even for Tokyo. The rooms are good with nice facilities even if they are a little small compared with others nearby; service though is very attentive and overall atmosphere is relaxing and a welcome break from hectic Tokyo life. Top floor bar is very good but pricing means it is a one drink destination! Free late check out was a bonus since it is rare in Tokyo.

Let's be honest - Tokyo is over-priced EVERYWHERE. So I'll take that out of the equation. They have a 24 hr gym that they do not charge you for (Hope you are listening Sheraton Miyako!!), numerous bars and restaurants, and you are close to a number of train stations and short cab trips to roppongi. If you are a traveler that looks for hotel points - stay here and get your IHG points and enjoy the best hotel value in the Roppongi area.

I stayed at the hotel for about a week and had a very good experience. Located next to the government area it is close to midtown ( on foot 15 minutes) and Ropongi hills ( may be 20 minutes?). Also on the subway line to Ginza and other areas. The rooms are large for Tokyo and well appointed. The breakfast is very good. Beautiful view form the 25th floor where my room was.The staff was polite and helpful. I would stay there again.

Have stayed there several times for business trips, because of proximity to offices. Everything clean and in good order as to be expected in Japan. Breakfast buffet is good except the coffee. Even if order cappuccinos, double espressos, etc. it just does not come right (must be either the beans or or the machine), but all else is really of good quality. Has an excellent Teppanyaki on the 37th floor (see Akasaka) with a great view. One more reason I like it, is the early morning jog around the Emperor Palace: 1.5km to get there, 5km around and then back. Splendid during sunrise. But still....get stay at better hotels for comparable price.

The concierge staff were great. This is a very well kept upscale business hotel, lots of pleasantries for a business traveller. Pricey but I loved the location. Very close to many great attractions. Near Tokyo mid town, Ropongi hills and many museums.

Nestled in the glamorous Akasaka, this is this is the Intercontinental brand at its finest. Nothing better than eating their delicious breakfast with sweeping views of the city and Mt. Fuji in the distance. Pros:-Comfortable, contemporary rooms with lush bedding.-Japanese toilets. Nuff said. :)-Fantastic breakfast with loads of options (NOTE: get the package with the Club lounge package to enjoy the view, free happy hours with wine, beer, delicious espresso, etc.). Location is fantastic. Walk to the US embassy, other 5 famous hotels, or delicious sushi joints within a few minute walk from the entrance.-You can take the bus directly from Narita door to door.-Staff is exceptional.Cons:-Smaller size room (then again, it's Tokyo)-Mixx bar at roof has a beautiful room, but drinks are absurdly overpriced. My advice: skip it.

Very attuned to international visitors, convenient location, good transportation to and from Haneda and Narita airports, attached to a mall and walking distance to good restaurants. Many amenities provided in room - for US travelers not used to Asian hotels, you get toothbrush and toothpaste, razor, shaving foam, water and many other items included in your rate with no extra charge.Rooms are not huge by US standards but very comfortable.

I stay at the ANA Intercontinental Tokyo and I do love the hotel, the thing is that the hotel misses the small things. I generally stay for at least a week and after paying over JPY 35,000 it seems that there are only 4-5 channels that are English and of those there are 3 of those that are "news" other than that there is FOX and National Geographic otherwise you have to pay for a movie. Surely at the rate the hotel pays they could subscribe to more English channels or even say HBO .....But the standard of accommodation is very good, focus on the small things and you have a perfect solution.

Not the best place to stay since it is a smaller sized room. There is a Michellin restaurant here and I was pretty underwhelmed to be honest. I've been to a few already and this restaurant was well...Went to the champagne bar, had two drinks, and 80 bucks later.. realized it was a hotel. They price out like a 5 star but the service was ok. Arrogant almost. To commute, you need to hit subways so thats not too good. But if you are cabbing it, its a good location. The rooms are small. You can do just as well at other properties like the Century Hyatt for a bigger room experience. But for that Hyatt, you need to get on a bus to the station. Can be just as much a pain as this place. All in all, would I go there again? Im not too sure. Im a Platinum Ambassador here and they didnt do much other than let me check in on the lounge floor but also reminded to pay an additional $100 a day to use it. a lounge? Speaking of the lounge, that place is a zoo. People bringing in outside food, having lunch there, drinking up a storm, children running around. it was a mess. For the price, you can do much better. For the location, its good. For the staff and service, can do better. If you want to be right on top of a station, go to the STRINGS Hotel. I dont think it is an ANA property so you might get better service.

The hotel is well located next to Roppongi area. The staff is friendly and willing to do their best to accommodate you.I was booked in a non smoking executive room but at the time of checking no non smoking room were available in that category. After a little discussion I got upgraded to a suite.The Mixx Bar & Lounge on the 36th floor has a breath taking view over Tokyo, and is just perfect to relax in the evening.

This is a clean conference type hotel. The rooms are small but nice. The beds were rather hard, but I'm a picky sleeper. The one real issue that I had with the hotel is that my highest level priority status with Intercontinental got me nothing, not even access to the lounge. The hotel reserves these perks based on room reservation type, not status. Seriously? The breakfast is nice, but expensive ($35 USD) per day. Many companies receive a breakfast discount decreasing the amount to about $20 USD so you may ask for that. The place is convenient, but I probably will try another hotel in the area before returning.

If this hotel has not got it,it does not exist,First impressions were of a very high standard.i stayed in an executive room & it was immaculately clean with a huge comfortable bed & every mod con that you can think of,everything is designed for your comfort.The complimentary toiletries were excellent {comb toothbrush & paste earbuds razor & gel hairbrush moisturiser shampoo showergel showercap} fantastic bathroom facilities include a state of the art toilet /bidet with heated seat...!!!! The vast selection of restaraunts & numerous bars were of a high standard & do advise the selection on the 36th floor just for the amazing views across the city.All staff were very smartly dressed,polite, courteous & very helpful at all time This hotel is a10 minute walk from The Imperial Palace & the Ginza shopping district.I would definetly recommend this hotel to anybody that likes a bit of luxury & pampering....

During last day of my stay in the hotel (after a busy week), I decided to have breakfast at the hotel. That was a disappointing experience.Got seated in adjacent lobby area in one of those low cocktail tables. Seemed the restaurant still had empty tables but the host refused to seat me there. After I was seated, there was no wait staff to serve the area. Took me 5 minutes to flag down someone to order coffee, used plates were not cleared out, and no refill of coffee at all.Guess I will stay at Hilton or Westin next time when I visit Tokyo again.
user_name:
Kel_c_hk
Hong Kong, null, Hong Kong

review_body: Although certainly not for budget traveller, this hotel is worth the price.. Its 5-star title is no joke.. The food is great, room service is available anytime, room amenities are more than adequate, and the location is a plus plus!We travelled with our 4yo and arrived early after a long 8 hours flight.. We were tired and the kid was a bit cranky.. The front desk was really understanding and kindly searched for an immediately available room for us to check in early..The concierge was also very, VERY, nice.. Helping us with directions and maps and what-not, and with very good English too.. It was year end, and all the regular working hours are altered.. The concierge helped us call each and every store/shop/restaurant we wanted to visit, to ensure their operating hours, so we didn't have to waste our time going to closed places..It was a pleasant stay for us.. If you seek a comfortable vacation and willing to spend at quite a leisure, I would definitely suggest this hotel..

Now japan is an expensive place and so is this Hotel so is it worth it .Do you just want to say its good because its dear and 5*. ? The answer is this Hotel is great from the service to the food to the rooms to the location. Its right over the train station so transport is not a problem to all the main sights in Toyko.Book a room and sit back on the heated toilet seat and enjoy.Set lunch in the steak house was great.

I stayed at this hotel from 13-16 Jan 2013 on a business trip. The hotel is about 90 mins from the Narita Airport via the Airport Limousine Bus (3,000 yen). The staff are friendly and helpful. The room is good size, clean and comfortable.The hotel is located near (3 mins walk) the Tameike-sano subway station on the Ginza line. For those of you coffee lovers, there is a Starbucks nearby. I took the subway to Asakasa Mitsuke station (same Ginza line, just one station away) last night where there are lots of night life and food options.I will choose this hotel again next time I visit Tokyo.

We ended our vacation in Tokyo and stayed here 2 nights. The room was large by Japan standards. Beds comfortable with nice linens. The bathroom was roomy enough. It was well supplied with wonderful toiletries.Breakfast, included with the room, was a full buffet. I really loved the yogurt. The food was excellent. The restaurant is in the lobby, it's very open, spacious and comfortable.The hotel staff were friendly and very helpful. There are upscale eating places around it in the Arc Hills & we also found a Lawrys across the street(for those who want something from home)The subway entrance is right next door but to get to the actual subway it's quite a walk and for the handicapped there are a few stairs that must be taken if you want to walk underground. But the area is clean, modern and quite peaceful so it was a wonderful hotel to start and end the day.This was our second time here and both times we loved it!

We stayed at the Intercontinental for 4 days with my fiancée and overall, it was very convenient.The +:- wonderful concierge which is key in Tokyo- room of descent size (c24sqm)- very good service in general (they gave us an early check-in for free)- central in Tokyo- good value for moneyThe -:- The hotel doesn't have much charm although you can see they're trying (photo exhibits, French bakery on the ground floor, piano on the mezzanine,..)- although central, the neighbourhood itself is a bit depressing- a bit noisy, hotel is on a main axe- no spa- breakfast is expensive and not amazing

During our trip in Japan this would definitely be the best. The concierge were very helpful and really tried to make your stay the best by helping you out with any questions. We were lucky enough to have access to the club lounge which meant daily breakfast which was very tasty and nice variety. Also there was afternoon tea which we only tried once but was very nice. The cocktail hour was 530-730 which included MUMM champagne, spirits, beer, sake etc as well as canapés such as sushi, cheese, crackers etc. the only thing that would be good would be to extent the cocktail hour each day. Our room was spectacular as we had a high floor facing towards tokyo tower. Rooms we spacious, clean, tidy etc. would definitely recommend this hotel! The service was top notch! Also since we stayed for New Years the concierge staff were able to recommend a countdown party. The club cocktail hour was great for pre drinks before heading out!
user_name:
RobynN_13
Sydney, New South Wales, Australia

review_body: Great price for Tokyo and a very good location near Roppongi and Ginza. Bus from airport drops you off right on the property, so convenient and way cheaper than a taxi from airport. Staff are very helpful - breakfast buffet is good but not spectacular. Rooms are on the small side but very nice - had a room overlooking the Diet and towards the Palace. Not as good as the Hyatt down the road but a very good option for a good price in Tokyo.
user_name:
Andre B
Long Island City, New York

review_body: I stayed at Intercontinental on my recent trip to Tokyo for the bulk of my stay, while not the cheapest of hotel options available certainly not the most expensive and certainly a notch above the average in terms of quality and staff competence.Nearly all staff I encountered spoke good basic english and the concierge services were amazing.A great selection of restaurants and bars to enjoy a drink.
