The Sky bar waiters will mix you a fantastic cocktail while you enjoy the superb view and ambience amongst the mix of local business men and travellers alike.

I wouldn't go as far as saying our time at ANA was amazing. It was a very typical large hotel.....interesting lobby with great water features. Rooms are small but well appointed. Definitely ask for a room facing Tokyo Tower as it is stunning at night. Breakfast buffet was just ok.....was expecting more after reading reviews. My husband and I definitely enjoyed a late night drink in the Whiskey Bar where there was live piano/bass providing a very tranquil atmosphere! One other thing to note.....our boys wanted to order room service dessert and were disappointed to learn that after 9:30 pm there is only one dessert option.

The location of the hotel is quite ok, though far from main tourist attractions, only near the imperial palace, near the the Ginza line station G06.However there is room for improvement especially in the restaurants where the services could be a lot quicker. i.e.: breakfast, the waiters are serving tea and coffee on each table, could far more efficient to let the guests doing it themselves, would avoid waiting to be served. We also had to wait to be served other drinks, vegetables were served too late, after the meat was served, ...So could be better. rooms are ok, but carpets on the floor would need a good clean up.

Great hotel, I have to say the intercontinental brand is one of the best, every intercontinental hotel I go just surprises me, and this one is no exception.The lobby is beautiful, very crowded, it's nice to be in a hotel where there's people coming in and out all the time.The rooms are great nice view, not so big but perfect, the bathroom is a bit small, can't fit to people in there. The staff is very helpful an polite.The location is perfect right next to the hotel is a subway station, and on the other side of the hotel there is a small shopping center the Ark Hills, full of restaurants. Bubby's is one of them, I have had the best pancakes of my life.Great hotel!!!

We looked at all of the luxury properties in Tokyo and were glad we chose the ANA Intercontinental. It offers a very nice balance of luxury, location and service at a price much less than some of the premium hotels in the area. The lobby is spectacular with large glass panels with cascading water. It was a great place to relax or visit with friends. As with many Tokyo hotels, rooms were on the smaller side but modern and very comfy. We especially liked the toilet with a heated seat! We never heard noise from the hallway and our city view was very nice. I suggest you book a rate that includes breakfast. It is one of the largest assortments I have seen, and you could choose breakfast or many lunch items as well. I especially liked the juice bar, and they always featured a different ultra-healthy juice made in their Vita-Mix. Croissants were as good as anything I've had in Paris. While available separately, the price is somehow easier to handle when mixed in with the room rate.;Staff were friendly and tried to please. We used the services of the concierge on many occasions, and each we spoke with were helpful and made great suggestions. There is grocery store steps from the hotel which is very handy if you need snacks or beverages. The hotel does not offer any of these items onsite so it was a very handy option. In room wi-fi was very fast, although you have to sign in each day, a minor inconvenience. There is a subway stop steps from the hotel and we mastered it pretty quickly. The concierge was also a great help in teaching us the ins and outs of using this very large and very busy system. Overall, a great choice whether visiting for business or pleasure.A note on getting to and from the hotel: We chose to use the high speed Narita Express to get to the hotel faster,, but the decision on using this versus the airport bus depends on a personal choice. The bus is slower and may be affected by heavy traffic but goes door to door, while the train requires you to take a cab to and from Tokyo Station.

We loved the Intercontinental. Located near a Tokyo Metro station, and near the hub of Roppongi, the hotel was near everything. Unlike other places, the reception and the concierge both spoke perfect English and in typical Japanese fashion, were extremely accommodating and helpful. The room was perhaps a tad small for the price paid, but I suppose with the intercontinental branding, you do pay a premium for it. Even despite the huge discounts I believe we received, it was still a little pricey. Nevertheless, it was a solid hotel, and would recommend it to others, if it were within their price range.We were also on the 20th floor, and I believe that level 19 is a smoking floor, so, a little smoke must've seeped through to level 20 via the air conditioning vents, which made things a little annoying. But that smell must have dissipated within hours.

Traveling with my daughter and grandson reception was prompt with request for extra trundle bed. We loved our stay at this hotel , good location close to the Metro.Room fairly clean,short on bathroom supplies, Concierge very helpful.Excellent breakfast buffet but don't order coffee.

We loved our stays at this hotel. Recommend the club level which adds so much to your comfort. Enjoyed the club lounge with excellent breakfast buffet and generous Happy Hour included. Jerome and his staff are so welcoming and helpful! Our room on the 33d floor was very comfortable with a great view of the city. Take the Limo Bus from Narita (Y3000) wich makes its first stop at the ANA Intercontinental, so it could not be more convenient. Practically next door (coming out - go left) is the Ark Hills complex. Lot's of little places to eat and enjoy.

We are coming to the end of our annual holiday in Japan.This is the 4th time we have stayed at ANA and we have always felt so comfortable here.The Concierge team,headed by Shinobu Momoi,has again been so helpful to us,in particular,Yusuke San.A special word also for Jerome Palacoeur, and Junko san,who did not hesitate to act on an issue I had with the initial room provided to us.As for the location of the hotel,I feel it is perfectly located with easy access to all the main areas of the city.

I stayed there for three nights and I did not find any shortcomings. The staff were helpful, the room, the bathroom, everything in it were good and clean. Good location with Roppongi and Akasaka withing walking distance, plus it is easy to get to from the airport with the limousine bus. The price comes with all the perks.

Everything works smoothly and the service is excellent. The atmosphere in the Mixx bar on the 36th floor is perfect and the view at night is priceless. The breakfast is very good and the food in the restaurants is top class. I tried the fitness center and it was also up to standards.

Wow. Cavernous lobby, giant waterfall and the sounds of a piano tinkling softly in the background. I'm used to hearing that sort of thing come from a small speaker in the ceiling, I turn to see a man playing up on a mezzanine level.Everyone is wearing a suit. Everyone smells nice.We burst in, rowdy family of six, and check in. The staff are lovely, the rooms beautiful.My poor spine still unaccustomed to the firmness of the beds suffers somewhat.Great location, close to rail and there are some great spots to eat nearby.WAs a fanily we might try a Holiday Inn next time but if I am ever in the area to do some secret agenty stuff I'll stay here again and lounge mysteriously in the lobby.

Great hotel. Pricey though and seems every American thinks they "own" the place. (its close to the American embassy in Tokyo). Location is excellent - the Narita shuttle to/from the hotel is a godsend!

I stayed in this hotel for 5 nights whilst on holidays in Tokyo and I must admit my overall stay was quite enjoyable. There were some setbacks though. The good: The foyer and F&B offering are truly "Asian 5star" The house restaurant was great with outstanding breakfast (highly overpriced but hey this is Tokyo so I won't mention the cost of food anymore). One of my greatest memories in this hotel (and Japan) happened at MIXX bar lounge. As a solo traveller, I took my camera and book up to the top floor lounge at happy hour. I was so immersed in my book that a very polite and friendly Jarek (Bar Manager) came to me and say: With all due respect, put your book down and look out the window - the sun is setting over Mt. Fiji - the weather is always overcast so this is a very rare sight - enjoy it (and here's a complimentary drink). WOW. Not only was the view amazing but the service, seriously.... Apart from that, reception and concierge were always polite and appropriate. The hotel is located on an awfully business-focused area of the city, near all embassies and prime minister residence. Its adjacent to a metro station (you actually walk 1k or so to get to the platform though but thats ok).The Bad: I had a tiny tiny room. Ok I booked the cheapest but this was seriously small. 1-2 nights would have been ok but for 5 it became very claustrophobic. Looking at the evacuation map, I could see that this was the only " Harry Potter Cupboard"-like room in the floor. To paint a picture, all minibar items were in front of the television as there was no room for a proper minibar display. The bathroom was also quite dated (very dated) and in need of a refurb. The bench tops were made of cheap marble-lookalike plastic...I also found speaking English to the staff a little challenging at times but I am an opened traveller so thats ok - I imagine busy executives to be a little more short tempered. I was also there over the olympic games and not a single channel played the games so that was quite annoying.

This hotel may not have the luxury appeal of the newer Grand Hyatt or the much newer Peninsula, Mandarin Oriental or Ritz Carlton but for the price this is an excellent option. The location is good - easy to access by limo-bus from the airport and convenient for the subway to get around town. The immediate viscinity offers a few restaurants in Ark Hills but the greater selections of Roppongi and Akasaka are just 10 mins walk away. The lobby is cool and opulent, if a little retro and the hotel bars and restaurants are good, though pretty much uniformally high-end. Only the Cascade cafe is a bit of a disappointment - quite expensive and mediocre in its breakfast selection. The gym is small but brand new and reasonably equipped and the outdoor pool is a rare treat in Central Tokyo in the summer. The rooms are generously proportioned for a hotel in this location (larger than the equivalent, though more expensive, Grand Hyatt) and in good order if a little blandly furnished. Staff are extremely pleasant and very willing to help wherever they can...but this is Japan so should be taken as read. If anything the service here is a little pared down from that seen at very high end options, for example you will be finding your own way to your room, but that is ok.Overall I rate this hotel highly. I have visited Tokyo tens of times and this is where I choose to stay on business and for pleasure. It is well located and offers, in my opinion, a more pleasurable stay than either the Okura or the Imperial (which would be priced roughly in line) and is much cheaper than the luxury options of the Madarin, Grand or Park Hyatts or Peninsula.

I went here with my partner on a business trip so I cannot comment on price to value ratio. I can comment on the excellent customer service I received-the front desk and concierge spoke English and were incredibly helpful and friendly. I toured around the city by myself and it was really important to get good, clear info BEFORE I set out on my own (once I left, I could not communicate with anyone). So, I was very thankful for the staff. The hotel is in a good, central location; it is near a metro stop, although you do have to walk a bit underground. But using this metro stop, I was able to go everywhere in this huge city. There were many restaurants around the hotel that I could walk to and it was fairly close to Roppongi (just down the road but does take a while in a taxi). The rooms are small(typical in Japan) but very comfortable.

I have stayed at this hotel twice and both times have been worth the visit. The GM and the staff are very accommodating and you will love the lounge and the Champaign Bar. Great restaurants in the hotel and very convenient to all of the tourist sights. Please stay at this hotel when coming to Tokyo!

Last time I stayed here I reflected that despite the great hotel, and premium experience, and awesome day/night views of the tokyo tower, it was in an odd place. Anyway, all the positive things remained during this trip, but the streets around seemed to have more going on around, and it feels a little more connected. The metro is still a long walk from the hotel, and going for a night out might mean going toward the grotty/tacky Roppongi area it's got a lot going for it still, as all of Tokyo is actually well connected, so if you are willing to use public transport you'll have no problems, and a good night's sleep.
user_name:
William B
Milton Keynes, United Kingdom

review_body: We stayed in this hotel for three nights on a family trip (2 adults, 1 child) to Japan and paid some 1.000€ in total, including a breakfast buffet. The hotel is top, and there is really nothing to complain about. The staff is friendly, and we benefited in particular from the concierge desk where we always got useful information, for example they were able to rent bicycles for us at 10€ per day per person. Rooms are excellent - we got one with a view to Tokyo Tower! The breakfast buffet is a feast, so you don't need much food intake over the day. Last but not least, their shuttle to Narita Airport is the absolute best and easiest way to get there! We will come again ...

This hotel was in a fantastic location at the heart of Tokyo, particularly if you want an evening out. The rooms are a good size, and clean and tidy as you would expect. My one major gripe is that for an expensive hotel the charges for WiFi are horrendous - we were offered the equivalent of £20 for 2 hours of internet access in the lobby area, which is beyond ridiculous, as it turned out it was a nice excuse to ignore the emails for an evening!! The lobby and reception areas were very impressive, and the bar at the top floor was worth visiting as the views were fantastic and there was a 'happy hour' promotion between 5 and 8pm when we visited meaning the drinks were reasonably priced. Breakfast was also very good, and all in all a good stay but perhaps just lacking the wow factor for the price...

location is great as other fellow travellers have commented, i want to concentrate on reviewing the rooms. we stayed in the standard room as well as the upgraded room so can review both quite objectively. the standard room is dated, very 80s and in need of facelifts (reminds me of rooms in china from that era?). the decor is really dark and the bathroom is really old. don't get me wrong, it's still comfy, but i think it will benefit from renovation, especially since it's a 4 star hotel so i expected more. personally i don't think the rate i was charged for this room was justifiable for the quality. the upgraded room is more like a standard 4 star hotel, and with one of the those bathrooms that you can see into from the room (i know some people hate those bathrooms hence i am mentioning it here). it has the japanese style toilet, which the standard rooms don't have, and the room's a lot brighter. i would have expected the rate i was charged at for the standard room to be more like this. the breakfast was great. i managed to get a package deal so the breakfast comes free, but i have heard that the breakfast is quite expensive. Tip: if u go across to the next building (through a bridge on 3/4th floor) there are quite a few places to eat. haven't had anything there so i don't know the quality of the restaurants. however, i recommend that massage place in the complex, it's really good (u know it's good as asahi tv's office is on the other side of the complex). i got a special deal and it was 12000 yen for 2 hours, which i think was pretty decent.

Arrived at the hotel after a long trip from the UK via Amsterdam. We were taken to the priority club check in desk. We had two bookings as we had paid for a king room on the first night and used 100, 000 points to book the following two nights. The receptionist said we would have to change rooms after the first night as we had used points for the remainder of the booking and this meant a standard room not a king. I argued this was ridiculous as we were platinum members and would expect an upgrade on the room - as a standard perk so changing rooms was completely unreasonable especially at a rate of 50,000 points per night. I was told that they were doing me a favour checking me in at 1pm instead of 3pm when as a platinum member this would be standard practice. Resolution required me asking for a manager and then common sense prevailed allowing us to stay in the same room for all 3 nights whilst waving under my nose the priority clubs highlighted rules for standard rooms or reward bookings. Bottom line - this hotel gives no room upgrades, no club access and no recognition of your platinum status! Would not recommend for platinum members!Concierge were outstanding they were the best part of the stay.

First off – We are budget travelers and stayed one night at this high end hotel paid for with reward points. Beware all you budget minded travelers, the hotel and its services are expensive. Example: 100 yen per 5 minutes of internet access at the Business Center. We stay at ANA properties in Japan whenever possible. We love the hotels and consistent 5 Star staff and service. It is a beautiful hotel located in an ideal location. Subway is a few minutes away so getting around is extremely easy. From check-in to check-out the level of service from the staff was 5 stars. My wife is Japanese so she took care of everything. Our accommodation was a standard room (see attached pictures) located on the 24th floor with a view of the Tokyo Tower and Hotel Okura (Stayed there in 1983 as part of the Asst Sec of Defense party). The room in a high end hotel such as this is small by western standards but it was quit nice for Japan. We did not eat in the Hotel but rather hit the Convenience stores for breakfast and the local blue collar joints for lunch and dinner.Beautiful hotel, Superb Service and Staff!

Fabulous view for Tokyo skyline. Comfortable setting and romantic. Beware of crazy rules on happy hour. And the female wait staff with a huge attitude. Ordered a rum and coke which was a happy hour item. But was told since I requested diet coke vs regular coke it was full price! Really? Upon check out I requested a comment card. Front desk had no comment cards and handed me a piece of paper. Really?Will drink my rum and diet coke at the Hyatt next business trip.

It was a good decision choosing this hotel, strategically located at the heart of Tokyo, two subway lines and everywhere is just a taxi away (famous places and landmarks) not far so its inexpensive...diverse food and restaurants within the hotel complex, michelin grade resto as well..and the service wow! its customer delight... can communicate well in English, can arrange your itinerary, plan your vacation and rescue you in stressful situation while travelling...

This was a great place to base ourselves whilst visiting Tokyo - the sights and attractions of Tokyo are quite spread out but this hotel is located next to a subway station so we found it very easy to get around. Taxis in Tokyo are very expensive so the proximity to transport is a big plus. The hotel itself is beautiful, with comfortable rooms and good food. The service we received was excellent. I didn't like the pillows much but they seem to be an Intercontinental standard - they are extremely soft. The hotel offers a reasonably priced airport transfer service which was helpful for us too.

I stayed for two days at the ANA Hotel in Akasaka Tokyo some time ago. It was a very nice experience. The staff were most gracious as one would expect in Japan. I loved my single room. My room was on the 21st floor and the view was magnificent. I could see Tokyo Tower from my window and this was particularly pleasing on the eyes at night time. I even had a Japanese toilet that was like sitting on Captain Kirk's seat in Star Trek. There were so many buttons on it and you could heat the seat ,etc. A new experience for me. There are many bars and restaurants in this hotel and the decor is excellent throughout the hotel. The breakfast consisted of a buffet meal and there was a wide choice from Japanese to Western food. The hotel is well situated and accessable to all public transport. I really enjoyed my stay there and will return again.

This hotel is very expensive, the rooms are quite noisy from the expressway outside and the rumbling lifts that seem to be audible from most rooms. Worst of all, I was charged >5000 Yen for a 4-minute international phonecall, and when I emailed them to complain, I still have not had a satisfactory response almost 2 weeks later.

When I booked my trip for October 2012 in 2011, I didn't realize I would be in competition for rooms against the huge IMF meeting that was occurring in Tokyo. The hotel was packed with IMF delegates while I stayed there, but I never felt rushed or ignored by the staff. Coming from the US where you receive indifferent, surly service from hotel staff, the ANA Intercontinental staff was refreshing. As a western US resident, I hardly walk (essentially drive everywhere). Walking to and from the Tameike-Sanno subway station and sightseeing wiped me out. The bamboo "Japanese Traditional Foot Massager" in the room was a godsend to soothe the aching arches. In the US, mid/upper hotels usually will sell you things like duvets, sheets, mattresses, and anything in the hotel room if you like them. Since I fell in love with the bamboo foot massager, I asked the concierge if the hotel sold it. No, they do not. But the awesome concierge directed me to the nearest TokyuHands where I could purchase something similar. Rooms are spacious by Tokyo standards. Rooms are pricey, but in line with similar properties near central Tokyo. Breakfast buffet is made to order. Menu doesn't change very much from day to day, but it beats trying to find a place to eat when your feet ache (yes, there's a lot of cheaper alternatives, but you have to walk to them, and when your feet are killing you it's just nice to be an elevator ride away from a nice meal.)
user_name:
Hiroko K
Phoenix, Arizona, United States

review_body: Love staying at this hotel. As an Ambassador member they treat you special the whole time you're here.The hotel is very nice and the rooms are kept clean and up to date. The hotel is also very central to most major Tokyo businesses and government locations. (A few minutes on the Metro- at most).This hotel is my #1 and only choice when I come to Tokyo for business.
user_name:
U9698TSpeterm
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Am currently staying at this hotel for the first time. As a PC Platinum member, I was very disappointed with the service/recognition. I did not expect much as IC hotels have their separate exclusive paid recognition program. However at this hotel, despite informing earlier that I am a PC Platinum member and even giving my card during check-in, no recognition. I was not even provided with the room I requested. As all other reviewers mentioned, first time at a Japanese hotel and also at a IC hotel where internet is not provided in a complimentary basis. It is 1575 JPY for 24 hours. For all these incoveniences, only the normal Japanese apologies provided ( after being here so many times, I know when they are sincere and when it is just mentioned as part of the remembered text).Compared this to the IC Yokohama which I just left before arriving here, I was provided with the correct room type, provided at least 2 bottle of water complimentary and complimentary internet.The only pro of this hotel is the location (if you need to be around the Roppongi area), you can walk to Roppongi Hills in about 15 mins. The hotel is quite close to 2 different metro station. As expected staff members are in general polite and friendly. I will consider seriously the next time I return to this area on this property. Will most probably return to either the Hilton or the Courtyard (where I am treated very well). I think the hotel needs to work on setting itself apart in an already luxurious and high demanding segment especially in a country like Japan.

All over Japan we found great personal service, but In the ANA they excelled. I was on business and my wife was exploring on her own. Not only did the staff help her unravel the mysteries of the Tokyo metro/rail lines (still went wrong a few times but there was always a friendly person offering to help) but could tell her the best places to find the fabrics she needs for quilting. They knew the department stores with a whole floor dedicated to crafts and the street where she could find small shops selling off remnants cheaply - she stocked up.As expected for a 5 star hotel the rooms were spacious, comfortable and well equipped. Our complaint is the food - after a few days travelling I had promised my wife a 5 star breakfast - on par with our experiences in Singapore, Bangkok, Hong Kong etc. This was a let down - yes it has most of what you expect but it was all just disappointing at best OK. We have had so much better in other hotels and not just in 5 star hotels. This impression was reinforced in the steak restaurant - Aberdeen Angus that was almost tasteless as well as very expensive for a small piece. Had much tastier steak in the large mid market chains let alone in our favorite steak houses.

I stayed at the ANA Intercontinental last week as part of a large group of MBA students. The hotel was spacious, comfortable and we were well looked after. The breakfasts in the morning were fantastic, and the variety, superb. I guess the only gripe I have with the hotel is the cost of the wifi. At almost $20/day, it makes staying connected quite an expensive venture. Other than that, the stay was great and I would definitely recommend it for someone wanting to stay in Roppongi or in Tokyo.

Easy access to the Ginza line makes this hotel ideal for visiting Tokyo. I found the staff to be friendly, efficient and very helpful, from our check-in to booking nearby restaurants for us. We had a suite on the 34th floor so our view over the city was stunning. The room itself was spacious, clean and well appointed; bathroom was a good size. The club lounge is very smart and has a wide selection of (mainly Japanese) food; breakfast was excellent. The lounge bar was priced reasonably for Tokyo and is cigar-friendly. Highly recommended.

This review is for hotel manager Jerome's awful attitude. In the matter of fact, I just checked in today. Instead of going out for sight seeing. I am sitting in my hotel room and writing this review. You can tell how upset I am.We prepaid over $5000 dollars two months ago for our hotel rooms. Today I landed first and my husband's flight would land three hours later.when I checked in, Jerome asked me to give him my credit card as a guarantee. I told him that my husband and his friend would check in 3 hours later and he could take their credit cards. Two rooms were already prepaid for 5 night. I can't understand why he couldn't wait for 3 hours. No, he just insisted that I had to give him my credit card and he kept telling me that a lot of guests left hotel without paying their bills. Excuse me, our rooms were prepaid 2 months ago. I don't know what he thinks I will do in the next three hours. So I will forfeit $5000 dollars and leave.I traveled a lot and stayed in so many 5 star hotels around the world. Every time when I ask hotels to wait several hours and take my husband's credit card, they all have no problem with it except this one. When I told Jerome that I was very disappointed with his service and didn't think we would stay with this hotel again. He just simply told me that was fine with him.This hotel was not our first choice, not even the second or the 10th. We chose to stay here simply because all hotels we wanted to stay were fully booked with IMF meeting hold in Tokyo. Now you know why when all nice hotels were fully booked and this one still had rooms. By the way, I just find a cracked sink in the bathroom. And Sauna room in this hotel is just for gentleman. This is just my first day, I can't wait to leave. updates: I think I have to give some credits to the people who work at the top management office of this hotel. They read my tripadvisor review and responded to it very quick. Jerome apologized to me and put a bottle of wine in our room. We agreed to put this behind us. But I still disagree with the hotel policy.I trusted this hotel enough and let them take $5000 dollars out of our account two months before we even landed in this country. And they can't trust me for 3 hours. What kind of policy is this?

We stayed for four nights a few weeks ago. Location is a bit annoying, but close to a train station ( although you still have to work for 10 mins inside to get anywhere!)I would recommend only if you have a budget, otherwise im sure they are better hotels.

I had booked this as a part of my corporate plan. it seems to be reasonably priced. I was on the 15th floor, which i would say isnt very noisy as it faced the road in front of the Hotel, i would recommend requesting for a Higher floor for the light sleepers...i was very comfortable...the Room was quiet adequately spacious, no complaints there, the Bathroom was good.though i didnt use the mini bar, it was adequately stocked.would have loved to had Breakfast included in my room cost, i was offered 20% discount as corporate offer, but i chose to have my breakfast at the close by Starbucks.the hotel is well located at the Ark Hills, which has a lot of restaurants and walkable distance from Roppongi Hills, i walked it out to Roppongi for the Tokyo Viewagain as Corporate offer, had free wired Internet and WiFi.there's an ATM in the Hotel, but if you use AMEX, you can use the 7 BAnk ATM next to the StarbucksI opted for the Airport Limousine Bus to narita which cost Yen 3000 per person. Overall, like the hotel, will recommend it.

expensive hotel, it doesn't have free internet access. the free coffee and tea was great the whole thing of the ihotel was almost complete, we found that the ducts in the bathroom was a little dirty. The room felt pretty clean and didn't smell cigarrettes. it has access to 2 subway lines and thats good. the airport limo bus stops at the hotel and it is convenient if you have lots of luggage. The staff is very efficient and their english is very good so they may have a slight superiority complex and I may seem ignorant to them but I was happy. will go back my wallet permitting

We stayed at the Intercontinental Ana for 4 nights at the end of September/beginning of October. The room itself was spacious, based on what we have seen for travel in Asia, and our view from the 28th floor was spectacular, including a great view of Tokyo Tower. We may have missed some views by not being on the "city" side of the hotel but it was quiet and the view was still great. The subway is less than a two minute walk from the front of the hotel, we used it to get to most of the major sights while in Tokyo. You can buy one day passes from the concierge for 600 yen a piece which is worth it if you are going to do a lot of hopping on and off. Each of the concierges we dealt with was helpful and had great suggestions for things to see and do. There are also lots of restaurants in the Roppongi neighborhood, which is between a 10-20 minute walk away. Overall we had a very pleasant stay and would return to the hotel if we were ever in Tokyo again.

I stayed twice on separate nights at this hotel in September in transit to other destinations in Japan. The rooms were spacious, super clean, comfortable and very well appointed. The rooms were very quiet, and no intrusion whatsoever was noticeable from neighbouring rooms. The staff was extremely helpful. I was able to leave one of my bags in storage for 4 days whilst I travelled light to another destination in Japan before returning, free of charge. I used room service twice, which was delivered very swiftly, was delicious and reasonably priced. I paid the equivalent of £200 for the room, excluding extras such as room service, minibar and note that internet access is not free, which is disappointing for such a prominent business hotel. This would be my one criticism. I did not eat in the restaurant, as there are more convivial and cheaper alternatives in the eatery couryard at the back of the hotel.There is a shuttle service which is bookable to Narita and Haneda airports, it is advisable to book this service when you check in, to avoid last minute hick ups with lack of space. Note that Narita is at least a 90 minute ride from the hotel, and can take up to 2 hours in heavy traffic, the cost each way is 3000 yens. For Haneda, I recommend a taxi to or from the Monorail terminal (about 1000 yens) and 15 minutes away, which itself will take you straight into Haneda at a fraction of the price and in about 20 minutes.I would recommend this hotel for business travellers.

Its central location in Minato-ku, within an easy walk to Roppongi, the Diet, U.S. Embassy etc is very convenient. I formerly lived in Tokyo, and whenever we had visitors we would put them up at the ANA. I went back for the first time in seven years (and stayed in the hotel for four days) and found that the hotel, while still pretty nice, is not in the same league of service that it once was. It was perfectly fine, but perhaps not on the same level as say the Okura.

Have stayed in this hotel for every one of my 7 business trip to Tokyo. It has been excellent with good locations and condition of the room. On this recent visit, I start to feel the hotel room is a bit dated. Maybe because they put me in a smoking room as the non smoking floor is fully booked. Also as the service attitude throughout Japan is excellent, a slightly less warm receptionist does stand out. I do feel there are better value options. However as a corporate hotel, it is hard to fault the location, right next to the Akasaka business district and walking distance to all the government buildings and palace.

We where slightly concerned after reading several negative reviews, but from the minute we arrived to the minute we left we could not fault this lovely hotel at all.Yes, it was very busy, but everything was done in a calm relaxed manner.The staff where very attentive, well mannered and extremely knowledgable.Our room was lovely with stunning views.We ate in the Steak Resturant one evening, the food, service, atmosphere all added up to be a most enjoyable evening. An extra bonus, two people could dine and you only paid for one.Although I would advise everyone to check their bill as they simply 'forgot the offer' until we pointed out to them they had charged us for two!!Agree with everyone else regarding the exorbitant charge to use the pool area, it just should not happen and needs to be addressed, especially as the changing area for both men and women was absolutely disgraceful and really lets the place down.There are a few very good shops in the hotel, it is worth continuing into the open courtyard area where there are numerous shops and resturants all realistically priced.All in all an enjoyable finish to our tour of China and Japan.

Visited again this past week. Things are still just on par. Glad to see the art work of regional southeast Asian artists back. Still not pleased with the french inspired Pierre Gagnaire restaurant and pastry shop. I got the mid sized room and it is a a very fair price. The location of the ANA is perfect for my visit situation near our offices and advisors. But, I would switch to staying at a Marriott if they only had a property nearby.

Normally I stay on the business floors and have access to the level 35 lounge. New management in the last 6 months has resulted in a vast improvement particularly in the lounge breakfast. I stay there about once every six weeks for the last five ears. Rooms are good as are bathrooms albeit a little small but on par with the other hotels in Tokyo. Good location .

Everything about this hotel is good. The are other better hotels in Tokyo, but the Ana is great for coming to do business. The rooms are good, the breakfast great, the Internet fast, and e hotel is well located in the right part of Tokyo to do business.

The ANA is a great stay in downtown Tokyo. The rooms are spacious and well set up for a western traveller. I've stayed there many times in many different rooms and I've always been impressed with the attention to detail and the quality of the staff. The rooms are surprisingly quiet despite being in the heart of Akasaka. There are plenty of restaurants within a short walk ( beware that many of them are cash only) so you don't have to eat at the good but fairly expensive hotel establishments. Breakfast at the hotel is very good, although a bit pricey, having a fine selection of different offerings from fresh fruit and vegetables to Chinese and Japanese staples. There is also a nice bakery on the lobby that I sometimes use for a quick and cheap breakfast or morning snack.

I had a 'corporate guest' package, which entitled me to using the pool and wireless internet without additional cost and gave me free late check-out until 3pm. This really made a difference.The good:Rooms are very spacious (by Tokyo standard), as well as spotlessly clean and come with high quality amenities. There is a free shoe-shine service (which I did not use) and an ironing board and iron available in every room.The gym is well equipped and the pool is large enough to do some laps. Staff is very well trained and extremely friendly.The bad:Minibar is a bit expensive, breakfast is not included (even in the corporate package).The ugly:3,000 YEN for using the pool is absolutely ridiculous. The pool came free of charge in my package, but charging hotel guests for the use of the pool is just so very wrong. This is a typical case of bad profits. If the pool was free for hotel guests more people would use it and also consume drinks/food from the bar - making the hotel more money than the cover charge and adding value to the guests' stay at the same time.

The ANA InterContinental is a great hotel for business travelers in Tokyo as it is situated relatively central in Tokyo and is not far from Roppongi nightlife and upmarket Ginza shopping. The rooms are comfortable and clean, staff is friendly and helpful, and the hotel features several restaurant and bar options.

Really perfect for my business trip. ideally located for all my business meetings. A bit expensive. the rooms were well equipped and i thought excellent for the wifi. Must improve the connection with the Airport with more frequent buses and faster.

No huge faults - Staff very helpful - Business centre great - Restaurants were outrageously priced - Nice Foyer - Good size Suite - Very impressive amenities.Cheap furniture - Slow lifts - Tiny fridge - Slow internet.The best part was the club and the amenities... I wouldn't even bother with a standard room I upgraded on arrival as it was tiny.

The service at this hotel was amazing. It truly earns its 5 star rating. The people at the concierge desk went out of their way to ensure that my daughter and I enjoyed this beautiful city. They recommended attractions and gave us detailed directions/maps on how to ride the subway and train system to each place. The rooms were clean and beautiful with excellent room service. The hotel is pricey but you get what you pay for and this hotel earns its fee.

We stayed here for the first part of our trip in Tokyo. It is worth travlling to this hotel by the airport limo service whoch is located at the airport desks upon coming out of arrival. This is a bus service which takes around 1.5 hours to get to the airport from Narita and costing around (3000 Yen= £25). I did notice that taxis are super expensive in Tokyo, unlike many other asian cities so it is best to take buses and undergroend to get around Tokyo. The hotel itself was chosen as we wanted to be near Roppongi area for the weekend. The loaction was bit further out than we expected, requiring at least 10min taxi ride, which equates to £15-20 taxi ride. However during the day time, there are 2 cose underground stations nearby. The hotel lobby is very impressive and the room is of a large size, espically by Tokyo standrads as I was about to fond out later. We went to Kyoto after a few nights stay here and our 2nd Tokyo was much smaller. The hotel room decor was nice apart from the toilet which was very average with a bath and a shower, albeit with a powerful shower. The bed was large and very comfortable. The rooms was very clean, much like most of Japan I suspect.The major negative I didnt like was the wifi charge which for 2 nights was 3000 Yen, which I thought was quite steep, espically considering many other similar hotels wouldnt charge for this. Would I stay again?? Probably not.. not beacuse of the service or the room but mainly because of the need to get taxi after a night out in the clubbing area of roppongi hill.

This was a nice hotel for the money, and offered good value. We stayed at the Park Hyatt on the first leg of our trip. However, nothing compares to that hotel. This property is half the price and we found it to be a good value. We had a nice king room with a modest view of the city. The service was good and the amenities were quite sufficient. The food and beverage were priced on the high side, comparable to the Park Hyatt.

This is a great hotel for business travel. Rooms and beds are very comfortable providing much needed rest after a long journey. Breakfast buffet is fantastic although pricey...traditional Japanese fare is available as well. You are able to catch the bus to Narita on the lower level...very convenient. Decent walk to Roppongi area. Some good restaurants nearby as well as Starbucks. Will stay here again!

I am a Gold Ambassador member and as such I am eligible for a few perks including a free room upgrade. The Intercontinental Tokyo did not disappoint me. My family and I were upgraded to an executive floor suite with access to the club. In my opinion this is one of the finest club lounges of all their hotels which over the years I have visited. The morning breakfast buffet was very nice and my children especially enjoyed the afternoon service which included the best French macaroons we've tasted to date. If you stay at this hotel I strongly recommend twisting your way to the club lounge.This hotel also boasts a 3 star Michelin restaurant which we enjoyed very much. There is also an amazing Japanese style Teppanyaki restaurant although the children got a bit upset to see the life lobster dance on the grill.

We stayed at this hotel when my husband was attending a conference. The weather was amazingly humid although the temperature only read 95 degrees F. Every short trip out of the hotel left us drenched in sweat. We began to enjoy the local customs: paper fans and small hand towels to wipe our faces and necks.Hotel: beautiful and clean hotel well situated for seeing the main sites of Tokyo. The check in was easy although slow and inaccurate. We were checked into a room with a full sized bed - my husband's 6'3" frame hung off the end of the bed. We we called to report this they arrived with "bed extenders" to attach to the end of the bed. The man attaching these devices realized we were booked into the wrong room - we were supposed to be in an Excutive King Suite. After and hour or so we were moved to the new room (a long wait with jet lag after a flight from Denver). The new room was the size of a traditional US hotel room with a sparkling clean bathroom (the housekeeping service was perfection!). Watch out for the slippery tub - nearly fell many times!Workout area: always clean and cool with the best water in the hotel (we fill our water bottles every day at the cooler to take with us into the humid city). Hotel Restaurants: with just a week in Japan we were careful not to get stomach issues. We didn't understand the local foods or language well so we decided to try the local favorite foods in the safety of the hotel. Yes, like other reviewers said, the restaurants were very expensive but we didn't mind paying for the safety those restaurants provided. Also, the food was incredibly delicious. We tried Sushi for the first time at Sushi Kenzan. It was a very intimate setting (at the bar with one chef serving us - he was a wonderful, knowledgable dining "companion"). The conference my husband attended provided sushi but none was as fresh and delicious as the Sushi Kenzen. The chef said they also have a restaurant in NY city (worth looking for!). Also, we ate traditional noodle bowls at Karin which is supposed to be a chinese restaurant. Again a wonderfully delicious meal in a beautiful atmosphere. Finally, we skipped the buffet because it just looked like way too much food. Instead we ordered curry off the menu at the Cascade Cafe. At the take out bakery, Pains et Gateaux, we had the freshest croissants and pastries we have ever had (including those we ate in Paris)! Watch out - these pastries are addicting! Finally, we had a business reception and dinner at the top of the hotel at Teppenyaki Akasaka. The food was fabulous: small traditional japanese dishes of sushi, tapas and desserts. Beautiful view and they provide menus with a map of the surrounding buiildings.Breakfast: we saved money by going to the Natural Food Grocery store (a short walk toward Roppongi). We bought yogurt, granola and milk for our coffee to store in our big refrigerator in our room. Also, I brought from the US, Starbucks instant coffee packets so I could make the morning coffee in our room (the room is stocked with coffee cups, spoons, sugar, large refrigerator and teapot).Concierge: wow - not enough adjectives to describe their incredible service! We arrived in Japan a few days earlier than the conference to enjoy our 20th wedding anniversary. The concierge made reservations for us at restaurants that ususally require a reservation months in advance. They were always ready with a full description of transportation services, ideas for fun, and advise - using their IPADs to show us pictures of their descriptions. NIce, nice people who are willing to please!Swimming Pool - too expensive for our tastes so we didn't use it.Transportation: the "Airport Limosine" was the best way to arrive - they are located at the airport with an efficient queue and accurate arrival and departure schedules. We walked up to the desk near the baggage claim, bought our tickets and waited in a specific line for about 15 minutes for our 1 hour ride to the hotel (this is a Greyhound style bus but very clean and comfortable). On our return to the US we made a reservation through the concierge and the bus arrived at the hotel and took us straight to the airport. The subway has multiple stops around the hotel. WARNING: I, a woman, was in the middle of "people pushing" in the subway - a horrible, inhumane experience! Athough the subway car was full, they pushed an additional 25 people into the crowded car. There was a large collective groan and a wave of men came toward me. I turned and braced myself - holding my arms out to brace against the wall. As the train moved and I had men completely jammed against my back and sides, I noticed a man next to me with his face and chest crushed into the wall (he was moaning slightly and the skin on his face was drawn tight against the wall). When the door opened he was thrust out in front of the crowd (all this humiliation and stress while he was just trying to go to work!). Hint: while on the subway keep yourself in a location where you can physically carve out a space for yourself - bracing against a wall worked well for me. All this happened around noon, not even rush hour! Next time I'll look harder for the all women's car. Overall, a wonderful trip and much of this was due to the beautiful ANA Intercontinental Hotel!

It is mid summer and one of the attractions of this hotel is the swimming pool. I then get told that there is a 3,000 Yen (more than $30) charge per person for the pool and so I need to pay around $100 per day for my wife and I and 7 year old to use the pool. Family were also visiting and we was told they would also need to pay $60 per person per day just to sit in the pool area. How dare you Intercontinental Hotel Group. If you want to charge like that then you better put a clear warning on all your booking websites. I am a company executive and I intend to ensure that no-one from my company stays here until the policy is changed. Room was nice but lobby is noisy and busy. No kids channel on TV. For families try Westin Hotel in Ebisu (unless you really need a pool and are prepared to pay).

I stayed at this hotel in 2011 and after some trouble figuring out its location on the subway map and access, I was pleasantly surprised with the level and professionalism of service provided to me by its staff. The room was excellent and comfortable, with plenty of amenities provided. Given that rooms are provided at a reasonable price, I would recommend that this hotel is worth travelling to, to enjoy the comfort and luxury it offers.

I've stayed at quite a few InterContinentals and this is the first one I've been disappointed by. The room rate was something like 32,000 Yen per night (USD 400+), and for this we received a small, cramped room which was a apparently an upgrade (by virtue of our InterContinental Ambassador status) - I don't know what a standard room would have been like! However this is Tokyo, so we accepted that high prices and small space were the norm. The furnishing / decor was still IC standard and pleasant, although the bathroom was not really comfortable (stand in bathtub shower, very tight on space).However over our short two night stay other things started to weigh down the experience. I went down to use the pool, and was told there was a 3,000 yen (USD 38) charge for hotel guests to use the pool! What!?! That's pretty steep for 15 minutes in the pool, on top of an already sky-high room rate. There was no turn down service, which seemed odd in 5* hotel and was standard in every other IC I've stayed in. We had a drink in the top floor bar, which was very nicely appointed and with great views. But despite paying 1,000 - 2,000 yen per cocktail, we were told we couldn't eat some of the Japanese snacks we'd pick up while strolling around during the day.Overall I just didn't like the place, and felt it was not good value for money. I wouldn't pay to stay here again.
Loved the room and the amenities! However, the walk to the metro station is a long one. Staff very good.

This is a great hotel and the club floor is a real treat. Fabulous city views from the 35th floor, breakfast, snacks and evening drinks and canapes. The service at the hotel is excellent and the room very well appointed and comfortableLoved every minute of it.

A large hotel serving international customers. An hour's ride in the airport bus takes you direct to the hotel lobby. Check-in is efficient as you'd expect and the rooms all to a good standard. Not the cheapest hotel in Rippongi but it tries hard to keep up standards.The hotel restaurant serves a great wine tasting option which is a good way to spend an hour or more working your way through an unlimited amount of French, German and Japanese wines in an evening, especially if you ate a large lunch !Located across the road from a large number of local restaurants and even some western ones there are lots of options other than eating in.

So far this has been the best hotel I've stayed at in the area. Great location to the embassies and subway. Starbucks next store, lots of great restaurants within a 10 min walk. Lobby is beautiful. Check-in was professional. Great service at concierge and the bellmen were prompt. The airport limo (bus) stops here for both airports and the price and times are great. Room is a little out-dated, but bed is very comfortable. Hotel and rooms do not smell like smoke (rare in Japan). Bathroom is simple and plain and could use updating, but it's very clean. Best thing: the cost is usually 1/2 the price of the Hyatt. Yah, they shouldn't charge extra for the pool, internet or extended check-out, but that's pretty typical for most of the big chain hotels here. I'd stay here again without hesitation.

i really hope that someone from the intercon group is reading this review. I have stayed at a lot of hotels around the world and rarely been so upset at the pricing policy of a hotel. Both the Ritz and Grand Hyatt in Ropongi are not that much more expensive but trying to charge Y3000 for use of the pool for in house guests is ridiculous. If it costs you that much to have a pool that you need to charge don't have one. If you do then put in bold letters on your website that you have this insane charge so that noone ever stays at this hotel.Secondly the rooms, 80s horrible decor with bathrooms that are an acrylic mess. ok positives....breath....positives are...location pretty good and the beds are nice and big i guess and thats pretty much. basically dont stay at this hotel ever.

I chose this hotel because the thought of a few laps outdoors would be great after a full day of office meetings. However, they charge ¥3000 per person per visit (that's the discount rate for hotel guests). I stayed at a regular queen room and moved to a king club after 2 days. The size and layout of the room is practically the same, and so is the view. So if you do not need the club lounge for work, don't book a club room and save yourself ¥6000 per night.

ANA hotel is one of the most convenient locations and rooms and restaurants are all great. Surprisingly or Not surprisingly for Japan, its too formal. Reception staff are extremely friendly but I wanted a couple of hours extension to check out after a weeks stay and they tried to charge me 200 usd!!. The last bus to airport leaves at 430pm and my flight was at 10pm. Was not much helpful. If you have been to Japan you know a taxi ride to the airport costs 300 usd. Train is from Tokyo station and not very convenient if you have to carry luggages. in the end took a taxi to the TCAT terminal (costs 40 usd) and took the bus, another 40 usd.. Japan is still not easy in terms of airport and access. ANA needs to get a bit of a warm touch and flexibility to its great service. I would probably not stay in ANA because the internet costs 20 usd a day. its not a big amount but don't think anyone should be charging for internet anymore.

The perfect location for the businessman and tourist alike. A short cab ride from the palace and Tokyo Cental Station whilst at the same time within walking distance of the great nightlife of Roppongi.

I used to live in Tokyo, very close to the ANA Intercon but I had never stayed there until this trip to Tokyo. I had eaten at several of the restaurants previously and attended meetings and functions but had never stayed. I would stay again as the location is ideal and the room rate is very good.I particularly like the location for business and pleasure as it's very near Roppongi and Akasaka. Also, the Narita Friendly Limousine Bus stops right below the main Reception.One complaint; the in-room safe is too small for a laptop.

Once again we chose the IC ANA Tokyo and as usual we had a wonderful time. On arrival surprisingly we were not checked in at the lounge but rather at the main desks in the lobby. The staff at this property makes every effort to ensure that all your needs are well taken care of. So I would like to thank the following, Junko the Club Lounge Manager and Yuko the Assistant Chief, Yuji and Sonoko. The club lounge is going through some changes, there is no more champagne, which is a shame as it was really nice to be able to sip on bubbly as an option while admiring the views from the lounge. I think management should rethink about bringing back the champagne. Initially we were given a nice Club King room but the washroom was very small with one sink for 2 people. The hotel staff kindly gave us a suite with a larger washroom and more room for 2 people. I was also informed that there will be no more Club Access for Royal Ambassadors which is a shame really as that is one of the draws for us to this property as well as the staff. Overall a very good property but if you like the night life in Shinjuku then I would recommend a hotel in that area.

Very impressive hotel, excellent location very close to the railway station clean large public areas. But the room is very old smoking room smelled unbearable like the room was continues to smoke alone. For a high price so I would recommend to renovate the rooms.

When I arrived my room wasn't ready (I arrived at 8am and check in isn't until 2pm). Staff were most apologetic and took me to the health club so I could shower after my flight and get changed for my meetings. Throughout my stay the staff were extremely courteous.The room was large and had good views of the surrounding area. Very comfortable hotel and perfect location for business.I didn't eat in the hotel but seemed to have a large range of restaurants.

As mentioned by other reviewers the location of this hotel for business is excellent. Getting there is easy, walk through customs and into exit area at Narita and buy a 3000 yen ticket on Limousine Bus, they take your luggage and almost immediately outside the gate is the bus terminal running every @ 30 mins. It takes about 1 hour 10 minutes and first stop drops you in the ground floor of hotel. Up an escalator and you are in reception. Equally easy getting back......However be warned the early morning buses get booked up, so suggest you book a few days ahead if you want to be sure.Everything here is expensive, but this is Tokyo, but everything worked as one would expect, you are not delayed queuing up to check in or out as you very often are in Europe and USA where the hotel has decided the balance of customers/staff should be in their favour. Service and food is good, the only complaint I had was in the top bar where we went to celebrate a successful day was wanting 1000 yen just to walk in, which I felt was a bit stiff especially considering the price of drinks and that it was at best 20% full. Would I come back here.......for business yes, because it works, for pleasure, I think I would try to find somewhere with a little less clinical.

I've been staying here since 2008 and am not pleased with the recent changes at the hotel. They appear to be trying to cater to the european visitor, and have lost some of the charm that make the ANA my favorite. The Manhattan bar has turned into more of a hollywood night club than a great place to have a cocktail and enjoy the view of the city before heading off to dinner. The cafe used to be a great spot for a good breakfast option (besides the expensive buffet). Now, it is a hassle to get a cup of coffee and the pastries are not good. I much prefered the previous cafe. Oh, and the artwork in the hotel used to be of regional asia artists, but now is more modern and doesn't give the ambience that you are in Asia. I appreciate the management trying to stay trendy, but I think they've gone too far in transforming this former gem of Asia into your standard westernized hotel.

It is definitely one of the best hotels in Tokyo - good location (1minute walk from the subway station); Airport Limousine bus service; amaising bird-eye view; spacious rooms; very good breakfast; nice ara around; friendly and helpful staff; good for conferences and leisure.

Service etc are flawless. The hotel is clean, tidy and offer a wide range of eating alternatives (up to 3 star Michelin restaurant. The design, interior, ambience etc are too stiff for my taste. Its a classic high class business hotel, nothing I would use for a romantic week-end.

The ANA was very easy to get to...the Airport Limousine bus drops you at the front door. The lobby was beautifully decorated with a wall/waterfall feature and pleasing tones. The room was spacious for Tokyo standards, and I had a really great view of the stacked freeways nearby. There was a bit of a musty smell in one of the closets, but everything else was nice and clean, and the box of amenities they leave for you was almost overflowing. My only complaint really, was about the area, as it was mostly shut down on the day I was there, Sunday. If I had to do it over again, I would have stayed there during the work week so that shops and restaurants nearby would have been open. One sparkling gem nearby though: the Tsukijiko Sushi restaurant. The fish comes fresh every day from Tsukiji, and the service was impeccable. My palate was very pleased!!

I have stayed here four times now and it's one of the better hotel experiences I have. I travel extensively in Japan, South Korea and Latin America, and the combination of accomodations, service, restaurant/lounge choices (both in the hotel and nearby) and proximity to shopping (Roppongi area) are great. The staff is always very courteous and professional, and the lobby is a visually stunning. The rooms are somewhat small, but comfortable, and are laid out in a convenient manner. It is also the first stop for the Airport Limousine Bus, which is a great feature after many hours in the air.

Firstly, taking the Narita Airport Limousine Bus Akasaka route you're the first stop, which is nice after an 11 hour flight from SFO. The hotel is spacious and well kept with the formal feel of an upscale property. I feel underdressed if I wear a t-shirt down to breakfast because the staff is in suits and most of the guests are in various degrees of business attire. A very polite and friendly reception staff, multiple in-house restaurants and nearby eateries, very well-appointed rooms, a bar with live music and a nice view, easy access to the subway, a pretty decent hotel gym... There are a lot of pluses for the hotel.Drawbacks are few... Price would probably be one of them but I feel like everything is expensive in Tokyo anyway. The hotel offers smoking and non-smoking rooms and smoking is allowed in the lobby area, so watch out for that if you're sensitive to cigarette smoke. Again, that's more a Tokyo issue than limited to the hotel. Mixx Bar on the 36th floor of the hotel offers drink specials in the late afternoon to early evening which is nice.

Stayed there for 11 days recently at this hotel. Really conveniently located.The Airport Limousine Bus Service drops you right at the doorstep.Check in was relatively smooth and was allocated a rather small room. Service was decent and breakfast at the Cascade Cafe had a decent spread. The only snag was that it was the same spread everyday. A decent alternative is the bakery on the ground floor. All baked goods are 50% off after 7 pm.Roppongi is a short 20 mins walk away, There is a train station right next to the hotel. The thing is is you have to walk like forever after you get off the train to get to the exit where the hotel is located.Great alternatives are available for food if you do not wish to eat at the hotel. The challenge with this is that a lot of the Japanese resturants do not have a English menu, but, thank goodness for pictures.For those not partial to Japanese Food, Ark Hills is just next to the hotel and you can find a few establishments serving western food there.Oh yes, a couple of gripes on my part.Although WiFi is free, you have to renew it everyday. I do not understand why they cannot just provide WiFi for the entire period of my stay.The other thing that got up my goat was the firmness, or the lack of, of the mattress. For someone who likes a firm mattress, sleeping on the one in my room was like sleeping on sponge.Those gripes aside, overall, a decent business hotel.

The club lounge is impressive in this hotel, which itself has a rather sensual, luxurious atmosphere. Located on the 35th floor (top floor 36 offers a selection of high-end restaurants/bars), this is by far the largest club lounge in Tokyo and spacious by any standard. Canapes and alcoholic beverages in the evening are of good quality though champagne is notably not offered. Breakfast features an "egg menu" though I was told a cheese omelette was not possible -- no problem, the wide selection of breakfast cheeses allowed me to place the cheeses of my choice directly into a freshly-made omelette which was hot enough to melt the cheese to a delicious texture.The lounge is quiet with attentive, efficient service, and the subdued noise level is partly due to the average customer age of 40-plus with a surprising number of even older couples on weekends. No problem if you're alone like a third of the crowd -- the lounge tends to be busy and you won't stand out.I can't comment on the club floor rooms as the hotel gave me an upgrade to a Japanese-type tatami mat suite with 2 low-rise Western style beds. It looked like a zen temple. The original upgrade was to a executive suite but these were fully booked during my stay and the hotel apologized for the "downgrade." To be honest, I liked the peaceful feel of the Japanese suite as it was not cluttered by furniture while subtle tones and motiffs provided a relaxed decor. Wifi is complimentary with all club floor rooms and in the lounge. If a club lounge is important to you, this along with the Prince Park Tower are amongst the best Tokyo has to offer.

The hotel is very close to the subway so it's very easy to get around. We took the subway and went to shibuya to check out the nightlife. It's close to the subway and also minimum cab fare to the nearest eateries. Also Tokyo tower is just a 10 min cab ride away

I was in Tokyo for work and this Hotel had everything I needed. Spotlessly clean room, bed was comfortable though slightly firmer that I like, WiFi with work area. Rooms were quiet. There is a shopping mall next to the Hotel with restaurants so if you want some additional (and lower priced options) they are conveniently located. The fitness center has a good selection of cardio equipment and weight / strength training. Close to the subway and serviced by the Airport limousine bus which offers a more reasonable alternative to taking a taxi to/from the airport  http://www.limousinebus.co.jp/en/  TV seemed to have the basic selection of English speaking channels (CNN, BBC, etc.)

Free wireless, easy access on the airport limo bus - 3000 yen, very clean rooms, comfortable beds, extensive breakfast and also close to Starbucks, and convenience stores. Can walk to imperial palace - about 1 mile away. Staff is very nice. Excellent english everywhere in hotel. Not far from train station - cab fare 1610 yen.

First-time staying at this hotel. Was assigned a corner room, one of the "larger" rooom, compared to the rest of the rooms on the floor. 80's decor room style, with view of the high-way . What was dissapointing was lack of proper shower stall. Instead, had to made do standing in a small bath-tub with sticky curtains.The shocker was the hair found on the telephone. Wonder how did house-keeping missed this in a country so focused on cleanliness.Othewise, very efficient check-in/check-out. Will I return, not decided until I check out the Hilton nearby.

We went to Tokyo for a 5 days leisure family trip with two kids and had a fantastic stay at ANA InterContinental.Access from the airport could not be more convenient, the hotel is on the route of the airport shuttle bus. Location is very central and the surrounding areas offer countless dining options. I would like to add a special mention for concierge. Concierge gave us a lot of insider tips for restaurants and places to see. Thanks to their referrals we discovered a number of hidden gems, we had a wonderful dinner in a Yakitori restaurant located in a lane a few blocks away from the hotel. Not only referring places, they also helped us to book tables, tickets to see Sumos (which we would probably would not have seen if they had not advised us).Outstanding!
A little sterile, service with a smile...but sometimes what was an offer didn't live up to expectations. The decor was a little gloomy

I stayed there twice in April 2012.Club rooms, with access to the Club Floor. Note there are different sized rooms. You pays your money . . . . The hotel is in very good condition given its relative (for Tokyo) age. Our second stay in a larger room was excellent, esp. the contemporary bathroom. The Club breakfast was good to very good. The afternoon tea was so so. The evening drinks were excellent. Good position in Akasaka. Also, very convenient as its on the Airport Limousine Bus route.
Good value, excellent location near business locations and restaurants.

Great Hotel in the heart of Akasaka, Minato-ku. Good for a business trip, but there isn’t much to see if you are a tourist. You can take a longer walk to the Tokyo Tower or seek out some small Shinto temples around. Fantastic staff and delicious breakfast buffet. The breakfast and the internet are typically included in your rate. Great gym and spa. I wish it had a steam room (just sauna). Good value at $300/night in Tokyo. There is a great sushi/sashimi restaurant within the building complex called Tsukijisushiko (you will get a great lunch for $40). Would not recommend the French Bistro also located within the complex. As they say, “when in Rome…”

My husband and I stayed here for 2 nights in April 2012. We arrived at Narita and took the limo bus directly to the hotel - so convenient! Check in was smooth, and although a Priority Club Platinum member, was not offered an upgrade - nor did I ask. :) Our room on the 16th floor was very clean, although it does need a bit of updating, especially the bathroom. Loved the duvet and the pillows on the bed! The concierge made a dinner recommendation to Ten and it was great. I must say the concierge were always very helpful, assisting with shopping and subway information, as well as suggesting some touristy things to do. English was not a problem at this hotel - if someone did not speak very well, they would get another person who did. The restaurants at this hotel seemed to be more for the business traveler as the prices were on the higher side. This hotel is very close to great dining and nightlife - we found a great karaoke bar - and it is all within walking distance. The Ginza subway line was steps from the hotel and was very easy to navigate. I would highly recommend this hotel for anyone who is looking for a hotel that has location, location, location!!

I visited the hotel as part of a business trip to Tokyo - my double room was very reasonably priced at 19,500 yen (thisis very good for Tokyo) Rooms are a good size with free wired internet but wireless is an additional cost. Once upon a time but nowadays with smartphones and tablets it probably should be the other way round. Breakfast is amazing and I suggest filling up there to get you through the whole day - lots of choices in both Japanese and western cuisine. I never ate there in the evenings as it was a little bland, but the metro line to Gionze is a two minute walk outside the hotel or you can turn left out of the hotel and walk to Ropingi in 10 minutes. Both are full of bars and restaurants offering lots of life and colour and at a much more reasonable price than the hotel.Staff at the hotel are very helpful and whilst expensive at 10,000 yen the whole day trips are probably the best way to see some of the traditional city (and some of teh shopping areas) if time is tight. Time was very tight for me on the last day, this was made worse by the fact that the last shuttle bus to Narita is at 4.30pm - thats way too early if you have a night flight when a taxi is 250 dollars. If you miss the shuttle your best bet is a taxi to Tokyo station then the train out to Narita.The location is very central, about a 15 minute walk to the imperial palace - so if you are in Tokyo and not on too tight a budget its ideal - enjoy

This was my first visit to Tokyo and Japan, and I'm very glad to have chosen this hotel for my stay. It's very conviniently located for exploring Tokyo, as there are several metro lines passing close to the hotel, most notably Ginza line (although some might require a bit of walking to get to) and one could even easily walk to Imperial park, Hibiya and Marunouchi/Ginza area. As Ambassador I was upgraded to a Junior Suite, which might not be the largest one of its kind, but very comfortable, beautifully styled, with almost all imaginable amenities and had some amazing views of Tokyo. Overall service was impecable, extremely friendly and always around when needed. Fantastic service - japanese style. It certainly is one of the better Intercontinental properties.Only drawback I could name, is that it's really a large hotel, and that the vast lobby might be overcrowded and a bit unwelcoming during rush hours.In any case, I would certainly recommend this hotel to anyone visiting Tokyo, and would come back myself.

I've stayed at this hotel quite a few times and they treat their Ambassador members well. I had a Junior suite this time around (smaller than the corner suite I've had before) but was sufficient for the short stay I had. Hotel staff the lounge can talk english well and are always very helpful. Club lounge has a decent selection of food during evening hours as well as for breakfast. The hotel has a direct limo bus from its doorstep to Narita and Haneda airports and it makes the travel a lot more easier..

Just finishing a three day trip to Tokyo, and my second stay at the ANA Intercontinental. The rooms are efficient, clean and well equipped. The bedding (my top criteria for happiness) is fantastic. The staff are helpful, the gym adequate, the location just steps from the Akasaka station. Very handy. You are also walking distance from literally 100s of restaurants. The hotel is not for someone traveling on a budget, and the restaurants in the hotel pricey. All in all, for business traveller, a good choice.

The ANA InterContinental is a jewel in Tokyo. One of the finest hotels my wife and I have ever stayed in. The service was fantastic from check-in to check-out, the rooms are exceptionally clean and the food was amazing. The staff was extremely friendly and helpful. You did not have to lift a finger. We stayed for 5 days on business and pleasure. We are still talking about our experience at the ANA to our friends. We can not wait to come back. If you are looking to be treated like VIP, look no further, stay at the ANA InterCon. It’s everything you’d expect and more. We loved it, wow!

Rooms: A good size without being overly generous. Decor is warm and inviting, understated, with an executive feel. Bathroom was well appointed with a good bath/shower. Large mirrors everywhere help add a sense of space. The views from upper floors are unbeatable, whichever way you are facing. My bed was very comfortable, firm, warm. Everything from the tea set to the mini-bar was tasteful and high quality.Service is typical for an expensive hotel in Japan. Very professional and courteous.The hugely expensive restaurants have been mentioned by other reviewers. Thankfully there is a wealth of dining choice in the neighbourhood, a short stroll in any direction from the hotel.I can not discuss price of the wifi or breakfast as these were paid by my employer. However the wifi certainly worked well, and breakfast was fantastic. This is an excellent breakfast by any standards. A wide choice of European and Japanese foods available. I stuck to the Japanese which included crab dumplings, pickles, miso soup, fried tofu, mackerel and salmon, and an extensive salad bar. The salad bar includes smoked salmon and herring, sundried tomatoes, all manner of leaves and dressings. Fresh kiwi fruit, dried mango and pineapple, prunes, lychees and many other fruits are on offer. Freshly squeezed orange juice, the usual range of other juices, teas and coffee are of course served. Table service is attentive, you will not run out of coffee.A range of pastries, cereals, breads, the "full English" breakfast items are also on offer. Give yourself at least an hour to enjoy this feast!The smoky sky bar presents splendid views and also a frightful drinks bill. We ended up enjoying much more reasonably priced beverages from the understated and friendly Geronimo cocktail bar a couple of blocks away. So this is an expensive, full-service business hotel where you can expect to pay through the nose for excellent service, restaurants bars and views, in a useful location.

We stayed at the ANA InterContinental Tokyo for 2 nights and we really enjoyed this hotel. This was our 2nd stay at an InterContinental on this trip and this hotel fared well compared to the others. The room was a bit small and the bedding and decor were somewhat dark but the room was very clean and comfortable. I loved the extra pillow with buckwheat and down feathers.Compared to the other InterContinentals we visited on this trip, the breakfast buffet was overpriced ($50 US per person with tax+service) and not really worth it. I was expecting Sushi and there was none but the Dim Sum and Smoked Squid were very good.The hotel was about 150 Meters from 2 different subway stations which was a bit of a long walk with our suitcases. After paying about $25 US in Train and Subway tickets to get there from Narita Airport we realized the Airport Express Bus was about the same price (Perhaps $5 more) and much more convenient.The outdoor pool was closed for winter. (You can see a reflection of the pool in the picture I posted (View from our room.jpg)We would stay again.

Stayed on business and was a great location for our trip. Gym was excellent and also had free water bottles which saved a fortune on getting water in room. Teppanyaki Restaurant was truly excellent, be prepared for the live prawns! Despite paying over 200 pounds a head they asked us to leave at 10 o'clock as they were closing. The steak restaurant is very average but still expensive.

Although you may not realize it at first, the location of this hotel is perfect for walking or taking the metro to Tokyo 's best attractions. A short walk in any direction will put you at numerous restaurants and shops. Tokyo tower and Roppongi are just a short walk and the metro station is nearly at the front door of the hotel. Inside, the lobby is beautiful, the food is delicious ( but expensive) and the rooms are great.

Just come from 3 nights at the hotel and left having had a wonderful stay. We arrived early from an overnight flight from the UK and whilst we couldn't cheek in straight away we did get our room a few hours early. Location is good depending on what you're doing. A bit of a walk to the centre of Tokyo but there are always cabs outside on the other hand it is very close to lively Roppongi for evenings out.
