Common areas are spacious and well fitted out, as are the rooms. We felt very well looked after. English is spoken throughout the hotel and there are even some English speaking tv channels. Only downside is that all the restaurants in the hotel are absurdly expensive. This dosent really matter as there are so many more to choose from in the building next door, but it did grate a little.

This is not your typical Intercontenental, as the many restaurants all have a different motif.The skytop lounge is breathtaking and there is even a Chapel which looks like it came from the land of OZ! Ofcourse, I recommend the Lunch Buffet for about $35. US, a bargan for Japan prices.... A 15 walk up to Roppongi where the Hyatt and exclusive shopping malls are located.

Stayed here for three nights with my boyfriend who was here on business. First impressions weren't great as upon arrival at the room we were allocated two single beds and when we called to ask them to fix it we were told point blank that there was absolutely nothing they could do about it, not a good start as I believe this could have been fixed somehow but apparently they couldn't even entertain the idea. Anyway apart from this, the rest of the stay was lovely: very helpful staff especially when booking an excursion and when asking for help with taxis etc. the waiting staff are polite and attentive however I wouldn't reccomend the dinner buffet - not a great standard for the price. Overall though a great place to stay when in Tokyo.

Imy family & I just moved here from the IC Bay (the other IC in Tokyo) because that other one did not have available rooms for tomorrow. At first I thought of using my status with IC to pay more and get a room at the first hotel, but then decided that I would give this one a try. This one cost a bit more and had similar ratings, but I figured that I would try it anyway. Boy, am I glad I did. Whereas the first one was one of the worst IC I had ever stayed in, especially with regard to the service ( se my. Review), the ANA IC is beautiful, modern, offering knowledgable staff, plenty of good restaurants, an amazing lounge ( perhaps the most impressive I have ever seen), a very good location,etc. if you like IC hotels don't even think about staying at the sister hotel in tokyo. Come to the ANA instead!

In all aspects, this is exactly what you expect of caring luxury hotel. Spacious rooms, absolute tidyness, comfortable lobby, plenty of restaurants, very well maintained gym... And most of all - devouted personnel.

As one would expect from an Intercontinental this hotel was excellant in all aspects.There can only be one minor negative, and it may be just a personal preference and that is the breakfast in the club lounge. Everything was as one would hope for, but the bacon was too crispy and cool for my taste.However the service and consideration by all staff was top notch and could not be faulted in any way.Just a possible hint, for regular travellers to the Intercontianel chain ofhotels around the world, it is definately worth considering paying for the Ambassador status, if for no other reason than to get the room upgrades at the Intercontinentals (sometimes others in the chain). Better rooms and "extras" and well worth the money for the additional comfort.

When we speak of service, Japan is unique that you get the same amount of attention and service even in a single star hotel. The property is located in the Centre of Tokyo's upscale locality. The comfort level is below what you expect by looking at the brand you are paying for. You can enjoy luxury in nearby Capitol hotel, New Otani and Imperial hotels at the same price.The rooms are small, though the management has tried to give it a traditional classic touch with typical Japanese color schemes, but yet guests would not feel the freshness or breath easily for amount of US$ 350+ you are paying for. I stayed in their club King room (upgraded due to membership privilege from Executive class). The bathrooms are extremely small by standard of this class of hotel, you feel cramped. The Shower is excellent. Amenities also do not match the class of Intercontinental. The club lounge is excellent, huge, comfortable and excellent service. The location is good for those who have to deal with Embassies or Japan Government offices but not for those who are dealing with financial institutions or on a holiday.

I last stayed at this hotel a couple of years ago and came with a memory of tired rooms. But I was pleasantly surprised by the improvements, especially to the bathroom. Everything in the room is intuitive/well placed so you can arrive from a flight, quickly set up your laptop on the free wifi internet (on Club floor) and get on with your meetings. Overall, a very efficient trip enhanced by the excellent Club Lounge experience. Will be back again soon.

Excellent business hotel. My room was very functional, very comfortable and calming. The service is good and discrete. The gym is very minimalist, super clean, and had a nice zen quality to it. While the neighborhood is not an exciting one, it is quite convenient with many restaurants and cafes. And it's only a 15 min walk to Roppongi.

the hotel looks impressive and so are the rooms. Typical japanese hospitality but.. the hotel is kinda next to one of the Roppongi stations however it seems you have to walk for miles and change to other train lines if you want to get anywhere.. And you need to pay for Wi Fi which is punishable!

Overall the hotel is great. It does not look stunning on the outside and the lobby probably could do with some renovations here and there. The rooms are spacious and luckily I got upgraded to the club floor which had free wireless access. Most of the floors seem to be newly renovated and definitely looked a lot better than the lobby itself. There are a number of restaurants and the teppanyaki place on the top floor is awesome. Walking to the Roppongi Hill and Moori Tower takes 10 minutes and the subway station is literally just outside of the hotel.

I stayed at this hotel for two nights in connection with a business trip. The rooms are a little worn and the bathroom is small. Anyway, it was not a big issue. The bed was good and everything was clean and nice. The service in the lobby area was exceptional. The breakfast was also really good.I arrived from the Haneda airport and it is just 20-25 minutes with monorail to the Hamamatsuchõ station (470 yen) and then 10 minutes with taxi (900 yen).The hotel was quite expensive, USD300+ per night, but I guess is the price level in central Tokyo.

As you would expect from an Intercontinental, this is a well appointed hotel in a great location. The Chinese restaurant is excellent and well worth a visit. The front desk staff can be a bit brusque and not particularly welcoming but the concierge staff and bell staff are friendly and helpful. The 'hot' part of the buffet breakfast could best be described as 'tepid' but the selection is otherwise good. Wifi throughout the hotel.

I recently stayed at the ANA, I found it to be ideally located. My stay was pleasant. My room was beautiful with a fantastic view. The staff was helpful, knowledgable and seemed highly educated as well. I found this hotel through a website called luxurygroup.com who highly recommended the hotel. I am pleased to say it was a very nice stay. Should I find myself in this area again I would stay at the ANA once again.

Just stayed at The ANA again. The staff continues to be the best. The declining condition of the work out room has been addressed. The new room, located on the fourth floor, is impeccable with state of the art tread mills and bicycles. It will take many visits to learn how to use the video system on these machines. It is an excellent distraction making the workout, mentally, less strenuous

We had 3 nights in Tokyo after skiing for a week and the Hotel delivered on the Japanese hospitality we had already encountered. From the porter to the Manager of the club lounge the service was great. The room, while not large, was comfortable, modern and very clean. Our room rate included access to the Club lounge which was very worthwhile.

I stayed at the Intercontinental ANA for 4 nights in February. The hotel was in a great location - only a 2 minute walk to the Metro Station. Although not as good as other Intercontinental hotels that I have stayed at previously, the room itself was comfortable and was a good size. The shower was great with fantastic water pressure in the shower. I was, however, disappointed by the staff at the hotel. Upon my arrival, I had to wait a long time to check-in. (There wasn't a long line, the actual check-in process itself was very tedious, taking far too long). I am a priority Club member and having previously worked for IHG, I know what to expect. I was not greeted as a priority club member, nor was I offered a complimentary newspaper and nor was I offered a late check-out not was I upgrade. Instead, I was told that there were no more King rooms( I had booked a king room) so would have to stay in a twin. This was very disappointing. I was given a password to wi-fi which was available throughout the hotel. When I questioned if this wifi was free of charge, I was told it was - when, in fact, it was not. I had a rude shock when I went to check-out and found 4 days worth of internet charges (it was not cheap!). I questioned this with the receptionist and he was very casual, saying "Yes, internet is charged'. When I told him I was not informed of any charges he did not seem to care. I was not offered an apology. Instead, I was grunted at and made to feel like a fool. He kept repeating that internet is charged so I kept telling him that I had not been informed of any charge. After about 10 minutes of silence, he threw the bill at me and told me that he had taken off the internet charges but next time I would have to pay. Obviously, I was satisfied that the charge had been taken off, however, I did not feel I was treated very respectfully. I also found that the staff did not go out of their way to greet guests nor provide them with any information unless they were promted.I would stay again at this hotel, mainly for the location.

I stayed at the ANA Intercontinental in Tokyo for ten nights and have nothing but great things to say about this hotel. It's close to a number of good restaurants, close to the Ginza subway line, their staff is very professional and friendly and the restaurants in the hotel were excellent. We were in a junior suite so I can't speak to the size of the regular rooms, but our room was lovely, quiet and spacious. The breakfast buffet was very good, although I would have liked to have more fresh fruit available. I would have given this hotel a higher rating, however, the gym facilities left much to be desired. At the moment the hotel is remodelling their regular gym and the alternative facility is a poor option. I found that the concierge was always helpful with suggestions and responding to questions. I would stay here again.

The hotel is very accessible: subway station is right outside, there is a taxi stand and the limousine bus going to and from the airport actually makes a drop to the hotel. It is about a 15 minute walk away from Ropponggi where you can find tons of restaurants. Had a bit of a problem with the bed = twas a ittle too hard for my back though.

The ANA Intercontinental is centrally located and provides convenient direct access to some of Tokyo's major attractions like Shibuya or Asakusa via the Ginza subway line from Tameike-sanno station (use exit 13 located literally a few steps from the hotel). The property is beautifully appointed and the room was nicely furnished. I stayed at the Japanese suite which was spacious and the bathroom had the toilet and shower/bath in their own separate room. The Club lounge was relatively large with plenty of seating throughout. The buffet breakfast was good with plenty of choices. However, the evening cocktail hour offered only a handful of small tidbits that needed to be replenished constantly as these were quickly devoured as soon as they were set. In the afternoon at certain times the club provides tea service with cookies, French macarons and canneles. The views of downtown Tokyo were impressive and there were plenty of windows to soak up the view. In addition, I saw two computer stations in the main seating area behind reception for patron's usage.The concierge desk was well staffed and very helpful. Service was very polite and proactive from all members of the staff. Overall this is a solid choice if one is looking for a deluxe property with a great location.

Decent hotel, well located with exceptional level of services from the concierge. I was accompanying my husband on a business trip and we decided to catch a concert by Florence and the Machines. The concierge arranged tickets, booked restaurants and provide us with detailed instructions on how to get from one place to another with minimum fuss (which is a challenge in Tokyo when your Japanese is limited). Meant that our trip was hassle free and we manage to explore the city in a short space of time. Rooms are small which is usual for Tokyo hotels, but manageable. Bar was nice and breakfast was expansive. As with most things in Tokyo food, drink and accommodation were expensive. Based on the level of service alone I would choose to stay in this hotel again.

Good location near subway and the shops and restaurants of Akasaka and Roppongi. Narita Express bus stops here first when arriving in the city which saves a little travel time. Hotel is large but a bit dated, restaurants are very expensive, best to have simple things like coffee and breakfast at places outside. Nice bar on upper floor with nice atmosphere and views in the evening. Rooms nice but bathrooms very small. Service not as good as other hotels I have stayed at in Tokyo.

Stayed for five nights recently in Jan. Lovely rooms, great views and superb service. The club lounge staff were excellent. And special mention to the concierge and Jerome. He was superb beyond belief with his information, smile and candour. Excellent beyond belief! Food was great. Service was immaculate. I can't state how happy I was with my stay. Well done to the team. The only wish I would have is perhaps better English entertainment. The only English channels I remembered was CNN BBC Fox and perhaps oneMore English channel. No English sports channels covering EPL or others stuff like tennis, or HBO.

Stayed overnight and upgraded to be club level. Really comfy hotel and easy to get there on the bus. Handy to rappongi and right next to the subway. Happy hour in the lounge was great and there are great views of Tokyo from up there. I'll be back.
user_name:
kellyenz
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: we arrived after a long flight to greeted by long long lines at check in.we were booked onto the club level and we quickly got escorted to a private check in.blissthe room was amazing and the service of the club beyond amazing.we used the concierge consistantly before and during our visit..thwy booked restauarants ,theatre tickets etc with ease.Even calling ahead to a local chicken hole in the wall diner to make sure the englsh speaking waiter was there to greet us(no one else spoke english).I cannot fault the service we recieved and would definately go back again again and again

I stayed at this hotel for two nights on the 18th and 19th of January. The hotel is very luxurious and the service cannot be faulted. My room was on the 31st floor and was very clean and comfortable. The bed was one of the most cosseting and comfortable beds I have ever slept in.What did take me by surprise are the prices of drinks in the hotel, I paid approx £23 for two black coffee's in the main lobby area which I think was expensive even for a great hotel like this.That said I would recomend this hotel to anyone and would go back again
user_name:
BurtonBloke
Burton upon Trent, United Kingdom

review_body: We arrived late after a long international flight into Tokyo, no one bothered to assist us with our bags when getting out of the taxi, we normally are more than happy to carry them ourselves however after a long flight and jet lag a bit of assistance would have been appreciated. Check in was a short wait, we are platinum PCR members our booking was made on PCR point which we earned by staying at IHG hotels continually, our booking was for a non smoking queen room. The girl on reception tells me that they don't have any queen rooms that are non smoking and our only option is 2 single beds on a smoking floor, however she offers that I can pay an extra $8000 yen for a club king non smoking room! I normally wouldn't ask but part of been a platinum PCR member you receive a complimentary upgrade, subject to availability! When I ask if we could be upgraded as this is one of our benefits she stated that because we aren't paying for the room we would not benefit from a foc upgrade, I bluntly responded stating so you are penalasing me for been loyal client with your hotels and earning point by staying at your hotels around the world, I ask for the managers details which they refuse to give to me, a formal complaint will be going to the Asia Pacific CEO of the organization as they clearly don't value loyalty. Over all the hotel is nice rooms are comfortable however service and knowledge of their programs would a minimum requirement.

This was a family trip, upon arrival we had the option to upgrade our rooms to the recently renovated ones on the upper floors for about $30 a night. we did not see the original rooms we booked with our package, but the rooms we stayed were large with well appointed furniture and great bedding. These rooms became our comfortable home during our 11 night stay. Daily breakfast was included; a wonderful elegant buffet consisting of delicious international and japanese foods in an open comfortable yet elegant dining room area with exceptional service and outstanding coffee. The hotel is centrally located, a block away from the metro station, the metro takes you conveniently to your destination.

Am now staying here. Extremely kind and hospitable staff. Japanese high quality standard! Reception is so kind and efficient, and room maintenance as well. Truly pleasant. The room, however, is also at a Japanese standard which is, unfortunately, rather small from Intercontinental standard. I stayed a number of intercontinental hotels in the world, and this hotel has probably one of the smallest rooms.Don't be upset because it has a reason. It used to be a ANA Tokyo hotel, which was actually a Japanese "business" hotel, meaning small inn for business fellows. When they changed the brands, they had to maintain the building size. Anyway, if you want to enjoy Japanese hospitality, this is a very good hotel. Location is also great. If you are expecting the intercontinental size of room environment, sorry this is a Japanese intercontinental!

Despite the hotel is not new and the design is like 1980s, the location is unbeatable - the hotel is close to 2 metro stations and Roppongi is within walking distance. The hotel is probably as convenient as Grand Hyatt at Roppongi but should be much cheaper. Did not spend 3K JPY taking the famous breakfast buffet as there are many decent cafe/bakery/CVS nearby. The room is quite spacious compared with other hotels in Tokyo. Will stay here again for sure.

Business trip for 6 nights in mid December. In my mind the location is good, although it was my first time in Japan and I cannot pretend to be an expert. Anyway, there were lots of different restaurants and bars just 5-10 minutes walk from the hotel. There is a metro station nearby and the metro is very effective so you can easily reach the sights of Tokyo as well as the shopping districts. The hotel itself is big & clean with spacious rooms and good, friendly service. The breakfast was quite good. There are also shops in the neighbourhood so you can buy snacks, beer etc. All in all I just have to give it ***** because I have no complaints whatsoever, only positive things. I paid some 200 euros per night for my room, which was some kind of a governmental guest price, the list price might be somewhat higher than that. I am quite sure that you can find at least as nice hotels cheaper in Tokyo but I warmly reccommend this hotel. There are no unpleasant surprises and everything works fine.

The ANA is in a good location in Tokyo, with easy access to many tours via a coach. We seemed to not get caught in ant traffic jams. The rooms are modern but small,and the lobby area is a little confusing.There are quite a few places to eat and drink within a 5 minute walk.

We spent a week at the ANA Intercontinental early December and initially booked into a smoking room (Naughty I know) - we had to be asked to be moved from the room because it smelt really really smokey. I wouldn't expect a smoking room to be as fresh as a non smoking room but because the windows don't open and the air con wasn't very powerful the room smelt like the end of a teenage disco. The hotel itself was lovely - our new room spacious and confortable. There is noise from the busy road outside even on floor 27 but the hum of the air con covered it mostly. A great place to stay to explore some of Tokyo and in walking distance of the Tokyo Tower (25 mins). Great restaurants very nearby and most of them have pictures to allow you to choose what to eat when the language escapes you !

Took the air limousine bus from Narita which was very simple, as my flight was late in I took the coach to the town centre air terminal (CAT) ( 5 minute wait) rather than wait the 90 minutes to the next direct bus and then a taxi from the CAT to the hotel. On the way back got the coach directly from the hotel. Opted for the return ticket which gives you two days use of the city metro system for free!The ANA is a lovely hotel right in the centre of Tokyo, with good acress to the Metro system which has English signs Ticket machine options so is OK to use, but watch out for linked stations as there can be long walks between them. I am an ambassador so I was upgraded to a junior suite, which gave more room and it had a lovely view of the Royal palace. The room was long and thin with a separate bath and rain effect shower in one end & work/sitting area at other with a flat screen TV and small table. Welcome fruit plate and water waiting for my arrival!The staff in the lounge were very efficient and helped with many enquiries of what to see and where to eat and even arranged a view of Mt Fuji on the first morning in the hotel! Had breakfast and early evening snacks in the lounge which were nice and even better as they were free. I ate in the Pierre Gagnaire restaurant on the first night, the food was lovely with excellent presentation but it was expensive so you can’t eat there every night. They offer a number, three (I think), of set menus each evening with a lovely mixture of tastes and textures. On the final night I ate in the Japanese restaurant (Unkai) which was OK, but still expensive!No hotel is cheap in this city but this one is good value for Tokyo, if you can every say that about this city! So if you are looking for a good hotel with a reasonable price for Tokyo you could do worse then try this one.

I just spent 1 night at the hotel room was standard, but spacious, was expecting a better view but was next to building, I really enjoyed the bar on 36 floor good snacks n drinks and very good view, location of hotel was good as I was able to EY around in roppongi area well! Breakfast was great and venue was crowded but maintained well by staff, although I felt that staff is very business like and not very friendly, but they try smiling, I asked a few staff at 1st floor about cover charge of Mixx bar but no one knows. But as I said choice and quality of breakfast was just fantastic, great job done there! Thanks.

Heavenly Hotel with a bird’s eye view of the city. The InterContinental @ Akasaka is situated at the best locales of Tokyo. The Roppongi district is just walking distance away so is the Kasumigaseki. The easy access to the Tokyo Metro stations by just walking to the Tameike Sanno subway station. Important places like the Imperial Palace, Senso-ji Temple, Ginza shopping district and the Mori Art Museum are stone's throw away. There are 8 restaurants and 4 fantastic lively bars in this hotel. A very lively place to be in Tokyo!

We were not sure if we wanted to stay here based on the reviews at first. The staff were really nice and most of them spoke english. Minimo in the concierge dept. was very nice and spoke excellent english. We were there for 6 nights and had room 2007. The view was very nice. The subway was within walking distance. The Ark Hills center next door, easily accesible from the third floor, has some nice reasonable priced places to eat. They have an excellent curry place as well as a subway sandwich shop. Starbucks is located on the first floor of the center as well as a convienient store. The pastry shop in the hotel has some great pastries. The conciege told us of a nice noodle bar close to the hotel next to the police station that was awesome. Loved the location and the staff.

The staff are very friendly at this hotel, the rooms are clean and comfortable. I have stayed twice at this hotel and I believe the rooms vary depending on which floor you are on. The first time I stayed my room felt quite modern, the second time a bit more dated. The views from the rooms are great.

I won a night in the club room last Christmas at a raffle so stayed there which felt strange since i only live 20 minutes away. I have to say though we were totally blown away with what a beautiful hotel this is. We won a night in the club room. For the extra money, i would highly recommend staying here if you are considering it. The tea and biscuits on arrival, the canapes and open bar in the evening , the grand buffet breakfast in the morning, and the use of the gym are all superb. Not to mention that the recently refurbished rooms are stylish, comfortable beyond belief and so convenient as you are located in Central Tokyo.We've been back for a night since which this time we paid for as we were so happy with the service last time.

I have only stayed at this hotel and the Ritz in Tokyo, obviously the Ritz is better, but this one was 1/5 the price, and was nice. I would rate it a 4 star. Nice lounge, very nice staff, within walking distance of subway and/or shops and restaurants. Perfect for business.
user_name:
Dan H
New York City, New York

review_body: After reading the various reviews in here, I guess I was lucky to have a new room so can't complain. However I was kind of startled to find that there's no complimentary mineral water, and more shockingly, even for hotel guest to use the gym, there is a per entry charge of 1,500 yen which is about 19 USD ???

Having read about how cramped the centre of Tokyo was I was apprehensive about my first trip to Japan. Would the hotel feel claustrophobic? would the rooms be minute? In fact all my concerns over the ANA Intercontinental Hotel were in vain. The hotel is as spacious and luxurious as you'd expect to find in any major city.The hotel lobby feels particularly spacious and contains the hotel bar, cafe and restaurant which gives a very pleasant open aspect when eating or drinking. The breakfast choice was very varied with the option of a western or Japanese style breakfast.I had a standard room which was perfectly adequate in size with free wifi internet and iron. My corporate rate also included free use of the gym, which is shortly to be refurbished ready for January 2012. The gym is open 24 hours, a pleasant distraction for the inevitable jet lag.What really impressed me about the hotel was the friendliness and level of service of the staff. Everyone was so helpful. This may be a reflection of traditional Japanese levels of high service and hospitality, but it any case I found the hotel to be very welcoming.The hotel is situated in centrally in Akasaka, usefully its the first stop for the airport limousine bus service making it easy to get to and from Nirata airport. I didn't find much in the way of shops nearby, there are many mini-supermarkets for essentials, a small high end shopping mall behind the hotel and a Starbucks and a couple of cafe bars if you fancy a change from the hotel.All in all, I found my stay here very pleasant. Its a large city centre luxury hotel, you won't have any surprises bad or good regarding your stay. It is expensive, but being the centre of Tokyo, you'd expect that.

This was a clean but slightly tired hotel. The breakfast buffet was extremely bountiful but like anywhere in Japan bad bread and not so great coffee if you like Italian coffee. The service and attentiveness of staff was excellent, the rooms were comfortable, but if you stay there try to get a better view than I had over what looked like a power plant.

I am very happy I could stay at this hotel at my first visit to Tokyo. It is located in the business-governmental area of Tokyo, in walking distance from Roppongi, the modern-style, night active area of Tokyo. The hotel offers all convenciences possible, the most amazing is the huge rooms, which is unusual for Tokyo or Japan in general. You have a huge, VERY comfortable bed, fridge, flatscreen TV, table+chairs, huge window, mirrors, w-lan and lan connections, bathroom with full-functional toilet, window into the room (not all rooms), very modern bathroom furniture. All in all, wonderful to stay there! In the ground floor meeting rooms and banquet rooms, we saw many wedding parties there. On the 27(?) floor an amazing lounge, just a bit expensive. Roppongi is in walking distance (7min.) offers lots of bars, restaurants, discos :)

ANA InterContinental is one of the older hotels in Tokyo, so it may not look as modern and minimalist as some of the newer hotels like Park Hyatt, Conrad, etc. But looks aside, this is a very nice comfortable, centrally located hotel. Rooms were of a decent size, well designed and very comfortable. And with a premium view as well - waking up to seeing Mount Fuji one very rare, clear morning was totally unexpected and a bonus! :) I checked in very late at night and was offered an upgrade to the 33rd floor, which I understand to be one of the Club Floors. However staff did not communicate to me on whether I was given access to the Club Lounge, given the upgrade, which on hindsight, I should have asked. Accessibility is excellent - there is a subway exit just outside the hotel, although it is a 10 minute walk underground before you actually reach the subway gates. The Airport Limousine stops at the 1st floor of the hotel, which allowed for an easy transfer to the airport. However, I find it peculiar for a 5-star hotel like the ANA that Bell Services was noticeably absent, as no luggage assistance was provided upon arrival, nor upon departure, even to the airport limousine coach bay on the 1st floor. However, concierge was present at their counters and professional in providing the necessary information when asked.

This was my first trip to Tokyo and it will be a memorable one because of the attention provided by the hotel. I had a very bad fall on my way back from the office to the Hotel. I hurt my ankle badly and limped back to the hotel. A couple of hours later I noticed that my ankle had swelled to the size of a tennis ball and i couldn't walk. I called my Japan colleague and she then called the hotel to assist me in getting to a hospital. They immediately called my room and asked what sort of injury it was. They then made a few calls to get find a doctor that could speak English as it was 7pm at the time. They conveyed to the doctor the sort of injury I had sustained. They then brought a wheelchair up to my room and got me into a taxi. They found out that hospital doesn't accept credit only cash. Since i didn't have enough cash they actually took cash out of their petty cash box and gave me 15,000 YEN to pay for the treatment. The fact they they they even thought of such details impressed me.I had my friend with to accompany me to the hospital but had she not been there I believe they would gone a step further and sent one of their staff to accompany me to the hospital and back.I was truly amazed at how efficient, coordinated and organized they were. They even manage to crack a few jokes to lighten the mood. Im truly grateful to the ANA Intercontinental Hotel for going out of their way to help me. This is what I call going the extra-mile. I left Tokyo with very good impression of the city and the Japanese people.
Nice hotel ... Rooms nice and clean booked std room to save costs ... Wrong decision :) ... executive level would have given value for money ..

This is my third trip to Tokyo. Previously I have always stayed at The Imperial which is an old style colonoial hotel with a new wing. The thing that was shocking was the size of the room. It was minute. They described it as a single room but I have never stayed in such a small room. It was booked via the Hong Kong office and the rate was Y18,000 which included breakfast and Internet. This compared with a rate of Y26,000 to Y30,000 at The imperial but I suppose you get what you pay for. The room was basic but comfortable. The bathroom was small but functional but all the soaps and shampoos were in containers strapped to the walls, and it badly needed an update.

The rooms and bathrooms are large for Tokyo (small for Western style, but large for Asia or any large city for that matter). Nice amenities including toiletries, robes, slippers, etc. Very comfortable beds. Our room had a king size bed, large flatscreen tv, small couch, table, desk, and bar area. The hotel has more of a business/minimalist/modern feel versus plush or romantic.The best thing about this hotel is the conceirge service. I had an exceptional experience here, and the conceirge service goes above and beyond to help you go/see/eat/do whatever you want in Tokyo (and probably outside of Tokyo as well). I had a question about a restaurant that they could not get in touch with at that moment. So when I got back to my room about an hour later, I had a typed letter waiting for me that answered all of my questions and even more. I was very impressed!There are several restaurants in the hotel, and there is an outdoor swimming pool open in the summer (rare in Tokyo!). Easy access from Narita airport; the Airport Limosine bus makes it's first stop here. There is a metro station right outside the hotel and at least 3-4 other stations within 5-8 mins walk.

We are staying here for four days, every time we use our key card in the room door it doesn't work the following time. It has nothing do with it being near my phone or other electronic devices. They can't seem to fix the problem, and all they do is say they are sorry! How about a free cocktail for all the BS they put us through... Not a chanceNext up is the 8+ percent fee on changing US$ into yen without mentioning this high fee. They tried charging me $85 when I converted $1000. I went right next door to the post office and there was no fee. The last one that got me was when we ordered the "fish and mushroom" soup in the cafe for $50 we received about 4 ounces of " mushroom water "All this for $450 a night... Get me the [--] out of here!Lastly

I had a very comfortable stay at this hotel and particularly appreciated how many restaurants were just outside the hotel. I skipped the pricey breakfast and went to Starbucks instead - it opens at 7am and is 5 minutes from the hotel. I found the staff friendly and responsive. The bed was very comfortable and the room was quiet despite being on a busy highway. The gym was nice and open 24 hours. Internet was free and reliable. My one complaint was checking in. It was very slow because everyone arrived by bus from the airport at the same time. I suggest the hotel consider a way to speed up check-in for large groups of people since this must be a common problem. And, after a 14 hour flight and 90 minute (awful) bus ride to the hotel, I was left to carry my own suitcases to the room. This is the first time in years of traveling that I was simply left at the elevator and no one took my suitcases to the room. Again, I think this was probably a result of such a large number of people arriving at the same time, but a hotel of this quality should find a way to accommodate this.
user_name:
bethpindc
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: We stayed there for 4 nights, service and amenities were great. The best thing about this hotel was the air-conditioning - it really functioned well and were really cool~ any frequent visitor to Japan knows that most hotels don't equip with strong air-con and that usually makes the room very stuffy.The biggest problem had to be location. There were 2 subway "exits" nearby but they were only "exits" not actually close to stations. We had to walk 10 mins underground to get on a train. Walking to Ropponggi takes 20-30 mins, no major shopping/restaurants nearby. Airport limousine buses for this hotel leaves airport every hour (unlike the ones for Shinjuku / Shibuya which leaves every 1/2 hour), so if you missed one you have to wait for a long time. So if you're there for business I think it's fine, but for shopping and having fun, this is definitely not the place. We used to stay in Shibuya Excel and it was far more convenient than Intercontinental. Also the decoration and upkeep not comparable to most other intercontinental hotels. Furniture a bit worn and just not very "luxurious".

Located around the corner from the US embassy, and next door to a subway stop, this location is hard to beat. There are hundreds, if not thousands of restaurants within walking distance, and numerous convenience stores open 24 hours. The staff is extremely professional and eager to help you. However, the rooms could use some updating.

Top notch customer service and quality. Nice size rooms and super comfy beds, as well as the pillows -- great to sink into after a long overseas trip. Easy to get to from Narita and Tokyo Station. Breakfast is a tad steep, which is the norm for hotels with this many stars, but the food was delicious with lots of Japanese and Western selection -- and fruit was fresh. Relatively well equipped exercise room. Try to get the higher floors for a nice view of Tokyo. I'll definately be staying here on my next trip to Tokyo. .

We have visited Tokyo on many occasions but this was only the second time that we stayed at the Roppingi area and the first time at this hotel. The location was really what sealed the deal for us when we tried to decide on where to stay. Firstly, it's the dropoff location for limo service from the airport, which makes things a lot easier for us. The fact that it's only 2 minute walk to the metro station with connections to 4 major subway lines also helped (although it does take another 8-10 minutes just to walk from the metro entrance to the platform.)The interior design of the hotel was a bit dated but we found the atmosphere to be quite comfortable. The room was spacious in Tokyo standard though a bit noisy at night since it faced the front of the hotel where there were a few overpasses connecting Roppongi to other parts of the city. The bathroom especially the bath-tub has definitely seen better days and could sure use a facelift.It was disappointing to find that there's no Wifi available in the rooms but if there's any consolation, there was a network cable there just in case you have a laptop computer. If you are using an iPhone/iPad, you can try what one hotel staff suggested to us - stand real close to the business center and try your luck connecting to the Wifi there. We tried our luck but no cigar.There were many nice restaurants in the hotel, ranging from Chinese, Japanese to French but there's a hidden gem at the corner - the pastry store by Pierre Gagnaire. Pierre was best known for innovative French cuisine but we were surprised to find that his little pastry store offered a nice variety of cakes at very reasonable price. We tried the taro mousse cake and chestnut/ginger cake and they were very delicious. It's definitely worth a visit.

Ticks all the 4-star boxes. Polite, attentive service, a business-ey feel, huge lobby with nice restaurants and bars. Outdoor swimming pool. A skybar with wonderful views at night.My room was ok and I am sure it was amazing in 1990 when the carpet was new and the furniture had not been worn out. Don't get me wrong, it is comfortable, roomy enough, nice bathroom, but no contemporary decor or furniture.Drinks in the spectacular skybar are furiously expensive (but really delicious), as is the cable broadband in the room. Room service and breakfast are also quite pricey. This is a business hotel for sure, bring the expense account card.The location is a bit of a walk from Roppongi proper and Akasaka, along an unappealing main road. However, take the rear exit from the lobby floor and there is a kind of open-air plaza with several restaurants and cafes, a very pleasant place to unwind and do lunch. The location is right amongst the embassy district, so you can lose your passport here all you like, and just walk to the embassy of your choice in a couple of minutes for a pink replacement. Sugoi!Rooms on the east side of the tower sport smashing views of Tokyo Tower, for those who like, um, views of Tokyo Tower. I'd come back for sure. But at a pinch I'd prefer to stay at the Grand Prince Akasaka.

We stayed only one night in this property, at check-in, we were given a temp room because our junior suite was not ready yet at the time, we left for lunch and later we returned to the hotel, our luggage was already moved from the temp room to our suite. A lot of time, what you see on the website photos about the room are different from the actual ones, but mine is just like the photo they show on the website. The club lounge is on 35th floor with view of Tokyo city, spacious and relaxing. The building right next to the hotel has several restaurants, bookstore, convenience store, and post office. The subway we used is Namboku line, it is only 3 minute walk to the station " Roppongi-ichome". Everything just works out for us.

I was only here 2 nights, but enjoyed it a lot. Not quite right in the center of Roppongi, but just a few blocks walk from the center, so not bad either. The ANA is a large hotel and has that feel, but that can be a good thing compared to the smaller places that often sound great but don't deliver. The room was very comfortable with a small sofa and the bedding was excellent. Bathroom also very nice and they have wireless, but like many big hotels, they charge 2,000Y per day for it which is a big thumbs down... The breakfast buffet downstairs is quite good and the hotel overall is very comfortable and decently priced as mid-range. It is recommended for a no-hassle comfortable stay in a great area with the large hotel feel. The concierge was really very helpful and patient! Staff stood out as better than the smaller boutiques..

Stayed in this hotel again after three years.They seem to have upgraded the decor of the room which makes it cosy. Service continues to be great at check-in/check-out and at the concerige. Room cleaniless was top notch. It is located near the entrance of the subway station with a few lines running through it. However, the walk to the actual platform takes 5-10mins.Breakfast was included in my rate and while it is a good, there is nothing special. The only complaint is the size of the room. There isn't too much space to move about. However, the amnities and features are good.I would stay in this hotel again!

I stayed here for work recently. Its right near the Ginza/Chioda Metro lines and near Roppongi. be warned the Marunouchi line is about a 1km walk - so better to take another line and change. The Club floor has great views and breakfast is much more relaxed up here than on the 2nd floor. Service was very good - particularly from the Concierge desk who always had maps and suggestions for where to buy/day trips.Ambassador rooms were spacious, very comfortable and well equipped. The bamboo foot massager a nice touch and the showers excellent. The Elemis products are some of the best I've had in hotels. The massage chairs on the Club floor were also very welcome.I was a little disappointed with some of the costs. Use of the swimming pool is a rather exorbitant Y20,000 per use and whilst gym is included in room rate, this is extra. For the business traveller who maybe wants a 30 mins swim before work, this is off-putting. Indeed, after being stung once, I declined to use it further. This is a shame, as its a large pool and had hardly any users when I visited. At the Hilton in Shinjuku this is included for example. I was also not impressed at having booked a King Executive room yet finding out upon arrival breakfast was not included. It certainly was not clear from the website that this was the case. The result an extra Y3,600 per day. Considering this does not include a full hot breakfast (no baked beans/runny scrambled eggs/ tomatoes etc) I felt this was a bit steep. Although I appreciate Tokyo is expensive, these elements prevented the hotel getting a top rating. There are not that many reasonably priced restaurants in the area. I would advise hopping on the metro to Shibuya, Meguro or Ebisu. At a push there are some very cheap noodle bars a few blocks away.

The ANA InterContinental in Tokyo was great for a trip to Tokyo. If you want to stay in Roppongi and want a decently sized room in a great location, this can't be beat. The service was very good and the room exceptionally nice. For a nice stay in Roppongi, ANA can't be beat.

We have just returned from a wonderful stay in Tokyo at the ANA Intercontinental. I had contacted the hotel some months before and secured a very good rate for our stay in a Club Intercontinental Room. From this first contact, the hotel staff have been very helpful. They happily obliged a cot for the baby and had no issues with our 5 year old sharing our bed (many hotels are strict about the number of people per room). The room was very pleasant - not large when compared to rooms in Indonesia or Thailand but large for a Tokyo hotel. The bathroom was great, if on the small side. The shower was fantastic! The bed was enormous - much larger than a king size. The room was serviced multiple times throughout the day (well it seemed like it as the bed was always made) and turndown service was available each night. A complimentary gift was there on our arrival. The rooms were quiet and the electronic curtains blocked out any morning light. We left the curtains open at night for a great view of the city lights.The Club Intercontinental lounge was fantastic - perhaps the best lounge we have ever used. The staff were helpful, the food and drinks were fantastic. With a 3 star Michelin chef in the hotel, how could the food be less than brilliant? Even with our noisy, messy little ones, the staff were super nice. The wifi and laptops available for use made researching our daily destinations very easy. The lonuge was very big and the Arne Jacobsen-Fritz Hansen 'Egg' chairs made a very comfy rest stop after a long day of sightseeing.The pool was great - the small kid’s pool was a hit with the little ones. The hotel is seconds from a Tokyo Metro exit (Ginza line etc) which made getting around Tokyo very easy. This station had lifts, which was great with our pram. The Akasaka area has many fantastic restaurants and bars if you want to eat out - just head towards the Akasaka-Mitsuke station and you cannot go wrong. Keep in mind that it is a lot quieter on Saturday nights as the Akasaka area is popular during the week with the politicians and bureaucrats that work here. Overall we had a fantastic time here and would certainly return on our next trip to Tokyo.

The hotel was what I call an 'ok' hotel - and benefits from the location. It was not really a happy stay (fittingly, at check-out I was not asked about my stay). The service in general was average to good, but not as what you would expect for this segment and what you would experience otherwise in Japan. The room was standard (small) size, a bit outdated furniture, a lot of noise from the street and the bathroom feels very cramped. The storage place (for clothes) felt a kind of dirty (at least my clothes had marks and were damp).To my surprise, no turn-down service in the evening, no welcome letter, no etc. At check-in I showed up bit too early (shortly before 12.00 o'clock) and was asked to check back after 3 pm for the room (I waited in the Lobby and was surprised to see that other guests were assigned immediately rooms). Bellboys were not available (visible) to help with the luggage, neither at arrival, nor at departure.The food (and the service) in the regular restaurant was average and still quite pricey. The sushi place was ok, but the atmosphere did not invite to come back.Positive was: Direct access to airport bus, good location, busy ground floor, pastry shop, good bed, good lighting system, well functioning A/C.

Booked this hotel for six nights along with airfare via Travelocity in March. My card was debited for the hotel and airfare at the time of the booking.Upon my return from Tokyo in August, my card was debited by the hotel for $230.00 per night. I contacted my credit card company and reported a fraudulent transaction. The card company gave me a temporary credit and cancelled the card. It took five days to receive the new card.Two weeks later, the hotel credited my account, but the credit was for a few cents less than their fraudulent charge. Instead of crediting the card for the correct amount, they apparently used the value of the yen at the time they issued the credit. I have used Travelocity and other travel sites before on various trips, and I have never had a hotel attempt to double charge me. Needless to say, I am very disappointed with this incident.

Being a seasoned business traveler, i've stayed at numerous hotel properties and the ANA intercontinental in Tokyo has taken a place in one of my top rated hotels. I've had a very pleasant experience with the staff, the rooms are well appointed, the facilities are well maintained and there is no shortage of restaurant options! The showers in the room I've stayed are fantastic and the hotel is walkable distance from Roppongi and also the Imperial palace..

Ana Intercontinental is in an excellent location with access to subway directly beside the Hotel (less than 2 mins walk). It is of the standard you would expect and has two Michelin Star restaurants with 3 stars between them. If you have never been to Japan before - rule 1 (a japanese one) - never eat in a Hotel unless invited (the prices are astronomical)Service is perfect, rooms are generous size, staff is friendly and helpful, good english all around. Tips for eating out and how to get there are available from concierge. The Hotel is a collection / drop off point for City Tours. The flaws: 1. ) Be aware that EVERYTHING is extra - user of the pool (20 Euro a day), Internet access (~ 20 Euro a day), Gym (15 Euro a visit - charged to your room when you use your keycard) - make sure to check what is included in your room rate and what is not.2.) The Hotel has an outdoor pool only - and it is only open 7am - 7pm - so if you are there on business you will not have much time to use it. (open during Summer only)There is also a Beer Garden - but again - not open on Weekends and closes at 9pm I stayed there for two weeks and had a memorable experience with my bill :-) somebody had the smart idea to demand payment after week one - just in case the credit card might be over the limit for week two - and they wanted to recoup some money.... (shows you how expensive even they think it is..)Have never had that happen before to me and after a stern NO - I pay at the end of my stay the matter was no longer talked about. Strange however in a Hotel of that class and not quite sure what the company policy was / is there. I will stay there again at the beginning of September so will update if there is any news.

Lovely hotel ideally situated for business in the centre of Tokyo. Public spaces are inspiring. Booked a king club room. The amenities are excellent, shower powerful and of course the Japanese toilet is a bit of a treat.The room itself is on the smaller side but more than enough space, closet and storage wise for 2 persons. The club lounge served a large buffet breakfast that was outstanding. Evening cocktails, wine and champagne were nice but brands were not as high calibre as in other intercontinental hotels. This can also be said for the appetizers. Although there were many to choose from every evening, they served exactly the same ones every night for the entire 5 nights we were there. Service was very good and bordered on excellent, however it did not peak to extraordinary as one expects in this category of hotel. I would definitely stay again. Great value for the money!The club lounge was open to children and although I do like little ones I found it diminished the atmosphere. It was loud, crowded and sometimes chaotic as the children ran about or helped themselves, sometimes touching things and putting them back, or butting in line or more dangerously appearing out of nowhere as I was walking with hot coffee. It would be nice if the lounge had some sort of restriction on children such as certain hours they are allowed in or a child friendly zone.

I loved the ANA IC Tokyo.I would definitely recommend booking a club room for the free internet, free club lounge access, breakfast at the lounge, computers, drinks, massage chairs etc. all included in the lounge.rooms are roomy for tokyo, nicely appointed. the bathrooms are kinda small, but nothin too bad. nice big mirrors in the room, great amenities, nice sofa, and fantastic bed.service is also top notch. would definitely love to come back and stay at this hotel
we went there on our honeymoon. Great quality on all levels. Great room, bed and facilities. Really unforgetable!

We got a great deal on this hotel for 2 nights, and it was our 'treat' part of our accommodation after staying in a B & B style hotel on the snow at Hakuba.5 star all the way, this hotel was luxury and we loved it.The room was very spacious and a decent sized bathroom was a pleasant surprise- not what I expected from Tokyo hotels.Location was handy to the subway, and we could walk to Roppongi, although wouldn't do at night.We loved it and would definitely stay again, although as to be expected from a hotel like this, rooms service, phone calls, etc are pricey.

Centrally located, amazing restaurants within the hotel builkding. Love the hourly Limosine to the Airport from B1. Makes life so easy. The malls around makes the restaurant very central to stay in Akasaka

I stayed at the ANA Intercontinental for business reasons but had the family along.The bottom line: the location is great, the Michelins are great, the noise insulation of the rooms is astounding, and the Occitane amenities are nice. BUT: one should not expect the “you think it and It happens even before you ask” kind of service of other Tokyo hotels in the same class.In addition to this stay at the ANA Intercontinental Tokyo, I’ve spent extended periods of time in Tokyo at the Conrad, the Hilton, and the Tokyu Shibya. The Ana clearly comes third in terms of service and overall product of the four and fourth in terms of value for money – comparing corporate rates all around.While most staff of Tokyo hotels provides you a distinctly personalized experience and generates the feeling that they would love to have you back, the ANA staff – with the exception of the reservations person – seems to be afraid of their costumers or annoyed by their guests. They clearly had some favorites, maybe long term stayers or very frequent repeat guests, but starting from the check-in experience where none of our personal information had made it from the frequent stay profile or the reservations correspondence into the room records, to the daily struggle to get a table for 5 arranged for breakfast, to the check out process nothing really went above and beyond and out of the box solutions are clearly not part of the repertoire. Same for taking any interest in building the perception of a personal relationship, we weren’t greeted by name throughout the entire almost two weeks of our stay, nobody cared to ask what we were doing, nobody cared to ask when we were planning to have breakfast in the morning so that a table for 5 could be arranged, even after a week we were still stopped at the entrance of the lounge area and asked for our room number.The breakfast itself, ranks third of the three places that I enjoyed breakfast in the lounge. A 100% self-serve all prepared deal, not even a hot beverage served by staff and nothing cooked to order. Same deal for the short two hours of appetizers and bar in the evening.Overall, the lounge product is more what you would expect from a similar place in NYC – sans the rowdy crowd – than any Asian offering. Though I have to say that the fellow guests were a very pleasant kind; no shouting into their phones and only the occasional American who seemed to feel that the entire Club needed to know about their intimate life or the details of their latest deal. Others have already mentioned that the pool is a place with a big likelihood of getting nickel and dimed or at least surprised: loungers and water were initially included in our package until the day when without notice the policy changed and we were asked $12 and hour for it.Finally, although it’s the first stop on the Narita Airport Bus, don’t bring too much luggage, as 1. you are on your own with the luggage at the door step of the hotel – bellmen service only for those who arrive by car (in a country that runs on public transport!) – and 2. room space is very limited, especially storage space. Be absolutely certain to read the floor-plan information very carefully and to picture clearly if those precious few square meters are enough space for you and your money – third smallest footprint of the four hotels mentioned above, on par with Tokyu.

My company's office is near so I frequently stay at Ana Intercontinental. I warmly recommend this:- bus service from Narita to hotel is frequent and easy to handle- staff is friendly, correct, and speaks English well- rooms and hotel overall are well maintained, everything is clean and fresh- GREAT restaurants including Michelin 2-star- easy access to Tokyo's vast subway system- just 30 minute taxi ride to Haneda airport- right in the middle of foreigner friendly Roppongi areaThe only down sides are:- small rooms- internet is charged- everything is expensive (but that is true for Japan overall)If you have time in Tokyo, Ana is your place to stay.
Everything you can expect to have in a 5 star hotel you will find it here. Friendly staff, good rooms, amazing and confortable bed linen.....I will stay here again if back to Tokyo

This time we met some of the truly lovely staff at ANA. They are always ready to help and made our stay absolutely wonderful. Have a shiatsu massage in your room to even out those kinks at the end of a long day sightseeing & shopping - you'll thank me for it!As usual, the room was fabulous, the view breathtaking, the breakfast magnificent and the evening cocktails on the 36th a total "must-do"!If we could, we would live here permanently.
Service is excellent - nothing is a problem for the wonderful team at the ANA. Centrally located for all business meetings in Tokyo. I will be back!

I recently stayed in the ANA in Tokyo whilst on business. The location of the hotel is excellent for both access from/to Haneda airport (about 30 minutes drive in Tokyo traffic) and also for my office in Ropponggi.I have previously stayed in the Grand Hyatt Ropponggi Hills (which is my favorite hotel in the world - and whilst more expensive is a significant step up from the ANA in my view).Anyway, check-in was (as usual in Japan in my experience) polite, effective and fast. The room (on a high executive floor) was also excellent and had fabulous views over Tokyo. Very spacious room and very clean. A good selection of toiletries, and a powerful shower - overall the room and bathroom were very impressive, if perhaps starting to feel a little dated and tired.I was in town when the earthquake and tsunami struck the NE part of Honshu. Obviously the shaking in Tokyo was quite severe (I was in the work office at the time), but on return to my room later in the evening you would never have known anything was amiss. Everything was perfectly in place, and it is obvious that someone had been in the room to correct everything before I had got back to the room later that same day. Impressive indeed given the number of rooms that must have had the same treatment in the hotel that day.One thing that did rankle with me was my access to the executive lounge. Given my flight was delayed by about 18 hours due to the quake, I would have thought I would have been allowed to use the executive lounge even though I had checked out - but no such luck. Still - a lot of others were much worse off, so I shouldn't complain I suppose.Overall the hotel feels just a touch dated now in my opinion, with places like the Grand Hyatt and the Park Hyatt relatively close by for ready comparison, and therefore I would probably pick those above the ANA, though the ANA is quite a bit cheaper of course.Overall though, I would recommend.

I just got back from a stay at the ANA Intercontinental in Tokyo and I was very happy with my choice. Here are a few comments:The room was large for Tokyo standards (King Bed, 2 siting chairs, desk chair). The bed was hard, but that's typical in Japan. The air conditioning worked PERFECTLY (I like it cold.. especially in a very hot and humid Tokyo Summer!). The bathroom was well appointed and the shower had great pressure and temperature. The room and bathroom were extremely clean! The hotel was extremely quiet and very convenient to both Haneda Airport and the Tokyo Subway. The concierge happily made a reservation for us at several restaurants and when we arrived, there were no problems. From Haneda airport, we took the Tokyo Monorail to the last station for 470 Yen per person. The taxi ride from Hamamatsucho to the hotel is roughly 1200-1400 Yen. We did the reverse on the return and it was really smooth and reasonable. I believe you can also take the 'airport limousine' which is basically a bus, but there are only 3 pick ups/day.The hotel is located right next to the Tameike-Sanno Subway station (Follow signs for Exit 13 when you arrive at the station which is a walk from the turnstiles, but all underground)All in all, it's a great choice for Tokyo.

As previous reviewers have stated, the ANA Intercontinental is a very good business hotel with impeccably clean and well equipped rooms as well as efficient and polite service. The location is central, and transfer to and from major transportation hubs (plus both international airports) is exemplary. From check-in to check-out everything runs like a well oiled and efficient machine. This level of service, hardware and location does come at a very steep price, though. Overall, there is nothing 'wrong' with staying at the ANA Intercontinental. Nevertheless, if given the personal choice (I was booked in for a corporate function) I would not come back to this hotel since it simply is nothing more (and less) than a big, impersonal business hotel. Don't get me wrong here: ANA Intercontinental is doing everything one usually expects from a 4-5 star business hotel predictably right; but nothing really strikes as impressively "above expectations" in terms of attention to detail and customer service. Frankly, when demanding the prices the ANA Intercontinental does, it is not enough in my opinion to just do things in a correct and efficient way. At this price level one simply comes to expect a true luxury hotel experience, which goes beyond being merely efficient and business minded. This ultimately includes making every guest feel not only welcome, but treated with utmost attention to detail and a very highly customized approach to service - a friendly smile here and there also does help a bit. ANA Intercontinental unfortunately falls quite short on this account , and thus does not register in my book as a true luxury hotel. If you choose to stay here, you will certainly not regret it, but you most likely will forget your stay the moment you walk out the lobby doors. What a pitty.

What you should expect from a well run business hotel. Well located on the Ginza line, staff helpful but not friendly as a whole. King club room was on the small side with bathroom door next tobed which created unconfortable situations in the middle of the night. Stuffy corridors and air con system not really performing. Electricity saving? Club lounge was busy but good breakfast and lovely cocktail hour. ATM located on 2nd floor next to registration. Cafe serves reasonably priced food for such an hotel. Finally i cannot agree more on the room furniture.. Really uncomfortable ( the couch was painful, the bed was slightly tilting ( too much use?)A great tip to share: if you travel with more luggage than you should ( like us...). Use the courrier system offered by most hotels.. You send your luggage ahead of time ( the day before ) checking out and it will be waiting for you at your next hotel. All this for a really reasonable fee. Try it, it will transform your experience of travelling by train in japan.

Excellent stay overall. We stayed in a King Club room - well-appointed large-ish room, v large bed, decent bathroom, quality breakfast (lots of choice) and evening drinks/canapes included in room rate helped make the stay much more enjoyable.Staff were all extremely courteous and super helpful - as you'd expect in Japan really but still worth mentioning - anyone visiting for the first time cannot fail to be impressed with the level and quality of service.Centrally located, close to several metro lines - it is a five to ten minute walk to Tameikesanno & Kokkaigijidomae station platforms but once you've travelled on the metro for a couple of days you'll realise these lengths of walks are fairly common to enter/exit most stations - especially if you're transferring lines.Well worth the extra rate to ensure the extra level of quality!

Everything you'd expect out of an Intercontinental Hotel. Nice and modern good quality rooms of a decent size and matching a good 4 or standard 5 star hotel. Location is also great, being a short walk to 4 metro lines and around 10-15 minutes walk to great bars and restaurants of Roppongi. The main downside is the pool charges, per visit being 2,000 YEN or around US$25. That's per visit to the pool and then you have to pay for deck chairs, around 1,000 YEN per hour. I've stayed at plenty of good hotels and never found anything like this. They do however have free cable internet but no wifi.

"Average for Intercontinental" should be interpreted to mean "everything you need for a comfortable and convenient hotel for business." In other words, the hotel did not blow me away, but I had a good stay. A few notes:1. The bathroom in my room was a bit cramped. I had a fairly reasonable sized King, but the bathroom was just too small. Plus, no mirror directly in front of the sink and instead a window into the bedroom. I would have preferred a mirror.2. The restaurants are expensive - there are several restaurants, which provide a lot of options if you want to stay in the hotel, but I have at least one bill that I am not going to submit for reimbursement, the meal was just too much.3. The hotel has a gym, but charges 1,500 JPY for use. When I went to the gym, they did not charge me - not sure if that is standard practice or not.Despite some of my critiques, I would definitely return to this hotel, but I would probably look at some other similarly priced options as well.
user_name:
Kevin W
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Lots of good things to say about this hotel. Fast, efficient, and courteous check-in. Excellent & huge breakfast buffet in the 2nd floor restaurant (complimentary in my case). A clean, elegant, well-furnished room with everything I needed - not large, but perfectly adequate. Free Internet access in the room. Plenty of in-house dining options (including a restaurant with 2 Michelin stars) - none of which I tried.Having said all that, it's one of those upscale business hotels that you'll probably forget the minute you leave. Not because it does anything badly; it just does nothing spectacularly well. Who cares? It does what it's supposed to do - expensively and predictably.

Background: 2-night stay at the Classic Queen bedroom.Room is dated. Service is good but kind of expected in Japan. This hotel needs to undergo major renovation to stay on top of the game. Certainly not value for money. Good thing Airport Limousine to Narita departs from here. Nearby subway is a labyrinth of tunnels and quite a walk underground to reach the station proper like Ginza line and Chiyoda line.

While our initial impression of the hotel was that it wasn't as luxurious as what we've come to expect from other InterContinental hotels, we left very happy with the hotel thanks to the excellent service. The rooms aren't particularly spacious (a vast different from my experience in the one in Bangkok!), the bed was very comfortable and it had all of the comforts and conveniences we needed. Overall, everything felt like it was a high-end 4-star hotel - so still good but not necessarily what I'd expect from a luxurious 5-star.However, the day after we arrived, the 8.9 magnitude earthquake hit northern Japan and as Tokyo felt the effects (as did we while walking down a street and watching buildings shake like leaves in the wind, in fact!) and it was really after this experience that the hotel showed its mettle as a great establishment. While pretty much all of the people we encountered during that difficult time were kind, polite, calm, courageous and just so incredibly civilised even while their country was going through a tragic disaster, the staff of the hotel were all those things and just went above and beyond what we expected. As we returned that first evening after the quake, the lobby and taxi queue were bursting at the seams with stranded guests and what I can only assume were other people who had found their way in (the whole city was stranded with public transport cut off and traffic completely chockablock). The hotel staff were calm, efficient, helpful, and really made great efforts to make sure absolutely everyone was being tended to, both in the rooms and the lobby and beyond. Water was handed out to people for the next several days and other small comforts were a very thoughtful touch.While we woke up to the sound of the building eerily creaking as it swayed slightly during the strong aftershocks, and there were a couple of cracks in the wall (and a small one on our room ceiling) the building had strong foundations and the hotel only had very minor damaged. We felt very safe there despite the uncertainty of what might strike next. Room service was as speedy as they could have been under the circumstances and adequately tasty. Mostly though, it's the concierge that would have us coming back here. Extremely helpful and patient, all of the concierge staff we encountered were exceptional, both before and after the major quake hit, impressing us in both an ordinary and an emergency circumstance. Location wise, with a city like Tokyo it's not easy to say what's plainly good and bad since it really depends on your tastes and what kind of area you'd like to stay near but if you're looking for something near Roppongi and/or Ginza, this is in a great location and within easy walking distance of a lot of spots. There's also nearby subway stations so even if you do want to go further around the city, it is an extremely well-located hotel that's convenient for getting around and seeing the city. While I'd like to 'shop around' for other places to stay next time I'm in Tokyo and just experience some other places as well, I would be happy to stay here again. The hotel itself was nice and nothing to complain about, it just wasn't anything special to us - the concierge, however, was and if I ever stay here again that'll be what I'm looking forward to again most!

One of the best hotels we've ever been to! When we got to our room, we were virtually speachless. Great room, superb bathroom, fantastic service, great location (after short recognizing walk you can find easy access to 4 subway stations). And the views... I know the views are maybe not so important in a hotel. BUT THIS VIEW!!!Hotel is dirty expensive, but so are all the good Tokio hotels.The only downside: the hotel website (and Google Maps to be honest) is not very good location advisor, especially when it comes to nearest subay station. The thing is that Tokyo sybway system is quite complicated, and sometimes it's quite a long walk from the entrance to the subway system from the street to the actual train. So if you're taking only DISTANCE under consideration the nearest station is Roppongi Itochme. But the nearest ENTRANCE to the subway system is for Tameike Sanno / Akasaka. Also - Tameike Sanno is much better connected if you want to hit the center.

My husband and I stayed in this hotel in November 2010. It was such a delightful experience. The staff is very helpful. Food is fantastic, there's a large range to choose from. Rooms are extra ordinary-lovely location. We enjoyed the stay to the fullest.

5 star, impersonal and huge hotel. Good location for Tokyo Metro and access to central Tokyo. Everything was fine and the hotel runs like clockwork. However if you are looking for a warm welcome and personal service, this is not the place to stay. As a luxury business hotel in Tokyo, it works well. Very clean rooms (as always in Japan). Check in and check out were efficient but not friendly at all and we did not feel at all welcome! Room size was standard and the view fantastic. Our room was very quiet and we slept well. On our visit the swimming pool was closed and no explanation given. We guessed that it may be a power-saving measure afer the earthquake.We recommend the 36/F from 5pm for happy hour overlooking the city and watching the transformation from day to night, but be aware you may need to book for this. We also recommend a restaurant in the adjoining building for French bistro style food, called Aux Baccanales.

Not quite sure why so many give this such a high rating. It is an average hotel in a good location. Try taking an early morning walk up and over the hill at the back and find somewhere for breakfast instead of dining in.

While this hotel is situated in a great location, near the metro, a renovation is in order with furniture and bathroom showing wear and tear. This hotel is not up to typical Intercontinental standards. For those worried about cleanliness, rooms are capetted and beds have bedskirts (isn't it time this changed!).

It´s all about the staff and location at this place.The check-in attendance is quick and easy going.And within 3 subways stations, surrounded by offices building complex, concert hall, shops, cafes and the roppongi street passing just in front of it, the locations is really unbeatable. No chance for Westin or Four Season at Chinzan so.It´s all there for you, if you don´t mind staying in a tiny room, with shower over the tub, old cheap furniture and a very dated facade.Japanese channels work so good in HDTV as international channels are a shame. Poor quality images with noisy sound.Cascade cafe has the expensive menu I´ve ever seen in Japan. 2,000 yen for a pasta that outside hotel wouldn´t reach 900 yen. Flavorless. Water at 900 yen...have no word to describe my staying.Next time I will not considerate these reviews stricktly.

Great hotel, perfect for our family of six with kids ages 9-16. Did the prepay rate, went cheap and got two connecting rooms with a rollaway in each room. Loved the location, it's near a major subway hub so easy to get everywhere. Ginza line (yellow) is the closest, but two other lines inside the station as well, so easy to get all around Tokyo. Went cheap on the vacation, took subway rather than cabs mostly, and ate outside the hotel (Starbucks at the Ark mall next door for breakfast (most places don't open until 11am, but Starbucks is open early), and various places around Tokyo near tourist attractions for lunch. Excellent dinner restaurant recommendations from the concierge (I really liked Ten - location a bit difficult to find on a side street across from a 7-11 store so get directions and map from concierge. Food and service at Ten were great. Husband said the house specialty fish (toga?) was the best fish he'd ever eaten. Despite going on the cheap, always fantastic service at ANA Intercontinental - when I asked someone by the front desk where I could eat cheaply outside the hotel with the four kids, someone more senior talking to him (hotel manager maybe?) helped me and personally escorted me to concierge and explained to her what I needed. That's pretty amazing service.Not much trace of earthquake problems while in Tokyo plus 1 day in Kyoto. The 6.0 off the coast while we were there felt like a 3 or 4 in the hotel room - which is pretty routine for us since we live in Southern California - it's noticeable but not scary - not a big deal. No power outs, everything open mostly - only thing we couldn't see was Disney Sea, Tokyo Anime center which was under routine renovation, and Edo Tokyo museum (closed on a Sat when we dropped by - don't know the cause). Carry some good walking shoes - Tokyo is a blast.
Just perfect!Service, quality and best Club Lounge I have ever been.

This Hotel has been a great choice, I am going to Japan quite often but this so far between all the 4 stars I've been was the best. The price ws good, the room where I was staying was absolutely gorgeous and I really have to recommend the French Restaurant at top Floor and the Meat Restaurant at the floor below that, very expensive both but worth. The location of the hotel is also very good as is Roppongi, the best place for foreign people in Tokyo, may bars, clubs, ...Anyway I would definitely recommend this hotel!!! *****

Stayed at the hotel on the day an earthquake struck Tokyo, not a stay to enjoy but I would like to comment on the exceptional levels of service on offer from the staff. The lifts were out and there was a lot of hanging around in the lobby waiting for them to get the all clear. The staff were distributing blankets and water and offering guidance and assistance to anyone who needed it, there was a whiteboard set ip in the lobby updated with details about transport options. Really I can't commend the staff enough. The room, once I got in to it was nice enough and the real boon was that the internet was still running and lighting fast at that, as were the land lines. There were slight tears in the wallpaper and the room groaned and creaked most of the night. Checked out the next day and was grateful to be able to head home.
