I'll look forward to visiting this hotel again in better times, if they can cope this well under trying circumstances they'd be a good bet any other time.

At first this looks like any other 5-star but the quality of service made this somewhere really special. As soon as we found out we were grounded by the ash cloud, we asked about staying on. We were offered a good rate (better than most online rates), told we could have a room for the three weeks we might have to stay but that we could cancel at any time and the staff in the Club room called the airline daily, even though they were kept on hold for over an hour, until we got a flight home. We were in the Club section which had wonderful food and a beautiful view.Airport buses go direct to this hotel.

When we arrived at the hotel they offered us an upgrade to a Club room for a reduce rate. It was definitely worth it as it included, breakfast and 2 hour evening cocktail. There is a few negatives about this hotel, firstly when you walked into the Lobby you are hit with a smell of smoke and secondly the lay out of the entrances. The location is great, close to 4 major subway lines. Overall its a great hotel and would stay in this hotel again.

Stayed here for the second year running and really enjoyed it despite not being a fan of the Roppongi location (I realise I may be in the majority here re Roppongi). We stayed in a suite which afforded us lots of room. Staff were great. We had a minor issue with our room and they insisted on moving us. Not something I was after but they were very concerned that our stay was enjoyable. Definitely recommend if you need/ want to stay in Roppongi.

A great hotel that exceeded our expectations for a short stay in Tokyo - large rooms, particularly for Tokyo, which had been refurbished (though the bathrooms were still in need of a makeover). We had a fabulous view of Tokyo Tower from our room. The hotel was well located less than a 10 minute walk to Roppongi, which had excellent options for dining, nightlife and shopping, and the hotel was also close to a number of subway stations for accessing all areas of the city.The airport bus was an added bonus, stopping right at the hotel and getting us to the airport in just a little over an hour without the need to lug our luggage through subway stations.Would definitely stay here on a return visit to Tokyo.

The hotel staff were helpful and friendly from the moment I stepped inside the front doors. I am a Priority Club gold member so I might have been granted a better room than the standard ones. My room was spacious, clean, quiet and very nice. Only one practical thing to complain about is the doors for the wardrobe - when open they blocked the entrance door. Room was clean and nice - and cleaned every day. The staff paid attention to details and made sure small things were fixed in the room (new toothbrush, towels, slippers, tea etc) whenever needed. Hotel is close to the metro where 3 of the lines passes by. Easy to get around. Always taxis available outside. Several restaurants at the hotel - not cheap but good food. The buffet restaurant serves breakfast, lunch and dinner (all you can eat) and food quality is very good. Supermarket and small convenient stores in walking distance. Also many other restaurants around - and Roppongi area is close. Fitness facilities are pretty good for a hotel but very crowded between 6.30-8.00 am. Unfortunately no WLan in the room - but internet via cable worked fine. For me internet was included in rate but price is around 1500 Yen for 24 hours. Pretty big mini-bar which left some space for me to store some own food too. I stayed 2 weeks at this hotel - and would not mind staying longer.

Stayed here in early 2011 for business. The hotel itself if very high quality, near two metro stations, great room and bed, quiet, etc., but it has set itself apart with the quality of service for a business traveler. First, the in-room internet connection is blazingly fast. Compared to the typical hotel internet connection in the US or Europe, this was amazing. Second, I forgot my Japanese-translated business cards and the business center was able to print some very nice quality translated business cards for me in-house in a matter of 3 hours. Third, the business center was also very helpful with FedEx packages and printing. Overall, this was one of the best hotel experiences I've had in quite a while.

We stayed here for 4 nights and really enjoyed our stay.ANA is located near Roppongi. Although not much around, it is walking distance to Roppongi, a starbucks across the road and a 7-eleven nearby. We chose this hotel for the room size as we heard that many of the central hotels had tiny rooms. ANA had generous room size, excellent service from all staff and an amazing buffet breakfast.It has a direct shuttle bus to and from Narita airport which is probably the most convenient way to ge to the hotel. Its fair distance so wouldn't receommend a taxi. The shuttle train will take you direct to Tokyo central. If you're not use the subway system and have a few bags, I would recommend for you to take the bus. Journey to the hotel took us 2 hours (due to traffic) but only 1 hour on the way back. The staff were great and friendly and always willing to help. We would stay here again.A Metro stop is located just outside the hotel so you can pretty much get anyway. Make sure you are wearign comfortable shoes/trainers as expect to do a lot of walking to get to your platform for the train. Although the subway entrance may be close, you may have to walk up to 1km to your platform. Those not use to the Japanese culture - be prepared that most locals do not speak English and NOTHING is written in English. Yes the subways but don't expect taxi drivers and shop keepers to. When buying things from 7-eleven, all packaging is in Japanese so hopefully you don't have any allergies as you won't know what is in the food. Overall, a great place to visit.

We stayed at the ANA Intercontinental Tokyo for 3 nights in December and it was great. We stayed in a King Club room, which was huge. The rooms are modern and nicely decorated and the bathrooms are wonderful - best shower in any hotel! The King Club room also included access to the lounge, offering breakfast, drinks and snacks all day. There is a cocktail hour from 5.30pm - 7.30pm which was really good value, considering the price of food and drink in Tokyo. Although the food isn't great, the drinks are extensive and is a great place for a few quiet drinks before heading out to dinner.The hotel isn't really near any of the "busier" areas like Shinjuku and Harajuku, but it's only a 10 minute walk to the main street of Roppongi with all the restaurants and nightlife. The hotel has a number of restaurants and bars, but we didn't try any of these - there are far too many great local restaurants with the best sushi and tempura to spend sitting in a hotel!The ANA Intercontinental is a fantastic hotel and all taxi drivers know it as a landmark, which is very helpful when you have no language skills! Also be mindful that Narita Airport is extremely far away from the city, so when leaving for your flight out of Tokyo, allow at least 3 hours prior to your departure - regardless of whether you take a bus or the N'Ex rail system. The subway takes almost 90 minutes from Tokyo station (which is approx 10 minute taxi ride from the ANA Intercontinental), and the Airport Limousine Bus Terminal is at least 1 hour 20 minutes (and 20 minutes taxi ride from the ANA).Tokyo is a great city and the ANA Intercontinental is a fantastic place to stay!

My husband and myself have been twice in this hotel during our stay in Japan. First time 4 nights and the second one only a night (this month of November). In both occassions we received a room on the 27th floor (2707 and 2710) with impressive views to the city and to Tokyo tower. The ANA IC is ideally locqated, with various metro stations giving access to the main metro lines at walking distance. It is a 15 minute walk to Roppongi, with all its restaurants and entertainment.Upon arriving in Narita, we took the aiport limousine bus, which has the ANA IC as first stop. The rooms are of a decent size, spotless clean, with a very good bed. Bathroom is a bit on the small side. A large flatscreen TV with a decent offer of foreign channels. We had free WIFI, and even if you can catch the IC WIFI, there are numerous other free WIFI channels of nearby restaurants that you can catch at the ANA IC. We did not have breakfast nor lunch at the hotel (prices are indeed steep), but there are plenty of coffee bars and restaurants nearby with reasonable prices. At night, we recommend to have a pre-dinner cocktail at the bar on the 35ft floor, which offers great viewsWe would definately recommend the ANA IC, and will not hesitate to return.

I was booked into this hotel as a good choice for a first-time westerner in Japan. It is conveniently located near two metro stations. I got a bus directly from the airport. I loved it, but my Japanese colleagues turned their noses up (only partly in jest), and insist I should stay somewhere else next time. What do I know?...I found nothing to complain about in the hotel. A westerner would feel quite at home here. The rooms were small, but not uncomfortably so. I slept well, and the food was very good. The loaction, in Akasaki (I think), means you are close to a huge selection of restaurants, so eating out is not a problem. I found Japanese food to be of a uniformly high standard, and very, very appealing. I would have no problem returning here, nor in recommending it to others.

Every year, I stay one week in Tokyo for business. I have been staying in several hotels, but the last few years, I kept returning to the ANA, now an Intercontinental.The rooms are newly renovated, not big, but just right. I prefer a room direction Okura Hotel, because there it is quiet.The service is very nice, the restaurants excellent, there is now even a 3 star Michelin chef. The restaurants are expensive though, but if you prefer it cheaper, easy to find quite a selection of restaurants near by, for example up at Roppongi Hill, there where the Grand Hyatt is standing.I am already looking forward to my next visit to this hotel next year.

The room was very nice and clean. The general finish of the building is good and you can find a lot of different restaurants (expensive but quality). The staff is welcoming.We had breakfast included, we enjoyed it a lot by the choice you're proposed and the tastes.

The Ana Intercontinental Tokyo keeps with in line with the Intercontinental chain of hotels worldwide. For a non-Japanese-speaking business traveller landing in Tokyo it was a huge relief to me to have all the staff be able to converse in English. It is a pricey hotel, but it's the service you're paying for. Concierge was very helpful and accommodating. For example, they helped me locate a local tailor to fix my pant hems, recommended sightseeing day trips and even called specific stores to find out hours of operation for me. The rooms are sizeable for Tokyo standards, and up-to-date, clean and most importantly quiet! A surprise for me was the lack of wireless internet. It's all ethernet cables here. There are several restaurants on-site, but these are quite pricey and in my opinion not worth the extra dollars. Tokyo has plenty of fantastic restaurants of all cuisines, it just takes a venture outside. Hotel is off the Roppongi strip (about a 10-15 min. walk) which I actually prefer, but right beside Ark Hills. Ark Hills is a residential / office complex which also has several restaurants and a foreign supermarket. I particularly enjoy going to Andersens for breakfast whenever I'm there. Supermarket was convenient for water, juice, fruits, etc. The hotel has a fitness room, but it's small and could use better upkeep. There is a pool but it's only open during the summer.
user_name:
Alee75
New York City, New York

review_body: ANA Intercontinental is very ideally situated near Roppongi, which is the 'happening' place in Tokyo. It has spacious rooms, excellent restaurants and very courteous staff.

I stayed in room 3315 for 4 nights in October 2010 on business. Overall, I liked (most) of the service, but the room was a mixture of good and bad. If other rooms are of higher quality, I would recommend the property. Regrettably, I don't know, therefore I cannot give a full-fledged recommendation. As usual, The Good, The Not-so-Good, and the BadThe Good1. Check-in process. Fast, very welcoming, informative and professional. What you would expect from a nice property.2. Bed comfort. King size, firm, selection of pillows (be sure to pull the one out from the closet).3. Room size. I stayed on the Club Level, and found the room to be of nice size, even more so because being in Tokyo. Not huge for 1 person, but large enough that I was very comfortable. Had embedded desk, embedded couch, good size closet, safe, clothes drawers, mini-bar...4. Room lighting options. Lovely control panel next to bed that allowed me to control lighting throughout room, establish alarm clock, open/close window shades, etc. And it was simple to use. Well done.5. Laundry/shoe shine service. On time and well done. Had early flight out and asked that my shoes be back at 06:30. I think my watch said 06:30:10 and my doorbell rang. Excellent.6. Bus service to-from NRT. While I assume this is not owned by ANA Intercontinental, they allowed for me to place return trip on room bill which I greatly appreciated.7. The gym. Decent size. Equipment in good shape, both cardio and weights. Open 24 hours.8. Level 35 - The International Club. Offered as a room upgrade and was basically a half-floor utilized as a breakfast/relaxation room with nice views. Room had a wide assortment of chairs, couches, tables, etc. where you could both work and relax. Nice touch with massage chairs. Breakfast offerings were limited but fine. In evening, had wine, beer, etc.The Not-so-Good1. Very musty/mold like smell in my bathroom. I noticed immediately upon entering the room. I had to keep the door closed, and make no mistake - it was each day. Did I complain? No - because I typically vote with my wallet, but it's regrettable the housekeeping staff could not realize the unpleasant odor and either fix the issue or alert management.2. Late one evening my 3 colleagues and I went to the bar on the 37thish floor. It was fairly quiet so we grabbed a table along the windows, only to have an employee inform us there was a 1000 Yen table charge. I laughed and we left. I understand table charges are common in Tokyo. But, we are all on the Club Level, we're all Priority Club members and likely to have a few rounds. They lost business that night and potentially more to come. I informed the employee what I thought but received no solution. It was not the amount (which was reasonable), but the principle that we were hotel guests - and premium ones at that.The Bad1. Housekeeping Training Program. Undoubtedly, if the housekeeping staff had been trained properly, they would have alerted their bosses of the musty smell of my bathroom. Cleanliness scores "poor" because of the consistent must bathroom odor. I do not highly recommend this property - unless the smell in my room is an anomaly.

This large hotel adheres to the Japanese concept of continuous improvement: its front desk became more adept at handling foreign customers and their habits after joining the Intercontinental chain years ago, staff became more cheerful, and now its club lounge became one of the larger and better ones in a city where lounges are often less spectacular than elsewhere in Asia.The rooms are functional and comfortable, but in standard form can feel slightly cramped. Budget allowing, it might be worth paying for higher level rooms with such included extras as free internet and lounge access, and standalone shower stall.The hotel's location is 'central', with a few subway lines nearby but no JR train lines within walking distance. There are plenty of eateries nearby.A special mention for the quality of the IC Ambassador fruit plate, which in the fall includes high-grade local grapes. Delicious!

Located near a supermarket and a few cafes. The hotel restaurant for breakfast was over priced and impossible to get coffeee refilled, but the rest of the experience was very positive. The concierge and tourist desk were very helpful though the map I was given was quite old without some landmarks

My wife and I stayed here for 8 nights in October. The room was quite small, but very clean, fairly comfortable and pleasant. The bed was a little hard and the overall space was tight, but this is Tokyo, so I was not surprised. We were in Tokyo for food, art and relaxation. This hotel is very well set up for business travellers and I could see giving it higher ratings and a more glowing review if the hotel were more fun or my trip purpose were more business oriented. We received an upgrade to club level, which I would always recommend at Intercons that offer it for the great added service, snacks, drinks etc. The club is comfortable and quite business like, but you won't feel out of place in casual attire. Service, as you would expect, from front desk to housekeeping, to restaurants is very formal, polite and deferential, if a little cool and robotic. One night after an exhausting day, we decided to "grab a quick late bite" at the main restaurant, Cascade. This turned into a torture fest of waiting until our mediocre and astronomically priced food arrived. Location is good, not great. It is very close to Roppongi-ichitome station and a pleasant walk to bustling Roppongi crossing and Roppongu Hills complex. Take a minute to stroll the hidden little terraced Ark Gardens on the hillside behind the hotel. The quiet, embassy neighborhood between the hotel and the Tokyo Tower also contained small cafes and bakeries worth exploring. We had a few drinks at the new Mixx bar on the 36th floor, which is trying like hell to be hip and cool by having a cadre of bumbling, Euro-trendy bartenders doing a clown-car impression at making pseudo-molecular $28 martinis. Fun for a quick visit, but if you are used to no smoking in bars (we are), the heavily smoking Asian and Euro customers will drive you out pretty quick. Awesome view, though! Overall, very good, not great. Certainly not a destination or resort oriented hotel, but highly recommend for business or no nonsense high-end accomodations in Tokyo.

The primary reason for choosing this hotel was that our office was practically next-door. That apart there was little otherwise to do or see in the vicinity (except for the Tokyo tower, to which a nice evening/night is surely worth). After office-hours the area becomes increasingly desolate and gloomy. The hotel itself is very elegant and plush (and so, expensive) and the rooms are comfortable and airy (mine offered good views of the aforesaid tower). Breakfast was not complimentary (and expensive even with our corporate offer) so we had to settle for the neighbourhood Starbucks. Didn't get to try out the restaurant, but heard that it is highly appreciated. Wasn't able to check out the other amenities as well. Internet is available for free though.

Just spent 3 nights at the ANA Intercontinental. Paid 29,500 yen a night for club level. Definitely do the club level room. Tokyo is insanely expensive. Club level comes with breakfast, cocktails and snacks and free drinks and also gives you free access to gym, pool and high speed internet. Definitely worth the extra 5,000 yen a night.The location of the ANA is good and it is a well known hotel. The Friendly Airport Limousine (Big orange bus) drops you at the hotel from Narita. This is the easiest way to get to the hotel. Each way is 3,000 yen or if you buy roundtrip at airport for 6,000 yen they give you a 2 day subway pass with it which costs 1,400 yen. Taxis are extremely expensive. Over $300 from airport to hotel. Taxis in general are expensive the flag pull is 710 yen ($9). Luckily the hotel is right next to a subway station with access to the Ginza, Namoboku and Chiyoda lines. These lines can get you all over the city. Since the hotel is in Roppongi, all the night life is a 20 minute walk or 5 minute cab ride away. Not far from Tokyo Midtown or Roppongi Hills.The hotel is a large hotel with a dozen restaurants and bars....all insanely expensive. I would go out to eat. Soo many good options in Tokyo.Hotel is decently priced compared to Mandarin Oriental, Four Seasons Marounochi, Park Hyatt, Peninsula etc. Next time I plan to try Mandarin or Four Seasons.Service at the hotel is very good. Staff is very nice and efficient. They all speak english very well. Room was cleaned in a very timely manner.The room was not large but sufficient. Bed was comfortable. However, pillows are extremely soft. Room has flat screen tv and tv in bathroom. Tub/ Shower is good with good pressure. The bathroom has an older model toto toilet. Room was clean with ample hangars. It had a remote control that controlled AC, blinds, lights etc.At night time the lounge can get very busy. We couldnt get in Saturday night because it was full. Breakfast is ok. Has eggs, sausage, bacon, dim sum, toast, croissants, fruit, juices, meats, cheeses and cereal. Its just ok, nothing spectacular. Overall, good hotel and would stay here again. No real complaints. A note, the manager credited my last night for not being able to use lounge. Only charged me for a regular room.
user_name:
Paul R
New York City, New York

review_body: Hotel though met our needs to be closer to office, it turns out to be expensive when you add up the additional costs. you end up paying additional for Gym and pool separately. expensive breakfast buffet. They offer a direct line phone in room, but you got to pay additional for the phone equipment if need to use direct line.it would have been better for us to be in apartment hotel.

Travelled with 5 yr old and 17 months old this September for 5 days. Location I must say is prime. Right next to 2 subway stations one of which is a crossline of 3 subway lines that will take you pretty much anywhere in the city. Grocerty store, coffee shops, bakery, restaurants are all right next to the hotel and 5-10 minute taxi ride to Roppongi Hills. Friendly and helpful staff, but would improve housekeeping. Our kids may have made too much mess for them but we've seen better housekeeping. Downside is as with any other hotel in Tokyo, rooms are rather small for a family with kids (for that price). We stayed in "deluxe" room but not at all deluxe in size. Tiny bathroom and pretty much no extra space for kids to run around. We will definitely consider this hotel if we ever travel to Tokyo in the future but will be smarter next time and reserve a bigger room. I would definitely recommend this hotel for business travellers though.

I generally stay in the ANA when I visit Tokyo on Business, and like all other Japanese hotels I have stayed in I do find the service fantastic. The rooms are a little small, but well appointed since they refurbished recently. The restaurants are very good (although a little pricey, I would probably go up the road for a ramen instead). The gym is also large and fully stocked. Value wise probably the best in the Akasaka/Ropongi area, and I have stayed at a few of them.

This is an alright hotel but having stayed at numerous Intercontinental Hotels worldwide, I expected a little more. Exactly what, I'm not real sure but there is normally something about this chain that you expect - that certain Intercon approach - I just didn't feel it here. The rooms (we had to change midway through our stay as there was a leaking issue in the room) were adequate....a lot smaller than I expected (and I expected the worse in Tokyo). Location is a bit far from places but only a 10 minute walk to Roppongi. For the money we paid, I would say it was average.

Service at this hotel was lazy starting from the front bell staff that didn't consider helping me with anything...was this because I was a woman travelling alone? I suspect so. Check in was also slow and incorrect for me considering I have an Ambassador Club membership and platinium level loyalty points with Priority Club. At the buffet dinner which cost more than $100 USD the staff allowed me to stand waiting at the stand for at least 15 minutes when they were not even very busy, just didn't see me, or were thinking I was waiting for a man? Once they finally acknowledge me, and seated me I discovered that most of the buffet food dishes were completely empty at around 6:30pm. I managed to get a piece of meat and a meager scrap of salad and drink service was painfully slow and this was in no way sufficient. The room was fine, and I left quickly in the morning not wishing to over pay to be ignored for a breakfast seating.

I've stayed here 4 times now during 2010, totalling around 6 weeks. I have had a very pleasant stay each time and enjoy the views of Roppongi and also the Tokyo tower. I would definitely recommend this hotel. My only complaint so far would be that the 36th floor bar has been made even more expensive since the recent renovation.

I travel to Tokyo about 6 times a year and I always stay here. I've stayed at the New Otani (old and run down if you're in the tower), the Imperial (old and run down - period), and the Hyatt in Shinjuku (nice but to far from my office). There are other hotels nearby that are nicer but for the money the ANA is quite nice and sufficient.Location gets a "B": The ANA is the first stop on the Limousine Bus which is great after a long flight however it's still about a 20 min taxi ride from Tokyo Station. Also it's a 15 minute walk to Rippongi which isn't bad but it's also a bit of a walk to the subway system. Overall the location isn't poor by any means but just keep in mind that you'll need to walk a little.Rooms are a "B": Small by American standards, large by European and Japanese standards. Well maintained and clean. Nothing extraordinary but adequate. Rooms all have high speed wireless internet and flat screen TV's. Television is mostly Japanese although you'll get CNN and occasionally Fox depending on time of day. Also CNBC is available in English when the American markets are open but other than that no other English TV.Service get's a "A": This is Japan. Expect to get great service by western standards. The staff at the ANA are excellent, professional, and always available. Frankly if you've not been to Japan you'll be shocked at the focus the Japanese people place on service. Why can't all countries be like this!!!Gym Facilities get a B+/A-: The gym is well kept, clean, and the equipment is in good working order. Gyms in Japan frequently are built for Japanese clientele and this means really "spa's" so a Western Style gym is a treat. The facilities are small but house 4 treadmills, 3 elipticals, 3 stationary bikes, a multi-function weight systems and two racks of dumbbells. Also a small area for stretching is available. They also have an outdoor pool but I've not used or seen it.Restaurants get a B: The lobby restaurant usually is buffet style for all meals and the food selection is quite good. The problem is the food here is quite pricey. Frankly I find myself visiting the market to keep my costs down. Breakfast will run you 3000 yen ($35). Lunch and Dinner are more. The hotel also has a few other restaurants - a steak house, a french restaurant, and an Italian restaurant. All VERY pricey. Sky Avenue on the top of the hotel is a great place for evening drinks and to look over the city. Again, drink prices are pretty steep but the view and the decor make it worth the visit at least once while you're in the hotel. The lounge in the hotel lobby is very comfortable and again nice decor, friendly staff, spaciousness, and overall ambience make it a good place for early evening drinks or a place to catch up after a long day.Overall this is a solid B hotel and relative to prices in Japan a reasonable value.

We booked our stay at the ANA Intercontinental Tokyo using my husband's Ambassador membership. There was a separate desk for Ambassador members' check-in and three officers, very charming and accommodating ladies, Junko, Phoebe and Satomi, personally attended to us and escorted us to our room. We had asked for adjoining rooms but since there were none available, Junko upgraded us to a Japanese suite which was around 40 square meters, gigantic for Tokyo standards, and featured 2 double beds with 2 twin beds that were pulled down from the wall, a central living area covered in tatami mats and a luxurious toilet and bath. The size of the suite was perfect for us as we had our two children with us. It was immaculately clean and kept so during our entire 8-day stay by an army of Japanese grandmothers who were very friendly despite the language barrier. As Ambassador members, we were entitled to free cocktails at the club lounge on the 35th floor which had a beautiful view of Tokyo and the food and cocktails were delicious. On the 37th floor was a teppanyaki grill where we had Kobe steaks that simply melted in our mouths. After dinner we would go to the bar on the 36th floor where I enjoyed delicious Moet cocktails along with the dazzling Tokyo skyline. We also went to the Tsukiji fish market and sampled superbly fresh sushi at the outer market.

It is what it says on the tin: a large 5-star hotel in a major city. This hotel is a true 5-star though, it is very elegant, but not intimate. Staff is extremely helpful and nothing appears to be a bother. Our Junior suite was immaculate, contemporary, as sizeable as other Junior suites in other large hotels had two flat screen televisions, blue ray player, iPod docking station and was extra clean. The large bathroom with separate shower featured Shiseido and L’Occitane products. The suite exceeded our expectation.Club Intercontinental on the 35th floor serves Roederer champagne, other fine wines and a good selection of snacks. the club breakfast, billed as “continental”, is more than sufficient. On offer is the usual breakfast fare plus noodles, fried eggs and freshly squeezed orange juice. After a busy day sightseeing the extraordinary massage chairs were a welcome surprise in a hidden club lounge corner.The well managed staff handled even checkout queues effective, efficient with grace, a bow and a smile.Only gripe is that the bedding seems to contain some man-made fibre, which I personally do not like and it caused me to sleep poorly.

Stayed on the 34th floor in a Club Intercontinental room, woke up by pressing a button to open the curtains and looked out at the snowy skyline of Tokyo. Service was excellent and the room was beautiful! Highly highly reccomend, have an amazing time guys!! Happy to answer any questions.

Room was small but perfectly pleasant and we didn't spend much time in it anyway. Definitely recommend Club Intercontinental - wifi, breakfast, drinks & canapes all included in the room rate. I'm not a massive fan of Roppongi but it will suit most foreign visitors and there is great shopping, food, nightlife, etc nearby.

There are plenty of other luxury properties in Tokyo to choose (Ritz Carlton, Peninsula, Four Seasons, Shangri-la, etc) to experience a luxury services.I specific choosed this property for a few simple reasons :- Need to use my free overnight voucher- My Gold Ambassador status benefits- The new club lounge- Will be out of the hotel most of the time (so why spend money for luxury hotel - which the services & facilities i would not use :)I booked 3 Nights stay - junior suite club intercontinental.- The room is ok - 52 m2 clean, a bit old style but offer a great view.It is an open space with two large window - one in the seating area and the other in the bedroom. Welcome amenity was received - fruit plate (I was expected something morejapanese). The club lounge is clean , large and well appointed. It offers a wonderful city view.Interior - is perfect - the set up is well - BUT The offer is just standard.The breakfast at the club lounge is acceptable - standard and nothing extraordinary. - Buffet style - food selections are very limited. I take a look at their main restaurant (Cascade Cafe) - which has better food selections.(PS: Management - why can you give your club room guests an option to choose -  either to dine at your main restaurant or club lounge ? i am sure it will solve some problem from unhappy guests :)The only highlight which i found very good is the coctail hours - the canapes are well prepare - tastful BUT... very small portion. The good thing is the Champagne options (incld. rose) which is great and generous. One down part (the club lounge coctail hours only from 5:30 PM- 7:30 PM), it is too shortand when you come after that hour - they only offer tea or softdrink.I also found the club hour is too short - it is closed at 10 PM Overall stay - is ok I found this property definetly much better in compare to their other sister property (The String). - in term of value from Club room.All agents are polite and very helpful but do not expect any extra miles or wow factor.This property is great for them who need good value hotel.The club lounge is beautiful but the service and offer are just plain standard in compareto other club lounge that i have been. PS: So far...Four seasons Hong Kong - has the best club lounge - i am sure if they send their manager there - maybe they can get better prespective about a great one.. :)

Booked this as it advertised a pool and I was visiting in August..BUT..had to pay £8 per person per day to use it!! Rooms very average with cigarette burns on the table in the room which smelt of smoke despite requesting non smoking room. Internet access £12 per day even in the business centre. Staff very snobby. All in all a very poor experience suggestive of being acceptable to those who really don't care what they are spending if it is at the expense of their company

I booked a corner suite that was clean & roomy. Suprb bathroom and nice living room. very quiet. Spacious Executive Lounge with excellent breakfast. Evening drinks are Ok but canapes not suuficient to make a real dinner. However plenty of restaurants in the hotel and nearby. I would recommend the French restaurant (Pierre Gagnaire) as well as the Japanese one (Akasaka Teppanyaki). Helpful concierge and good service.

This is an excellent luxury hotel.it is axiomatic that space is at a premium in Tokyo, so although the rooms were perhaps slightly on the small side for other cities, they were still roomy enough.The hotel is in a slightly boring business area, although close to the Royal Palace and Park.We ate in the Unkai Restaurant in the Hotel and had the 'Taste of Japan' set menu. I would say this was possibly the best food I have eaten in a decade, and, whilst pricey, if you want an introduction to the many styles of Japanese cuisine this is an excellent way to do it. Absolutely wonderful.My only smallish complaint is with regard to the reception staff. Whilst they were helpful it was a bit of a struggle language wise. Even those who were designated as speaking it had quite limited english. And yes I do appreciate the fact that I don't speak a word of Japanese so what right do I have to criticise, but for an international hotel I would have expected a bit better. But it is an incredibly minor quibble.There is a lovely roof bar, with great views, but be aware as well as fairly pricey drinks, you will also enjoy a table charge.

This large and well-run hotel is located in an area with a high concentration of international financial companies, and hence restaurants and entertainment outlets catering to foreigners. The area has gone upscale with the opening of the Roppongi Hills complex harboring fancy restaurants and shops some years ago, and affluent Japanese residential neighborhoods are only a short walk away.The rooms are somewhat compact but comfortable and fairly posh.The recently renovated executive lounge is very spacious and nice, and offers above-average food.There is a subway station close to the hotel, and traffic in the area is usually not too bad, making taxi trips viable. I found the bell staff competent and very friendly.

Stayed at the ANA IC for 4 days during a business trip to Tokyo. Firstly, the bus shuttle from the airport stops at this hotel and that a major plus. Its U.S 35 per person for the 45 - 60 minute trip. On the way back to Narita, I used the Narita Express Rail link which costs a few dollars more but takes almost the same time. Would always recommend the bus since they have baggage handlers on board. I have rated the hotel high on location, room and sleep quality and service but at U.S 400, a bit expensive but not complaining considering its Tokyo. The check in was smooth and got a high floor as requested but twin instead of a Queen / King bed. The room was suitably equipped with average views overlooking the highway and the neighbouring tower office blocks. The service was impeccable. I used the priority service option several times and they never failed to impress. Usual response time was immediate or 3 minutes. No language or communication barrier either. The rooms are average size, infact roomy by Tokyo standards. Mine had free lan internet.The location is superb: The subway station is 100 meters which offers good connectivity to Shibuya, Ginza etc and the highway helps to connect to the rest of the city as well. I used the taxi several times and the flag down rate is U.S 7Used the lobby bar and cafe for drinks and breakfast and was the quality and service was good. Several other cafes, reastaurants and bars are 10 minutes walking distance and Starbucks is across the road.A great hotel and will definately stay here again or recommend it to friends.

Few words to describe the experience at the ANA I/C. Just the best!Amazing service, amazing standards, nothing was pretentious. Great location few blocks from Roppongi, near metro station.Among my top#5 hotels in the world.If you can afford it, stay there.

the hotel not at all child friendly, they didnt give extra bed for my third child, the hotel staff dosent speak any english at all, so if you want to order any room service forget about it, you will have to take at least 15 min to explain it to them, what you need. then there is no english channels at all, so all the time i was in ana intercontinental my children were bored and without tv.... all in all very bad for people with kids

Massive hotel with large, vibrant and impressive reception lobby. Easy check in and upgraded to a club room with access to club lounge. Highly recommend doing this, we paid an extra £40 per night for both of us and this included free cocktails and canapes from 5pm until 8pm every night and a decent breakfast in the morning. As prices for alcohol in Japan (and everything else!) are expensive, having 3 hours of champagne and nibbles between 2 of us every night seemed like a bargain for £40!! Plus we got a a gorgeous room with an amazing view of Tokyo. Enough of the alcohol...the location is fine, a bit of a trek over to the west of Tokyo which is probably a more vibrant area but this area was more in the business centre and felt really safe, very smart and clean. About a 10 minute walk away was Akasaka (?) district which has loads of restaurants (mainly Japanese but some European and Asian) and a couple of good bars. Its quite a vibrant area in the evening. I would recommend this hotel, it might seem quite business like and smart for tourists but it was a lovely start to our honeymoon. There is also a roof top pool and a fitness centre - we didn't try either but they looked good.

Ideally located, access to Roppongi Hills and Shibuya a quick cab ride away. The hotel itself is nice, but located near a busy highway - can be an advantage if you need to get somewhere quick although it hinders the view a bit from the hotel rooms. World class dining/chef if that's of any interest.

Stayed in a club level room so service was excellent and the staff was extremely attentive to my needs. Had to use the hotel's laundry service to clean and press a few dress shirts. Made a phone call to the concierge desk and the butler was at my door in less than 3 mins. Shirts were returned as promised and in excellent condition.Free wired internet in the room and free wireless in the club lounge. The airport limousine bus takes you directly to and from Narita Airport with a bus stop right in the lobby of the hotel.Would definitely return to the hotel!

This is one terrific hotel. Excellent staff . Thank you . Very quiet and classy hotel. The location, and subway station just can't be beat. Very quiet rooms, many with fantastic views. Lots of restaurants of all types and price range are close by. We highly recommend this hotel.

Good hotel, very central Tokyo, near Roppongi. I have stayed here before Intercontinental bought the ANA Hotels group. Seemed to me that it used to be better (nicer) service when it was still run by ANA Hotels. Still a very decent hotel, very comfortable beds, good internet connection, and the area is great. It is practically in the center of Tokyo, with a very good japanese and french restaurant. There also is a building right next door with a Starbucks and some small restaurants. Roppongi is just a few minutes away on foot with a great deal of entertainment. A wonderful concert hall is also just next to the hotel with interesting concerts almost every day. I would stay here again.

Have stayed at this hotel many times and love it. Around Christmas its just superb. Has the feel of a quiet business oriented hotel or a fun cool place depending on your need or mood. A number of great bars and bar staff with proper bar skills...And they remember your name. Restaurants are also excellent, including a great sushi place, but be warned the sushi place does not allow you to charge to your room.Great breakfast offering really good Japanese and western choices.Newly relocated and vastly improved club lounge is one of the best I've been to, perhaps even better than the Ritz Carlton in Bahrain.The rooms are big enough, though not especially errr....roomy. But they are nicely done. Roomservice menu is a real shocker - really poor choices. Can't vouch for the quality never been tempted.This place is a gem. The staff are superb and will do anything for you, but more than anything its just got a nice atmosphere and feel about it.

Large comfortable rooms, very clean and nicely fitted out, with all the usual room amenities and toiletries. Internet is decently fast in the room. Room service food quality is average and poor value. I ordered a tonkatsu don and it didn't taste nearly as good as the average Japanese takeaway lunchbox. Staff is very attentive and polite. I did not try the restaurants at the hotel so cannot comment on that. Shuttle bus from Narita door-to-door is very convenient if you are like me who don't like dragging luggage around the subway on your own. The closest subway station has elevator going up to the subway exit so that's a plus even if you decide to take the subway/rail to/from airport.If you want to use this as a place for shopping around Tokyo, think again. By the end of the day when you are carrying handful of bags, it's tough walking 15min underground in the subway tunnels before getting back to hotel. There are a few convenience shops and one or two cafes within 10 min walk from the hotel. There is otherwise not much around the hotel other than commercial buildings. Not much choice of food within the hotel area. Felt reasonably safe at night on my own within 5 minute radius of hotel and to/from subway station. It looked a bit too quiet to wander any further for single females.

Well located for finance district and Ginza. Airport bus from Narita stop so easy access with the usual 90 minutes transfer time. Always taxis outset and taxi drivers know "ANA" when returning at end of day/evening. My room was relatively large with all needed for work and of course the futuristic toilet in the bathroom. Traffic noise noticeable even on a fairly high floor. The Teppanyaki on top floor is very good - the top price set menu (with lobster and steak) is well worth splashing out on. Shinjuku Hilton probably has the edge over this one for service and rooms.
The room was very spacious, especially if you compare to the average Japan hotel room size....Location is good, at least for us, as we mainly move around in the Roppongi & Ginza district.

- Close to the Subway station, but expect to walk at least 200 meters to get to a train!- Great Service through out. Rooms were constantly being cared for.- Awesome Lobby, 3 bars and numerous restaurants. The champagne bar was especially cool. - Hotel Restaurant has an awesome buffet. A bit pricey, but actually worth it if you skip a meal afterwards!- Good size rooms, especially for Tokyo. - Smart interior design. Great cabinets and shelfs! Smaller functional furniture to make for larger open space. Clever.- Location is great, but be ready to walk.

Stayed at ANA Intercontinental for two nights last April. Check-in took some time and my room wasn’t ready, but I understand that it was a busy time, and I was there before the check-in time anyway! The staff are extremely polite and speak very good English. Concierge was extremely helpful, gave me very good advice on what to see and how to get around. Took bus from the airport to the hotel that included a free tube day pass for only Y3100. It was more convenient that taking train which a travel companion of mine took and regretted later! It’s not at the heart of the town, but very convenient since tube station is literally next door! It’s cheaper to get the tube ticket (day pass) from the hotel than to get it from the stations, which I found rather odd but nice!Breakfast was very good, one of the best I have had, and reasonably priced considering it is Tokyo. Room was pretty big by Tokyo standard. Well appointed and very clean, too. Bathroom was nice and pretty high-tech! LOVED the Shiseido bathing products, absolutely amazing!Very good experience, will stay there again if I have the chance to visit Tokyo again.

A fanstastic comfortable hotel for business or touring Tokyo.We have stayed at this hotel twice and have had very comfortable rooms with great views. Its in a very centrtal location with easy access to the subway system and has direct bus services to and from Narita.The hotel is large and roomy with decent sized rooms for Tokyo. The room facilities are all 1st class and appreciated.On top of the 11 hotel restaurants and bars, it also features three Michelin starred Chef Pierre Gagnaire and his amazing french cuisine and the view from the restaurant has a stunning perspective over Tokyo. If thats not enough, the tower compex nect door offers many quality bar and restaurant options.The concierege team needs some work on getting instructions right, but tries hard.

The main thing stopping me from giving this hotel the full 5* rating is that, compared to other hotels of the same class in the Asia region, the service at the ANA Intercontinental was lacking. The staff were courteous and helpful when approached, but it felt as though one had to ask for assistance before we got it. For example, on arrival at the hotel we received no assistance whatsoever with our suitcases and we had to bring our own suitcases up to the main lobby on the 2nd floor and then (after checking in) up to our room. Luckily for us, we packed light and were in good spirits, so we didn't make a big deal of it. At the buffet breakfast, the staff did not clear our empty plates and dishes or refill our coffee/tea unless we asked them to do so. We had to resort to stacking the plates and placing them on the table next to ours. When we called the hotel's "Instant Service" line to make a dinner reservation at one of the hotel eateries one night , the staff always had to confirm times, info etc. before calling us back. Those were just three examples, but there were others. I had researched hotel reviews on this site before booking, and decided to go with this one when I found out that my first choice hotel (the Grand Hyatt) was full. I decided not to pay for the Club room, because I had read that the lounge benefits were not nearly as good as at other Intercontinental hotels and that the lounge had long queues at breakfast and peak times. All in all, I'm happy that I made that choice.The buffet breakfast was fine, but it would have been nice if they had varied the menu just a little bit more.The hotel had a "business" atmosphere and feel to it, so if you're looking to completely unwind this may not be the place for you. Try the Mandarin Oriental instead. We booked a deluxe room with a king sized bed overlooking the city, which was very clean and comfortable. The bathroom, while clean and new, was small. People with larger frames may find it claustrophobic. Only one person could stand comfortably at the bathroom sink at any one time. We ate only one meal at the hotel coffee shop towards the end of a (tiring) trip. The food was average and the menu was extremely limited- was expecting better food based on my experience at other Intercontinental hotels in Asia. We had wanted to try the teppanyaki at the Japanese restaurant, but couldn't get a good time slot as we left it to the last minute. Getting to the hotel from the airport is hassle-free and reasonable if you take the Airport Limousine bus. One single ticket for adults costs 3000Yen and the bus will take you directly to the G/F of the hotel.On the plus front, the hotel was well situated in the heart of Tokyo, which made it perfect for exploring the city. Roppongi is within walking distance, albeit up a gentle slope. Taking a taxi to the major crossing at Roppongi would set you back about 710 Yen (flag-fall price on the taxi meter). Tokyo Tower is about 900 Yen away by taxi. The nearest metro station is Tameike-sanno (Exit 13), which is served by the Ginza line. However, the location of the hotel means that there is an overlap between two metro stations (i.e. Tameike-sanno and Kokkai-gijidomae). This is a definite plus because it means that you will have immediate access to 4 different metro lines- the Ginza, Namboku, Chiyoda and Marunouchi lines. The walk from the hotel to Exit 13 of Tameike-sanno is 1 minute, but the walk to the actual platforms is longer and in certain cases can seem like a trek in itself. That said, once inside the metro compound, you will feel safe and be protected from the elements. If you plan on doing a lot of sightseeing and wish to hop on and off the metro, consider buying an unlimited one-day pass which costs 710 Yen for adults (or 1000 Yen if you also want to use the Toei metro lines).

Travelled on a tour of Tokyo with some family and friends, arrived on Mar. 28. The Hotel has a nice facade, location is right smack in the middle of Tokyo (good?),it's walking distance to the subway line. It has a nearby 7-11 store which is a plus since not much stores are open around the area after 8 pm. The rooms are okay but a bit old for my taste, the beds are quite small compared to other 5 star hotels, no free internet, no free computers you can use at the business center either, you'll have to fork out 600 yen for 30 minutes of use at the BC!! But the rooms are clean I'll give them that. Service is quite nice though, as all things I requested were taken care of. The breakfast could be better , as they serve the same things over and over again for 5 days!! Overall, i'll give this hotel a passing grade, but barely.

I stay here quite a lot an always end up with the same issues, even as a regular guest The check-in/out is always extremely slow, extremely manual and with no consideration for express or return guests. They also always ask me to upgrade my company booking but then inform me I would need to pay more. Then they ask if I want a smoking room even thoguh my booking is for N/SNow the 5th time in a row this little drama plays outThe only rooms available (even after booking weeks in advance with my preference) are either smoking or twin or failing that back to the old 1960's type roomsThe rooms are drab (some are new most are not) and I always seem to get the biggest but oldest room but with the tiniest TV on the other side of the room. The channels are nearly all in japanese (hello, is this an international hotel?) The occasion I did ask to be moved only had smoking rooms available.Room service is good and the restaurants are fine but expensive even for Tokyo. Laundry is also very good but roomservice often forget to provide new slips for each days laundry bagI only stay here to get the frequent flyer points for the decent hotels the chain has elsewhere around the globe.
user_name:
David B
Auckland Central, New Zealand

review_body: Lovely hotel to finish our Japan holiday in. Very comfortable, big room, great views from the room and excellent spot to have a drink at the Manhattan Bar on Level 36 (view of Mt Fuji) on western side. Only issue I would comment is the trip to airport via subway/trains was a few changes which is a bit of a drag with bags however not really worth complaining about - only comment because I think there are some hotels that are really direct. Didn't sample anything in the hotel except gym which I think my husband found to be ok. Pool was closed and only open during summer so bit disappointed about that. As mentioned bar on top level was a good place to soak up the magnitude of the city. And access to internet in the business centre was a bit rich at 550Y for 15 minutes!

I stayed here for 3 nights in March on a city break. I'm an InterContinental Gold Ambassador so booked a very good room and recieved an upgrade to a club level with access to the lounge on the 35th floor.The twin bed room was very small, even by comparison with my standard room at the Marriott last time I stayed in Tokyo. Suprising for Club Level. The lounge was nice however I did find the selection of drinks rather limited during the day-time. The cocktail hour was also rather short I thought and staff seemed quite robotic in enforcing the time restrictions when I arrived when it was closing one night, despite it being exceptionally quiet.The concierge were quite helpful and the Manhattan Bar on the 36th floor was very nice and had good views and service. The Champaigne Bar near the lobby was closed on two of the nights I was there, despite it being the weekend, but I tried it on the last night and it was enjoyable. I dined in the main restaurant one night, it was just ok, however had to send one dish back as it was undercooked and very dry, they still tried to charge however I made them remove it as it was unedible.Check-in/Check out was efficient.

We redeemed points for this stay, so I can't comment on the dollar value of this property. We stayed here for the first few days of a 13 day trip to Japan (our honeymoon), and were very satisfied. Some comments about location: its true that it is close to the subway, but only to the entrance - once you get underground, its about a 10 min walk. Also, there are a fair number of stairs to deal with if you have luggage. The room was great - very large and modern...it did not need any updating. What really impressed us was the concierge serivce. We asked about going to see a sumo practice a few days in advance - the attendant on duty prepared a reservation for us to visit a practice session, provided tips, directions (perfect), and all the necessary information. The experience of seeing sumo practice really made my trip and we appreciate the trouble they went to to ensure it was memorable for us. I would recommend this hotel to anyone visiting Japan.

I've stayed in Tokyo on a couple of occasions. Despite the efficiency and strive to perfection, I'm always aghast at the cost of basic subsistence in 5 star hotels. The ANA Intercontinental doesn't change this. Despite offering many of the usual Tokyo luxuries and efficiencies, I found it hard to justify the cost of £28 for breakfast, £36 for lunch and £60 for the basic dinner buffet, which was no more spectacular than any other 4/5star. The steakhouse charging £140 for Kobe and £80 for a normal steak seems extravagant. We opted for 10 mins walks into Akasaka, which offered plenty of choice, from excellent Korean, Thai, Indian and of-course outstanding, Sashimi and Sushi. The Laughry steakhouse across the road is better value at around £50 a steak.The gym was minimal and always full in the AM hours. I was not charged ... but some guests were!! Overall, I was not impressed with my room, the make-up service and the room service was average at best. In terms of value, enjoyment and quality of stay, I’d rate the HK and Singapore InterContinental’s above the Tokyo ANA. We has coffee in the Tokyo bay, which seemed better value

We landed on the roof of Ark Hills, next door, greeted by a team from the ANA.So they had us at hello, and a really nice room upgrade cemented the deal!Really well polished staff on every level. I can't think of anything bad to say about the place. It's a big hotel that really knows how to service it's guests. The club is especially excellent. When you stay up in the club level you feel like you're staying in a really nice smaller hotel.Breakfast and all food in the club outstanding. I wanted a special knife and the company would not ship to the USA, nor could I navigate their website. Shinobu from the club ordered the one I wanted and sent it on to me in the USA. Thanks again Shinobu for going the extra mile! You are fantastic and are great at your job. This place made us happy and we can't wait to go back again next year. it renewed our confidance that a big property really CAN make you feel special, it just takes pride in your work.
user_name:
Dana S
Armacao dos Buzios, RJ

review_body: Stayed here for 5 nights in a club intercontinental room.Booking a club room gives you access to the club lounge on the 35th floor. As part of the package, there was also a full buffet breakfast and a 'cocktail' hour (actually longer), which offers more choice than than just cocktails (wine, spirits, champagne, soft drinks, sake etc...). All of this is served in the lounge where the views are fantastic, especially at night.The room on one of the higher floors (below the lounge), whilst on the small side (though not unusual for Tokyo) was just right with a small sitting area, massive bed, excellent and large shower and bath (combined). Large TV in bedroom and small one in the bathroom. Everything was spotless. We did not use any of the other many dining/lounging options in the hotel, all of which looked very good. There is also a small bakery/coffeeshop which we found excellent.The hotel is a short 2 min walk from the main Roppongi area and about a 10 min walk from the huge new Roppongi hills upmarket shopping area. The hotel is joined with the Ark Hills complex comprising Suntory hall and several dining and coffee/bar options. It is a 2 min walk from Roppongi-icchome subway station (Namboku line - Exit 3) and adjacent to the Tameike-Sanno subway station (Maranuchi line and others) exit 13, which is actually a 7-10 min walk underground from the actual station. The subway is the best way to explore if you are a tourist - the combined N'EX with Suica card deal from JR is the best deal if you arrive at Narita airport. It is available ifrom the pass office at Narita JR station. To get to the hotel take NEX to Tokyo station then Maranouchi line to Tameike-Sanno. All in all this was a great hotel, relatively well situated for exploring, with spotless rooms and common areas and great service. I would highly recommend the club intercontinental package which works out to be a great deal when considering that it provides an excellent breakfast and unlimited lounge drinks with a priceless view.

Stayed on business late last year. The food was excellent offering many cuisine types representing countries from around the world. I found the service to be excellent, the location perfect and the rooms very comfortable.I would highly recommend this hotel to any business traveler and have referred many people travelling to Tokyo on business who have had equally enjoyable stays.

I spent 1 night at this hotel for the Valentine's day. My original choice was "The strings", another Intercontinental hotel in Tokyo, but after comparing the reviews (and the price), we decided on this one.The Good:- Great location, 10 min walk from the (in)famous Roppongi bar/club district. On the main Roppongi street, from the crossings toward the Tokyo tower is filled with trashy bars and clubs. However, you will also find some small but nice eateries in the back alley. In the opposite direction, there’s Roppongi Midtown, the luxurious shopping mall with great restaurants and surprisingly spacious park in the back. Toward Azabu st, there’s Roppongi Hills, another shopping mall, but less luxurious than the Midtown.We got off at Kokkai-gijido mae st, but it was a long walk to the Exit #13. Roppongi Icchome might have been closer.-Heavenly bed. The mattress, the Duvet, the softness of the fabric, they were all excellent! There were 2 separate TV Channel guide, which was a bit confusing, but not a big thing. The room was clean, with a big window, which had a great view of Tokyo.-Club Intercontinental Floor. This comes with variety of exclusive services: evening cocktail and canapés, all day refreshments, complimentary use of Fitness Center etc. Note: If you’d like to use the shoe shine, which is part of the above exclusive service, you need to call the front and make a reservation. I thought it was somewhere I could go to get it done on the spot, but they will actually come to your room to pick the shoes up, and bring them back to you.-The bath. Nice size, clean, a shower with good water pressure. Though all the channels were local Japanese program, you can watch TV while you’re in the bathroom. The towels and the robes were nice and absorbent.The Bad-The food. The canapés served in the evening weren’t great, just mediocre. Neither was the dessert. The morning buffet was pitiful, worst 5 star hotel buffet so far. The selection was very limited, bread was really dry, the coffee from the machine was horrible (though they seemed to be using the great illy coffee bean)We’ve also tried the Manhattan Lounge Lunch buffet after check out, but the food was not good either. Its décor was a bit bizarre, almost like 60’s club. They should have refurbished this place as well. Other restaurants may have been good, but rather pricey. Considering the location, you can easily find better restaurants outside of the hotel.-The breakfast buffet. The club room was already close to the full capacity when we tried the evening canapé,even though we arrived there about 3 min after the cocktail time. I suppose it’s because they have too many people for the club floor. So I asked one of the staffs how it would be like for the breakfast buffet. She told us that the it’d be so crowded that people would line up till the elevator, unless we arrive “early” and that she was sorry for the inconvenience . Early, she meant 7-7:30 am. I really didn’t want to get up at 7am on the Sunday morning, but I’m a big hotel buffet fan and had to give it a go. So I woke up 7am and hit the buffet. 8am came, but there were still plenty of seats available. I suppose for the business use, starting the breakfast at 7am is right. But to accommodate all the other client, it would be great if they either extend the breakfast time or appoint bigger space. There are few points that can be improved, but my overall stay was satisfactory.

I recently stayed at the ANA Intercontinental Hotel in Tokyo, Japan - A five star property in the heart of Tokyo.THE LOCATIONThe ANA Intercontinental is located in the Roppongi area of Tokyo. This area is famed for its nightlife but it's also famed for as a place where foreign riff-raff and trashy locales meet, often with unsavoury results. The area has gone upmarket in recent years with the new Roppongi Hills and Tokyo Midtown shopping developments, but the main strip is still somewhat trashy. The ANA Intercontinental is a 10 minute walk from Roppongi and it's easier accessed from the Tameike-Sanno Station of the Tokyo Metro (rather than the Roppongi station). The hotel is in ARK HILLS which offers a few dining options, so it's best to go to Roppongi for more options. The American Embassy and the Japanese Prime Minister's residence are all within walking distance of the hotel.THE ROOMAll the rooms in the hotel were refurbished in 2009, a year after the hotel became an Intercontinental. We reserved a Junior Suite which allowed us entry to the Club Intercontinental Lounge. The check-in was fairly efficient, if a bit mechanical and done in the main lobby (although you can check-in in the Club Lounge). We were escorted to our room by the staff, and showed the facilities in the room. The room was big (about 52 squared meters) with two big windows which allowed in plenty of light. The room had a separate sitting/work area with its own 37 inch widescreen LCD TV with an interactive service and iPod connector, a DVD Player, tea making facilities, and two complimentary bottles of water. This lounge/work area also had a big work table, a speaker phone, an in-room safe as well as high-speed LAN Internet service (complimentary for Club Intercontinental) and but no WIFI. The minibar was fully stocked with snacks, alcoholic and non-alcoholic drinks. The semi-separate sleeping area had a comfortable king size bed, a wardrobe (actually in the bathroom), as well an iHome alarm clock which has a slot for guests to connect their iPods. The bedroom also had a separate 37 inch LCD. The bed was quite comfortable and was given a turn down service in the evening. The furniture and the design of the room had a tasteful modern Japanese look and were well taken care of! The only qualm I had with the room was that there was no real closet space, except the small closet in the bathroom. The view from our room was OK: We had a view of the Tokyo skyline although a huge residential tower blocks most of the good views.THE BATHROOMThe marble bathroom was unique as it was almost part of the room (a sliding door can close the bathroom/toilet area with the bedroom). There were two sinks, a separate bathroom/shower room with a separate bath (with a small LCD TV) and a shower - All in the same glass enclosed area. The shower was great as it came with numerous jets on the length of the pipe as well as being a rain shower - One can get a goat soak! The toilet was in a separate enclosed room and contained a new Japanese washlet (bidet). There were all the usual extra amenities such as toothbrushes and razors as well as REN branded amenities in the bath. There were plenty of towels for use. As mentioned, the bathroom is unique but can be nerve-racking for shy people as it's not really private unless the entire area is closed off with the opaque sliding door.THE EXECUTIVE LOUNGEAs we were staying in the Junior Suite, we had access to the Executive Lounge. The lounge is quite big with its own separate shower facilities for guests who wish to freshen up after checking-out of their room. The food area provides free soft drinks and cookies all day. The breakfast spread in the morning is big with a good variety of both hot and cold options. In the evening, an evening cocktail ritual provides champagne, wines, beer and a variety of canapes, cheese and biscuits, sushi, fruit, olives, pate, salami and the like. The quality of the food was very good and the alcoholic selection was more than satisfactory. The Lounge also had a meeting room, and dedicated concierges as well as complimentary WIFI. Overall, the Executive Lounge is worth the upgrade if you can afford it.THE HOTEL FACILITIESThe hotel offered a variety of facilities for the guests, some of which require an extra tariff. There was an outdoor pool (open in the summer months), (small) fitness facilities, as well as a separate spa/esthetic salon (The pool and the fitness facilities require an extra tariff but this is waived for those on Club Intercontinental floors). We didn't use the facilities. The common areas of the hotel were recently refurbished, and look modern but not really luxurious. The hotel also has a shopping arcade but the prices and quality of the goods are suspect - There are more options near Roppongi. The hotel gets a lot of foot traffic from visitors to the bars and restaurants so the common areas can be noisy.THE RESTAURANTS/BARSThe hotel had 7 restaurants (serving Japanese, Chinese, Italian and buffet selections), 4 lounges/bars and a delicatessen to choose from. We ate at the Cascade (main) restaurant which serves an international buffet and found the food and price reasonable. The hotel will soon open a three Michelin starred chef restaurant – Pierre Gagnaire on the 36th floor. There are countless other food options right outside the hotel in the Roppongi district.THE SERVICEOverall, the service of the hotel was good as everyone was courteous, smiling and professional (with the exception of the surly check-in staff). Communicating in English was not a major problem although the staff's word choice can be a bit abrupt. I don't think that it's intentional, but further training in polite English use can be ideal. It's worth noting that the hotel is actually a co-branded ANA (All Nippon Airlines) and Intercontinental hotel which is unique in Japan. This is not a major problem unless patrons try to convert their ANA Intercontinental PRIORITY CLUB points to Japan Airline miles (ANA's rival in Japan), which is impossible. The point accumulation is also a bit different from other Intercontinental hotels so it's best to check with the hotel for details.THE CONCLUSIONThe ANA Intercontinental Hotel bills itself as a luxury establishment but in fact is a good five star hotel. It is a bit off-located but it has good facilities and service. It mostly cateres to business people due to its location, but it can be a good base for those who are visiting Tokyo as the city's main sights are easily accessible with the Metro (subway). The price of rooms in this hotel are lower than the other newer luxury properties in Tokyo. Overall, a great experience!

Service level could be improved greatly: a few more smiles would help too. Exec. rooms are small, but well-appointed. Lobby-level breakfast is probably better than the Exec lounge, but the lounge is good to relax or talk business if it's not crowded. Not too far from Tokyo Station and from Akasaka night-life area.Not a bad hotel, but not the usual standards of an Asian Intercontinental..
A great, clean excellent service hotel! Lovely food! Lovely people! We were upgraded as it was our honeymoon! Lovely view from room of Tokyo Tower.

We stayed in this hotel for 3 nights, and stayed on 22nd floor. We didn't want to take the airport train.. too much trouble when just look at their subway system.. so we decided to take a bus service direct from airport to this hotel.. cost about 3000yen per person. We like the location a lot. The metro station was just right outside of the hotel, and there was a little coffee shop right outside of the hotel... 300yen for a cup of expresso... not so bad in Tokyo after all. Our room was in a good size, and we felt in love with their heated seat toilet...oooo.. Hotel staffs were very friendly and helpful, and internet was free (was told if you stayed 22nd floor or up ...don't know why) ..too bad their pool didn't open in the winter.

We stayed in two rooms during December 2009 with our two teenagers. One room was on the club level and the other on a standard floor. Both rooms were small. Although the club level room was noticeably nicer, the upcharge for the club level was not worth it. The club level lounge was often quite crowded. Concierge staff were extremely helpful and knowledgeable. We took Narita Express to the hotel which worked quite well. Hotel can email to you the exact directions from the Narita to the hotel via subway which is a good option, particularly at rush hour. If you take the subway be aware that there are many stairs -- so not a good option if you have lots of luggage. Great restaurants in the Roppongi area which is quite close to the hotel. Taxi service is impeccable - very professional (but a bit on the pricey side).

I have stayed here a few times - once for a long weekend on holiday and the other times on business. I would describe this hotel as functional and unspectacular but a great option for both business and pleasure.Positives are the staff and service, it has most of the amenities you would expect (although the gym is rather small) and it's a short walk from the nightlife in Roppongi if that is what you are after. The negatives are few and far between but the rooms are very small so you wouldn't want to spend much time in them at all.In short this hotel won't blow you away but the times I have stayed here I have paid a very reasonable rate (by Tokyo standards anyway).

ANA Intercon is a typical 5 stars hotel. Service is good, so is location, and the room are up to the expected standard. Contrary to the other Intercon (see my review), there is a little more atmosphere there is you have the club floors: the newly refurbish coktail lounge at the club levels is just Wow! Modern style, with an excellent view of Tokyo skyline.I am always amazed by the prize of the 5 stars hotels in Japan. If you don`t know which one to choose between the 2 Intercon, I recommend this one.

I were very lucky that when I reached Tokyo last year (around early April), the local colleagues told me that the season for cherry blosoom just started that week. Just next to my hotel, ANA Intercontinental, it is a famous landscape for seeing the cherry blossom. In a Saturday morning, when I walked to the street next to the hotel. A very romantic scene was there (you can look at my photos)In addition, I found that the Japanese food is excellent there. I love to eat the Sushi, and the Japanese restaurant there is a very good choice.

Beautifull hotel, middle of Tokyo, walking distance of touristic places. Rooms were small (even the executive rooms) but fully equipped and nicely decorated. Paying more to have access to executive floor & lounge is not worthwhile the money, free beverages are limited to only a few hours per day and very few snacks (and the same every evening)

Nice hotel. A bit too business-like but grand. The breakfast is excellent. We stayed there for 2 weeks so we were lucky the rooms are large and refreshing. I wasn't impressed with the night buffet but our young daughters loved it.

I stayed here for one night at the end of a Far East tour. I got the chance to stay at the Intercontinental Hong Kong and the Intercontinental Singapore before this hotel. I will be honest - I got a great upgrade thanks to my Ambassador status but I did not think the hotel had any atmosphere and lacked a certain something......My room was great - as you would expect in a Suite but outside of that things were a little impersonal. The restaurants were not very welcoming, the prices were outrageous - and I have stayed in some expensive hotels!!!!I had access to the Club Intercontinental Lounge which had spectacular views and free champagne for 2 hours but no atmosphere and the evening nibbles were laughable. Having just come from the Intercontinental Singapore which did not have champagne on tap but had some great evening snacks - I preferred Singapore by a long way. The views are great from the lounge though I will admit. The staff only wanted to serve a few select business men - return travelers I have no doubt.It is not often I feel uncomfortable in a hotel - I have stayed in many many hotels in my time - including lots of Intercontinentals, which is my hotel of choice. Walking around the lobby, avoiding all the Japanese business lunch folks, I had a distinct feeling of not being welcome. No smiles, no hellos no staff to ask directions, when I wandered around looking a little lost no one to jump out and help as in other hotels.I loved the room - the bathroom was superb - but my overall feeling was almost of an airport hotel - I had a cosier feeling in the Crowne Plaza at Narita than I did in this top class hotel. I couldn't tell you one particular incident that makes me think this - just a feeling as I wondered around. Funnily enough - I had just stayed in Hong Kong and Singapore and this was the most expensive stay - and the least enjoyable.I would not stay here again - although it is a fabulous looking hotel, it appears to have lost the ability to look after its guests - they are just an after thought to the conference meetings, business lunches and the like.

Tokyo is an amazing city and this is right at the centre of that excitement. This Hotel is truly in a different class... we had a great experience here.. in particular in terms of service - the consierge and experience manager is second to none I have ever found. If you want a 3* michellin restaurant for tomorrow night - they will (SOMEHOW) get it for you... if you want a noise and authentic noodle bar... they will direct you to just the spot... are you looking for the freshest sushi in Tokyo... they will have in flappin on your plate - these wont be touristy places but authentically Japanese places where REAL people stay and eat and enjoy. The rooms are great.. the club floor is unparalleled and the location ideal for exporing Tokyo by day or night.

The first time we stayed at this hotel we had a nightmare night with our next door neighbour practicing his golf at 3am.... the staff dealt with our complaint in a professional manner and since then we have stayed there 4 times and have received fabulous service everytime. It has a metro stop outside but close to walk to Rappongi in the evening for dinner / drinks. As we are ambassadors we get lounge access and it is one of the nicest ICH lounges with great food and a really good breakfast buffet. There are 2 members of staff - Jerome and Dorothe who are particularly lovely and welcome us back with friendly smiles. The concierge are very knowledgeable and helpful... what more can I say. I do love being in Tokyo so I guess that also makes my stay here pleasurable. I have 2 small complaints.... on is the junior suites have a DVD player in the 'lounge' ares - but not in the bedroom and there really isn't enough wardrobe space for 2 people on a week holiday... We have been back with friends twice and will continue to stay here on our future visits...

This was my 3rd stay. I met the concierge Jerome Palacoeur [--] on an earlier stay and found him extremely helpful so emailed him in advance and he arranged business conference rooms, dinners,etc. He and his staff do extremely good work. The hotel has recently had some of the rooms renovated and they are very very nice. The Club Room on 35rd floor has been redone and has really good breakfasts and cocktails gratis for those staying on club level. The conference room there is available at no charge for those who are staying on the club level for 2 hours/day gratis and it is well equipped with a large screen for powerpoint presentations. Their staff also serve tea/drinks to you and your guests so it makes for good meetings.Location is perfect. You take the Limo Bus from Narita airport right to the hotel.
