As I have mobility issues the hotel makes arrangements for me to have a mobility scooter when I arrive and the staff takes such good care of me. Try it--believe you'll be like me and find it one of your favorite hotels. I've stayed in many of the Intercontinental and continue to be impressed with the level of service. Another plus is they have world class restaurants in the hotel which make it easy to transition from business meetings to Japanese/Chinese/French dinners with your customers who appreciate the location and access to trains,etc.

We finished our trip to Japan with a night at the ANA because it is an easy direct link to Narita via the Narita Express. We had a stunning view from the 34th floor (a club room) and the drinks and canapes, and breakfast, included the next day were of an astoundingly high quality, and they gave us a 2pm checkout. It has a useful subway line just outside, and is a great base. I would't stay for a whole visit, because it is like any international 5 star hotel, but it is excellent for arriving and departing Tokyo in style.

We stayed at the Intercontinental for 6 days as part of a sightseeing trip to Tokyo. We had a room on the 23rd floor with a great view of the city. The room was very comfortable but had a couple of odd design features: there was a window between the bathroom and bedroom which meant that if either of us went to the bathroom at night the light would wake the other; and the television was placed in front of the window, blocking some of the view.The hotel was spotlessly clean and all of the staff we encountered were extremely good. The concierge team in particular were superb: they were very knowledgeable and one even translated a brief written message into Japanese for us.The top floor bar had a great view but was staggeringly expensive, even for Tokyo. As often occurs in Japan there was a high cover charge even if you are just having drinks. All of the restaurants seemed overpriced compared to similar places to eat in the neighbourhood.Transport links are good - the Friendly Airport Limousine company has a shuttle bus from the airport to the hotel every 30 minutes, there is a very busy taxi rank at the hotel, and there are two subway stations within 5 minutes walk (although to get onto one of the lines you have to walk 600 metres underground once you've got into the station!). There are plenty of restaurants and convenience stores in a short walk - on our last night we wondered into Akasaka (over the main road) and found several streets full of places to eat and drink. I definitely recommend Ramen Jyangara for hearty cheap fast food, and Ninja for an entertaining meal.The only disappointment was that the pool was already closed for the season, despite it being about 28º C and sunny during our stay.If staying here over a weekend, I would definitely recommend joining the Intercontinental Ambassador programme - they give you a free weekend night voucher which is worth more than the cost of the membership, and you get other perks as well (room upgrade, free newspaper etc.).

The hotel by itself is not bad. A big, ample building with lots of amenities, but the most basic of them, the ones you can expect for the price you´re paying, are available at additional price, not advertised when you book. This is what I call "hidden costs".Let me explain. I paid around 150 euros per night from Sept. 11 to Sept 15 booking well in advance, for a double room taking advantage of a special discount rate from Intercontinental via Internet, that cannot be cancelled or modified after you purchase it. The price was right, having into account that Tokyo is a expensive city and the hotel is well located (Akasaka Area). But, as soon as I arrived, I was ofered an "upgrade" to my room to have access to the pool, free internet (incredible, since at the Rose Garden Hotel, a modest but very good hotel in Shinjuku, it was free), free drinks and other things that didn´t interest us for around 60 euros per night more. I refused, and immediately I was offered another "option" that for 3000 yen per night more granted free internet access and, I want to believe, a better room. The recepcionist spoke very bad english, a let down in a hotel like this.To add insult to injury, the nearest subway station is very near the main hotel entrance, but then you have to walk around 7 minutes to actually reach the trains, a very big disadvantage specially at night when you return with bags and tired of a long sightseeing day. You cannot use your Japan Rail pass, since the Yamanote line, the one that circles the center of Tokyo is a bit far away, and you have to pay "twice" to use the subway instead of the pass.My recomendation is that you look for a good price-quality hotel like the Rose Garden in Shinjuku, with free internet access, very well located, within walking distance of a bunch of shopping malls, atraction, subway station (Nishi-Shinjuku), kind english-speaking staff, lots of places to eat for cheap around and nice (a bit small but confy) rooms.

We spent our last night of a 14-days round trip through Japan here. I booked our room through the hotel's website and rate was 27.000 yen for double room with club privileges. A standard room was then around 19.000 yen, so the extra 8.000 yen for Club Floor was really worth it !Club Lounge is on 35th floor and our room was on 29th. I think that our room is exactly the same as the Executive Room (without Club privileges). Now, I travelled a lot for business and have seen great and terrible Club Lounges, but this was indeed the finest ever. Fully renovated with expensive Scandinavian and other-good-taste design, very large and - also quite rare - true Champagne as much as you want during 'cocktail hour' (each day from 5.30 to 7.30 PM). During cocktail hour, you could also have many other types of alcohol and fingerfood. At other times, no alcohol was available. Room itself was standard size (around 26 sq m) and we had a nice view of Tokyo Tower. Frankly, I don't understand why others are so keen on having a room with a view on Tokyo Tower... the other side of the hotel tower looked out towards Shibuya and Shinjuku (we saw it from the Lounge) and this was equally impressive in our opinion. Our room was recently renovated, so nice decor and good, functional bathroom. I have to say, though, that lobby was often crowded and looked dated. I suppose therefore that standard rooms are not renovated neither. Our experience would have been less positive on these floors, so.... go for Club in this hotel ! Location wise : not too practical for getting around a lot, but good for local area (Roppongi). Oh yeah, last tip : there is a shower room just next to Club lounge, which was handy for us since our flight was late in the evening. You will need to ask the reception on Club Floor to unlock it when you want to use it. All in all : great Club experience, but would not recommend Standard rooms > for 150 euro, you get better deals.

I had a quiet, clean room, but no interesting view. The staff was courteous, but not really friendly. The whole hotel seemed a bit restrained and almost boring. Breakfast is very expensive, so either explore the neighborhood, or include it in your room rate. The bedding was very comfortable and I had a sound sleep after a long flight. This hotel is part of a larger complex of office buildings and theatres. The whole concept is "planned" but not as lively as many other neighborhoods in Tokyo.

Stayed here for our full stay in Tokyo during our vacation.Before we went to tokyo we read through the reviews and looked at the pictures on tripadvisor. As we wanted a good hotel to get back to after hours of shopping.The first thing that made me a bit mad when we got there was people here saying the location is no good, no restaurants nearby etc etc.My bet is that someone here is raised with a macdonalds on their doorstep, cause this hotel got plenty of good restaurants around it. Closest one was just across the street, a literally 5 min's walk! And if you care walking a bit further, say 7 mins you'll find heaps of restaurants. Curry houses, Japanese fish restaurants, Japanese BBQ.The hotel is a 10 minute walk from Akasaka train station and a 10 min walk from another station i cant remember the name of. Ginza shopping district is only 2 stops away and it takes you straight into the centre.We walked to Roppongi from the hotel, would take us around 15 mins to get into the main areas with restaurants and bars. Beware though, after Nigerian criminals have settled here they spike your drink and rob you if you're not careful.Don't go to the bars with a lot of "inward bouncers".The room of the hotel was great! Had a living room when we first came in, with 2 chairs, a office desk with a view and a LCD tv. Huge bed with LCD screen. Huge bathroom with drizzle shower, bathtub and tv on the wall. We ate brakfast 3 times while we stayed there, one in the room, one upstairs in 35 floor and one downstairs in the restaurant. Japanese breakfast in the room was a bit tasteless, but clean and ok. The restaurant in 1st floor was crowded and filled with queues, so for the rest of our stay we just went out to eat on various restaurants.Concierge was very helpful and efficient, so we felt we had Japans Google in first floor helping us to find rock bars, Fugu restaurants and all sorts of stuff to do.Hopefully i will be back in tokyo soon, and I would be glad if i could stay in this hotel again.

I work in the hotel industry, so it takes a lot to impress me. My stay at the ANA InterContinental was nothing but first rate. The staff were more than accommodating, the rooms well maintained and the decor modern and inviting. I had the pleasure of staying on the Club InterContinental floors and again, the staff was first rate. The lounge was well appointed and the free internet was a nice bonus. The location was extremely convenient. I walked to most areas and when necessary, the metro station entrance was located right in front of the hotel.And one last comment...thank you to the previous reviewer that recommended Airport Limousine. Great tip! Door to door from Narita to the hotel in 90 minutes, hassle free.I will definitely stay at the InterContinental again!

Spent three days at the ANA. The first impression of the room was amazing - the evening view of Tokyo was great. We had a twin room on the 24th floor - a reasonable size considering that I have heard many Tokyo rooms are small. Location was great - short walk to the metro station (but a bit of a walk down to the actual platforms) and to Roppongi (for shopping and nightlife). Were surprised that they charged guests to use the swimming pool, nice enough outdoor pool. Watch out for the cover charge at the Manhattan Lounge Bar - top floor bar with almost 360 deg views.

This was our first stay in Tokyo and the ANA turned out to be a great choice. The rooms are very well designed and although not huge by US standards they feel quite large and have everything you need. And of course Japanese toilets......(for those of you yet to experience these they're normal toilets with heated seats and a number of fancy bidet options accessed by very clearly labeled buttons). Rates were on the expensive side but that seems typical for Tokyo. I wasn't looking forward to getting down into town from Narita but this hotel is on the bus route and it was easy and efficient. All hotels in town are about 60-90 minutes from Narita and this one took about 70 minutes. Taxis are ridiculously expensive so rail or bus are your choices. Check-in was fast and we had upgraded to the executive club. Got a high floor room and rooms were very quiet....no noise issues. Spent two nights here and the first night the club level wasn't crowded but was much busier on the second night. Still, no problems with getting food and the wine selections were excellent. You can walk around from this hotel to a couple of local shrines if you feel the need to stretch your legs.....10/15 minutes walk and nice to see them in the midst of concrete modern Tokyo. The Imperial Palace is also nearby and walking distance but a little further. We didn't make it there this visit but will do so next time. Subway is close and convenient. The ANA is a high quality hotel with comfortable rooms , excellent service and easy transfers to/from Narita.....we would stay here again

This was my first visit to Tokyo and the reviews and website indicated that this was a good choice of property. They were correct.I agree with some reviewers that the lobby looks a little dated. I booked a Club Intercontinental Room which gives you access to the new Club Lounge on level 25. Check in is also handled in the lounge. The Club is very modern and chic, decorated in warms browns and greys with some great views.Check in was a little slow due to some confusing elements in my booking. The porter was very patient and waited with our bags. He was very pleased to show us the facilities in the room.The room itself was of a reasonable size and had recently been renovated so had a great modern feel to it. The bathroom had a shower in the bath and had an odd design whereby some of the water drained over the edge to an overflow. First reaction was to assume flooding but it is designed to channel the water to the drain - quite neat really. The room had all the trimmings you would expect of an interantional five star hotel. The addition of complimentary internet in the room for Club guests is a great touch as is use of the fitness centre.For the first two days the Lounge was pleasant with a good ebb and flow of guests making it comfortably relaxing. On the last two days there was a national holiday and the hotel was fully booked which meant the lounge was full to the brim. This then involved queuing for breakfast and cocktails in the evening - not what you expect. The poor staff where overwhelmed by the crowds and were struggling to cope.I must admit to being dissatisfied with this and made this known to the team. At the time a suitable solution was not offered but on my return in the afternoon the Director of Guest Experience sought me out to apologise. This was very much appreciated and he did well on his service recovery. I do understand that I was not the only guest to have an issue with this!!The lounge breakfast and canape offerings are identical each day. This is clearly not a disaster but some variety may be appreciated if you are there for a few nights. The wine and spirits range in the evening is excellent.We also used the lounge concierge to find us a local high end restaurant and she found us an excellent option in Ginza. We also made use of the concierge on the ground floor to assit with Shinkansen train reservations, she was also excellent.Overall it was a great option for a hotel in Tokyo. Very close to the entry of the subway (although be prepared to do some walking!). I also recommend using the Limousine Bus Service to and from Narita for JPY3,000 each way. It drops you off and picks you up at the door so there is no need to negotiate the subway system with bags.

Stayed on a corporate rate - so discounted. Orignally put in one of the lower floor rooms. Room spelt unpleasant and I complained in the morning. Who wants to stay in a smelly room? I then had a good experience - the front desk manager, sorted the problem out by moving me. I got moved to a higher floor in the thirties. The rooms on this floor have been renovated and are a vast improvement over the lower floor rooms which are very dated. The rooms are a reasonable size for Japan and the bathroom in the second room was nice - wet room type shower, bath tub etc. The gym is small and is to be honest for a 5 star hotel hopeless - a few sad looking dumbells and a multigym plus some joggers etc. I've stayed at the Conrad before and that's got a much better gym plus a swimming pool to write home about. Like many hotels in Japan you have to pay for everything - gym, swimming pool, even the pool chairs. That said if you're here on a corp rate they comp the gym etc.So net-net, not bad depends on which floor. The hotel is right next to the metro and is convenient. 15 mins at most to Tokyo train station in a cab. To get in from Narita take the airport bus. It takes around 90 mins.

fabulous place - don't think twice about choosing this as your hotel for Tokyo. next to 2 subway stations that'll get you anywhere. Super friendly & helpful staff. Clean, clean & clean. great rooms, nice bathroom. Breakfast buffet - excellent! shops & restaurants in and around the hotel complex - a truly great hotel

First impressions of the hotel were that it was rather dated. The lobby was very 1980s We had executive rooms on the 34th floor which were pleasantly modern but small. Wireless broadband (cost included) and a choice of English language channels were available. Tried the gym which was very small, especially for such a large hotel. Gym use is complimentary for those in executive room but was, I think, Y1,500 for others. As there were no staff in the gym the charge relied on an honesty book system. Didn't try the pool as it was on a different floor and as its outdoor I gathered it was only open in the summer months. Strangely there was no lift direct from the executive floors to the gym, you have to change lifts half way down the building.Between 5.30pm and 7.30pm drinks and canapes are served in the executive lounge which we enjoyed but was very busy. The lounge could do with more tables and chairs.We went out to Roppongi for dinner but had breakfast in the executive lounge before checking out. The selection wasn't great and there was a queue to get a table even at 10am when breakfast finished at 11am. Again the lounge needs to be expanded.The area around the hotel is quiet. A 15 minute (uphill) walk gets to to lively Roppongi and we would rather have stayed there. There are metro stations nearby so its convenient for sight seeing in other parts of Tokyo.All in all its a comfortable hotel but I think there are better out there for the cost charged.

Stayed here for 1 night during a visit to Tokyo. Check-in was very quick and the staff was excellent at mentioning all of the features and benefits of the hotel. The one thing I thought was odd was that they did not offer to help me with my large luggage.Room - I stayed in a Deluxe room and it was perfect. It had an overall feel of being cozy and had all modern amenities. There was a large LCD television with plenty of channels. The alarm clock had a dock for my iPod, which was nice. The bed was large and very comfortable. The bathroom was a bit small, but very clean and updated. It even had a small LCD television with a limited number of channels. Food - I ate lunch at the cafe downstairs. It was very pricey, but this is expected of a nice hotel. I also visited their deli/bakery and it had a vast selection of breads, pastries and snacks. There are countless other restaurants specializing in all types of food. I was impressed with all of the choices.Location - The hotel is located in the central part of Tokyo. Access to the subway system is not bad. There are 2 stations within a few minutes of walking from the hotel. There is plenty of nightlife in nearby Roppongi. Getting to/from Narita airport is easy with the Airport Limousine Bus (3,000 yen each way).Overall, this is a great hotel with modern amenities and central location. I would stay here again in the future.

We stayed at the hotel JUL 9th - 12th. Suite 2901.Beautiful room, with an excellent lounge.Jerome the Director of client relations made our stay even more enjoyable. He went out of his way to help us with the little things that can mean alot to hotel guests.Sunoko and Ms Sakanishi in the lounge were excellent, both went above and beyond with their customer service skills and in assisting us with varioous matters.The gym is small but adequate. The Ginza metro line is not too far from the hotel, can be reached by walking in 10 mins.Please ignore the negative reviews about this hotel. Write to me if you need more information.

The airport limousine dropped us off straight at the hotelcheckin went fast and smooth, we got offered a room to the club level and took it.As we flew koreanair and they managed to loose our bags, we asked the concierge for anything he had ( extra razor/deo and other basic needs) and our needs where met.The concierge also did everything they could by contacting korean air and trying to locate our bags.. so a biig thanks to the exxelent concierge service.Our room was goodsize, very nice bath, with exxelent shower !the view from our hotel at night as we stayed on the 35th floor, the view at night was just WOW, just for this i would returnBreakfast in the morning was sufficient perhaps could have been a little more but it had all you can imagen.The subway station is 5 min walking away and everything within the station is in english and it showed you exactly where to exit the station to get back to the hotelAll in all a good stay and would def go back !

We found an unbelievably good rate for the hotel (about 30% more than the usual tiny business hotel we use when in Tokyo, whereas the differential is usually more like 200%) so couldn't resist. I've stayed here before several times over the last 20 years, and it's a classic good quality hotel, in a good location (between the entertainment of Roppongi and the offices of Akasaka and Kasumigaseki). It's big and sort of international-bland decor, but perfectly pleasant. The rooms aren't big by international standards, but adequate, and well finished, with fast internet, kettle, well appointed bathroom, and a usable work desk. Your business acquaintances will acknowledge it as a good quality hotel, as evidenced by the amount of weddings they cater for at weekends. Service was generally good as you'd expect, an we made full use of the concierge and bell captain's services. An extra plus is that it's a direct stop for the frequent "airport limousine" buses to/from the airports.The only disappointment was that although the hotel has a decent sized lap pool, it's open only 10-5, meaning that it's no use for business travellers wanting a workout.Tokyo's currently over-supplied with top-end hotels, so shop around carefully as rates zoom up and down rapidly. But if you can get a decent rate (anything under JPY20,000 for a regular room) you'll be getting excellent value.

We stayed at ANA Intercontinental for 3 nights in June. Being that it was our first trip to Tokyo, I had read up on the Tripadvisor reviews before booking the ANA and let me just say that all the positive reviews on this hotel were right on!We arrived at Narita International Airport and took the aiport limo bus at a cost of $30 and we were dropped off at the hotel's doorstep in 1 hour. The porter received our bags and whisked us to the front desk efficiently. Upon check in, we were offered an upgrade to the Club Intercontinental and we accepted.Our guest room, although small by US standard, had all the comforts of a discriminating traveller - flat panel TV, CD player, electronic curtains, superb mood lighting, etc., and a great view of the Tokyo Tower.Having access to the club lounge, we were offered complimentary breakfast, afternoon tea and hors d'ouvres and cocktails in the evening. The presentation and quality of the food was superb! The staff were also pleasant and courteous and made us feel very welcome (there's no lost in translation here).The hotel is located next to the subway and although it is a good 5 minute walk to the actual subway line (Ginza, Shibuya and Marinouchi), it wa a great location to be in this part of town.If you are considering staying at this hotel, have no second thoughts! This hotel is worth the money, enjoy it!

I loved my stay at this hotel. It was the quality you would expect from an intercontinental but this hotel went above and beyond. I had a prescription that I needed filled that was in English (I had forgotten to bring my refill on the trip) and the concierge spent hours calling around to pharmacies to find a pharmacist who spoke english and then had my prescription filled for me at the pharmacy next to the hotel. The concierge was just so unbelievably helpful, I cannot give them a better review. Some other things I loved were the view from the top (AMAZING), the breakfast buffet (which I promise is worth the price at least once) and the airport shuttle for only $30 USD (which is about the same price as lugging your stuff to the train). My only complaint about this hotel is that there is not free wifi. However, if you go right next door to the hotel (to the right of the lobby if you are looking at the hotel) there is a little strip of cute cafes and bakeries and there is free wifi there that we used. This hotel surpassed my expectations, it was great. I would recommend it to anyone.

We stayed 3 nights at this hotel, then cancelled Ryokan reservations to stay another 2 nights. Reason being, travelling in Japan, can be and usually is tiring, exhausting and it's easy to get run down. Sleeping in comfy beds, with room service at your finger tips can never be undersetimated when one is beyond exhaustion from walking all day and sight seeing in humidity and heat.Speaking of room service, after 10 hours flight from Australia, then hour and half on the Limousine Bus, we were tired and hungry. 2 club sandwiches, 2 cokes and 375ml bottle of red wine, came to roughly $150 Aussie dollars...ouch. Only order RS if you are desperate, as it is extremely expensive and what everyone imagines it to be. Wander down the street and you and your partner can eat like kings for $50, it's up to you.We stayed on floors 31 and 34 which are the Club Intercontinental flloors, which give you access to the Club Lounge and late check out. The service is impeccable, not too mention the breakfasts on the 35th floor if you are a club intercon guest.This Hotel is absolutely outstanding, i really couldn't fault it, the toilets and bathrooms are amazing and havce recently undergone an upgrade, curtains are all electronic controlled and the plasmas are in the bedroom and loungroom, oh and you can also watch TV on the wall whilst you bathe or shower!The train station is 1 minute from the hotel.We'll go back...for sure!

At the moment of writing I'm in my room in this hotel (internet access is complimentary in club rooms). It's a great hotel with modern rooms; I'm in a King Bed Clubroom on the 29th floor and my room is fitted with some handy features as automated curtains, a selection of television (42" flat screen) input ports (HDMI, VGA and a USB port), an iPod dock, TV in bathroom and so on.The service at the hotel is excellent as well; check in (at 10 AM) went smoothly even though official check in time is set at 3PM. Housekeeping is really fast: I asked to borrow a nailclipper and they were at my door step within 2 minutes!Concierge service is extremely helpful and they really take their time to help you. I planned some outings together with the concierge member and she went all the way in figuring out transportation options (including times, track numbers and more).Upon checkin the checkin clerk congratulated me with my birthday and today I returned to my room where a bottle of red wine and a card was waiting for me; compliments of the guest relation services.Haven't used any of their restaurants so can't comment on them, but they looked fine and were quite busy at any given time.Location: there is a subway ENTRANCE around the corner, but beware... This is only an entrance to the subway system which means that the nearest track is about 350 meters of underground walking (Ginza Line), other lines are accessible as well, but one of the lines takes you about 900 meters befor you actually get there... This is no downside as the underground feels safe and the exit brings you straight to the hotel (1 minute walk).All in all, this Intercontinental is an excellent choice for your stay in Tokyo! Are there any downsides? Well, during my stay the hotel looked /felt packed and that also showed in their recently refurbished "Intercontinental Club" (Lounge for Clubrooms). It was packed with mainly Japanese people during peak hours (breakfast and evening canapes), but other than that the lounge was (more than) adequate, so no... No real downsides to this hotel!!

At least once a year, business takes me to Tokyo, sometimes also twice. A friend of mine booked me into the ANA Hotel the first time. Since then I keep returning. The location for me is ideal, as two Metro stations are just next to the hotel and for many meetings it takes me just 5 min, by taxi from the hotel.Service is of course excellent, but for us Europeans, service is excellent everywhere in Japan. The room I usually get is great, big enough and everything there one needs. I by far prefer the view to Tokyo Tower and the higher the room, the better. They have by the way also wonderful Junior-suites and suites, only for me a "regular" room is just right.They have a great choice of restaurants with wonderful food. For us Europeans a little expensive but the quality is such, that it is still worth going.I especially love their breakfast buffet, a combination of European and Japanese breakfast,. One can taste new things or just stick with what you eat back home also.They by the way have renovated a lot, since I went there for the first time, the hotel looks better and better each time I return. I am already looking forward to my next visit next September.

We've stayed in other Incontinentals (Sydney, etc.) and enjoy the ambiance and friendliness of the club-level service. My wife and I stayed at the Ana in a junior suite on the 34th floor at a very good rate and enjoyed great views of Tokyo. The room provided terrific amenities including a first class bath, multiple TV's, super-comfortable bed, etc. Best of all was the staff, especially in the club. Multi-national, friendly and extremly customer oriented. The club even has a first-class business conference room that I used for meetings--very convenient. It just went through a renovation and they hit a home run with style, comfort, space, etc.The location in Tokyo is excellent. Close to the American embassy, walking distance to Roppongi and the Gov't center., a great outdoor plaza with lots of restaurants adjacent to the hotel. Short cab rides to Tokyo and Shinagawa stations.  Would recommend this hotel in a heartbeat. If you absolutely need a pool, know that it is outdoors and only open in the summer. Wasn't a big deal for us.

Stayed here for 3 nights as part of a recent Japan trip. Hotel is very close to a subway station, however, to get to/from the actual train to the hotel subway exit is a good 500+ meters and about a 5 minute walk. Very nice lobby, and very busy. The hotel was always bustling with activity while we were there. Stayed in a club room on the 31st floor and got a nice view of the city. Club lounge was nice, and a decent breakfast was provided (if you have lounge access of course). Rooms were a a fair size for Japan, very nice bathroom with a TV in the bath area. Clean rooms that were nicely appointed. Lady at checkout was a little gruff, but other than that, no problems.
user_location: Wherever the cheap fares take me
user_name:
trahveller
Wherever the cheap fares take me

review_body: As this was a first visit to Tokyo, many factors contributed to the choice of ANA Intercontinental. First was location: the hotel is centrally located, although it is mainly a business area. They were running some special prices, which was very helpful, and finally, they are a familiar brand.First positive was the fact the Narita Bus stop at the hotel. Was good that this was a household name. Reception staff were efficient and gave us a room on the 19th floor, which had an amazing view of Roppongi Hills. The room itself is pretty small, but I guess this was to be expected from Tokyo. Nevertheless, the furniture and decoration were very tasteful, like a typical Intercontinental room. Bathroom was nice and featured the famous hi-tech toilet seat, which was very exciting for me!The lobby area is airy and very beautiful, in an 80s kind of way. The hotel also features an outdoor swimming pool, which must be quite rare for Tokyo. Although it wasn't included in our rate, we decided to fork out the JPY 3000 for breakfast/brunch on Sunday and were very impressed with the choice and quality. Definitely recommeded if you're very hungry.Location is very good, with a Ginza line subway stop just outside, taking you to Ginza and Shinjuku. The closest area to walk to is Roppongi, about a 15 minute walk and worth checking out for the modern art museum, some nice restaurants (Gonpachi - a must! Lots of fun and reasonably priced, great food and Joel Robuchon, the very expensive french/asian fusion chef) and the view from Roppongi Tower.Finally, the staff is very friendly. Concierge seems to be a bit complicated, as a simple request to book a restaurant is made to look very complicated and ceremonial.Would definitely recommend and will be going back, once the Yen/GBP rate comes down.

We just returned from Japan and while we were in Tokyo we stayed on the Club Level of the ANA Intercontinental. It was an excellent choice. The club level room costs not much more than a regular room, but was much larger and included a small living area. Full breakfast in the club lounge was included with as much coffee as you could ever want. In the evening, they had a good selection of appetizers and wine available for patrons. Our room had a spectacular view over the city. We were able to use computers in the club lounge and the staff in the lounge and in the hotel were very hospitable. We felt like the hotel was a real bargain.

OVERALL: While there are some luxurious touches here and there, this hotel feels tired and old. The lobby area is inviting with its open ceilings, but once you get into your room, claustraphobia sets in. The location is central, but could be a bit deceiving if you're expecting to walk right off the train platform to your hotel.ROOM (booked the cheapest rate available): Nothing to write home about. Size of the room is ok for central Tokyo, not small but not exactly big either; good size for 2, but will feel crowded with 3 adults. The LCD TV was on the smaller side (probably 19"), expected more for this class of hotel. The views are hit or miss, as the lower floor views will be blocked by the surrounding buildings or expressway... so book/request a high floor if you can. Bathroom, fixtures and furniture are at least 10 years old and could use some updating.DINING: only ate at the breakfast buffet (included in rate we found), very good selection of Japanese and Western food. Expensive if you pay separate (3000+ yen), but probably worth it if you're extremely hungry. Other dining options seemed ridiculously expensive, probably catering to tourists who are unwilling to venture outside the area.LOCATION: The subway entrance/exit (Tameike-Sanno Station) is right next to the hotel, but the actual subway platform is a good hike (5+ min at a brisk Tokyo pace)... might be a bit taxing if you plan on dragging around a lot of baggage. The good news is you have direct access to the Ginza Subway line, great for tourists wanting to see Shibuya, Harajuku (Omotesando), Ginza, Odaiba (via Shimbashi) or Asakusa. Also on the up side, limousine buses bound for both airports (Haneda and Narita) stop at the hotel, making for an easy trip to/from. If you plan on taking a Hato Bus tour, they pick-up/drop-off at this hotel as well.

Stayed here for one night in January. We were initially given a 16th floor room with a terrible view of nothing but air conditioning units on roof tops, but complained as this was a special night for us, and we were moved to a 23rd floor room with an excellent view of the Tokyo Tower. The room was great, with a much better bathroom, bigger bed etc. They are building a new tower block alongside the side if the building we were staying on, and this may obscure things for those staying on lower floors. They were working at almost exactly our level on the new building - don't know how high they are going! The lobby restaurants and shops were all very nice and open until 10pm. The food/drink is as expensive as you would expect for a place like this. So this is a nice hotel overall.The only negative side is where this hotel is. It is close to a couple of metro stations, which sounds great but if your aren't Tokyo savvy then you may struggle with getting to them. This isn't close to any of the airport lines etc. Although the Limousine Buses may call there (check their website). The closest area with any shops and restaurants at non-hotel prices is Roppongi, this is a good 10-15mins walk, and not the nicest of areas of an evening - a little bit seedy and full of tourists. I'd really only recommend this hotel for a night or two, and if you can afford to either use it as a base to go elsewhere, or if you can afford the hotel restaurants.
user_name:
William B
Milton Keynes, United Kingdom

review_body: I spent 3 nights here recently on business. The hotel has a very grand reception area and it is really the public areas of the hotel that make it stand out as good choice.It has a number of different restaurants and bars (the bar up on the 40 something floor has fantastic views, but does come with a table charge which I thought unnecessary) and the ones that I tried I found very good.The hotel is not located in the best shopping/business districts of Tokyo, but it is next to a metro station so getting round is very easy.I found the room size comparable with that of other city centre hotels (slightly small but large enough for a short stay) but did have a really good view of Tokyo Tower. The hotel was modern, clean and the staff friendly and efficient.Overall a very good hotel

As a previous review mentioned ....most of the guests were westerners and on a business trip or at a conference. Mind you saying that whilst I was there the hotel held a very traditional Japanese wedding on the saturday and from what I could gather no expense was spared ! So perhaps the hotel is held in high regard by the locals ? ANA is a very clean and modern hotel. I stayed in a basic room on the 24th floor as I was only staying in Tokyo for 4 nights. Last time I stayed in Tokyo I was in the Palace Hotel and I felt that the hotel was in need of an 'upgrade' ...for want of an expression. ANA is perfect for the business traveller....and suits if travelling with your partner. Everything you need is in your room...if not ask and it will be . .. In fact if you need anything at all, the staff are all very eager to help and do more than is required of them. They really did try to make my stay as comfortable as possible and ALL staff were curtious, always willing to please and bent over backwards to help should you need any. For the more 'adventurous traveller' the hotel is located near the Roppongi ..literally a 10 minute stroll. ... Tokyo isnt necessarily the cheapest town in the world and the hotel certainly reflects that. I personally found the eating and drinking ''in house'' was particularly expensive. I had one incident which was most unexpected....got up one morning and there was NO water supply at all to the hotel...it was only off for 30 mins...but if one had appointments it was no consolation. When I returned later that day 2 bottles of red wine awaited me with a letter prefuse apology....which was very nice. I will stay again when I return to Tokyo . I would also recommend other business travellers and tourists ( if it's within your budgets) to stay there too.
user_name:
TheGeez
Chiclana de la Frontera, Spain

review_body: fantastic nighttime view of tokyo tower and the whole city from our 27th floor room. even more fantastic japan sunrise. elegantly designed interiors, more to the minimalist side. near to 2 train stations. 7-11 is just beside the property. located in ark hills where there are several dining options to choose from (aside from the hotel's numerous bars, restaurants and lounges.

This is one of several Intercontinental hotels in Tokyo, and is located near the Roppongi entertainment district. It is better known as the ANA. It has a subway station (tameike-sanno) on the Ginza line (colour coded yellow on transport maps and signs) almost outside but this not particularly helpful for reaching either Tokyo or Shinjuku stations which are the two stopping off points for the Narita Express train from Airport. This is because the Ginza line connects directly with neither and you need to make one change in order to get to the terminal points. There can be a lot of stairs too in Tokyo metro, so a problem if you are carrying luggage. We found a taxi back to Tokyo Station cost YEN 1520 (only twice what the 4 metro/local train tickets would have been. A good option, for two or more travelling together.The hotel is a skyscraper of 37 floors with a bar on 36th floor and outstanding views. Worth YEN 900 for a glass of white wine (though watch the extra cover charge after 19.00). The reception in the hotel is not at street level but on the next floor up. Wide open area.We stayed 3 nights from Sunday 5 to Wednesday 8 October 2008.Because of our Ambassador Priority Club card we got quick check in at the discrete desk at left side of main reception and a room on the 21st floor served by the express lift. The fixed advance purchase tariff did not qualify to use the Business Lounge on 34th floor but a chance encounter and discussion with the General Manager resulted in him offering access. Worth having for the free drinks and breakfast there.Room 2133 was a fair size and equipped with comfortable beds. A bowl of fruit awaited us. The wardrobe door was broken but quickly repaired while we went out for dinner. But the room was nowhere near as good as we had got in the Group's Crowne Plaza hotel in Hiroshima. As in 3 of the 4 hotels we used in Japan, there was iron and ironing board. The TV irritatingly had Japanese dubbing of English channels like BBC and CNN. The bathroom had the now familiar electric toilet but without the automatic flush after each use which had caused so much noise after nocturnal calls of nature.. The shower was in the bath. There were supplies as in every one of the 4 hotels of toothpaste/brush, disposable razors, washcloth etc. The soap was liquid in a container so bring a bar if you prefer that.We had breakfast in the spacious 2nd floor entrance area. Lots of business people - almost entirely male, having business discussions. Reasonable fare though as in every Japanese hotel, short on fish and fresh fruit. A bit more bread and cheese but not much. To see what the Intercontinental is capable of offering for breakfast, try its hotel in Warsaw! Here it cost YEN 3500 each. One morning we went across the linking walkway to Ark Mori building and had two excellent breakfasts in Andersens for YEN 2650. We would have done that on day 3 if we had not been given access to Club Lounge. If you are on holiday, want breakfast without a networking meeting, give it a try.The business centre at the side of reception had several PCs. These were good but Internet access was YEN 525 for 15 minutes. About 500 metres down the road past the subway station is a branch of FedEx Kinkos with access at half that price.The hotel pool, which we did not see, as it had closed for the winter two weeks earlier, is outside on the 4t h floor. It was very disappointing. I for one am prepared to swim in unheated pools. Outside temperatures were 20 C + during our stay.The concierge was exceptionally knowledgeable and helpful, and spoke good English. We found this was rare in Japan and you do need to be sure that "Yes" in answer to your question is more than "yes, I have heard your question but not understood it" as there can be misunderstandings.We did not eat dinner in the hotel as prices are steep. Go next door to Ark Mori building, unless someone else is paying and unless your Japanese client will be impressed by the luxury surroundings. Holidaymakers like us found better value outside.Most guests were westerners and apparently on a business trip or at a conference. You don't get a feel of being in Japan.If you need an ATM accepting Western plastic cards (most do NOT), go to post office ATM on third floor Ark Mori building. It is inside so wait until PO opens at 09.00.We paid an average of YEN 25000 (EUR 175) per night inc tax and service but excluding breakfast. I would stay again if in the area.
disappointing - lacks the Japanese quality of service.

Recently spent 3 nights at ANA Intercontinental Tokyo and give it high marks. From the moment you step from the taxi you are greeted with bowing and huge smiles. A staff member took my luggage and escorted me thorugh the grand lobby area to registration. Upon completion of registation, the same staff accompanied me to my room. The room was exceptional in amenities and cleanliness. Air conditioning worked beautifully.The location is less than a block to a Metro station and a 7-11 store. Also nearby is the American Embassy.As expected, hotel food was pricey.

Really enjoyed my stay here (business trip). The lobby is grandiose and stunning, with some very large falling water features next to the escalator, separating the lounge area from the reception. My room was clean, modern, and comfortable. I had two really nice meals in the hotel's sushi bar. The atmosphere is perfect, it's small and intimate, and perhaps needless to say the food is terrific. If there's anything to compain about, it would be the shear size and volume of the place... impossible not to feel like just one of the flock here. But some people like it like that.Will definitely stay here again when in Tokyo.

The ANA Intercontinental Hotel in Tokyo offers a good but somehow average stay. It definitely had one of the best services we have ever experienced. The "Concierges" are always available and helpful; although you may have some difficulties to communicate in English, they always solve your problem or answer your question. The lobby is very fancy and "cool" with its waterfalls, lights, plants and bars. The rooms are clean and pleasant, with views over the city, improving according to how high floor you stay at. But they remain very "business" and quite standard. If the hotel gives a feeling of luxury, it might not be as exquisite and special as you would expect it to be. Of course the panoramic views over the city from the Manhattan Lounge (36th floor) are definitely worth it, (and they have good Japanese steak meat). On the other hand, the inroom food you might order at night (you feel pretty jetlagged :)) is nothing special for the price. You unfortunatly have to pay extra to access facilities such as the pool and the gym, (1000Y to 1500Y per person and per session), which really feels like useless expenses, especially since the pool is pretty average (more of a public pool than a 5* hotel's). The location is ok (10 minutes walk from Roppongi and near a couple of subway stations), but if I should return to Tokyo I'd probably pick something like Shinjuku, Ginza or Shibuya, which are much more lively. The service is really the one thing that made us enjoy our stay at this hotel.

We (Mom, Dad and teenage daughter) arrived at the ANA on the Friendly Bus from Narita, tired from our overly long plane ride. As we left the bus, various ANA staffers took our bags, ushered us to reservations and helped us to our rooms. No tipping necessary. The ANA staff offers service the likes of which most 5 star American Hotels can only aspire to. The staff tries to anticipate your needs and respond accordingly. We also stayed at the ANA in Kyoto. Another great experience. You will not be disappointed by the rooms, service or staff. Price was a value compared to most costs in Japan.

As a family of four with two teenagers, we booked two superior rooms at an excellent rate of just ¥24000 per room, per night. Now that may seem quite expensive, but that is less than the average price for a hotel in the same class, eg. the Hilton was ¥28000, Ritz was over ¥50000, Four Seasons ¥40000, Mercure ¥24000 etc. We stayed for a grand total of four nights.We arrived from Osaka in the afternoon and took a taxi from Tokyo Station to the hotel. The ride cost just ¥1600, which is great value for Tokyo. It was a pretty short distance as well. Taxis are quite cheap in Japan, because you don't pay for sitting in traffic. The hotel staff immediately took us to check-in and we went through a very thorough check-in procedure. The hotel wanted to know every guest in every room. A bit much, but it was just so they could make room keys if we lost our one. We were given interconnecting rooms. We asked if there was a view and she said that the interconnecting rooms were very limited. We are Priority Club Platinum Elite, and the only real benefit was a complimentary drink for ONE person. We were also given a quite high level. We had booked to be between the bottom floor to the 20th, and we got the 17th floor. We were whisked up to our room by the bell desk people. The rooms were very big for Tokyo, and had been recently renovated. We did have a nice view looking out over the Roppongi Area. The bathroom was particularly nice, and they had a box of complimentary amenities eg. razor, combs, brushes, toothbrushes etc. The beds were very plush and comfortable. There was a complimentary in-room safe, and the TV had quite a few English-language channels (CNN, BBC, NatGeo etc.) They also had French, German, Italian, Chinese and Korean language if you are interested. Some guests have said that you can hear the traffic on the busy highway running outside the hotel. Perhaps you can hear it on the very low floors, but the windows are sound-proofed, double glazed and covered with a transparent film to stop it. On top of that, you can always pull back the curtains. We didn't have any trouble whatsoever with the traffic. The hotel provided a complimentary English-language morning newspaper (Wall Street Journal, International Herald Tribune etc.) and filtered ice cubes are available. If you need anything in your room, contact Instant Service. They answer the second you press the button and in whatever language you speak, and they are able to provide anything that you might want in your room.The hotel has a business centre equipped with many brand new Sony Computers. The cost is reasonable, ¥525 for 15minutes. However, i think in a business-style hotel like the IC they should at least give you a few minutes free to check email, 10 minutes should be sufficient.Now onto attractions in and around Tokyo. The Roppongi Hills area around the hotel is very nice. There are lots of restaurants, shops, convenience stores etc. The area is popular with foreign tourists and is well policed. The area is quite busy 24/7 and you feel safe. The Akasaka area on the other side of the hotel is also good. In the Roppongi Hills area is the Mori Tower. It is taller than the Tokyo Tower and has a good viewing deck. I think the Mori viewing deck is better because you can see further, and you can also get a good view of Tokyo Tower from the top. Take my advice and go to the Mori Tower if you want a nice view of Tokyo.Around Tokyo are many small wards, such as Shibuya, Ikebukoro, Shinjuku, Asakusa, Ginza etc. We took two days of our trip to go around the city. I recommend visiting the Tsukiji Fish Market in the morning for some fun!Outside of the city you should try and visit Mt. Fuji, Hakone and Nikko. Only go to the Mt. Fuji and Hakone area if the day looks nice. You can go to Yokohama, but I didn't think that it looked very appealing for tourists, more of a business city.The concierge at the hotel is very helpful, and can assist with getting around the city. The best staff member experience we had was with the Director of Guest Services. He was French and was very helpful in assisting us, as he was extremely fluent in English while the other staff were just OK. He came and asked us how our day was going, and was able to give us an excellent restaurant recommendation.There are many dining options I can recommend. The hotel has like 5 restaurants, 3 bars and a bakery. The Cascade Cafe has a dinner buffet for a regular price of ¥7000. However, they were having a July special and we got ¥1000 off. They had a lot of choice, and there were chefs preparing food right in front of you. The only downside at the restaurant was that the staff were slow in taking you used plates away.The Delica Shop in the hotel is a small bakery, and they sell heaps of freshly baked bread and patiserie items at reasonable prices, less than ¥400 for everything except cakes.If you go on the Japanese version of the hotels website they have a discount coupon available. I can't read Japanese, but I translated it and found the coupon. Look in the restaurant section. Note that this is not the IHG website, this is the hotel's private website. You can get 10% off all the restaurants and 5% off at the Delica Shop.I highly recommend going to Precce in the Tokyo Midtown complex. It is a high-end supermarket and you can pick up rice, noodles, tempura, beef, chicken etc. They also sell wines, cheese, sashimi etc. They also have a preparation area so you can warm up your food and they provide cutlery. Prices are reasonable. All of us ate for less than about ¥6000 with drinks, dessert and meal.The Guest Services director recommended Umaya to us for Japanese food. All the concierge people recommend this restaurant because of its high quality food. We went for lunch and had an excellent set menu for ¥1500 each.The hotel is close to the Roppongi-Itchome, Roppongi and Tameike Sanno stations. From Tameike Sanno you can walk underground to another station, so it is basically two stations in one. Ask at the hotel for a metro map and figure out which station best suits you, or ask the concierge for the subway directions to your destination. The JR Lines only run in the Shibuya-Shinjuku-Ikebukoro area and the Tokyo Station area.We didn't use it, but the hotel can arrange a limousine, taxi or bus transfer to Narita or Haneda airport at a fee.If you are going to be using taxis, or asking for directions to the hotel, say that you want to go to the Zennikku. That is how the Japanese say ANA. In addition, you could ask for concierge to write down the name and address in Japanese.I hope this review helps you choose a hotel in Tokyo. I highly recommend this hotel because it is good value and has excellent service. We loved the place except for the slow table service at the Cascade Cafe. Please have a look at my photos for a real look at the hotel.

We stayed here for one night as part of our honeymoon adventure.This was an experience we will remember with much happiness, upon check-in where we were met with a smile you really felt you were in a 5 star hotel, we started off booked into a standard room, as we arrived early we were directed to the lounge for a complimentary coffee while our room was prepared and asked to come back for the key in 10 minutes, fine. When we returned we discovered to our delight we had been upgraded to an executive room, yay honeymoon! The room was fantastic! Clean, modern with an amazing view and really held to that 5 star promise. During our stay we had help from the concierge who politely smiled through our fumbled attempt at the language and provided us with maps, fantastic direction and a shuttle bus out to the airport.We booked in for the buffet breakfast the next morning and were extremely happy, everything that a buffet breakfast should be.Our checkout went extremely smoothly, the whole stay which was our last night for Japan which we loved couldn't have left a happier memory.

It had been years since I stayed at the "Zen-Niku" as it's known locally and I didn't have high expectations. I selected the hotel for its location and competitive room pricing. Since my previous visit the hotel has affiliated with Intercontinental and renovated the rooms. But there was more to appreciate than the new badge and the room reformations. Staff quality has definitely improved -- you'll find foreign faces at the front desk and on the floor. In years past, even some of the best Tokyo hotels had trouble with staff communicating with non-Japanese speakers. Even though I speak Japanese, I found it effortless to communicate with most staff in either English or Japanese. The room was clean, modern, efficient and functional. My only complaint here, a common traveler's lament, was the daily charge for internet in the room. I sampled two restaurants: the sushi bar (no complaints here) and the lobby lounge, where I had the breakfast buffet. The charge for the buffet, I thought, at about 40 dollars, was way too high. There are cheaper eating options in the attached Ark Mori complex. There is no doubt that the entry in the past couple of years of foreign super-luxury hotels into the Tokyo market has forced the traditional second-tier properties to upgrade as well. Being walking distance to Akasaka and Roppongi the ANA is an attractive choice for business and leisure travelers.

Well I don't normally title a review like that. It sounds like a review written by someone who has nothing to compare it to. But I usually do well over 100,000 miles travel a year (this year could be twice that), so I stay a lot of places (check out my other reviews), and this hotel really was just terrific.The service is impeccable from beginning to end. Just go visit the bar (which by the way is on the 3F) and watch in awe as your drink is placed precisely in front of you and served immaculately. Or go to the panorama bar (actual name is the Manhattan Room) on 36F and sip a Mojito whilst looking out over the city lights. That has to rank as one of the most romantic locations I've ever been. Pity I was on a business trip!The rooms are again precisely set out with Japanese attention to detail. Every conceivable amenity is there for you (iron, kettle, bar, snacks, very comprehensive bathroom bits and bobs). The style is sort of Frank Lloyd Wright with lots of darker wood. The bed compares closely to the Marriott Heavenly Bed. Actually a bit soft for my preference but luxurious.If you are leaving from here to go Narita the Limousine Bus goes from here. You can buy your ticket from the hotel and put it on your bill. I checked out and gave them my bags, then went off to a meeting for the morning. On returning in time for the 12.30 bus, without any further query on my part my bags were brought right to the point where the bus leaves, and were loaded for me. That was very cool.I only had one meal here, a lunch in the bar. It was terrific and presented with great style (great "plating" as they say). There are a great variety of on-site restaurants but I did not use them.I suppose there is not too much more to say. If you are looking for a refuge from a busy world and just want everything to be taken care of, I highly recommend that you stay here.

I stayed at this hotel for the 2nd time in 3 weeks and loved it once again. As a Priority Club Ambassador member I was upgraded from a standard club level room to a club level junior suite. The hotel is good for it's location and offers convenient transportation to and from Narita for only 3000 yen.The showers in the club level rooms are very good and offer multiple shower heads and nozzles for a full body cleanse.I'm already looking forward to my next visit.

Had a great start of our trip in the Ana Tokyo. 7/11 shop nearby forshoping and ATM. Nice ground floor bakery. Metro in walking distance. Easy to travel from Narita, pick-up service for trips and sending luggage to your next hotel.

I often travel to Tokyo for work and usually stay at either the Hotel Okura or the ANA InterContinental Hotel.The best thing about the ANA is the location. It's steps from the Tameike Sanno station on the Ginza and Nanboku lines. Plus, it's only a 10-20 minute walk to Roppongi and Akasaka.The rooms are average for hotels in this price range. Everything is in good order, but there is not much to wow you. The size is okay for central Tokyo. The furnishings are nice, though a little old (particularly the carpeting). The beds are comfortable but nothing like the fancy mattresses in most upscale hotels in the US these days.The bathroom feel especially outdated. The bathtub and the tiles are right out of the 1970s or 1980s. The shower curtains are quite utilitarian. The towels provided are merely average. I think you should get more from this level of hotel.The gym on the 6th floor is not bad. The equipment is relatively new and well maintained. If you are staying on a corporate or government plan, you can use the gym for free.Internet access in the rooms is provided by Ethernet jacks (not WiFi). Cat-5 LAN cables are in the desk drawer to connect your computer. As with the gym, if you are staying on a corporate or government plan, Internet access is free.Noise can be an issue if you are staying on the side facing the the elevated expressway. Cars and motorcycles zoom by at all hours of the night. I recommend asking for a room on the Tokyo Tower side of the hotel if you wish for peace and quiet.The level of service from the staff is good. They are both polite and helpful. No complaints on this front.Overall, the ANA InterContinental is a solid choice for business travelers. You won't be lacking anything.

WOW, the first visit to Tokyo really was exciting. To top it off, I stayed in this amazing hotel. High rise, awesome view, great service, easily accessible too. Rooms are big bathrooms too. Great hotel amenities. Very central to Rippongi and akasaka. Even though it is more business district area, the subway close by can whisk you to all ends of Tokyo. Conceierge was extremely helpful. Also there is a direct limousine bus ride to and from Narita airport. Great service. I would definately consider staying here again when I come back.

The hotel is in a good location one block from the American Embassy. The rooms are well done, with safes, refrigerators and marble baths. The staff is incredible. Bedding was spectacular. The location of the hotel is good with three major subway lines very nearby. There are not very many restaurants near the hotel, and the eateries in the hotel are quite costly. Tokyo is a spotlessly clean city and very easy to get around via the metro system. Walking, however, is another matter as few streets have street signs. Although I have a very good sense of bearing and direction, I never was able to discern north, south, east or west....odd! I would highly recommend a stay at this hotel. I paid $238/night which is considerably less than the room rate at the Marriott or Hilton, and I consider an Intercontinental a step above those two chains.

Very good hotel.LOCATION: Convenient. Close to lively districts. 4 Metro lines within walking distance.STYLE: Grand. Business style hotel. Attention to details in decoration.ROOMS: Good. Stayed in a superior (25th floor). Nice view of skyline. Rooms are just reasonably sized. Bathroom small. Good finishes. Good equipment (from VOD to hairdryer). Excellent bed. Spotless Clean.GYM: Average. Not spacious but very clean. 3 treadmills. Weights and weight multi-machine. If not staying in superior or up, small entry fee is chargedBUSINESS CENTRE: Good. But Internet is expensive (>15 usd per hour).POTENTIAL DOWNSIDES: 1) Noise 24h coming from highway below if room overlooks it (even on high floors).2) a bit impersonal being mainly a business hotel
Excellant location - Roppongi 10 mins walk in one direction, Akasaka 10 mins in the other. Very close to the tube station. Staff all very helpful.

My new husband and i stayed here from the 4th April for 10 nights on our honeymoon. The hotel is absolutley stunning, the lobby is beautiful. We were originally meant to be staying on the 19th floor, but when they found out we were on our honeymoon they bumped us up to the 24th floor, which i think was an upgraded room. The room was lovely and larger than i had expected from some of the reviews on here, the bathroom was quite small but wasnt a problem in the slightest. The view from our window was amazing, we could see the Tokyo tower (see my photos), i spent ages just sat in the window doing my ''Lost In Translation'' thing, just looking out over the city. The room was so clean, the in-room amenities were really good, really nice shampoo, conditioner, body lotion, plus you get toothbrushes, tooth paste, razor, brush, comb, plus the usual shower caps, sewing kits, stocked mini-bar, tea & coffee facilities etc... we also had an iron and ironing board, hair dryer, fridge, safe, slippers, Japanese style robes and dressing gowns. Nice flat screen TV, 2 english channels (i think they were CNN and BBC world news) we loved watching the wacky japanese night-time tv shows. The closest metro station was Tomeike-Sanno, which was literally a 2 minute walk away, and right on the Ginza line. The metro was so easy to use, we bought open day tickets every day which cost about 700Yen each (you can pay extra for tickets that include use of the Toei line, but we never needed to use this, you can get every where just with the metro lines). To get to and from Narita airport we used the Limousine Bus, which was really good, friendly staff and really clean and comfortable coaches, took about an hour and a half to get to the hotel, it cost 6000Yen each, for one way. The hotel is in a good location, not noisy at all. A few convenience stores close by (we mainly used the 7/11 next to the metro station to buy snacks and drinks) Most nights we walked down to Roppongi from the hotel, which was only about a 15-20 minute walk, which is great for shopping, restaurants, bars and nightclubs. We didn't eat in the hotel restaurants as they did seem quite expensive, even a cup of coffee was over 1000Yen, (but totally worth it, te best Cappuccino i've ever had!) because we were staying for quite a while the hotel gave us ten tickets for complimentary coffees for use in either the Atruim Lounge or the Cascade Cafe. The hotel staff were so friendly and helpful, but then every Japanese person we met were exactly the same, so courteous, friendly and polite. The hotel staff spoke really good english, but not everywhere else did, luckily my husband speaks Japanese so we got on perfectly fine, so before you go i would definately recommend you learn at least the basics or you will struggle when out and about, and in shops and restaurants. I would definatley recommend going to the Asakusa Kannon Temple, Tokyo Tower, Harajuku, the Meiji Shrine, the Imperial Palace and Akihabara. We went on a day trip with the JTB Sunrise tours to Mount Fuji and Hakone (which could be booked at the hotel, but we booked beforehand with Expedia), sadly for us the day we had picked for our trip we had terrential rain and Mt. Fuji was so entirely shrouded in mist and cloud that we didnt actaully see it! We were totally gutted as the day after the weather was beautiful. Overall we really had the best holiday ever and cant wait to go back and will definatly go back to the ANA Intercontinental again. We booked our trip wit Expedia, and it cost just over £2000 for the two of us including our return flights with BA. (we flew from Heathrow Terminal 5 which was absolutely fine, despite all of their current problems).  -- Check out my photos ---

I travel to Tokyo about 4 times per year and always stay here. Its a superb location and the rooms are modern and well maintained. All staff are 1st rate and very attentive . Food and drink tho is expensive so be carefull what you order ... All in all 9/10

Over the past 3 years I've travelled to Tokyo frequently (approx 5 times a year). The company I work for have corporate rates with ANA InterContinental Tokyo so I always stay there.I love staying at ANA because the rooms are very clean and spacious, very high tech and the service is always good. Oh, and they have an excellent room service menu! I usually stay on one of the corporate floors so not really sure what the rooms on the lower floors are like.I used to stay at this hotel back in 2000-2001. Back then the hotel was very bling/decked out in gold and the rooms looked like they were from the 70s. They've since renovated the hotel and whilst the lobby is still a little too bling for my taste, the rooms are very nicely decorated in chic, neutral tones.The location of this hotel is excellent - walking distance to Ropponggi (for restaurants and bars) and there is a subway station right near it, so you can easily go to other areas of Tokyo.The service is excellent and the staff go out of their way to be of assistance. Once they even went to the convenience store to purchase deodorant for me, coz I forgot mine at home and was running late for work.
user_name:
corky_c
New York City, New York

review_body: While at Tokyo on business, I stayed at Hotel Ana. Service is quite excellent. Even if there were plenty of guests awaiting check-in, there are many front desk staff to accommodate us, and rooms are large and overly clean. But the breakfast buffet on their ground floor restaurant is the best breakfast I have ever tasted in a hotel, and I have been to far more bigger and more expensive hotels. The location is very near the train station, and I spent a free afternoon at the Tokyo museum at the city's lovely Oueno Park.

I had to go to Tokyo for a Thursday meeting. They now run service from Hongqiao to Haneda, versus Pudong to Narita, thereby saving 1.5 hours at least of trip time in each direction. We left Wednesday night and came back Sunday mid-day.We stayed at the ANA as 1) corporate rate was $231 USD per night, 2) my office HQ is in the Akasaka Mori ARK next door and 3) this hotel has a great location and easy access to the Tokyo Metro.It took about 25 minutes and 6000¥ to get to the hotel from Haneda. We were drinking at the champagne bar by 6pm where pricing is on par with the location and the city itself. Afterwards, a short walk to Fukzushi for sushi. The rooms, service, etc. are what you expect, impeccable, clean and quiet. Breakfast in the morning was the usual mix of Western and Japanese offerings and quite good and was included in my corporate rate. We also used the bar at the top of the building which has a great view to the West of Asakasa. Pricing is expensive.This hotel, and you can get rates close to my corporate rate, is an outstanding value for Tokyo and Asakasa. It's well located, easy access to the metro and quiet.

Service is great, and very typical of fine Japanese hospitality. The staff were effiecient, always friendly and professional. The location was convenient, located walking distance to Tamieke-Sanno subway station with direct access to the Ginza and Chiyoda lines (and to some extent the Namboku line), getting around was easy. Access to Shinjuku on the Maranouchi line is also very convenient. The station did not get overcrowded at peak times so it was easy to travelThe hotel has good food, and a bakery selling scrumptious looking pastries and cakes. Rooms were comfortable and roomy, very clean. The rooms come with information on Tokyo in general and the Akasaka area, these come in handy. I would definately stay here again if in Tokyo

My most recent stay at this hotel found it spotless, as usual. All staff are professional, efficient, competent and impeccable. The lobby is airy and relaxing with water effects, plants, etc. There is a small shopping arcade which includes clothing & accessory boutiques, convenience store, flowers, bakery, etc. There are several somewhat pricey restaurants in the hotel. The common areas of the hotel are immaculate.The room had nice lighting, a flat panel TV, small frig, hot water pot, desk, small sofa (some of the ANA room sofas are so small as to preclude sitting), an overly firm mattress, great comforter/duvet and the most wonderful soft fluffy pillows. Two types of robes are provided - traditional western and yukata. The plumbing was excellent. A fabulous shower/tub with superb water flow (wish my home bath was like this!). The mirror was fog free, the toilet the usual many functioned Japanese toilet. There were complimentary toothbrushes, toothpaste, sewing kit, cotton tips, etc.There was complimentary instant coffee, "plum tea" (more of a salt broth type flavor), and green tea (bag type) - however, all were of low quality. The hotel location is good for riding the Metro - located between two subway stations. A variety of dining nearby. There is a great little grocery store (Pororoca) less than 2 blocks away that has fresh produce, and a variety of drinks, snacks, chocolates, etc. at reasonable prices. I have stayed at the ANA Tokyo many times, the most recent being after the Intercontinental acquisition of ANA hotels. Prior to the takeover, I stayed on the club floor. This last stay was on a non-club floor. So I'm not sure if some of the changes are due to the new owners or just the difference between the club floor and regular floors. I say all that to say this: the standard room of this most recent stay (after IC takeover) had bulk toiletries in the shower - large dispensers of shampoo, conditioner and soap, all Shiseido brand and smelled nice. There was a bulk soap dispenser at the sink. Conspicuously absent was LOTION. My stays on the club floor prior to the takeover, I seem to remember all kinds of charming little toiletries, including lotions, all individual sized. With the current airport restrictions on liquids/gels, I have come to depend more on hotel toiletries. I never used them before, but now I find I carry only the most unique (to me) items that will fit in the quart size bag - and rely on the hotel to supply the (more common) rest. So the absence of lotion was annoying. Sooo - whether the absence of toiletries was due to non-club floor or the new IC way of doing things, I'm not sure.The only negatives that were experienced with this stay were minor: the pens in the room were cheesy and wouldn't write - they replaced them and the next batch was fine; the hairdryer on the "cool" and "set" settings was useless unless you have three days to dry your hair - the high setting worked OK; the weight scale didn't work, probably due to dead battery. The used glasses and tea cups were not sanitized - apparently just rinsed off in the sink at best - which often doesn't actually get them clean. For me personally, this is intolerable. Makes me wonder if they are sanitized or just rinsed after the last guest!!! And I do not care to re-use MY OWN glass without sanitizing it between uses. Overall, this hotel is an excellent value. A similar level of atmosphere/service in the USA would cost three times what I paid here. And I have stayed here enough times to find them to be consistently superior. Whether the new IC ownership will change this remains to be seen.

We had a great stay at this hotel in early November.Staff very helpful and polite at check in. The reception area was ultra spacious and airy.Arrived at the hotel at about 11.45am but couldn't check in until 3pm. My husband said that the staff didn't speak that good English so he wasn't sure if that was because we were being upgraded. We were really tired and this was a bit irritating but we did get a fantastic room with a great view towards Roppongi Hills and Tokyo midtown.There are eating places behind the hotel and a Starbucks coffee place which were handy while we waited to check in. There is also a bakery shop in the hotel and I recommend the cinnamon swirls with cream on top!The metro stations we used were Roppongi 1 itchome which was only a few minutes away and Tameike Sanno station literally steps away at the front of the hotel. Although this station is close the Ginza line was a bit of a walk underground.The bar at the top of the hotel was great for cocktails with a fantastic view of the Mori Tower at Roppongi Hills. I also enjoyed the Da Vinci bar on the third floor which had low lighting and a pianist which was relaxing.We had a meal at the restaurant on the same floor as reception. Food was excellent but very small portions. They did a buffet which looked good but this stopped at 9.30pm.We found out by accident that you needed to book the Limousine bus back to Narita which thankfully we did. It took about an hour and a half to get to the airport.I would recommend this hotel for it's location ameneties and great rooms.
user_name:
IOMtravels
Isle of Man, United Kingdom

review_body: Usual Intercontinental standards and prices! We upgraded to an Executive room, (only because I wanted to be on a high floor 33+) but we got a lot more than we bargained for, free buffet breakfast - including small selection of hot items, free pre dinner drinks and canapes (including champagne), so we managed to get our monies worth!! Rooms well decorated and recently rennovated (although bathroom was a bit small). Again as with all my recommendations for Japan, do not eat in the hotel (the quality is good but very over priced). You really need to research the area well and ensure the restaurants in your guide book still exist, you'll need full addresses (as during our 6 night stay not one taxi driver knew were he was going!).

I found the ANA InterContinental to be pretty much just what I expected. Large and rather impersonal with good quality rooms and all the amaneties you would expect from an InterContinental hotel.Room size is rhather on the small side but everything in general was in very good condition. Maybe with the exception of the tiny bathroom that would have needed some refurbishment.What makes it an above average hotel in my opinion is a) the perfect location close to many things andb) the superior service offered by it's staff.All in all a place I would return to.

Nice but nothing special, big, lots of marble and anomymous.Staff are frantic all the time and it gives the impression of being disorganised which to their credit it is not. The business centre was very expensive and not as helpful as they could be. I asked for something to be translated and they just looked at it and said 'too difficult' eventhough they do advertise a translation service.The beds are fantastic though. Minibar could do with doubling the content!!!

I stayed in the ANA Intercontinental at the end of September for five nights and thought it was great. The room was large, particularly by Tokyo standards; though I have the feeling I may have been upgraded to a superior room. The bed was very comfortable. Decor was black marble, which is what Intercontinental seem to be going for in a lot of their hotels and seems to work in modern city locations. The serivce is very good and anticipates your needs. The restaurants are pretty expensive, but are very good.Access to the underground network is very easy, though the station next door is huge and you can end up doing a lot of walking to get the line you want. It's pretty easy to navigate and is the best way to get around Tokyo. Taxis aren't that expensive either. There is a frequent bus service that takes you from the hotel to Narita airport.The only complaint is that they do seem to have decorated the hotel and forgotten about the bathrooms, they were small and basic.In summary, for it's location and standard of decor and service, the ANA Intercontinental is good value for money for Tokyo and I would stay there again.

I arrived at this stereotypical hotel with it’s Western feel, but impeccable Japanese friendliness and quickly located my room, through the vast impersonal lobby.
