The view from the twelfth floor window overlooking Tokyo was impressionable, even better the amazing view from the top floor bar and restaurant.Room had the normal ‘bits and bobs’ you expect from a hotel of this calibre, but the bathroom was miniscule; had to breathe in to close the door. Also the room size wasn’t too great.Centrally located, a 700 yen cab ride to the nightlife of Roppongi and adjacent to Tameike-sanno tube station, which also links by walking underground to Kokkai-gijidomae, in case you are arriving via Tokyo station; as the latter has a direct connection on the Marunouchi line (red). The underground walkways at the former two stations are extremely large, so head for exit 13 to locate the hotel, which is just in front of you as you pop up, if you take 20 paces in the same direction as the escalator you are travelling on.The hotel won’t set you alight, as you will expect by it’s price and star rating a high quality, but it is a safe bet. Finally, don’t miss the Tsukiji fish market for a great 7AM early morning experience.

Arrived at the Intercontinental on the airport bus - reasonably priced, took an hour. The hotel is in the luxurious bracket, lots of marble and shiny surfaces, good reception staff. The room was large enough, with a comfortable bed, an LCD TV and enough space to walk around. The bathroom, as has been said in other reviews, is pretty small, and was was the only downer. Internet access was very fast and fairly cheap.The bar on the top floor was very nice with good views, I didn't try the food.Location wise, only a 20 minute walk to Rappongi (if you really have to go, I wouldn't bother), or 660 yen in a taxi. The metr is bang next door so it is easy to get around the city.The best price I found was on the hotel's own website.Overall, a very nice place to stay.

I very much enjoyed my stay here. I stayed in a double room (I forgot if it was called a standard or a superior). The room was large and very comfortable. The color scheme and decor of the room was modern yet inviting and warm. The bathroom, however, could not be called luxurious - unlike the decadence to be found at the Shinjuku Park Hyatt or the Four Seasons. It was large enough and merely adequate. However, this hotel cost me $350 less per night than the other places (I booked on a Japanese travel site called Jalan).The Manhatten Lounge on the 36th floor, in my opinion, was just as good, if not better than the bar at the NY Grill at the Park Hyatt. The color scheme and decor was stylish yet more inviting. I also chatted quite a bit with the friendly and very skilled bartenders. The view over Roppongi is colorful and lovely.I can't say much about the food because I didn't eat much there aside from breakfast, which was standard for a hotel of this caliber. I would caution, however, that the concierge I encountered was very ill-informed about the limousine bus service going to Haneda airport. There is only one bus per day that stops at this hotel that runs to Haneda. The concierge told me that I have to make a reservation and that they would have to send a fax to get on another bus at another location to go to Haneda. Not so. I took a cab to the Cerulean Hotel in Shibuya (Y1600) and easily hopped the limousine bus to Haneda from there.

Being conveniently located in Ark Hills right near a subway station and an Airport Limousine dropoff was my original reason for staying here, but I've since stayed here two more times. Service and room accommodations are Westernized, but with Japanese style and the highest level of quality applied to every facet of the hotel.I think the original Cascades waterfall was more beautiful back in 2003 as it had marble streams that flowed into the lobby. It's still quite magnificent, though the 'streams' are gone. But with the remodeling came some very futuristic additions - electronic placards display hotel events & restaurant menus, digital world clocks, and an array of artistic images electronically projected on large screen monitors.The main restaurant offers breathtaking views of Tokyo, complimented by a piano bar and other live venues on the occasion. One night the pianist played something quite familiar - the Brady Bunch theme!Strange, but amusing.The only real meals I had during my multiple visits was breakfast, which were all fine continental affairs with the addition of traditional Japanese fare. Business kept me away during dinner time, but I'll try next time.The rooms are smallish, but well appointed with wide screen LCDs, every digital appliance you could need, a wet bar, and a firm mattress with buckwheat pillows.This was also the first time I've ever used a bidet, though it took a few tries to operate it without getting doused, as the instructions were in Japanese. The multi-lingual hotel staff was quite helpful, and the currency exchange was quite fair, unlike my experiences in other cities where you would expect to take a beating for the convenience. I can't really say anything negative about the ANA Hotel. I fell in love with Japan here, and the pleasant memories linger.

BookingWe booked our stay over the Intercontinental website. The process was easy and even though we booked an advance purchase rate, my credit card was only charged upon check-out.LocationThe hotel is pretty well located (Akasaka) with access to the subway within 5 minutes by foot. There are 4 subway lines accessible - the Ginza line is closest (300m) and the others are up to 1km away, all underground. The hotel is not too far from Roppongi - cab fare is Y600 - Y800. It's about Y1,500 from Tokyo station by cab.Check-InCheck-In was a smooth process. We arrived a little early and were accommodated (the hotel didn't seem very full) straight away. Staff were friendly and polite (common theme throughout the country).RoomsThe room was of a decent size. We were able to accommodate 2 full sized suitcases without tripping over them. We were on the 20th floor and had a decent view looking towards Roppongi. Housekeeping was a little slow though, our room would only be made up in the late afternoon which is not optimal when you head back lunch time for a rest.I really struggled with the bed, it wasn't comfortable at all. Furthermore, the standard pillows were way too soft, so I requested hard ones and these were like bricks. I didn't sleep at all well any of the 3 nights we spent at the hotel.The mini-bar was well stacked, but prices were as you'd expect in a 5-star hotel and we didn't partake.MealsMeals inside the hotel were on the expensive side and with so much on offer in a fantastic city like Tokyo, we only ate one breakfast at the hotel. The breakfast buffet itself was brilliant, but a little costly. We certainly attempted to eat enough for value! There are a couple of cheaper places in the adjoining arcade if you're looking to spend a little less, but still enjoy close-by convenience.PoolThe pool looked good (from our hotel window), but we didn't actually use it. We didn't see anyone swimming, although it was quite hot and humid.Concierge / ActivitiesThe friendliness and assistance provided by the concierge was extremely welcome. There was always a knowledgable English speaking person at the desk, who was eager to assist and they provided us with some valuable tips to maximise time efficiency.The business centre was well equipped, although once again, the prices were a bit on the high side. I think Internet access cost approx Y500 for 15 minutes. The lobby was large, airy and elegant.Check-outOnce again a smooth process although it took a while to convince them to give a short check-out extension as we had a time-clash with our Imperial Palace excursion. They were able to store our luggage for the remainder of the day.OverallThere is nothing wrong with the hotel, but my feeling towards it is neutral, considering the price one has to pay. Whilst we got a good deal for a 5-star hotel, I have stayed in other 5-star hotels worldwide where my experiences have been standout and the prices have been comparable or better. I would probably select a different hotel next time I'm in Tokyo.

I am currently staying at this hotel. This is also my first trip to TOKYO and was not sure what to expect. Unlike hotels in major cities where the lobby and ambience is great but lack the service, this hotel truly offers excellent service. My room though nonsmoking smelt of residual smoke. I talked to the reception and they immediately changed the bedding and provided me with a deionizer.Service calls were answered in less than 5 minutes.The hotel is in a good location. I would recommend checking out the local restauarants before eating in the hotel restaurants since they are pricey.

I stayed at the ANA Intercontinental for the first leg of my business trip (Taipei and Beijing followed). The hotel is/feels gigantic but the staff is extremely attentive and the amenities (health club, etc) are very nice. I was on the club floor which had nice rooms and access to the lounge--light breakfast, drinks and a light dinner. The rooms are nice and large--but mine was a little dated. For a high end hotel, i would expect the shower head to be intact and not leaking (streams of water flying everywhere).Since this was my first trip to Tokyo, i have no frame of reference. The rooms seemed larger than I had envisioned and the food was better. The location of the hotel was great--but it didn't feel like a 5-star property--the Grand Hyatt in Taipei and Raffles in Beijing were definitely nicer.

We stayed in the executive floor, which features spotless and very classy rooms. The lounge is wonderful, with Glenlivet and other high end liquor on tap, and tasty snacks. The remodeled rooms featured plasma screens, and electric everything. Overall just beautifully appointed, and not too expensive by Tokyo standards. The staff is wonderful, too.The hotel is maybe a quarter mile from a subway intersection, but the walk is long if the weather isn't cooperating. It's not walking distance to anywhere else, really, although there are some nice restaurants within a couple of blocks.Bottom line: a five-star hotel, a three-star location

Great hotel for business purposes. Staff was highly professional, expedient, and competent. At times it seemed as if there was one staff member per guest in the lobby - all ready to help with a nod of your head. Room quality excellent; bedding was very comfortable. Gym accessible via only a few elevators and relatively small (however rarely busy).Sleek, contemporary design in lobby area - amazing flower arrangements - ikebana - if you're interested in that sort of thing. Superb dining choices, particularly if you don't have time to leave the hotel. Excellent spot for business meetings. Small, limited selection of tourist shopping inside; just enough to satisfy someone there for a short stay. Right around the corner from the US Embassy and within walking distance to Roppongi. (That said, try NOT to make Roppongi your only stop should you be a first-time visitor to the city.)

We stayed at this hotel on 3 occassions over 2 weeks and we were very happy with the accommodations. I’m very surprised someone grumbled it wasn’t up to Intercontinental standards, I’ve stayed in over a dozen Intercontinentals and it certainly is. If you get the right room. We were booked into a standard room (generally floors less than 20) The room wasn’t too bad,but just a little tired looking. The furniture is the same as in the superior rooms, it just appears to have been more used. The rooms are much larger than what we expected for Tokyo. You can get a view of Tokyo Tower if you really want to. The station was a bit of a hike, about 15 minutes, which was a bit of a downside. Also, the bathroom while nice had a shower curtain instead of a glass door, but otherwise the bathroom was top notch. Note that in a standard room, you get the fairly sad Intercontinental own brand of toiletries, but in the superior rooms you get really nice Elemis(a top spa brand) toiletries. This is an easy way to figure out if you are in a standard or superior room. I’m sorry to say but in our second stay, we got put in a standard and we were told it was a superior. If it wasn’t for the fact that we had been in a superior, we would have been none the wiser. So be careful about this. However, we were put into a club room when we complained, which intriguingly was smaller, but it did have a nice view and of course lounge access. Didn’t eat in the restaurants, but I met Iron Chef Hiroyuki Sakai in the lobby so I’m sure the food must have been of a high standard. Meeting him was a big high point for me, and if you are an Iron Chef fan, Chen Kenichi’s restaurant is also nearby. Feel free to email me if you want more Iron Chef information, we went to most of their restaurants. As mentioned by others, the airport bus goes straight there, just under 1 hour if there’s minimal traffic, 1.5hrs if there is. Don’t even think about trying to use the train if you have anything more than hand carry luggage, even if you can find the lifts(we couldn’t) the path to the hotel is still very long. Additionally, everyone in the train and station will hate you. Spend the $30 for the bus.

Huge modern hotel in Akasaka. Scores of restaurants; very large, elegant lobby. Great service, like in all good Tokyo hotels (far and above the level in USA or Europe).The location is good; 100 feet from a metro station on the Ginza line; about 5 stops to Ginza and 5 stops to Omote Sando (Harajuku/Ayoama area).I had a phenomenal view of Tokyo Tower from my window.One thing that many visitors don't know is that a few blocks away is the Akasaka entertainment district (basically one long street chockfull of restaurants, bars, clubs). At night, it's very festive and fun to walk around.

We stayed for 2 nights in April while traveling to Tokyo for leisure; the ANA is a very nice contemporary hotel and what you would expect for a room that cost in the mid-200 dollar range per night. The rooms are large enough - i.e., you won't feel claustrophobic and there is enough room for 2 people to room together comfortably. Free internet access. The bathrooms are nice & clean (I'm very picky about bathrooms). The staff speaks limited English but are very accomodating and polite. Breakfast at the Intercontinental Lounge (for members) was excellent with gorgeous views. Beautiful lobby/atrium. About a 5 minute walk to the Tokyo metro station, with a mall nearby. More impressively, we lost our cell phone (we didn't remember where - train or taxi) and the staff was able to locate it for us within an hour.We also stayed at much more expensive places this trip (Mandarin Oriental Tokyo and Gora Kadan resort in Hakone) and felt the ANA was a better value for the money. Not a super luxurious hotel where one goes to be pampered, but definitely a good balance of price and quality. Keep in mind that there is something like a 15%-17% tax on all hotel rooms.

I found the ANA Intercontinental to be merely acceptable. The room was not particularly clean, the staff were okay but not particularly friendly, the breakfast buffet was decidedly average, and the phone in the room (which was important to me as a business traveller) was circa 1980. Having said that, if you have business in the Ark Mori business or at an embassy, the location is great. I will be trying the Okura next time around as it is similarly located and I have recently heard some good reviews.

We spent one night at the ANA Intercontinental Tokyo and loved it. The staff was very friendly and helpful. I requested hypo-allergenic pillows and the staff brought me several pillows to choose from.My nine year old daughter especially liked the heated toilet with all sorts of gadgets. Also, the mirror in the bathroom is heated so after you shower you can still see in the mirror. Great for men who shave after showering. Our room on the 23rd floor looked out towards the Tokyo Tower ~ an especially nice view at night. Sidenote: be careful of the 600 yen "seating" charge just for being at the lounge on the 36th floor. The hotel is centrally located and close to the subway station. We walked to the Tokyo Tower (about 20 minutes). Close to Rappongi. I would definitely stay here again.

Stayed at the Ana Hotel in Tokyo in March, and found it very comfortable and clean. We paid 19,500 yen a night for a standard twin room on 26th and 22nd floors (we stayed for four nights initially, and three nights a week later). Both our rooms were pleasantly decorated in a neutral, western style with good lighting, comfortable beds with duvets and flat screen TV. In particular, the beds were extremely comfortable! Whilst not huge, the design and inclusion of a small seating area in front of the large window providing great views across the Imperial Palace and Diet Building from one room, and the Tokyo Tower and Roppongi in the other, gave some sense of space. The bathrooms in both rooms were adequate- unlike the room decor and furnishings these don't appear to have been upgraded recently.Our first room, on the Imperial Palace side of the building, suffered from condensation- the picture window would mist up and in the morning was covered in condensation. There was no sign of damp in the room and the problem seemed confined to the window itself, but still it was annoying as it meant missing out on an amazing view. Looking from outside the Hotel, it seemed this was a problem for some other rooms too.Other than a bit of a wait at check-in for our first stay because of a french film festival being hosted at the Ark Hills concert hall, service was efficient and helpful. The conceirge secured us a great table at the Park Hyatt New York Grill for lunch and booked our spaces on the bus back to Narita without fuss. Communal areas are attractive with lots of comfortable seating.Breakfast (buffet) at the hotel was very good indeed, with a wide choice of Western and Japanese options, and more reasonably priced at than the other hotels we stayed in Japan. In the immediate vicinity to the hotel there are some restaurants dotted around the Ark Hills Complex. Aux Baccanales provides acceptable french standards and has a good range of wines by the glass. The Andersens bakery/cafe provides an excellent, filling breakfast for 650-800 yen.We very much liked the location of the hotel- the immediate vicinity is reasonably quiet, being next to the Ark Hills Complex with its gardens and the American Embassy behind- and you can walk to the Imperial Palace, Ginza and Akasaka within 15 minutes each, and there's a subway station just outside the hotel. We would definetely consider staying again.

The ANA Tokyo recently converted over to an Intercontinental property (on April 1, 2007), and it certainly lives up to the standards of a Tokyo luxury hotel and the Intercontinental standard.The staff is excellent and a bit less obvious (in a good way) than at several of the other 4 and 5 star properties in Tokyo. The location is great for getting to Shibuya, Ginza and most other central Tokyo business districts. It is also close to a subway station, which makes it more convenient and affordable to get around the city.The views from the bar and restaurant on the 36th floor are quite impressive, as are the room views that face the Tokyo Tower (see attached pictures). The rooms themselves are a bit on the small side but are well-appointed.If you're heading to Tokyo on business or for a nice vacation, I highly recommend the ANA Intercontinental.

Have traveled to Japan every year sinc 2003 and always stayed at the ANA because of it's great location in Akasaka. It is close to the Tameike-Sanno station of the Ginza line. You can walk to Roppongi and to the many bars and restaurants in the Akasaka area. The premium floor room have flat screen tv and great views of Tokyo. I always ask for a Imperial Palace hotel view.

It'll be interesting to see what Intercontinental Hotels do with this hotel when they take over ANA in the New Year. The service and staff here are excellent with one of the most efficient check-outs I've ever seen and a bell-boy/concierge service that is run like a military operation. The rooms however are a little dissapointing but having come from generous rooms in Singapore, I guess I just had the wrong expectation. Breakfast on the Exec Floor was limited but good and once again the staff most courteous. If I were Interconti - I'd upgrade the rooms, but leave the rest - it works.

The ANA hotel was one of 3 different hotels offered to me by the organizers of a conference I was attending in Tokyo. I had no idea which of the 3 hotels would be best as I had never been to Tokyo before. A Trip advisor forum expert for Tokyo suggested the ANA would be the best selection of the 3 hotels offered to me by my conference and the advice was perfect!ANA hotel was located right next to a subway station that has service on 5 different lines on Tokyo metro line which was perfect as the subway is the best way to get around the city.The hotel is in a neighbourhood that is bustling and very cosmopolitan, the area is filled with various shops and many restaurants (both Western and Japanese) all within walking distance.Rooms were spacious especially for a busy city such as Tokyo, rooms were modern, well designed and very clean. An impressive lobby area will greet you for check in and the rooms do not disappoint after your initial greeting.Hotel amenities are good, service is excellent , hotel has a polite and friendly staff most of whom speak English very well.

I just had a family holiday in Tokyo and we stayed at the ANA Hotel Tokyo for 6 nights. It is located next to the US Embassy in Akasaka in the ARK Hall office complex. The hotel is simply excellent in all regards. The lobyy and the rooms are tastefully decorated. The service is courteous with superb attention to detail. The breakfast is very adequate. The bathroom is tiny and basic but cleanly maintained (and slightly larger than most Tokyo hotels already). They charge hotel guests Y1000 to use the pool and that made my daugther very upset but she was soon pleased when the hotel gave her a ANA children's toy package as a gift (those they give away on ANA planes). The hotel is about 15seconds walk from Exit 13 of the Tameike Sanno subway station,which is around 200m from the station itself. Sadly the station only serves the Ginza line and to go to major shopping places like Shinjuku, Ikebukuro or Ginza, you need to change to the Marunouchi line at Akasaka Mitsuke, which is convenient. Taxi from Tokyo station and Shinjuku costs Y1300 and Y2100 respectively. Roppongi Hills is just up the road but there is no convenient public transport to get there from ANA (except taxis). To walk from Roppongi Hills to ANA Hotel is easier as it is a 15 minute downhill walk.Overall, I strongly recommend ANA Hotel for business visitors to Tokyo. The attention to detail is impressive. I have stayed in 9 other Tokyo hotels and this is amongst the best. However, for family on holidays with a focus on shopping and visiting places like Disneysea etc, the location in a business / office area is not always so convenient, especially if you don't like to walk long distances. There is simply neither shopping nor family orientated restaurants around this hotel.Finally, I also would recommend flying ANA to Tokyo. It is as good as Cathay Pacific, which must be one of the best airlines in Asia.

We stayed here with friends and whilst it was a little expensive, we thought it well worth the price. The hotel itself is lovely, with a very impressive lobby. We stayed on the executive floors (I think these are the floors above 30) and the view is fantastic. It was a lovely way to introduce our friends to Tokyo.Perhaps the best part was the little touches in the room. The T.V in the bathroom, the fax machine, the humidifier with aromatherapy oils, the bathrobes and night gowns etc.. The room was small but wonderfully decorated and thought out. The staff were friendly and couteous. We had breakfast in the executive lounge on the 34th floor which wasn't amazing but sufficient. The lounge itself was rather like the business class lounges you find at airports and the food about the same. We dined in the building next door (very nice Italian restaurant) and then spent an evening in Roppongi (5 minutes in a taxi), visiting local bars and just watching the night life.It was an enjoyable stay and I would go back again.

I work in the office tower right next to this hotel, and whenever I'm busy and the hotel happens to offer great rates, I tend to stay here. The rooms are larger than most Tokyo hotels. Some of the restaurants are really good. Aburi offers very nice lunch menus (good value for money, too) and Karin, their Chinese restaurant is pretty good. The rooms are decorated in a quiet, modern way. Staffs are courteous and helpful. Nothing luxurisou, but there is everything you need in the room, and a lot more you can request from the housekeeping. Now the hotel is close to two subway lines, and it made ths place even more convenient than before.Since the hotel is in the same complex as the famed Suntory Hall, you often see orchestral musicians coming back from concerts. Sharing elevators with them is fun as well!I recommend this hotel to business travelers and tourists alike.

I stayed only one night at the ANA Tokyo. I was impressed with the hotel. I stayed in one of the premier rooms which offers a great view from the upper floors, free internet access and use of the fitness room (1500 Y otherwise). The hotel room was spotless, the room very nicely decorated in a clean contemporary style and the bed and linens were very comfortable.The Happy Limousine Bus serves the hotel and takes about an hour to get to the airport. The hotel is located by Tameike-Sanno (Ginza line) metro station which connects with Kokkaigijido-Mae (Chiyoda line)station (take exit number 13 to arrive about 20 yrds in front of the main hotel entrance.The Chiyoda line is a great way to get to Harajuku, Omotesando or the green Yemonote line.I booked my room through AmEx travel online and it cost $207 for the room. THis is a great bargain in my mind for a hotel of this quality in the middle of Tokyo.
It was located in a convinient to attractions and was excellent refurbished in 2004. I will be here in this April again.
